title: 3 ARE ACCUSED OF BRIBE OFFER ON S.I. PROJECT
description: A site manager at the New York Exposition and Convention Center and two electrical contractors who work elsewhere were indicted yesterday on charges of offering a $100,000 bribe to be named developers of a $32 million shopping and office center on Staten Island.

title: AVANTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Westphal Gets The Last Laugh
description: T he names have whirred about him for many years. Jo Jo White, Don Chaney and John Havlicek of the Boston Celtics have become Trent Tucker, Edmond Sherod and Rory Sparrow of the New York Knicks. But to Paul Westphal, who began his career as a Celtic in 1972 and now, at 32, is the oldest Knick, the key to success in pro basketball is still the same.

title: Bank Rescue: F.D.I.C. Role
description: The agreement for five California banks to take over operations of the failed American City Bank was reached after the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation agreed to assume roughly 70 percent of the book value of the institution's assets. The bank's seven branches opened for business as usual this morning after a Los Angeles County judge approved the agreement late Sunday.

title: TWIN CITY BARGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Natural Answer for Natural Gas
description: Some Democratic responses to President Reagan's proposal to deregulate natural gas have been quick, bitter and misguided. One liberal opponent labels it a joke; another calls it absurd. In truth, the proposal is an inventive, even elegant solution to an increasingly aggravating problem: how to protect both consumers and producers during the present transition to an efficient competitive market for natural gas.

title: GULF INTERSTATE CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
STATEN ISLAND WINS CITY U. TOURNAMENT
description: Staten Island won the City University of New York basketball tournament for the third straight year by beating John Jay College, 74-56, at City College's Nat Holman Gymnasium last night.

title: AYDIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LIBYAN DELEGATION IN CHAD FOR TALKS
description: President Hissen Habre said today that a Libyan delegation had arrived here, apparently to seek discussions leading toward a peaceful solution of Libya's dispute with Chad.

description: B-Net loss...C-Net income

title: COGHLAN FELT NEAR OUTDOOR RECORD
description: It seemed like a fairy tale, Eamonn Coghlan said yesterday, in recounting the events that led to his dramatic world-indoor best of 3 minutes 49.78 seconds for the mile run on Sunday.

title: DAYCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
GERBER SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to jan 31
description: Results include operations of Gerber Scientific's 80 percent owned subsidiary, Gerber Systems Technology Inc but do not reflect the acquisition of Camsco Inc in Jan 1983

title: Arrows Name Machnik
description: Joe Machnik, the director of operations and head of referees for the Major Indoor Soccer league, was named coach of the New York Arrows yesterday. Machnik replaces Don Popovic, who was dismissed last week.

title: JAMES L. CAMP JR.
description: James L. Camp Jr., a former lumber and paper company executive, died Sunday at his home in Franklin, Va., at the age of 87. He was formerly chairman and president of the Camp Manufacturing Company, a lumber company, and chairman of the executive committee of the Union Bag-Camp Paper Corporation, predecessors of the Union Camp Corporation.

title: It Pays to Bowl
description: The Women's International Bowling Congress tournament is an event with perhaps the richest treasure in all ''amateur'' sports. And it is getting richer.

title: KIDNEY DISEASE: ADVANCES PROMISE EARLIER TREATMENT
description: A new era in the treatment of kidney disease is fast approaching, according to experts at a National Kidney Foundation symposium that began here today.

title: Rumasa Units Reopen
description: All 1,200 offices of the 18 banks of the Rumasa holding company resumed normal operations today. They were closed last Thursday when the Socialist Government nationalized them.

title: Egypt Says Libyans Have Pulled Back
description: The Egyptian Government said today that Libyan troops who had massed along the Egyptian-Sudanese border had pulled back.

title: Truck Driver Dies In Crash in Jersey
description: An unidentified truck driver was killed in a fiery three-truck accident here at 5:20 this morning on westbound Interstate 80, and traffic was tied up for four hours over a five-mile area.

title: Group's Role
description: The National Kidney Foundation, a private organization, is less well known than its counterparts like the American Heart Association and the American Cancer Society.

title: GAF Plant Sold
description: The GAF Corporation, which makes building materials and chemicals, said that it had sold an idle asphalt roofing plant in Denver to the Georgia-Pacific Corporation. The price was not disclosed, but is believed to be under $3 million. Although GAF said that the roofing plant had been sold because it was nonproductive, a dissident shareholder, Samuel J. Heyman, is preparing to wage a proxy fight because certain demands, including the sale by GAF of its roofing business, have not been met.

title: Bulgarian Is Reported Asked About Walesa Plot
description: Sergei I. Antonov, the Bulgarian airline representative detained since November on suspicion of having taken part in a plot to assassinate Pope John Paul II in 1981, was reported this evening to have been interrogated about a possible plot to kill Lech Walesa, the leader of the Solidarity union in Poland.

title: SULLAIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a net charge of approximately $5.2 million for the qr and yr for provisions for the writedown of certain assets and increases in certain reserves...C-After a loss of $1,580,000 from discontinued operations...D-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $1,927,000

title: Three Young Singers On Program in Jersey
description: Three young singers who come from show-business families will be featured in the show ''Stars of Tomorrow'' on March 12 at 8 P.M. at the Orrie de Nooyer Auditorium, 200 Hackensack Avenue, Hackensack, N.J.

title: SOME RULES TO LIVE BY FOR EVERYONE ELSE ONLY
description: Mary Bealle works a 40-hour week as a shortorder cook in a Senate cafeteria where she has been employed for 15 years. She makes $11,000 a year. Abby Everett, who has worked in the same cafeteria for 21 years, makes $13,000, while William Harris, another cook employed for seven years, makes $13,500.

title: FLIGHTSAFETY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revs for the previous yr include nonrecurring income of $501,000 from a settlement of a contract between a customer and Marinesafety International, a subsidiary, and $687,000 from the settlement with the U.S. Government involving the loss of use of one of the company's training aircraft

title: PROF. MIDDELDORF, ART SCHOLAR, DIES
description: Prof. Ulrich Middeldorf, an outstanding figure in Renaissance art historical studies, died in Florence on Feb. 20. He was 81 years old. Professor Middeldorf was a professor at the University of Chicago from 1935 to 1953 and subsequently was professor of art history at the University of Florence and director of the German Institute there.

title: NASHUA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MISCONCEPTIONS IN 'DIATRIBE' AGAINST SECRETARY WATT
description: To the Editor:

title: TUESDAY, MARCH 1, 1983; The Economy
description: The Supreme Court upheld the antitrust settlement under which A.T.&T. agreed to divest itself of its local operating companies. The vote was 6 to 3, with the dissenters arguing that the Court should not have ruled in the case without a full briefing. (Page D1.) A.T.&T. plans to raise $1 billion through a new offering of common stock. It will be the company's second huge offering since December. (D1.)

title: YANKS' MATTINGLY ROOKIE ON THE MOVE
description: The Yankees, in the free agent era, have not produced the caliber of rookies who dotted the major leagues last season, players such as Steve Sax, Johnny Ray, Cal Ripken Jr., Kent Hrbek and Dave Hostetler. This season Don Mattingly hopes to change that pattern.

title: JUDGE CENSURED FOR ADDRESSING LAWYER AS 'GIRL'
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice was publicly reprimanded yesterday by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct for referring twice to an attorney appearing before him as ''little girl.''

title: U.S. Official Tells Legislators Aid for Israelis Is Generous
description: A senior State Department official today defended the Reagan Administration's $2.48 billion aid program for Israel against Congressional complaints that it was not enough.

title: Alabama Voting Plan Cleared
description: The Justice Department today approved a reapportionment plan for the Alabama Legislature, saying it was ''fair to black and white citizens alike.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp. announced that it had begun a joint venture with Osaka Transformer Co. Ltd. of Japan to develop the technology for manufacturing electric-utility distribution transformers with amorphous metal cores.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Name and Variations

description: B-Including a tax credit of $319,000...C-Including an increase of $495,000 due principally to reversal of inventory reserve established early in the yr...D-Netincome after a reduction of $6.3 million from reserves established for plant closings

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes charge of $700,000 related to adjustments of carrying value of certain assets

title: REPUTED MOB LEADER PAROLED
description: Nicholas Civella, the reputed head of organized crime in Kansas City, was ordered paroled immediately from Federal prison today because of ill health.

title: CREST-FOAM reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
TV: 'HAPPY ENDINGS' AND THE CIRCUS ON CBS
description: IN ''Happy Endings,'' tonight's television movie on CBS at 9, John Schneider plays an aspiring writer named Nick Callohan. You know he is a writer because his San Francisco apartment is decorated with poster-size photographs of D.H. Lawrence, Mark Twain, F. Scott Fitzgerald and the like. He also sits intensely before a typewriter, ripping out and crumbling sheets of nearly blank paper. Otherwise, Nick is just your average ninny, always turning everything into a joke.

title: Topics; Atmospherics; Impounded
description: One way to take your mind off your own family is to spy on another, which is why heaven blessed America with such as ''Dallas'' and ''Dynasty.'' But Britain's blessing was the greater: for centuries it has had ''Royalty.''

title: MYOPIC POLICY ON PAKISTAN
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee meets Wednesday to review President Reagan's offer of $3.2 billion in military and economic aid to Pakistan over the next six years, and a House committee will hold public hearings next week. This proposal deserves critical examination.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bob Arum set May 27 as the date for his twin title bouts at the Sun City resort in Bophuthatswana, a tribal homeland within South Africa. Davey Moore, the World Boxing Association's junior middleweight champion, will face Roberto Duran, and Ray Mancini will defend his lightweight crown against Kenny Bogner. ... Joe Gilliam, the former Pittsburgh Steeler quarterback who had hoped for a comeback with the United States Football League, has been dropped by the Denver Gold. ... Ted Kitchel, Indiana University's star forward, underwent surgery last night to repair a ruptured disk.

title: ANTI-IMMIGRANT GROUP PARALYZES ASSAM BY CALLING GENERAL STRIKE
description: A predominantly Hindu movement demanding the ouster of hundreds of thousands of mostly Moslem immigrants brought the northeastern state of Assam to a halt Sunday night and today with a 24-hour general strike.

title: ELEPHANT SEALS REDUX
description: THE northern elephant seal, nearly exterminated by hunters in the 19th century, has made one of the most remarkable comebacks yet seen, two California scientists have reported.

title: Jersey Man Sentenced In Tylenol Extortion Case
description: Vernon Williams Jr., of East Orange, was sentenced today to a two-year prison term for mail fraud for attempting to extort $100,000 from the manufacturer of Tylenol by threatening to put cyanide in the medicine.

title: AIRLINE COMPUTERS GENERATE FARE RIFT
description: A quarrel has erupted over whether two major airlines could take unfair advantage of the way tickets are sold at most travel agencies. With perhaps tens of million of dollars at stake, the Civil Aeronautics Board has expedited hearings on the matter.

title: ATCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rugby Star Reinstated
description: When it was disclosed last week that he had been negotiating with the Dallas Cowboys to become a place-kicker, Naas Botha, a star of amateur rugby in South Africa, was suspended from competition. Yesterday, after a two-hour hearing by the disciplinary committee of the Northern Transvaal Rugby Union, Botha was reinstated and cleared to sign with the Cowboys without jeopardizing his amateur status in rugby. The reason for the ruling, according to the panel, was that in all the fine print of the International Rugby Board's regulations barring professionalism, there was no reference to United States football.

title: Louisiana Republicans Seek Support of Blacks
description: Louisiana Republicans are courting blacks and other minorities with a platform promise of economic advancement through free enterprise and better education.

title: CONFRONTATION ON LYRICS STIRS VOICE OF AMERICA
description: It began with a discreet memo three weeks ago from Frank Scott, director of programming at the Voice of America, to ''all division and service chiefs.'' He wrote: ''We must be particularly careful not to present music/lyrics which may be offensive to any segment of our audience.''

title: Conrail Rates Rise
description: Conrail is raising rates Tuesday an average of 2.5 percent for its piggyback freight rail service throughout most of its system, the company announced. It cited increased costs for the first significant rise in rates for the service since December 1980. The new rates will affect shipments of truck trailers or marine containers transported on flatbed rail cars, the company said.

title: OIL EXPORTERS CONTINUE TALKS
description: Oil ministers from Venezuela, Algeria and Kuwait met today as part of a continuing international effort to avoid a precipitous decline in world oil prices.

title: TEXAS INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a writedown of $2.9 million of the company's discontinued operations...C-Net income

title: ELECTRONICS CORP OF ISRAEL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SHARON FILES SUIT AGAINST MAGAZINE
description: Former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon filed a $270,000 libel suit in a Tel Aviv court against Time Inc. and Time-Life International today, charging that he had been damaged by a false allegation in Time magazine that he had urged the Gemayel family to take revenge for the murder of President-elect Bashir Gemayel of Lebanon.

title: COURT GETS TRANSCRIPT OF TALKS ON TEAMSTER FUND
description: The Government ended its case today in presentencing hearings for the teamsters' president by presenting the transcript of a conversation in which two of his co-defendants and a reputed Mafia chief discussed plans to try to regain control of the union's pension fund.

title: Greyhound Unit
description: The Greyhound Corporation has sold its Greyhound Rent-A-Car Inc. subsidiary to Sidney H. Cohen, president of Value Rent-A-Car, Greyhound announced.

title: ON THE ROCK: SHOPPING IN SPAIN IS A BREATH OF AIR
description: When the apes leave, the local legend says, so will the British. The simian analogy is perhaps not very flattering, but legend is legend and so for decades the colonial authorities have kept a close watch on the band of 40 or so tailless monkeys that scamper around the limestone caves, tugging at the camera straps of tourists and generally making a nuisance of themselves.

title: BUCKHORN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $490,000

title: CONCERT: 'WINTERREISE'
description: THE first performance of Schubert's ''Winterreise'' was the composer's own; he sang the melancholic songs to some friends who remained skeptical about their unremitting gloom. The performance at Merkin Hall last night, some 150 years later, had the sort of intimacy and directness that the cycle must have had on that first occasion. But a different sort of gloom was glimpsed.

title: Charlotte Curtis; A Tale of Two Cities; Wherein a prestigious New York law firm finds cause to establish roots in Ohio.
description: SIMPSON, THACHER & BARTLETT is a big, prestigious, old New York law firm that had no plans to open a branch in Ohio. Yet when the American Electric Power Corporation, one of its biggest clients, finally acquired the Columbus and Southern Ohio Electric Company and began moving its New York headquarters to this city on the Scioto, a river only residents pronounce properly, Simpson, Thacher gamely rethought the matter.

title: EVANS, BOB, FARMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
CLEVERLY DESIGNED PESTICIDE IS SAFE POISON
description: RESEARCHERS in the rapidly growing field of industrial biotechnology have developed a strategy for making safe and potent pesticides, using chemicals harmless to man and all other vertebrates. The chemicals are converted into deadly poison by enzymes present only in insects.

title: S.E.C. PLANS A REVIEW OF TENDER OFFER TACTICS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had formed an advisory panel to review some of the tactics used by corporations in tender offers to acquire other companies.

title: GIANT PORTLAND & MASONRY CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
7th AVE. WINNERS: COAT DRESSES, SUITS
description: Best-selling styles on Seventh Avenue provide a good idea of how women will dress this spring and summer. These are the clothes ordered heavily by stores throughout the country. The emphasis they are placing on some specific types will also have an influence on the clothes designers will present for next fall and winter. Design rooms have already switched from the production of warm-weather fashions to fashions for winter, the strongest selling season.

title: HELLER TO SELL 2 FINANCE SUBSIDIARIES
description: The Security Pacific Corporation has agreed to acquire two commercial lending subsidiaries of the Walter E. Heller International Corporation for $400 million, plus an undetermined portion of future earnings, the two companies announced today.

title: 3 Killed in Texas Poker Game
description: A gunfight at a West Texas poker game left two men dead and apparently sent another wounded player running to a nearby house, where he was shot again and killed, the police said today.

title: Methods of Measuring Cable TV Audiences
description: The cable television industry is slowly moving toward finding a proper method of measuring audience that will be fair to it and the broadcast crowd. If it is to become a big league advertising medium, this is a must.

title: Vilas Beats Slozil In W.C.T. Final
description: Guillermo Vilas breezed past Pavel Slozil of Czechoslovakia, 6-1, 6-4, 6-0, today and won the rain-delayed $300,000 World Championship Tennis Gold Coast tournament.

title: U.S. TESTS SHOW CONNECTICUT SITE OVER PCB LIMIT
description: Federal officials reported yesterday that some of the samples they had ordered taken at a large hazardous-waste disposal facility in Connecticut contained excessive levels of a suspected carcinogen.

title: REAGAN WEIGHING MORE U.S. ADVISERS FOR EL SALVADOR
description: President Reagan is considering an increase in the number of United States military advisers in El Salvador beyond the current limit of 55, a senior White House official said today.

title: Contributions By Bankers
description: More than 80 percent of the Representatives and Senators sponsoring bills to repeal the scheduled withholding on dividends and interest have received contributions from the political action committees of the three leading banking industry trade associations, according to a study by Congress Watch.

title: MOBILE COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Topics; Atmospherics; Cold Comfort
description: In a season in which the state of the art of weather forecasting turned out to be remarkably shaky, it is reassuring to learn that Government weather experts have just uncovered a verity: how uncomfortable the weather makes you feel depends on what you're used to.

title: CONCERT: TASHI PLAYS THE BEETHOVEN SEPTET
description: TASHI offered another of its provocative chamber music programs at the 92d Street Y Sunday. At the center was Beethoven's E flat Septet - a piece we tend to push aside, but one more beloved by his contemporaries than all the sonatas and symphonies together.

title: Chess: Tal Wins the Chigorin Title At Sochi on the Black Sea
description: Mikhail Tal won the 16th Chigorin Memorial Tournament, held in the Black Sea resort of Sochi in the Soviet Union. The Latvian former world champion scored 10-5 against a strong field.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * ARA Services Inc., Philadelphia, has named Joseph Neubauer chief executive officer.

title: SMITH COLLEGE PLANS TO HONOR MRS. KIRKPATRICK IN ABSENTIA
description: Smith College, reversing its customary policy, said today that it would give an honorary degree in absentia to Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States representative at the United Nations, before the college's commencement exercises in May.

title: LOWE'S COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
LUBRIZOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EDUCATORS TEST A NEW CATEGORY, MASTER TEACHER
description: WHEN Jon Harkness was offered a chance to give up teaching and become a curriculum supervisor, he accepted only on the condition that he could continue to spend half his time in the classroom. Now, he teaches two physics classes and helps coordinate the entire science program for the public schools of Wausau, Wis.

title: AMERICA'S NEWER IMMIGRANTS CHOOSING SUBURBS OVER CITIES
description: At the Original Coney Island in downtown St. Paul, Frances Arvanitas, a native of Greece, is in her 54th year of serving hot dogs to a neighborhood that once teemed with European ethnic families but is now home to bands of native, but homeless, poor.

title: WEYENBERG SHOE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: New regulations aimed at easing midtown congestion take effect today, with the elimination of 62 privileged parking spaces.

title: State Dept. Has Reservations About New Immigration Law
description: Congressional efforts to tighten United States immigration laws could hinder the Government's attempts to persuade the Soviet bloc to adopt more liberal emigration policies, a State Department official said today.

title: JERSEY ASSEMBLY VOTES TO PROHIBIT VIDEO GAMBLING
description: The New Jersey Assembly gave final passage today to a bill that would ban the use of video games as part of the state lottery.

title: BERGEN STATE BANK (BERGENFIELD, NJ) reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
DANCE: LYDIA ABARCA IS BACK
description: LYDIA ABARCA returned to the Dance Theater of Harlem on Sunday afternoon at City Center, and what a return it was! Miss Abarca, one of the company's first ballerinas, danced the title role in Michel Fokine's ''Scheherazade'' with indolent passion. Every gesture was a caress, every toss of a head that of a restless feline.

title: Tools of Trade
description: It is usually hot, sometimes 95 degrees, where Dwight Braxton is training for his March 18 light-heavyweight unification title fight with Michael Spinks.

title: LIFTING OF JAIL CAPACITY LIMITS URGED
description: New York City officials asked a Federal judge yesterday to suspend court orders that limit the number of prisoners in city jails. Unless the orders are lifted, the city contended, some inmates will have to be released from Rikers Island this week.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that Douglas D. Danforth would become chairman and chief executive officer Dec. 1 to succeed Robert E. Kirby, who will reach the company's retirement age of 65 on Nov. 8.

title: N.C.A.A. Upheld In Trust Case
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association did not commit antitrust violations when it established women's championships in 1981-82 and put a women's athletic group out of business, a judge ruled today.

title: ACCOUNTING RULE CHANGED
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board yesterday changed the way that good will can be amortized in certain acquisitions of banking and thrift institutions.

title: DOME PETROLEUM IN DEBT AGREEMENT
description: Dome Petroleum's four main Canadian bankers agreed today to extend repayment of $1.4 billion (Canadian) of debt while discussions on a rescue continue.

title: PALM BEACH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss includes income from discontinued operations of $15,000...C-After loss from discontinued operations of $379,000

title: IN WORLD'S DEEPEST MINE, RESEARCHERS HEAR THE ROCKS 'TALK'
description: THE experience of getting to the bottom of the world's deepest mine is basically not much different from that of riding the IRT from Lexington Avenue and 59th Street to Grand Central Station, then taking the shuttle to Times Square and switching to the Broadway Local for another stop or two. The major difference is that you are traveling straight down.

title: Post Tour Vetoed
description: C.W. Post's basketball team had been looking forward to a nine-game tour of Hungary March 26 to April 14. But the National Collegiate Athletic Association has vetoed the trip, citing its rule that allows foreign tours only if the athletes do not miss a day of classes.

title: CGA COMPUTER ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest 9 mos reflect a nonrecurring loss of $440,000 from a blood bank provision; results were reported on a pooling-of-interests basis

title: DEVELOPMENT CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration is revising proposed rules to tighten prohibitions against use of Federal funds for lobbying by recipients of Government grants or contracts. The move follows protests from business groups and hundreds of public charities.

title: Books Of The Times
description: THE QUEEN'S GAMBIT. By Walter Tevis. 243 pages. Random House. $13.95. FORGET just for a moment that Walter Tevis's ''The Queen's Gambit'' is a novel about the game of chess - the best one that I know of to be written since Nabokov's ''Defense.'' Consider it as a psychological thriller, a contest pitting human rationality against the self's unconscious urge to wipe out thought.

title: Appeals Rejected In Race-Fix Case
description: The Supreme Court today rejected appeals from three of 14 people who were convicted four years ago of a widespread scheme to fix horse races at East Coast tracks.

title: CAMPBELL RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. TRADE DEFICIT LESS IN JANUARY
description: Rising farm exports and declining oil imports narrowed the American trade deficit to about $2.96 billion in January, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Talking Business with Lambert of Eastdil Realty; Present Status Of Real Estate
description: As interest rates decline, institutional investors are looking with renewed interest at commercial real estate, a market that has been going through a difficult period. One executive who is greatly involved in real estate these days is Benjamin V. Lambert, president of Eastdil Realty Inc., a New York-based international real estate investment company. In its latest year, he says, Eastdil advised clients about purchasing more than $2 billion worth of property.

title: CHAIRMAN OF CHANNEL 13 WILL STEP DOWN IN JUNE
description: George T. Piercy, chairman of Channel 13, the New York metropolitan area's major public television station, intends to step down at the board's annual meeting in June, officials on the board confirmed yesterday.

title: John Lodge Gets Switzerland Post
description: President Reagan today named John Davis Lodge, the 79-year-old former Governor of Connecticut, to be United States Ambassador to Switzerland.

title: PREWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $816,000 or 30 cents a shr due to a reduction in LIFO inventory

title: MISSOURI PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary credit from a coal price settlement of $1,052,251

title: Dow Declines 8.32, to 1,112.62
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday as investors cashed in some recent profits. The main casualties were precious-metal issues, responding to a sharp drop in bullion prices.

title: Generic Sales Picture
description: If you think that the present depressed economy has helped increase the sale of generic and private-label products in supermarkets, think again. Unlike the trend that was seen in 1980 and 1981, Selling Areas-Marketing Inc., a Time Inc. subsidiary, reports that sales of private label and generic goods were probably down last year because food-store prices increased by only 4.3 percent, compared with 9.9 percent in 1981.

title: The Mind's Eye and the Vatican
description: Among the many pleasures of ''The Vatican Collections,'' the Vatican's first official traveling exhibition, now at the Metropolitan Museum, are four that have so far remained uncelebrated.

title: Wallace Leaves Hospital
description: Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama was released from a hospital today after a weeklong stay for treatment of an inflamed colon. Mr. Wallace's press secretary, Billy Joe Camp, said he did not expect the 63-year-old Governor to require continued medication for the ailment, but he added, ''That will depend on the doctor's assessment.''

title: DELTONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a charge of $22.7 million for the qr and yr to provide for future costsresulting from the denial of development permit for the Marco Island community...C-Net income

title: Rain Insurance
description: Edward Bennett Williams, the owner of the Baltimore Orioles, figures that the seven home games postponed because of rain last year cost the Orioles perhaps $1 million in lost revenue. So this year, Williams has a new insurance policy designed to soften the economic blow of rain postponements.

title: BRAZILIAN DANCERS LATEST TO JOIN 'A CHORUS LINE'
description: Rain was leaking from the roof onto the stage, rats scampered about the orchestra pit, the dancers were wearing jackets to protect them from winter winds blowing through the broken windows and the rehearsal was being conducted by candlelight because of a power shortage. Soot still blackened the theater walls from a firebombing by a right-wing group unhappy with the treatment of the title character in a just-ended production of ''Jesus Christ Superstar.''

title: GOLD: DECLINE FEEDS ON ITSELF
description: After soaring $200 an ounce since last June, gold prices have lost more than half this gain in less than a week, including a $42.50-anounce drop in New York yesterday. It was the biggest one-day decline in almost three years.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Closing Out a Concession

title: Salvadoran Rebels Call Truce
description: El Salvador's leftist-led guerrillas today announced a cease-fire for the visit of Pope John Paul II next Sunday. At a news conference in Mexico City, Guillermo Ungo, the Salvadoran opposition leader, said the guerrillas wanted to help create ''favorable conditions'' for the Pope's stay.

title: Mutual Fund Sales Up
description: Sales of mutual funds rose to $3.01 billion last month, from $886 million in January 1982 and $2.08 billion in December, the Investment Company Institute said today. The figures include all but short-term mutual funds. Redemptions rose to $1.02 billion, from $914 million in December and $411 million a year earlier, making net sales a record $1.99 billion, up from the previous high of $1.16 billion in December and $476 million in January 1982.

title: TRIATHLON THRIVES ON 'WIDE WORLD'
description: Spanning the globe to bring you the constant variety of sport, as ABC's ''Wide World of Sports'' claims to do, often requires a good deal of scouring the globe first. We have been called new liberals, new wave, turncoats and technopols, among other things. But the label that has stuck is Atari Democrats. The label is glib but it flows from a basic truth: our concern for keeping America technologically competitive with Japan and other countries.

She replied that, well, she just wasn't a ''lesson plan kind of teacher.'' When a subsequent editorial in The New York Times suggested that lesson plans were an obsolete requirement that ''kills spontaneity,'' it drew a flood of letters from angry school administrators. They asserted that an attack on lesson plans was tantamount to an attack on sound educational management. That was in 1971.

title: TO MEET GREEK NEEDS
description: Recent signals on both sides of the Atlantic - including plans for a mass demonstration against the United States's presence to take place tomorrow in Athens and the Reagan Administration's proposal to double military aid to Turkey in fiscal 1984 - may bode ill for the negotiations, begun last October, on the future of the United States military bases in Greece. Since Athens insists that the first phase of the talks must be completed within months, the next few weeks may be decisive not merely for the bases but for American-Greek relations generally. The solution to the immediate problem can be found only in an arrangement by which the United States continues to maintain the military balance between Greece and Turkey, satisfying Athens's security needs.

Thousands of words have been written about the revolution, which highlights a mixture of culinary cultures; a return to the rustic, the homespun and the simple; an emphasis on fresh fruits and vegetables, fish and poultry in place of red meats; the use of meat as a condiment rather than the center of the meal, and the disappearance of thick gravies and cream sauces.

title: TV: REVIEW OF THE NEW FEDERALISM
description: PUBLIC television examines President Reagan's ''new federalism'' tonight in an intelligent documentary film. It lucidly shows that Mr. Reagan was advocating a philosophy as much as he was pressing a legislative program when he called for the ''new federalism'' last year, and that even though this particular legislation foundered, the philosophy still lives. The legislation would have had Washington take full responsibility for Medicaid, while the states took over the basic welfare programs. The philosophy says that local governments can do some things better than Washington. Thoughtful people, the documentary takes pains to point out, disagree on what this is all about.

Real Estate
description: THE Meadowlands in New Jersey is undergoing a new stage in its evolution, according to real estate experts there. Garbage dumps and polluted streams were followed by warehouses and industrial development and the sports complex. But now the growth in warehouse and industrial development has slowed to a near halt, and the emphasis is more on office space and housing.

title: THEATER: 'THE TOOTH OF CRIME' AT LA MAMA ANNEX
description: SAM SHEPARD'S ''Tooth of Crime'' is his most savage vision, a diabolical duel between the fading king and the fast-rising challenger. Both men, Hoss and Crow, are rock stars, but on this multi-metaphorical landscape, they are also cowboys, auto racers, gangsters and starship commanders, in each guise vying for the supremacy of power and fame.

title: Careers; '83 Seniors As Efficient Job Hunters
description: REPORTS indicate that job recruiting at many colleges and universities will be down about 20 percent this spring. Even the best students at top-rated institutions face a squeeze as a result of the recession. They may have as many interviews as seniors did in prior years but probably will not receive as many offers.

title: Military Analysis
description: Syria and Jordan are acquiring new weapons that Israeli and American intelligence sources agree will raise questions about accepted strategic concepts in the Middle East.

title: Artist's in Quest of Recognition
description: They weren't celebrating the demise of ''M*A*S*H,'' much as they disliked its portrayal of their country. This Monday evening gathering was a rather obscure segment of the city's growing Korean community talking about how not to stay that way.

title: AMERICA'S I.M.F. STAKE
description: The appropriations bill proposed by President Reagan to increase America's contribution to the International Monetary Fund by 50 percent ($84 billion) deserves bipartisan support. Contrary to some protectionist Democrats' fears, the plan will save American jobs even as it employs people in the developing world. The argument of some Republicans that a few losses might discipline private banks for the future overlooks the consequences of such discipline on debtor nations and on American business.

title: Florence Gould Dead; Benefactor of the Arts
description: Florence Gould, a patron of the arts, died in her villa on the Mediterranean on Monday, friends reported. She was 87 years old.

title: LATE CANADIEN GOAL TIES THE ISLANDERS
description: Better, yes. But still not magnifique. The Islanders, on the verge of breaking a four-game streak without a victory with a dazzling third-period offensive display, instead settled tonight for a 3-3 tie with the Montreal Canadiens. New York's winless streak (0-2-3) is the club's longest since the start of the 1979-80 season.

title: KNICKS DEFEATED BY 76ers, 106-94
description: It was almost like the old-time chic at Madison Square Garden last night. The stars, like Woody Allen, Mia Farrow and Peter Falk, returned from wherever stars go when their team is not winning. They were back, presumably, because the Knicks were coming off their best month since their last championship season 10 years ago.

title: Fannie Mae Sells Certificate Issue
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association issued $401.7 million of 11 1/2 percent mortgage pass-through certificates. They were offered at a price of 97 1/2 to yield 11.78 percent through underwriters led by Warburg Paribas Becker.

title: NORDSTROM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
GOVERNORS ASK U.S. TO REDUCE DEFICIT IN FEDERAL BUDGET
description: In a shift away from their past policy on the Federal budget, the nation's governors formally appealed to the Federal Government today to reduce deficits by slowing military spending and restricting money for some domestic programs, including Social Security.

title: DOW RISES 18.09, TO RECORD 1,130.71
description: Growing optimism that the economy will continue to improve sent stock prices up sharply yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average soaring 18.09 points, to a record close of 1,130.71.

title: PARTICIPANTS AND DISPUTES IN RAIL STRIKE
description: The striking employees of NJ Transit are the 780 conductors and trainmen who are represented by United Transportation Union Local 1384. They had been working without a contract since Jan. 1 when the state took over nine railroads that had formerly been operated by Conrail.

title: Dome and Affiliate Offer Some of Pipeline Shares
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., the debt-burdened oil and gas enterprise, and its 48 percent owned exploration affiliate, Dome Canada, today announced a $281.9 million (Canadian) sale of TransCanada Pipelines stock that will reduce their holdings by more than half. The Canadian dollar is worth about 81 cents in United States currency.

title: Mayor to Face Ex-Mayor
description: Mayor Richard Berkley and former Mayor Charles Wheeler finished first and second in today's mayoral primary and will face each other in the March 29 general election. They ran ahead of City Councilman Joe Serviss and a Socialist, Bob Kutchko. Although the City Charter calls for nonpartisan elections, Mr. Wheeler, who was Mayor from 1971 to 1979, billed himself as a Truman-style Democrat, and Mr. Serviss promoted himself as ''the'' Democrat in the race. Mr. Berkley is the first Republican to serve as Mayor since the 1920's.

title: HOW TO FUND RACES FOR THE U.S. SENATE
description: To the Editor:

title: THE AIR DELIVERY FREE-FOR-ALL
description: The ads for overnight package delivery have a frantic quality. Couriers and planes race to overtake rivals while hapless customers grow beards and miss business opportunities.

description: Federally owned Petro-Canada Exploration Inc. said it had made its previously announced offer for all the outstanding class A and B shares of BP Canada Inc.'s BP Refining and Marketing Canada Ltd. It is offering $1.236 per class A share and $12.414 per class B share for acceptance until March 31.

title: BUELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
JAZZ: SAHEB SARBIB QUINTET
description: GROUP chemistry is one of jazz's eternal mysteries. The Saheb Sarbib Quintet, which played Sunday and Monday at Sweet Basil, is a band of diverse individualists that should not cohere, but does - and, on the evidence of Sunday's first set, does so magnificently.

title: HOUSE VOTES CONSERVATION CORPS TO PUT 100,000 YOUTHS TO WORK
description: The House of Representatives today approved, over the objections of the Reagan Administration, a bill that would establish an American Conservation Corps to provide jobs for young people preserving the nation's natural resources.

title: Knapp Communications
description: Harry Myers, who became publisher of Knapp Communications' Geo magazine after 20 years with the Meredith Corporation, has now been named group publisher of all Knapp magazines - Architectural Digest, Bon Appetit and Home, in addition to Geo. He will be working in New York and will succeed John L. Decker, 47, who will remain at Los Angeles headquarters ''in a yet to be determined capacity.'' Mr. Myers, 51, joined Geo in the spring of 1982. At Meredith he had been, among other things, the publisher of Apartment Life who repositioned it as Metropolitan Home.

description: To the Editor:

title: ABC OFF 6.4%
description: The American Can Company said yesterday that net income in last year's fourth quarter plunged 83.2 percent because of weak demand for containers and packaging, polyethylene resins and forest products.

title: RANGERS ELIMINATE PENGUINS
description: By playing to a 3-3 tie with the Penguins tonight, the Rangers eliminated Pittsburgh from a playoff berth for the first time in five years and moved within 2 points of clinching a berth for themselves.

title: TEXT OF GOVERNORS' RESOLUTION ON FEDERAL BUDGET
description: Following is the text of the position paper adopted by the National Governors Association on the Federal budget: The nation's governors are extremely concerned about the large Federal deficits that are projected over the next five years. These deficits are projected by the Congressional Budget Office to increase from $197 billion in fiscal 1984 to $267 billion or 5.6 percent of the gross national product (G.N.P.) in 1988 in spite of the fact that real G.N.P. is assumed to grow between 3 and 4 percent per year over this period.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: MITCH EASTER built his Drive In Studio in his parents' garage in Winston-Salem, N.C., shortly after he graduated from the University of North Carolina in 1978. Five years later the studio is still in the garage, but it has attracted a steady stream of clients from among America's leading new wave rock groups.

title: HOUSE UNIT TENTATIVELY BACKS MOST OF SOCIAL SECURITY PLAN
description: The House Ways and Means Committee, rushing to complete work on a Social Security bill, agreed tonight to let the full House of Representatives vote on how to assure the system's long-term financial health.

title: WCI CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Serving Together
description: Jerome and Aurelia Green of the West Bronx, members of Community School Board 9, are the only husband and wife on a district board in the city. But Eileen and William H. Caulfield of Bayside, Queens, will be running May 3 in District 26, which also includes Douglaston and Little Neck.

title: SCAASI'S DRESSES IN EXOTIC BLOOM
description: THE show opened with two fitted checked jackets shimmering in sequins over puffy red or navy net skirts - certainly not quiet, unassuming fashion fare, but why should it be? This was Arnold Scaasi's made-to-order collection, one of the last bastions of custom-made clothes in this country. Many of the styles had been previewed in Palm Beach, Fla., last week at a benefit for St. Mary's Hospital, and one observer said they held their own alongside the hibiscus and bougainvillea.

title: Braniff Deal Still Pending
description: A Federal appeals court in New Orleans was still considering yesterday a proposal by the Braniff International Corporation and PSA Inc. to use 30 of Braniff's planes to start a new service at Dallas-Fort Worth Airport by next summer.

title: CHIEF N.J. TRANSIT NEGOTIATOR REGARDS HIS TASK AS PUTTING TOGETHER A PUZZLE
description: Martin E. Robins - lawyer, transit offical, career public servant and dreamer -likes to approach complicated problems as if he were playing with a puzzle.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have a 30-gallon gas-hot-water heater that is very noisy. When it is running it sounds as though there is air bubbling on the inside or as though the water is boiling. The heater is kept on the warm setting, not on high. I drained the tank, but it is still very noisy. Is there any way I can eliminate the noise?

title: Rules Issued to Protect Handicapped Infants
description: The Government is issuing rules to protect handicapped infants from discrimination by being denied lifesupporting nutrition or medical care and is setting up a 24-hour hot line to receive complaints, Acting Health Secretary Thomas Donnelly said today.

title: City to Keep Funds For Pollution Plant
description: New York City can keep $76.7 million in leftover sewage treatment funds to continue work on the North River plant on Manhattan's West Side, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: DOUBLEDAY CUTS STAFF AT TWO DOUBLEDAY SUBSIDIARIES
description: Doubleday has discharged dozens of employees in its financially troubled Delacorte and Dell subsidiaries. The dismissals, which a company official said would amount to ''less than 65'' but which sources within Doubleday said could reach as high as 100, take effect tomorrow. They include at least two editors, as well as people in the art, publicity and sales departments.

title: JOINT FILM PROJECT SET
description: Universal Pictures and Lorimar Productions will co-finance three movies, including a film version of the popular television series ''Dallas.'' Such a co-financing arrangement and 50-50 profit split between a major studio and an independent is considered unusual.

title: E.P.A. Likely to Relax Rules on Air Pollution

title: AGE BIAS LAW HELD BINDING ON STATE GOVERNMENTS

At Village West, Hudson at Bank Street, she combines her attributes to build a performance that has sparkle, freshness and the delights that come from a constant series of surprises.

title: MIXED MEDIA

HERS
description: I wish I could remember who said that in middle age we become the person we always were. I think it might be so. In fact I feel it happening. Bits and pieces of self, discarded in adolescent frenzy or early adult preoccupation, seem to be floating downstream and fetching up on my shore. I imagine that when I reach middle age I will be a rock covered with moss born by spores on the wind and lichen brought by who knows what. At any rate, it will all be familiar. We'll all shake hands - the rock, the moss, the lichen, the visiting toad and the perching dove and say, ''Nice to see you again.'' And then we'll settle in to stay.

title: SIX LONG MONTHS
description: Six months have passed since the announcement of the Reagan Administration's ''peace plan'' for the Mideast. The Israelis saw it as a betrayal of solemn agreements made at Camp David; the radical Arabs rejected it because continued warfare is their reason for being; the Saudis told King Hussein of Jordan not to join peace talks without P.L.O. blessings. The ill-conceived plan is dead in the water; it should never have been put forward.

title: The Salvadoran Cross
description: The more alarms the Administration sounds about El Salvador, the more alarming its course appears. Its first reaction to some recent guerrilla successes was ominous talk about sending more military advisers and giving Americans a larger role in a bitter civil war. Wisely, the White House retreated, saying it would suffice to provide $60 million in additional military aid. Unwisely, it also hints that if Congress balks, the money will be drawn from a discretionary Pentagon fund.

Burger King said that the fast-food company gave its seven-story, 88481-square-foot building in suburban Kendall to Florida Holdings Inc., which in turn will acquire $12.5 million worth of restaurant sites - nearly 50 locations -around the country for Burger King. Burger King said it plans to remain in its building until a new Miami-area building is completed.

It seems that ''Fame,'' which has been having its ratings problems in this country, is extremely popular in Britain, sometimes No. 1 and always placing in the Top 10. Songs from the program have made the best-seller record charts. So, presumably in gratitude, several members of the cast, headed by Debbie Allen, agreed to participate in a stage production that was given a British tour last December. According to reports, that too was extraordinarily popular.

''You want to know why she's so good,'' Don Peters, the coach of the United States national gynmastics team, said yesterday. ''She's so meticulous, that's really why. Julianne probably won't like me saying this, but I walked into her room the other day, and I was shocked. She's the only person I know who folds her shoelaces. I asked her 'Why?', and she says, 'Cause it's neat.' She's a fanatic.''

title: FRIDAY, MARCH 4, 1983
description: International The Pope spoke of human rights in Central America and called for increased international action to curb abuses. Hours before John Paul II's statement in San Jose, Costa Rica, the Guatemalan Government, rejecting a request from the Vatican, executed six men found guilty of subversive acts by a secret military tribunal. The Vatican denounced the action in a statement that gave no hint the Pope would change his plans to visit Guatemala next week. (Page A1, Column 1.) Advanced elections in El Salvador have been scheduled, according to Salvadoran politicians. They said that the provisional Government had decided to hold the presidential elections in December instead of next March. The Reagan Administration had pressed for such a change. (A1:2-3.)

description: ''Sliver'' buildings - tall, narrow residences that tower above their neighbors - were banned yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The board voted unanimously to change the zoning code after 24 witnesses stepped to the microphones in City Hall to criticize the slivers. Some said that bulldozers had been digging furiously to avoid the ban, which takes effect immediately. Work can be continued only on those with foundations in place.

title: Electrification Funds For L.I.R.R. Rejected
description: An appropriation of $15 million for electrification of the Long Island Rail Road, approved by the House Appropriations Committee last week, was rejected on the House floor today.

title: THREE STOOGES NOSTALGIA IS TODAY'S NEWEST FAD
description: Who grunt, growl and screech, commit unthinkable acts of mayhem upon each other and bumblingly reduce to rubble whatever they touch, wherever they happen to be?

title: Now the Dutch Have a Palace Intruder
description: An emotionally disturbed man who said he was searching for William the Silent, a Prince of Orange who died in 1584, invaded Queen Beatrix's residential palace as she was holding a formal dinner, officials said today.

title: ARTHUR KOESTLER AND WIFE SUICIDES IN LONDON
description: Arthur Koestler, an archetype of the activist Central European intellectual who drew on his Communist background for the antitotalitarian novel ''Darkness at Noon,'' was found dead with his wife at their London home yesterday. Police officials said their deaths were apparently by suicide.

title: THEATER: 'DOG EAT DOG,' HARD TIMES IN SUBURBIA
description: THE setting for Mary Gallagher's new comedy, ''Dog Eat Dog,'' is an affluent suburb close to John Cheever country. However, hard times have struck this particular Bullet Park. Citizens are facing a recession and a depression, both upper and lower case. Businesses are collapsing, breadwinners are losers, there are squatters at the country club, and the community is besieged by hoarders, cadgers and thieves. The play is, of course, a complete fabrication, except to those who are about to experience it in real life.

title: News Analysis
description: Determining what, in the end, a labor contract provides and what it does not provide can be exceedingly difficult, as the agreement negotiated this week between the United Steelworkers of America and seven major steel companies demonstrates.

description: EVIDENCE continues to accumulate that the recovery is in motion. The Government's index of leading indicators jumped 3.6 percent in January, so spectactular a gain that Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige cautioned that it was probably exaggerated by mild weather in January and the rapid growth of the banks' new money market accounts.

description: Assets of the money market funds declined at least $1.5 billion during the week ended Wednesday, Donoghue's Money Fund Report said yesterday.

description: NEW YORK apparently made Porter Wagoner nervous. Mr. Wagoner has been a leading country singer for 27 years, and still has the trappings of an old-line Nashville performer - sequined suit, silver cowboy boots and cornball jokes between songs. title: ART: CHUCK CLOSE SHOW, WITH FRIENDS AS MODELS
description: IT'S not true that if you've seen one Chuck Close portrait you've seen them all, but it's getting there, and that may well be the artist's intention. Mr. Close's current show at the Pace Gallery, 32 East 57th Street, occupies two floors and consists of heads, full face and profile, which run from 2 to 8 (or more) feet tall and are in black and white or shades of gray. The models, as usual, are the artist himself and his friends, who include the composer, Philip Glass, and they have all been strained in one way or another through the same democratic grid.

The Dow Jones industrial average rose 3 points, to 1,138.06, while the Big Board's composite index rose 0.70, to 88.48, and Standard & Poor's index rose 1.18, to 153.48. title: Richard Needs Surgery
description: J.R. Richard, the Houston Astros' pitcher, has suffered another setback in his attempt to resurrect his major league career. A neurologist said Thursday that Richards must have leg surgery to restore proper circulation in his left leg. and that he will be out of action for about six weeks. Dr. William Fields said the surgery to replace an artificial graft would be performed early next week in Houston.

description: Indian troops have been ordered to extend their control over Assam as a result of fighting in which at least 41 people were killed on Wednesday.

description: President Reagan called on all Americans today to help meet the $77 million cost of fielding the national Olympic team next year. In backing this effort, he complained that the news media did not adequately cover the scope of voluntary activity in this country.

title: Bell Puts Breakup Cost at $1.9 Billion
description: The divestiture of its 22 operating companies will cost the American Telephone and Telegraph Company at least $1.9 billion between 1983 and 1987, the company estimated in a filing with the Federal Communications Commission. The expenditures, which would eventually be passed through to consumers, do not include administrative expenses, it said.

title: RACE IS CLOSE FOR SKIING TITLE
description: The competition between Phil Mahre and Ingemar Stenmark for first place in the World Cup standing is so close that officials of the United States ski team say they do not expect the championship to be decided until the last race of the season in Furano, Japan, on March 21.

BOLCOM AND MORRIS'S AMERICA, IN POP AND CLASSICS

There will be a guest appearance by Percy Danforth, an 82-year-old architect, who is recognized the world over as a virtuoso player of a uniquely American percussion instrument, the bones. Somehow, at a Bolcom and Morris concert, not even a bones virtuoso is entirely unexpected.

ART: 2 UNUSUAL WOMEN
description: THEY were artists, friends, Marxists, and each developed her talent in the shadow of a gifted man. Both died in their 40's. But beyond that, the painter Frida Kahlo and the photographer Tina Modotti don't seem to have a lot in common. Kahlo (1907-54) was a bourgeois rooted in Mexico, whose life was turned inward by physical disability; Modotti (1896-1942), of Italian working-class background, was a peripatetic militant, who turned from art to political activism. Their work was certainly dissimilar: Kahlo's intensely personal, permeated with fantasy and obsessive self-image; Modotti's concerned with formal values and down-to-earth people and objects.

title: 'TENDER MERCIES,' ROBERT DUVALL AS TEXAN
description: WHAT better proof can there be of the distinctiveness of Australian film-making than ''Tender Mercies,'' a film by Bruce Beresford that manages to be thoroughly Australian though it features Texas settings and an American cast? Mr. Beresford, the director of ''Breaker Morant,'' has brought a hauntingly spare look to this story, which is set on a prairie as endless and barren as Australia's. And the characters are as silent and unyielding as the landscape. Indeed, ''Tender Mercies'' has a bleak handsomeness bordering on the arty, but it also has real delicacy and emotional power, both largely attributable to a fine performance by Robert Duvall. Mr. Duvall's versatility seems to know no limit; in his role here as an over-the-hill country singer, he creates yet another quietly unforgettable character.

title: LA DIFFERENCE
description: When I met Grierson for lunch the other day at the Italian Pavilion, he was, as usual, in the throes of a cause. Earlier that morning, he had signed a petition recommending the admission of women to the Century Association, and he was impressed by the loveliness of his hero's pose on the ramparts of justice.

title: Friday; 17,000 GERMAN BOOKS HERE
description: The Frankfurt Book Fair is venturing out of its hometown in West Germany for the first time to offer a German Book Fair in New York. More than 500 publishers, mostly from West Germany, will be exhibiting some 17,000 titles today through Monday at the Sheraton Centre, Seventh Avenue and 52d Street. In addition, exhibits, readings and talks are scheduled at the hotel and at other sites. For instance, a panel discussion with Max Frisch, Gunter Grass, John Irving, Joyce Carol Oates and others on ''The Responsibility of the Writer in an Endangered World,'' moderated by Ted Solotaroff, is scheduled for Sunday at 7 P.M. at the New School for Social Research, 66 West 12th Street. It's all free. Information: 765-9124.

title: A Modest Deal in Steel
description: The top leaders of steel unions and companies are breathing easier now that local union presidents have ratified a new 41-month contract. The beleaguered companies gained significant concessions. The unions obtained a face-saving promise that saved monies would go to modernize facilities. Both sides avoided a strike in August that might have cost them billions in lost sales.

title: ROBERT C. STOLK
description: Robert C. Stolk, a former senior vice president of the American Can Company, died Monday at Princess Margaret Hospital in Toronto. He was 67 years old and since his retirement in 1979 had divided his time between homes in Southport, Conn., and Lake Simcoe, Ontario.

title: RANGERS ARE BEATEN 4-3

They had been hoping to overtake the Washington Capitals for third place in the division, but it was the Capitals who beat New York last night at Madison Square Garden, 4-3. Instead of cutting Washington's lead to 7 points, the Rangers let it grow to 11.

description: The United States Information Agency announced today that its director, Charles Wick, will visit Brazil this month. He will go to Brasilia, Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo between March 6 and 16.

title: Housing Still Needs Tax Help
description: New York City's J-51 program grants tax concessions to landlords who make rundown buildings habitable again. Its renewal is currently caught in Albany between friends who emphasize the housing it has produced and enemies who object to its costs. Governor Cuomo proposes a compromise that would reduce the cost - but by cutting the scope and potential of J-51 just when Federal and state housing programs are in the doldrums, and the demand for rental housing is rising.

Both galleries have moderate-price offerings, but the Christie's sale, next Wednesday at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M., is expected to bring higher prices.

title:
DEBATING THE DURABILITY OF RECOVERY;
Economic Analysis
description: The American economy, which has wallowed in a trough for four years, is finally starting to recover. Last summer, the Federal Reserve shifted to an easier monetary policy. Now, pretty much on schedule, consumer spending, especially for housing, is coming to life.

title: Detroit News Editor Resigns

Mr. Giles, 56 years old, has been succeeded by the executive editor, Lionel Linder, 51, said Jim Clark, a spokesman for the Evening News Association, the newspaper's parent company. BEST VIEWS OF THE NEW CITY OF LIGHTS
description: NEW YORK has never been a dark city, but never has it been so obsessed with light as now. The city has become brightly, intensely lit up - every month, it seems, a new skyscraper top goes ablaze with floodlights; every season a new facade takes on a nighttime presence. It is difficult to believe that it was not half a dozen years ago that the energy crisis was turning off public displays of light all over town, for now there is little thought of limits, little thought of restraint. We are at a moment when the more light we have, the more we seem to want.

ART: THROUGH THE AGES WITH SYMBOLIC BEASTS
description: NOT everyone thinks of the Pierpont Morgan Library as an institute for advanced study. title: G.&W. in Talks On Sale of Unit
description: Alexander N. Brainard, president of the Consolidated Cigar Company, is head of a group negotiating to buy the company from Gulf and Western Industries for about $120 million, G.& W. said yesterday. The MacAndrews & Forbes Group had agreed last summer to buy the company for about $105 million, but the deal collapsed.
