title: World Labor Agency Plans Polish Scrutiny
description: The International Labor Organization today gave Poland until April 15 to permit an on-the-scene study of its treatment of labor unionists.

title: DEVILS' PLAYOFF BID ENDED BY FLYERS
description: The Philadelphia Flyers ended the Devils bid for the National Hockey League playoffs here tonight with a 4-1 victory at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: A Soviet Dissident Implicates U.S. Agents
description: A Soviet dissident arrested 15 months ago has made a televised confession that his actions were wrong and charged that he was manipulated by United States intelligence agents.

title: Citicorp Selling Issue Of Floating Rate Notes
description: Citicorp, a pioneer in the issuing of floating rate securities, is selling a $750 million issue of floating rate notes through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. Strong demand for the issue, whose yield changes weekly, enabled underwriters to increase the size from $200 million.

title: Fearful Symmetry
description: A friend once said Arthur Koestler belonged to the ''unpardonably brilliant Hungarian emigration which has peopled the universities, the publishing houses, the laboratories and the authors' societies of the West.'' John Strachey added that Mr. Koestler was to Europe what Europe was to the world: small, intelligent, aggravating and indispensable.

title: The Cruel Sea
description: Billie Jean King had to endure an embarrassing and expensive lawsuit to maintain her right to her Malibu, Calif., beach house. But now, more than a year later, that which had been given to her by the law has been taken away by the sea.

title: Bright American and faded German
description: AMERICAN regional cooking, so long neglected in fashionable culinary circles, is at last getting the attention it deserves. The latest and one of the most engaging examples of such cooking can be found at Carolina, a six-week-old restaurant on Restaurant Row -46th Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. Even after so short a period, this restaurant, with its wood-burnished barbecued and grilled meats, grainy cornbread, custardy corn pudding, chili-fired souffles and sauces, and luxurious down-home desserts, is worth a visit for its own sake, even if you are not going to the theater.

title: AUSTRALIA'S PERSISTENT SLUMP
description: No matter who wins the national elections on Saturday, the severe recession that has gripped this resource-rich nation of 15 million people is unlikely to end soon, analysts say.

title: The U.N. Today; March 4, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Trade Law Commission, Working Group on International Contract Practices - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: SBE INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
Advertising; National Alumni Publishing
description: AN entrepreneurial thinker in Tucson and a New York national advertising representative have joined together to remove the burden and expense of alumni magazine publishing from some of the nation's universities. And at the same time, perhaps, make a bundle for themselves.

title: SALVADORANS, PRODDED BY THE U.S., SAID TO PLAN ELECTION IN DECEMBER
description: El Salvador's provisional Government has decided to hold presidential elections in December instead of next March, Salvadoran politicians reported today.

title: Taiwan Aluminum Plan
description: The state-owned Taiwan Aluminum Corporation said today that it was seeking financial or technical help from foreign companies to produce high-strength aluminium alloy plate.

title: ACAPULCO Y LOS ARCOS RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
BIG THREE AUTO SALES BARELY UP
description: The Big Three auto makers reported today that, on a daily selling rate basis, they sold about the same number of cars in the last 10 days of February 1983 as they did in the similar period of 1982.

title: 'Grandpa' Closing
description: ''Goodnight, Grandpa,'' Walter Landau's play starring Milton Berle and directed by Jay Broad at the Entermedia Theater, will close after the matinee Sunday. It will have had 14 previews and six performances.

title: Director of M.A.C.  Gets Securities Job
description: Heather L. Ruth, executive director of the Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York, is leaving to become executive director of the Public Securities Association on April 1.

title: DR. BENJAMIN FRIEDMAN
description: Dr. Benjamin Friedman, former professor and chairman of the department of ophthalmology at New York Medical College, died Saturday of a stroke at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old.

title: Banks to Alter Income Report
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday voted to eliminiate the dual approach that bank holding companies use to report earnings.

title: Deadline For NATO
description: The latest polls indicate that the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, will do well enough in this Sunday's elections to continue governing.

title: WILLIAM B. HARVAY
description: William B. Harvay, a New York manufacturer of jewelry glass, died of a heart attack Wednesday in Flushing Hospital.

title: White Divison
description: White Consolidated Industries announced that it had agreed to sell its Sarco division to Spirax-Sarco Engineering P.L.C, a British company, for about $29.9 million in cash. Sarco, which manufactures steam traps, temperature and pressure regulators, and strainers, had net income of about $5.8 million in 1982 on sales of $26.4 million. White is a Cleveland-based manufacturer of home appliances and machinery.

title: DANCE, MIME, CIRCUS FESTIVAL
description: MARTIN RUSSELL saw the restless 1960's die at an avant-garde arts institute in London, where he had set up an experimental theater. It was the end of an era, and the young English director-producer and his American wife, Jill, went over to Paris to study with Jacques LeCoq, who developed a style of acting with masks that many mimes and acting teachers use today.

title: ANTITRUST CASE LAWYERS ASSAILED AND FEES CUT
description: United States District Judge Joseph L. McGlynn yesterday slashed nearly $16 million off the $20.2 million in legal fees sought by the lawyers involved in a $50 million antitrust case against the paper industry.

title: Pact Gives Mattel Solid State Control
description: Solid State Scientific Inc. of Willow Grove, Pa., said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell 1.7 million common shares, or 51 percent of its common stock outstanding, to Mattel Inc. for $7 a share, or about $12 million. According to the agreement, Mattel will also obtain a five-year warrant to purchase an additional 300,000 common shares at $1 a share.

title: Racer Drowned After Car Crashed
description: An autopsy today showed that Olivier Chandon de Brailles, a French race car driver, drowned Wednesday after his car crashed through a barrier at Moroso Motorsports Park and sank in a canal, authorities said.

title: BOSTON MUSEUM CURATOR NAMED DIRECTOR OF GETTY
description: John Walsh Jr., curator of paintings at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, was appointed director of the Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., yesterday following an intensive search on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: A Corning Closing
description: Corning Glass Works said it would close its color television bulb manufacturing plant in Bluffton, Ind., by mid-May, idling about 460 workers. Corning cited overcapacity in the domestic color TV market and competition from foreign manufacturers. Workers at the plant had offered Corning a package of concessions to keep their jobs, but a company spokesman, Robert Edwards, said the concessions would not have mitigated the basic problem of low demand.

title: 'BRITANNIA HOSPITAL,' A SATIRE
description: INSIDE London's venerable old Britannia Hospital, the administrators, the medical staff and the service personnel are making frantic, last-minute preparations for that day's festive celebration of the hospital's 500th anniversary, which will be marked by a visit by Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother. There are, however, unexpected complications, some major, all rude.

title: An Appreciation
description: ''I won't talk politics,'' Arthur Koestler notified an interviewer in 1976 before the fellow had had a chance to pose a single question. ''I won't give any more political interviews. Because even if you write with the pen of an angel, it will appear as part of the old ding-dong battle I left long ago. I want to wipe off the label stuck to me by political partisans.''

title: CITIZENS' INPUT
description: To the Editor:

title: A Car Delivery Delayed for Now
description: Terry Leach is not going to send his car to New York from spring training this year as he has the last two seasons. He has spent too much money on transportation, and besides it's too bothersome.

title: ISLANDERS TRIUMPH ENDING 0-2-3 SLUMP
description: Their names have been stamped on three Stanley Cups, along with the other Islanders, but Bryan Trottier and Mike Bossy seem to stand out more.

title: Papp's play deal with British stirs happy ripple effect.
description: JOSEPH PAPP was marveling about ripple effects. ''Once you start something, you find yourself stimulating other things,'' he said. At least that's true if you are Joseph Papp. He arranged for a swap of plays with the Royal Court in London. Half the result was ''Top Girls,'' Caryl Churchill's play, which arrived at his Public Theater from London and did so well that an American cast took over last week when the British cast went home.

title: ROYAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Wife of Orval Faubus Found Dead in Houston
description: The estranged wife of former Gov. Orval Faubus of Arkansas was found dead today in the bathtub of her Houston house, the police said.

title: 6 GUATEMALANS DIE
description: The Government of Guatemala executed six people that it said were subversives at dawn today despite a request from the Vatican to grant them clemency.

title: CLEANUP DELAYED AT OHIO WASTE SITE WHERE CHEMICALS LEAK INTO GROUND
description: In a field near the Great Miami River here, unidentified chemicals ooze from hundreds of rusted barrels, forming oily patches in the earth as they seep into the ground. Some barrels leak powders or sludge and some give off offensive odors. Most are unlabeled, though the contents are believed toxic.

title: BLACK WITNESS TELLS OF ATTACK BY WHITE MOB
description: A 30-year-old black man yesterday described in court the terror he felt after having been smashed on the head with a bottle in what authorities say was a mob attack by white youths.

title: PIONEER INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Yr to Nov 27
description: B-After a loss of $264,000 on the equity in earnings of an unconsolidated company...C-Including a gain of $192,000 on the equity in earnings of an unconsolidated company

title: FARE-CARD PLAN DRAWS SUPPORT AND SKEPTICISM
description: The idea of eliminating subway and bus tokens in New York City in favor of magnetic cards - much like the ones used for bank cash machines - got a generally favorable response yesterday from business leaders and civic associations.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 40,000 Win Hearing Over Jobless Benefits
description: About 40,000 workers who have been denied unemployment benefits by the state over the past five years will be given a new chance to plead their cases.

title: Agency Criticized On Subway Tubing
description: A Manhattan Assemblyman charged yesterday that the Transit Authority was ''dragging its feet'' in the removal of polyvinyl chloride tubing from the subway system. The tubing emits toxic fumes when heated to high temperatures.

title: REAGAN BEING WARNED AGAINST BYPASSING CONGRESS ON SALVADOR AID
description: Congressional leaders of both parties plan to advise the White House against acting on its own in giving more aid to El Salvador and to ask Congress for the money.

title: VYQUEST INC reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
description: Results do not include extraordinary tax credits of $130,400 for the latest yr and $380,315 for the previous yr which have been credited to shrhldrs equity

title: TIGHTER CREDIT IN FARM BELT
description: Bankers across the troubled farm belt are tightening up on their agriculture loans, under the watchful eye of state banking officials.

title: Redskins Sign Riggins
description: John Riggins, the Washington Redskins running back, signed a long-term contract with the Super Bowl champions today, the team announced.

title: A Jumping Bengal
description: Dan Ross, an all-pro tight end for the Cincinnati Bengals, plans to jump to the United States Football League, but not right away. He told the Bengals that he would play out the last year of his contract this fall and then join the Boston Breakers next spring.

title: GETTING AUDIENCES TO LIKE NEW AMERICAN MUSIC
description: BUILDING a career on 20th-century American music is a chancy thing for both soloists and performing groups. Audiences distrust the stuff, echoing the attitude of a few musicians and numerous program boards. But composers continue to compose, performers continue to learn new works and somehow the music is heard.

title: I.M.F. GOLD SALE IDEA REJECTED
description: The Reagan Administration considered having the International Monetary Fund sell gold to raise money to lend to hard-pressed developing countries but decided against the idea after canvassing major trading partners, Beryl Sprinkel, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, said today.

title: Republic Air Plan
description: Republic Airlines said it would now require holders of free bonus tickets to present positive identification matching the name on the ticket before they are honored. The Minneapolis-based airline, which introduced a new frequent-flier promotion on Jan. 1, said it was taking the step to prevent its bonus tickets from falling into the hands of black marketeers. ''Our concern is that unsuspecting travelers will think they have bought a bargain, only to find out the airline will not accept what actually is a bogus transaction,'' a spokesman said.

title: ELECTIONS IN PARIS: OF CELERY STALKS AND SOCIALISM
description: The city votes twice on Sunday: first, and officially, on things like garbage collection, noise and free boat rides on the Seine for old people; then, figuratively at least, in a national canvass on almost two years of French Socialism.

title: Pole-Vaulter Dies
description: William (Tom) Sebastian, an 18-yearold senior on the Columbus East High School track team, died at Methodist Hospital in Indianapolis today from injuries received in a pole-vaulting accident.

title: PARK AVE. LUXURY IS ATTRACTING BUYERS
description: By almost any measure, 500 Park Avenue Tower, which is being developed by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States and the Tishman Speyer Development Corporation, is an exceptional project. The 11-story commercial section of the building will open for occupancy in the late summer; the 56 residential units above it will be ready next January, according to Tishman Speyer officials.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A 22-year-old off-duty probationary police officer, Anton Kozlowsky, fatally shot a man who attacked him with two knives at 2:30 A.M. at 198th Street and Briggs Avenue in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx, the police said. The assailant's identity and the motive for the attack were not known. ... A 16-year-old Brooklyn youth, Sherwood Young, was found at 8:30 A.M. in front of 71 Kenilworth Place in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn with a gunshot wound of the head. He was listed in critical condition at Kings County Hospital. ... The body of an unidentified man was found wrapped in a blanket and covered by a plastic bag in a vacant lot at 123-05 30th Avenue in College Point, Queens.

title: SIDEWALK ACUMENADE
description: To the Editor:

title: FACTORY ORDERS UP 2.4% MORE
description: The Commerce Department reported today that new orders to factories rose 2.4 percent in January after climbing 3.9 percent in December. January's results provided more evidence that the economy is recovering.

title: U.S. TASK SLIGHTLY UPHILL IN DAVIS CUP
description: The first round of the Davis Cup for the United States tennis team begins in this South American capital Friday, and the consensus on both sides is that the Argentines are slight favorites.

title: METRO NORTH ISSUES REMAIN
description: Negotiations between the Metro-North railroad and its conductors and trainmen failed yesterday to resolve their differences, and the talks were recessed until 3 P.M. Sunday.

title: THE N.B.A. MONEY GAME
description: Dr. Strangelove, it may remembered, had this unusual problem with his right arm. It had a tendency to jerk up, and he controlled it only by wrestling it down with his left hand.

title: ITALY IS SAID TO INVESTIGATE 8 IN A 1981 PLOT TO KILL WALESA IN ROME
description: Eight people, four of them Bulgarians, have reportedly been informed officially that they are under investigation for possible links to a purported plot to kill Lech Walesa, the Polish labor leader, during his trip to Rome in January 1981.

title: CUT DEFENSE OUTLAYS
description: The following statement was prepared by McGeorge Bundy, Robert S. McNamara, Cyrus R. Vance and Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE SKATING PARTY. By Marina Warner. 180 pages. Atheneum. $10.95.

title: Group Won Big Payoff
description: The largest parimutuel payoff in American history, which occurred Tuesday night at the Palm Beach (Fla.) Jai-Alai Fronton, was won by a group of bettors who had wagered more than half the $988,326.20 they received, a spokesman for the fronton said yesterday.

title: Big East Finish
description: The experts didn't expect Boston College to be near the top at the end of the Big East Conference's basketball race, but the Eagles are there, adding to the muddling of the picture.

title: RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Wednesday about the Indian Point nuclear power plants misattributed a quotation. It was Edward C. Wallace, Councilman at Large for Manhattan, who said, ''Until the likelihood of an accident is zero, which I believe will never be, we ask the board to consider the consequences, which are beyond calculation, and certainly beyond compensation.''

title: Sharing Prizes
description: The Brooklyn Half-Marathon on March 13 will be unusual in that the first 10 male and 10 female finishers from the metropolitan area will share in cash prizes totaling $10,000. As a Minnesotan, Dick Beardsley, the nation's fastest marathoner except for Alberto Salazar, will not be eligible for the money, which will be put in trust for the amateur athletes by The Athletics Congress.

title: Required Reading; El Salvador and Vietnam
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, in remarks to reporters before the Senate convened on March 2, 1983: ''El Salvador is not Vietnam. The situations are entirely different.

title: Rolls-Royce to Cut Another 6,000 Jobs
description: Rolls-Royce Ltd. plans to cut 6,000 additional jobs over the next 12 months as part of a program that has already reduced staff by nearly 25 percent over the last two years, Lord McFadzean, chairman and chief executive, said.

title: NETS THRIVE ON ASSISTS IN RUNAWAY
description: With the pick-and-roll and the give-and-go, the assist, a valuable but often overlooked basketball staple, has made a quiet comeback in the National Basketball Association. By the end of February, 34,313 assists had been recorded, compared with 32,286 by March 1, 1982. Eighteen of the N.B.A.'s 23 teams have increased their assist output over last season.

title: PICKETS ASSAIL CUTS IN ARTS
description: Joseph Papp, Beverly Sills, Douglas Dillon and other leaders of the New York arts world gathered with signs on the sidewalk in front of Lincoln Center's Plaza yesterday at noon to protest Governor Cuomo's proposed cut of $4.5 million in aid to the arts.

title: STORMS IN CALIFORNIA EXPECTED TO RAISE U.S. GROCERY PRICES
description: The storms that have ravaged much of California in recent weeks will force up the price of many kinds of fresh vegetables and fruits around the nation for weeks to come, agricultural officials said today.

title: Prison in the Present, A Paralegal Job in the Future
description: Nine felons at the state's Bayview Correctional Facility on West 20th Street, appearing in flowing white graduation gowns and mortarboards with red tassels, had good reason to smile yesterday. They had completed a course in criminal law, legal research and law library management.

title: INCREASE DISGUISED AS A WITHHOLDING
description: To the Editor:

title: Marine Midland Sells Preferred
description: The latest issue of adjustable rate preferred stock - a $100 million offering by Marine Midland Banks Inc. -sold out quickly though underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb.

title: Saxon Unit Sale
description: Saxon Industries said it had agreed to sell its Missisquoi division to the Boise Cascade Corporation for an undisclosed price.

title: Bonn's Jobless Level Is Highest Since War
description: Unemployment in West Germany increased in February to 2,535,836 people, or 10.4 percent of the labor force, the Government said today.

title: STEWART LEADS BY A SHOT ON 65
description: The $400,000 Honda Inverrary Classic, beginning its final appearance at its old stand, got ideal weather for golf today and saw Payne Stewart take the first-round lead.

title: MOYNIHAN'S VIEWS OF PARADE STIR IRE OF THE IRISH
description: Her last name might not be Irish, Mary B. Soderlund granted as she sat in the quiet sun of Henry A. Whelan Park on Perry Avenue in the northern Bronx, but that was only through circumstances of marriage. In truth, she said, everything about her is Irish, starting with her maiden name of Doran. But these days, she said, she has little patience for the state's highest elected officeholder of Irish descent, United States Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

title: FIRE DEPT. FRICTION ON WOMEN GOES TO COURT
description: The friction between the men and women in New York City's Fire Department since the women were admitted to the department last September has broken into the open.

title: COMDIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss; results for the latest periods include operations of Stromberg-Carlson Telephone Systems Center and American Telecommunications acquired from General Dynamics in Oct 1982

title: 6 CONVICTED OF PARTICIPATING IN QUAALUDE CLINIC SCHEME
description: Six defendants were convicted yesterday of operating sham clinics that distributed millions of dollars of prescriptions for methaqualone, commonly known by the trade name Quaaludes.

title: Air Canada Plea Denied
description: A Federal court today rejected Air Canada's plea to block a Civil Aeronautics Board order depriving about 100,000 passengers of cut-rate airline fares between Canada and the United States.

title: NATIONAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Carlton's Choice
description: Steve Carlton of the Philadelphia Phillies may be getting his wish of becoming the highest-paid pitcher in baseball, but he is going to have to take a pay cut later to do it. Carlton had been all set to sign a four-year, $4.15-million pact that would have increased his salary to $1.15 million starting in 1984 when an arbitrator awarded Fernando Valenzuela of the Los Angeles Dodgers a $1 million salary for 1983.

title: Campaneris, at 40, Tries to Be a Yankee
description: Only five players who were members of the Oakland A's teams that won three consecutive World Series in the 1970's remain in the major leagues. Bert Campaneris is ready to make that six.

title: Value Line Options
description: Options on Value Line stock index futures will begin trading on the Chicago Board of Trade on Friday, under an agreement between the board and the Kansas City Board of Trade.

title: ACMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Boston Fed Hampered
description: A power failure in Boston curtailed some operations of the Federal Reserve Bank here today, but the Boston Stock Exchange remained open. The blackout began Wednesday after an explosion in a utility manhole.

title: PIEDMONT MANAGEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Operating earnings...C-Including extraordinary credits of $463,444 for the qrand $1,354,172 for the yr

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration is in a mood of crisis over El Salvador. Salvadoran officials share Washington's concern about how the war against the guerrillas is going, but not the sense of urgency, which seems to have grown out of the Administration's way of reacting to a crisis some officials saw coming months ago. The military situation in El Salvador deteriorated in the guerrilla offensive of January and February, which provoked few public expressions of concern by the Administration at the time. However, a recent nine-day trip to the region by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations, at President Reagan's request led to what officials said was anxiety in the White House.

title: PIONEER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27

title: ALEXANDER GODUNOV IN 'WORLD TO DANCE IN'
description: THE dancer as artist or sex symbol - you can have your choice in ''Godunov: The World to Dance In,'' a curious bit of promotion from Channel 13 tonight at 10:30. The subject is Alexander Godunov, the Russian dancer who defected to this country in 1979. His career has since been, at best, erratic, but this Peter Rosen film, produced for Metromedia, is determined to give him superstar status.

title: New Construction Off
description: Contracting for new United States construction in January slipped by 3 percent from the strong rate reached in December when the Dodge index of construction activity climbed to a three-year high of 131, the F.W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company said yesterday. The $11.4 billion of newly started construction in January brought the seasonally adjusted Dodge index to 127, up substantially from November's 122. A decline in public works contracts accounted for the slide from December.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REMARKS BY THE NICARAGUAN LEADER
description: Following are excerpts from the speech of Daniel Ortega Saavedra, leader of Nicaragua's junta, welcoming Pope John Paul II today, as translated by The Associated Press from the official Spanish version:

title: TV: LABOR UNION PROBLEMS IN THE SUNBELT
description: ''Labor in the Promised Land,'' the newest of the ''NBC Reports,'' is really two programs, even as it tries to be one. In general, ''NBC Reports'' is examining labor's problems in the Sunbelt, but the first half of the program looks at carpenters in Houston who earn $16.25 an hour, while the second half looks at semiskilled workers in Freeport, Tex., who earn a good deal less. The first half is informative; the second is inspirational. The program, or programs, will be seen on Channel 4 at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: STRATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Military Analysis
description: El Salvador needs better battle leadership, personal motivation and field training as much as it needs ammunition, helicopters and guns, according to American and Salvadoran officials here.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Embattled Priest Serves On 'Restaurant Row'

title: Sofia Denies Involvement In Attempt Against Pope
description: Bulgarian authorities have written to the magistrate investigating the assassination attempt against Pope John Paul II, denying any Bulgarian involvement, the Bulgarian press agency said today.

title: 5 HONORED AS EXEMPLARS OF ROSSEVELT'S IDEALS
description: Five distinguished Americans were honored here today, the 50th anniversary of Franklin D. Roosevelt's first inauguration, for maintaining the spirit and ideals of the Four Freedoms he said were essential to democracy.

title: Massey to Issue Shares to Canada
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. said it will issue 5 million common shares to the federal Government of Canada and 3 million common shares to the Government of the Province of Ontario instead of cash dividends. The shares represent $60 million (Canadian) in unpaid and future cash dividends owed on $200 million (Canadian) worth of preferred shares that the two governments acquired in a 1981 refinancing.

title: STOCKMAN CALLS REVENUE SHARING BEST WAY TO AID POOR AND JOBLESS
description: David A. Stockman, the budget director, suggested today that Congress could more effectively provide assistance to poor, homeless and unemployed people through general revenue sharing than through new job and public works programs.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: M*A*S*H Notes for Mozart

title: ANGLOPHILES AND OTHERS SAVOR MEAL WITH QUEEN
description: George D. Hart was among the 270 guests invited to dine with Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip at the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco Thursday night, but he could not make it. He was in the hospital undergoing heart bypass surgery.

title: Susanna D'Alton Wed to Physicist
description: Susanna D'Alton, coordinator of exhibitions at the American Federation of Arts in New York, was married yesterday to Douglas Marshall Alde, a research associate in nuclear physics at Columbia University. Msgr. Harry J. Byrne, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Epiphany, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.

title: Your Money; Auto Accident Compensation
description: WITH at least 165 million vehicles on the highways today and some 50,000 accidents every day, according to the National Safety Council, an individual's chances of having an auto accident at some time or other seem strong.

title: TWO GOVERNORS SAID TO FAVOR HIGHER TOLLS AND PATH FARE
description: Governor Kean and Governor Cuomo are near an agreement to increase Hudson River tolls and PATH fares, officials familiar with their discussions said yesterday.

title: ALLEGHENY BEVERAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income of $211,000 from equity in net earnings of Macke Co

title: LINK SOUGHT IN KILLINGS OF 3 WOMEN IN HOUSTON
description: Houston homicide detectives said today that striking similarities in the slayings of three women, including the estranged wife of Orval E. Faubus, the former Governor of Arkansas, suggested that the killings might be related.

title: A Correction on E.P.A.
description: An editorial last Saturday said incorrectly that John Todhunter, assistant administrator for pesticides and toxic substances at the Environmental Protection Agency, was once a consultant to the Formaldehyde Institute. We apologize for suggesting that his participating in a decision concerning formaldehyde raised a conflict of interest.

title: U.S. MAY INCREASE SALVADOR ADVISERS
description: President Reagan, warning that other nations in the hemisphere ''would follow'' if El Salvador falls to leftist rebels, said today that he might increase the number of American military advisers in El Salvador, but would not use them in combat.

title: Class in Cello Literature
description: The cellist Heinrich Joachim will present a master class in the interpretation of the cello literature of the Neo-Romantic and modern periods Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Westchester Conservatory of Music, 20 Soundview Avenue in White Plains.

title: Bechtel Oil Contract

Dale Murray, Rudy May and George Frazier may also pitch. The Orioles will look at Jim Palmer, Storm Davis and Tim Stoddard. (Radio - WABC, 770, 1:15 P.M.).

description: The United States announced today a tentative agreement in its dispute with Canada about the sale of deeply discounted airline tickets, apparently ending weekend travel uncertainty for thousands of ticket-holders.

description: Leamon Hall, the former Army quarterback who was cut by the Arizona Wranglers after an 11-day trial, has been acquired by the New Jersey Generals for their 10-man development squad. The Generals re-signed Dave Jacobs, to be their place-kicker and punt. He had been signed earlier, then cut. . ... If the reports coming out of Washington are close to the mark, John Riggins may have passed up a lot of money to stay with the Redskins rather than jump to the U.S.F.L. The reports say that the four-year pact Riggins signed with the Redskins is worth more than $2 million - a lot of money, to be sure, but less than the $2.5 million that the Michigan Panthers had reportedly offered him for three years. ... Steve Garvey, the San Diego Padres' first baseman, citing irreconcilable differences, has petitioned for divorce from his wife, Cyndy.

description: Iona and Fordham will meet Saturday for the championship of the Metro Atlantic Conference after scoring victories tonight before a crowd of 6,323 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Anne Harrison Wed to Timothy Forbes
description: Anne Shepard Harrison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Southworth Harrison of Deer Isle, Me., formerly of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Timothy Carter Forbes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Stevenson Forbes of Far Hills, N.J., and New York. Civil Court Judge Bernard Fuchs performed the ceremony at the Forbes family's town house in Manhattan.

title: PORT AUTHORITY FORECASTS A LAG IN THE RECOVERY

description: President Reagan today expressed continuing confidence in Anne McGill Burford, the Environmental Protection Administrator, despite allegations of wrongdoing at her agency and criticism of the White House by Mrs. Burford.

title: A COURT APPROVES CITY'S RIGHT TO TAX NONPROFIT GROUP
description: An appellate court has unanimously approved the Koch administration's effort to tax a nonprofit Manhattan institution. The head of New York City's Law Department said the decision could mean that most museums and possibly foundations in the city could lose their property-tax exemptions.

title: TREASURY ISSUES FALL IN PRICE
description: Prices of United States Government securities drifted lower in quiet trading yesterday and yields rose as investors withdrew from the credit markets, taking a wait-and-see attitude about how low oil prices would fall before committing funds.

description: The Republicans and Democrats on the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, in their annual report released today, generally agreed on the need to reduce proposed military spending and to contain the growth of entitlement programs such as Social Security.

description: In the aftermath of surging trading volume and wide price drops in gold, silver and copper, the Commodity Exchange has faced confusion in its clearing operations, with about 50 percent more than the usual number of unmatched trades.

title: JERSEY CASINOS FAWN ON MOB, INQUIRY IS TOLD
description: Four days of hearings on the credit practices of Atlantic City casinos have unveiled a portrait of fawning submission to organized-crime figures who are lavished almost daily with free rooms, food, travel, entertainment and even chips that have been cashed in to finance mob activities ranging from loan-sharking to narcotics.

title: British Car Sales Rise
description: British car sales for the first two months of 1983 rose 29.7 percent from a year earlier, to 308,202, the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders said today.

title: Las Vegas Offers $55,000 For Planter of Bombs
description: The authorities offered a $55,000 reward today in a public appeal for leads on the bomber who has planted four dynamite devices here this week.

title: FALL IN HOME OIL PRICES SPURS COMPETITION
description: Prices for home heating oil are beginning to fall in the metropolitan area, forcing suppliers into fierce competition and making the steady customer a highly valued commodity.

description: For an indication how far the troubles o f the world darm economy reach nowadays, come to Bone Valley, t he center of Florida's $3.5 billion phosphate industry.

title: HER MAJESTY ENCOUNTERS SACRAMENTO'S OLD WEST
description: Queen Elizabeth II visited Sacramento, California's capital today, lunching with the Governor and taking a keen interest in the legislators, then returned to San Francisco to entertain the President and his wife, Nancy, on their anniversary.

In the preceding three-month period the New York Fed used more than $100 million to settle what it saw as disorderly market conditions.

In the second tirade, the speaker said the pitcher was being sent for a physical examination because ''I'm afraid some of my players might get hurt playing behind him.''

title: CANDLELIGHT AND FLOWERS CAN BE OBSTACLE COURSES
description: Candlelight and flowers can be beautiful as table decorations, but if improperly used they can be more of a nuisance than an enhancement. And both are often improperly used these days, in restaurants as well as homes.

The designers say the group of satellites could be used instead of a large space platform that has been proposed as a center for communications.

title: Killer's Conviction Is Upset

Hews was sentenced to life in prison nearly 13 years ago after he admitted the shotgun slaying of a Chicago man in a Seattle robbery attempt. He pleaded guilty to second-degree murder, which implies that he intended to kill the victim, but he insisted that he did not intend to kill the victim.

description: Chester H. Ferguson, chairman of the board of the billion-dollar Lykes Brothers conglomerate and former chairman of the Florida Board of Regents, died Thursday. He was 74 years old and had been in a coma since apparently suffering a heart attack on Feb. 8.

The weekly Cabinet meeting approved applications from Credit Commercial de France, the First Interstate Bancorp's First Interstate Bank of California, the Sumitomo Bank of Tokyo and Banca Commerciale Italiana, they said.

description: New York State's unemployment rate for February remained unchanged from January's 8.8 percent, while unemployment dipped slightly in New York City and showed a minor rise in New Jersey, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Tough Stance on Drugs
description: The United States Football League announced a program designed to identify players with drug problems, to help those who want to overcome their dependency and to get rid of those who don't. ''We are trying to identify these people so we can intervene,'' said Ted Diethrich, a heart surgeon and co-owner of the Chicago Blitz, who added that a special screening had identified one player on his team with a drug problem. ''We are checking him twice a week,'' he said, noting that the standard league contract provides for complete physical examinations at any time. Dr. Diethrich, who helped set up the program, said that players who sought help would receive comprehensive treatment, while those discovered to be involved with drugs who had not sought help would lose their contracts.

title: EARLIER SCHOOLING
description: ON-HUDSON, N.Y. - The proposal by Gordon M. Ambach, the New York State Education Commissioner that children start school at 4 and end high school after the 11th grade is inspired. The danger in advocating reorganization of the educational pattern is that structural reforms can obscure the crying need for improvement in the substance of what is taught, at the beginning and end of schooling. We are in a crisis of education in language, general knowledge, science and mathematics of enormous proportions and devastating social and political consequences. Even though it will require more than shifting the ages of schooling, that may be the place to start.

title: IN SEARCH OF THE VANISHING COATTAIL
description: In a reversal of the normal balance of trade in political technology, Washington politicians are covetously looking north of the border at the work of a young Canadian consultant to see if it can be imported to the United States to help them solve the case of the vanishing political coattail.

title: COASTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss after an extraordinary charge of $76 million

title: Money Funds Decline
description: Assets of the nation's 304 money market mutual funds dropped $1.7 billion during the week ended Wednesday, to $189.5 billion, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: HENRY BOTKIN DIES; ABSTRACT PAINTER
description: Henry Botkin, an abstract painter known for his collage-paintings, his promotion of abstract art and his artistic influence on his cousin, the composer George Gershwin, died yesterday in New York City of heart disease. He was 86 years old.

title: News Analysis
description: N.J. Transit's demands for wage cuts and changes in work rules and Metro-North's demands for reductions in crew sizes are part of a broad effort in American business to reduce labor costs by seeking wage and benefit concessions and by altering manning provisions and other work rules.

title: U.S. LOSES IN OPENER OF DAVIS CUP
description: On a day in which John McEnroe was shut out in a Davis Cup set for the first time, Argentina moved into a strong position today to sweep the first two singles matches against the United States in the opening round of the 1983 cup series.

title: TANO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Manhattan Girl, 13, Runs With a Goal
description: In Nigeria, the country in which her parents first met, her name -Shola - means ''one who brings honor.'' If her achievements up to this early point in her life are a true indicator, Shola Lynch will indeed live up to the lofty ideal that has been bestowed on her.

title: HOUSTON NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
A Reprieve for Silas
description: Paul Silas, the beleaguered coach of the last-place San Diego Clippers, got a vote of confidence of sorts when General Manager Paul Phipps denied that he had already made a decision not to rehire him when his three-year contract expires at the end of the season. ''He has the whole year,'' said Phipps, who reaffirmed his intention of evaluating the coach's performance when the season closes.

title: Injured Rangers Are Improving
description: The two Rangers injured in Thursday night's 4-3 loss to Washington got improved medical reports yesterday. Rob Ftorek, who suffered a sight concussion when his head hit the ice, is expected to practice today and to be able to play tomorrow.

title: SENATE PANELS HEARS OF MOB LINK TO CHICAGO KILLING
description: The chief agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation here said today that he believed the slaying of Allen M. Dorfman, a millionaire insurance executive with ties to the teamsters' union, had been ordered by top leaders of organized crime.

title: Washington Opera Gets $150,000 Corporate Gift
description: The American Express Company has announced that it will give $150,000 to the Washington Opera for its joint production, with the Orchestre de Paris, of Mozart's ''Cosi Fan Tutte''

title: CELTICS TOPPLE 76ers, HALTING STREAK AT 10
description: The Boston Celtics ended the Philadelphia 76ers' 10-game winning streak tonight with a 115-110 victory at the Boston Garden. Larry Bird, with 32 points, and Kevin McHale, with 21, led the Celtics as the 76ers lost for only the fourth time in 29 road games this season.

title: CHARGES DISMISSED IN CASE OF EX-TRANSIT OFFICIAL
description: A Brooklyn judge yesterday dismissed charges that a former top official of the New York City Transit Authority had violated state and city laws by receiving $900 worth of lunches and dinners over seven years from companies that did business with the agency.

title: Defendant Guilty in Bombing
description: The final defendant in the August 1980 extortion bombing of Harvey's Hotel-Casino at Lake Tahoe has been found guilty of three Federal charges. Ella Joan Williams, a friend of John Birges Sr., mastermind of the plot to extort $3 million from the resort, was convicted Thursday of attempted extortion, conspiracy and interstate travel in aid of extortion. Mr. Birges was sentenced to 40 years in prison last year after his conviction, while two co-defendants were sentenced to seven years each.

title: PRESIDENT OF BEI IS FOUND GUILTY
description: The president of a used computer sales and computer scrap business and the company itself were found guilty today of conspiring to steal computer equipment from the Nixdorf Computer Company.

title: Arrows Game Set
description: The Arrows announced yesterday that their game against Golden Bay that was postponed by a snowstorm Feb. 11 had been rescheduled for 8 P.M. March 23 at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Seaver's 2 Innings: One Hit but No Pain
description: For the first time in nearly six years, Tom Seaver pitched for the Mets today, coasting two innings in a training-camp game with these results: 15 pitches, one hit, no runs, no pain.

title: KMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $17,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary taxcredit of $222,000...C-Net loss after a loss of $2,430,000 from discontinued operations

title: Mine Union Chiefs Sue Over Campaign Tactics
description: Top officers of the United Mine Workers have filed a $6 million lawsuit accusing another union official and others of conducting a smear campaign in last year's election.

title: An Eagle's Day in Court
description: Leroy Harris knew he was in court, he knew he was under oath, and he knew his estranged wife's lawyer was trying to establish that he had had enough money left over from a $60,000 year-end bonus from the Philadelphia Eagles to catch up on his support payments. But what the Eagles' fullback didn't know on Thursday was that there was a newspaper reporter in the courtroom in Camden, N.J. And when he was asked what he had done with the last $25,000 or so of the bonus, Harris replied, ''I'm a junkie,'' and then specified, ''cocaine.''

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: LEON SPINKS FIGHTS TO PAY THE BILLS
description: Leon Spinks makes his 1983 debut Sunday and, since the opponent is a boxer, he has a chance of winning. Last year, he boxed twice, won twice, but did not do so well in two other major bouts: one with his former wife in divorce court, the other with the Internal Revenue Service over back taxes.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Unfashionable Poverty

title: Big-League Gamble
description: When Roone Arledge persuaded his ABC colleagues to commit time and money to win exclusive rights to the 1972 Olympic Games and then televise them in prime time, bosses at rival networks shook their heads. Amateur sports, especially such relatively obscure ones as gymnastics, swimming and, of course, speed skating, would never lure the hard-core prime-time viewer, let alone fickle sponsors.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Reinsurance Co., a subsidiary of Aetna Life and Casualty Co., said its wholly owned subsidiary, American Excess Insurance Co., would no longer write or renew direct excess and surplus lines casualty business.

title: MOSCOW STILL HOPES FOR UPSET IN BONN
description: The Soviet Union has maintained its attacks against Chancellor Helmut Kohl and his Christian Democratic Party right to the eve of the voting in West Germany.

title: Radioactive Water Spilled
description: A cleanup crew today was pumping out about 25,000 gallons of radioactive water that spilled at the Philadelphia Electric Company's Peach Bottom Unit 3 nuclear plant. The spill occurred Thursday when a false signal activated cooling water pumps at the facility, flooding the open reactor vessel while it was being refueled, refueling, officials said. The cleanup is expected to last several more days.

title: Flyers' Wilson Given Suspension
description: Behn Wilson, the Philadelphia Flyers' defenseman, was suspended today for six games as a result of a stick-swinging incident during a National Hockey League game Feb. 19. The ban takes effect March 11.

title: STORER COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to dec 31
description: B-Including a net gain of $1.3 mill for the qr and yr from the sale of the co'sformer corp headqtrs bldg and a net gain of $3.2 mil for the yr on the sale of the co's Chicago radio station;C-Including a net gain of $1.7 mil for the qr andyr from the sale of an investment in a cable construction subsidiary

title: BRIEFING
description: Mending Party Fences

title: POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Quake Jolts 2 Prairie States
description: An earthquake measuring 4.4 on the Richter scale rattled a 6,000-square-mile area of South Dakota and Nebraska today, cracking building foundations and breaking dishes.

title: KOHL CONFIDENT AS CAMPAIGN NEARS END
description: West Germany's election campaign neared an end today with Chancellor Helmut Kohl expressing optimism about the outcome of Sunday's voting and his Social Democratic challenger, Hans-Jochen Vogel, on the defensive.

title: CHIEF OF E.P.A. ASSERTS ITS FILES CAN BE OPENED
description: Anne McGill Burford, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, told aides today that she believed she could now legally open her agency's files to Congressional investigative committees and ignore a complex arrangement for disclosure worked out by the Justice Department.

title: LATE RISE PUTS DOW AT 1,140.96
description: A late upswing spurred by a static unemployment figure enabled the stock market to end slightly higher yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average advancing 2.90 points, to 1,140.96, its fourth consecutive closing high.

title: Fifth Suspect Sought In $11 Million Theft
description: A Queens man on parole in a Federal drug case was named yesterday as a fifth suspect in the theft of $11 million from the Sentry Armored Car Courier Company in the Bronx.

title: STERNER LIGHTING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After tax credits of $113,000 for the qr and $392,000 for the yr; the 1981 qrand yr shr earnings reflect 5-for-4 stock split in Dec 1982; the 1981 operatingresults have been restated to reflect the 1982 acquisition of Pam Systems Inc accounted for as a pooling of interests

title: Seahawks Target of Suit
description: The American Civil Liberties Union filed suit in Federal Court in Seattle, seeking to block a high school assembly featuring members of the Seattle Seahawks discussing their religious beliefs. The A.C.L.U. maintains that such an assembly would violate the constitutional separation of church and state.

title: Floods in China Kill 27
description: Floods caused by heavy rains have killed at least 27 people and damaged more than 900 houses in Guangdong Province, in south China, China Daily reported today. The newspaper said the Northern River rose 5.6 feet above flood level 47 miles north of Canton before the rains stopped, and the Western River rose 8.8 feet 50 miles west of Canton in 24 hours.

title: Two Brothers Sentenced In Doctor's Abduction
description: Two brothers were sentenced to long terms in prison today for their parts in the abduction of an abortion clinic operator and his wife.

title:
PATENTS;
A Talking Copier To Ease Operation
description: A talking copier has been invented for the Xerox Corporation. Kenneth K. Park, a former member of the company's staff in Rochester, obtained patent 4,375,329 this week on the improved machine.

title: FORGETTING THE CHILDREN
description: Choosing a Chancellor for New York City's public schools should be serious business. There may be no more important responsibility, short of the Mayor's, in the city. Yet every sign suggests that the process may be more petty, faction-ridden and lacking in vision than it has been in the past.

title: JOHN HUSTON HONORED BY FILM WORLD
description: The tone of the American Film Institute's Life Achievement Award dinner each year is foreshadowed in its opening minutes, when a man or woman whose films ''have stood the test of time'' walks past the 1,100 stars, directors, and studio presidents who form his honor court.

title: THE CORE OF HIGHER EDUCATION IN NEW YORK STATE
description: To the Editor:

title: WELLS-GARDNER ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $1,208,000

title: Robert J. Trainor Dies; A State Justice 9 Years
description: Robert J. Trainor, a former Assemblyman, Westchester County District Attorney and New York State Supreme Court Justice, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. He was 81 years old and a resident of Eastchester, N.Y.

title: DRUG WITHDRAWN AFTER FIVE DEATHS
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that it was considering new labeling requirements for Zomax, a prescription painkiller that has been associated with five allergyrelated deaths. The manufacturer has withdrawn the drug from sale pending the new labels.

title: VIOLIN RECITAL: MISS CHUNG
description: Kyung Wha Chung's concert of violin music at Carnegie Hall Thursday night blended serious musicianship with total technical control. There was no real virtuosity for its own sake until the very end.

title: American Hoist Seeks Work Cuts
description: The American Hoist and Derrick Company, trying to shave costs, has offered its 2,000 salaried employees a choice of two unpaid days off a month, fewer working hours or temporary leaves of absence.

title: Full Course on Ice
description: A follow-up: Julian Kaplan, Michael Eisenberg, Joel Bierenbaum and Steven Lefland accomplished their feat Thursday night. Driving from the Meadowlands to Madison Square Garden to Nassau Coliseum, they managed to see one period of each of the three National Hockey League games played in the New York metropolitan area that night. It was the first time the Devils, the Rangers and the Islanders all had home games scheduled for the same night, and so the peripatetic quartet claimed a record.

title: WYLY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $11.9 million...C-Net income after income from discontinued operations of $1.4 million and a tax credit of $3.7 million; the 1981 results were restated to reflect the discontinuance of the company's computer equipment brokering business

title: APPLIED DATA RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $238,000 for the qr and yr; yr-ago resultsinclude a nonrecurring gain equal to 31 cents a shr from the sale of a product line

title: HEALTHDYNE GAINS WITH CRIB MONITOR
description: A baffling infant disorder and an electronic solution have brought profits and prominence to Healthdyne Inc., a 13-year-old medical equipment company based here.

title: Autopsies on the Koestlers Are Labeled 'Inconclusive'
description: Autopsies on the bodies of Arthur Koestler and his wife, Cynthia, found dead at their London home Thursday in an apparent double suicide, were ''inconclusive,'' the police said today.

title: Cameron Layoffs
description: Cameron Iron Works Inc. said it would lay off 250 hourly and 325 salaried workers on March 11, bringing total layoffs in the past 10 months to about 3,500 people, or 45 percent of its domestic work force.

title: OCEANEERING INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN AIRLINES GETS LABOR PACT CONCESSIONS
description: Members of the Transport Workers Union ratified a three-year contract with American Airlines yesterday that calls for concessions in work rules and wage rates for new workers in return for wage increases and greater job security for current workers.

title: NATIONWIDE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UNITRODE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: ARTIFICIAL HEART RECIPIENT SUFFERS PNEUMONIA
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark, the artificial heart recipient, has developed a new complication, aspiration pneumonia, and has been put back on a respirator, his doctors reported yesterday.

title: EX-AGENT NOT GUILTY IN PLOT TO KILL FOE OF QADDAFI
description: A Federal District Court jury tonight acquitted Edwin P. Wilson, the former Central Intelligence Agency operative, of plotting the assassination of an opponent of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.

title: CITY IN PERFORMING ARTS: NO.1 WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: Jim Self, a young dancer and choreographer, moved to New York several years ago even though he enjoyed the work he was doing in Chicago. ''In dance, New York is the place where you have to go to prove yourself,'' he explained.

title: STEINBERG INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Jan 15
description: Yr-ago results have been restated; the company is listed on the Montreal and Toronto stock exchanges

title: Flight Attendants Settle, Averting T.W.A. Strike
description: Trans World Airlines and the union representing its flight attendants reached a tentative agreement on a new contract early today.

title: Now Scouting for Orioles, Earl Weaver
description: When the Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles began their spring exhibition schedule today, Earl Weaver was sitting in Section 2, Box 4E, Seat 3. Joe Altobelli was sitting in the seat in the dugout that Weaver had occupied for the previous 14 springs.

title: CASH FOR COUNTING
description: The Census to Save New York is a project of the New York Landmarks Preservation Commission in which every structure on the 850,000 building lots in the city is being inventoried. So far, it has been proceeding slowly, with only about 54,000 parcels inventoried in areas such as Manhattan south of 23d Street and west of the Bowery.

title: Miss Gleicher Engaged To Stephen Eisenberg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rubin Gleicher of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Arlene Gleicher, to Stephen Eisenberg, son of Ruth Eisenberg of Yonkers and Arthur Eisenberg of Chicago. The wedding is to be on May 1.

title: GRANDPARENTING
description: It's nice being a grandchild. You're sitting on the floor being screamed at by Mommy for shaving the Oriental rug with Daddy's razor, and the phone rings, and it's Granddaddy saying, ''Bring the kid over here so I can love him up.''

title: MARSH AND MANSION
description: Constitution Marsh, a 270-acre Audubon sanctuary bordering on the front lawn of the Boscobel mansion in Garrison, N.Y., will be the subject of a color slide lecture to be presented at 2 P.M. each Sunday of this month in the meeting room of the mansion.

title: Concert by Newband
description: Newband, a 20th-century-music ensemble, will present a concert tonight at 9 o'clock at Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street, in TriBeCa.

title: RED TAPE DELAYS ADOPTION
description: MANY potentially adoptable children are caught in the state's Division of Youth and Family Services system because of barriers within the agency, the courts and legal processes needed to free them for adoption, according to a recent report by the Association for Children of New Jersey, a child-advocacy group based in Newark.

title: GETTING YOUR SUGAR-FREE LUMPS
description: IAM a reformed sugarholic. I am sugar-cured, sugar-free, a bornagain health advocate, you might say. And, like other recent converts, when I was first fired up with the message, I should have been temporarily locked in a closet until I cooled down.
