title: A WAY TO KEEP THE GOVERNMENT HONEST
description: THERE are certain things that everyone is in favor of as a matter of principle, but that somehow never seem to win out when real decisions are made and votes are counted. Balancing the budget is one example; getting rid of pork-barrel projects in the Federal budget is another. At times we make some progress to support these goals, but the fact remains that real, signifiant, lasting political reforms are rare indeed. That is why we ought to consider very carefully before we undo the most vital reform of the past decade - the decision to index our progressive income tax to inflation.

title:
LEISURE;
HOMEGROWN SHALLOTS CAN PROVIDE A LAVISH CROP
description: When a stock splits four for one, it makes headlines on Wall Street. Yet gardeners who grow shallots would be disappointed with a mere four for one split. They expect at least eight for one, but more often it's 10, 12, or 15 for one. To attain these big shallot bulbs, plant as early as possible, as soon as the ground can be worked.

title: CONCERN OVER RENTS GROWING IN NASSAU
description: LATE last year, Lynn and James Scully received a notice from their l andlord that the rent on their two-bedroom apartment in Hempstead w as going from $395 to $600 a month when their lease expired Dec. 31.T hey had lived in the apartment four years.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Going It Alone in N.Y.C.

title: Miss Jacobs Is Affianced To a Banker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jeremy M. Jacobs of East Aurora, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisann Jane Jacobs, to John Victor Holten of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jan Holten of Kristiansund, Norway. The wedding is planned for April 9.

title: THE G.O.P.: A PARTY IN SEARCH OF ITSELF
description: In the morning of the State of the Union address, President Reagan and his aides ere briefing Republican leaders on their new program. One of those attending the White House session was Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada, and after almost an hour of talk he became alarmed. ''I never heard the reality of unemployment raised except in passing,'' he recalled later.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THE FINE ART OF CARVING FURNITURE
description: THE show ''Century of Revivals: 19th-Century American Furniture'' at the Newark Museum includes a dozen pieces made by this city's own John Jelliff.

title: ROTISSERIE FARE AT AN UNUSUAL SITE
description: DUE TORRI in Hauppauge is an unusual restaurant for the Island. It is on the fourth floor of an office building on Motor Parkway, and by day it commands a view mainly of the Long Island Expressway. One area of the large, elegantly appointed dining room is occupied by an open gas-fired rotisserie and a counter where a chef puts the finishing touches to many of the dishes.

title: THE TIFFANY TOUCH IN METAL
description: Louis Comfort Tiffany's gloriously colored, sinuously shaped and pierced metal designs - candlesticks, lamp bases, vases, small screens, boxes, jewelry, clocks, inkwells and desk accessories - have been assembled in what may well be the most comprehensive exhibition of the designer's work in this medium. On view in ''Tiffany Studios: Metalwork and Other Decorative Arts'' at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design, 2 East 91st Street, are 75 turn-of-the-century selections in bronze, silver, gold and enamel on copper. The show remains through April 17.

title: In the Doghouse
description: ''I love animals,'' said Dan Barnshaw, the dogcatcher of Rosenberg, Tex. ''I love my work.'' The two loves clashed last month, and Mr. Barnshaw made news across the country.

title: After Assam Vote Killing Goes On
description: After a month of communal and tribal violence that left more than 2,000 people dead, and an election that was boycotted by local opposition parties, a new government was installed last week in the northeastern Indian state of Assam. But the restoration of state authority after a year of direct rule from New Delhi seemed more legality than reality.

title: VITALITY AND VARIETY BUOY NEW MOVIES FROM BRITAIN
description: It's still too early to describe it as a trend, but the fact is that three of the best and most entertaining films in New York first-runs at the minute are from Great Britain, with one more coming up soon. One might have been able to say ''from England,'' except that one of the three current offerings is ''Local Hero'' by Bill Forsyth, who is a Scottish director and Scots don't take kindly to being described as English. Old boundaries are to be respected.

title: Imperial Ballet Debut
description: The Imperial Ballet will make its American debut on March 20 at 8 P.M. at the Performing Arts Center of Kingsborough Colege in Brooklyn.

title: Liverpool Wins by 5-1 As Dalglish Scores 2
description: Liverpool maintained its 14-point lead in the English League First Division with a 5-1 victory over Stoke City 5-1 today.

title: WARDING OFF SHOCKS FROM ELECTRICAL APPLIANCES
description: WHEN an electrical appliance develops a defect in its insulation that allows current to ''leak'' to the housing, anyone touching that appliance who also happens to be in good contact with a ground (for example, touching a water pipe or standing on damp ground) can get a lethal shock. The current will flow through that person's body as it seeks the shortest path to the ground. As little as one-quarter of an ampere of 110-volt household current can be fatal in certain circumstances.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: FOR many, a car is merely a means of transportation, but they are probably not suburban teen-agers. A car for them is symbol as well as object, a vehicle for a rite of passage at least as significant as first kiss and first date - getting a license.

title: JOHN LINNELL: PORTRAITS AND LANDSCAPES
description: VISITORS to the John Linnell show at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven might suppose initially that the artist is yet another star in the golden age of English landscape. But Linnell (1792-1882), being 20 or more years younger than Turner, Constable and the lesser stars and passing his formative years in an England cut off from the Continent by war, is really another proposition entirely.

title: SERVICE OFFERS RESPITE-CARE
description: THE main function of the Westchester Self-Help Clearing House is to serve as an umbrella organization for more than 100 self-help groups, but recently it announced a new and unusual service, ''Project Time-Out.'' As a network of respite-care providers, the project's volunteers will stay with the mentally ill, the developmentally disabled, the retarded and the frail elderly in the patients' homes so that family members can take ''time out'' from their responsibilities.

title: Andrea L. Avery to Wed R.G. Renault
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Edwin Avery of New York and Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Louise Avery, to Richard Gilbert Renault, son of Genvieve Rossi of Versailles, France, and the late Gilbert Renault of Paris.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
THE COIN MARKET CONTINUES TO PICK UP STEAM
description: For coin dealers the long recession appears to be at an end. The first two months of 1983 have witnessed a sharp increase in activity at coin shows and auction sales, and prices have also begun to move steadily higher.

title: YOUNG IS SELLING A CITY OTHERS SELL SHORT
description: Mayor Coleman A. Young was on hand to deliver some good news the other day. A buyer had been found for the bankrupt Bob-Lo Island amusement park, the Coney Island of the Detroit River and one of the country's first amusement parks. The park would open on Memorial Day, as it has for the last 93 years, for the enjoyment of Detroit's families and the summer employment of many of its young people, no small matter in a city where the jobless rate is nearly 17 percent.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: NIGEL CHATTEY, a 54 year-old English marine engineer and economist, says he wants to change the state of New Jersey. Literally, that is, according to a new book, ''Chattey's Island,'' by James Ehmann (Ticknor & Fields, 52 Vanderbilt Avenue, New York, $14.95), a lively presentation of geopolitics by a reporter for The Post-Standard of Syracuse, N.Y.

title: Miss O'Connor to Wed Dr. W. S. G. Rea
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. O'Connor of Huntington, L.I., and Siesta Key, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deirdre Elizabeth O'Connor, to Dr. William Samuel Gibson Rea, son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Rea of Mount Vernon, Ohio. The wedding is to take place July 3.

title: LAWYERS AT WORK
description: THE PARTNERS Inside America's Most Powerful Law Firms. By James B. Stewart. 395 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: AN ANCIENT FORM FINDS CONTEMPORARY FAVOR
description: The revival, during the past decade, of artists' interest in expressive over intellectual modes of work has by no means skipped the graphics field. It's to be seen in a resurgence of the block print, produced by the crude, energetic technique of digging into a block with a sharp instrument. The advantage of block, or relief printing - so-called because the print is made from what remains of the surface of a block of wood, linoleum or other medium after all non-image areas have been cut away - is that it encourages directness, simplicity of line and economy of design, thus aiding lyric and emotional expression.

title: Anne Fuchs Sets A June Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Clement Fuchs of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Elizabeth Fuchs, to Donald Michael Blake Jr., son of Mr. Blake of Upper Brookville, L.I., and the late Aileen M. Blake.

title: SINGAPORE'S CUISINE REALLY TAKES A POUNDING
description: The success of Singaporean marriages, it is said, depends on how well the bride can 'pound' chilies and other ingredients into the paste that forms the basis of the island's native cuisine.

title: Here and There
description: To the Editor:

title: PICKING UP THE PIECES IN THE GREAT BEACHCOMBING DEBATE
description: THE art of beachcombing is steeped in controversy. There are greater beachcombers and lesser beachcombers, and there is little about the art upon which they agree. The critics of beachcombing, although limited in numbers, are growing increasingly articulate and louder in their criticism.

title: ASBURY PARK PLANS FACE CHALLENGE
description: A CHALLENGE to a bid by a millionaire general contractor to buy and rejuvenate this resort's mile and a quarter of beachfront will be heard tomorrow in Superior Court in Freehold.

title: AFTER THE E.P.A. INVESTIGATIONS
description: THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency may have set in motion events that will lead to a backlash of public sentiment against its purportedly lax policies and a swing of the political pendulum toward more stringent regulation and enforcement of hazardous-waste matters.

title: SIGHTS AND SOUNDS
description: The ''C.O.N.E. Plus Film'' concert, to be given at 8:30 P.M. Saturday in Lyman Auditorium at Southern Connecticut State University in New Haven, is a collaboration of the Chamber Orchestra of New England and the photography of Wes Thomas.

title:
ART;
SOMETHING BEYOND SEEING
description: IN his 1978 study of American visionary painters, the art historian Abraham A. Davidson described them as ''poets of the inner mind,'' whose achievement was the manifestation of a realm beyond reality. Tracing this trend from 1800 to 1950, he deplored the lack of the visionary impulse in contemporary art, stating that, in the last few decades, ''the painters considered leaders and most influential, those who have attracted the most critical attention, have produced an art that is not only nonvisionary but antivisionary.''

title: CONCERT: CHOIRS FROM TEXAS
description: The Texas Boys Choir, in tandem with the Dorothy Shaw Bell Choir, performed everything from Palestrina to ''Annie'' at Carnegie Hall on Friday night - over 50 selections in all. The two Fort Worth-based ensembles were in New York under the auspices of the Pearl S. Buck Foundation, an organization devoted to bettering conditions for Amerasian children.

title: DR. DOUGLAS BUSH, 86, AUTHOR AND FORMER HARVARD TEACHER
description: Douglas Bush, an expert on Milton and a noted educational theorist who taught English literature at Harvard University for 33 years, died Wednesday in Boston of pneumonia. He was 86 years old.

title: BROTHELS, SPOOKS, WAR
description: FAT TUESDAY By R. Wright Campbell. 372 pp. New Haven & New York: Ticknor & Fields. $15.95. FLOATING DRAGON By Peter Straub. 515 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $15.95. THE BURNING MOUNTAIN A Novel of the Invasion of Japan.By Alfred Coppel. 438 pp. San Diego and New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $15.95.

title: Strategic Retreat For Steelworkers
description: And now the United Steelworkers of America joins the growing number of unions that have swapped benefits for a measure of job security. Presidents of union locals last week approved a 41-month contract that, among other things, temporarily cuts wages by $1.25 an hour and reduces vacation time.

title: Tours Abroad For Children From 8 to 14
description: Castles, zoos, farms, amusement parks, miniature villages, trick fountains, trained animals and other attractions calculated to appeal to children between the ages of 8 and 14 are part of a series of family tours scheduled this year.

title: Coast Man Guilty of Murder
description: Daniel Hyde, a 30-year-old former reserve police officer, was convicted Friday of murdering a love rival whose body was never found. He faces 25 years to life in prison when he is sentenced April 7.

title: TREES THAT ONCE SAVED CROPS FALL VICTIM TO FARM ECONOMY
description: As the nation this week marks the 50th anniversary of Franklin D. Roosevelt's Presidency, some will remember his personal and public interest in conserving the country's natural resources. The preservation and planting of trees were especially close to his heart.

title: GETTING AHEAD--AND STAYING MARRIED
description: Psychologists and psychiatrists say more people than ever are seeking professional counseling to help them through the sometimes overwhelming strains of dual-career marriage.

title: THE COURTLIEST TENNIS GAME OF THEM ALL
description: AT 6:30 P.M., London time, Friday, March 18, a racquet will be twirled, a server selected and the world championship of tennis will get under way - a fact of no conceivable interest to millions of tennis fans around the globe. A pity, that, for the contest will have elements of tactical brilliance and physical endurance seldom equaled at Wimbledon.

title: America's Neglected Elderly
description: Didi Moore's article, ''America's Neglected Elderly'' (Jan. 30), was excellent. Having experienced the trauma of placing a parent in a home when all other alternatives were tried, I found Miss Moore's presentation sensitive and understanding of the situation.

title: No Blame Seen
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Criminals Without Bars
description: A person who made the unlikely bet that certain criminals might one day take comfort in a Reagan Administration policy might have collected last week. In his first major speech on prisons, Attorney General William French Smith said the Justice Department was looking for ways to punish nonviolent criminals such as embezzlers and corporate price-fixers without locking them up.

title: 834 Arrested in South of Italy In Wide Crackdown on Crime
description: The police arrested 834 people today in a crackdown on crime throughout southern Italy.

title: ONE MAN'S JUNK...
description: Neighbors may not appreciate the sight of a boat, truck, car, old washing machine or the like stored in an adjacent backyard, but there is usually nothing they can do about it except to put up a fence. But in Killingworth, Conn., a rural town of 4,000, there is an ordinance prohibiting the storage out of doors of many such common items.

title: LABOR LEADER FOR AUSTRALIA
description: A decade ago, when Robert James Lee Hawke was being urged by admirers to run for Parliament, he told an interviewer that if he did become a member of Australia's legislature, ''I would want to go to the highest possible position.''

title: N.R.C. OFFICIAL QUESTIONS FAILURES AT JERSEY PLANT
description: A commissioner of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that equipment failure at the Salem 1 nuclear power plant in South Jersey had raised questions about the plant's maintenance procedures, the quality of its operating staff and about the commission's own safety enforcement program.

title: LIBERALS TAKE SOME LUMPS
description: The Liberal Party played its traditional role in Governor Cuomo's uphill victory last year. It endorsed him early, assuring Mr. Cuomo of a line on the ballot even though leaders of his own Democratic party supported Mayor Koch. Thus, the Liberals pressured the Democrats, just as they had in countless elections in the last 40 years - elections that until recently confirmed the organization's unique place as the state's third party in a two-party system.

title: Brooklyn Tech Wins Track Title
description: Charles Marsala of New Dorp High School and Roger Hunter of Thomas Jefferson tuned up for tough tests in tomorrow's Eastern States track and field championships by winning two events each yesterday at the Public Schools Athletic League indoor meet in the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: Holly P. Mayock to Wed W.G. Luff Jr.
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Lee Mayock of Wynnewood, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Holly Peruzzi Mayock, to William George Luff Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Luff, also of Wynnewood and of Ocean City, N.J.

title: LIFE AFTER ELECTION DAY
description: ONE day late last month, John Aristotle Phillips was at O'Hare Airport in Chicago, catching a plane for home after lecturing at several colleges in the Middle West. He heard a bustle, looked up and saw an exhausted Jane Byrne, plodding through a curious crowd toward a plane for Palm Springs, Calif. It was the day after the Mayor of Chicago had lost her party's primary election for renomination.

title: A FAMILY LAWYER
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE BEGINNING WAS JUPITER
description: FORTY miles to the east, here in Sri Lanka, where I now live, the sun has just climbed above the Sacred Mountain, which for so long has haunted my imagination. Another quarter turn of the planet and it will bring a cold winter dawn to the English seaside town where I was born 65 years ago this morning.

title: MARGARET NAUMBURG, WALDEN SCHOOL FOUNDER, DIES
description: Margaret Naumburg, an educator, author and art therapist who founded Manhattan's Walden School, died on Feb. 26 at her home in Needham, Mass. She was 92 years old.

title: Press Too Free For Yugoslavia
description: Some Yugoslavs are engaging in un-Yugoslav activities such as freely reporting the country's economic troubles in the press. Orthodox Marxists say it's got to stop.

title: St. John's Trounces Pitt, 91-73
description: St. John's scored an easy 91-73 victory over Pittsburgh yesterday to finish the regular season in a three-way tie for first place in the Big East Conference with Villanova and Boston College.

title: EXPLORING A BOUNTIFUL COUNTRY
description: Devon is a county of bountiful variety, and both of its coastlines possess a colorful mixture of intimate small towns. The English adore Devon - flocking to its beaches throughout July and August - or simply enjoying Dartmoor, a brooding, ancient moorland, source of the sparkling streams and rivers with which Devon is well endowed.

title: 3 Convicted in Shooting Of Israeli Ambassador
description: A court convicted two Jordanian students and an Iraqi businessman today of trying to assassinate Israel's Ambassador to Britain, and sentenced them to prison terms ranging from 30 to 35 years.

title: MORE SNOW SOUGHT FOR RIVER IN WEST
description: In a steep valley in western Colorado, Federal land managers are studying a scheme to cut patches from the thick groves of aspen trees so that more runoff from melting snow will find its way into mountain streams.

title: Alicia Bradford To Wed in May
description: Elsa H. Bradford of Meriden, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Alicia Merriman Bradford, to D. Alan Scribner 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Alan Scribner of Glens Falls, N.Y. The wedding is to be May 14.

title: YESTERDAY IN POUND RIDGE TODAY
description: WHAT do a mastodon and a writing desk have in common? And what do either of them have to do with a hatter, mad or otherwise? The answer to the riddle literally lies in the new Pound Ridge Museum, which today opens its doors to the public. The three seemingly disparate entities have all played a part in the history of this northern Westchester community and now are among the exhibits that have been created for the museum.

title: No Headline
description: All the comparisons of Placido Domingo and Luciano Pavarotti make interesting reading for an opera lover, and I imagine the controversy over who is No. 1 will always be a first-class contest. I do object, however, to Mr. Holland's general comments about the intelligence of all tenors, Mr. Domingo excluded.

title: 3 LATIN COUNTRIES PLAN PEACE TALKS WITH NO U.S. ROLE
description: Three Central American Governments are planning a meeting to discuss methods of bringing peace to the region and have decided not to invite the United States, according to Government officials here.

title: SANDANISTS ARE INDIGNANT AT POPE, DISSIDENTS DELIGHTED AT HIS POLITICS
description: Pope John Paul II's visit here Friday has sharpened the political and religious differences between supporters and opponents of Nicaragua's Sandinist Government.

title: Ann K. Thompson Is Engaged to Neal B. Goldberg
description: Dr. and Mrs. John Clair Thompson of Storrs, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Kirsten Thompson, to Neal B. Goldberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Goldberg of Hartsdale, N.Y. A May wedding is planned in Hartsdale.

title: AND SUDDENLY EVIL ERUPTS
description: THE DARK SIDE OF GENIUS The Life of Alfred Hitchcock. By Donald Spoto. Illustrated. 594 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $20.

title: COLUMBIA AND BARNARD AGREE ON JOINT ATHLETIC PROGRAMS
description: Columbia University and Barnard College will combine their intercollegiate athletic programs, beginning next fall. The arrangement will enable Columbia to offer a full range of athletic teams to the first coeducational class in the school's 229-year history next September.

title: A MORE MENACING SCARECROW
description: WHILE some scientists and inventors strive to make a better mousetrap, Dr. Michael R. Conover is developing a better scarecrow. One that moves. And crows, at least, think it is deadly.

title: FEUER CALLS I.R.S. ACT 'EMPTY GESTURE'
description: THE Internal Revenue Service has returned the Feuer Transportation Company's New York State operating license and its Interstate Commerce Commission license. Without the licenses, the trucking company, which has been in business for 50 years, could not legally operate.

title: SHOULD DANCE TRY TO COMPETE WITH WORDS?
description: Recent programs by the Charlie Vernon Performance Company of Chicago and Johanna Boyce and Performance Group involved dances to words, as well as to music. That alone made them slightly odd for, whereas no one objects to dancing to music, dancing to texts is considered suspect in some circles. Yet dancers keep on doing it.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE newly appointed Mercer County Surrogate has started an investment program aimed at earning maximum interest rates on the funds he manages for children and their guardians. Involved are 750 accounts with assets totaling $4 million.

title: CASE FOR AND AGAINST N.F.L. ANTITRUST EXEMPTION NEEDED TO PROTECT CITIES
description: UNLESS Congress acts this year, the National Football League and other sports leagues will have to change their schedule of newsworthy events. Besides playoff games, the Super Bowl, the Stanley Cup and the annual college drafts, a new highlight will become part of the annual saga of professional sports. It could be held in the main room at Christie's or possibly Sotheby-Parke Bernet. Maybe it would be nationally televised, with Howard Cosell and Jimmy the Greek commenting and predicting the winners.

title: FEDERAL AGENCY TO MONITOR TEST OF EMERGENCY PLAN
description: PLANS exist for coping with a nuclear accident at Indian Point, but at the moment, only the operators officially maintain that the preparations are adequate. On Wednesday, hundreds of people will participate in an exercise to simulate some of what would happen if there were a major release of radioactivity, in an attempt to see how far the plants have come in meeting the emergency-preparedness requirement.

title: NEW SOCIAL CONTRACTS
description: WORKING TOGETHER By John Simmons and William Mares. Illustrated. 319 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95. JAPAN IN THE PASSING LANE An Insider's Account of Life in a Japanese Auto Factory. By Satoshi Kamata. Translated and edited by Tatsuru Akimoto. Introduction by Ronald Dore. 211 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $14.95.

title: SLOW TO RESPOND
description: To the Business Editor:

title: REAGAN PLAN GROWS STALE AS BUYERS REMAIN ALOOF
description: President Reagan's Middle East peace initiative was six months old last week and more than a few American Middle East hands and Arab leaders were beginning to wonder whether it would live out the year. Having failed to attract buyers in the region, the initiative seemed increasingly in danger of joining the Johnston plan of the 1950's, the Rogers plan of the 1970's and the Camp David autonomy proposal as another example of frustrated American Middle East diplomacy.

title: THEATER RECEIVES A GIFT
description: MICHAEL PRICE, the executive director of the Goodspeed Opera House Foundation, has a new space in which to experiment: a 40,000 squarefoot factory where he hopes to unveil a series of new plays starting in August.

title: POPEYE'S FAVORITE VEGETABLE IS EVEN BETTER FRESH
description: FRESH spinach is one of the most versatile vegetables on the market. It can be used raw in salads; cooked and pureed to make soups, sauces and even pasta dough; creamed, added to quiches, pizza or turnovers such as the Greek spinach pie wrapped in phyllo pastry; or quickly sauteed in garlic and oil and used to create a bed of verdant green upon which to present veal, chicken or fish.

title: STATE SENATE PASSES NEW FINANCIAL-DISCLOSURE BILL
description: The State Senate has revived a constitutional debate by passing a bill requiring organizations that try to influence state ballot propositions to make full financial disclosure to the State Board of Elections.

title: ACCORD ON TAXES PROVES ELUSIVE
description: FACED with a worsening state budget deficit, Connecticut's General Assembly began searching last week for an elusive accord on new and higher state taxes that could attract enough votes to be enacted.

title: A LOVE SONG TO WHAT WOULD BE LOST
description: THE END OF THE WORLD NEWS An Entertainment. By Anthony Burgess. 389 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Co. $15.95.

title: Headliners; Mrs. Allende Won't Be Coming
description: The Justice Department may have smoked out Canadian ''propaganda'' films on acid raid and the freeze movement, but the State Department is no less vigilant. Last week it defused a threat from South of the border. Hortensia Allende, the 68-year-old widow of slain Chilean President Salvador Allende, was denied entry into the country because of her ties to the World Peace Council, which State says is a communist front. Mrs. Allende, who planned a speaking tour, professed not to know what the ruckus was about. ''I don't think I'm so dangerous at my age,'' she said.

title: Film Ruckus, in Slow Motion
description: The gossip has been that Attorney General William French Smith never approved his department's eccentric decision to brand three Canadian documentaries as ''political propaganda.'' Zealous subordinates are said to have acted alone, using the Foreign Agents Registration Act to pin a derogatory ''P'' rating on films about acid rain and nuclear war.

title: TRANSIT OFFICIALS AND CONDUCTORS BARGAIN, RIDERS PAY
description: Just two months after New York and New Jersey took over the local commuter rail lines from Washington, serious labor problems have erupted. Last week, there was a walkout of conductors and trainmen on the nine N.J. Transit lines that normally carry 70,000 commuters each day. And the 85,000 who ride the three lines of Metro-North - the Harlem, the Hudson and the New Haven -were facing a possible strike at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: MAYOR Angelo R. Martinelli of Yonkers will take his battle with the United Technologies Corporation over its planned closing of the Otis Elevator Plant to Washington Tuesday, in an attempt to gain support from the leadership of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. The move comes two weeks after the United Automobile Workers and the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers agreed to assist the city in its anticipated lawsuit against the Hartford-based United Technologies. Both unions represent workers at the Otis plant.

title: FEDERAL CASE LEANS ON A LAW AGAINST RACKETEERING
description: IT would be hard to find a better example of the adversary system of justice than the legal proceedings arising from the Brink's armored car robbery and killings that took place 17 months ago in Rockland County. The case not only pits defense attorney against prosecutor but also prosecutor against prosecutor, since both Rockland County District Attorney Kenneth Gribetz and United States Attorney John S. Martin Jr. are investigating the shootout, which claimed the lives of two police officers and a Brink's guard, and the events surrounding it. The result, not surprisingly, has been some exceedingly complicated maneuvering, including the postponement of the state trial, a series of four Federal indictments and defense motions challenging everything from pretrail publicity to hypnotized witnesses. These two articles examine the prosecutors' strategies and their problems with defense attorneys and each other.

title: Iranian Team in London For OPEC Price Parley
description: An Iranian delegation arrived here today to join the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' consultations on prices, raising hopes of averting a world oil price collapse.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IN all the years we have been enriching the Metropolitan Transportation Authority together, I cannot remember one time when Earl has been late. I also cannot remember one day of my commuting life when I did not delay until the last 10, 9, 8, or 5 minutes my rush from my South Shore home to the Long Island Rail Road station up on Sunrise Highway.

title: GONZALEZ
description: There are artists whose fate, it seems, is to be rediscovered in every generation, and the Spanish sculptor Julio Gonzalez (1876-1942) is apparently one of them. Sought out by Picasso as an artistic collaborator in the 1920's, seized upon by the American sculptor David Smith as an artistic model and inspiration in the 1930's, canonized by sculptors on both sides of the Atlantic in the 1940's and 50's, Gonzalez has remained a sacred figure for sculptors and connoisseurs of sculpture down to the present day - a master who decisively altered the medium in which he worked. Writing in the 1970's, the British sculptor William Tucker described Gonzalez as ''essentially an explorer, a beginner: the provider of a multitude of clues and leads for others'' - meaning, of course, other sculptors like himself. When sculptors speak of Gonzalez, it is always with a special tenderness and respect.

title: SIDNEY A. DIAMOND
description: Sidney A. Diamond, a lawyer who served as Federal Commissioner of Patents, Trademarks and Copyrights in the Carter Administration, died Friday.

title: TWO BY COWARD
description: ''Suite in Two Keys,'' a Noel Coward creation starring Betsy Palmer, Barry Nelson and Kim Hunter, opens Wednesday at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn.

title: House Begins Firing for Effect At Defense Funds
description: Defense budgets almost always have a way of standing up to the most withering cross fire. But as Congress began settling down to the drudgery of budget-making last week, the Administration's plans to increase military spending to $245 billion from $214 billion this year were taking a virtually unprecedented pounding.

title: Sampson's '50' Retired
description: Basketball jersey No. 50 is being retired today at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville.

title: CORRUPTION CASE EXPECTED TO GROW
description: Federal agents are pursuing a spreading investigation into suspected police corruption here after presenting evidence to a grand jury that has already issued five indictments, including conspiracy and extortion charges against an inspector who retired in the inquiry.

title: MIME'S PIED PIPER RETURNS
description: Offstage with Marcel Marceau, it is impossible to get a word in edgewise. The man who helped revive and propagate the moribund art of pantomime almost talks his head off when in private. He can be gabby in English, French, Italian, Spanish and German. The torrent of words is understandable from someone who has remained mum on stage for almost 40 years while perfecting what Mr. Marceau calls ''silent acting.'' Absent from Broadway since 1975, he opens Wednesday at the Belasco for a six-week run.

title: Julianne M. Flach Married in Jersey To F. S. Sowinski
description: Julianne Mary Flach, daughter of Ellen Finley Flach of Franklin Lakes, N.J., was married there yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Blessed Sacrament to Frank S. Sowinski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Sowinski of East Hanover, N.J. The Rev. Carl Hinrichsen performed the ceremony.

title: On Joblessness
description: To the Business Editor:

title: THIS TIME, THE SPOTLIGHT MAY FLATTER ROSTENKOWSKI
description: When the 97th Congress convened in 1981, the new chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Dan Rostenkowski, paid a call on President Reagan. As the Illinois Democrat recalls it, he told the President: ''We're both new in our jobs. I'd like to be a success, and I'd like to help you be a success.''

title: VILLAINS HAVE THE FUN
description: STICK By Elmore Leonard. 304 pp. New York: Arbor House. $14.50.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: THEATER Nicholas Kazan's ''Blood Moon,'' a modern equivalent of a Jacobean revenger's tale, has reopened for an extended run at the Actors and Directors Theater on Theater Row, after a previous successful engagement at the Production Company. The dramatic events may seem improbable, but the playwright has craftily arranged the mechanics of his plot so that the audience is swept past its initial disbelief.

title: CONTAIN MOSCOW; COOPERATE, TOO
description: Reciting the litany of Soviet misconduct in the late 1970's is no longer enough to justify the absence of a policy other than containment.

title: Town-Built Water Tower Falls in Bayside, Tex.
description: This Gulf Coast community's hope for a steady water supply collapsed when the town's new water tower, built by the 79-year-old Mayor and volunteers, came tumbling down as it was being filled.

title: MUSIC: SIX AT LA MAMA
description: The inaugural program of New Music at La MaMa on Thursday presented six composers rarely heard in New York. The dominant style might be called postminimalism - using repetition for texture rather than structure, and embracing sounds from jazz and the classics.

title: HUNTINGTON SPLIT
description: To the Editor:

title: 9 Die on Bus in Turkey
description: A bus plummeted over a 395-foot cliff in eastern Turkey on Friday, killing 9 people and injuring at least 36, most of them critically, the Anatolia News Agency reported today. The accident occurred as the bus traveled through the mountainous eastern Black Sea region, which was hit by severe snowstorms recently, the agency said.

title: THE SELLING OF SMALL-TOWN AMERICA
description: IMAGINE yourself an embroiderer for a moment. You are about to make a sampler of small-town America, and the picture you come up with is likely to resemble Flemington: an orderly main street of 19thcentury storefronts, houses, churches, even the mandatory Civil War momument.

title: POPE, IN PANAMA, CAUTIONS AGAINST GUERRILLA WAR
description: Pope John Paul II arrived here today on the third stop of his tour of eight countries and urged Central America's peasants to reject ''the temptation of violence, armed guerrilla struggle and the egoistic struggle of classes.''

title: Hilary Paley Byers Becomes the Bride Of Joseph Califano Jr. in Washington
description: Hilary Paley Byers was married in Washington yesterday to Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare in the Carter Administration. The Rev. Sanford Garner performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: More Walton Woes
description: Bill Walton, the 30-year-old San Diego Clippers center who has been playing full time since Jan. 15, says he may have to go back to parttime play. He does not plan to be in today's game against the Kings in Kansas City.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the article "What's Doing in Sarasota" (Travel, Feb. 27), Pan American World Airways was said to have the only daily nonstop flight from New York.

title: OIL PRODUCERS TRY TO WIDEN BAHRAIN LINKS
description: By the end of next year, a four-lane highway atop a stone causeway will link this island to the Saudi Arabian mainland, 20 miles away across the emerald waters of the Persian Gulf.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE CONQUEST OF MOROCCO By Douglas Porch. Illustrated. 335 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: OBJECTS TO BE LOOKED AT AND USED
description: HANDCRAFTED appointments for windows, walls, floors and even corners are being featured this month at America House Gallery here. ''Interiors: Craft Works for Private and Public Spaces'' offers a wide, tastefully selected variety of furniture and accessories for residential and office settings.

title: 20 VIE TO BECOME SAN DIEGO'S MAYOR
description: Maureen O'Connor, a former City Councilwoman credited with getting San Diego's ''Tijuana Trolley'' rolling, and Roger Hedgecock, a County Supervisor with strong support among environmentalists, have emerged as front-runners in a field of 20 candidates for Mayor of San Diego.

title: Mailbox; Amateurism And Walker
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Egypt and Soviet Set Ties
description: Egypt and the Soviet Union are preparing to exchange ambassadors again, restoring full diplomatic relations for the first time in 18 months, state-controlled newspapers reported here Friday. The reports said Deputy Prime Minister Nikolai K. Baibakov of the Soviet Union delivered ''definite ideas'' on repairing the rift in a meeting with Assistant Foreign Minister Shafei Abdel-Hamid.

title: THE OUTSPOKEN PRESIDENT OF YALE
description: On a good day, I view the job as directing an orchestra. On the dark days, it is more like that of a clutch - engaging the engine to effect forward motion, while taking great friction.''

title: Yanks Lose 2
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: UNIVERSAL IMAGES REACHES FOR THE STARS
description: NOW in its 12th season, the Theater of Universal Images, Newark Symphony Hall's semiprofessional resident black company, is reaching for the stars.

title: CHART OF THE SAILINGS
description: The following guide to cruise ships is arranged by destination and primarily covers saltwater cruises. Cruises are also offered on many of the world's major rivers, such as the Amazon, the Mississippi, the Nile, the Yangtze, the Columbia, the St. Lawrence, the Rhine, the Danube and the Volga. Details on some of these river cruises and on some freighter cruises are also included. The guide basically covers sailings from March 7 to Nov. 30 and is the first of two planned this year. The next will be published Nov. 13.

title: THE MET RESURRECTS A 1956 'TOSCA' FOR LOVE AND MONEY
description: For a decade, the Metropolitan Opera has been offering historic broadcast recordings from its long-running Saturday afternoon series to help raise money for the company, and to date this campaign has brought in $2.3 million, according to Marilyn Shapiro, assistant manager in charge of fund-raising. Now, 21,490 albums later (representing nine releases), the latest has just been released, a ''Tosca'' from the broadcast performance of Jan. 7, 1956. In the cast are Renata Tebaldi, Richard Tucker, Leonard Warren and Fernando Corena. The conductor is Dimitri Mitropoulos.

title: EX-CHINATOWN GANG MEMBER SLAIN ON STREET
description: A 23-year-old man identified as a former member of a Chinatown youth gang was fatally shot early yesterday on a street in the East Village.

title: THE LEGACY OF TENNESSEE WILLIAMS
description: ''I, like almost everyone of my generation, went into the theater because of my exposure to Tennessee. In high school, we did those ridiculous, old-fashioned comedies, and then I got to play Tom in 'The Glass Menagerie,' and it was then I fell in love with theater.'' -Lanford Wilson

title: SINGERS SEIZE THE LIMELIGHT ON DISKS DRAWN FROM THE PAST
description: It might seem odd to consider LP reissues of ancient vocal recordings a growth industry, a burgeoning field with a burgeoning audience. But even as recording technology pushes forward to its new, digital future, the history of recording stretches out ever longer behind us, fast approaching a century.

title:
GARDENING;
AREA FLOWER SHOWS BECKON TO SPRING
description: TO introduce the theme of this this year's Boston Flower Show, an article in The Leaflet, a publication of the Massachusetts Horticultural Society, offers the following quotation:

title: Alexandra Hughes to Wed Joseph Foley in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter L. Hughes 3d of Basking Ridge, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alexandra Hughes, to Joseph H. Foley 3d, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Foley Jr. of Colonia, N.J.

title: BAY AREA GIVES ELIZABETH A FESTIVE SEND-OFF
description: Queen Elizabeth II left a soggy dockside celebration in which cookies and Cheerios were served Saturday for a rest in majestic Yosemite National Park, capping a week of dinners, demonstrations and downpours across California.

title: Katherine L. Proctor to Wed a Physician in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Barton Allen Proctor Jr., of Darien, Conn., and Richmond, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Lynn Proctor, to Dr. John Courtenay MacIlwaine, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Andrew MacIlwaine of Waynesboro, Va.

title: Gail P. Gibson to Wed Daniel George Ciaburri
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Gibson of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail Patricia Gibson, to Daniel George Ciaburri, son of Marie A. Ciaburri of Middletown, Conn., and Daniel H. Ciaburri of Haddam, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: Eleanor L. Vogelbach to Marry John M. Gavin Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Vogelbach of Thompson Ridge, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eleanor Lindsay Vogelbach, to John Martin Gavin Jr., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Gavin of Philadelphia.

title: ROADS NEED A LOW-SALT DIET, TOO
description: IN PREPARATION for winter storms, New Jersey's state, county and local road departments stockpile more than 120,000 tons of road salt every year. Tens of thousands of tons were distributed in last month's ''Blizzard of '83.''

title: INEQUITIES EXPAND AS THE STABILIZATION SYSTEM AGES
description: FORTUNATELY for her temper, a woman who occupies a studio apartment on the East Side is unacquainted with another woman in a similar studio a few floors below.

title: Arafat in Saudi Arabia
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader, discussed the Middle East today in Riyadh with the Saudi Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal. The official Saudi press agency gave no details of the talks.

title: DESEX SCHOOLING FOR JOBS
description: It is difficult to praise vocational training institutions for preparing students for the world of work when these schools reinforce the inequities of the workplace by training girls for one set of jobs and boys for another.

title: DECOY DUCKS GO BILL TO BILL IN ANNUAL L.I. COMPETITION

title: THE SQUEAL RULE
description: Rarely does one side in a controversy grab the moral high ground by the coinage of a phrase. A generation ago, opponents of the union shop urged the passage of what they called right-to-work laws, building their argument into the name of the game: Who could be against the right to work? (Organized labor called the legislation union-busting laws.) In the same way, the truth-in construction was effective, from truth-in-securities in 1933 to truth-in-packaging later. More recently, issue-titling was enhanced by groups that favored legal abortion and called themselves prochoice, a move that was then countered by antiabortion groups that selected the positive prolife.

That perception would seem simple enough, but its ramifications have been confounding a good many people in the business of cable television. Individuals and corporate entities have jumped into that business with an almost reckless faith that enormous profits will be waiting for them somewhere down the line. In some instances, the high prices paid for municipal franchises would indicate that the profits could very well be a couple of decades down the line. Doubts are increasingly being voiced about the wisdom of such investments.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
WHEN THE CAMERA RELIES ON PAINTERLY PRECEDENTS
description: In painting and poetry, as well as photography, the strategy of Surrealism is to combine seemingly unrelated things to suggest, or reveal, heretofore unsuspected connections between them, and there is a sense in which much of modern photography is Surrealist by nature. The camera records whatever is in front of its lens at the moment of exposure, and when small hand-held cameras are used outside the controlled environment of the studio, they often record odd bits and pieces that are unrelated to the photographer's main subject, yet may cast an odd light on it. Thus, in news photographs of fires, accidents and other disasters there are often people standing about looking the other way as if nothing were happening - a bizarre effect that seems to say something profound about human beings and their relation to one another.

title: School Desegregation, Commuter Style
description: Eighty percent of St. Louis's 59,000 students are black. In September, 15,000 are to be bused to largely white suburban districts, as part of the first court-approved voluntary interdistrict busing plan. The deal St. Louis has struck with its suburbs sends an important message to other cities where hopes for desegregation may be fading.

title: 'Stick'
description: ELMORE LEONARD, the author of more than a dozen entertainments, is never more entertaining than when one of his villains is stealing a scene. They are inspired hams, these bad actors, so empty inside that they only become themselves when they are playing a part, milking it for all it's worth. There is therefore something desperate about their zest, which nevertheless releases our own. (Think of Laurence Olivier playing Richard III; think of Marlon Brando playing the bounty hunter in ''The Missouri Breaks''; think of Orson Welles playing anything.) They are treacherous and tricky, smart enough to outsmart themselves, driven, audacious and outrageous, capable of anything, paranoid-cunning and casually vicious - and rousing fun. Mr. Leonard's villains upstage his heroes, who are sticks, and his heroines, who are as modish and blank as the dummies in Bloomingdale's windows.

title: REALISM TOWARD SALVADOR, NICARAGUA
description: Concerned with changing military conditions, President Reagan has asked Congress to appropriate $60 million in additional military aid to El Salvador - and with good reason. With every passing month, the situation in Central America becomes more intractable and dangerous. The political, military and social trends in the region are moving in a direction unfavorable to United States interests and clearly the Administration's policies are not working. For me, this raises dire questions not only about the means that the Administration is using in Central America but also about its goals.The Administration is not only insensitive to large-scale human rights violations and lacking any historical perspective on Central America but, more important, its tactics are wholly unsuited to its goals. Washington's aid to El Salvador, even if increased significantly, is no substitute for the social reforms that would be necessary to undermine the appeal the guerrillas hold for many Salvadorans. Nor could the United States possibly provide enough aid to achieve a stalemate or defeat the revolution against the Salvadoran Government. What is Mr. Reagan's goal? It is simple enough: to prevent the countries of the region from going the way that Cuba has gone. The assumptions underlying the goal are more complex, and it is useful to untangle them. The Administration believes: * Cuba would have become a Communist state whether United States policy toward Havana during the last 24 years was benign or hostile. * Nicaragua is rapidly becoming a Communist state.

title: HOW CAN WE ADMIRE A LESS THAN HUMAN HERO?
description: Almost any play by the British dramatist Simon Gray could legitimately be construed as a withdrawal symptom. Butley, Mr. Gray's venomous teacher in the well-known play of the same name, effected his withdrawal from society in a particular way, the most dramatic his author has yet managed to devise. He attacked. He attacked mainly with his tongue, flicking out poisonously in all directions, but also with his restless, threatening, overbearing presence. He drained the air out of the commonroom that was meant to be shared with his colleagues until his colleagues, gasping for breath and for surcease, simply fled. But Butley had emptied out more than the room. Emotionally speaking, he'd emptied out his world, ridding it of friends, acquaintances, people. Having rather violently withdrawn from all human relationships, he at last stood alone, apparently satisfied.
