description: Dr. and Mrs. Howard I. Blum of Merrick and Hampton Bays, L.I., and St. Petersburg, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendi Ellen Blum, to Dr. Brian G. Kushner of McLean, Va., son of Dr. and Mrs. Roger Kushner of Lewiston, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: MERRY MONGOOSE
description: ARCHIBALD LEE MOORE, known as the Mongoose the ''Merry Mongoose,'' he corrects - former light-heavyweight champion of the world; professional boxer for 29 years; holder of the record for most knockouts in major competition, 145; retired from active fighting in 1965 to ''enter the cinema and television fields'' - his most prominent role was Jim in ''Huckleberry Finn''; now primarily a ''master boxing instructor,'' a trainer and manager in San Diego and Los Angeles, but still, he admits, an unofficial international ambassador of good will (once, when stripped of his title by a commission for inactivity, he appealed to the United Nations), and he is still going strong at 69, or 66 -his mother put his birth date as Dec. 13, 1913, but he insists the year was 1916. ''My mother should know, she was there,'' he once said. ''But so was I. I have given it much thought, and have decided that I must have been 3 when I was born.''

title: Miami Patrolman Kills Unarmed Black Man
description: An unarmed black man was fatally shot Friday by a white police officer after a high-speed automobile chase that ended in a predominantly black neighborhood, the authorities said.

title: POLICE CORRUPTION INVOLVING DRUGS LEADS TO NEW SUPERVISION ACTIONS
description: The use and sale of narcotics by police officers and other criminal acts by officers involving drugs has become one of the Police Department's most serious corruption problems, according to an annual report submitted to Commissioner Robert J. McGuire.

title: Reagan Authorizes Aid For 31 California Areas
description: President Reagan has authorized Federal assistance for 31 California counties battered by a week of fierce storms that caused damage estimated at $203 million, a figure that is expected to rise.

title: FINGERPRINTING PLAN FOR CHILDREN GAINS
description: A RISING fear of child abduction among parents has prompted police officials in Nassau and Suffolk Counties to prepare voluntary programs for the fingerprinting of elementary school children.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Hair Replacement After Therapy or Illness

title: Mary E. Savage To Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. John C. Savage of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elizabeth Savage, to John S.W. Wasley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wasley of Manhattan.

title: Lewis of U.S. Triumphs In Freestyle Wrestling
description: The United States, South Korea, the Soviet Union and Japan each won one gold medal today in the two-day International Freestyle Wrestling meet.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A GOOD TIME FOR APPRAISALS
description: FINE, early American antiques especially well-designed and wellconstructed furniture - continue to bring top prices in Connecticut as they do wherever else authentic antiques are treasured.

title: R. P. Krist Wed To Miss Cornell
description: Candice Cornell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cornell of Prescott, Ariz., and New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Peter Krist, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter C. Krist of Westport, Conn., and Quechee, Vt. Justice of the Peace Hazel Rich Hobbs performed the ceremony at the Waveny House in New Canaan.

title: No Headline
description: If nursing homes ''select'' their patients, it is not because of an egregious motive to do less for more (money) but to try to meet the enormous needs of their current patient population. For me to approve admission of a ''heavy-care patient'' when my nursing units are filled with totally dependent ill elderly would border on patient neglect! An already stretched staff, reduced to minimum levels by cutbacks and retrogressive state and Federal reimbursement formulas, might be unable to competently provide the care and safety needed. ETHEL MITTY, Director, Nursing Service, The Jewish Home and Hospital for Aged, New York City

title: Politics Follow Pope on Tour of Central America
description: Pope John Paul II last week took his message of ''peace, concord and hope'' to millions of Central Americans. His eight-country tour brought out throngs who cheered as he blessed them from his bulletproof vehicle, a concession to the security risks inherent in a region torn by civil war and economic stress.

title: BEST SHOTS: SOME EDITORIALS ON THE E.P.A.
description: Time to Get E.P.A. Back Into Business

title: TABLE-HOPPING AT SEA
description: Eating aboard cruise ships traditionally has been a test of one's capacity and stamina: huge full-course breakfasts, morning bouillon, elaborate lunches, either in dining rooms or on decks, afternoon teas, cocktails and hors d'oeuvres, vast multi-course dinners, desserts and after-dinner drinks in the lounges and midnight buffets.

title: THE TURKS AND CAICOS, QUIETLY
description: When you arrive by air at Grand Turk, Patsy Taylor, the Collector of Custom, greets you with minimal but stylish formalities, jiving to soft rock from her radio and tapping gray high heels with fancy bows that flicker like trapped butterflies. She starts one thing, then another, interrupting her interruptions as if to abolish time itself. Buoyantly courteous, she gives you the full treatment: the stamps, the punches, the forms and the copperplate signatures are her mystery and she wants you to remember it.

title: GUATEMALAN CALLS POPE AN ALLY
description: Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, in an apparent attempt to mend relations, hailed Pope John Paul II today as an ally in an anti-Communist crusade to build a ''new Guatemala.''

title: DANCE: 'TERRAIN' PREMIERES
description: By calling it ''Terrain,'' Jennifer Muller set up the expectation of some reference to the natural world in her group piece, which was given its New York premiere by Jennifer Muller/ The Works on Thursday at City Center. Could the dance's first section be a dance for sky and clouds, its second section one for the earth and the closing dance a summoning up of the sea? It certainly seemed so, on one level.

title: New Rochelle Gains
description: The College of New Rochelle women's basketball team captured the East Regional final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III tournament with a 75-58 victory over Rhode Island College tonight. New Rochelle (28-5) was led by the junior forward Lois Salto with 22 points. New Rochelle now advances to the national quarterfinals against the tournament.

title: STUDY URGES CITY TO UPDATE TRAINING FOR JOBLESS
description: New York City's job training programs should be linked to city and state economic development programs that will provide employment, according to a study of the city's employment problems.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: EVERY Saturday, the Speaker of the Assembly, Alan J. Karcher, Democrat of Sayreville, can be found ''relaxing'' in school. Since last October, he has been attending day-long seminars in literature, philosophy and the arts.

title: Capitals Beat Flyers, 4-3, on 2 Fast Goals
description: Milan Novy and Paul McKinnon scored 59 seconds apart tonight to help the Washington Capitals to a 4-3 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Suzanne Bassett, Will Be Married To William Derby
description: Thomas A. Bassett of New York and Millbrook, N.Y., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Suzanne Sherman Bassett, to William Harlan Derby, son of Robert A. Derby Jr. of New York, and the late Mrs. Derby. The wedding is planned for October.

title: HOW CASH GOT INVOLVED
description: Johnny Cash is Henry Vaccaro's partner in Asbury Park because Mr. Vaccaro backed two young men in a guitar-making venture.

title: Patricia Weber to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. Charles M. Weber of Edison, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Ann Weber, to Richard Ethan Bedrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Bedrick of Livingston, N.J. A June wedding is planned.. The future bride is personnel manager of Ally & Gargano Inc., an advertising agency in Manhattan. Mr. Bedrick is assistant general counsel of the Volvo of America Corporation in Rockleigh, N.J.

title: U.D.C. HEAD TO CUT CONSULTANT COSTS
description: The new head of the state's Urban Development Corporation says he plans to cut in half the $20 million to $30 million the agency spends yearly for outside consultants.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: One impressive debut this week hardly seemed to be a debut at all. Alan Feinberg, who gave a piano recital at Merkin Hall on Wednesday night, has already performed widely with contemporary music groups, including the New York New Music Ensemble. Moreover, his recital of 20th-century piano music did the opposite of what most debuts do; it directed the attention to the music rather than to the performer.

title: MRS. BURFORD SAYS SHE WILL FOLLOW REAGAN'S ORDERS NOT TO OPEN FILES
description: Anne McGill Burford said today that she would follow President Reagan's orders ''plain and simple,'' and not throw open Environmental Protection Agency files to Congress.

title: MILAN
description: Milan has all the trappings of being one of the world's wealthiest cities. In the shopping area cloistered between the via della Spiga and the via Montenapoleone are boutique after boutique with instantly recognizable fashion names - Gucci, Missoni, Armani, Versace, Fendi, Valentino, Krizia, almost all of them flanked by expensive jewelers.

title: THE ALHAMBRA
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
AREA FLOWER SHOWS BECKON TO SPRING
description: TO introduce the theme of this this year's Boston Flower Show, an article in The Leaflet, a publication of the Massachusetts Horticultural Society, offers the following quotation:

title: O'NEILL VOTES QUIETLY
description: GOVERNOR O'NEILL was on the winning side one day and the losing side the next when members of the National Governors Association debated energy and budget issues at their annual Washington conference last week. And he was quiet about it.

title: Arrests at Embassy in Taipei
description: A man and a woman have been arrested for threatening to set themselves on fire at the Dominican Republic's Embassy here if the embassy did not grant them political asylum, the police said today.

title: ISLANDERS TRIUMPH OVER THE DEVILS, 5-1
description: Al Arbour's theory is that all the parts are interchangeable, and tonight it worked again. Arbour put together an array of different lines, using all 12 of his forwards, and the Islanders, backed by balanced scoring and 39 saves by the goalie Billy Smith, defeated the New Jersey Devils, 5-1, before a sellout crowd of 15,230 at Nassau Coliseum.

title: BRITISH ALE
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CASE FOR A WITHDRAWAL OF OUR FORCES
description: President Reagan's 1984 budget, submitted to Congress on Jan. 31, is engulfed in controversy, not the least of it over $274 billion of appropriations requested for defense. With a projected deficit for 1984 of $189 billion, critics of almost every political persuasion have targeted defense spending for some cuts.

title: HISTORIC DEVONSHIRE
description: Devon is heaven -though it hardly becomes a Cornishman to say so, for there is a certain rivalry between these two westernmost counties of Britain. But Devon, three times the size of Cornwall, is one of the largest of English counties, with a historic cathedral city, Exeter, thrown in.

title: Kell, Alston on Hall List
description: George Kell, Walter Alston and five former shortstops who were noted primarily for their defensive skills are among 25 candidates for election to baseball's Hall of Fame next week by the shrine's Committee of Veterans.

title: ART
description: Paper means a lot more to artists these days than it did, say, a decade ago, when its principal use was as a surface - for pastels, watercolors and drawing. Now it's ''hot'' as a medium in its own right, and artists of every stripe are hand-making, hand-coloring, hand-molding and otherwise manipulating the pulpy mess that paper begins with, to wonderful effect.

title: JERSEY BILLS SEEK $75 MILLION FOR JOBS PROJECTS
description: A total of $75 million would be provided for projects intended to ease unemployment and increase property values under a pair of bills passed by the New Jersey Assembly.

title: 30 YEARS LATER, STALIN'S IMAGE LINGERS
description: Five floral bouquets on the black granite stone atop his grave here were the only visible reminders today that it was 30 years ago, on March 5, 1953, that Stalin died.

title: THE 'NONALIGNED' COUNTRIES SEEM MORE SO THAN USUAL
description: When the summit meeting of 100 states professing nonalignment begins tomorrow, the heads of government will be sped in bulletproof cars past a dominating billboard on which the benign image of a smiling Mahatma Gandhi peers over his words: ''Nothing enduring can be built upon violence, non-violence is the summit of bravery.''

title: Mrs. Burford's Intimations
description: Anne McGill Burford's tether to the Environmental Protection Agency stretched almost to the breaking point last week. The House Republican leader and the chairman of the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee, among others, called for the President to replace her. Yesterday, Mr.Reagan again expressed ''full confidence'' in his E.P.A. administrator, saying she could stay in office ''as long as she wants to.'' Mrs. Burford had told aides she expected to be ''fed to the wolves'' if the crisis continued.

title: SISSELA BOK: A VIEW OF LIFE AND ETHICS
description: In a sunny, book-lined writing room just a few steps down the hall from where James Russell Lowell wrote his poetry, a cultivated and genteel woman has spent much of her time these last few years writing about two of the darker areas of the human mind: lying and secrets.

title: IN A VAN POOL, THE CARES AND JOYS
description: GARY DRISCOLL, a sales supervisor with the Great Northern Paper Company in Stamford, swung a shiny blue and gray 18 seat Metropool commuter van into the empty Bradlee's parking lot one recent Monday morning, halting not far from an abandoned shopping cart.

title: A PUNT, A PASS AND WALKER, TOO
description: IF YOU haven't heard of Herschel Walker by now, it doesn't mean you're a hermit; it only means your cave is a little off the beaten path.

title: Christmas Past Is Retired
description: Christmas Past, who was the champion 3-year-old filly of 1982 and defeated males in the Gulfstream Park Handicap a week ago, has been retired.

title: AQUEDUCT SIMULCASTS TO VEGAS
description: In a surprise move, the New York Racing Association yesterday began televising its racing program at Aqueduct simultaneously via satellite to Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev.

title:
GARDENING;
SPRING BECKONS AT FLOWER SHOW
description: SEVERAL hundred alumni and backers of the Farmingdale College Foundation declared their readiness for spring by supporting a $100-a-plate black-tie ''Swing Into Spring Ball'' last Friday evening at the Farmingdale campus of the State University of New York. The ball was scheduled as a kickoff to the 1983 Long Island Spring Flower Show, now under way at the George E. Nold Exhibit Hall on the campus.

title: Faint Signs Of Progress In Lebanon
description: In the Middle East, any small stirrings in the diplomatic logjam look like progress. Last week, special United States envoy Philip C. Habib got a cold reception from Israel for some compromises to unjam the negotiations over withdrawal of Israeli forces from Lebanon. But after the 20th session of the talks, the Lebanese reported what looked like an easing of Israel's insistence on manning five permanent outposts in southern Lebanon.

title: PROBLEMS PERSIST FOR ONCE-POTENT REDS
description: After losing 101 games last season, the Cincinnati Reds can look forward to these developments this spring: Johnny Bench is still playing out of position at third base. Cesar Cedeno is switching out of position to right field. Tom Hume, the best relief pitcher, is coming back from knee surgery. Charlie Puleo, acquired from the Mets for Tom Seaver, just had knee surgery. Alex Trevino, the catcher, has trouble throwing out runners.

title: MANAMA, Bahrain
description: THE foreign banks that have flocked to this tiny island-state off the Saudi Arabian coast in the past few years may soon have to start working harder for their money.

title: THE TOLL CONDITIONING CAN TAKE ON ATHLETES
description: IN May 1981, at the age of 17, Mary Wazeter finished eighth in the L 'eggs mini-marathon in New York, beating some of the world's best w omen road racers. That summer, she won the women's division of the P epsi 10-kilometer race over the George Washington Bridge and set a n ational age-group record for a half-marathon. She then enrolled at G eorgetown University with an athletic grant-in-aid.

title: IN WHATEVER FORM, THEATER'S THE THING
description: ''I think I've been one of the luckiest humans alive,'' said Arthur Whitelaw. ''Everything I've dreamt I'd do, I did.'' And when Mr. Whitelaw, who grew up in Roslyn, turns 43 tomorrow, there will be a lot for him to look back on. The the dreams he realized - and is still realizing - are concerned with show business.

title: Added Safety Checks Set for Grain Elevators
description: The Reagan Administration says it is stepping up inspections of grain elevators while continuing work on new safety standards to cut the risk of death from fires and explosions.

title: Susan L. Somekh Becomes Engaged
description: Saida Somekh of Forest Hills, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Susan Linda Somekh, to Charles Norman Lipton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey L. Lipton of East Rockaway, Queens. A June 12 wedding is planned.

title: Boston College Gets Share of Title
description: John Garris and Michael Adams scored 20 points apiece to lead Boston College to an 81-66 victory over Providence tonight for a share of the Big East Conference regular-season title.

title: 'LEMON LAW' AIDS A RETIRED COUPLE
description: EVERY new-car owner takes the automobile for a leisurely spin or two to work out the kinks, but for Chester and Ann Sobolewski, their test runs this week had special meaning.

title: IN ONTARIO'S VACATIONLAND
description: Spring comes late in Canada. The calendar says it starts on March 21, like everywhere else, but that's an illusion. The most enjoyable part of spring in Ontario, for example, is from the third or fourth week in May through the summer solstice of June 21. It is traditional among Canadians to open their summer cottages on the first holiday of the vacation season, Victoria Day, which used to fall on May 24 but now falls on the Monday on or before May 24. That's when Canadians, like Americans on the Fourth of July, set off skyrockets and Roman candles.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES SOME CHARGES IN COAST SLAVE CASE
description: A Federal District judge has dismissed most of the slavery charges against 10 people accused by the Government of forcing indigent Indonesians to work as domestic servants.

title: 'LET'S': A CONTRACTION OF TERMS
description: ''LET'S have breakfast together this morning,'' I suggested. A novel idea, instead of the usual lunch out. I could already taste the bacon and eggs made at the nearby diner. In her mind, she could already taste the croissant.

title: BOSTON 'LAYOFFS' LAID TO FAILURE TO GIVE TO MAYOR
description: Edwin F. Colby has been out of work for over two years now, an unemployed engineer at the age of 57, and it is hurting financially. He has had to dip into his savings account and he has borrowed on his life insurance.

title: Allen's Arm Passes First Test
description: In his first test of the Mets' most important sore elbow of 1982, Neil Allen zipped through two perfect innings in a camp game today and reported no pain.

title: A BAILOUT PLAN FOR THE BANKS
description: TELEGRAMS go out to banks around the world. Another country cannot pay its debts. What is to be done? The banks and the country's government start out on a well-worn path. The bankers get together to add up the country's debts. The government seeks help from the International Monetary Fund. The I.M.F. sends out a mission.

title: POLAND'S ABUNDANCE OF SCARCITY
description: CASTING about for a way out of Poland's desperate economic crisis, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski and his aides came up with ''Socialist renewal,'' a program of reform that was supposed to revitalize the Communist system by giving more decision-making power to local factory managers and - perhaps some day - even to workers' councils.

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK URGES U.S. TO ADOPT LATIN MARSHALL PLAN
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that Washington should initiate a major economic aid program for Central America similar to the Marshall Plan in Europe after World War II.

title: PAINTING A BETTER PICTURE OF ART
description: ALMOST any child at Yonkers Public School 26 can tell you where it was that cats wore earrings and fashionable women shaved their heads and adorned themselves with perfumed wigs. As the children in this school well know, these strange descriptions fit conditions in ancient Egypt.

title: Armuth To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Armuth of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Lynn Armuth, to Neal Wolkoff, son of Martin Wolkoff of Massapequa, L.I., and the late Evelyn Wolkoff.

title: CHANGING THE RULES IN SUFFOLK LEGISLATURE
description: Mr. Prospect's diatribe highlights two crucial questions: Why do we have a Suffolk County Legislature? How do its current members stay in office, notwithstanding the abuses they impose on county residents?

title: CONCERTS BY ARTISTS OF FAME AND FUTURE
description: MORE and more performers are including Connecticut cities among their ports of call: the French organist Marie-Claire Alain, for instance, will give a free recital (her only one this season in New England) this afternoon at 4 at New Britain's South Congregational-First Baptist Church, while London's Academy of St. Martin in the Fields ensemble visits Woolsey Hall in New Haven on March 16 at 8 P.M. (call 776-1444 for ticket information).

title: AN EXPLORER CHARTS THE PASSAGES OF THE EXECUTIVE MIND
description: SEVERAL times a week for two years, Abraham Zaleznik, a Harvard business school professor and practicing psychoanalyst, was welcomed by the chairman of a major American corporation in its plush offices a top one of Boston's skyscrapers. Commissioned to write a biography of the executive, Mr. Zaleznik would settle into an easy chair and start his tape recorder, and the businessman would talk of his ambitions and emotions, of projects he had championed and of his plans.

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;
MILAN
description: Milan has all the trappings of being one of the world's wealthiest cities. In the shopping area cloistered between the via della Spiga and the via Montenapoleone are boutique after boutique with instantly recognizable fashion names - Gucci, Missoni, Armani, Versace, Fendi, Valentino, Krizia, almost all of them flanked by expensive jewelers.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: A MAJOR confrontation has developed between business interests and an ad hoc coalition of environmentalists, labor unions, community groups and firefighters over a bill to give workers and local residents the right to know what hazardous chemicals are stored or used in a place of business.

title: U.A.W.'S DEPARTING CHIEF TO STAY ON CHRYSLER BOARD
description: Douglas A. Fraser said today that he would remain a director of the Chrysler Corporation after he retires as president of the United Automobile Workers in May.

title: PASIDOMO DISCUSSES NEW ALBANY POST
description: JOHN PASSIDOMO, the Supervisor/Mayor of Harrison, is going to Albany, but not for the job he sought. ''Soon after the November election I sent Governor Cuomo a resume,'' he said, ''for Commissioner of Taxation and Finance.'' Last week, he was appointed Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.

title: FRENCH LEFT EXPECTS LOSSES IN THE MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS TODAY
description: France votes in municipal elections on Sunday, with Socialist leaders conceding that their candidates will suffer losses in the first nationwide balloting since Francois Mitterrand became President in 1981.

title: REPEAL: A BIG STEP TOWARD RECOVERY
description: OUT there in the fog of current Administration tax policy looms the $90 billion that the Government will sacrifice because of tax indexing. Of all the obstacles in the path of steady economic recovery, none is so menacing - nor so seductive.

title: A NOSTALGIC END FOR DALY'S SALOON
description: ONE last round of drinks will be poured at the long, amhogany bar of Daly's Dandelion Saturday at noon, and when the glasses are empty, the fixtures and furnishings of the well-known New York City saloon will be auctioned off. The view outside, however, will not be of the corner of Third Avenue and 61st Street, but of the Berkshire foothills near the home of the former owners of Daly's, the musician Skitch Henderson and his wife, Ruth.

title: WATSON BOWS OUT AS BOWDOIN COACH
description: The final game of Sid Watson's college hockey coaching career was a 14-9 playoff loss to Holy Cross last Saturday. It wasn't a happy end to 24 years of directing a team from Bowdoin College, but Watson had to smile at the irony of the score. It sounded more like a football result, and football was the sport that brought Watson to Brunswick, Me., in the first place.

title:
DINING OUT;
AMONG COUNTY'S PRETTIEST SPOTS
description: SASSAFRAS is a pretty place and a popular one. Of an evening, both bar and dining areas are jammed. Most diners do not seem to mind the crush at the bar or the wait for food that often looks better than it tastes. Reservations are taken only for dinner groups of six or more, annoying for those who would like the assurance that dinner will be over within a reasonable time.

title: College Board Will End Nine Tests in New York
description: The College Board has announced that because of New York State's ''truth in testing law,'' it is withdrawing nine achievement tests taken by the state's high school students for admissions and placement purposes at colleges and universities.

title: Queens District Stays Democratic
description: ''We can't afford a liberal Democrat representing your community,'' President Reagan wrote to Republicans in the Seventh Congressional District in Queens. But the community, or at least a surprisingly large portion of it, decided last week that it couldn't afford to be without one.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As long as the Government in El Salvador can sustain its own internal divisions, and and as long as the levels of our military assistance are comparable to what we've been providing, there isn't any danger of losing the war.'' - Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, United States delegate to the United Nations. (11:1.)

title: FORDHAM DEFEATS IONA IN FINAL
description: Mark Murphy's 22-foot jumper at the buzzer gave Fordham a 54-53 victory over Iona and the championship of the Metro Atlantic Conference today at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: STORES SHARPEN UP FOR SHARPER BUYERS
description: THE buying habits of Long Island consumers are changing, and so are the major stores they shop in, where retailers hope to offer value and style as well as entertainment.

title: M.T.A. Chief Wants a New Way to Pay
description: The token may have taken its toll long enough. Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said last week that replacing the coins used on city subways and buses with magnetic cards would be his ''highest priority.''

title: LEGAL PLOYS, LITTLE PROGRESS IN ROCKLAND
description: ''WE made an agreement with the Federal people - an understanding, really,'' said Kenneth Gribetz, the Rockland County District Attorney who is in charge of the state's Brink's investigation. ''The people apprehended at the scene and the evidence gathered there were ours. Our case is totally independent of the one developed by the Federal Government.''

title: Gerard Weerts Is Married To Martha B. MacDonald
description: Martha Bernice MacDonald, daughter of Mrs. Royal B. MacDonald of Bridgeport, Conn., was married yesterday in Southport, Conn., to Gerard Jean-Marie Fernand Weerts, son of Dr. and Mrs. Fernand Weerts of Eupen, Belgium.

title: CONCERT: ALMAAS AT FOLK CITY
description: Grinning all the way, Beat Rodeo played an exuberant set of pop songs Wednesday at Folk City. The quartet's tunes, written and sung by the guitarist Steve Almaas, stick to pop's most venerable topic - falling in and out of love - while living up to pop's most stringent standards.

title: New Oil Taxes Owed to Future Generations
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: A CHAIN OF VOICES. By Andre Brink. (Penguin, $5.95.) This engrossing novel by a South African writer, which portrays an early 19th-century slave revolt in the rugged country northeast of Capetown, illuminates the present and the past. As the characters' voices combine to tell the story, the book explores ''the fullest meaning of slaveholding as a social and human phenomenon,'' Julian Moynahan said in his enthusiastic review. Andre Brink, he added, has devised a narrative method that ''works brilliantly most of the time.''

title: ON THE SOCIAL SECURITY EXPRESS
description: SELDOM does major legislation skid through Congress as swiftly as the Social Security financing package is doing. In only a month, Congressional panels have heard scores of witnesses, fashioned a bill, reported it out of a subcommittee and the House Ways and Means Committee and readied it for expected approval on the House floor this week - with the recommendations of the bipartisan National Commission on Social Security Reform virtually intact.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 23 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction.

title: GREECE REFUSES TO JOIN IN NATO MANEUVERS
description: Since last month the military chiefs of staff of most member countries of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have been exchanging messages on how to deal with a hypothetical threat to the alliance. But Greece has refused to join in this exercise as part of its continuing dispute with Turkey over the Aegean Sea area.

title: Conner Falters In Trials
description: The rise of American skill in international gymnastics competition was vividly demonstrated yesterday at the opening day of the eighth annual McDonald's American Cup competition at Madison Square Garden.

title: A Correction
description: An article on selections to the Basketball Hall of Fame that appeared on Feb. 20 gave two names incorrectly. Lloyd Leith, a coach and official, and Lou Wilke, an administrator, were elected to the hall.

title: Miss Mars and Lawyer Are Wed in New York
description: Sallie Mars, daughter of Daniel Mars of New York and Emma Mars of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Galperin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Galperin of Wilmington, Del. Rabbi Shlomo Riskin performed the ceremony at the Lincoln Square Synagogue, which was founded by the bride's father.

title: It's 'Wait and See' for Clark In His Battle With Pneumonia
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark, the artificial heart recipient, was reported in fair condition today with aspiration pneumonia he developed from problems with breathing and his stomach.

title: FLORIDA JOINS STATES RAISING TAXES ON MOTOR FUELS
description: State and local sales taxes on gasoline and other motor fuels sold in Florida could rise by almost 6 cents a gallon by fall to a total of about 13.7 cents a gallon under legislation adopted by state lawmakers.

title: Maureen Flahive Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Flahive of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maureen Mary Flahive, to Lieut. John Harold McGee, U.S.A. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold McGee of Chatham, N.J. A fall wedding is planned. Lieutenant McGee, a graduate of the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., is stationed at Fort Rucker, Ala.

title: No Headline
description: Didi Moore overlooked what may be the greatest single shortcoming in the care of frail and impaired older Americans - mental and emotional health care.

title: DANCE: ATMA GROUP AT RIVERSIDE THEATER
description: There were interesting and mysterious things about Thursday night's performance by the ATMA Dance Collective at the Theater of the Riverside Church. But most of those things had more to do with the overall conceptions of the works presented than with their actual choreography.

title: SATING HUNGER IN COUNTY'S BACKYARD
description: A FOOD distribution center in affluent Bergen County, N.J. A soup kitchen in equally affluent Westport, Conn. In New York City, the City Council President, Carol Bellamy, investigates the possibility of broader food services. Here, too, in Westchester, there is clear evidence that people are going hungry. One response was the establishment of the Cortlandt Emergency Food Bank.

title:
DINING OUT;
THE ITALIAN ROSTER KEEPS GROWING
description: ANOTHER chic and promising new Italian restaurant has just opened in the state. This one, Repetti's, is in the Union County community of Kenilworth, and its attractive decor and reasonable prices make it an appealing addition to the growing roster.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;
description: Jim Clancy, the Toronto Blue Jays right-hander who led the American League in starts with 40 in pitching 266 innings and compiling a 16-14 record last season, has signed a four-year contract believed to be worth $3 million. The 27-year-old Clancy, originally acquired from the Texas Rangers in the 1976 expansion draft, has a career record of 51-70.

title: Villanova Strong in IC4A
description: Mike England, limping with pain over the final 30 yards, easily won his semifinal heat in the 1,000-meter run this afternoon and helped to place Villanova in a commanding position to win the 62d IC4A indoor track and field meet.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY EXPECTS SMALLEST BENEFIT RISE
description: The 1983 cost-of-living increase in Social Security benefits for nearly 36 million people is likely to be 3.4 percent, the smallest rise on record, according to authoritative estimates.

title: KNICKS SURPRISE CELTICS
description: After the Knicks compiled a 14-4 record in the last six weeks, mostly against a series of teams with sub-.500 records, the question was how effective would they be in March when the schedule included games against the league's better teams.

title: Noncoercive Action On Car Safety Favored
description: We have been pleased to hear of Dr. Leonard Krassner's overwhelming concern for the safety of young children while riding in automobiles (''Buckle-Up Law for Youngsters Needs Support,'' Jan. 23). He is, in fact, pediatrician to our two children, who ride in safety seats all the time. However, we are deeply concerned with the moral and legal aspects of the legislation recently passed criminalizing the act of not having children aged 4 and under restrained. This legislation refutes our legal guarantee that all are assumed innocent until proved guilty; and further, it will not work since it does not address the entire scope of the problem.

title: SICK, SICK
description: When I read for relaxation, I relish suspense, drama, mystery and thrills as much as anyone else, but don't give me John le Carre or Ross Macdonald. The fixture on my night table is a fat book - covered in brown simulated leather -that, possessing neither plot nor characters, for sheer mesmeric power puts these authors to shame. It's ''The Merck Manual of Diagnosis and Therapy'' (14th edition, 1982, edited by Robert Berkow, M.D.), printed on 2,578 pages of tissue-thin Bible paper and known simply as ''Merck'' to me and other card-carrying hypochondriacs.

title: A THRILLER IN FRENCH
description: ''Choice of Arms,'' which opens today at the Embassy 72d Street Theater, is yet another lethargic, pretentious policer by Alain Corneau, the French director (''Serie Noire,'' ''The Case Against Ferro'') who claims to have been most influenced by Howard Hawks. That claim amounts to slander.

title: BUSES AND SUBWAYS ARE BASIS OF METRO-NORTH'S STRIKE PLANS
description: In preparation for a strike on the Metro-North rail lines, threatened for 12:01 A.M. Monday, officials have set up special bus service between some, but not all, train stations and New York City. Metro-North commuter passes will not be honored on the buses. Some buses will travel to Manhattan and others will connect with subway lines in the Bronx. In addition, Westchester County has designated temporary car-pool staging areas. These are details of the preparations:

title: STATIC BREAKS IN ON REAGAN'S GOOD NEWS
description: It should have been one of Ronald Reagan's best weeks. The stock market closed at new highs amid spreading euphoria that economic recovery had begun at last. On Capitol Hill, the bipartisan Social Security rescue package easily cleared its first tests, and it appeared that a nasty confrontation over jobs and aid for hardpressed families would be avoided.

title: WORTHY SCORES 28
description: James Worthy scored a personal season-high 28 points, and Jamaal Wilkes got 26 tonight to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 122-108 victory over the Detroit Pistons.

title: A Threat to Free Agency
description: The National Basketball Association said yesterday that it would attempt to delay the rights of players to become free agents if the players go on strike, as threatened, April 2.

title: Gail E. Brandstatter to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Brandstatter Jr. of Mountainside, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail Eleanor Brandstatter, to Craig Alan Cope, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephan Cope of Springfield, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

title: Karen Kapel Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Karen Lynn Kapel to David Isaac Astrachan has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Saul Kapel of Scarsdale, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Boris Astrachan of Hamden, Conn.

title: WAR ON CHEATS USING CONNECTICUT TOKENS WANES IN THE COURTS
description: The war against commuters who used Connecticut's 17 1/2-cent turnpike tokens for 75-cent New York City subway rides began last November with well-publicized arrests and threats of serious punishment, but it has quietly foundered in court.

title: DANCE: BOWERY PROJECT
description: According to a hit song of 1891, ''They say such things, and they do strange things on the Bowery.'' The dancers didn't say anything at 133 Bowery on Tuesday night, but they certainly did strange things in two solos that were presented as part of the Bowery Project's series of music and dance events.

title: Susan H. MacColl To Marry Sept. 10
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman Alexander MacColl Jr. of West Hartford, Conn., and Wianno, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan Herron MacColl, to Kenneth Buckley Walker, son of Mrs. Thomas Riggs Cox Jr. of Bloomfield, Conn., and the late Paul Frederick Walker. The wedding is planned for Sept. 10.

title: Tolentine Is Surprised By McClancy, 70-67
description: Tolentine, the three-time Catholic High Schools Athletic Association champion, was upset, 70-67, by McClancy High School of Queens yesterday in the quarterfinal round of the playoffs at Manhattan College's Draddy gymnasium.

title: A NOVEL DESIGN FOR FAIR LAWN OFFICES
description: Ordinarily, an empty school building in sound condition in an area zoned for business would be eagerly sought by developers. But for 10 years, no one could see a way around the architectural and design problems presented by the vacant convent and school annex of St. Anne's Parish in Fair Lawn, N.J.

title: EXPATRIATES AND IMMIGRANTS
description: STAND WE AT LAST By Zoe Fairbairns. 609 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $15.95. ELLIS ISLAND By Fred Mustard Stewart. 396 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $15.95. NILE By Laurie Devine. 476 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: THE NEW MONEY MAKERS AT HEARST
description: IN the 1920's, William Randolph Hearst was convinced that a bridge w ould be built across the Hudson River near 57th Street. So positive w as he that this would increase land values near Columbus Circle thath e bought a great deal of neighboring property, setting aside one p lot for a building to house some of his thriving publications.

title: HOW TO GET TAX BREAKS ON RENTALS
description: MANY people who are not professional landlords earned income from a p iece of residential property for the first time last year and now a re wondering how to handle their tax liabilities on that income.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Gasoline stations have become something of an endangered species. Many were forced out of business as prices soared and gasoline supplies dried up. But lower prices and a glut of crude oil will not bring them back. Instead, their number is likely to shrink still further.

title: Everyone Benefits From Auto Inspections
description: This is in response to an article by Lori Dillman that appeared on the Opinion Page on Feb. 6 (''Emission Inspections: What's Next?''). I sympathize with Ms. Dillman's position. As a conscientious citizen who keeps her car in proper running condition she resents having to prove that fact at a state inspection station.

title: ARGENTINA PRESSED TO INVESTIGATE UNMARKED GRAVES
description: Several Argentine human rights groups and opposition political leaders are demanding swifter and more open action by the courts in investigating the 1,500 unmarked graves that were uncovered last October.

title: Data Update
description: * Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffex, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic. ** Comparable data unavailable because method of computing homewonership costs has changed.

title: CHANGING THE RULES IN SUFFOLK LEGISLATURE
description: In response to ''Putting a Stranglehold on Suffolk County Legislation,'' I'd like to say that the rule changes in the Suffolk County Legislature that will give a few legislators veto power over proposed bills by the use of stacked committees are both unadvisable and unnecessary. However, I will take the argument put forth in the article one step further and venture a guess at the motives of the Presiding Officer and the Republican majority.

title: CONDOMINIUMS: WHO'S BUYING?
description: TWO years ago, when Harvey and Joyce Gladstein had three small children, they lived in a two-bedroom rental apartment. Later, they acquired a four-bedroom house in Brooklyn, and when the children grew up, the Gladsteins soldt heir house for so much money that Mrs. Gladstein said she felt like J esse James. Now, once again, they are living in a two-bedroom a partment. This time, however, it is a condominium on East 49th S treet worth almost $400,000. If the kids come to visit, they go to ah otel.

title: Healing a Split In North Africa
description: Seven years ago, Morocco broke diplomatic relations with Algeria over its support for the Polisario's war of independence in the Western Sahara, which Morocco won from Spain in 1975. Last weekend, the two North African neighbors met for the first time since their split to discuss a solution to a conflict that has brought them almost to blows and bedeviled African relations in general.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MARCH 6, 1983
description: International

title: A FRESH PATH IN DESIGN LEADS TO FIDELITY WITHOUT FUSS
description: Evolution tends toward ever greater complexity, and the question is when you hit the limit and head for extinction. Sobering thoughts of this sort have inspired a new tack in audio design conceived as an antidote to complexity by an offbeat company called Meridian.

title: Masters Invites Aoki, 41
description: Among the 15 foreign golfers invited to the Masters tournament is Isao Aoki, the first Japanese to win on the United States tour. Aoki, 41, has played in eight previous Masters.

title: WHERE'S THE LEGISLATION TO HELP COMBAT VIOLENT CRIME?
description: VIOLENT crime continues to spill over into Nassau County at an ever-increasing rate. The atrocities last year at the Sea Crest Diner in Old Westbury and the brutal robbery and murder of Leon Stern, an attorney, at his home in Roslyn Harbor are some of the most publicized incidents of terror in our county.

title: PRO FOOTBALL IN THE SPRING: THE TIME IS NOW
description: This preview of the United States Football League season was prepared and written by William N. Wallace. THE United States Football League, a concept that first came to the mind of David F. Dixon, a New Orleans sports promoter and a former plywood manufacturer, 18 years ago, begins its first season today with games at Denver; Los Angeles; Tampa, Fla.; Tempe, Ariz., and Washington. A sixth game will be tomorrow night at Birmingham, Ala.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: BARGAIN FARES ON THE HORIZON
description: Lower trans-Atlantic air fares and such enticements as tourist menus tailored to the needs of budget-conscious travelers are among the lures designed to convince increasing numbers of Americans that they should visit Europe next summer.

title: AT THE U.N., LABOR STRIFE SETTLES DOWN
description: On his first day in office in January 1982, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar had lunch with Susanna H. Johnston, president of the Staff Committee, which is the nearest thing to a labor union the 5,400 workers here have.

title: BIAS CASE AGAINST ASIANS PROVES COSTLY FOR RICHMOND CONCERN
description: A local real estate company has agreed to pay $67,357 after a Federal jury found it had discriminated against prospective tenants at an apartment complex because they were Asian.

title:
CASE FOR AND AGAINST N.F.L. ANTITRUST EXEMPTION;
IT THREATENS FREE ENTERPRISE
description: INITIALLY, Al Davis was reluctant to hire a Washington lobbyist because he could not believe that the United State Congress might pass a bill such as the Sports Community Protection Act of 1982 that would nullify retroactively a jury decision in Federal Court after two and a half years of legal fights.

title: Data Bank; March 6, 1983
Marcia P. LaPidus to Wed Jay Ross Zaretsky, Student
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. LaPidus of Baldwin Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marcia Pat LaPidus, to Jay Ross Zaretsky, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Zaretsky of Saddle River, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN PARIS
description: After enduring a cooler than normal winter, when almost daily snow flurries replaced the endless Feburary showers, Parisians are in the mood for spring. By mid-February, when temperatures still refused to rise above freezing, the city's cafe tables were already out on the sidewalks, and Parisians had begun the spring and summer ritual of cafe sitting.

title: 10,000 Meters to Salazar
description: Alberto Salazar broke free of Michael Musyoki of Kenya in the final mile and a half today and went on to set an American record of 28 minutes 1 second in a 10,000-meter run.

title: WHY ARE WE IN VIETNAM?
description: Two U.S. officials were explaining why the Reagan Administration had pressed the Government of El Salvador to hold an early election.

title: Changing the Rules In Suffolk Legislature
description: Legislator Wayne Prospect's article ''Putting a Stranglehold On Suffolk County Legislation'' (Opinion Page, Feb. 6) was both accurate and frightening.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES POPULAR SONG
description: One way for a performing artist to become a legend is to be reclusive and elusive - and, of course, to have talent. It might be called the Greta Garbo Syndrome although Anita Ellis would be more deserving of the identifying connection.

title: Cystic Fibrosis And a New Era of Genetic Testing
description: Medical testing for genetic defects was once reserved to the unfortunate few - ethnic and racial populations or families - plagued by heritable diseases. In its report to Congress last week, however, a Presidential commission envisioned genetic screening for the many with profound ethical implications for all.

title: WHY ST. MARTIN'S HAS ENDURED
description: For reasons no one can quite explain, it was not until 1980 that the Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields made its first appearance in the United States. This leading British chamber orchestra had been around for 21 years; its records were among the top sellers, and their sound was so well known on radio stations that Stereo Review once ran a cartoon in which a radio announcer was saying, '' . . . played now by the Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields . . . '' and a parrot in the room added, with a glazed look in its eyes, ''Neville Marriner conducting''.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE DELAY FORCES NASA TO SET AN AFTERNOON LIFTOFF
description: The delays caused by engine problems aboard the space shuttle Challenger have forced NASA to overhaul the schedule for the ship's maiden flight, mandating the shuttle program's first afternoon liftoff.

title: MERRYL BECKER BETHROTHED TO PETER ALAN MANDLER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Becker of Greenlawn, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Merryl Aleen Becker, to Peter Alan Mandler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Mandler of Williston Park, L.I.

title: AIR CRASH LIABILITY: MONTREAL PROTOCOLS GOOD FOR AMERICANS
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS STRUGGLES TO RAISE ITS PRICES
description: Even Alcoa, the world's largest producer of aluminum, has been powerless to dictate its own prices, let alone raise them. With demand cut by the recession, Alcoa could not find any takers when it offered raw ingots last year at 76 cents a pound. Buyers were finally enticed to ante up only after Alcoa offered discounts of nearly 40 percent. ''The most frustrating thing,'' sighed one Alcoa vice president, ''is how far prices have come unglued in the last two years.''

title: JAZZ
description: Trumpeters and trombonists are in the spotlight this week at Sweet Basil, the jazz club and restaurant at 88 Seventh Avenue South (242-1785). The trumpeter Johnny Coles, who is leading a sextet Tuesday through Saturday, is a resourceful, heartfelt, sometimes mournful, but always lyrical improviser.

title: Stopping Bullets
description: After his butcher shop in Brooklyn was robbed four times in one month, William Levine bought a bulletproof vest in 1980. Other business proprietors who shared his anxiety about crime asked him where they could get a vest like his. Mr. Levine began taking orders as a sideline.

title: PICKING STOCKS ON LOWER OIL PRICES
description: WHENEVER corporate profitability stands to gain from a major economic development, investors rush in and bid up the shares of the obvious beneficiaries. Such is the case with the break in oil p ricing. The cuts thus far as well as those yet to come have propelled upward the stocks of airline, paper and chemical companies, all of which consume enormous amounts of petroleum products.

title: RONALD RIBMAN WRITES OF A VIOLENT WORLD
description: A young woman picks up a college professor in a bar and brings him home for the night; after taking her to bed, he stabs her in the heart with a knitting needle. A derelict peacefully curled up on the street with his bottle of wine is accosted by a hostile young man carrying a radio; as a blood offering to a woman he covets, the young man slashes the derelict's throat.

title: NONPROFIT GROUP GOES INTO BUSINESS
description: Confronted with a $5 million cut in Federal grants to help New York's jobless, the 49-year-old Federation Employment and Guidance Services says it considered scaling back its program drastically.

title: HALDEMAN CLAIM IS REJECTED
description: -A Federal district judge has rejected H.R. Haldeman's contention that the Government owned him monetary damages for seven years that officials held his personal diary. Judge John Garrett Penn ruled that Mr. Haldeman, White House chief of staff under President Nixon, could have copied the material before the Government took it after his resignation in April 1973.

title: 'JERSEY WOMAN': HOW IT GREW
description: PROFESSIONAL distributors wouldn't touch a new, untried magazine, so the first issue - 24 pages with a black-and-white cover - was distributed by friends and family to local convenience stores and newsstands.

title: H.L. WELDON ENGAGED TO JUDITH B. DE BARANY
description: Dr. and Mrs. Cornelius de Barany of Madrid have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Barbara de Barany, to Henry Lorimer Weldon, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lorimer Weldon of New York.

title: A SLIP IN ALBANY HURTS LANDLORDS
description: A mistake made last year when the State Legislature revised laws g overning cooperative and condominium conversions has barred New Y ork City landlords who want apartments for their personal use from e victing rent-stabilized tenants.

title: PAROLE DENIED MAN IN ESCAPE BID
description: The United States Parole Commission has denied the parole application of a man convicted of air piracy and kidnapping in a 1981 attempt to free an inmate by helicopter from a Federal jail in lower Manhattan.

title: JAILER DESCRIBES ATLANTA KILLER'S YEAR IN JAIL
description: Wayne B. Williams, 15 pounds heavier and a ''little impatient,'' spends his days writing, reading and watching television in the isolation cell where he has lived since the Atlanta police proclaimed him a mass murderer a year ago.

title: RECORD CASINO FINE SEEN AS A WARNING
description: ALTHOUGH refusing to acknowledge that it has done so, Caesars Boardwalk Regency has quietly paid the largest fine ever assessed against a hotel-casino here, $257,000. It was levied by the state's Casino Control Commission on Jan. 4 for ''deliberate'' violations of gaming regulations.

title: Belgians in Debut
description: I Fiamminghi, the Belgian Chamber Orchestra, will make its New Yor debut at 2 P.M. today at Town Hall, presented by Peoples' Symphony Concerts. The 11-member orchestra, directed by Rudolf Werthen, will perform Britten's ''Simple Symphony for Strings,'' Bach's Concerto for Violin in D minor (BWV 1052), Haydn's Concerto for Violin in C, Rossini's Sonata a Quattro No. 1, and Bottesini's Grand Duo for Violin and Contrabass with Strings.

title: Deserting the Aged
description: Elderly people unable to care for themselves were being abandoned on Long Island in hospital emergency rooms. Social work officials at the hospitals said in November 1981 that families that had been caring for the abandoned simply felt unable physically and financially to continue.

title: MONEY, POWER AND THE FAMILY BUDGET
description: Like her colleague at Stanford, a Northwestern University sociologist discovered that money often equals power in a dual-career marriage.

title: Argentina Sets An Election Date
description: Argentina's military rulers last week promised to return to the barracks in 11 months - if they are still around to order retreat. President Reynaldo Bignone said the junta had agreed to let civilians hold elections on Oct. 30 for a President and national Congress that would take power at the end of January 1984.

title: THE PERILS OF NOVELTY
description: It is commonly accepted that a new move in the opening, even if only a modest departure from well-grooved lines of play, often reaps rewards far beyond its objective merits.

title: CRUISE LOG: THE NEW TRENDS
description: For the traveler whose idea of a vacation begins with a gangplank leading to a ship gently pulling at anchor, the range of choices and incentives is satisfyingly wide these days. And for those whose destination is Europe - and who prefer not to cope with jet lag and rumpled clothing - the lure of the sea remains strong.

title: Plastic Keys To Freedom
description: In addition to accepting bargains on pleas, New York City courts will soon be offering easier terms on bail. Last week the Committee on Jail Overcrowding proposed - and the city accepted - a plan to release suspects who put down as little as 10 percent, and allow them to pay with personal checks or credit cards.

title: COPING WITH DOCTORS' STRESS
description: SUSAN WAGGENHEIM, a second year medical student at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, was beginning to wonder how she ''could live with the demands of the medical profession and live a fulfulling life outside of it.''

title: A RENAISSANCE MAN RETIRES
description: NEW JERSEY lost one of its finest public servants last week. Sidney Glaser, director of the state's Division of Taxation, retired after 36 years.

title: WHEN YOUR NEIGHBORS ARE ALSO YOUR TENANTS . . .
description: CENSUS BUREAU figures indicate that there are 2.25 million two family houses across the nation. These homes are increasingly attracting first-time house buyers as the only affordable ones because of the opportunity for a rental income to help offset high mortgage and maintenance costs.

title: Pupil's Cubicle Dismantled
description: A teacher who put a 7-year-old boy in a two-and-a-half-by-three-foot cubicle for four school days went too far in disciplining the youngster, but no action will be taken against her, according to Arthur Gaines, a deputy superintendent said. The makeshift cubicle in the corner of a second-grade classroom was dismantled Thursday after complaints from the boy's mother.

title: Rain Puts Off Golf
description: Wet grounds delayed resumption of the rain-delayed first round of the Samaritan Turquoise L.P.G.A. Classic today, and officials decided to cut the tournament from 72 holes to 54.

title: Dr. Pamela J. Murray To Marry in Summer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving Murray of East Meadow, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Pamela Jane Murray, to Dr. Christopher Max Horwitz, son of Nuri Mass of Summer Hill, New South Wales, Australia, and the late Sidney Horwitz.

title: M.T.A. AND UNION TO RESUME TALKS
description: Metro-North and its conductors and trainmen were scheduled to resume negotiations this afternoon in a dispute over work rules that threatens to halt train service tomorrow morning for 90,000 commuters from New York City's northern suburbs and southwestern Connecticut.

title: SUFFOLK CELEBRATING A BANNER YEAR - ITS 300TH
description: DAVID AMRAM has composed an overture glorifying it. The residents of Centereach are making a quilt to comemmorate it. Fourth graders in Brentwood are daily writing paragraphs about it and then reading them over the public address system.

title: GUNTER GRASS AS PRINTMAKER, POET, STORYTELLER AND FABULIST
description: In the drawings and lithographs of the German novelist Gunter Grass, which can be seen Thursday through March 31 at the Weyhe Gallery, 794 Lexington Avenue at 61st Street, there is continued an ancestral German tradition - that of the black mark on white paper as one of the most versatile of all modes of expression.

title: Miss Nolan to Marry Mark I. Curran
description: Katherine Anne Nolan, an internal auditor at Bank Leumi in New York, and Mark I. Curran, a supervisor at the New York Commodities Exchange for Dean Witter Reynolds, plan to be married April 9 at St. Teresa of Avila Roman Catholic Church in Summit, N.J.

title: 27 YEARS OF TRAINING DOGS TO HELP THE BLIND
description: GUIDING Eyes for the Blind of Yorktown Heights has helped more than 2,500 people achieve greater mobility through the use of highly trained guide dogs. ''With a guide dog, the blind person receives more attention,'' said Geoff Lock, general manager of the nonprofit organization. ''If they are unaccompanied by sighted people, more courtesy is extended to them out of respect for the working relationship of the dog and human being.''

title: Sherod Santos to Receive Schwartz Poetry Prize
description: Sherod Santos has been named the fourth recipient of the $1,000 Delmore Schwartz Memorial Poetry Award.

title: British Ale
description: To the Editor:

title: Well-Tempered Tenors
description: In ''The Well-Tempered Tenor'' (Jan. 30), Bernard Holland zeroed in on the Pavarotti-Domingo rivalry.

title: PENTAGON DETAILS $7.8 BILLION AIR DEFENSE PLAN
description: The Pentagon is fleshing out a $7.8 billion plan to strengthen the nation's air defenses against what it regards as a looming threat from a new generation of long-range Soviet bombers.

title: DANCE: 'COMMONPLACES' BY DANIEL MCCUSKER
description: Daniel McCusker is one of the best modern dancers to be seen in New York today, a performer who cuts deftly into space, giving just the right emphasis to every phrase. Not all good dancers make good dances. But Mr. McCusker proved, on Wednesday at the Theater of the Riverside Church, that he is a choreographer of striking and original gifts.

title: Gromyko Sees Two Envoys
description: The envoys of Iraq and Iran met separately today with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko at their own request in what appeared to be a Soviet attempt to mediate in the war between the two countries. The Soviet Union and its East European allies have maintained a position of neutrality in the war.

title: AFTER 'CHARIOTS OF FIRE,' HE EXPLORES THE LEGEND OF 'TARZAN'
description: It was a very busy rain forest, packed with such exotic wildlife as pink flamingos, striped antelopes, and men shouting ''quiet, everyone,'' ''action'' and ''cut.'' In a clearing, a well-known British actor was patiently standing waist-deep in a rock pool. ''Five-twoseven take four,'' echoed through the steaming foliage, and Ian Holm proceeded yet again to soap his body, scrub his face and duck his head beneath the waterline, watched by a cooperative python and by a young man mimicking his actions from a nearby log. Mr. Holm is portraying a Belgian explorer in Africa; the young man, Christopher Lambert, is playing none other than Tarzan, the legendary ape man, whose story is once more headed for the screen.

title: Wild Horse Adoption Fee Cut
description: The Federal Government, seeking to reduce the number of wild horses on public lands and get more people to adopt them, is reducing the fee for the adoption to $125 from $200, effective Friday. The fee to adopt a wild burro remains $75. Applicants must show they have space to keep a horse, pasture to feed it or money to buy it hay, some experience in horse training and a horse trailer.

title: REAGAN, IN OREGON, FORECASTS POWERFUL ECONOMIC RECOVERY
description: President Reagan carried his message of America on the mend to the forested reaches of the badly depressed lumber industry today, predicting that the nation's economic recovery would be ''powerful and sustained.'' He told industry executives, ''the economy is revving up.''

title: JAMAICA'S RESORTS IN REVIVAL
description: When I first visited Jamaica in 1980 it was wonderful for bargainhunting vacationers: round-trip air travel from Chicago or New York to Montego Bay was less than $300; good seaside lodging for two could be had for $40 a night and fresh seafood, such as lobster or kingfish, cost less than the price of a hamburger at certain New York City hotel dining rooms.

title: 22 Food Outlets in City Cited For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Health Department cited 22 food establishments last week for violations of the city's health code.The department also named two restaurants that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations.

title: GENERALS ARE IN THE SPOTLIGHT AS NEW LEAGUE TAKES THE STAGE
description: ALTHOUGH comparing team speed in football is difficult, the New J ersey Generals would seem to be fast, beginning with Herschel Walkera t halfback. Chuck Fairbanks, the coach of the Generals, had quick t eams when he was coaching Oklahoma and later the New England P atriots. But Fairbanks, as are other coaches in the United States F ootball League, is not sure how good a team he has assembled for itsf irst game today against the Express in Los Angeles. ABC will t elevise the game beginning at 3 P.M.

title: HOW A SMALL FISH SURVIVES IN A BIG POND
description: Steering a Mediterranean ministate through the shoals of international diplomacy is never easy, as events of recent weeks in Malta again showed. Last month, two mutinous Libyan lieutenants hijacked a plane carrying 158 people and landed in Valetta. Prime Minister Dom Mintoff talked the officers into surrendering, but then he faced the choice of handing them to Col. Muammer el-Qaddafi for likely execution or releasing them and offending the Libyan leader. Last week, he was still thinking about it. On Malta, Libya is no joke.

title: No Headline
description: Indiana Defeats Illinois, 67-55

title: CONCERT: COMPOSERS' RETROSPECTIVE
description: The Fromm Music Foundation has been commissioning new pieces for exactly 30 years, and there was a retrospective celebration Friday night at Sotheby's on York Avenue. The event was a presentation of the Whitney Museum's Composers' showcase.

title: MENTAL CARE SHIFT IS URGED BY PANEL
description: A federally financed study by a committee of mental health experts has urged Governor Cuomo to close some New York State psychiatric hospitals. Local hospitals and community-based mental health centers, they say, should take over the care of the state's chronic mentally ill.

title: A FAMINE IS SAID TO THREATEN 300,000 IN CHAD
description: Hundreds of relief workers and dozens of medical teams are reported to have fanned out in this drought-stricken country to aid hundreds of thousands of people threatened with famine.

title: Princeton Clinches Ivy Title
description: Princeton clinched the Ivy League championship tonight with a 72-56 victory over Columbia at Jadwin Gym.

title: Selfish View Of Emissions Law
description: In response to the recent controversy over Connecticut's new emissions inspection law, and in particular to Lori Dillman's article on Feb. 6, I must express my dismay at the general selfishness and lack of concern shown by the residents of this state.

title: CAPTURING COUNTY'S LEGACY
description: HENRY BETJEMANN, a retired architectural designer, has spent more than 30 years sketching hundreds of Suffolk County scenes mainly nostalgic renderings of historical buildings, lighthouses, windmills and homes that show the character and beauty of the county as it was centuries ago. In honor of Suffolk's Tercentenary, he has contributed 27 of his prints to the county.

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN:;
WEST BRIGHTON
description: OFFICIALLY, West Brighton doesn't exist. That's all right with its residents, none of whom care if their corner of Staten Island is ever discovered.

title: PLAN TO CUT SCHOOL AID FOR THE AGED DRAWS PROTEST
description: APROPOSAL to cut state support for education for the elderly has drawn an avalanche of critical letters and telephone calls from legislators, educators, the aged and even the state's Division on Aging.

title: CONCERT: POP SONGS BY IGLESIAS
description: Julio Iglesias, the Spanish pop singer who is said to have sold 70 million albums worldwide, has begun a campaign to capture the non-Spanish-speaking American market. And at the first show of a fournight stand at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday, the suave 39-yearold singer, backed by a 40-piece orchestra, sang in five languages.

title: ROME: ARTICHOKES USHER OUT THE WINTER
description: Roan spring, whatever poets and travel brochures may say, is usually uncertain, fickle and brief. The winter rains drip on and on, punctuated by a few balmy days. Then, suddenly, the Eternal City's magnificent summer arrives. During those first hot days, Romans will again tell one another: ''We haven't had any spring this year.'' It may indeed be hard to know when the southern winter has ended, but a sure way to find out is to ask for ''carciofi romaneschi'' at the nearest trattoria. A glory of Italian cuisine, Roman artichokes are a certain harbinger of spring.

title: A 'BLACK SPOT' VOWS TO DEFY PRETORIA PLAN
description: Hilda Gamede, an 82-year-old widow, says that whenever she goes to collect her state pension, officials tell her to ''go and get married'' instead.

title: The 'Right' Rice Pudding
description: There was a very special recipe for English rice pudding on the food page of The New York Times Magazine recently (''The Starch of Life,'' by Craig Claiborne with Pierre Franey, Jan. 16). My mother, who died a few months ago at 88, made a delicious rice pudding which my family, especially my daughter, all loved.

title: 'Don Quixote'
description: To the Editor:

title: NEEDIEST CASES FUND ENDS WITH RECORD $1,886,50
description: With a record total of $1,886,500.24 in donations from a record high number of 13,236 donors, the 71st annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ended last Monday.

title: COUNTY PREPARES FOR SECOND DRILL AT INDIAN POINT
description: SOMETIME Wednesday there will be a system ''failure'' at Consolidated Edison's Indian Point 2 plant, signaling the start of the second full-scale test of emergency plans in Westchester and in neighboring Putnam, Orange and Rockland Counties to cope with an accidental radiation release.

title: A DYBBUK ON STAGE
description: HUNGRY HEARTS By Francine Prose. 213 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $12.95.

title: FOLK MUSIC: OSCAR BRAND
description: Oscar Brand, a veteran folk singer who has been a professional since 1945 - and who for seven years before that sang the militant songs of the moment for the pure pleasure of making a statement - is playing his first extended engagement in a nightclub in many, many years. He will be at the Cookery, University Place and Eighth Street, through the end of March.

title: CONSUMER RATES
U.S. Trails in Davis Cup, 2-1
description: The United States escaped elimination in the first round of the Davis Cup today when the doubles team of John McEnroe and Peter Fleming outlasted Guillermo Vilas and Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina, 2-6, 10-8, 6-1, 3-6, 6-3.

title: KOCH 207 LEADING BY SHOT
description: Only Friday night Ray Floyd, leading by three strokes, was saying, ''I see no way I'll come back tomorrow and not play well. There's nothing that's going to make my game leave me tonight.''

title: Man Sets Himself Afire To Protest Joblessness
description: An unemployed construction worker called a television camera crew to the town square here late Friday night and, in front of the cameras, set himself afire to protest unemployment in America.

title: Miss McLaughlin To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. David T. McLaughlin of Hanover, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Dean McLaughlin, to Joseph Phillip Jangro Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jangro of Wakefield, Mass. A June 25 wedding is planned.

title: Pursuing the Hare In Snowy Woods
description: TO some, the cry - drifting through a snow-draped hemlock forest - of a beagle on the spoor of a snowshoe rabbit is sweet music. From the first excited yelp when the dog comes across the faint scent and begins to unravel the direction in which the hare is moving, to his almost continuous song when the chase is truly under way, the hunter's excitement mounts.

title: BITTER PILL
description: THE PILL, JOHN ROCK, AND THE CHURCH The Biography of a Revolution. By Loretta McLaughlin. 243 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $15.95.

title: Future Events; Honors All Around
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Student Aid

title: Dubious Loyalties
description: Contempt

title: Infinity Braves Rocks and Is a Winner
description: Considering the plight of the first fleet in the Miami-Nassau race, it is remarkable there was a second. Only three of the 12 boats that started the 1934 race finished after easterly storms pushed up tumultuous seas in the Gulf Stream.

title: A WOMAN'S WORK IS NEVER DONE
description: Wenda Brewster-O'Reilly, a researcher at Stanford University's School of Education, wanted to observe dual-career marriages under what she considered the best of circumstances. Her purpose: to determine just how equal these husbands and wives were. Her finding: not very.

title: SALVADOR 'CRISIS' SHARPENS THE DEBATE OVER POLICY
description: WHATEVER their differences going in, Congressional leaders coming out of a White House briefing on El Salvador last week were uniformly grim. ''The President made it clear that there is a serious problem in the region, that the national interests of this country are deeply involved in the outcome of that struggle,'' said the Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr. And Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said the crisis extended beyond El Salvador; the guerrillas could threaten all of Central America and Mexico too.

title:
STAMPS;
BALLOONING DEPICTED ON NEW BLOCK OF FOUR
description: One of the most colorful issues of the year from the United States, a statement that can be made with certainty even though the year is still young, is a block of four for ballooning. The issue not only heralds ballooning as a sport, it also marks its place in history and its advances in science and space.

title: VARIABLE-RATE PREFERREDS-THE TALE OF A GOOD IDEA THAT WAS CRIPPLED BY WALL STREET FERVOR
description: ONCE again, Wall Street seems to have overdone a good thing. And once again, a rush to make a lot of money too quickly seems to have maimed, only 10 months after its introduction, what could have been a continuously successful, innovative financing instrument.

title: 'DON QUIXOTE'
description: To the Editor:

title: SEGOVIA ALTERED THE COURSE OF INSTRUMENTAL HISTORY
description: In some ways, Andres Segovia was already an anachronism when he made his New York debut at Town Hall on Jan. 8, 1928. Olin Downes, then music critic of The Times, described the 34-year-old guitarist this way in the course of an enthusiastic column-long review: ''The appearance of Mr. Segovia is not that of the trumpeted virtuoso. He is rather the dreamer or scholar in bearing ...'' With his flowing hair, velvet tie, black frock coat, spats and black-rimmed glasses, he must have reminded many in his first American audience of an earlier, more genteel time when serious musicians looked like artists, talked like artists, dressed like artists and expected to be treated like artists. The young Spaniard also played like an artist, which did not hurt.

title: 190 Killed in Assam, Police Official Says
description: At least 190 people were killed in clashes last month on a remote island in the northeastern Indian state of Assam, a police official said today.

title: CRIME
description: Peter Turnbull's DEAD KNOCK (St. Martin's, $10.95) is set in Glasgow. Gerald Hammond's THE GAME (St. Martin's, $10.95) is set in nearby Edinburgh. The geographical relationship is the only thing the two books have in common.

title: Sandra Norris to Wed William Lomas
description: Mr. and Mrs. William K. Norris of Bedford, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sandra Lewis Norris, to William Alan Lomas, son of Harold E. Lomas of New Castle, N.H., and the late Dorothy S. Lomas of Westport, Conn.

title: No Headline
description: As senior-services coordinator in my town, I read ''America's Neglected Elderly'' with special interest. I was disturbed by the gloomy picture it presented.

title: ONE 'NORMAL' HOT DOG, COMING UP
description: AS I drove my teen-age son off to another dinner with a friend, I asked, ''How come you never invite any of your friends to eat with us?''

title: LOUDON WAINWRIGHT TAKES A DARK VIEW
description: Loudon Wainwright III's ''Fame and Wealth'' (Rounder 3076) finds one of pop music's most piquant social satirists at the top of his form. The 36-year-old singer, songwriter and guitarist has long been recognized as a witty chronicler of the stresses and joys of upper middle-class life. Such subject matter has traditionally been the province of literature and comedy more than of pop music. But Mr. Wainwright, a skillful versifier and superb comic actor, has perfected a rock-inflected folk style that doesn't contort his homely verses. The singer's Chaplinesque humor is matched by a sense of musical timing that keeps his lyrics from sounding like doggerel.

title: PENNY-CONCIOUS GOVERNORS GANG UP ON FEDERAL BUDGET
description: One of the ironies of modern government is the extent to which elected officials promise one thing but in practice deliver something quite the opposite, even when the promise is made in good faith.

title: May Wedding Planned for Gwendolyn Armstrong
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Munday Armstrong of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gwendolyn Badgley Armstrong, to Judson Palmer Mellott 3d, son Mr. and Mrs. Mellott of Bridgeport, Conn.

title: MUGABE'S FIFTH BRIGADE: GROUNDED IN LOYALTY
description: The Government campaign against what it calls dissidents in the country's western province of Matabeleland has focused attention on the army's Fifth Brigade.

title: GEORGE ABBOTT DUSTS OFF A BROADWAY CLASSIC
description: George Abbott, who has made magic in the theater as an actor, writer, producer, director and play-doctor for 70 years, is back in town. He is 95, a trifle deaf, a trifle stiff-jointed, but no man either to remain seated when help is needed to wheel a rehearsal piano around the floor or to be found hesitating when his services are wanted to breathe new life into an old show.

title: DANCE: 'LEGEND' PERFORMED
description: Although they lacked definite plots and specific characters, the works that Ann Roberts and Dancers presented Wednesday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio occasionally hinted at evolutionary themes. Yet the choreography itself seldom really evolved.

title: TWO CITIES WELCOME LAW RETURNING A TAX
description: A NEW law that will return a half cent of the sales tax to New Rochelle and Mount Vernon was welcomed last week by both cities - although Mount Vernon's Mayor Thomas Sharpe said the legislation should not have been needed.

title: PRINCETON MUSEUM: THE INFANCY OF PHOTOGRAPHY
description: TWO important shows are running in tandem at the Princeton University Art Museum through March 27. They are ''Masterpieces of the French Calotype'' and ''The Robert O. Dougan Collection of 19th-Century Photography.''

title: New York Times Magazine;       March 6, 1983
description: William Safire 12 On Language The Squeal Rule Russell Baker 16 Sunday Observer Grandparenting Steven V. Roberts 31 The G.O.P. - A Party in Search of Itself William E. Geist 42 The Outspoken President of Yale Now that A. Bartlett Giamatti has put Yale on a sound financial footing, the big question is, could he become the national leader higher education so sorely needs? Hilton Kramer 44 Gonzalez Almost as unknown now as at his death in 1942, Julio Gonzalez, a master of modern sculpture, will be honored this month with a major show at The Guggenheim Museum.

title: 2 Killed in Bolivia
description: Two youths were killed Friday night in disturbances after a strike by public workers opposed to economic austerity measures proposed by the Government. The police said the two youths were killed by storekeepers trying to protect their property.

title: U.S. SUES HAWAII OVER CONDITIONS IN 2 PRISONS
