description: The Reagan Administration has charged in a civil lawsuit that two Hawaii state prisons subject inmates to cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Constitution.

title: JERUSALEM'S MODERN ARK
description: The wolf shall dwell with the lamb, and the leopard shall lie down with the kid, and the calf and the lion and the fatling together, and a little child shall lead them. This familiar prophecy from the Old Testament (Isaiah 11:6) is fulfilled each spring at the Biblical Zoo in Jerusalem. Tiger cubs and baby goats, wolves and lambs are placed in the same enclosures and coexist. Initially, in fact, the tiger cubs tend to be a bit afraid of the butting and baaing kids, but they swiftly discover the delights of play.

title: STAYING BEHIND WITH 'HAMLET' WITHER AUDEN?
description: NOT so long ago, I attended a brief drama entitled ''An Actor's Nightmare,'' in which the main character found himself either wearing the right costume but walking into the wrong play, or wearing the wrong costume but cast in the right play. In any event, he entered stage left garbed for a part in ''Hamlet'' - doublet, hose and scabbard - only to find the scenery, dialogue and leading lady proceeding with a Noel Coward-style drawing room comedy - flapper dresses, Art Deco decor. From there on, it was perspiration and improvisation all the way - or so it was made to appear. The audience loved it.

title: Recovery Now, But How Strong?
description: ''We are making a lot of January,'' said Martin S. Feldstein. Indeed, after a midweek report that the index of leading indicators leaped 3.6 percent in January, higher than it has since 1950, economists were celebrating the advent of recovery from four years of back-to-back recessions.

title: Making Some Points On Indian Point
description: For the last two months, Westchester residents have been exposed to heavy Con Ed radiation regarding Indian Point - in the form of widespread newspaper advertising with photographs and interviews of members of Indian Point's first-line and middle-management team at home with their families.

title: MICRONESIA'S MALE SUICIDE RATE DEFIES SOLUTION
description: In the islands of Micronesia, young men are killing themselves at one of the highest rates in the world, researchers say, and no one knows what to do about it.

title:
CAMERA;
UNUSUAL EFFECTS POSSIBLE WITH INFRARED FILMS
description: The films normally used in regular photography are designed to record ''visible'' light - that is, they record the world the way it is seen by our eyes. However, beyond the scope of visible light there also exists a number of ''invisible'' types of radiant energy, some of which can be recorded on special films. Although we can't see these invisible rays with our eyes, we can see its results in many cases. For example, invisible X-rays are used regularly to take pictures of the inside of the human body.

title: WOMEN FAVOR REAGAN LESS
description: Women continue to have lower opinions of President Reagan than do men, according to the Gallup Poll, and the difference is three times as great as has been found for any previous President.

title: SERVING THE NEEDS OF OTHERS
description: AS bad economic times have swelled the number of hungry and homeless people in Connecticut, the generosity of neighbors coming to the aid to the needy among them has increased, too. From members of churches and synagogues, to volunteers at shelters or soup kitchens and individuals acting on their own, the haves of the state are responding to the plight of the have-nots with donations of cash, food, clothing and a place to stay on a cold night.

title: Helen Clark to Wed Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Doran Clark of Chevy Chase, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helen West Clark, to Timothy Granger Atkeson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy Breed Atkeson of Washington. A June wedding is planned.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE DAY THEY CAME TO ARREST THE BOOK By Nat Hentoff. 169 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $10.95. (Ages 12 and Up)

title: 2 COMMUTERS WIN JUDGEMENTS AGAINST CONRAIL
description: A small-claims judge, citing complaints of late, dirty and crowded Conrail trains, has awarded two commuters damages amounting to 10 percent of the cost of their tickets.

title: Katie Hazlett to Marry William C. Schmidt 2d
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul Hagerty Hazlett Jr. of Dorado Beach, P.R., of the engagement of their daughter, Katharine Ellen Hazlett, to William Charles Schmidt 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wilson Schmidt of Wayland and West Tisbury, Mass.

title: Math Problems, Cash Solution
description: With more than a dozen bills in Congress to improve science and mathematics education, the White House changed its tune. In contrast to previous budgets (in which he tried to almost eliminate National Science Foundation activities in this area, for example), President Reagan proposed a $200 million package.

title: Debbie Reynolds 'Blacks Out' On Stage in 'Woman of Year'
description: Debbie Reynolds, who took over the lead of the long-running musical ''Woman of the Year'' last month, collapsed on stage during a matinee yesterday and was taken to Roosevelt Hospital for tests.

title: FAVORED COPELAN IS SECOND
description: A few minutes before post time, it seemed like a perfectly reasonable question: Why had Croeso, an undistinguished gelding from California, been supplemented for $5,000 to run against top Kentucky Derby prospects today in the Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park?

title: Jane F. Butler Engaged To Wed Daniel Lindau
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Butler of Seattle have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane F. Butler, to Daniel A. Lindau, son of Mr. and Mrs. David S. Lindau of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: CHANGES SOUGHT IN HOUSING CASES
description: The New York City Commission on Human Rights plans to ask the City Council to let it prosecute landlords who illegally deny apartments to people with children.

title: WHO BREAKS THE LAW ON TV?
description: Is television unfair to the rich and powerful? Do entertainment shows nibble away at the pillars of the community by painting establishment figures as crooks and bunglers? Questions like those are suggested by two George Washington University sociologists in a study commissioned by the Media Institute, a Washington-based watchdog group with a conservative outlook. Nonetheless, this study touches on issues of concern to people across the political spectrum. After examining how crime is depicted on network dramas, adventure shows and comedies, the two researchers contend that businessmen, professionals and even police are portrayed as lawbreakers in numbers out of all proportion to reality.

title: MONDELLO GETS MARGIOTTA NOD
description: SNUFFING out the last vestiges of opposition, Joseph M. Margiotta paved the way last week for Joseph Mondello, a Hempstead Town Councilman, to replace him as Hempstead and Nassau Republican leader if Mr. Margiotta is forced to go to prison.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: LAST November, Connecticut's Democratic United States Senator, Christopher J. Dodd, said he was expanding his schedule of speeches out of state so that ''if lightning were to strike,'' and he was asked to be someone's Vice Presidential running mate on the party's 1984 national ticket, his name would be familiar across the country.

title: JAPAN PLANNING STEPS TO SPUR THE ECONOMY
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone plans to seek modest cuts in personal income taxes and to increase public works spending in the fiscal year that starts April 1, according to officials close to Mr. Nakasone.

title: SAFETY AGENCY SHOWS SIGNS OF A BUREAUCRATIC BREAKDOWN
description: ''I am getting rid of the car, I don't know what else to do,'' Helaine Zonderman, owner of a 1980 Pontiac Phoenix, told a Congressional subcommittee last week. Mrs. Zonderman said General Motors Corporation had recalled her car and twice repaired the rear brakes, which tended to lock and make the car skid.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;
A NEW BUOYANCY STIRS THE ECONOMY
description: Euphoria swept over the economy last week. Investors, bond traders and Government officials decided - at least for the time being - that plummetting oil prices meant better times ahead. And they became even more enthusiastic over news that the nation's leading indicators had climbed 3.6 percent in January, the largest monthly gain since July 1950. An 8.9 percent rise in construction spending during the month - the biggest since March 1946 - and a 9.9 percent increase in single-family home sales seemed proof positive that the recession was over.

title: PAINFUL MEMORIES
description: ONE of the most provocative books about sports in the previous generation was Jim Bouton's ''Ball Four,'' an irreverent look at baseball. In a turn of events that some will see as poetic justice, one of the more provocative books this year will be ''Home Games: Two Baseball Wives Speak Out,'' written by Bobbie Bouton and Nancy Marshall. The book, to be issued by St. Martin's/Marek next month, is a gripping look at their marriages to Jim Bouton and Mike Marshall. But ''Home Games'' is less about two headstrong athletes than about the women who bore their children, kept their houses, drove the station wagons every time they were traded, and in the end felt their loyalty had been misplaced.

title: PACE QUICKENS IN PHILADELPHIA RACE
description: W. Wilson Goode, followed by supporters of his mayoral campaign, made his way through the crowd, occasionally gripping an outthrust hand, occasionally letting a tight-lipped smile break through a somber countenance.

title: Five Rings and the Galactic Center
description: Astronomers have long wondered if the strange occurrences at the center of our galaxy could be caused by a black hole. That vexing issue has now been re-examined by a team of scientists under Charles Townes, the Berkeley physicist who has been advising Secretary Weinberger on how to deploy the MX missile.

title: PEETE EXPLAINS HIS EXIT
description: Calvin Peete, who left the Honda Inverrary Classic golf tournament suddenly after a verbal exchange with a spectator Friday, said tonight that he knew the spectator and that the incident was ''personal, not racial.''

title: Sabres 6, Red Wings 4
description: Tony McKegney scored twice to help Buffalo extend its unbeaten streak to eight games. Buffalo's Mike Foligno broke a 2-2 tie at 5:07 of the second period with a 20-foot backhander, and McKegney's second goal made it 4-2 at 6:43.

title: RISE SHARP IN ORDERS AND OUTPUT
description: Industrial companies have reported a pronounced turnaround in February, with new orders, production levels and other economic indicators up sharply, according to the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: Opinion Poll Shows 24% Back Increase in Arms Spending
description: Some 24 percent of Americans back President Reagan's effort to increase arms spending, a new poll disclosed today.

title: Briefs
description: Debt Issues

title: Commodities; Settling Contracts In Cash
description: WHAT do the leaders of the futures industry talk about at their annual conference besides having had another year of record volume and profits? Their problems, of course.

title: SAMPSON ENJOYS GOING-AWAY PARTY
description: ''Speeeeech,'' said the students of the University of Virginia. ''Speeeeech. Speeeeech.'' And Ralph Sampson, after the last home game of his college basketball career, walked to a microphone at the end of a frantic afternoon in University Hall, the building that has come to be known as Ralph's House. His 10-foot jump shot with four seconds to play had been the winning points in an 83-81 victory over Maryland.

title: MONDAY, MARCH 7, 1983
description: The Economy

title: Basketball Coach Out at Dartmouth
description: Tim Cohane, the basketball coach at Dartmouth, resigned today. ''This has been a learning experience for all our coaches and for the players as well,'' Cohane said.

title: U.S. OUT OF CUP
description: Argentina eliminated the United States in the first round of the Davis Cup tennis tournament today when Guillermo Vilas stunned John McEnroe in three straight sets. Leading by 4-2 in the first set, McEnroe, in an extraordinary lapse, dropped 15 straight games.

title: DON'T LET A DEFICIT CRUSH THE MENTALLY ILL
description: To the Editor:

title: GEORGE S. GREGORY
description: George S. Gregory, real-estate developer and president of the Gregory-Roth-Schenker Corporation, which built commercial and residential buildings in New York City and elsewhere in the country, died Saturday of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis in his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: French Golfer Leads
description: Anne-Marie Palli of France shot a fourunder-par 69 today to take a four-stroke lead in the second round of the Samaritan Turquoise golf tournament.

title: Crocker's Latin Loans
description: The Crocker National Corporation, parent of the nation's 11th-largest bank, has disclosed that it has $2.26 billion in loans outstanding to five Latin American countries that may not be repaid on schedule. Crocker said in its annual report that it foresees no material adverse effect arising from the loans, which represent about 10.9 percent of its total outstanding. Crocker said its total nonperforming assets at the end of 1982 rose to $770.6 million from $433.7 million at the end of 1981.

title: American Art Songs, By Bolcom and Morris
description: The pianist William Bolcom and the mezzo-soprano Joan Morris have a mission - to reclaim vaudeville, ragtime and show tunes for the American art-song tradition. To that end, their Alice Tully Hall program Sunday included songs by Charles Ives as well as by Irving Berlin, Eubie Blake and Stephen Sondheim, and featured a bones player from the minstrel-show tradition, Percy Danforth.

title: INDIRA GANDHI'S RESPONSIBILITY FOR 'THE FIRE IN INDIA'
description: To the Editor:

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball

title: BANDITS WIN, 21-17, AS REEVES EXCELS
description: John Reaves passed for 358 yards and three touchdowns, including a 33-yard game-winning toss to Willie Gillespie, and led the Tampa Bay Bandits to a 21-17 victory over the Boston Breakers in a United States Football League opener today.Reaves completed 28 of 39 passes and connected with Gillespie with 10 minutes 17 seconds remaining before a crowd of 42,437 in Tampa Stadium.

title: Australia's Winner Calls U.S. Ties Essential
description: Australia's next Prime Minister, Robert Hawke, said today that his new Labor government would pursue a more independent foreign policy than that of Malcolm Fraser, whose conservative coalition was toppled in elections Saturday. But Mr. Hawke asserted that his country's relationship with the United States was ''fundamental.''

title: Softer Attitudes About Death
description: Conventional wisdom holds that the politics of crime is a politics of fear, an irrational territory in which reason and pragmatism are banned - and never more so than when the issue is the death penalty. New York's Governor Cuomo, like former Governor Carey, is a conspicuous exception to the norm: few politicians are willing to stand up to the perceived level of public emotion.

title: THE TOP WOMEN IN BUSINESS JOIN FORCES
description: It is a group that defies stereotyping. The membership reaches across the country, drawn from almost every type of business and industry and spanning the generations. The women in the Committee of 200 have only one thing in common: power. Each one either owns a business with an annual volume of at least $5 million or runs a corporation or corporate division with more than $20 million in annual sales.

title: Washington Watch; Oil Tax, Deficit And Recovery
description: THE idea, on its face, is very appealing: now is the time to levy a tax on imported oil because it will provide needed income to offset some of the Federal deficit, and the bite on consumers will be more like a nibble while oil prices are falling.

title: BROOKER OF CANADA TRIUMPHS AT ASPEN
description: Todd Brooker of Canada won the men's World Cup downhill race today on a windswept Aspen Mountain course that was rutted with soft snow - the aftermath of a severe storm that forced the postponement of the race Saturday.

title: Ontario to Buy Streetcar Plant
description: The government of the Province of Ontario said it would spend $9.2 million (Canadian) through a government-owned agency to buy control of a plant that builds rapid transit equipment in Thunder Bay, Ontario. The plant is owned by Hawker Siddeley Group Ltd. of Toronto.

title: MEANWHILE BACK IN SALVADOR
description: Two years after then Secretary of State Alexander Haig proclaimed El Salvador a ''major test of East-West relations,'' that tortured country is back in the news.

title: THE TAXI SYSTEM: CITY SEEKS WAYS TO IMPROVE QUALITY OF SERVICE
description: Had a visitor from Mars suddenly been deposited on Third Avenue and 51st Street on a recent drizzly Friday evening, he might have thought that the natives were waiting to hail their leader. Dozens of anxious looking men and women lined the avenue, one hand raised high in what appeared to be a form of salute. In fact, the New York natives were only trying to hail a cab. For most, the effort proved frustrating. As in other parts of Manhattan on that and similar evenings during what is commonly, if ironically, known as the rush hour, almost every yellow car on the road either already carried a passenger or displayed an illuminated sign reading ''On Radio Call.''

title: The U.N. Today; March 7, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: TV: HANK WILLIAMS JR. STORY AND OTHER FARE
description: THE new fare on tonight's schedule includes a television movie, a music special and the debut of a situation comedy. Richard Thomas stars in ''Living Proof: The Hank Williams Jr. Story'' on Channel 2. Duke Ellington is the subject of a musical portrait on Channel 13. And, back on Channel 2, Darren McGavin returns to television in a Walt Disney Productions series called ''Small & Frye.''

title: INDIRA GANDHI'S RESPONSIBILITY FOR 'THE FIRE IN INDIA'
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A left fielder, still in fair territory, catches a fly ball, but his glove and ball are in foul territory. Is the catch in fair or foul territory? In a game during the 1982 season, a fielder caught a ball in fair ground, but his momentum carried him into foul territory, where he jumped a fence and dropped the ball. This was ruled a four-base error because the fielder did not close his ungloved hand over the ball. What was meant by that?

title: 'LANDSLIDE, A LANDSLIDE!' KOHL AIDE SAYS
description: There was more at stake in the West German voting today than there has been in many years, but by the time the results became known election night was like any other: full of relief and heartbreak.

title: 'E.T.' Success Is Linked By China to U.S. Woes
description: Millions of Chinese who got their first glimpse of E.T. today were told that the extraterrestrial film character's success meant that Americans were seeking escape from their economic woes.

title: Grimm's Tales
description: Charlie Grimm, the former first baseman and manager of the Chicago Cubs, is now 84 and hasn't worn a major league uniform since he managed the Cubs briefly in 1960.

title: MESSY CHILDREN'S ROOMS
description: THE day finally came when Roberta Schoenfield could no longer bear t o argue with her 13 1/2-year-old son, Eric, about the unmade bed in h is room and the clutter on the floor.

title: LOST MEDICAL CARE FOR JOBLESS: COST MAY BE HEALTH OR LIVES
description: Of all the pain and problems the recession has produced, none may be as severe or long-lasting as the damage done to the health of people who, having lost their medical insurance along with their jobs, are not getting the medical care they need.

title: COVETED ON CAPITOL HILL: THE HIDEAWAY
description: What is probably the most coveted status symbol in Congress is something seldom displayed by those who have it - the Capitol hideaway.

title: FUR INDUSTRY SALES ROSE BY ONLY 5% LAST YEAR
description: During a recent fur sale at Bloomingdale's, three saleswomen were seated comfortably on chairs, chatting, as a lone browser wandered in. Alexander's fur department was similarly deserted.

title: Bad Day for Derby Hopefuls
description: Most of the trainers who were full of hope Saturday that their colts could win the Florida Derby and perhaps go on to win the Kentucky Derby in nine weeks had soured by today after their colts had run so uninspiringly at Gulfstream Park.

title: HAMILTON SURPRISES BOYS & GIRLS, 82-70
description: Alexander Hamilton High School will face Springfield Gardens in the Division A final of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball tournament Sunday, but even a victory then could hardly top Hamilton's 82-70 upset of Boys & Girls High yesterday in the semifinals.

title: OUTCOME PLEASING TO WASHINGTON BECAUSE KOHL BACKS A-ARMS PLAN
description: Reagan Administration officials privately expressed relief today at the outcome of the West German election, with its decisive endorsement of the Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

title: FRENCH SOCIALISTS LOSE GROUND IN MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS
description: Conservative and moderate opposition parties scored major gains against the Socialists and Communists of the Government coalition Sunday in the first round of national municipal elections.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JEWISH ART

title: Daniel Ronald Stern Wed To Susan Ellen Steinberg
description: At the Park East Synagogue in Manhattan yesterday, Susan Ellen Steinberg, daughter of Mrs. Albert K. Lippmann of Roanoke, Va., and the late Moe Steinberg of New York, was married to Daniel Ronald Stern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur P. Stern of Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Pole Flees to Canada As Stowaway on Jet
description: A Polish airline mechanic fled to Canada over the weekend by hiding in the baggage compartment of a Polish jet for 14 hours. He said he had left Poland because the Government tried to blackmail him into signing a loyalty oath.

title: GENERALS LOSE LEAGUE DEBUT
description: It was an event of distinction as one of today's five inaugural games in the United States Football League, but distinctions were not expressed on the field here as the New Jersey Generals lost, 20-15, to the Los Angeles Express.

title: Plastic-Heart Patient Is Improved but Weak
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark, the artificial heart recipient, appeared to be winning his bout with pneumonia today, his wedding anniversary, but remained on a respirator and a regimen of antibiotics.

title: Thrift Unit Merger
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has given permission for the merger of the Leader Savings and Loan Association of Monroe, La., into the Pelican Home and Savings Association of Metairie, La.

title: LOUISVILLE CAPTURES 27TH ON LAST SHOT
description: Milt Wagner scored all 6 of Louisville's points in overtime, and hit a shot with one second to go that gave the Cardinals a 64-62 victory over Memphis State today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Friday on increased college costs gave an incorrect total for tuition, room and board at Cornell University in 1983-84. It is $12,300.

title: MATCHMAKER, MAKE A MATCH, DISABLED CHINESE ASK
description: A year ago Feng Lanxiu seemed a discouraging prospect for marriage. She was totally deaf and unable to speak even in sign language, and she was still being cared for by her parents.

title: John Notte, a Governor Of Rhode Island in 60's
description: John A. Notte Jr., a former Governor of Rhode Island, died today at Rhode Island Hospital after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: CONVENTION SITE FACES OVERRUNS OF $16 MILLION
description: Construction cost overruns for New York City's Exposition and Convention Center will reach at least $16.8 million, according to center officials.

title: Townsfolk Rally for Aid As Fire Below Burns On
description: Church bells rang, sirens blasted and flags waved in the smoky air as residents rallied today for government help to ''Set Centralia Free'' from the perils of a 20-year-old underground fire in abandoned coal mine shafts.

title: Trial Starts Today In CBS Slayings
description: The man accused of killing three CBS technicians and a Federal witness in an embezzlement investigation is expected to go on trial today.

title: MORE MEN UNDER 21 HOUSED IN CITY SHELTERS FOR HOMELESS
description: Shelters for the homeless in New York City are housing an increasing number of men between the ages of 18 and 21, according to the city's Human Resources Administration.

title: BRIEFING
description: 'Pro-Life Activists' Poll

title: Chinese Trade Official Arrives In Moscow for Start of Talks
description: Jia Shi, a Chinese Deputy Foreign Trade Minister, arrived in Moscow today for talks on developing trade between the two countries.

title: A 4-YEAR-OLD PLANS A FUSS IN THE GARDEN
description: LARRY LEMBO was minding his own business. For the previous several hours, he had been at work on a basketball court at Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Queens, making decisions and blowing his whistle during a Big East Conference game between St. John's and Syracuse. More than 30 minutes after the game, his whistle put away and his black-and-white striped shirt replaced by a coat and tie, the referee walked in a corridor beneath the stands.

title: Diplomat's Wife Object of Search
description: A citywide search is under way for a Yemeni diplomat's American-born wife who has not been seen since she withdrew $500 from her midtown bank on Thursday, the police said.

title: NKOMO SAYS ARMY TRIED TO KILL HIM
description: Zimbabwe's opposition leader, Joshua Nkomo, charged today that Prime Minister Robert Mugabe sent troops to kill him and his family in an attack Saturday on his home in the southwestern city of Bulawayo.

title: WHY 'ICEMAN COMETH' DID NOT ARRIVE THIS YEAR
description: After a valiant try, ''The Iceman Cometh,'' one of Eugene O'Neill's masterworks, is not coming to Lincoln Center or Circle in the Square or Kennedy Center or to Broadway. At least not this season.

title: BLACK-OWNED HOSPITAL SOLD IN NEW ORLEANS
description: Flint-Goodridge Hospital, one of the largest and oldest black-owned businesses in Louisiana, has been sold to a national hospital chain for $1.8 million.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Honest politics is persuasive politics.'' Chancellor Helmut Kohl. (A1:6.)

title: U.S. GYMNASTS EXCEL AT GARDEN
description: In a field that included 43 athletes from 14 countries, the United States proved dominant yesterday in the McDonald's American Cup gymnastics competition at Madison Square Garden.

title: OIL CUT TO HURT POORER NATIONS
description: No matter how much OPEC eventually decides to cut prices, the oilproducing countries of the third world face a serious and disruptive decline in revenues.

title: Promise to Field Strike Team Made
description: Sam Schulman, owner of the Seattle Super-Sonics, has said he will field a new tame if his players strike. ''We will be prepared a week after April 2,'' Schulman said. The National Basketball Players Association has set an April 2 deadline for reaching a new collective bargaining agreement with the league.

title: FEAR OF AIDS HAS RED CROSS DISCOURAGING CERTAIN DONORS
description: The American Red Cross says it will inform homosexual males, Haitian immigrants, drug users and others considered at high risk of carrying a dangerous disease, acquired immune deficiency syndrome, that they should not donate blood.

title: COMMUTER ALTERNATIVES
description: In the event of a strike against Metro-North, buses will run from some train stations on the Hudson, Harlem and New Haven lines. Some buses will travel to Manhattan; others will connect with subway lines in the Bronx.

title: Karen Morris Weds Alan D. Levenson
description: Karen L. Morris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Morris of Wilmington, Del., was married there yesterday to Alan D. Levenson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Levenson of Pittsburgh. The ceremony was performed at Temple Beth Shalom by Rabbis Jacob Kraft, Kenneth Cohen and Herbert Morris, an uncle of the bride.

title: TENACIOUS LEADER OF THE GREEN PARTY: PETRA KARIN KELLY
description: Woman in the News

title: E.P.A. CHIEF PLANS WHITE HOUSE LEGAL TALKS
description: Anne McGill Burford, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, plans to meet early this week with White House officials to discuss legal representation, a spokesman for her agency said today.

title: WOMEN IN THE PHONE BOOK
description: Though it may never become more than a footnote to feminist history, more and more married women have been requesting equal billing with their husbands in the residential listings of the telephone directory.

title: BOSTON COLLEGE SPRINGS A SURPRISE AGAIN
description: Boston College, which was the surprise team of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament a year ago, was the surprise of the powerful Big East Conference this season. With their 81-66 victory over Providence Saturday night, the Eagles finished in a tie at 12-4 with Villanova and St. John's for the regular-season championship.

title: Big Deal in Cat World
description: Cats were a hot ticket off Broadway yesterday - at Madison Square Garden. Thousands of people, slowed by fire regulations, waited in line to look at 600 of them, from Abyssinians to Tonkinese.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: * Rate depicted in Long- or Short-Term Rates chart.

title: Bridge:; All the Top-Ranked Teams Survive in Grand Nationals
description: All the top-ranked teams survived the Swiss stage of the Grand National Team Championship at the New York Hilton Saturday, but some were in jeopardy in the final rounds. The 15 top teams qualified for knockout play yesterday at Adelphi University in Garden City, L.I., where they were joined by 17 Long Island teams.

title: SPECIAL OPEC PANEL IS OPTIMISTIC ON PACT ON COST AND OUTPUT
description: A group of OPEC oil ministers expressed optimism today about the prospects for a comprehensive agreement on production policies and the first official price cut in OPEC's 23-year history.

title: A Break for the Nervous At 'A Bundle of Nerves'
description: A new Off Broadway musical revue about what makes people nervous, ''A Bundle of Nerves,'' is gathering especially appreciative audiences with a canny gimmick. Theatergoers who can prove they are seeing a psychotherapist (through a canceled check or doctor's statement) get half-price seats to previews at the Top of the Gate.

title: Daniel J. Jick Marries Elizabeth Etra in Cedarhurst
description: Elizabeth Etra, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Etra of Lawrence, L.I., was married at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., yesterday to Daniel J. Jick, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leon A. Jick of Lexington, Mass. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Leo Jung, grandfather of the bride, and the bridegroom's father, who is chairman of the department of Near Eastern and Judaic studies at Brandeis University and the Irving and Esther Schneider Professor of American Jewish Studies there.

title: THEATER: 'ON YOUR TOES,' A '36 RODGERS AND HART
description: THE biggest thrill offered by ''On Your Toes,'' the 1936 musical revived last night at the Virginia, is the poster outside the theater. There you will find three of the most illustrious names of Broadway history - Richard Rodgers, Lorenz Hart and George Abbott - as well as a fourth name that transcends both Broadway and history, George Balanchine. It's sad that the show heralded by the poster has only a marginal relationship to the giant talents who share top billing.

title: From Mandolins to Menus
description: To Theresa Costello, the display windows at 289 Bleecker Street, on the corner of Seventh Avenue South, ''looked nicer'' full of mandolins, accordions, Victrolas, records and ''O Sole Mio''-style sheet music. Now they hold dramatic bouquets - orchids yesterday - and limousines line up in front for the Vanessa restaurant.

title: BERKELEY DIVIDED BY A NEW DISPUTE OVER FREEDOM OF SPEECH
description: A civil rights dispute evoking the Free Speech Movement of 19 years ago has gripped the University of California campus here since a demonstration interrupted a lecture by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations.

title: A WEEK OF CLOUDS IN THE WEST, NOT ALL IN THE SKY
description: President Reagan seemed close to fearless on the subject of the environment as he made the final stop of his long week out West by visiting troubled timberland executives in Oregon. His path dogged daily by the growing controversy over the Environmental Protection Agency, the President nevertheless chose the occasion to defend industry's treatment of nature and to complain about backpackers' concern over woodlands.

title: 300TH FOR MIDDLETON
description: Rick Middleton scored a pair of goals, including the 300th of his National Hockey League career, and led the Boston Bruins to a 5-2 victory tonight over Edmonton. The Bruins' victory ended the Oilers' three-game winning streak.

title: MUSIC: MENUHIN AND BRAHMS
description: YEHUDI MENUHIN was one player among many at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night, but it was his musical character that most strongly influenced the proceedings. The music was all by Brahms, this year being the 150th anniversary of his birth. Mr. Menuhin and Andras Schiff played the D minor Sonata for violin and piano; Nathaniel Rosen's cello joined them in the early Trio in B, and at the end was the Sextet in B flat for Strings.

title: Penny Wise, Barrel Foolish
description: Imagine that you have a serious illness but treatment has eliminated most of the symptoms and the prognosis is fair. Does it now make sense to stop paying premiums on your life insurance?

title: NETS TOP SIXERS
description: For most of this season, the distance between the Nets and the Philadelphia 76ers has been vast. And it hasn't been measured by just victories and defeats, but by the respect that a team has earned for its reputation as a contender.

title: SUFFOLK TRIUMPHS
description: Suffolk County won the New York State scholastic wrestling championships, which ended early this morning at the Onondaga War Memorial, with 215 1/2 points, eding runner-up Rochester with 211 points.

title: MUSIC: FOSS PRESENTS COMPOSER AS PERFORMER
description: THE theme of the ''Meet the Moderns'' concert presented by Lukas Foss and the Brooklyn Philharmonic at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Saturday night was ''The Composer as Performer.'' And though not every composer represented on the program participated in the perfomances, they were all on hand to offer brief observations on their music after intermission.

title: CURATOR'S DISMISSAL DRAWS PROTEST
description: Fifteen people prominent in New York cultural circles have sent a letter to the New-York Historical Society protesting the dismissal last December of Mary C. Black, the society's curator of painting and sculpture since 1970. The letter comes in the wake of a complaint filed by Mrs. Black with Federal and state agencies contending the society had violated sex- and age-discrimination laws.

title: TV: 'CHILDREN OF PRIDE'
description: ''CHILDREN OF PRIDE'' is manipulative and slick, possibly out of place on public television's ''Frontline'' series, and at the same time probably the best thing that ''Frontline'' has done this season. This is an absurd contradiction, of course, explained best by saying that ''Children of Pride'' is so special it scarcely fits any category at all. It will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: U.S.F.L. VIDEO GAME
description: FROM the beginning, the United States Football League has projected the idea of a video game more than a pro football game. Something to watch on Sunday afternoon in the spring, no matter what the caliber of competition. And for the last week the sales pitch has been obvious. Slip your Herschel Walker cassette into your video recorder and watch him run. But yesterday, Herschel Walker didn't run that much, not even when the New Jersey Generals needed him to carry the ball in the final minutes of their 20-15 loss to the Los Angeles Express.

title: World Inflation Slowed in 1982
description: Inflation in industrial countries slowed substantially last year, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

title: NEW RABBIS CALLED HOPE OF ORTHODOX
description: Seventy-seven young rabbis sat before one of their faith's most revered scholars yesterday for a convocation marking their entry into the Orthodox rabbinate after several years of rigorous religious studies at Yeshiva University.

title: CORPORATE BORROWING MODEST
description: Nearly $3 billion of corporate notes and bonds came to market last month, a supply that market participants described as moderate, since it was roughly half the $6 billion sold last October and the lowest monthly total since last July.

title: DISSIDENT HOLDER FIGHTS TO OUST GAF BOARD . . .
description: When Samuel J. Heyman was an assistant United States Attorney in New Haven, he says, he did not lose a jury trial in more than three years. Now he is a businessman and has embarked on another sort of legal contest where there are winners and losers -a proxy battle.

title: UNIONIST TELLS CUOMO EARLY RETIREMENTS CAN END NEED FOR LAYOFFS
description: A state union leader has told Governor Cuomo he expects as many as 10,000 state workers to retire early and that the 8,400 layoffs called for by Mr. Cuomo in his budget are unnecessary.

title: PARTNERSHIP SEEKS TO FILL VOID IN THE SALE OF SMALL COMPUTERS
description: When Jan Levine and John Vasil looked out across the highly competitive field of small-computer sales a year ago, they saw an opening. Everywhere, small businesses were rushing to automate, and, in the profusion of complex new equipment, many were confused about what to buy.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MARCH 7, 1983
description: International

title: GAMBLE RESTLESS WITH ROLE ON BENCH
description: When the Yankees' 12-inning exhibition game with the Montreal Expos ended today, Oscar Gamble thought he was headed from left field at West Palm Beach Municipal Stadium to the executive trailer back at Fort Lauderdale Stadium for a chat with George Steinbrenner.

title: AMERICA'S WORLD ROLE
description: Two years after Ronald Reagan was elected to the Presidency, the American people and opinion leaders oppose some of the major foreign policy initiatives of his Administration. Since World War II, American Presidents -backed by a majority of foreign policy opinion leaders - have succeeded in shaping popular attitudes in support of an internationalist foreign policy. To achieve that objective in this decade will require a narrowing of the differences between the Administration and opinion leaders.

title: Acid Rain Expert Coming To Botanical Garden
description: The co-discoverer of acid rain in the Northeast, Dr. Gene E. Likens of Cornell University, is coming to the New York Botanical Garden to direct its new Institute of Ecosystem Studies. Focusing on people in relation to environment, the institute would join with the garden in ''some very urban studies pertinent to the New York megalopolis,'' Dr. Likens said the other day.

title: WHAT PRICE NUCLEAR SURVIVAL?
description: To the Editor:

title: CHAMPION IN QUEST FOR NEW IMAGE
description: SCOTT HAMILTON and Greg Gibson sat side by side at the recent Sullivan Award dinner in Indianapolis. Gibson, a Marine sergeant, is the first man to win world-championship medals in one year in all three branches of wrestling - freestyle, Greco-Roman and sombo. He weighs 220 pounds and looks larger.

title: Miss Navratilova Routs Mrs. Lloyd
description: Martina Navratilova overwhelmed Chris Evert Lloyd, 6-1, 6-2, today to win a $165,000 tennis tournament, her fourth of the year without the loss of a set.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: OUT ON A WHIM. By Gerald Nachman. 332 Pages. Doubleday. $6.95.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Advertising; Nashville, U.S.F.L.  On Cable
description: TODAY is to be a particuarly big day in cable television circles, with five hours of live coverage to introduce the Nashville Network, and the first Monday night coverage of the new United States Football League on the ESPN Cable Network.

title: VILLANOVA WINNER
description: Villanova's trans-Atlantic talent helped the Wildcats win the 62d IC4A indoor track and field championship today.

title: Manhattan Opera Sings Massenet's 'Cleopatre'
description: ''Cleopatre'' was one of the last gasps of Massenet's operatic career. It was first played in 1914, two years after his death; and if the Manhattan Opera Theater is correct, its performance Saturday afternoon at Cami Hall was a New York premiere.

title: Anthony Blunt, Fourth Man in British Spying Scandal, Is Dead at 76
description: LONDON, March 26 -- Anthony Blunt, a former curator of Queen Elizabeth II's art collection who in 1979 was exposed as having been the mysterious fourth man in a Soviet spying ring, collapsed and died at breakfast in his London home today. He was 75 years old.

title: MISSISSIPPI HUNTERS REDISCOVER MUZZLELOADER
description: The loud clap that sounds as the hammer strikes home on the percussion cap or flint is quicly followed by a building thunder and a ring of gray smoke-another primitve weapon has been fired by a Mississippi sportsman.

title: Mickelberry Reports Large Gains in Quarter
description: About 60 percent of the revenues of the Mickelberry Corporation come from its three ad agencies, which have neither overseas offices nor recruitment advertising subsidiaries.

title: POPE MAKES PLEA OF RECONCILIATION FOR SALVADORANS
description: Pope John Paul II arrived in El Salvador from Costa Rica today and made a plea for a reconciliation that would include all Salvadorans and end the three-year-old civil war.

title: Farm-Export Rise Doubted
description: John R. Block, Agriculture Secretary, said today that farm exports could not be expected to increase until at least the end of 1984.

title: CITY CHAINS POST 5.7% SALES GAIN
description: Sales by seven major retail chains in New York City rose an average of 5.7 percent in February from a year earlier, according to a spotcheck conducted last week. But the overall average gain was sharply inflated by one store chain's 16.7 percent increase, and four of the seven respondents posted declines for the month.

title: Nancy R. Newhouse Marries a Lawyer
description: Nancy Riley Newhouse and Michael Iovenko were married yesterday in Manhattan. The Rev. Daphne Hawkes, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the couple's home.

title: Beatrice Foods
description: The Beatrice Foods Company expects proceeds of $250 million in the next two years from a divestiture program announced two weeks ago, James Johnson Jr., senior vice president and chief financial officer, has told analysts.

title: DE LEON STOPS LEON SPINKS IN 6TH ROUND
description: Memories. Leon Spinks has a few. And now, at the age of 29, perhaps his career as a contender is a memory. With Muhammad Ali, who brought back some fonder memories, sitting at ringside, the 1976 Olympic champion and 1978 world heavyweight champion was battered into meek submission after six rounds by Carlos De Leon today at Harrah's Marina Hotel Casino.

title: MILLER IS WINNER IN INVERRARY
description: Johnny Miller fended off a challenge from Jack Nicklaus today to win the Honda Inverrary Classic by two strokes.

title: CHANGING VIEWS OF BRINK'S CASE: NARCOTICS ALLEGATIONS EMERGE
description: Soon after the Brink's robbery and killings in Rockland County in October 1981, Federal agents searched a hurriedly abandoned Mount Vernon, N.Y., apartment and found a green ledger book that they believe is a guide to many expenditures by the radicals who have been charged in the crime.

title: ROME COMMUNISTS SEEK ALLIES
description: Italy's Communist Party wound up its national congress tonight with an urgent bid to the Socialists to join them in an electoral alliance. The Socialists now govern with the Christian Democrats.

title: KNICKS LIFTED BY KING'S PLAY
description: On the open floor, Bernard King has a flair for the spectacular. He excites the fans with his quickness, penetration, passes and drives to the basket.

title: Defender of the City Has Been at It Since 1906
description: There's nothing like having a talent that never goes out of style. With 16,000 new negligence claims filed against the city each year, there has always been plenty of work for Martin Devine in the office of the Corporation Counsel, the city's legal arm.

title: ALLEN WINS AGAIN IN NATION'S CAPITAL
description: It had been more than five years since George Allen worked the sidelines in Robert F. Kennedy Stadium. For seven seasons he was a master and magician as the Washington Redskins' head coach, leading them into the National Football League playoffs five times and a Super Bowl once, using many players that no other team would have because of their advanced age.

title: CONDUCTORS AND TRAINMEN STRIKE METRO-NORTH, STRANDING 90,000
description: Metro-North and its conductors and trainmen sought yesterday to break an impasse over work rules and to avert a strike this morning that would halt service for 90,000 residents of New York City's northern suburbs and southwestern Connecticut.

title: DETENTE WITHOUT ILLUSIONS
description: A managed contest and a detente without illusions - this should be our policy toward Moscow.

title: SAFETY OFFICIALS DISAGREE ON EFFORT TO MONITOR DEFECT IN FORD AUTOS
description: Top officials of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration are sharply divided over whether the agency is monitoring the Ford Motor Company's program to deal with a tendency of many of its cars to slip from ''park'' into ''reverse.''

title: Roy C. Olson Is Dead at 78; Longtime Sands Point Mayor
description: Roy C. Olson, a former Mayor of Sands Point, L.I., and a retired executive with the Otis Elevator Company, died of heart failure at his home in Sands Point Saturday. He was 78 years old.

title: TAX-EXEMPT OFFERING PACE IS BRISK
description: The credit markets continue to enjoy a respite from major Treasury financings. The next one will be an auction of two-year notes on March 16.

title: Bell Units Weighing Cable TV Role
description: Some local telephone companies, now owned by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company but scheduled to gain their independence next year, are proposing for the first time to build and own cable television systems as a way to develop new sources of revenue.

title: Let My Sitcom Go
description: Columbia Pictures and Getty Oil can sell new movies or old game shows to individual television stations, but under a 1970 order of the Federal Communications Commission, ABC, NBC and CBS can't. Similarly, Walt Disney and MCA can retain a profit from network programs that are repackaged as, say, video cassettes or cable TV programs; the networks can't.

title: Senator Tells Salvador Rebels To 'Negotiate at Ballot Box'
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today that the guerrillas in El Salvador should ''negotiate at the ballot box,'' but Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, called for a cease-fire to see if the rebels are bluffing about negotiations.

title: . . . BUT COMPANY CHIEF SAYS IT'S ALL 'NONSENSE'
description: Jesse Werner, the 66-year-old research chemist who has been GAF's chairman for almost 20 years, has been one of the nation's most embattled chief executives in recent years.

title: ZIMBABWE'S PRESS, LIKE RHODESIA'S, IS UNADVENTUROUS
description: When Joshua Nkomo, this country's officially disgraced opposition leader, held a news conference recently to produce documents rebutting Government statements about him, no Zimbabwean reporters came to hear his side of the story. The omission, Mr. Nkomo said, showed that ''there is no press in this country.''

title: Biomedical Enters Consumer Publishing
description: The Biomedical Information Corporation, which publishes a professional journal and a physicians' desk reference, has branched out into consumer publishing with a six-a-year magazine called Rx Being Well.

title: Port Authority Sets Meeting
description: More than 40 advertising agencies from New York and New Jersey have been invited to a presentation Wednesday in the World Trade Center by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which may be switching ad agencies. It is currently being served by Homer & Durham.

title: P.L.O. 'Personalities' Are Banned by Israel
description: The Israeli television and radio have been ordered to stop referring to ''personalities in the P.L.O.'' in newscasts because the term has positive connotations, a spokesman for the state-subsidized Broadcasting Authority said today.

title: HEALTH COST BOOSTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * J. Breed Clothing, New York City, has appointed Jay Entner vice president of sales.

title: S. CAROLINA AIMS TO CURB NUCLEAR INDUSTRY'S RISE
description: South Carolina has begun to temper its 30-year quest to become, as former Gov. James B. Edwards once proclaimed it, ''the nuclear capital of the world.''

title: NEW ARCHBISHOP OF SALVADOR CONDEMNS 'A LACK OF FAITH'
description: Archbishop Arturo Rivera y Damas addressed his congregation today for the first time since being elevated to the post and said ''a lack of faith has become a social sin, which has culminated in a crisis.''

title: News Analysis
description: It seemed like old times in the House of Representatives last week. For three days in a row, the lawmakers approved spending bills to create an American Conservation Corps, subsidize better science and mathematics instruction, create new jobs and provide humanitarian relief for destitute families.

title: A Skiing Dispute
description: Did Bill Koch ''steal'' the World Cup? That's what some of the coaches and administrators of the Scandinavian cross-country ski teams say about the American champion's performance last year.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 24 incorrectly reported a transaction involving the Hamburg Savings Bank and the College Point Savings Bank. They have merged.

title: 276-Year-Old Manuscript Is Found in Nebraska
description: An ''odd-looking yellow parchment'' found on a Nebraska City bookshelf has turned out to be a 276-year-old work by the colonial poet Edward Taylor.

title: 145 DOWN-AND-ACROSS FANATICS BATTLE IN TOURNEY
description: Nature abhors a vacuum and so does Alice Kaufman. ''When I see that empty crossword,'' said Mrs. Kaufman, who lives in Scarsdale, N.Y., ''I just have to fill it in.'' Today 144 others shared her competitive obsession for crossword puzzles. They gathered here - minds attuned to rum cocktails and Iraqi leaders, Albanian currency and Moorish percussion - to battle in the sixth annual nationwide Crossword Puzzle Invitational at the Marriott Hotel, sponsor of the event.

title: Training the Mind
description: The outlook was not bright for the University of Illinois basketball team this season. The Illini, sixth in the Big Ten last season, had lost its three top scorers through graduation, and Coach Lou Henson found himself with a squad that included four freshmen and four sophomores. Nevertheless, the Illini were in contention for the conference championship until they lost to Indiana on Saturday night.

title: Bonnie Laskin Drath Is Married to Carl H. Seligson
description: The marriage of Bonnie Laskin Drath to Carl H. Seligson was performed yesterday at Temple Shaaray Tefila by Rabbi Harvey Tattlebaum. The bride, a learning-disabilities specialist in the New York school system, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Laskin of Newburgh, N.Y. Her husband, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold P. Seligson of New York, is managing director of the Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group and a vice president of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith.

title: WHAT PURPOSE ARMS TALKS?
description: To the Editor:

title: CANUCKS 6, JETS 2
description: Darcy Rota scored two goals for the second straight night as Vancouver outskated and outchecked Winnipeg.

title: ENCOURAGING EFFORT FOR LEARY
description: For the third straight day, the Mets tested a comeback pitcher today, and for the third straight day the initial result was favorable.

title: U.S. Calls Smoking Addictive
description: Cigarette smoking is ''the most widespread example of drug dependence'' in the United States, the Government said today in a new pamphlet.

title: Barbie Undergoes Operation for Hernia
description: Klaus Barbie, the convicted Nazi war criminal extradited to France last month from Bolivia, underwent an emergency hernia operation today in a heavily guarded operating room after being rushed to a Lyons hospital from the prison cell where he is awaiting a new trial, doctors and the police said.

title: Brooklyn Children Find Bomb
description: Children playing in Prospect Park found a live pipe bomb near the Kate Wollman Skating Rink at 2:07 P.M. yesterday, the police said. The police bomb squad removed the 10-inch brass pipe, which had a timing device and two batteries, from the Brooklyn park. The bomb was taken to the department's range at Rodmans Neck in the Bronx where it will be examined.

title: Rain Halts Race
description: A late-afternoon rain halted the Carolina 500 Grand National stock car race after 143 laps, causing Nascar officials to reschedule it. The remainder of the 492-lap race will be run next Sunday.

title: Why the Poor Get Food Stamps in Lieu of Cash
description: To the Editor:

title: Music Noted in Brief; Beethoven Society Offers Missa Solemnis
description: Given its standing as one of the unquestioned masterworks of the choral repertory, Beethoven's Missa Solemnis is all too rarely heard in the concert hall. On Saturday afternoon, the New Haven Symphony Orchestra, the Cornell Choir and a vocal quartet consisting of the soprano Lorna Haywood, the alto Jan De Gaetani, the tenor Seth McCoy and the baritone David Arnold teamed up for a bristling performance at Alice Tully Hall, under the auspices of the Beethoven Society.

title: EGYPT ACCUSES P.L.O. OF INTERFERENCE
description: President Hosni Mubarak has reprimanded the Palestine Liberation Organization for what he called interference in Egyptian affairs and for ''attempting to play Egyptians against each other.''

title: NONALIGNED LITMUS
description: This week, at the great third-world conclave in New Delhi, we shall see to what degree Indira Gandhi's India is in the Soviet orbit and how much the rest of the ''nonaligned'' nations are prey to a double standard.

title: Market Place; Gains Defy Forecasts
description: ON the New York Stock Exchange last Thursday, 337 issues sold at their highest prices in 52 weeks, while only one stock set a new low. It meant that the bull market, defying repeated forecasts of stumbling blocks, kept moving ahead nimbly.

title: DEVILS DEFEAT RANGERS BY 6-4
description: The Devils opened a three-goal lead and held off a late rally to beat the Rangers, 6-4, at Madison Square Garden last night and move out of the Patrick Division cellar.

title: U.S. AIDES FEEL REASSURANCE
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's conservative coalition won a decisive mandate Sunday to govern West Germany for the next four years.

title: MORE THAN COAST IS CHANGING
description: After his Malibu home was destroyed by waves last week, Robert Webber, an actor, told an interviewer: ''This used to be a Garden of Eden.''

title: Loudon Wainwright 3d In Town Hall Concert
description: Loudon Wainwright 3d's fusion of original folk songs and satirical standup comedy has evolved to the point where his solo performances aren't simply concerts but theatrical events. And having recently completed a stint in the Broadway musical, ''Pump Boys and Dinettes,'' Mr. Wainwright's comic timing is sharper than ever.

title: Airlines Attacked in Iraq
description: The manager of the Air France office in Baghdad, Iraq, died today of injuries received Saturday when a boobytrapped package exploded, airline officials here said. The state-run Iraqi press agency, meanwhile, said the police dismantled a second bomb today at the office of Kuwait Airways in the Iraqi capital.

title: TIME INC. IN ELECTRONIC ERA
description: When Time magazine put a computer on its ''man of the year'' cover in January, its imprimatur was stamped on the technological revolution. But long before that, the magazine's corporate parent, Time Inc., had already come to terms with the future.

title: PRICE TALKS BY OPEC POSTPONED
description: The 13 OPEC oil ministers who gathered here to seek an accord on lowering oil prices postponed their first full meeting until Tuesday - and perhaps later - after Iran insisted it would never agree to a cut in OPEC's official prices.

title: NEW I.B.M. MODEL DUE
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is expected to announce today a more powerful version of its personal computer as well as other hardware and software that will extend the line into the office computer market.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MARCH 8, 1983
description: International

title: Republic Air's Oversight
description: Flights by Republic Airlines between Valdosta and Dothan, Ala., are suddenly among the most popular in the nation because of an oversight that allows travelers to claim more than $600 worth of free tickets by taking the $54 Valdosta-Dothan trip.

title: BRIEFS
description: Anthem Electronics Inc. of San Jose, Calif., said its board had declared a 3-for-2 stock split, payable on March 31 to shareholders of record March 17.

title: Chess: Belyavsky Ties Kasparov In the Soviet Quarterfinal
description: Aleksandar Belyavsky, a 29-year-old Soviet co-champion, won the fourth game of his quarterfinal match in Moscow for world championship candidates and achieved a 2-2 tie in the series with his countryman, 19-year-old Gari Kasparov.

title: U.S.F.L. DOES WELL IN RATINGS NUMBERS
description: Do television viewers care about pro football in March? On a Sunday afternoon when quality pro and college basketball was available, as were boxing, golf, figure skating and skiing, the opening of the United States Football League's season dominated the struggle to attract New York's viewing audience.

title: TO CARE FOR VETERANS IN NON-V.A. FACILITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Making a Case For Dow 1,500
description: HEIKO H. THIEME is no starry-eyed broker who automatically tells clients that stocks are headed for the moon. But, as a Wall Street professional who views United States markets from a European perspective, he believes the Dow Jones industrial average will reach 1,500 by August 1984. Yesterday, the Dow edged up 0.78, to 1,141.74, its fifth-straight record closing.

title: Barclays Group Profits Fall 21%
description: The Barclays Group, which includes Britain's largest clearing bank, reported today that profits in 1982 slumped 21 percent, to $550 million, from $697 million in 1981. Provisions for bad and doubtful debts more than doubled, to $481 million, from $212 million in 1981, while higher taxes and lower interest rates further hurt earnings.

title: Net Rises 18.2% At H.J. Heinz
description: The H.J. Heinz Company reported today that third-quarter quarter profits rose 18.2 percent from a year earlier, despite a decline in revenue.

title: 'Particles' Found In Shuttle Satellite
description: As technicians prepared to re-install the repaired engines of the space shuttle Challenger, the space agency said Monday it had found another problem that could potentially delay the flight: contamination of the giant tracking and data relay satellite the shuttle is to carry.

title: Poles Indict Ex-Union Aide
description: Jan Kulaj, head of the outlawed Rural Solidarity union, has been charged with accepting bribes to obtain new cars for union members, the army newspaper Zolnierz Wolnosci said today. Mr. Kulaj is one of about a dozen former union leaders and advisers charged with crimes by the Government.

title: GAS DECONTROL FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE CONSUMER
description: To the Editor:

title: 1983 MICHELIN RATINGS OF FRENCH RESTAURANTS
description: The 1983 ratings of the Michelin Guide to France were issued here today, demoting three top-rated three-star restaurants to two stars. No restaurants in France were upgraded to three stars.

title: JAPAN'S NEW NONCONFORMISTS
description: Japanese companies seeking new employees typically have one goal in mind: hiring the graduates of leading national universities. Masaya Nakamura, president of Namco Ltd., however, takes an entirely different approach.

title: Paying, and Not Paying, for Transit; Token Injustice From the Bench
description: Some New York City judges take a lighthearted view of subway cheats who use 17 1/2-cent Connecticut Turnpike tokens to steal a 75-cent subway ride. Dismissing one such prosecution recently, Judge Martin Erdmann said the token cases were ''of so little import as to shock the common taxpayer.''

title: MAURICE J. D'AGOSTINO
description: Maurice J. D'Agostino, former proprietor of the Cranbury (N.J.) Inn, died of cancer Thursday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 60 years old and lived in Cranbury.

title: N.B.A. Talks to Resume
description: Faced with an April 2 strike deadline, negotiators for the National Basketball Association resume talks in Manhattan this morning with the union representing the league's players.

title: Bauer Is Moving Up
description: Less than a year ago, Mike Bauer left the University of California to become a touring tennis pro. Now, with a victory over Jimmy Connors, he has leaped from 89th in the world to the top 50 in one week.

title: CATHY BERBERIAN, MEZZO-SOPRANO
description: Cathy Berberian, the American vocalist best known for her riveting and unorthodox performances of contemporary music, died, apparently of heart attack, in a Rome hotel on Sunday. She was 54 years old.

title: INDUSTRIAL ACOUSTICS CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
PENN ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Havel, Dissident Writer, Released From Hospital
description: The dissident Czechoslovak playwright Vaclav Havel, who had been seriously ill with pneumonia, was released from a hospital Friday, emigre sources in Vienna said today.

title: Reagan Will Cooperate With Atomic Agency
description: President Reagan told Congress today that he intended to continue Washington's cooperation with the European Atomic Energy Community despite lack of an accord on the reprocessing of United States nuclear fuel.

title: Gerard H. Manges Dead at 48; A Specialist in Corporate Law
description: Gerard H. Manges, a partner in the New York law firm of Gadsby & Hannah, died of a heart attack en route to a hospital Sunday after being stricken at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 48 years old.

title: LIFE IS BITTER FOR WIVES OF SOVIET POLITICAL OUTCASTS
description: Only two days remained in her husband's laborcamp term, so Katya Abramkin packed him a new suit of clothes, got her small son ready and checked the train tickets. She never made the trip.

title: ROSE'S STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
Prudential May Get Bank
description: The Prudential Insurance Company is studying whether to buy a bank, Robert A. Beck, chairman, said in response to questions at the company's annual news conference.

title: DILLON, READ TO RECOVER CONTROL FROM BECHTEL
description: Dillon, Read & Company, the Wall Street investment banking house, said yesterday that its managing directors had agreed to buy a sufficient number of Dillon, Read shares from the Bechtel family of San Francisco to give the banking house's management control of the firm.

title: BIRTCHER CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Comings and Goings
description: Mike Schmidt, the power-hitting third baseman for the Philadelphia Phillies, underwent minor knee surgery and will be out of the spring training lineup for two weeks. . . . Joe Montana, the San Francisco 49er quarterback, underwent knee surgery and is expected to be fully recovered within two months. . . . Naas Botha, a 25-year-old South African rugby star, has been signed by the Dallas Cowboys as a candidate for the punting job. He will join the team in training camp this summer. . . . Mark Taylor, the Philadelphia Flyers' right wing, has refractured his left leg and will miss at least two weeks.

title: A Pipe Bomb Is Found In Henry St. Basement
description: Hundreds of Henry Street residents were evacuated from their homes near Chinatown for three hours last night after a pipe bomb was found next to a gas main in the basement of 219 Henry Street, the police said.

title: Nonprofit Theater Group Gets a $25,000 Grant
description: Home Box Office, the pay television service, yesterday gave $25,000 to the Theater Communications Group, the national organization of nonprofit professional theaters.

title: HURCO MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
League Draws 243,070 Fans
description: Following is a list of announced attendance figures for the season opening United States Football League games: New Jersey Generals at Los Angeles Express: 34,002.

title: First Chicago to Lend $59.5 Million to Mexico
description: The First Chicago Corporation will increase its loans to Mexico by $59.5 million under terms of a worldwide credit pact that was negotiated through the International Monetary Fund, the bank said in its annual report, which was published today.

title: 3 Soviet Police Aides Ousted
description: Authorities in Soviet Georgia have announced the dismissal of three police officers in a new drive against bribery and graft there. A report in the Georgian Communist Party daily, Zarya Vostoka, said the punishment of the three, who included a criminal investigations chief, was meant to serve as an example to other law enforcement officials.

title: PACO PHARMACEUTICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 12
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Nov 24, 1982

title: JUSTICE DEPT. SAYS IT WILL REPRESENT MRS. BURFORD IN CONTEMPT CASE
description: The Justice Department said today that it was willing to continue representing the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency in court cases involving her contempt-of-Congress citation, though it would not represent her or her aides in Congressional hearings into allegations of improprieties in the agency.

title: Panthers Win, 9-7
description: Novo Bojovic kicked three field goals to give the Michigan Panthers a 9-7 victory over the Birmingham Stallions tonight in the United States Football League.

title: Las Vegas Team Riddled by Illness
description: Several Nevada-Las Vegas basketball players, including Sidney Green, are ill and may not be at full strength for the first round of the Pacific Coast Athletic Association tournament, which starts Thursday.

title: TV Rights Awarded For Kickoff Classic
description: Katz Sports, an 18-month-old independent television production company, has won television rights to college football's first Kickoff Classic at Giants Stadium Aug. 29. It bid more than $1.2 million for the game.

title: Bethlehem Steel
description: The Bethelehem Steel Corporation said it planned to re-fire its second blast furnace at the Burns Harbor mill next week, resulting in recalls for about 135 laid-off workers.

title: Aid for Kosher Kitchens
description: Saying that 33 percent of the Bronx's 90,000 Jews are ''at or near the poverty line,'' Representative Mario Biaggi was concerned that none of the 930,000 pounds of Government-surplus cheese awaiting distribution from a Bronx warehouse was kosher.

title: Trial in Judge's Killing Brings Perjury Decision
description: Jo Ann Harrelson was found guilty today of lying to a Federal grand jury about the purchase of a hunting rifle that might have been used by her husband, Charles Harrelson, to kill a Federal judge.

title: Pan Am Outlook
description: Pan American World Airways expects to be ''back in the black'' on its profit and loss account for the month of March, C. Edward Acker, chairman, said at a news conference. He said the company, which lost $485 million in 1982, had a substantial earnings improvement in both January and February, but gave no earnings forecast for the first quarter as a whole. Mr. Acker also said that Pan Am, which operates flights to China, is planning to resume flights to Taiwan.

title: MUSIC: AN EVENING WITH PAUL SHEFTEL
description: PAUL SHEFTEL is not only a pianist, but also a composer and scholar. On Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall, he demonstrated original and convincing ideas about the music he plays, as well as the technique to bring them to fruition.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Johnson Sidelined

title: Hamilton Is Trailing
description: Jean-Christophe Simond of France took an early lead in the men's World figure skating championships today, earning the best marks in all three of the compulsory figures.

title: OPI Inc. Default
description: OPI Ltd., based in Edmonton, Alberta, said its United States subsidiary, OPI Inc., was in default on a substantial share of its United States bank loans.

title: Business and the Law Antitrust Ideas: 3 Problems
description: PROFESSIONAL economists do not agree among themselves on what constitutes anticompetitive behavior - so where does that leave antitrust lawyers?

title: Boeing Jet Approved
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has approved the Boeing Company's largest jetliner, the 747-300, for commercial service after a four-month flight test program, Boeing said today. The new jetliner accommodates more passengers than Boeing's 747.

title: U.D.C. CANCELS CONTRACT WITH EX-VICE PRESIDENT
description: The new head of the State Urban Development Corporation yesterday canceled a $50,000 consultant's contract to a former vice president of the agency.

title: G.M. Ohio Plant
description: Nearly a year after losing their jobs in a layoff that claimed the entire second shift, furloughed workers began returning to the General Motors Corporation's car assembly plant.

title: WILLIAM BLACK, FOUNDER AND HEAD OF CHOCK FULL o' NUTS CORP., DIES
description: William Black, founder and chairman of the Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation, died of cancer yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Georgetown Beats Syracuse
description: Patrick Ewing scored 26 points and pulled down 11 rebounds, enabling Georgetown to end the regular season with an 80-75 Big East Conference victory over Syracuse.

title: Q & A
description: Q. The snowfall that blanketed the New York area last month was said to range from 19 to 22 inches, depending on where the snow fell. Since snow drifts about so much, how can it be measured with any degree of accuracy?

title: ALTERNATIVES FOR COMMUTERS
description: During the strike against Metro-North, buses will serve some train stations on the Hudson, Harlem and New Haven lines. Some buses will travel to Manhattan; others will connect with subway lines in the Bronx.

title: NEW YORK DOMINATES IN SCIENCE TALENT HUNT
description: New York State won 8 of the top 10 awards tonight in the annual Westinghouse Talent Search. A 16-year-old student from the Bronx High School of Science, Paul Ning of Washington Heights, won the first prize, for a project in advanced number theory.

title: NUN DEFIES ARCHBISHOP ON MEDICAID ABORTIONS
description: A Roman Catholic nun here is defying her Archbishop's order to resign as state director of social services because she will not denounce the state-financed abortions for poor women that her department administers.

title: Paying, and Not Paying, for Transit; Worthy Sacrifice From Cummuters
description: In taking a strike by the United Transportation Union, which represents conductors on what are now called the Metro-North lines, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority makes an important point: it is determined to get its hands firmly on the cost throttle. M.T.A. riders have a big stake in its winning the point; in that sense, the inconvenience, discomfort and financial loss of the strike are a reasonable price to pay.

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: FRENCH LEFT, SET BACK, PLANS FOR LOCAL RUNOFFS
description: Socialist and Communist leaders met today to discuss tactics for the second round of the national municipal elections next Sunday after the first round of balloting showed the left taking greater losses than it considered acceptable.

title: FROST & SULLIVAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Miss Palli Wins by 7
description: Anne-Marie Palli, a 27-year-old French professional, turned the rain-shortened $150,000 Samaritan Turquoise Classic into a runaway today, shooting a five-under-par 68 and winning by seven strokes.

title: RECITAL: 'WINTERREISE'
description: CHRISTA LUDWIG'S singing of ''Winterreise'' at the Metropolitan Opera Sunday evening required a certain suspension of disbelief. Schubert's great song cycle tells, of course, a man's story, and the words of Wilhelm Muller's poems are those of a hero not a heroine.

title: Brooks Seen as Mets' Fixture
description: If you ask Hubie Brooks how many men have played third base for the Mets in their 21 seasons, he will answer: 72, which is correct. If you ask him to name the player standing between him and a long-term lease on the job, he will answer: Hubie Brooks, also correct.

title: Bunting's New Home
description: John Bunting, the linebacker who was abruptly released by the Philadelphia Eagles a month ago, has found a new football home in Philadelphia -with the Stars of the United States Football League. Financial details were not disclosed, but Bunting's brother, Jim, a Philadelphia lawyer, said the two-year pact provided ''long-term security'', including an offseason coaching position. Bunting had accused the Eagles of letting him go because of his vocal leadership as the team's player representative in last year's players strike, a charge the Eagles denied.

title: RAIL STRIKE CLOGS TRAFFIC ON ROADS IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Nearly 90,000 commuters joined car pools and crowded onto buses, subways and clogged highways yesterday as a trainmen's strike shut down New York City's principal rail arteries from the north and east.

title: Topics; Wobbles and Walls
description: Button-Down Theory

title: A BROOKLYN JURY DELIBERATES IN KILLING OF TRANSIT WORKER
description: A jury yesterday began deliberating the fate of an 18-year-old man charged with murder and other crimes in the fatal beating in Brooklyn of a black man, after hearing summations by the prosecution and defense and instructions from the presiding judge,

title: Anchor Hocking Sale
description: The Anchor Hocking Corporation announced today that it had completed the cash sale of its Dutch metal closure operation, Lindner Industrie B.V., to Numan-Blikemba N.V. No price was disclosed.

title: New Casino Plan in Jersey
description: A major South African hotel group announced today that it intended to develop a $250 million casino complex in Atlantic City.

title: BIRD'S SURGE FOILS NETS
description: There are certain things a team can try to do to stop Larry Bird. Tonight, nothing the Nets tried worked. After sitting out the first six minutes of the final period, Bird scored 13 of Boston's next 19 points and finished with 30 as the Celtics defeated the New Jersey Nets, 121-114, at the Civic Center.

title: MUSIC: RARE VISIT BY BRITONS
description: WHEN one contemplates their vast catalogue of recordings, it is a little disconcerting to realize how few concerts the Academy of St. Martin in the Fields has given on these shores. But the British group made up for lost time at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday night with an exquisite evening of music under the direction of Iona Brown.

title: Italian Fighter Is Out of Coma
description: Claudio Cassanelli emerged today from the coma he was in since his defeat in a heavyweight fight here Feb. 25.

title: NATIONAL HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes extraordinary gains of $346,000 for the qr and $8,017,000 for the yr...C-Net loss which included income of $891,000 from discontinued operations

title: BALLET: AN IDAHO TROUPE
description: IT'S always a pleasure to discover ballet thriving in unexpected places. Given its lack of major metropolitan centers, Idaho would seem to be a most unlikely place for ballet. Yet, since 1972, it has been the home of the American Festival Ballet, the little troupe that appeared Sunday night at Brooklyn College.

title: KELLY JOHNSTON ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE KIDNEY'S MARVELS
description: IN most of us, organs of the body don't usually inspire much in the way of awe and wonder. They do their jobs and just keep plugging away until one day they fail or stop. But doctors who work with them constantly, doctors who really love what they do, are in fact often struck with the majesty of something as common as, say, a kidney.

title: German Votes, and Chits
description: Americans should be pleased with the outcome of the West German elections, mainly because the Russians made them into a crude choice between East and West. Economic issues alone can explain Chancellor Helmut Kohl's triumph, but the Russians thought they would frighten the Germans into deserting NATO's position on Euromissiles. Having interfered, Moscow stands rebuffed. There'll be no cheap way to keep American missiles off the Continent. Western arms restraint will have to be bought in negotiations, with Soviet reductions.

title: Davis Adds 2 Records
description: Clinton Davis, the outstanding schoolboy sprinter from Steel Valley High School in Homestead, Pa., posted national indoor high school records for 300 yards and 220 yards tonight at the 10th annual Eastern States track and field championships in Jadwin Gym.

title: Dow Posts Fifth Straight High; Gains 0.78, To 1,141.74
description: Stock prices finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average registering its fifth consecutive closing high.

title: BRIEFING
description: Baseball, Anyone?

title: Search for Dissidents Goes On in Zimbabwe
description: Security forces threw cordons around Bulawayo's predominantly poor townships again today in the third day of their hunt for dissidents. The Government termed ''absolute nonsense'' an assertion by Joshua Nkomo, the opposition leader, that Prime Minister Robert Mugabe had sent troops to kill him.

title: RATES JUMP AT WEEKLY SALE
description: Rates rose sharply at the weekly auction of new 90- and 180-day Treasury bills yesterday. The average discount rate on the 90-day bills climbed to 8.205 percent, from 7.944 percent a week earlier, while that on the companion six-month bills advanced to 8.171 percent, from 7.948.

title: Mortgages Down to 13.59%
description: The average interest rate charged Americans for new mortgages fell in February to 13.59 percent from 13.90 percent in January, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

title: POLITICAL MOTIVE IN STATE'S ADS DURING ELECTION CAMPAIGN IS DENIED
