description: A former New York State Commerce Commissioner testified today that he had had no political intentions when, under instructions from then-Governor Hugh L. Carey, he stepped up television commericals touting New York's economy immediately before the gubernatorial election last fall.

title: CONSOLIDATED PIPE LINES CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
COURT LIFTS BAN ON GROUP HOME FOR THE RETARDED
description: A New York State appeals court ruled yesterday that restrictions written into deeds in a Suffolk County community could not be used to prevent the state from establishing a group home for eight mentally retarded adults there.

title: Diplomat's Wife Calls After Search
description: The wife of a Yemeni diplomat who had been reported missing in New York since last Thursday telephoned relatives yesterday and said that she had been visiting a friend in Connecticut, the police said.

title: Monsanto Sale
description: The Monsanto Company said it had agreed in principle to sell its European acrylic fiber business and had set a provision for losses on the sale of $18 million. Monsanto said the provision would reduce its 1982 earnings to $352 million, or $8.79 a share, from $370 million, or $9.25 a share, previously reported. The company said said the business would be acquired by Montefibre, a unit of Montedison of Italy.

title: THIRD WORLD CHIEFS HEAR MRS. GANDHI
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi opened a conference of third world leaders here today with a speech stressing conciliation on political issues and appealing for immediate debt relief and more aid for poor nations. She said such aid should be followed by a world economic conference that would seek to overhaul the international monetary and financial system.

title: WARWICK INSURANCE MANAGERS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: The latest yr includes the results of the Warwick Insurance Co which first commenced operations during 1982; the latest period's per shr figures were adjusted for stock splits in Mar and Nov 1982

title: A Salute From Overseas
description: Marife Hernandez began a television program, ''The Puerto Rican New Yorker,'' in 1970 and went on to become one of that community's most active representatives.

title: Optimism Voiced On City Budget
description: City officials said yesterday that the fiscal outlook for New York might not be as grim as had been forecast earlier this year. Mayor Koch said in January that he might have to reduce the size of the Police Department by 1,800 officers, scrapping plans to hire 1,000 officers, and that he planned to lay off 4,000 Board of Education employees.

title: RIP ENGLE, 76, FOOTBALL COACH OF BROWN, PENN STATE TEAMS
description: Rip Engle, who made a national power of Pennsylvania State University's football team in his 16 years as its head coach, died yesterday in Bellefonte, Pa., at the age of 76.

title: Hartford Seeks Loans For Jobless Payments
description: Connecticut asked the Federal Government today for an additional $24 million in loans to help provide unemployment benefits next month, Gov. William A. O'Neill said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HAPPY BIRTHDAY, IRVING

title: ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Battle on the Thames
description: Oxford has seven straight victories over Cambridge in their famous crew race up the Thames, and for the last five of them, 28-year-old Boris Rankov has been in the Oxford shell.

title: BONANZA INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $9,000 for the qr and $345,000 for the yr...C-Net los

title: Learning to Drink
description: Much has been written about the tendency of children to copy the bad habits of their parents, especially with regard to alcohol consumption and cigarette smoking. However, a new study by psychologists at the University of Michigan suggests that mimicry of parental drinking behavior occurs only when that behavior fits in well with the community norm.

title: DEBATE OVER NUCLEAR BAN: CAN U.S. SPOT CHEATS?
description: WHEN President Reagan announced several months ago that he was postponing United States efforts to negotiate a complete ban on nuclear testing, the underlying arguments for that decision began a debate among scientists that has grown more heated with each passing week.

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE TOWNS WILL VOTE ON ACID RAIN
description: Eighteen years ago, when a graduate student, Tom Siccama, catalogued the species, the growth rate and density of the trees growing on Camels Hump mountain in adjacent Vermont, the forest was thick, dark green and flourishing. Some of the red spruce were 100 feet high and more than 300 years old.

title: U.S. AGENTS GET WIDER LATITUDE IN INVESTIGATIONS
description: Attorney General William French Smith today issued new guidelines making it somewhat easier for Federal agents to investigate groups that try to ''achieve political or social change'' through the use of violence.

title: KOHL, THE ANCHOR
description: The election in West Germany stands as a striking victory not only for Helmut Kohl and his Christian Democratic Party but also for moderation, stability and the Western alliance. Voters streamed to the polls in almost record numbers to assert their abiding commitment to a consensus of the middle. While welcomed by the United States - and with good reason - Sunday's results in no way diminish the need for Washington to develop a more sensitive and flexible policy toward West Germany.

title: QUEEN BIDS U.S. FAREWELL AS WEST COAST JOURNEY ENDS
description: Calling it ''a wonderful and enjoyable journey,'' Queen Elizabeth II today completed her travels along the length of the West Coast and set sail for Canada.

title: SOVIET SAYS KOHL RECEIVED NO MANDATE ON MISSILES
description: The Soviet Union issued a series of news commentaries today warning the West German Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl of retaliation if it took its victory in Sunday's elections as a mandate to proceed with the deployment of American nuclear missiles.

title: Post Seeks Shift
description: Citing a desire to resume rivalries with Hofstra, Fordham and other nearby schools, C.W. Post College has asked the National Collegiate Athletic Association to drop its football team from Division II to Division III.

title: HARDY SUBURBAN COMMUTERS BECOME COMRADES IN COPING
description: Orphans of the storm and of the strike, 90,000 commuters greeted the grayest of Mondays yesterday. They left their beds before dawn to try to reach their jobs before lunch, employing an impromptu armada of buses and vans, limousines and station wagons, car pools and subways.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE LATIN POOR VS. POOR
description: The old house crouched comfortably on the hillside overlooking a valley. The long porch was cool, even in the midday heat. The family, originally from Canada, talked casually in Spanish, French and English about land redistribution, the personality of the Archbishop and political trivia.

title: Penney Videotex Plans
description: The J.C. Penney Company said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent with First Bank System Inc. of Minneapolis to acquire the bank's videotex systems operation. Ralph B. Henderson, a Penney executive vice president, said the company had been involved in a number of videotex tests and was ''well placed strategically to enter this business because of our existing communications network capabilities.''

title: BLUE-COLLAR REVOLT AGAINST SUBURBAN ESTHETICS
description: Gary Gross said that at a time when image was everything - when people wear their clothing tags on the outside and insist on French water that bubbles with sophistication - he should not be surprised that officials in this suburb have passed an ordinance forbidding him and other tradesmen to park vehicles with commercial license plates in their driveways overnight.

title: A.T.&T. Forecast
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said earnings for the first quarter would decline about $287 million from the $2.01 billion reported in the quarter a year earlier. An A.T.&T. spokesman said the drop would reflect an accounting change for deferred taxes. Without the accounting change, results for the period would be ''essentially unchanged from that for the first quarter of 1982,'' the company said.

title: Pan Am Vice President To Head Service Unit
description: Gerald L. Gitner, executive vice president for finance and chief financial officer at Pan American World Airways, has been named to the additional post of chairman of Pan Am World Services.

title: Stokely-Van Camp Faces Esmark Bid
description: Esmark Inc., the Chicago holding company, disclosed yesterday that it had acquired 6.1 percent of the common stock of Stokely-Van Camp Inc., the large food packer, as the first step in a possible takeover.

title: STRATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ACROSS AMERICA, DIOXIN
description: Despite the public outcry over dioxin contamination at Times Beach, Mo., and disclosures of Environmental Protection Agency misconduct, one of the most scandalous aspects of the toxic chemical situation has been largely overlooked: Millions of pounds of herbicides containing dioxin continue to be used across the United States, including urban areas and land where food and cattle are raised.

title: GATES LEARJET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Lost Opportunity
description: The National Invitation Tournament would love to have the University of District of Columbia basketball team. The school would love to be in the N.I.T., with its television exposure and big-city publicity.

title: 88 Young Scholars Get Fellowships
description: Eighty-eight young scientists and economists have been chosen to receive two-year research fellowships of $25,000 each, the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation announced yesterday. The fellows, working on problems in chemistry, economics, pure and applied mathematics, neuroscience and physics, are attending 47 colleges, universities and research institutions in the United States, the foundation said.

title: Advertising; Lark Drops Its Drowsy Approach
description: THE camera opens up on a small group of luggage-laden burros standing quite docilely. What's this? One is standing on its hind legs and doffing its head.

title: LOGISTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TADPOLES' STRONG KINSHIP AWARENESS
description: TADPOLES spawned by a species of frog native to Oregon and Washington have been found to be able to recognize their own brothers and sisters as well as their half siblings, and can tell which parent they have in common. According to the scientists who made the discovery, their finding marked the first time that such finely tuned kin recognition had been pinpointed in a creature other than a mammal.

title: First Maryland Set To Sell Large Stake
description: Allied Irish Banks Ltd. said today that it had agreed to buy a majority interest in the First Maryland Bancorp. of Baltimore for about $150 million.

title: MEM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NBC FIGHTS TO SAVE 'ST. ELSEWHERE'
description: MOST of the time low-rated television programs are allowed to expire as quickly as network executives find more promising replacements. Occasionally, however, a show with poor audience ratings inspires such critical acclaim that a network throws its resources into keeping it afloat.

title: SETTLERS TO LEAVE WEST BANK SITE
description: Defense Minister Moshe Arens today ordered the evacuation of a small settlement in the Israeli-occupied West Bank that was set up last year by followers of the former Jewish Defense League leader, Rabbi Meir Kahane, the Israeli Army radio reported.

title: At Least 67 Die In Turkish Mine Blast
description: At least 67 miners were killed today when a gas explosion tore through a coal mine on the Turkish Black Sea coast east of Istanbul, the local provincial governor said.

title: IN RWANDA'S FORBIDDING JUNGLE, MAN GREETS ENDANGERED GORILLA
description: THE guide high in the mountains bordering Rwanda and Zaire motions to the members of his small group to be still. Rare and endangered mountain gorillas, which are capable of crushing a human skull with a single bite of their large jaws or of easily breaking a neck with arms that span seven feet, have been sighted in a clearing in the thick jungle.

title: CHOCK FULL STOCK IS UP AGAIN
description: The price of Chock Full o'Nuts stock rose yesterday amid speculation on Wall Street that a new battle would soon develop for control of the big coffee producer and restaurant chain.

title: ITALIAN, OFF TO U.S., EXPECTS NEW RESPECT
description: Foreign Minister Emilio Colombo left for Washington today with a sense that the United States, perhaps better than European members of the Atlantic alliance, had overcome a long-held view of Italy as a junior partner.

title: Grain Talks Set for April
description: Policy makers from major grainexporting countries have scheduled a meeting for April 26 to 28 to discuss huge surpluses and increasing competition for world markets.

title: COMPUCORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes an extraordinary gain of $270,000

title: WORLD BANK'S PROBLEM LOANS
description: In West Africa, near limestone quarries in southeastern Togo, the World Bank in the 1970's pumped $60 million into a plant that bakes ''clinkers.'' These bricks of limestone are then crushed and mixed with gypsum to produce cement.

title: Divers Assess Damage To Coal Ship That Sank
description: The owners of the sunken Marine Electric said today that divers who examined the wreck found a large hole in the ship's hull that could have been caused when she struck bottom while aiding another vessel in distress.

title: SALE OF WEATHER SATELLITES STUDIED
description: The Reagan Administration is considering selling satellites used by the National Weather Service to private companies, a spokesman for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said yesterday.

title: MIKE FERRARO'S TRAUMA
description: For the last decade, Mike Ferraro had been working and waiting for the opportunity to be a major league manager. Suddenly, early last November, the Cleveland Indians hired him. Even more suddenly, early last month the 38-year-old former Yankee coach needed surgery for the removal of a cancerous left kidney. But two weeks ago, he arrived to take command of his team. And today, less than four weeks after the operation, Mike Ferraro will be managing the Indians for the first time in their exhibition opener.

description: B-Net loss; results for the latest periods include operations of Vapler-Fisher Corp acquired on Jan 1, 1982

title: HEINZ, H J, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
INMAN'S 2D CAREER: TACKLING JAPANESE TECHNOLOGY
description: When Bobby Ray Inman resigned last spring as deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, he said it was because he had lost his ''zest'' for bureaucratic infighting after 30 years on the Government payroll.

title: JACKSON NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 50 percent stock divd and the sale of 850,000 common shrs; the current qtr and yr net includes investment income equal to 14 cents a shr

title: Eastern Airline Talks On
description: Eastern Airlines and the International Association of Machinists resumed negotiations today to try to avert a weekend strike that leaders say could be ''disastrous'' for south Florida. A 30-day cooling-off period ends at 12:01 A.M. Sunday, and union leaders say they will not hesitate to ask their members, including 13,500 mechanics, baggage handlers and ground employees, to walk out.

title: SGL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
RAIDERS SEIZE 7, REPORT BREAKING A BIG DRUG RING
description: Displaying more than $1 million in cash, 37 fur coats and trays of expensive jewelry seized in early-morning raids Sunday, agents of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration said yesterday they had broken a major heroin ring based in Harlem.

title: A CAB RIDE INTO FUTURE BY EXPERTS
description: The time is the hypothetical future. The place is New York. The protagonist is the city's typical taxi rider, who, studies have found, is a 35-year-old woman earning $27,000 a year. Heading home from the office on this imaginary day, she faces a galaxy of choices. She can telephone a livery service, selecting the one that suits her best on the basis of price and availability. She can go out into the street and look for a cab displaying a green light that indicates it is charging a cut-rate fare. If she doesn't find one right away, she can choose instead a cab displaying a yellow light indicating a standard fare. And if that fails, she can hail a cab with its red light illuminated, meaning that service is at a premium rate.

title: FRANC OFF, MARK RISES; DOLLAR IS MIXED IN U.S.
description: The franc fell sharply today in response to the French Socialists' losses in Sunday's municipal elections. In West Germany, bankers predicted that the mark would grow in value as a result of that country's elections, which returned Chancellor Helmut Kohl to power.

title: YUGOSLAV ECONOMY: A SENSE OF URGENCY
description: Out in New Belgrade, where the Yugoslavs have stamped out row upon row of apartment blocks on fields where Serbian nobles once hunted pheasant, the wind trilled around the windows of Milorad Savicevic's office in one of the two towers that house his company's headquarters.

title: MAIN ISSUES IN STRIKE: STAFFING AND OVERTIME
description: PARTICIPANTS: The striking employees of the Metro-North rail system are the 622 conductors and trainmen represented by the United Transportation Union. They have been working without a contract since Jan. 1, when the state took over nine railroads that had been operated by Conrail.

title: Foremost's Planner Of Drug Takeovers
description: Since 1967, Foremost-McKesson Inc. has been restricted in its attempts to acquire drug-related companies. But that has changed, and Kenneth L. Larson expects to be spending more of his time mapping acquisition strategies.

description: B-Includes a writedown of $18 million on Corco's property for the qr and yr andalso an extraordinary gain from pension terminations of $1.3 million for the yr...C-The company said that the 1982 results could not be compared with 1981 because of the drastic change in its business; the company is listed on the Pacific and Philadelphia stock exchanges

title: Composting as a Business
description: Jack Flanagan helped found Bronx Frontier in 1976, when he was a police detective serving the 41st Precinct as community-affairs officer.

title: SHIFT IS URGED AT VATICAN BANK
description: A leading member of the commission appointed by the Vatican to investigate its links with the failed Banco Ambrosiano has advocated putting operations of the Vatican bank in the hands of laymen.

title: ATTACK ON THE FOURTH
description: Not long after President Reagan's Task Force on Violent Crime recommended in 1981 that Congress legislate a ''good-faith exception'' to the so-called ''exclusionary rule,'' a Task Force member told me privately that the rule did not really prevent many criminals from going to jail.

title: JUSTICES AGAIN REFUSE TO SETTLE ASBESTOS CASE
description: The Supreme Court refused again today to settle a conflict over insurance liability for diseases caused by asbestos. The action increased the pressure on Congress to resolve the growing confusion over conflicting lower-court interpretations of insurance coverage in asbestos cases.

title: CORRECTION
description: An illustration on the Style page Feb. 28 with an article about new roles of women in comics carried an incorrect credit line for Cathy Guisewite's cartoon strip. It should have read: '' c 1983, Universal Press Syndicate. Reprinted with permission.''

title: SPLIT THE OIL PRICE BREAK
description: To the Editor:

title: 7 Officers Go on Trial In Beating of Blacks
description: The trial of seven white New Orleans policemen accused of beating blacks in a hunt for an officer's killer began today as protesters marched outside the courthouse demanding an end to ''police terror.''

title: Mobil Accord Proposed
description: The Department of Energy has proposed settling for $27 million, or less than 3 cents on the dollar, more than $920 million in claims against the Mobil Corporation for reported violations of now-expired price controls on oil, Government sources said today. Under the settlement, which awaits final approval of Energy Secretary Donald P. Hodel, civil enforcement actions related to Mobil's transactions with crude oil ''resellers'' would be suspended unless the resellers were convicted of criminal violations.

title: SEAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $41,000 for the current qr and $49,000 for the yr-ago period

title: NOT AIMING TO FILL SAMPSON'S SHOES
description: In a moment of insight, Olden Polynice, the 6-foot-10-inch center for All Hallows High School in the Bronx, said recently that he would not be Ralph Sampson's replacement. An eventual successor, perhaps, but never a replacement.

title: Judge Bars U.S. Reply In Freedom Rider Suit
description: A Federal district judge barred the Justice Department today from presenting its defense against a $1 million lawsuit by a former Freedom Rider because Government lawyers refused to divulge secret documents.

title: HOW MUCH TRUTH?
description: How much truth can a campaigning politician tell the public and still get elected? Later, once elected, how much truth can he tell them without stirring up such a fuss that he loses the ability to govern?

title: SERVO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MONETARISTS CRITICIZE SURGE IN MONEY
description: The Shadow Open Market Committee, a group of prominent monetarist economists, attacked the Reagan Administration and the Federal Reserve yesterday for a ''resumption of inflationary policies.''

title: ANTAGONISTS IN THE METRO-NORTH RAIL STRIKE SHARE AN INTENSITY IN CONVICTION
description: Peter Eugene Stangl

title: Prices Decline On Eurobonds
description: Dollar-denominated Eurobonds were slightly lower in quiet afternoon trading today, reflecting the lower opening on the New York bond market as Federal funds rose to the 8 3/4 percent level, dealers said.

title: Houston Lighting Bond Yield 12.47%
description: The Houston Lighting and Power Company's $125 million issue of 30-year first mortgage bonds was given a 12 3/8 percent coupon and priced at 99 1/4 to yield 12.47 percent, Kidder, Peabody & Company, the lead manager, said yesterday.

title: DUBIOUS READING OF INFANT MORTALITY BAROMETER
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Peter Tannen has been named senior vice president at Benton & Bowles Inc.

title: U.S. IS REPORTED TO HAVE EVIDENCE THAT BARBIE VISITED IN '69 and '70
description: The Justice Department has found evidence to support a report that Klaus Barbie, a former Gestapo officer twice convicted as a Nazi war criminal, made several trips to the United States from his Bolivian refuge in 1969 and 1970, according to Federal officials and Congressional investigators.

description: The company changed to a calendar yr from yr ended Jan 31; the 1981 figures arefor 11 mos ended Dec 31

title: TUESDAY, MARCH 8, 1983
description: International

title: Injured Cheerleaders
description: A generation ago, cheerleaders led the spectators in chants of sis-boom-bah and then sat down. Modern cheerleaders, with their tumbling and three-high pyramids, are more active - and more prone to injury.

title: COLONIAL PENN GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Operating loss...C-Net loss

title: POPE ISSUES PLEA FOR INDIAN RIGHTS IN GUATEMALA VISIT
description: Pope John Paul II today condemned violence and the persecution of Indians here, warning that ''God will punish'' those who mistreat their fellow man.

title: E.P.A. COUNSEL CONCEDES LAPSE IN CLEANUP CASE
description: The general counsel of the Environmental Protection Agency conceded today that he should not have participated in a settlement on cleaning up a toxic waste dump that had been used by a subsidiary of his former employer.

title: Magnuson Petition Due
description: Magnuson Computer Systems Inc. said yesterday that it planned to file a petition to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Johnson Estimates Withdrawal Costs
description: Johnson & Johnson said it estimates that 1983 after-tax earnings will be reduced by about $20 million as a result of product returns and expenses resulting from the recently announced temporary worldwide withdrawal of its Zomax pain-relieving drug.

title: MISS WILLIAMS SETS MARK IN 200 METERS
description: For Angela Williams, the ninth annual Colgate Women's Games at Madison Square Garden last night was a particularly sweet experience. Miss Williams, one of the top high school sprinters in the country and a three-time Colgate champion in the 200-meter dash, broke her national high school indoor mark in the event with a time of 24.01 seconds.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When you trample a man, when you violate his rights, when you commit flagrant injustices against him, when you submit him to torture, break in and kidnap him or violate his right to life, you commit a crime and a grave offense against God.'' - Pope John Paul II. (A1:1.)

title: U.S. CATHOLIC CONFERENCE ASKS SHIFT ON EL SALVADOR
description: The United States Catholic Conference urged the Reagan Administration today to undertake a ''significant policy shift'' on El Salvador that would focus on a political settlement of the civil war there.

title: Bridge: Only New Yorkers Survive In Grand National Teams
description: Form prevailed Sunday in the Grand National Team Championship at Adelphi University in Garden City, L.I. Two rounds of knockout play cut the field of 32 teams to eight, all from New York City. The pairings in the quarterfinals, by captain, are: Michael Becker vs. August Boehm; Brian Glubok vs. Greg Woods; Alan Greenberg vs. Mike Rosmarin; John Solodar vs. Kathie Wei.

title: MAHRE NEARS WORLD CUP TITLE
description: Phil Mahre of the United States won his first World Cup race of the season today in a giant slalom on Aspen Mountain, and moved closer to his third straight overall Cup title.

title: REICHHOLD LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a special loss of $6,700,000 and a loss of $6,675,000 from discontinued operations

title: LUXURY HOUSING IS BEING ERECTED ON THE EAST SIDE
description: Ground was broken yesterday on 34th Street, overlooking the East River, for construction of what city planning officials said would be the largest privately financed apartment building to rise on the East Side in a quarter-century.

title: U.S. Oil Geologist Kidnapped in Colombia
description: An American employee of a subsidiary of Texaco Inc. was kidnapped today and his two bodyguards shot to death, the police said.

title: ALBERTSON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
ISLAND TELEPHONE CO LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
WAGNER AND MARIST ADVANCE IN PLAYOFFS
description: Art Redmond scored on a dunk shot with 25 seconds to play to help Wagner to a 67-65 victory over St. Francis College last night in the opening round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Metro-North playoffs.

title: Mellon Receives Merger Approval
description: The Federal Reserve System's board of governors said it had approved the Mellon National Corporation's merger with another bank holding company, The Girard Company of Philadelphia. The board also approved the Pittsburgh-based Mellon's acquisition of Mortgage and Trust Inc. of Houston.

title: Study Shows Drop In TV Ad Awareness
description: Just in time to catch the fancy of the multitudes of intense people who will be attending the annual two-day meeting of the Advertising Research Foundation starting today at the New York Hilton, Leo Bogart, executive vice president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, and Charles Lehman, an associate, have written a less-thancomplimentary lead piece about television advertising in the February/ March issue of the Journal of Advertising Research.

BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: COLLEGES PRESS ALCOHOL CURBS AS STATES RAISE DRINKING AGE
description: Backed by higher minimum drinking ages in many states, colleges across the country have begun systematic efforts to reduce the consumption of alcohol by students and to provide help for those with drinking problems.

title: A Gamble That Almost Cost a Game
description: With 4 minutes left in their opening United States Football League game Sunday, the Los Angeles Express were leading the New Jersey Generals by 5 points, 20-15.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Time Inc. incorrectly described Time's disposition of The Washington Star. The newspaper was closed in 1981.

title: Kodak Trust Sale Of Company Stock
description: The Eastman Kodak Charitable Trust plans to sell up to 399,192 shares of Kodak common stock, a Kodak spokesman announced.

title: MUSIC: PIANIST IN NEW WORK
description: THE American Symphony Orchestra divided its time between the old and the new Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. Randall Hodgkinson, the pianist, straddled both these worlds - as soloist in John La Montaine's new Symphonic Variations for Piano and Orchestra and in the Schumann Introduction and Allegro appassionato.

title: THE SPECIALTY AT CRISFIELD IS SEAFOOD
description: Glimpses of Washington's past are not easily perceived through its restaurants. Anyone suffering from unrequited nostalgia for the club-like, wood-paneled Harvey's in its original location, or the lively and colorful lunchtime scene at the old Occidental next to the Willard Hotel, may get a spiritual lift from one of the area's few enduring culinary landmarks, Crisfield in Silver Spring, Md.

title: Gain for Jockey
description: As the result of a decision handed down last month by the state's highest court, the New York Racing Association is considering whether to pursue its case against Larry Saumell, the jockey it accused of having an illegal battery prod at Belmont Park in 1981. In its decision, the Court of Appeals upheld the association's underlying right to make exclusions independently of the state's Racing and Wagering Board, but said that the association had violated due process by barring Saumell without first holding a hearing.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Jewelry valued at $500,000 to $1 million was stolen from the Modell Pawn Shop at 517 West 181st Street in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan. Entrance was made through the shop's front door sometime between Saturday evening and yesterday morning. ... Burglars broke through a vault of the I.D. Watch Case Company at 137-11 90th Avenue in Jamaica, Queens, and stole $200,000 worth of gold and diamonds between 5 P.M. Friday and yesterday morning. ... A fire at 1:22 A.M. in the Canarsie neighborhood of Brooklyn heavily damaged a one-story building, at 10325 Glenwood Road, that contained eight stores. Two firefighters were treated for minor injuries. ... An unidentified man was shot to death in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn about 12:30 A.M. in front of a funeral parlor at 2625 Harway Avenue.

description: William Anson Beebe

PUBLIC MOOD TIED TO MOBILE'S HOSPITAL CARE WOES
description: The emergency room at Springhill Memorial Hospital was bustling. A hallucinating 25-year-old with slashed wrists required 10 doctors, nurses and ambulance drivers to pin him down on the examining table. In rapid succession came two more overdose cases, an 18-year-old with a stab wound in his back, a woman who could not breathe and a child with a sprained arm.

title: WALKER TO BE USED MORE NEXT SUNDAY

After its repair, the storms came again, leaking into the Gillets' expensive drawing room, dripping on the expensive furniture and menacing the expensive handpainted wallpaper that Sister Parrish, the very expensive decorator, had so carefully selected. But the Gillets are resilient. They cheerfully carried on, checkbook at the ready.

title: THEATER: 'SLAB BOYS,' A TALE OF SCOTTISH WORKERS
description: JOHN BYRNE'S ''Slab Boys'' is set in a dingy workroom of a carpet manufacturer in Scotland. The walls are institutional green; the towering windows are so grimy that the sun hasn't a chance of peeking in. Yet the effect is far from depressing. This is a cell where the title characters mix the paints that are used by carpet designers, and those pigments are splattered willy-nilly over nearly every inch of the place. Though the setting may well be a Dickensian sweatshop, it somehow manages to contain the jagged, abstract hint of a rainbow.

N.T.T.'s plan comes after criticism last month by Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, of a two-year-old accord between Japan and the United States aimed at giving American companies access to bidding on N.T.T. contracts.

On the most elementary level, I wonder how often I have been told my name ''doesn't fit into the computer.''

title: EXCERPTS FROM ATTORNEY GENERAL'S NEW GUIDELINES FOR F.B.I. INVESTIGATIONS
description: Following are excerpts from ''Criminal Intelligence Investigations,'' a section of ''Guidelines on General Crimes, Racketeering Enterprise and Domestic Security/Terrorism Investigations,'' issued today by Attorney General William French Smith: Domestic Security/Terrorism Investigations 1. General Authority a. A domestic security/terrorism investigation may be initiated when the facts or circumstances reasonably indicate that two or more persons are engaged in an enterprise for the purpose of furthering political or social goals wholly or in part through activities that involve force or violence and a violation of the criminal laws of the United States. In determining whether an investigation should be conducted, the F.B.I. shall consider all of the circumstances including: (1) the magnitude of the threatened harm; (2) the likelihood it will occur; (3) the immediacy of the threat; and (4) the danger to privacy and free expression posed by an investigation. b. Authority to conduct domestic security/terrorism investigations is separate from and in addition to general crimes investigative authority, racketeering enterprise investigations and international terrorism investigations. c. In the absence of any information indicating planned violence by a group or enterprise, mere speculation that force or violence might occur during the course of an otherwise peaceable demonstration is not sufficient grounds for initiation of an investigation under this section. This does not preclude the collection of information about public demonstrations by enterprises that are under active investigation.

title: I.B.M. EXTENDS LINE OF SMALL COMPUTERS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a more powerful version of its personal computer yesterday and lowered prices on the older model by as much as 15.5 percent.

title: MUSIC: CAL ARTS FESTIVAL
description: THE California Institute of the Arts' Contemporary Music Festival fulfills a valuable function, as a showcase for West Coast composers and as a forum for other composers from around the country and the world.

title: Shamir Coming to U.S.  To Confer on Lebanon
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel will go to Washington at the end of the week for talks with Secretary of State George P. Shultz on the negotiations with Lebanon.

title: Packers Report $2.1 Million Loss
description: The Green Bay Packers corporation, in its annual statement to stockholders, is reporting a net income loss of $2.1 million for the strike-shortened 1982 season, compared with a profit of $871,230 the previous year.

title: SEOUL COURT UPHOLDS DEATH FOR 2 IN ARSON CASE
description: The South Korean Supreme Court today upheld the death sentences of two Christian activists charged with setting fire to the American Cultural Center in the southern port city of Pusan in March 1982, killing a student.

title: Renault Denies Import Report
description: Regie Nationale des Usines Renault said it categorically denied a report in the United States journal Automotive News that the American Motors Corporation, in which Renault holds 46.4 percent, will stop importing the R-18i sedan when new models are introduced next year.

SOUTHAMPTON VOTES DOWN SUBURBIA
description: Living in the Hampton closest to the rest of Long Island, Southampton residents have long worried that parts of their town looked a little too much like nearby suburban Brookhaven and not enough like resort-filled East Hampton.

title: TV MOVIE: 'SVENGALI'
description: ''SVENGALI,'' the made-for-television movie on CBS this evening at 9 o'clock, has a problem. Offering still another variation on the ''Trilby'' novel that George du Maurier published in 1894, the film has been produced slickly enough by Robert Halmi and directed smoothly enough by Anthony Harvey. And it has three substantial stars: Peter O'Toole, Jodie Foster and Elizabeth Ashley. The only problem is that it is basically silly, if not downright unbelievable.

title: THE CO-CAPTAIN WHO DOESN'T PLAY
description: In all the years of St. John's University basketball, only eight men have ever been captain more than one season. Two of them, David Russell and Trevor Jackson, are now finishing their second seasons.

title: TV: DOCUMENTARY ON THE FAMILY
description: ''HAPPILY EVER AFTER'' looks at the married, unmarried and remarried and then asks if the family, as we have known it, is dead. Actually, this intelligent WOR-TV documentary doesn't supply an answer, although it does suggest that, one way or another, everyone is worried about the question. The documentary will be seen on Channel 9 at 7:30 tonight.

title: House Panel Backs Aid To Jobless on Mortgages
description: Homeowners threatened with mortgage foreclosure because they have lost their jobs could get emergency loans from the Government to tide them over under a bill approved today by a House subcommittee.

title: Stand-In for Travolta Is At It Again
description: Jeff Zinn's feet are busy standing in for John Travolta's again - this time in Manhattan instead of Brooklyn and only as part of the whole man.

title: N.B.A. Talks Go 5 Hours
description: Negotiators for the National Basketball Association and the union representing the league's players met twice in Manhattan yesterday, for a total of five hours, the longest session the two sides had held in more than a month.

title: Let Congress Write the F.B.I. Rules
description: Attorney General William French Smith's new guidelines for F.B.I. domestic security investigations make clear why Edward Levi, who held Mr. Smith's office under President Ford, was such a distinguished Attorney General. Mr. Levi's 1976 guidelines marked the Government's first attempt to regulate the bureau's former freewheeling investigations of suspected subversion. But the Levi guidelines stood for more than that, and the Smith guidelines are something less.

title: A Jerk, a Jolt, a Lurch And a Lost Lawsuit
description: The courts give and the courts take away. In August 1981, Creda Mystal of Jamaica, Queens, was awarded $55,000 by a Civil Court jury in her lawsuit against the city's Transit Authority. Mrs. Mystal had boarded an F train at Rockefeller Center when, she said, it suddenly ''lurched forward,'' sending her sprawling onto the floor.

title: POSSIBLE DESTRUCTION OF E.P.A. DATA UNDER INQUIRY
description: The acting Inspector General of the Environmental Protection Agency, Charles Dempsey, is opening an investigation into whether John A. Todhunter, an assistant administrator for toxic substances, deliberately destroyed Government documents.

title: CHIEF OF INSURANCE DEPT.
description: When the State Senate today unanimously confirmed James P. Corcoran as Superintendent of the State Insurance Department, it also, for the first time this century, approved a man who comes from the industry he is charged to regulate.

title: El Salvador's 9-to-5 War
description: Not lies but Huck Finn's word, ''stretchers,'' best describes the Reagan Administration's tales about the imminent collapse of ''our'' side in El Salvador's civil war. There was the one about the possibility that the Salvadoran Army would run out of bullets in 30 days. Or the State Department's forecast that Nicaragua's 40,000-strong army might invade El Salvador, presumably without being noticed as it crossed Honduras.

title: HYSTER'S WAGE-JOB TRADE-OFF
description: Some workers suspected from William Kilkenny's first words - ''The Hyster Company wishes sincerely to find a way to stay and expand in Scotland'' - that they were about to receive an ultimatum from the chairman of the forklift manufacturer, which is based in Portland, Ore.

title: A Family Affair
description: He has his critics, but nobody can say that Edward J. DeBartolo isn't an equal-opportunity father. The shopping-center developer, who set up his son, Edward Jr., as the owner of the San Francisco 49ers in the National Football League, now hopes to establish his daughter, Marie Denise York, as the owner of a Pittsburgh franchise in the United States Football League.

title: Rose Bowl Gets Army-Navy for '83
description: The Army-Navy football game will be played this year at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif., but will return to its long-time Philadelphia home in 1984 and remain there for at least five consecutive years, Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman Jr. said today.

title: KOCH URGES NATIONAL SERVICE AT AGE 18
description: Mayor Koch, saying he believed he had a solution to some of the country's ''critical problems,'' proposed yesterday that Americans be compelled to spend a year performing national service when they reach 18 years of age.

title: BRIEFS

title: Japan Videotape Output

U.S. JURY CHOSEN IN BRUTALITY CASE
description: An all-white jury was seated today to decide if seven white New Orleans police officers violated the civil rights of blacks by brutally interrogating them about the killing of a police officer.

title: THINKING BIG THOUGHTS AWAY FROM THE CAPITAL
description: It has become standard operating procedure, Washington style: If a policy problem is too big or too important to be solved in the high-pressure capital, take it out of town. A weekend of ''brainstorming'' at one of the sylvan reateats scattered around the city has become an increasingly important way in which Washington gets its business done.

title: Bridge: New Laurels Are Collected By Wei-Radin Partnership
description: Judged by any objective standard, the most successful women's partnership in recent years, locally, nationally and internationally, has been that of Kathie Wei and Judi Radin of New York.

title: Health Nominee Confirmed
description: The Senate confirmed John A. Svahn as Under Secretary of Health and Human Services today by a vote of 80 to 11. Senator David Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas, had urged his colleagues to reject the nomination, contending that Mr. Svahn had shown a lack of compassion as Social Security Commissioner in 1980, eliminating 300,000 people from the program's disability rolls.

title: Real Estate; Caldor's Expansion Onto L.I.
description: IN recent years Caldor Inc., the discount retailer based in Norwalk, Conn., has emerged as one of the country's soundest merchandising chains. While some discount giants have marked time or suffered losses during the recession, Caldor has not only remained financially secure but has also steadily expanded in the Northeast.

title: CONCERT: BETTE MIDLER PERFORMS AT MUSIC HALL
description: BETTE MIDLER has always tried for the nearly impossible onstage: the creation of a show-business personality who could embrace the worlds of vaudeville, legitimate theater and rock all in a single evening. Miss Midler has long possessed the theatrical resources for the task, for her sensibility contains a multitude of full-fledged characters, from sad-eyed waifs to her scintillating bawdy alter ego, The Divine Miss M.

His lunch was interrupted first to exchange pleasantries with a wealthy real estate developer and later to josh with Hamilton Jordan and an aide to Senator John Glenn, the Ohio Democrat and Presidential aspirant.

title: CANADIANS WIN ROUND ON LUMBER

title: RECORD FOR VISITS TO CENTRAL PARK ACHIEVED IN '82
description: There were more visits to Central Park last year than at any other time in the park's history, according to estimates in a new study crammed with information about the changing uses of the 126-year-old park.

title: STAGE ABSENTEEISM SAID TO BE RISING

''The only way you went out of the theater back then was feet first. But now, even though there are some younger performers who never miss, there are others who seem to take it much more lightly; they would stay home if they had a fever of the fingernail.''

title: Devils Beaten, 5-4
description: Chico Resch, who has performed brilliantly for the New Jersey Devils most of the season, allowed four goals on the first six shots he faced tonight and was removed 12 minutes 11 seconds into the game.

title: ELAINE ZAYAK'S BID IS HALTED BY INJURY

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: Anna: ''I think you were conditioned never to allow yourself anger. Was it considered a crime in your mother's house?'' Ned: ''Yes, it was.'' Anna: ''Why?'' Ned: ''We were brought up to believe that the surfaces must be kept pleasant.'' Anna: ''I think it's much healthier to let anger out than to bury it so deep you don't even know it is there.'' Ned: ''It may be better for oneself but it's hard on other people.'' Anna: ''Oh Ned, do you think it's easy on me when you freeze up against me? Can't you see that that is just as punishing as you feel I am when I attack you? And it's worse, maybe, because you refuse to have it out. You refuse to talk. And every time you do that and bury your own anger, we get further apart.'' - From ''Anger,'' a new novel by May Sarton (W.W. Norton) ANGER is without question the most apparent, most talked-about and most poorly handled emotion in modern American society. Many people, faced with conflicting messages about the proper time, place and way to express anger, find themselves damned if they do and damned if they don't.

title: TALKS IN JERSEY DELAYED A DAY
description: Negotiations in the eight-day strike against nine rail lines in New Jersey were adjourned today until Thursday. Two mediators now directing the negotiations said they needed a day to review bargaining positions that they had gathered Monday and today in separate meetings with officials of N.J. Transit, which operates the struck lines, and two feuding factions of the striking United Transportation Union.

title: THE MYSTERIES OF FLYCASTING
description: Wooed from my desk by a rare day of warm sunshine early this week, I sallied forth to clean up my vegetable garden in preparation for spring tilling, but went astray as I passed by the rack that holds my flyrods.

title: Consolidated Cigar Is Sold by G.& W.
description: Gulf and Western Industries said yesterday that it had sold its Consolidated Cigar Company operations to a management group for about $120 million in cash and securities.

title: REAGAN ANNOUNCES ACCORD GIVING CONGRESS ALL PAPERS
description: President Reagan accepted the resignation of Anne McGill Burford as Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency today and said he would turn over all documents sought by a House subcommittee investigating the agency.

title: GLAMOUR NO; TYPING, FILING AND LONG HOURS, YES
description: Capitol Hill is a small city in itself, with its own subway system, its own post office, more than its share of peculiar local totems and taboos and a huge concentration of typewriters and computer terminals.

title: An Unhappy Slugger
description: Kent Hrbek, last year's rookie sensation for the Minnesota Twins, was back at first base yesterday after staging a one-game strike to protest what he considered an inadequate contract offer. ''I was upset with the offer, really upset,'' said the 22-year-old slugger, who sat out Tuesday's exhibition game against the Toronto Blue Jays after learning that the Twins would pay him $85,000 for the season.

title: ROLL-CALL VOTE IN HOUSE ON RAISING RETIREMENT AGE TO 67
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 228 to 202 by which the House of Representatives today voted to raise the retirement age to 67 in the next century. A ''yes'' vote is for the higher retirement age. Voting ''yes'' were 76 Democrats and 152 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 188 Democrats and 14 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, no; Erdreich, no; Flippo, yes; Nichols, no; Shelby, yes.

title: SPEED-O-PRINT BUSINESS MACHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income...C-Including a gain of $304,000 from the sale of assets

title: ACID RAIN ASSAILED IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: A resolution asking Washington to do something about acid rain was approved at more New Hampshire town meetings tonight, bringing to 100 the number of communities passing the measure.

title: RUSSIANS TRIUMPH IN PAIRS
description: Elena Valova and Oleg Vasiliev of the Soviet Union won the gold medal in pairs tonight, and Rosalynn Sumners of the United States retained her lead in the women's individual event at the world figure-skating championships.

title: Burroughs Model
description: The Burroughs Corporation said it would begin producing the B2925, a new entry-level computer for its 900-series of midrange systems, replacing a 2800-series model it no longer builds.

title: CONVICTIONS REVERSED IN MASSACHUSETTS DROWNINGS
description: The State Supreme Court today reversed the convictions of seven youths who were found guilty of manslaughter in the drowning deaths of two teen-agers from a neighboring town. But the court said the youths could still be sentenced for assault and battery.

title: PIANO ARTISTRY A RUBINSTEIN LEGACY
description: THE piano artistry of Arthur Rubinstein, who died at age 95 in January, is in no danger of being forgotten. As much as any musician of this century, he left an extensive legacy for listeners. Dozens of recordings span a half century of his career, and the picaresque events of his life are exuberantly detailed in two large volumes of memoirs.

title: GREYHOUND LINES OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including special gains on the sale of property of $632,285 for the latest qrand yr and $3,715,295 for the yr ago qr and yr

title: Advertising; Playboy Casino Campaign
description: WHEN he got his first look at the Playboy Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City last fall, Robert R. Maxey was appalled by the fact that its layout broke several basic rules of casino construction. It is not on the first floor of the building. (Who ever heard of such a thing?) And it is not all on one floor but on three. (Do you believe that?)

title: Museum, Complementing Big Ones, Planned for SoHo
description: SoHo's ''museums'' have been its art galleries and loft studios but now it stands to get a real one. The vacated four-story bakery on Prince Street between West Broadway and Wooster Street, once the rumored site of a new Bloomingdale's branch, has been bought by a California collector who plans to open a museum of contemporary art.

title: ATLAS VAN LINES INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $1,322,484

title: REVCO DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 5
'Care Partners'
description: They came to the movies in pairs, looking and listening as the Charlie Chaplin and William S. Hart silents reeled along to piano music, sentimental or menacing, by 75-year-old Abraham H. Lass.

title: Connors, Lendl Gain in Belgium
description: Jimmy Connors and Ivan Lendl scored victories today in the Belgian indoor tennis championships. Connors advanced to the quarterfinals with a 6-2, 6-2 triumph over West Germany's Klaus Eberhart. Lendl beat Brian Teacher, 7-6, 6-1.

title: BROADWAY STARS DRESSING ROOMS GET TOP BILLING
description: THE dressing rooms of Broadway's stars are a lot like the shows that open on the Great White Way each year. Some make big splashes. Others are quiet and tasteful. A great many are just so-so. And then there are the turkeys - threadbare and badly in need of a little color.

title: Schomburg Center Loses Its Chief
description: Wendell L. Wray has resigned as head of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture. The New York Public Library said Mr. Wray left his $38,000 a year post Monday ''to pursue research and educational interests.''

title: Turk Hurt in Belgrade; Armenian Role Claimed
description: Turkey's Ambassador to Yugoslavia, Galip Balkar, 47 years old, was seriously wounded in the head and shoulder by two gunmen today as his car stopped at a red light.

title: WORLDWIDE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Air Florida Debt
description: Air Florida is trying to renegotiate its debt load and divest itself of the aircraft that are most expensive to fly, according to Donald Lloyd-Jones, president.

title: Raiders' Return Sought
description: A member of the House reintroduced legislation today aimed at returning the Raiders to Oakland. The bill offered by Representative Fortney H. (Pete) Stark, a Democrat who has represented the Oakland area since 1972, would give the National Football League a limited antitrust exemption allowing the league to bar franchise movements.

title: BRIEFING
description: Diplomatic Limbo

description: To the Editor:

description: Basketball

description: * House of Burgundy wine importers, and Swirl Inc. clothing lines to David Deutsch Associates.

title: MOLLOY, ST. PETER'S GAIN CATHOLIC FINAL
description: In overtime games, Archbishop Molloy and St Peter's won last night at Fordham University to reach the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association final.

description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $363,000 for the qr and $357,000 for the yr...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $105,000 for the qr and $185,000 for the yr

title: THURSDAY, MARCH 10, 1983
description: Markets

title: VISITING RUSSIANS GET SCANT ATTENTION
description: Some weeks, it seems, are harder than others, especially when you're out to spread peace, understanding and good will.

title: Zimbabwe vs. Zimbabwe
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe won high praise after Zimbabwe's birth in 1980, when he backed noble words with promising deeds. To an Africa torn by tribal conflict and racial hatred, he offered a vision of harmony and power-sharing: After guerrilla war and bigoted white rule he would forge a constructive partnership. That dream is now trampled by a Robert Mugabe who drives openly toward a one-party tribal state.

title: Giants Already 2 Behind
description: For their 100th anniversary season, the Giants, of San Francisco over the last quarter of a century and of New York before that, are a contender again. But if the Giants are to win the National League West, they must recover from already being two behind in the loss column, the loss of two Giants who showed their teammates how to stay in the race last season until the final weekend. Joe Morgan and Reggie Smith

title: Italian Aide Bids U.S.  Forge New Missile Plan
description: Foreign Minister Emilio Colombo of Italy called on the United States today to make a new proposal to the Soviet Union on nuclear missiles stationed in Europe.

title: Goodrich Offers Notes and Stock
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company is selling an unusual $50 million issue of eight-year floating rate notes in the domestic market with an interest rate set half a percentage point above the London interbank offered rate for three-month Eurodollar deposits.

title: Rizzo Disdains Election Poll
description: Frank L. Rizzo, a former Mayor who is seeking the Democratic mayoral candidacy, discounted a Philadelphia Daily News poll today that showed him trailing his opponent, W. Wilson Goode, by 25 percentage points. ''The only poll that counts is on May 17,'' the date of the primary election, Mr. Rizzo said.

title: Q&A
description: Q. During the holidays someone attached some decorations to the walls of our apartment-house elevator with the double-stick tape normally used for putting down carpet. When the decorations were removed, the tape left a sticky, shiny film that won't come off. What can I use to remove the film without damaging the dark finish of the elevator's plastic panels?

title: Greasing the Ball
description: It has long been suspected that Gaylord Perry has prolonged his career as a major league pitcher by throwing a spitball. During a segment of an hourlong science-oriented television special entitled ''Search,'' which will be aired Sunday evening on ABC, Perry shows how a pitcher prepares to throw the spitball while sitting in the dugout between innings and where to hide the grease.

title: Eurobonds Mostly Lower
description: Dollar-denominated Eurobonds recovered slightly in late trading today, but the rest of the Eurobond market remained quiet and prices were generally lower.

title: Lone Star Issues Downgraded
description: Lone Star Industries' senior debt issues were downgraded to a speculative BB category from BBB, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.

title: COOKE APPEALS FOR A PARADE OF PEACE
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke said yesterday that the St. Patrick's Day Parade should not be an expression of support for the Provisional Irish Republican Army.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
HANDY TOOL ORGANIZERS
description: TWO tool organizers newly on the market help keep the shop, selling table or hobby table free of clutter and make any job go faster by speeding the hunt for the tool in need.

title: Transactions
description: AMATEURS

title: Argentina Refinancing
description: Argentina will refinance $1.4 billion of short-term external debt falling due in the next few weeks over three years, Julio Gonzelez del Solar, president of the central bank, said in an interview reported today.

title: FENDI AND LAGERFELD TRIUMPH IN MILAN
description: Karl Lagerfeld and the Fendi clan proved they were one of the most brilliant teams in contemporary fashion this morning. In a powerful presentation that may not be equaled here or in any fashion center for a long time to come, all the pieces came together. The models seemed to be enjoying themselves - sables do that. The operatic music was easy to listen to, and an air of authority was apparent from the beginning. The pacing was varied, the accessories carefully assembled, and the theatrics worked. But in a fashion show, even the most dramatic presentation cannot take the place of the clothes. They happen to be sensational.

description: * Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues
