description: Following are the texts of the letters exchanged by Anne McGill Burford, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, and President Reagan: Mrs. Burford's Letter

title: Only the Best
description: There are more than 250 basketball teams in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's top division, and not all are powerhouses on the order of, say, Indiana University.

title: TRANS-LUX CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
EX-PRESIDENT OF BARD COLLEGE
description: The Rev. Dr. Reamer Kline, president emeritus of Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., and who had headed Episcopal parishes in Connecticut, Massachusetts and New Hampshire, died yesterday at his home in the college community. He was 72 years old.

title: Lackawanna Plant
description: Kenneth E. Lipke said he is confident he can find investors to join in a package deal to buy most of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation plant in Lackawanna. Mr. Lipke said a month ago that he was quitting as chairman of the Gibraltar Steel Corporation to raise $250 million to buy the plant. Bethlehem plans to close the basic steelmaking there this year. A shutdown would mean permanent loss of 7,300 jobs at the Lackawanna works and another 8,000 jobs in a ripple effect on other businesses in western New York.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is now clear that my resignation is essential to termination of the controversy and confusion generated by the outstanding dispute over Congressional access to certain E.P.A. documentary materials.'' - Anne McGill Burford. (B12:1.)

title: THACKERAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The U.N. Today; March 10, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: IROQUOIS BRANDS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $395,000 for the qr and $449,000 for the yr and an extraordinary loss of $98,000 for the qr and yr from the prepayment of a long-term debt...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $2,782,000 for the qr and $2,825,000 for the yr and an extraordinary gain of $362,000 for the yr; results include operations of Pharmacaps Inc since its acquisition in Apr 1981

title: LATE RALLY SENDS DOW UP 12.86
description: Stock prices resumed their upward trend yesterday after Tuesday's sharp selloff. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 12.86 points, to finish at 1,132.64.

title: Arco Increases Gasoline Prices
description: Even as the world's major oil producers were meeting in London to seek agreement on lower prices, the Atlantic Richfield Company raised its wholesale gasoline prices by 3 cents a gallon.

title: Victor House, Lawyer And Former Prosecutor
description: Victor House, a former assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York and later a special assistant Manhattan district attorney, died last Thursday at San Juan (P.R.) Hospital. He was 89 years old and had homes in San Juan and Manhattan.

title: A SALVADORAN MASSACRE'S MESSAGE TO THE U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Busch Files Suit
description: Anheuser-Busch Inc. has filed a trademark infringement suit in Federal court against the Florist Association of Greater Cleveland because the group used the phrase ''This bud's for you'' in a flower-selling promotion last year. Busch said that it had spent $200 million developing the slogan to sell Budweiser beer and that the word ''Bud'' is a registered trademark. ''I think they're overreacting, frankly,'' Harry Shaffer, executive secretary of the florist group, said.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MARCH 10, 1983
description: International

title: WORDS BY DIETZ, HONOR BY ASCAP
description: Howard Dietz kept his day job for 40 years, loyally ballyhooing Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer films. But yesterday he was honored for what he did in his spare time - writing the lyrics for more than 500 songs, including such American pop classics as ''Dancing in the Dark,'' ''You and the Night and the Music'' and ''That's Entertainment.''

title: IRAQIS SAY JETS ATTACKED IRAN
description: Iraqi planes bombed Iranian targets at Missan in the southern sector of the front today and new ground clashes were reported by the Baghdad radio.

title: FRENCH GENERAL OUSTED FOR DISPUTING CUTBACK
description: The chief of staff of the French Army was replaced today after complaining about planned cuts in the army's manpower and missions.

title: Scali, McCabe Resigns Chesebrough Business
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves, which resigned its Revlon business in 1976 to get a piece of Chesebrough-Pond's and enter more fully into the exciting world of package goods, yesterday resigned its Chesebrough-Pond's assignment and took another one from Revlon.

title: Sullair Finally Chooses New Chief Executive
description: Sullair Inc., a manufacturer of air, gas and refrigeration compressors, has been looking for a new chief executive for several months and yesterday announced that it had found one. He is Robert T. Bloomberg, 56, who will be president and chief executive.

title: Michigan Nun Confirmed As State Welfare Chief
description: Sister Agnes Mary Mansour was confirmed by the State Senate today as Michigan's welfare director. An Archbishop had ordered her to resign from the job because of her refusal to repudiate state-financed abortions.

title: ACCESSORIES: THEY CAN MAKE OR BREAK A ROOM
description: OF the word ''accessories'' the late English decorator John Fowler is said to have remarked: ''I love that American word. It sounds like something on an automobile.'' Call them accessories, bibelots, chatchkas, objets de vertu or bric-a-brac, the decorative nonessentials we leave lying about our homes finish the job that furnishings and fabrics start.

title: Kuwait Losses Affect Bahrain
description: Two investment companies in Bahrain said today that they had made substantial provisions for losses on postdated checks relating to dealings in Kuwaiti stocks.

title: Dakota Murder Suspect Discusses Surrender
description: Tentative guidelines were worked out today for the surrender of Gordon Kahl, a tax resister accused of shooting to death two Federal marshals in North Dakota last month.

title: PENTAGON ASSESSES AFGHAN CONFLICT
description: The Defense Department said today that the Soviet Union could not win its war against insurgents in Afghanistan with its present force despite the recent deployment of more soldiers, advanced fighter planes and the use of scorched-earth tactics.

title: REAGAN RECEIVES CATHOLIC PROTEST
description: Roman Catholic bishops have protested to President Reagan about recent remarks by Vice President Bush and Secretary of State George P. Shultz suggesting that the church seemed to support Communist movements in Central America.

title: 12,000 JERSEY BUS RIDERS STRANDED AS RAIL CONDUCTORS PICKET GARAGE
description: Thousands of strikebound New Jersey rail commuters were stranded without emergency buses in yesterday morning's rush hour after train conductors set up picket lines at a bus garage in Paterson and drivers refused to cross it.

title: AEG BAILOUT PLAN IS REPORTED BACKED
description: Nearly all of AEG-Telefunken's creditors have approved a plan to reorganize the ailing West German electronics company's $2.1 billion of debt, the company's court appointed receiver said today.

title: MEESE DENIES ASKING MISS LAVELLE FOR REPORT ON TOXIC DUMP
description: The President's counselor, Edwin Meese 3d, and an official working under him today sharply challenged the sworn testimony of Rita M. Lavelle that Mr. Meese or someone acting on his behalf had asked her for ''a status report'' on one or more toxic waste dump sites.

title: AEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BLOCKED ON GRUNDIG, THOMSON TURNS TO AEG
description: In a blow to France's effort to garner a larger share of Europe's consumer electronics market, the West German Office of Cartels today blocked the effort of the French Government-owned Thomson-Brandt Company to take over Grundig, the German electronics concern.

title: WARSAW CALLS FOREIGN PRESS BIASED
description: The Polish Government spokesman accused Western correspondents here today of dishonest reporting and suggested that it would have been ''better for them to stay at home.''

title: NEW REAGAN PROPOSAL ON TAX AID FOR EXPORTS
description: The Reagan Administration today proposed new tax breaks for exporters to replace the 12-year-old Domestic International Sales Corporation program that has been declared in violation of international trading rules.

title: RATES FIRM IN LIGHT TRADING
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday in quiet trading. After four days of declining prices, participants in the Treasury market said there was not so much selling pressure from securities dealers and speculators who wanted to reduce their inventories in advance of upcoming Treausry auctions.

title: CHICAGO RIVET & MACHINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a nonrecurring gain of $1,229,409 from the sale of a building and acharge of $289,536 on the sale of a Mexican affiliate

title: MARGARET HECKLER TAKES OATH AS U.S. SECRETARY OF HEALTH
description: Margaret M. Heckler was sworn in as Secretary of Health and Human Services today in a brief ceremony in the Oval Office of the White House.

title: Post for Nancy Littlefield
description: Nancy Littlefield was named president yesterday of a new film and videotape studio that is scheduled to open in Queens next January. Miss Littlefield, who resigned Tuesday as director of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting, will be heading (212) Studios, a 6.9-acre facility in Long Island City, Queens. A spokesman for the company said that total investment in the project would be $24 million, including $13 million for renovation.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's denunciation of a nuclear freeze and of the Kremlin as the focus of evil in the world is viewed by some politicians as the keynote of a drive to induce Congress to approve a large rise in military spending and to deflect pressures for what Mr. Reagan sees as undesirable concessions to Moscow. Other politicians called his speech on Tuesday before a convention of Evangelical Christians in Orlando, Fla., ''a vintage Reagan performance,'' intended to mend fences with disgruntled right-wing supporters. Some said it might have a wider unintended impact.

title: FLOWER TIME INC reports earnings for Yr to Jan 30
A DANCER'S STYLE IN CLEANING
description: Vance Baxter Vogel does not do windows on the outside nor will he iron, but he does scrub bathroom tile, polish floors and vacuum furniture. Then, after an exhausting day cleaning Manhattan apartments, he goes to the theater, where he slips on black satin toe shoes and dances ballet.

title: MILLER-WOHL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
4 ON COUNCIL CALLED KEY TO VOTE ON SEXUAL RIGHTS
description: Four freshman Democrats on the New York City Council held the key to bringing the homosexual rights bill to a vote, politicians on both sides said yesterday as they assessed the defeat of the measure on Tuesday.

title: OPEC SAYS PRICING ACCORD IS NEAR
description: OPEC's ministers reported today that they were close to an agreement on pricing, which conference sources hinted would be based on a price of $29 a barrel for Saudi Light crude.

title: CREW SIZE IS KEY ISSUE IN METRO-NORTH'S STRIKE
description: The Metro-North rail strike, in which 90,000 commuters have been forced to find other means of transportation, centers on one issue: management's insistence that it determine crew sizes, and what the union sees as its need for strong contract language to protect its members' jobs.

title: HOME BEAT
description: THE third annual Progressive Architecture Furniture Competition has about 870 entries and the results will appear in the architectural magazine's May issue. ''Our only rule is that the design can't be in production at judging time,'' said Bob Jefferson, an assistant editor who was in charge of the competition this year.

title: DEMOCRAT WINS SUFFOLK ELECTION
description: Ralph Bivona of Centerport, L.I., a Democrat, was the victor in a special election to choose a member of the Suffolk County Legislature from the North Shore 18th District, officials said today. Mr Bivona, a 54-year-old school speech pathologist who also ran on the Independent Party line, got 4,265 votes to 3,545 votes for Mayor Peter J. Nolan of Northport, 38, who ran on the Republican and Conservative Party lines.

title: QUEENS SITE TO BE CONVERTED INTO INTERNATIONAL DESIGN CENTER
description: EVER since it closed at the end of 1981, the American Chicle Building, a chewing-gum factory on Thomson Avenue at the foot of the 59th Street Bridge in Long Island City, has presented a tantalizing development opportunity. Now the American Chicle Building and its neighbor, the Bucilla Building, are part of a 10-acre property that is being converted into the International Design Center New York.

title: MUSIC: SLOVENIAN SYMPHONY
description: THE Slovenian Symphony Orchestra of Yugoslavia ended its first North American tour on Monday night in Carnegie Hall. The orchestra, also known as the Radio-Television Orchestra of Ljubljana, was founded in 1955.

title: PUT HEAT ON JAPAN
description: No major company should expect to participate in a foreign market if its activities are limited to selling products and taking the profits home without investing in the host country. Nor should any responsible company expect to enjoy a long-term presence in a foreign market if it has unfair political and economic advantages that are denied the host country's own basic industries. Free trade is not fair trade as long as any company or government violates either of these two principles.

title: PIANO RECITAL: MISS WICKETT
description: HELENE WICKETT, who was presented at Merkin Hall by Pro Musicis on Tuesday night, is an intelligent pianist who shapes music with with care and sensitivity. But her playing also often lacked visceral impact and dramatic continuity.

title: Thrift Units Set Corporate Plan
description: A program that will provide more than $1.5 billion for long-term, floating-rate loans to companies has been announced by a group of savings and loan associations led by the Western Savings and Loan Association.

title: IDLE BUSES GET BIG WORKOUT IN RAIL STRIKE
description: In normal times, they may rumble into Atlantic City with players for the gaming tables or lie idle between runs to and from Westchester schools. But as two railroad strikes continue in the metropolitan area, buses of all description have been used to transport many of the 145,000 rail commuters.

title: Breland Stops Blanding in Third
description: Mark Breland, the 19-year-old world amateur welterweight titleholder from Brooklyn, stopped Greg Blanding at 56 seconds of the third round of their New York Golden Gloves semifinal bout last night at the Felt Forum. Breland, a contender for a fourth straight 147-pound Open Division title, knocked Blanding to the canvas in the first round for an 8-count.

title: PHILHARMONIC'S SEASON
description: The 1983-84 season of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra will open Sept. 15 at Avery Fisher Hall with a program of William Schuman's Symphony No. 10 and Beethoven's ''Eroica'' Symphony. The conductor will be Rafael Kubelik, although Zubin Mehta, music director of the Philharmonic, will lead the orchestra during 16 weeks of the season.

title: MAYNARD OIL CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
News Analysis
description: The controversy between the White House and Congress over the Environmental Protection Agency, which reached a climax tonight with President Reagan's capitulation on two major points, has handed Democrats a valuable political opening, in the view of both Republicans and Democrats. The setback Mr. Reagan has suffered was reflected in his decision today to turn over all the agency documents sought by Congressional committees and his inability or unwillingness to protect Anne McGill Burford from the pressures that forced her to resign tonight as the agency's Administrator.

title: Citibank, Nissan
description: Citibank and the Nissan Motor Company of Japan have reached tentative agreement on a financing plan for Nissan cars sold in the United States, Citibank said. It marks the first time a Japanese auto maker and an American bank have reached such an accord. Susan Weeks, a Citibank spokesman, said in New York that she did not have details, but the Japan Economic Journal reported earlier this year that Citicorp would provide financing for all Nissan car sales to dealers in this country except on the West Coast, where Nissan has its own own financing arm.

title: PROBLEMS SEEN FOR ST. LOUIS SCHOOL DESEGREGATION
description: Leslie Wolff, a junior at predominantly white Mehlville High School, said she had no interest in transferring to a school 12 miles away in St. Louis to enhance school desegregation. ''I would rather not have desegregation because it doesn't make sense to take people out of their surroundings,'' she said.

title: Danish Fisherman Will Fight British Fine in Europe's Court
description: A Danish fisherman appealing a conviction for illegal fishing off Britain's coast was allowed today to take his case to the European Court in Luxembourg.

title: DELAY TO BE SOUGHT IN TRIAL OF 2D YOUTH IN BROOKLYN SLAYING
description: A lawyer for a second white youth to be tried for murder in the fatal beating of a black man in Brooklyn said yesterday that he would seek a postponement of several months because of the publicity in the trial of the first defendant. That trial ended with a manslaughter conviction Tuesday night.

title: Steelmakers Recall 20,000
description: Steelmakers in the United States recalled 20,000 laid-off workers last month following modest gains in steel shipments and production, the American Iron and Steel Institute said today.

title: SOUTHERN UNION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: B-Net income; results for the latest first qr reflect startup costs of the Bricktown, N.J. replacement unit and shuttering costs of the two closed units in thesame marketing area

title: CLARICE L. PENNOCK
description: Clarice Leavell Pennock, former director of field work for the social sciences department of Vassar College, died Feb. 9 in Charlottesville, Va., after a long illness. She was 85 years old and formerly lived in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title: ALL EYES FOCUS ON EVACUATION AT INDIAN POINT
description: From bus drivers to county executives to the Lieutenant Governor, 2,000 people tested their ability yesterday to respond to a major accident at the Indian Point nuclear power plants here.

title: Oneok Write-Off
description: Oneok Inc. said it would charge 57 cents a share against second quarter earnings to reflect the write-off of its $12.8 million investment in an offshore Malta oil-exploration venture.

title: SOVIET EMIGRE LAWYER JOINS BAR AFTER 4 YEARS
description: Within a few days of his arrival here from the Soviet Union in 1979, Peter Rabinovich, then 55 years old, made two pilgrimages, each to a vaguely familiar and yet frightening and foreign place.

title: Comings and Goings
description: David Moorcroft, the 5,000-meter record-holder, has hepatitis and will miss most of the track season. . . . Steve Podborski, the World Cup downhill skiing champion who hurt his knee in a fall Sunday, may have suffered less damage than had initially been feared. He underwent surgery in Toronto and is confident he will be a contender in the 1984 Olympics. . . . Lonnie Nichols has resigned as basketball coach at Oklahoma City University, paving the way for the possible return of Abe Lemons, the former Texas coach. . . . Michel Galarneau of the Hartford Whalers will be out three weeks recovering from a hairline ankle fracture. . . . Jaime Garza, the undefeated superbantamweight boxer, hurt his leg, forcing the cancellation of Saturday's scheduled bout with Mike Ayala. . . . Ken Read, the first Canadian skiier to win a World Cup downhill race, is retiring. . . . Rodney McCray, the 6-foot-7-inch center from Mount Vernon, N.Y., who led Louisville to the Metro Conference championship, was named the league's player of the year. . . . Sylvester Stallone acquired the right to film Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini's ring career.

title: OIL COMPANIES LED IN REVENUES IN '82
description: Petroleum companies again led the country's 25 largest nonfinancial companies in revenues during 1982. Reflecting the effects of the world oil glut, however, their revenues were generally much lower than in 1981. Over all, during recession-bound 1982 the 25 companies registered an average rise in revenues of four-tenths of 1 percent, according to a compilation of last year's corporate results. For 1981, these companies had posted an average gain of 13.4 percent. Exxon No. 1 Again

title: INFORMATION DISPLAYS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $230,000

title: Police Wound Man In 86th St. Battle
description: The son of the owner of the Bremen House, a food store at 220 East 86th Street, was wounded yesterday morning in a gunfight with two policemen in an office above the shop, the police said. The officers were not hurt.

title: TAX YIELD HIGHER IN CONNECTICUT
description: Receipts from the state sales tax, Connecticut's biggest revenue-raiser, rebounded in January to a three-year high, it was learned today.

title: NEW TRAINER AT CALUMET FARM
description: David Whiteley is only the eighth trainer for Calumet Farm since its devil's red and blue silks started becoming the most famous and successful in American throughbred racing more than four decades ago. Whiteley admits that he can't help feeling ''a little staggered'' by the tradition of his predecessors and what they accomplished: eight Kentucky Derbies, more than $26 million in purses, 35 champions who won enough trophies to stock a gold mine, and four legged legends like Whirlaway, Citation, Twilight Tear, Tim Tam and Alydar.

title: HORN & HARDART CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Onward, Christian Soldiers
description: When a politician claims that God favors his programs, alarm bells should ring. That is what Ronald Reagan has just done. Speaking to the National Association of Evangelicals in Orlando, Fla., he said that belief in God should make Americans join him in opposing a nuclear freeze and pressing a vast buildup in U.S. weapons.

title: UNITED SOUTHERN BIDS FOR BUTCHER HOLDINGS
description: United Southern Bank of Nashville said yesterday that it has begun negotiations to buy a major portion of the banks owned by C.H. Butcher Jr. and his brother, Jake.

title: Grand Jury to Consider Officer's Slaying of Boy
description: A grand jury will decide whether to indict a policeman who killed a 5-year-old boy, prosecutors said today.

title: BUDGET TIME: FRUSTRATION AND JOCKEYING
description: At 9:58 this morning at the Senate Budget Committee meeting, Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, installed a constituent, Betty Cain Lackey, in a chair on the Senators' platform. Considering that lobbyists and energy lawyers had lined up at 8:30 for public seats at the start of the committee's work on the Federal budget, Mrs. Lackey was getting very special treatment.

title: Randolph Plans to Quit His Senate Seat in 1984
description: On the 50th anniversary of the date he was sworn in as a member of Congress, Senator Jennings Randolph announced today that he would not seek re-election in 1984. He has served longer than any other current member of Congress.

title: 270 Die in China In Mammoth Landslide
description: More than 270 people were killed in a landslide that engulfed a village in northwest China, the New China News Agency reported today.

title: LORIMAR PRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
THE STRUGGLE TO GOVERN THE UNGOVERNABLE SUDAN
description: With internal political divisions, an external threat from Libya, and a ruined economy, the Sudan is struggling to maintain at least a veneer of stability as the regime of President Gaafar al-Nimeiry enters its 15th year.

title: POPE IN HAITI, ASSAILS INEQUALITY, HUNGER AND FEAR
description: Pope John Paul II flew here today at the end of his eight-day tour of Central America and the Caribbean and condemned what he described as the excessive inequality and misery, hunger and fear suffered by many people in Haiti.

title: NKOMO TAKES EXILE, DAYS AFTER FEARING MUGABE DEATH PLOT
description: Joshua Nkomo, who was once hailed as the father of Zimbabwe's independence movement, fled today into exile in neighboring Botswana.

title: S.& P. to Rate Money Funds
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday that it would provide ratings for taxable money market mutual funds upon request, beginning next summer.

title: RIPPLES OF A FAILED BROKERAGE
description: It struck out of the blue. One of the Bell & Beckwith brokers remembered sitting down to a cheerful Sunday dinner at his mother's when he got the grim news from a colleague: Federal regulators were shutting down the brokerage house where he worked. Charges of fraud had been leveled.

title: Syracuse Coach Expecting a Bid
description: Syracuse University's basketball coach, Jim Boeheim, says it shouldn't be necessary for his team to advance beyond even the first round of the Big East Conference tournament to merit an invitation to the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship tournament.

title: Burford Cites Job Pressures As She Talks of Resignation
description: Anne McGill Burford quit because inquiries and media pressure made it impossible to work, she said in a Washington interview for Thursday's Denver Post.

title: Technology; More Miles Per Gallon
description: LAST September, when most American motorists had already begun seeing a decline in gasoline prices, Peugeot S.A. arrived in Detroit to show off its automotive engineering. Peugeot's demonstration made clear that, despite the swift advances made over the past five years in fuel efficiency, more progress is yet to come.

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Slow-Lane Auto Safety
description: The brakes on 240,000 of General Motors's 1980 X-model cars may be defective. The company notified owners a few weeks ago, but the recall could have come earlier, with a saving of life and limb, if the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration hadn't dawdled in the slow lane.

title: LEBANESE WAR HITS EGYPT
description: Nine months after the invasion of Lebanon, Egyptians are still taking the measure of the damage it has done - and continues to do - to the Egyptian-Israeli peace. In Egypt, the real victors of the war are the opponents of Camp David who argue that America's friendship is worthless - that it has helped neither to check Israeli aggression nor to solve the Palestinian problem.

title: GAS DEBATE STARTS IN SENATE
description: Energy Secretary Donald P. Hodel told Congress today that President Reagan's plan to decontrol natural gas prices would correct the ''extreme market distortion'' that he said was responsible for the sharp increases in consumers' bills in the last several years.

title: MERCANTILE STORES CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The 1983 full yr results included net income of $916,000 or 16 cents a shr fromthe sale of land against net income of $365,000 or 6 cents a shr, from the saleof a closed store in 1982; the company said that the full yr cost of calculating inventory under the LIFO method was 18 cents a shr in the latest yr compared with 39 cents for the prior yr

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HOROWITZ: A Biography of Vladimir, Horowitz. By Glenn Plaskin. 607 pages. Morrow. Illustrated. $19.95.

title: Agreement on Lebanon Is Expected by Summer
description: A State Department official said today that the United States expects agreements to be reached this summer for the withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces from Lebanon.

title: MILGRAY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
V.A. CARE PRIORITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: SOLIDARITY AIDE IS PUT ON TRIAL
description: Anna Walentynowicz, a crane operator whose dismissal helped set off the Gdansk strike that led to the creation of Solidarity, went on trial today, charged with continuing union activity after the imposition of martial law.

title: Production Set to Begin On Sequel to 'Raiders'
description: Steven Spielberg will begin production on his sequel to ''Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' next month in Sri Lanka, Hong Kong and England.

title: CHRONOLOGY OF EVENTS IN THE E.P.A. DISPUTE
description: Following is a chronology of events leading up to the resignation of Anne McGill Burford as Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: MASSEY IN ACCORD ON DEBT
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the troubled Canadian manufacturer of farm equipment, announced today that it had completed a refinancing agreement on its debt of $1.27 billion (American currency) that will save it $600 million.

title: National Search On for Father Suspected of Burning Son, 6
description: A national alert has been issued for a father suspected of setting a fire around a motel bed occupied by his 6-year-old son.

title: Former British Official Killed in Car Accident
description: Viscount Boyd of Merton, who served as Colonial Secretary for three Conservative prime ministers in the 1950's, was hit and killed by a car, the police said today. He was 78 years old.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: I get out of bed and go to open the window, but the handle comes loose in my hand. - From ''A Dreamer's Diary,'' by Luigi Malerba

title: Survivors of Coal-Mine Blast In Turkey Charge Negligence
description: Survivors of Turkey's worst mine disaster in 50 years blamed official negligence today for two explosions that killed a hundred miners.

title: SETON HALL SCORES UPSET IN BIG EAST
description: No one expects Seton Hall, a team with only six victories this season, to beat Boston College, a team with 22 triumphs, in the first round of the Big East Conference tournament at Madison Square Garden tonight. But last night the Pirates earned the right to give it a try.

title: Mets to Try Out Japanese Catcher
description: The Mets agreed today to try out a Japanese catcher, who was an all-star five times in Japan's Central League, and indicated that they would probably sign him to a minor league contract.

title: RECITAL: FOURNIER
description: PIERRE FOURNIER, the distinguished French cellist, is now 76 years old and appears in this country infrequently. On the basis of his recital Monday night at the Abraham Goodman House, it cannot be said that his once seemingly effortless technique is all that it was.

title: DOME PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After nonrecuring losses of $305.9 million for the qr and $314 million for the yr from the writedown of U.S. oil and natural gas assets and a loss on the sale of assets...C-Net income; figures are in Canadian dollars; yr-ago revs have been restated to conform to the 1982 presentation

title: COASTLAND CORP OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-After a loss of $96,000 from discontinued operations

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: PIECES of scrap wood, plywood and plastic can often be used to make inexpensive but useful accessories for the home, even if do-ityourselfers have only simple hand tools.

title: HAMPTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
STAGE: MARCEL MARCEAU
description: IT is edifying to see a consummate artist continue to grow. Such is the case with Marcel Marceau. Only weeks away from his 60th birthday, he is still expanding his talent, sending his alter ego, Bip, on different journeys and, as an actor-author, entering new arenas of comic absurdism. Opening last night at the Belasco Theater, in his first New York engagement in eight years, he begins with a program that includes five new sketches and only a few that could be considered Marceau classics.

title: THE CATTLE SHOW
description: A healthy new phenomenon is establishing itself in preprimary Presidential politics: it is called ''the cattle show.'' In a cattle show, national candidates are herded into a ballroom, which then becomes a kind of stockyard-showcase. Local politicians poke them to see if their flesh is pressable; national pundits prod them to find variances in their views; the local party profits on ticket sales.

title: PHILADELPHIA SHOW ABLOOM WITH IDEAS
description: The proper way to see the Philadelphia Flower Show is with notebook in hand. Although many visitors sling cameras, shopping bags or toddlers over their shoulders, seasoned gardeners know that paper and pencil are just as important as sturdy walking shoes at this year's event, which closes Sunday.

title: TEACHER SALARIES: A FAILED REFUTATION OF UNDERPAYMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: GETTY MUSEUM ACQUIRES MANUSCRIPT COLLECTION
description: The Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., has acquired 144 illuminated manuscripts from the collection of Dr. and Mrs. Peter Ludwig in Aachen, West Germany. One of the finest holdings of its kind ever assembled, it is quite certainly the most important that was in private hands. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: HOCKEY PLAYER HAS BRAIN INJURY
description: Ed Kea, an eight year veteran of the National Hockey League now in the minors with the Salt Lake Golden Eagles, was in a coma today after suffering a brain injury in a game Monday night.

title: SENATE, TAKING UP JOB BILL, RESISTS EDUCATION CUTS
description: As the Senate began consideration of a $3.9 billion emergency job bill today, the lawmakers took a slap at President Reagan and passed an amendment putting themselves on record against any further cuts in education programs.

title: Return of a Boxer
description: He was once the lightweight champion of the world, a fighter of such affecting style that he enthralled crowds from Madrid to Madison Square Garden and earned his niche in the annals of the ring. So why, a year after announcing his second retirement, was 38-year-old Ken Buchanan pounding away at an unknown opponent in an unsanctioned bout in an obscure London suburb Tuesday night? ''To earn money the only way I know how,'' he said.

title: BANK GUARD KILLED BY JERSEY GUNMAN
description: A bank guard whose brother was killed in a bank holdup eight years ago was fatally shot today in an attempted holdup, the police said.

title: CANAL-RANDOLPH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Yr-ago revs figures has been restated to conform with current yr presentation

title: U.S. Envoy to the Hague Said to Be on Way Out
description: The United States Ambassador to the Netherlands is being removed amid reports of Dutch unhappiness with his hard-line salesmanship of President Reagan's policies on nuclear arms in Europe, Administration officials said today.

title: THE THEATER: 'BUCK,' SLEAZE AND CABLE TV
description: CABLE television, you may recall, was that wonderful invention designed to transport us into a new, enlightened age of mass culture. There would be hundreds of channels offering the civilized programs that the big, bad commercial networks never go near. In ''Buck,'' the playwright Ronald Ribman takes a different view. Mr. Ribman shows us a hugely successful cable production company whose star product is a sleazy series of ''murder re-enactments'': anonymous bums and prostitutes are hired off the street to impersonate the notorious perpetrators of grisly crimes.

title: A Bigger Sound For Nets' Games
description: After the way they were beaten by the Knicks on Wednesday night, the Nets may not be first in the hearts of quite so many of the area's basketball fans. But beginning next season, their voice will be louder and stronger.

title: Peruvians on Strike Over Steep Inflation
description: A 24-hour nationwide strike began today to protest the Government's failure to curb a 70 percent annual inflation rate.

title: The Lord and the Freeze
description: After all the pieties, on both sides, about a nuclear ''freeze,'' can we please get back to policies?

title: KUBOTA LTD (JAPANESE CO) reports earnings for QTr to Jan 15
description: Shr earnings are per American Depositary Shrs each of which represents 20 shrs of common stock; results have been translated at the rate of 230 yen equal $1

title: DEMOCRATS URGE TAXING SERVICES OF PROFESSIONALS
description: Democrats in the Assembly today proposed that the sales tax be extended to fees of lawyers, architects, engineers, accountants and other professionals.

title: N.F.L. BASE PLAY MADE PUBLIC
description: The National Football League Players Association has circulated a salary directory showing 1982 base pay for 1,630 players ranging from the $22,000 league minimum to $600,000 for the quarterback Archie Manning of the Houston Oilers.

title: CONCERT: ALCIDES LANZA
description: IMAGINE the mysterious sounds of a summer night in the the country when frogs, insects and night birds are particularly vocal, and you are on the way to imagining the sounds of Alcides Lanza's ''Plectros III,'' a work for piano and tape music performed by the composer at Roulette on Tuesday night.

title: SNAG IN CONSIDERATION OF JOBS BILL RISKS A DELAY IN FUNDS FOR STATES
description: A proposed amendment caused a serious stumbling block today in the Senate's consideration of a $3.7 billion job bill. The delay raised the possibility that some states would run out of money to pay unemployment benefits next Tuesday because Federal money to subsidize those payments is contained in the bill.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Universal Insurance Co., Providence, R.I., has elected Charles F. Cook president and chief executive officer.

title: ALL ABOUT THE CLUBS
description: Improv, Ninth Avenue and 44th Street (765-8268). Comedy showcase, usually begins about 9 P.M., with second show at midnight on Friday and Saturday.

title: A CHINESE JOURNALIST ON THE AMERICAN WAY
description: Americans. They're nationalistic. They buy on credit. The Democrats are foundering. Mayor Koch twists arms and Governor Cuomo is an intellectual.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: BUNRAKU, JAPANESE PUPPETRY AS ART
description: TOKYO THE Japanese are good at doing things on a small scale. This is apparent from so much in their culture, from bonsai trees to electronic chips. It is also evident from the extraordinary puppet theater of Japan known as Bunraku. On Saturday, New Yorkers will have their first chance since 1973 to see Bunraku, when a troupe of nine puppeteers and other performers from the Osaka Bunraku Theater begins a run of 10 performances in the 300-seat Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium at the Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street.

title: WRISTON RULES OUT JOB AS FED CHIEF
description: Walter B. Wriston has effectively taken himself out of the running for chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. He told a group of financiers Wednesday night that it would be a ''conflict'' for any commercial banker to take the job, now held by Paul A. Volcker.

title: BELL'S TARNISHED DEBT RATING
description: The Bell System discovered yesterday that united it stands and divided it falls - at least in the bond market. After years of issuing gilt-edged securities, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and all but one of its subsidiaries and affiliates had their credit ratings lowered yesterday by Moody's Investors Service.

title: Pargas Buyout
description: Forstmann Little & Company said it had agreed to purchase Pargas Inc. of Waldorf, Md., in a leveraged buyout transaction for $42.25 a share cash, or a total of about $173 million. In addition, under terms of the agreement, all outstanding Pargas 5.50 percent cumulative preferred shares and $2.64 cumulative preference stock, series A, will be redeemed for about $1.5 million, plus accrued dividends, before the closing.

title: Kea Undergoes Brain Surgery
description: Ed Kea, a 35-year-old defenseman for the Salt Lake Golden Eagles, underwent four hours of surgery Wednesday night to drain a dangerous buildup of blood and fluid from his brain.

title: ALLEGATIONS AGAINST E.P.A. UNDERCUT REAGAN IN BID TO PROTECT DOCUMENTS
description: High officials of the Justice Department, which had advised President Reagan to claim the executive's privilege to withhold certain Environmental Protection Agency documents, said today that allegations and evidence of wrongdoing at the agency that they had not foreseen had undercut his position. Mr. Reagan backed down from the claim on Wednesday.

title: MUGABE'S MILITARY AIDE CALLS NKOMO A COWARD GOING INTO EXILE
description: A Cabinet Minister said today that Joshua Nkomo had fled into exile because he was a ''paranoiac'' and a ''coward.'' The official denied that the Government had ever planned to arrest Mr. Nkomo or ban his party.

title: 2 OFFICIALS CAUTION ON ECONOMY
description: Two of the nation's top economic officials said today that the recovery was under way, but they tried to dampen expectations of a strong rebound.

title: 2 ARE NAMED BY CUOMO TO HEAD STATE AGENCIES
description: Governor Cuomo today appointed James L. Larocca, the State Energy Commissioner and chairman of the State Energy Research and Development Authority, to head the Department of Transportation. The Governor also named William D. Cotter, a newspaper editor, to replace Mr. Larocca.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Semifinalists at Met Relishing Their Stay

title: MUSIC: ANDRE WATTS AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: TWENTY years ago, a 16-year-old pianist named Andre Watts broke into public view in the way every young artist dreams of, substituting on short notice for a big star and coming away in triumph. The star was Glenn Gould, who fell ill and could not play with the New York Philharmonic. Leonard Bernstein chose Mr. Watts to replace him. Mr. Watts in turn chose the Liszt Concerto in E flat.

title: Lefton Getting Alfin Brands
description: Alfin Fragrances are wafting toward Al Paul Lefton Inc., which is already the agency for Joy and 1000 from Jean Patou Inc. The reason that conflict problems can be overlooked is that Irwin Alfin is president of both companies.

title: 2 Accused in Manila Of Plot to Kill Marcos
description: Two businessmen jailed since February 1982 have been charged with plotting to kill President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his family, the Government said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Sports Pages yesterday about a Japanese catcher who will receive a tryout with the New York Mets gave his name incorrectly. He is Yoshiharu Wakana.

title: SMITH COLLEGE AND THE AMBASSADOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Wharton Post Is Discussed
description: Russell E. Palmer, the 48-year-old chief executive officer of Touche Ross International, has been talking with representatives of the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School about the possibility of becoming its dean, according to a spokesman for the school. Donald C. Carroll, dean of the prestigious business school since 1972, is leaving in June.

title: EIL INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CARIBBEAN: A TALE OF TWO AIRPORTS
description: To the Editor:

title: FASHION VERSATILITY
description: Like baseball players, some designers here have several chances at bat. Gianni Versace was a good performer in his previous turns this week with collections under his own name and for Callaghan, and he kept his average up with his show for Genny today. Luciano Soprani repeated Wednesday's respectable performance with his collection for Basile today.

title: Crew Dispute Settled
description: That Oxford-Cambridge crew race on the Thames is going to be held, after all, and Boris Rankov, the Oxford rower whose eligibility had been questioned by Cambridge, will be in his accustomed spot in the Oxford shell. Cambridge, which had threatened to boycott the April 2 race, the 129th in the series, agreed to compete after Oxford ackowledged that eligibility rules needed tightening and agreed to discuss the issue on March 19.

title: NEW CHIEF'S DEPUTY IS USED TO RUNNING THE SHOW
description: At the Department of Health and Human Services today, the first full day of work for the new Secretary, Margaret M. Heckler, the chief topic of speculation was how she would get along with her deputy, John A. Svahn.

title: Herald Tribune Appoints Paley
description: William S. Paley, the chairman of CBS Inc., was named co-chairman yesterday of The International Herald Tribune, which is jointly owned by The New York Times Company, The Washington Post Company and Whitney Communications.

title: MUSIC: ANITA ELLIS SINGS
description: THE elusive Anita Ellis overcame her frequently proclaimed fear of singing in public to be the first performer in a series in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Monday evening. The series is called ''Five Ladies of Jazz'' and is a mixture of concert and interview in which the singer discusses her career and work with John Gruen. The other singers will be Sylvia Syms, Dolly Dawn, Carrie Smith and Janet Lawson.

title: GENOVESE DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
G.O.P. WOMEN ASK FOR PRESIDENT'S HELP ON EQUITY MEASURE
description: A usually uncomplaining organization of Republican women is pressing President Reagan to ease their political problems by facing and solving some of the economic problems encountered by women.

title: What Has to Change at E.P.A.
description: The resignation of Anne (Gorsuch) Burford as head of the Environmental Protection Agency gives the Reagan Administration an opportunity to recast its policy on the environment. The first priority is to restore the battered morale and credibility of the agency by appointing an administrator who will be as committed to the environment as to the White House's goal of regulatory reform. But the new administrator will also need new instructions from the President.

title: WHAT'S DOING FOR KIDS AT MUSEUMS
description: YOUNGSTERS looking for something to do this weekend might consider hunting dragons, making creatures, meeting a banjo-strumming frog, tooting a trombone or observing people who only seem to be there. Such activities may seem more inviting than, say, a trip to a museum - but that is exactly where these and many other adventures may be pursued.

title: BEEFSTEAK CHARLIE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 22
description: B-Including a tax credit of $395,000

title: The Death Penalty Is Vetoed by Cuomo
description: Governor Cuomo today vetoed a bill that would have restored the death penalty in New York State. At the same time, he submitted a bill to mandate life imprisonment without parole for those convicted of first-degree murder. There were sufficient votes to override Mr. Cuomo's veto in the Senate, but sponsors of the bill in the Assembly have said they could not muster sufficient votes to do so.

title: Frances Farmer Film
description: ''Come and Get It,'' the 1936 film starring Frances Farmer, begins a two-week engagement today at the Quad Cinema II, 34 West 13th Street. The film, based on an Edna Ferber novel, tells a story of greed and jealousy in the wilderness of the Pacific Northwest, in which a father and son are pitted against each other for the love of a woman. It was directed by William Wyler and Howard Hawks, and also stars Edward Arnold, Joel McCrea and Walter Brennan, who won the 1936 Academy Award for best supporting actor for his role.

title: Boston College Gains, 79-56
description: Boston College, the top-seeded team in the Big East tournament, stormed back from a surprising 10-point deficit at halftime by outscoring Seton Hall, 53-20, in the second half and trouncing the Pirates, 79-56, in the final first-round game at Madison Square Garden tonight.

title: FARMERS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including net gains on the sale of real property of $1,411,000 or 4 cents a shr for the qr and $3,036,000 or 9 cents a shr for the yr...C-Including a net gain of $629,000 or 2 cents a shr on the sale of real property

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Alston, Kell Join Hall of Fame
description: George Kell and Walter Alston, two quiet men who rose to baseball heights unaccompanied by much fanfare, received the ultimate tribute today when they were elected to the Hall of Fame by the Committee on Veterans.

title: SMITH COLLEGE AND THE AMBASSADOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Seagram Earnings
description: The Seagram Company expects to report that its earnings for the quarter ended Jan. 31 declined from the total a year ago of $77.9 million (United States currency), its chairman, Edgar Bronfman, told reporters after a special stockholders meeting.

title: THE MARIO LANZA YEARS REMEMBERED
description: MARIO LANZA died in Rome in 1959 at the age of 38. His movie career, spanning about 10 years, consisted of only seven films. Yet he seems to have had a strong influence on major figures in the music world. On a television special last year, Luciano Pavarotti cited Lanza as a major inspiration in his career. And tonight at 9 on Channel 13, a documentary titled ''Mario Lanza: The American Caruso'' has as its host Placido Domingo, who insists that the Lanza name has signified ''magic for two generations.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on March 1 about Diet Coke incorrectly described the ownership of Jesse Meyers' Beverage Digest. The owner is Mr. Meyers.

title: Rex Marshall, 64, Announcer On Radio and TV Since 1937
description: Rex Marshall, a radio and television announcer who for 25 years was the commercial voice for the Reynolds Aluminum Company, died Wednesday at the Veterans Hospital in White River Junction, Vt. He lived in Woodstock, Vt., and was 64 years old.

title: First-Time Jobless Claims Off
description: The number of Americans filing firsttime claims for unemployment benefits in the last week of February was the lowest since mid-September 1981, in the first months of the recession, the Labor Department reported today.

title: CONSUMER DEBT RISES SHARPLY
description: American consumers took on $2.93 billion more in new installment debt than they paid off during January, the biggest monthly increase in nearly two years, the Government reported today.

title: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS TO PEER BEYOND E.P.A. SMOKE
description: White House officials today took up the delicate task of choosing a new Administrator for the Environmental Protection Agency and containing the political damage from the environmental controversy with Congress that some strategists fear might extend into next year's Presidential election.

title: REAGAN SETS A ZONE 200 MILES OFFSHORE, CLAIMING RESOURCES WASHINGTON,
description: March 10 (Reuters) - President Reagan proclaimed a 200-mile-wide coastal economic zone today in which the United States will exercise exclusive rights over all resources.

title: WORKERS IN THE GDANSK SHIPYARD DEMAND RESTORATION OF SOLIDARITY
description: Shipyard workers in Gdansk have sent an open letter to the Polish Parliament demanding the restoration of the outlawed independent union Solidarity. The letter warned the Government that it cannot ''turn back the tide of history.''

title: 2 Men Indicted in Deaths Of Women in Bathtubs
description: Two men were indicted on murder charges today in two of the three recent cases in which women's bodies were found in bathtubs.

title: IONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NO. 1 BOSTON BANK TO ADD MAINE UNIT
description: The First National Boston Corporation, the largest banking organization in New England, announced yesterday that it had agreed to pay $55 million to acquire Maine's largest bank holding company, the Casco-Northern Corporation of Maine.

title: HORN & HARDART CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $750,000

title: Weather Saved $2 Billion On Heating, U.S. Says
description: One of the mildest winters in half a century saved Americans more than $2 billion in heating bills, the Government reported today.

title: Japan Syndicate Sets Disney Loan
description: A syndicate of 17 Japanese and foreign banks signed a contract here today for a loan of 15 billion yen, or about $63 million, to Walt Disney Productions. The move is linked to the company's plan to open a Disneyland near Tokyo next month.

title: AGE OF DIVERSITY (1)
description: The contrast between the seventh nonaligned summit meeting here and the first, held in Belgrade in 1961, is a better measure of the way the world has evolved than Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger's estimate of the power balance.

title: RED MITCHELL, BASSIST, BACK FOR DEBUT AS PIANIST-SINGER
description: PICTURES of Red Mitchell 30 years ago, when he was playing bass in Woody Herman's band, in Red Norvo's trio and in Gerry Mulligan's quartet, show a very lean young man with a long, prominent nose dominating a thin face. Now, at 55, Mr. Mitchell has filled out, his nose has settled back into a rounded face, the flame of his red hair has subsided and is noticeable primarily in the soft wisps of a modest beard. Peering out over the half-moons of his unframed glasses, he might be part of a Norman Rockwell painting of a gathering around a pot-bellied stove in a New England country store. His gentle, homey, philosophical manner of talking is in keeping with that portrait.

title: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

title: Peter F. Cohalan
description: The Suffolk County Executive ... .a Republican with a family tradition in politics and law ... .lives in Bayport, L.I. ... 45-year-old lawyer is married and has two children. ... ..born in Bay Shore ... his grandfather was a Surrogate, his father the Islip Town Supervisor and later a state appellate judge ... graduated from Manhattan College in 1959 and the Fordham Law School in 1963 ... went into father's law firm and was a lawyer for Town of Islip and the Sayville School District ... elected Supervisor of Town of Islip in 1972 and was re-elected to three more two-year terms ... lost race for Congress in 1976 and a race for a State Supreme Court judgeship in 1978 ... challenged and defeated fellow Repubican John V.N. Klein for County Executive in 1979 ... ran unsuccessfully for the Republican nomination for lieutenant governor last year. Charles R. Pierce

title: EXCERPTS FROM NEWS CONFERENCE HELD BY THE FORMER E.P.A. ADMINISTRATOR
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference held in Washington yesterday by Anne McGill Burford, former Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilites of Cable News Network:

title: PIANO RECITAL: LEON BATES
description: IT wasn't until the end of Leon Bates's recital at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night that the pianist seemed to have something compelling to say about the music he was playing. In the original version of Rachmaninoff's Sonata No. 2 in B-flat minor, there were glimpses of an attention to musical gesture and dramatic development that would have served Mr. Bates well elsewhere in the recital.

title: AUCTIONS
description: PERIOD jewelry, which has grown in interest among collectors in recent years, will be up for bidding next week at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Christie's and Phillips, Son & Neale. Although most of the necklaces, rings, bracelets, brooches, stickpins, pendants and watches, all of moderate quality, in these sales are from the early 20th century, some date from the 18th and 19th centuries as well.

title: Market Place; Bright Outlook For Auto Parts
description: WHAT'S good for General Motors - and Ford, Chrysler and American Motors, as well - is good for the automotive parts industry. That, in a nutshell, is the thesis espoused by several investment firms about a business that consists of two sectors, original parts and replacement parts.

title: Mr. Hurley at Folk City
description: The songwriter Michael Hurley will make one of his infrequent New York appearances tonight at Folk City, 130 West Third Street (254-8449). Admission is $5, and shows begin at 9 P.M. and midnight.

title: JAZZ: JOHNNY COLES AND HIS OWN SEXTET
description: JOHNNY COLES, a versatile trumpet and fluegelhorn player who has been in the big bands of Duke Ellington, Count Basie, Gil Evans, Clark Terry, Quincy Jones, Machito and Thad Jones and Mel Lewis, stepped out of his sideman's anonymity this week and is leading a sextet at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, through tomorrow.

description: Postmaster General Sees a Brighter Picture

3 in Egypt's Cabinet Accused by a Court In a Corruption Case
description: Three members of the Egyptian Cabinet were accused of corruption today in a case related to the judicial proceedings against Esmat Sadat, half-brother of Anwar el-Sadat.

title: DIFFERENT JOKES FOR DIFFERENT FOLKS
description: DURING the last couple of weeks, comedies of many stripes have opened in New York. You've got your black, or savage comedy in ''Britannia Hospital'' (with its director, Lindsay Anderson, telling us that civilization is terminal, and that maybe it's a good thing, too); you've got your gentle, or pastoral comedy in ''Local Hero'' (with Bill Forsyth, its writer-director, telling us that even an oil executive may respond to a sunset), and you've got your romantic comedy in ''Lovesick.''

title: FRIDAY, MARCH 11, 1983; The Economy
description: Utilities may charge wholesale customers for the costs of building new electric generating plants before they go into service, Federal energy regulators decided. The move would raise the bills of consumers of about one-tenth of the nation's electricity. The utilities said it would improve their cash flow. (Page A1.)

title: DANCE BY TWO TROUPES IN REGIONAL THEATER
description: New York may be the dance capital of the country. But dance has long-established roots beyond the Hudson, too. The Dayton Ballet, which will perform tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 3 at Lehman College's Center for Performing Arts in the Bronx, is one of the oldest regional companies in the country. And the New York-based Uris-Bahr and Dancers, which may be seen in debut performances tomorrow and Sunday nights at 8 at the Theater of the Riverside Church, grew out of the regional tradition and looks to it for continuing vitality.

title: INQUIRIES ON E.P.A. IN CONGRESS GO ON, PANELS' CHIEF SAY
description: Anne McGill Burford's resignation as head of the Environmental Protection Agency and the Reagan Administration's promise to release subpoenaed agency documents will not slow the Congressional committees investigating the agency, several committee chairmen said today.

title: LONG TERM EROSION IS FEARED ON COAST
description: The tropical storms that swept scores of homes into the Pacific Ocean and closed parts of the scenic oceanside highway this winter have fundamentally eroded long stretches of the California coast.

title: SCREEN: GOSPEL 'AMEN'
description: ''Say Amen, Somebody'' was shown as part of the 1982 New York Festival. Following are excerpts from a review by Janet Maslin in The New York Times of Oct. 5, 1980. The film opens today at the 68th Street Playhouse, at Third Avenue.

description: How much does extended preparation count in boxing? Efrain Nieves may find out tonight when he fights Victor Acosta in the 10-round junior-lightweight feature at Manhattan Center.

Dow Is Down by 11.70, to 1,120.94
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell sharply yesterday after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries again failed to reach an agreement on oil price cuts and production quotas.

title: Miss McKinney Wins Slalom
description: Tamara McKinney moved another step closer today to becoming the first United States woman to win the overall World Cup championship as she took her second giant slalom event in two days.

title: Green Party Warned To Keep Bonn's Secrets
description: The ecologist Green Party was explicitly warned today that its pacifist members of Parliament may not be allowed access to West Germany's military secrets.

title: Funds' Assets Fall $2.2 Billion More
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds dropped $2.2 billion for the week ended Wednesday, to $187.4 billion, the Investment Company Institute announced yesterday. The drop last week was $1.7 billion.

title: Decision File New Standards For Helicopters
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has adopted new airworthiness standards for large helicopters designed after March 2.

title: ISLANDERS WIN ON LATE RALLY
description: Tonight, after rallying for a 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins, the Islanders may have learned a lesson late in a season filled with disappointments.

title: STUDENT AID CUTS OPPOSED IN HOUSE
description: The Reagan Administration's proposal to require students receiving Federal aid to pay a larger share of their own college costs met skepticism and opposition today from members of Congress.

title: New Plea on Soviet Jews
description: The Interparliamentary Conference on Soviet Jewry, made up of members of national parliaments in Western Europe, asked American and other delegates to the European Security Conference today to speak up for Soviet Jews. ''We are appalled,'' the group said in a statement, ''at the worsening of the situation facing Soviet Jews since the conference was convened in November 1980.''

title: GTE Capital Plans
description: The GTE Corporation plans 1983 capital spending of about $3 billion, about $200 million more than last year, the company's chairman and chief executive officer, Theodore Brophy, said. Mr. Brophy, in Europe for talks with financial institutions, said, however, that the company planned to provide much more of its capital internally than it had in the past.

title: GENUINE RISK-SECRETARIAT FOAL IS DUE
description: They hope to be passing out cigars, or perhaps carrots, at Catoctin Stud in Waterford, Va., on or about March 21. That's the day Genuine Risk is due to deliver her first foal, a son or a daughter of Secretariat who will be the first offspring of two Kentucky Derby winners.

title: The Sciences Magazine To Take Advertising
description: Sooner or later, or so it seems, publishers of magazines that do not take advertising fall in line and go out looking for those extra bucks.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MARCH 11, 1983
description: International The nations of Central America ''are in the midst of the gravest crisis in their history,'' according to President Reagan. In a policy speech, he proposed an emergency $298 million military and economic aid package for the region that includes $110 million in arms assistance for El Salvador. (Page A1, Column 6.) An open letter to Polish leaders from shipyard workers in Gdansk demands the restoration of the outlawed union Solidarity and warns that they cannot ''turn the tide of history.'' Meanwhile, Lech Walesa, the union's leader, has called for ''protests, hunger strikes, strikes'' to halt new trials and arrests of Solidarity activists. (A1:4-5.)

title: THREE MEN CHARGED WITH TWO MURDERS IN STRING OF HOLDUPS
description: Three men were arrested at their homes yesterday and charged with two robbery-killings and five other robberies of grocery stores in New York City and Westchester County, the police said.

title: The U.N. Today; March 11, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: ONE ACTRESS'S VIEW FROM THE BRIDGE
description: IF ever life prepared an actress for a role, it prepared Saundra Santiago. In the revival of Arthur Miller's ''View From the Bridge'' at the Ambassador, she plays Catherine, a 17-year-old innocent who is the object of her uncle Eddie's possessive love. Eddie Carbone's unwitting, unarticulated passion for his niece leads finally to catastrophe.

title: Insider Case Faces U.S. Probe
description: A Federal prosecutor said yesterday that he is conducting a preliminary investigation of an insider trading case involving Thomas C. Reed, who is now a national security consultant on the White House staff.

title: ENVIRONMENT UNIT GREETS NEW HEAD
description: Yesterday he was just another deputy administrator, but this afternoon, when John W. Hernandez stepped into a crowded elevator at the Environmental Protection Agency, the occupants burst into applause. ''Way to go, John!'' someone shouted at the new Acting Administrator while others thumped him on the back.

title: BLACK TELLS TEXAS FEDERAL JURY OF NEW ORLEANS POLICE BEATING
description: Twelve white Texans heard a black man testify today that he was beaten and stamped upon two years ago while he was being questioned by New Orleans policemen who were seeking the killer of a fellow officer.

title: KASLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid Feb 15, 1983

title: 'TALES OF ORDINARY MADNESS'
description: THE best that can be said for Marco Ferreri's ''Tales of Ordinary Madness'' is that somewhere inside its unworkable blend of pretension and pornography, there's a serious film about art and sexual abandon struggling to get out. The worst, which can be said with considerably more accuracy, is that Mr. Ferreri's film is strained, absurdly solemn and full of inadvertent howlers.

title: Massachusetts Power Loss
description: Freezing rain and chunks of falling ice knocked out power to more western Massachusetts homes today, leaving upwards of 1,500 without electricity. The problems, which began early Wednesday, felled hundreds of ice-encased trees and snapped cables, affecting at least 5,000 homes from the Berkshire Mountains to Springfield, utility officials said.

title: Books Of The Times
description: SALVADOR. By Joan Didion. 108 pages. Simon & Schuster. $12.95.

title: WHERE TO FIND THE FUNNIEST COMICS IN TOWN
description: YOUNG people who want to be comedians or comic actors appear to be in inexhaustible supply; in fact, there seem to be multitudes of them at large these days. Which makes it quite pleasant to frequent the standup-comic showcases, cabarets and weekend comedy clubs that are the native habitats of these sometimes very funny people.

description: The first launching of the new space shuttle Challenger was postponed today because the satellite it is to carry aloft may have been damaged by a storm last month.

description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies, which includes the Shell Oil Company in the United States, announced today that net income in 1982 rose slightly, to $3.21 billion, from $3.2 billion in 1981.

title: AN EVOLVING 'FREEZE'
description: On the day the House Foreign Affairs Committee approved, 27 to 9, a compromise nuclear freeze resolution, President Reagan in a warlike speech to a religious group denounced the freeze idea as a ''very dangerous fraud'' that ''at current levels of weapons would remove any incentive for the Soviets to negotiate seriously.''

title: SENATE GIVEN BILL ASSURING PENSIONS
description: The Senate Finance Committee, working late to hasten action on Social Security, approved a bill tonight to assure the solvency of the system and sent the measure to the Senate floor.

title: SHIFT SEEN AT G.& W.
description: Gulf and Western Industries is expected to announce the resignation soon of David N. Judelson as president, Wall Street sources disclosed last night.

title: Casino Credit and Credibility
description: So much for all the official claims that Atlantic City's casinos are free of corruption and fair to gamblers. Testimony to the State Commission of Investigation shows casinos are providing easy credit to gangsters and letting compulsive gamblers destroy themselves.

title: UTILITIES ALLOWED FASTER RATE RISES TO PAY FOR PLANTS
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission voted today to allow utilities to charge wholesale customers for the costs of building new electric generating plants without waiting for the plants to go into service.

title: K Mart Net Jumps 43.8%
description: The K Mart Corporation, operator of the nation's second-largest general-merchandise retailer after Sears, Roebuck & Company, reported yesterday that fiscal-fourth-quarter profits jumped 43.8 percent, despite a provision for the closing of certain stores.

title: Mets Pitchers Are Hit Hard
description: Pitching, which was supposed to rescue the Mets, abandoned them today when they opened the exhibition season by losing two games under a barrage of seven home runs in two cities 60 miles apart.

title: Advertising; Corning's Choice: B.& B.
description: AFTER a fairly long search, the Corning Glass Works' Consumer Products division has decided on Benton & Bowles as its ad agency. In doing so it is leaving behind Calet, Hirsch, Kurnit & Spector, its agency of 12 years, and for a change, no hard feelings. ''They were a wonderful client, a terrific client, a very good client and we understand their desires for a much larger agency,'' said Larry Spector, president and chief executive of Calet, Hirsch, which will continue doing advertising for Corning's Photochronic Lenses.

title: Betty Carter Sings Jazz
description: The jazz singer Betty Carter will perform tonight and tomorrow night at 9 and midnight at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880). Tickets are $7.50.

title: SATELITE LINKED TO SPACE STATION AS RUSSIANS AIM FOR LARGER CRAFT
description: In an important test of the Soviet Union's ability to assemble larger space stations, a satellite was linked yesterday to the unoccupied, Earth-orbiting Salyut 7 and all systems were reported to be functioning normally, the official Soviet press agency Tass announced.

title: Economic Scene; OPEC Failing As Cartel
description: NO matter what the immediate outcome of the turbulent London meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, we have been watching a highly contentious and failing cartel. It now looks as though some sort of face-saving agreement will be put together to cut the price of OPEC's benchmark crude oil by $5 a barrel, to $29, and to assign quotas to member countries to limit total OPEC production to 17.5 million barrels a day. But OPEC cannot police this agreement and it seems likely that the price of oil will continue to decline.

MCGARRIGLES AT CARNEGIE
description: If folk musicians are the ones who carry acoustic guitars, then the double bill tonight at 8 in Carnegie Hall is a folk concert. But the music of Kate and Anna McGarrigle and of Leo Kottke makes more sense as the work of uncompromising individualists who find something personal in a tangle of folk traditions.

title: MRS. BURFORD SAYS SHE DECIDED TO QUIT BEFORE PRESIDENT YIELDED TO CONGRESS
description: Anne McGill Burford said today that she decided to resign as Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency before President Reagan agreed Wednesday to turn over subpoenaed documents to House investigators.

description: People
