Rating Helps Sale Of Sewer Bonds
description: A $48 million issue of Chicago sewer bonds sold quickly yesterday after underwriters led by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank offered them with yields ranging from 5.4 percent in 1985 to 8.2 percent in 1994. By late afternoon, about $8.3 million of bonds remained unsold.

title: 'VICTORY MARCH,' TRAINING A BOOKISH G.I.
description: ''VICTORY MARCH,'' which opens today at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, is a new film by Marco Bellocchio, the Italian director who sometimes makes fascinating movies, like the recently released ''Leap Into the Void,'' and sometimes films that display the same degree of intelligence and idiosyncrasy, but which are not so good as their parts.

title: EMMPLOYEE OF U.S. DIES IN GUATEMALA
description: Four people, including a Guatemalan working here for the United States Agency for International Development, have been slain by Government troops, the army announced today.

title: K MART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
description: Results for the latest yr include a pretax provision of $44.5 million for storeclosings

title: Bridge: Grand National Pairs Final Ending Today in Honolulu
description: For nearly all the thousands of players assembling in Honolulu today, the Spring National Championships have not yet begun. But 156 are already hard at work: the final of the Grand National Pairs began yesterday and will conclude today.

title: CAPITAL SPENDING PLANS ARE 3.8 PERCENT LOWER
description: American business executives plan to cut spending for expansion and modernization by 3.8 percent this year after adjustment for inflation, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: FRENCH LEFT IS TESTED IN A 'SAD, GRAY LITTLE PLACE'
description: Clichy looks like this: rotting buildings, tiny grocery stores, dead concrete slabs slapped into housing projects. On one side, alleys, cobblestones, updated Zola; on the other, Mean Streets, low-rent apartment buildings 10-stories high, a Reader-Adviser who has set up shop in the back of a truck parked on the sidewalk.

title: SCHEIB, EARL, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SPORTS PEOPLE
description: They were No.1 and No.2 to the fans who cheered them at the University of Michigan and at Grambling, and now Anthony Carter of the Michigan Panthers and Trumaine Johnson of the Chicago Blitz have won the right to retain their single-digit jerseys in the United States Football League. In a ruling issued late yesterday, the league said that two players on each of its 12 teams could be exempt from the league's universal numbering system, which would have required the two wide receivers to wear a number in the 80's.

title: Mark Twain Musical
description: The Cathedral School choristers and players of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine will present a musical version of Mark Twain's ''The Prince and the Pauper'' tonight at 7:30 and tomorrow at 2 P.M. in the cathedral's synod hall, Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street.

title: PRO-SOVIET GROUPS SET BACK AT THIRD WORLD CONFERENCE
description: Pro-Soviet groups at a conference of nations that call themselves nonaligned have suffered several setbacks in the drafting of declarations on political and economic issues to be issued here this week.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Brooklyn Heights With Sound and Lights

title: Kodak Films To Be Coded
description: The Eastman Kodak Company announced it would put codes on its film that could be used by future ''smart'' 35-millimeter cameras to adjust exposure automatically.

title: News Analysis
description: OPEC is in disarray again as it struggles to regain control over the price of oil because it finds itself incapable of learning the lessons of the past.

title: NONALIGNMENT'S AIMS, AND OURS
description: As well-heeled officials from 101 primarily third-world nations parade across the podium making pious declarations about peace, global crisis and economic development, the temptation is great to dismiss the nonaligned movement as a hypocritical farce.

title: Friday; PREMIERE OF BEHAN FARCE
description: Brendan Behan's last play, ''Richard's Cork Leg,'' is a satirical, farce set in a graveyard. It has bawdy, music-hall humor, lots of songs and is ''quite crazy - very funny but deeply cynical,'' according to Jim Sheridan, who is directing and acting in the New York premiere of the production, which opens tonight at 8 at the Irish Arts Center, 553 West 51st Street. Behan, who died in 1964, did not quite finish ''Richard's Cork Leg,'' but Mr. Sheridan says the incompleteness is appropriate to the work. Tickets: $6 ($5 for over-65s). Reservations: 757-3318 (1 to 6 P.M. weekdays). RUTGERS REVIVES RAMEAU

title: MUSIC: ROSTOPOVICH
description: Whatever Mstislav Rostropovich's gifts may be as a conductor of day-in, day-out repertory in Washington, his programs with the National Symphony when he brings it to Carnegie Hall are usually devoted to the Russian music he loves so deeply.

title: WHERE THE WOULD-BE ENGINEERS ARE
description: To the Editor:

title: Pinone Point Wins
description: Connecticut came close to a major upset in the first round of the Big East tournament yesterday, but Villanova kept its poise and beat the Huskies, 69-68.

title: L.I.U. WINS BY 101-98 TO GAIN FINAL
description: Robert Brown scored three field goals in overtime, including the go-ahead basket with 1 minute 41 seconds to play, to help Long Island University defeat Fairleigh Dickinson, 101-98, last night in an Eastern College Athletic Conference Metro playoff game at Schwartz Athletic Center, Brooklyn..

title: News Analysis
description: After 10 weeks of direct negotiations on Israel's conditions for withdrawing its troops from Lebanon, the problem remains unsolved: How to reconcile Israel's demand for security with Lebanon's desire for sovereignty.

title: Butcher Filing
description: C.H. Butcher Jr.'s Southern Industrial Banking Corporation, an uninsured loan company, filed a reorganization petition in United States Bankruptcy Court today. Southern Industrial's investors withdrew $27 million in less than a month, prompting the concern to stop the run Tuesday by banning further withdrawals.

title: 3d Skate Title to Hamilton
description: Scott Hamilton of the United States overwhelmed his opposition in the world figure skating championships today, executing six triple jumps to win his third straight gold medal.

title: Peru Orders Debt Renewal
description: Peru's central bank has ordered the renewal for 360 days of all short-term foreign loans of working capital falling due up to Dec. 31, and the renewal for 90 days of all short-term commercial debt maturing at dates up to May 31, according to the Government press agency, Andina.

title: Ford's Suppliers Object to Terms
description: The Ford Motor Company's suppliers said they might have a tough time meeting the auto maker's terms for future business.

title: '83 Starts in Housing
description: The Georgia Pacific Corporation yesterday raised its forecast for housing starts in the United States this year to 1.45 million units from the 1.3 million it had predicted earlier.

title: COLEGE AID RULE BLOCKED BY JUDGE
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that a law denying Federal loans to students who have not registered for the draft is likely to be held unconstitutional. He issued an injunction forbidding enforcement of the law.

title: Adolph Krejtman Dies; Philanthropist Was 87
description: Adolph A. Krejtman, a business executive and philanthropist, died Wednesday night after he fell or leaped from a window of his apartment at 900 Fifth Avenue. He was 87 years old.

title: Mother's Adage Put to Test
description: A dele Carnesecca has told her son the adage a thousand times. Maybe even a million times: ''A hungry cat fights hardest.'' Lou Carnesecca believes his mother so avidly that he chalked the adage on the bulletin board Wednesday while the St. John's basketball team was preparing for the Big East tournament.

title: WEISFIELD'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Chicago White Sox, exhibition, at Sarasota, Fla. Among the pitchers for the Mets will be Tim Leary, trying a comeback after long inactivity caused by a shoulder injury.

title: KNUDSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FOR BLACKS, RACISM AND PROGESS MIX
description: In the last Congress, the members of the Congressional Black Caucus often felt all but irrelevant. They sat in clusters in the House chamber for vote after vote, watching helplessly as a conservative tide swept in. Their appeals in behalf of the poor, the unemployed and the dispossessed were largely dismissed as special pleading.

title: How the precincts tally, page B3.
description: New York City's crime rate, after soaring to record highs in 1980 and 1981, dropped 5.1 percent last year, the Police Department's annual crime report showed yesterday.

title: 'WEAPONS-GRADE' PLUTONIUM UNFIT FOR WEAPONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Reports Death Of Maclean, British Spy
description: Donald Maclean, the British diplomat who spied for the Soviet Union more than 30 years ago, has died here at the age of 69, a spokesman for the institute where he worked said today.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''T HIS has got to be the chicest line in town tonight,'' Carol Beller was saying in the rain sometime after 9 o'clock as the 500 or so formally attired people inched toward a brightly lighted Cartier's. Mrs. Beller wasn't kidding: even a passing panhandler was requesting dollar bills from the men and women who emerged from stretch limousines before queuing up.

title: Roman haven for U.S. arts.
description: THE American Academy of Rome has long been a place to kindle the imagination. Founded in 1894 by the architect Charles Follen McKim, its eight buildings are spread over 10 acres on the Janiculum Hill, above the Trastevere section, one of the oldest parts of Rome. Each year, American artists and scholars go to the academy to live and work, and to profit from a city that the painter Al Held, a former resident and now a trustee of the academy, says ''just keeps going back and back and back in time.''

title: ART: ALEX KATZ'S WORKS, EVER NICE, NEVER EMPTY
description: IF we had to be reincarnated, one of the better ideas would be to come back to life in a painting by Alex Katz. The weather would always be good, there wouldn't be an ugly or a disagreeable person in sight and every house would be in decent repair.

title: REAGAN PROPOSES $298 MILLION MORE FOR LATIN REGION
description: President Reagan, saying that the nations of Central America ''are in the midst of the gravest crisis in their history,'' today proposed an emergency $298 million military and economic assistance package for the region that inclues $110 million in arms aid for El Salvador.

title: PUBLISHING F.B.I. FILE ON HEMINGWAY
description: A LITERARY scholar says he has turned up new evidence of an effort by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to discredit Ernest Hemingway in his attempt to spy on potential Nazi sympathizers in Cuba during World War II.

title: TV: SCIENCE ON 'SEARCH'
description: IN its first venture into prime-time television production, The New York Times Company has lent its resources to what is essentially a one-shot electronic magazine aimed at the vast number of Americans with limited scientific training but an appetite for greater understanding of current developments in science and technology.

title: Comings and Goings
description: J.R. Richard underwent his third major surgery in three years, this time to correct a circulation problem in a leg, a difficulty that had apparently been caused by the second operation. Afterward, Dr. William Fields said the Astros pitcher was ''just fine'' and should be throwing again within two months. ... Billy Taylor, the former Giant running back, and Ken Brown, a wide receiver from Nebraska, were cut by the Boston Breakers. ... Major Jones of the Houston Rockets was fined $300 and placed on probation for two years after decling to contest a drunken-driving charge. ... Buddy Hardeman, a running back for the Washington Federals, was charged with assaulting a policeman during a squabble outside a capital nightspot. A teammate, Phil Dubois, a tight end, paid a $10 fine for disorderly conduct in the same incident.

title: SAFETY OF SHOREHAM PLANT DEBATED
description: The Suffolk County Executive yesterday accused the Long Island Lighting Company of playing ''a casino game with the people's safety'' by pressing to complete the Shoreham nuclear power plant, and the chairman of Lilco said the County Executive's opposition threatened to turn Long Island into ''an economic wasteland.''

title: Nicolette Leads By 2 With 66
description: Mike Nicolette, after a year of obscurity and 106th place on the money list, took the lead in the opening round of the Bay Hill Classic today.

title: Talks Denied By Brokerage
description: Paine Webber Inc. denied yesterday that it was negotiating to buy Conticommodity Services Inc. as part of its program to expand its brokerage business. The denial was made despite indications that such talks were being held in Chicago and New York.

title: 2 Co-managers Offering Zero-Coupon Securities
description: Merrill Lynch Government Securities Inc. and the Bankers Trust Company are co-managing an offering of about $558.7 million of zerocoupon Treasury securities, called Treasury Investment Growth Receipts, or ''Tigers.''

title: IT TAKES A LAWYER, NOT A JUDGE, TO QUIZ PROSPECTIVE JURORS
description: To the Editor:

title: FEBRUARY STORE SALES DOWN 0.4%
description: The nation's retail sales, vital for economic recovery, dropped four-tenths of 1 percent in February from January's level, pulled down by a decline in auto sales, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: VIATECH INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After an $88,683 gain on the disposal of a subsidiary

title: ARGENTINA, WOOING CUBANS, FAULTS U.S.
description: The Argentine Government, which has been seeking Cuban support for its claim to the Falkland Islands, called in the United States Ambassador Wednesday to express concern over an American document distributed here this week on Cuban subversion in Latin America, Foreign Ministry officials said.

title: Suharto Is Chosen For a Fourth Term
description: The Indonesian Assembly unanimously elected President Suharto to his fourth five-year term today and granted him expanded powers.

title: INDIANS AND PAKISTANIS IN ACCORD
description: India and Pakistan completed an agreement today to form a joint commission aimed at improving economic, industrial and cultural relations.

title: TALKS IN METRO-NORTH STRIKE ARE SET TO RESUME SUNDAY
description: Negotiators in the Metro-North rail strike have agreed to resume talks Sunday, a mediator announced yesterday. The talks will be the first since the walkout, which has affected 90,000 commuters in New York's northern suburbs, began on Monday.

title: PARIS OFFSPRING AND EAST MEETS WEST
description: WHEN a much-celebrated young Turk of France's nouvelle cuisine opens a restaurant in Greenwich, Conn., the event is noteworthy far beyond the boundaries of that community. Aware that the Paris restaurant run by the 29-year-old chef Guy Savoy rates a star in the Michelin Guide and 18 out of a possible 20 points in the Gault-Millau guide, food buffs want to know how well the chef's talents travel. Based on three dinners that I can compare with a delightful lunch enjoyed last year at the Paris original, I would have to say the answer is disappointing. There is some good food here, but too many dishes are contrived and tasteless, indicating that much of the chef's creative efforts here go into presentation rather than into developing flavor.

title: STUDY SEES NUTRITION PARADOX
description: Americans may be well aware of the value of proper nutrition and regular exercise, but do they incorporate them into daily life? Not often, if the population at large is typified by those residents of suburban New Rochelle in Westchester County who participated in a study made public yesterday.

title: SHELL OIL COMPANIES reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: The latest yr's net includes $2,157,000,000 for the Royal Dutch Petroleum Co and $1,230,000,000 for the Shell Transport & Trading Co; the Group's 1981 net includes $2,324,000,000 for Royal Dutch and $1,232,000,000 for Shell Transport

title: ACTRESS AND PERSONALITY
description: Faye Emerson, an actress who achieved national popularity in the 1950's as one of television's first late-night interviewers, died of cancer Wednesday on Majorca. She was 65 years old.

title: Iraqi Navy Contends It Sank 6 Iranian Ships in Persian Gulf
description: The Iraqi Navy sank six Iranian ships today as they were entering an inlet on the northern tip of the Persian Gulf, the Iraqi News Agency said.

title: Du Pont Unit Sale
description: Reichhold Chemicals Inc., White Plains, announced it had agreed in principle to acquire the E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company's vinyl acetate/ethylene emulsion business for more than $20 million. The agreement, scheduled to take effect in the second quarter of this year, includes the sale of Du Pont's Elvace manufacturing plant at Seneca, N.Y., and all patent, trademark, manufacturing and marketing data pertaining to Elvace products, it said. The new business will become part of Reichhold's Emulsion Polymers division, which has headquarters in Dover, Del.

title: Woman's Place Is Every Place
description: That men and women are different is a verity. That they live, or should live, in different ''places'' is a handy hypothesis, trotted out whenever the times, or an occasion, seem to demand it. National Women's History Week, which ends tomorrow, celebrates the search for the many places that have been women's over the centuries.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Fall; Concern Over Fed's Actions
description: Treasury note and bond prices fell modestly yesterday amid growing concern among traders and investors that the Federal Reserve is not likely to foster declines in short-term interest rates in the near future.

title: A TRIBUTE IS GIVEN TO WILLIAM BLACK
description: William Black, who turned a Times Square shelled-nuts stand into the Chock Full o'Nuts restaurant chain, was remembered during a memorial service yesterday for his philanthropy, as well as for his concern for his employees. Mr. Black died of cancer on Monday at the age of 80.

title: Deflated Figure
description: The United States Football League's opening week of play was slightly less successful than it had appeared.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Mellon have given the Yale University Art Gallery a group of 16 paintings by Pierre Bonnard, Eugene Boudin, Georges Braque, Paul Cezanne, Edgar Degas, Eugene Delacroix, Albert Marquet, Claude Monet, Camille Pissarro and Edouard Vuillard.

title: TELESPHERE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Shr earnings give effect to the 50 percent distribution on Jan 10

title: 'ELISA, VIDA MIA'
description: NEAR the end of Carlos Saura's ''Elisa, Vida Mia,'' Fernado Rey, in the role of an aging ascetic named Luis, talks movingly to his daughter, Elisa (Geraldine Chaplin), about his youthful artistic pretensions. He recalls that he used to spend hours and days polishing a letter, getting the syntax right, refining the thoughts and elevating the tone. Now, he admits, he prefers the spontaneous letter, unrefined, natural, with crossed-out words. Luis has no interest in Art.

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Herbert L. Laube, 83, Founder Of Air-Conditioning Company
description: Herbert Livingston Laube, founder and former president of the Remington Corporation, an air-conditioning manufacturer, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at his winter home in Juno Beach, Fla. Mr. Laube, who also lived in Camillus, in Onondaga County in New York, was 83 years old.

title: Women's Rape in a Bar Enrages New Bedford
description: Workers using a chainsaw today dismantled a bar where the police say a woman was repeatedly raped by four men on a pool table as other patrons cheered.

title: OIL TALKS FOCUSING ON PRODUCTION QUOTA
description: With the outlines of a new oil-pricing agreement in hand, OPEC ministers became bogged down today in talks on production quotas and recessed until Friday.

title: ST. JOHN'S AND VILLANOVA TO MEET IN BIG EAST SEMIFINAL
description: St. John's opened the Big East Conference playoffs by beating Pittsburgh, 64-53, yesterday at Madison Square Garden, but the Redmen had to resort to some uncharacteristic methods to win.

title: NORSTAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The yr-ago figures were restated to reflect an accounting change

title: A Diplomat Suggests Soviet May Weigh On-Site Inspection
description: A Soviet diplomat said today that nuclear arms control talks with the United States were ''terribly deadlocked'' but suggested that Moscow might at some point be willing to consider on-site inspection to verify future agreements.

title: CARTER REAFFIRMS SUPPORT OF ISRAEL
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that his deep religious belief had led him to a commitment to the existence of Israel as a Jewish state. But he urged Israelis to seek a peace with justice for the Palestinians.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Making Music At an Early Age

title: DEVILS ARE BLANKED BY WHALERS, MILLEN
description: Coach Billy MacMillan of the Devils admitted after they were beaten, 3-0, tonight by the Hartford Whalers that his team may have reached its low point in the National Hockey League season.

title: Books of The Times
description: here is a special kind of practical information that the visitor to El Salvador acquires immediately, the way visitors to other places acquire information about the currency rates, the hours for the museums. In El Salvador one learns that vultures go first for the soft tissue, for the eyes, the exposed genitalia, the open mouth. One learns that an open mouth can be used to make a specific point, can be stuffed with something emblematic ... if the point has to do with land titles, stuffed with some of the dirt in question. One learns that hair deteriorates less rapidly than flesh, and that a skull surrounded by a perfect corona of hair is a not uncommon sight in the body dumps.'' <TD WIDTH=2

title: Savin Arranges Financing Plan
description: The Savin Corporation said it had arranged a three-year secured revolving credit financing agreement with the General Electic Credit Corporation.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Feb. 20 on Houston's financial condition incorrectly listed those of the nation's 10 largest cities that have the highest bond rankings. Dallas and Houston both hold the top rating from Moody's and Standard & Poor's.

title: DEALER IS INFORMANT
description: Federal authorities, using extensive information provided by Leroy (Nicky) Barnes, yesterday accused nine men of distributing ''massive quantities'' of heroin and killing six suspected informers in a narcotics operation in New York City.

title: Galway Plays Sunday
description: James Galway, the flutist, and the New Irish Chamber Orchestra will appear Sunday afternoon at 3 in Carnegie Hall, playing music by Bach, Duff and Vivaldi. Tickets, at $10 to $17.50, are available at the box office or through CarnegieCharge, 247-7459.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN'S SPEECH OUTLINING PROPOSALS FOR CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Following are excerpts from a speech by President Reagan to the National Association of Manufacturers today, the text of which was made available by the White House:

title: Wyoming Girl Guilty Of Aiding Father's Killer
description: A district court jury late today found 17-year-old Deborah Jahnke guilty of aiding and abetting manslaughter in her father's gunshot slaying Nov. 16.

title: PRESIDENT RESIGNS POST AT WARNER AMEX CABLE
description: John D. Lockton, 44, has resigned as president of Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc. ''to pursue other business interests,'' the company announced yesterday.

title: MOR-FLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BALL CONTROL HELPS ST. JOHN'S
description: W hen St. John's took command of its Big East opener against Pittsburgh midway in the first half at Madison Square Garden yesterday, the Redmen did it with the help of a defensive tactic sent in by Coach Lou Carnesecca. When the Redmen assured themselves of the victory in the closing minutes, they did it with an offensive tactic from the coach.

title: SAP IS BEGINNING TO FLOW: IT'S MAPLE-SYRUP TIME
description: Once again it's maple-syrup time north of Times Square, with many upstate and Connecticut sugar bushes stoking their fires this weekend to mark the opening of the season with demonstrations of how to tap trees and to make syrup, some even providing pancakes to go with the syrup.

title: Argentine Raid Reported
description: Argentine forces made a hit-and-run raid on the uninhabited British island of Thule, 400 miles southeast of the Falklands, after the war for the South Atlantic islands ended last year, the Defense Ministry said tonight. A spokesman said the landing was discovered Dec. 19 when a British survey ship visited Thule. He said the Argentines had ripped down the British flag and hoisted the Argentine flag.

title: CONNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 6
HOUSE UNIT CRITICIZES BAXTER
description: The Justice Department's antitrust chief, William F. Baxter, was sharply criticized by members of a House subcommittee today, and one suggested that Mr. Baxter resign for failure to uphold the law.

title: CITY IS ALLOWED TO RUN NOTICES IN ENGLISH ONLY
description: An appellate court has ruled that New York City need publish notices of public hearings only in English, even though residents of some neighborhoods in the city speak other languages.

title: SYRACUSE DEFEATS GEORGETOWN, 79-72
description: Just three days after Syracuse suffered a 5-point loss to Georgetown for the second time this season, the Orangemen came back strongly last night and beat the Hoyas, 79-72, in the first upset of the Big East tournament.

title: ENERGY MINERALS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results are for the 9 mos ended Dec 31, 1981; the company changed its fiscal yr-end from Mar 31 to Dec 31

title: MOSCOW OUSTS A U.S. DIPLOMAT, CALLING HIM A SPY
description: The Soviet Union today ordered the expulsion of an American diplomat who it said had been caught ''red-handed'' while in possession of equipment that included a portable electronic transmitter and notes written on special soluble paper.

title: The Nashville Network Begins With Optimism
description: Tuxedo-clad country musicians were beamed by satellite into an announced total of seven million homes Monday night over the new Nashville Network.

title: Reagan Pledge On Farm Tax
description: President Reagan promised today to sign legislation to remove a major tax problem facing farmers who enroll in the Government's new crop reduction program.

title: No Headline
description: Nevada-Las Vegas Triumphs by 74-67

title: One More First
description: Frank McGuire, who claims he led other St. John's players onto the court moments before the first college basketball game at Madison Square Garden, on Dec. 29, 1934, will have another first to his credit when he leads the first St. Patrick's Day parade in Columbia, S.C., next Thursday. Marching with him at the head of the parade will be his wife, Jane, who is not quite so sure as Frank about her Irish ancestry.

title: A NIGHT OF PIEDMONT BLUES TRADITION IN TRIBECA
description: JOHN CEPHAS and Phil Wiggins, who are performing at the Alternative Museum in TriBeCa tomorrow night at 8 P.M., are leading exponents of the Piedmont blues tradition. Outside of blues circles, this tradition is little known. Blues from the Mississippi Delta and elsewhere in the Deep South, and the fiercely electric Chicago blues that developed when Southern bluesmen moved north, have received much more attention, perhaps inevitably. Delta and Chicago blues are gritty, hard-driving and aggressive, and while Piedmont blues does not lack fire, it tends to be gentler, more lilting, more melodic.

title: Brazil Ends '86 Cup Bid
description: The effort by the United States to be chosen as host of the 1986 World Cup received an unexpected boost yesterday when the Government of Brazil announced that it would not support any effort to have the tournament played there.

title: Pintor Injured
description: Lupe Pintor, the World Boxing Council's bantamweight champion, was injured in a motorcycle accident in Mexico City and will be unable to fight for six months. As a result, Pintor, who last defended his crown in June and had been under pressure from the W.B.C. to schedule another defense, may be stripped of the title before he is well enough to fight again. ... Larry Holmes, the World Boxing Council's heavyweight champion, set March 27 as the date for his title defense in Scranton, Pa., against the European champion, Lucien Rodriguez of France. ... Marvelous Marvin Hagler will put his middleweight crown on the line in a 12-rounder against Wilford Scypion on May 13 in Providence, R.I. Bob Arum, the promoter, had sought a 15-round bout, but the World Boxing Council is standing by its 12-round limit, a safety precaution for the boxers.

title: ART: GONZALEZ SURVEY, A SCULPTOR'S RESHAPING
description: HE was a very late bloomer who started out as a craftsman and essentially remained one until his early 50's. But today, the Spanish sculptor Julio Gonzalez (1876-1942) is seen as one of the prime innovators of 20th-century art.

title: 'GUARDSMAN' BACK WITH LUCKINBILL AND LUCIE ARNAZ
description: LAURENCE LUCKINBILL and Lucie Arnaz, a married couple who have never before worked Broadway together, are headed in that direction to appear in a revival of ''The Guardsman,'' by Ferenc Molnar, the Hungarian playwright. ''The Guardsman'' last played Broadway in 1924, with Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, another acting couple, in their first joint stage appearance.

title: HOUSING CONSTRUCTION NEAR EAST RIVER
description: New York City's housing developers are saying ''Dig we must'' these days in Consolidated Edison's own backyard. Nowhere in Manhattan does Con Ed have a stronger presence than along the stretch from 41st Street to 35th Street on Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. The properties include the inactive Kips Bay generating station east of First Avenue between 35th and 36th Street and the active Waterside generating station on the superblock from 38th to 41st Streets.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Motors Corp. said it would end production of its Eagle four-wheel drive vehicles at Kenosha, Wis., beginning next week, increasing the number of layoffs at the plant to 2,600, from 1,350.

title: IT TAKES 2 TO MAKE MIDEAST PEACE
description: As the impasse drags on in the Middle East - in Lebanon and the occupied territories - there is a strong temptation to see Israel as the only obstacle to peace. Prime Minister Menachem Begin is seen to have been severely wounded by the inquiry into the Sabra and Shatila massacres, and it is widely thought that Israel can be pressed to make major concessions. This is a dangerously unrealistic view - based on false assumptions about Israel's vulnerability and on a sadly biased notion of who is responsible for the failure to make peace. In fact, it takes two to prolong a stalemate, and Israel is hardly alone in blocking progess toward an agreement.

title: Walker's Golden Touch
description: Just two weeks after he became the highest-paid player in professional football, Herschel Walker has established a sports financial record, his lawyer said yesterday. According to Jack Manton, the lawyer who negotiated Walker's three-year, multimilliondollar contract with the New Jersey Generals, the running back has now signed what Manton contends is the largest single endorsement contract ever made by a football, basketball or baseball star: a 10-year pact with the Adidas shoe manufacturer that will bring him between $1 million and $2 million.

title: Offer New Arms Plan, Senator Urges Reagan
description: The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee urged President Reagan today to make a new proposal for limiting intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: MEZZANINE: WHAT DOES IN MEAN?
description: Long, long ago, people who bought mezzanine tickets at Broadway t heaters were seated on a level between the balcony and the o rchestra. In recent years, however, some theaters began to call the u pperlevel seats farthest from the stage, which many people would t hink of as a balcony, ''rear mezzanine.'' This aroused the ire of m any theatergoers who were infuriated when they found themselves s itting far in the back.

description: The Baldwin United Corporation, a holding company with interests in insurance, banking, and savings and loan operations, is seeking to restructure about $900 million in short-term debt. Baldwin, which is based in Cincinnati, has retained Goldman, Sachs & Company as a financial adviser. Baldwin said it hoped that it could extend its short-term debt, about half of which is due Monday, intially through June 30, and that it eventually could reach an agreement on a longerterm financing plan.

description: A referee enlivened tonight's game more than any player as the Nets rallied from a 15-point deficit and surprised the Boston Celtics, 98-93, before a capacity crowd of 20,149 at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: TV: NBC'S 'MONITOR' A NEWS MAGAZINE
description: ''Monitor,'' the new NBC News program, has a magazine format - four segments connected only by Lloyd Dobyns, the anchor. It is unpretentious in tone, and it looks at things with what seems to be a random, almost whimsical, eye. Clearly, it wants to entertain as much as to enlighten. ''Monitor'' will be seen at 10 tonight on Channel 4.

title: DRIESELL DENIES INTIMIDATION
description: The Maryland basketball team, in Atlanta for the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament, left behind in College Park a controversy involving the coach, Lefty Driesell.

title: FILM MARKET ON COAST ENJOYING BRISK BUSINESS
description: Film buyers from 64 countries have come to haggle over the wares at the third annual American Film Market in Los Angeles this week, and 64 flags fly from the Sunset Strip hotel that is the market's new headquarters. That the 64 countries and 64 flags do not match is an augury of the Byzantine trading climate that prevails.

title: SNAKE EYES
description: .2,2LONDON - The world's most implacable gambler surely must have been the fellow who requested in his will that his bones be converted into dice and that his skin used as covering for dice boxes. I would like to affirm that no such I will pen no such bequest. Nobody is going to shake, rattle and roll me when I die. The irony would be intolerable, inasmuch as luck has never been a lady to me.

description: The playwright Tennessee Williams left most of his estate, estimated at about $10 million, to the University of the South at Sewanee, Tenn., stipulating it should be used to help creative writers.

title: RESCUE PLAN ADVANCES AT WASHINGTON POWER
description: A plan to raise $1.05 billion to refinance $2.25 billion in bonds of the Washington Public Power Supply System was endorsed today by directors of a Washington State public utility association.

Ackerman in the 12th District. Mr. Ackerman was elected to the House of Representatives in a special election March 2.

description: A Federal grand jury today indicted Gordon W. Kahl, the fugitive tax resister, and five others in connection with the Feb. 13 slaying of two United States marshals in North Dakota.

title: DRAMATIC DROP IN U.S. OIL IMPORTS
description: The nation's crude oil imports were lower in February than in any month since May 1968, with many of the nation's largest oil companies buying less than half the foreign oil that they had projected would be needed to meet their average demand over the course of the year.

title: LABOR IN JAPAN COOLS TO ROBOTS
description: For years, Japan has been robot heaven. Experts bicker over what is and is not a robot, but they generally agree that by any standard Japan has more of them than the rest of the world combined.

title: An Early Finish
description: Andrea Jaeger didn't want high school studies to interfere with her busy tennis schedule in the spring and early summer. So she took extra credits the last few weeks and graduated from Adlai Stevenson High School in Prairie View, a Chicago suburb, yesterday rather than in June.

description: Interest rates declined slightly late yesterday and prices rose on renewed buying of Government securities after the Federal Reserve reported a smaller-than-expected increase in its basic measure of money available for spending.

title: HOW WITHHOLDING WILL WORK
description: Beginning July 1, under a law enacted last year, banks and corporations will be required to withhold 10 percent of interest and dividends paid or credited to individuals. It puts these payments on the same footing as wages and salaries.

description: To the Editor:

title: NEW STOREFRONT HEALTH CARE
description: Despite criticism from some doctors, consumers in ever greater numbers are using house-call services and emergency centers in shopping malls to treat common family illnesses. Proponents say these alternatives to a hospital emergency room or a doctor's office fill a major gap in American medical care. Detractors say they provide only superficial medical treatment.

title: 2. SAVE LEVER HOUSE
description: Lever House, in New York City, was completed a mere 31 years ago. Graceful in form and human in scale, Gordon Bunshaft's design is a milestone in this nation's architectural history.

title: WHY CLASSICAL GREEK?
description: Alt hough much has been written of late on the virtues of studying Latin, the case for learning classical Greek, if made at all, is mentioned only in passing. It happens that Hillcrest High School, in Jamaica, N.Y., in September will become the only New York City public school, and one of only a handful of schools in the United States, to offer a course in classical Greek (along with Latin, which was reintroduced last year). This is a watershed in education in the United States.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, exhibition, at St. Petersburg, Fla. Tom Seaver, back with the Mets, gets the start against the world champion Cardinals. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, exhibition, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. (Radio - WABC, 770; 7:15 P.M.) title: Koestlers Are Cremated After Memorial Service
description: Arthur Koestler, author of ''Darkness at Noon,'' and his wife were cremated today after a memorial service at which excerpts from his writings on life and death were read.

title: PREMIER AND CABINET TAKE OFFICE IN AUSTRALIA
description: Robert Hawke, the leader of the Labor Party, took office as Australia's Prime Minister today and promised to ''change the face of decision-making in this country.''

title: Temple Stops Rutgers
description: Terence Stansbury of Temple scored 19 of his game-high 29 points in the second half and the Owls controlled the inside play of 6-foot 9-inch Roy Hinson to upset Rutgers, 72-67, tonight. They will advance to the final of the Atlantic 10 Conference tournament Saturday, meeting West Virginia, who beat St. Bonaventure, 86-62, tonight

title: CONCERT: ANDRES SEGOVIA PERFORMS AT AVERY FISHER HALL
description: All those who were fortunate enough to be in Avery Fisher Hall last night will be able to tell incredulous listeners in years hence that they heard Andres Segovia give a technically fluent, mesmerizing recital when he was a month past his 90th birthday. The hall was packed with the great Spanish guitarist's admirers, of course, and the audience overflowed into stage seats for what, by any measure, was one of the season's notable occasions.

title: Atari-Coleco Pact
description: Warner Communications Inc., its Atari Inc. unit and Coleco Industries said they had settled all issues that were the subject of litigation. Under the agreement, Coleco has become licensed on a royalty basis under Atari's patents to continue making and selling the Expansion Module No.1 for the Colecovision video game system and the free-standing Gemini video game system.

title: WD-40 CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't think they'll be happy until the White House looks like a bird's nest.'' - President Reagan, on environmentalists. (1:5.)

title: Unwanted Rest
description: Elaine Zayak of Paramus, N.J., the 17-year-old former world figure-skating champion, is back home and had her right ankle put in a cast yesterday.

title: NEW DELHI MEETING IS HELP FOR EGYPT
description: At the meeting of third world nations in New Delhi, President Hosni Mubarak improved relations with some of the Arab nations that broke with Egypt over the peace treaty with Israel.

title: 14 Postal Workers Held In Drug Case in Jersey
description: Fourteen Postal Service employees were arrested today on charges of selling narcotics to co-workers at the giant North Jersey mail-handling center here, postal authorities said. Two other workers were being sought.

title: 5 ACCUSED OF FENCING GEMS STOLEN IN MAFIA OPERATIONS
description: Five men were charged in Manhattan yesterday with conducting an organized-crime fencing operation that obtained millions of dollars of jewelry from burglaries throughout the United States.

title: The Seniors Take Burden at Syracuse
description: T his was no way for a college career to end. For more than two seasons, Leo Rautins had been an essential part of the group that had accomplished something remarkable at Syracuse University. Basketball games had turned into events that attracted crowds in such large numbers that many fans in the Carrier Dome could hardly see the ball, much less hear it bounce. The fans just beneath the roof did not seem to mind because they returned again and again.

title: Philadelphia Textile 72 C.W. Post 68
description: Philadelphia Textile scored its last 9 points on free throws in the final 3:16 as the Rams won an openinground game of the N.C.A.A. Division II Eastern Regional Tournament at Bloomsburg State College.

title: ERROL JOSEPH LINDEN
description: Errol Joseph Linden, who played 10 seasons in the National Football League, died of cancer in a hospital here Thursday at the age of 45. Mr. Linden, a native of New Orleans, was a starting tight end and defensive end at the University of Houston before being picked by the Detroit Lions in the N.F.L.'s 1960 draft.

title: Woman Accused Of Killing Teacher
description: A 38-year-old woman was being held yesterday on charges of murdering a schoolteacher, who was stabbed to death Thursday morning in her Bronx apartment.

description: BASEBALL SEATTLE (AL) - Gary Thomasson, an outfielder formerly with the Dodgers and most recently with the Yomiuri Giants in Japan, joined spring training camp on a conditional basis. COLLEGE

title: Jobless Youth and Useful Work
description: In the rush to do something about unemployment, the full House and the Senate's Budget Committee have given quick approval to reviving the New Deal's idea of the conservation corps. It would help only a fraction of the chronically unemployed youth, probably not more than 100,000 a year, but it has merit nonetheless.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bass Brothers Enterprises and Terry R. Bass said in an S.E.C. filing that they had lowered their stake in Fairchild Industries to 44.4 percent of the $3.60 series A cumulative convertible preferred shares outstanding.

title: U.S. TO PUT RADAR SYSTEM IN HONDURAS
description: The United States has decided to set up and operate a sophisticated radar system in southern Honduras with the intention of monitoring what the Reagan Administration says are Nicaraguan arms shipments to Salvadoran guerrillas, according to well-placed Hondurans.

title: Trans World Sues Odyssey
description: The Trans World Corporation, parent of Trans World Airlines, said yesterday that it had sued Odyssey Partners in Federal court in New York, charging it with forming an illegal group to wage a proxy fight to promote the dismemberment of the company.

title: 2 MISSING PROFESSORS THOUGHT TO BE SLAIN ON TRIP TO INDONESIA
description: Two English professors from City University who disappeared two months ago during a vacation in Indonesia are believed dead, killed during a robbery, the sister of one of the men said yesterday.

title: DISPUTE ARISES AFTER REPORT OF PURGE IN ARMS TALKS UNIT
description: Reports of a recent request by President Reagan's negotiator on strategic arms reduction that some officials at the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency be dismissed stirred a new dispute today over Administration policy and personnel in arms control.

title: OIL INDUSTRY FACES SQUEEZE IN EUROPE
description: It is simple supply and demand. Europe's oil refining and marketing companies have been turning out more oil and oil products than Europeans have been buying. Accordingly, the companies have been struggling through a severe earnings squeeze, somewhat tardily seeking to right themselves by cutting capacity.

title: FROM MILAN, PASTRIES WITH STYLE AND ELEGANCE
description: Among Europe's most civilized pleasures are the luxurious little pastry shops-cafes where one may buy homemade cakes to take out, or sit for a while sipping coffee, tea or aperitifs while nibbling on small hot or cold dishes or on a selection of exquisitely crafted pastries.

title: Emigre Charges Poland Has Secret Penal Camps
description: Secret military penal camps were set up last fall by the Polish Government and have been used since the suspension of martial law as internment centers for thousands of Solidarity activists and supporters, according to a former leader of the outlawed union now living in New York as a refugee.

title: Stay Granted in Arizona For Condemned Prisoner
description: Robert Wayne Vickers won a reprieve today, four days before he was scheduled to die in the Arizona State Prison gas chamber for killing his cellmate.

title: MINORITY LEGISLATORS ASK WAGNER TO QUIT RACE FOR CITY SCHOOL CHIEF
description: Black and Puerto Rican legislators said yesterday that they had asked Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. to withdraw from the competition for Schools Chancellor in favor of their candidate. Mr. Wagner said that he had declined to drop out and that he was in the running to stay.

description: To the Editor:

SWITCH TO UNQUALIFIED PILOT CITED IN CRASH OF A CARGO JET FATAL TO 3
description: A flight engineer who had been disqualified for future pilot assignments because of ''proficiency'' problems was apparently flying the United Airlines DC-8 cargo plane that crashed while taking off from Detroit Jan. 11, according to Government documents made public yesterday.

title: Attendance at Issue
description: The way David Bradley, a former San Diego State basketball player, is telling it, he was admitted to the college three years ago on the basis of credits in courses he never attended. The way school officials are telling it, Bradley was cut from the team for disciplinary reasons at the start of the season and is now engaged in a personal vendetta.

title: World Skating Title to Miss Sumners
description: Rosalynn Sumners of Edmonds, Wash., earned eight of nine first-place votes in the freestyle program tonight and won the women's title at the world figure skating championships.

title: Keep the Three-Family House
description: Why does the builder of a ''two-family house'' in a middle-income New York neighborhood advertise a five-and-a-half-room ''hospitality suite'' in the basement? Chances are the basement suite (which may be mostly above ground) is just a third apartment, described as guest space because zoning limits density to two apartments under each roof.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Edward McGruder earns his living shining shoes in a cul-de-sac at the top of a flight of stairs in Grand Central Terminal. Mr. McGruder has been shining shoes for 15 years; before that, he was a sleeping-car porter on the railroad for nearly half a century. Mr. McGruder liked being a railroad man, as he calls himself, and he likes working in the terminal. And so these days he finds himself caught between old loyalties and new economic realities, losing money hand over fist during the Metro-North strike and missing his old commuter customers, but always mindful of the plight of the train worker.

title: SYRACUSE DEFEATED BY 80-74
description: Jim Boeheim, the Syracuse coach, observed after his team had lost to Boston College, 80-74, in the semifinal round of the Big East Conference tournament at Madison Square Garden last night: ''All season long, any team that has pressed us has been helping us. Boston College didn't help us tonight.''

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, MARCH 12, 1983
description: International A terror campaign in Lebanon against Palestinian civilians has been going on for the last month, according to refugees and United Nations officials. The goal of the campaign is to force Palestinians to leave the country. They have been subjected to bomb attacks, murders, kidnappings, threatening leaflets and visits in the night by hooded vigilantes. (Page 1, Col. 3.) The United States plans to install a radar system in southern Honduras with the intention of monitoring what the Reagan Administration says are Nicaraguan arms shipments to Salvadoran guerrillas, Honduran sources said. The radar system would be similar to the one used in last month's joint United States-Honduran military maneuvers. (3:1.)

title: Chicago Board Options Record
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange registered record volume yesterday in becoming the first exchange to trade cash-settled market index options.

title: 2020 Foresight on Social Security
description: ''This bill gives us all something to complain about,'' said Representative Claude Pepper, the energetic opponent of reducing Social Security benefits. But to their credit, Mr. Pepper and a majority of the House have voted for a Social Security rescue plan that would both reduce benefits and increase taxes. Indeed, they took a big step beyond the safe political ground created by the Commission on Social Security. By approving a gradual increase in the standard retirement age, they've done their part to assure the system's long-term solvency.

title: L.I.R.R. PLANS 25 MORE MILES OF ELECTRIC RAIL
description: The Long Island Rail Road plans to electrify an additional 25 miles of track in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, a move that railroad officials say would cut commuting time by 22 minutes between Pennsylvania Station and Ronkonkoma.

description: President Reagan promised to veto the $3.7 billion jobs bill if it still contains a rider repealing tax withholding for interest and dividends income when he gets it from Congress. He was clearly angered by an anti-withholding drive of the banking industry. (Page 1.) Mr. Dole was opening Finance Committee hearings into what he described as the ''unusually low'' income tax rates enjoyed by banks. (9.)

description: One of Ronald Reagan's favorite targets in his campaign for President and since his inauguration has been the food stamp program. Mr. Reagan has frequently regaled audiences and White House visitors with charges of fraud and deception by food stamp users.

title: You Know Me, Alma
description: Dear Alma: This year I am really not kidding when I say this year we could take it all. I know that's what I said in '80 when I got fired for finishing fifth and in '81 and '82 when I got fired twice for two last-place finishes, but those were not baseball teams I was managing, they were debating societies, crybabies and cream puffs. What's gotten into ballplayers anyhow, Alma? I still can't get over that fight with P.B. Laguna during the Tigers game in '81 when I moved him to sixth in the batting order and he said he couldn't bat sixth because he had athlete's foot and, therefore, ought to bat leadoff as the itch would make him get down to first faster.

title: STATE WORKERS TRYING TO COPE WITH LAYOFFS
description: It may be Friday, but Frank Conte does not have much to look forward to this weekend. Mr. Conte, a 42-year-old Transportation Department worker, expects to find a letter in his mailbox any day, telling him that his $32,000-a-year job with the state is about to end.

description: The Environmental Protection Agency improperly reviewed the proposed starting up of an aging reactor used to make plutonium for nuclear weapons, Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, charged today.

description: White House Drive Stalls

title: LOAN BANK CHAIRMAN TO RESIGN
description: The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, Richard T. Pratt, will announce his resignation on Monday, a spokesman for the board said today.

title:
PATENTS;
Seismic 'Streamer' Gathers Subsea Data
description: Information on subsea formations can be gathered with the aid of a seismic ''streamer,'' a cable towed behind an exploration vessel. Microphones on the streamer relay to the vessel reflections of waves sent to the sea floor by an explosive such as an air gun.

title: SOVEREIGN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW YORK CITY TRADITION OF SHEDDING LIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: Healing Their Own
description: The State Health Commissioner, Dr. David Axelrod, who has a reputation for integrity, said the other day in a reasoned speech that misconduct, impairment and incompetence among physicians in New York were more widespread that generally believed. The reason the public doesn't know about this, he said, is that hospitals, doctors and others in the medical community are reluctant to bring complaints against their colleagues and that, as a result, ''a great deal of medical misconduct is going unreported.''

title: OPPOSITION BLOCKS RULES ON LOBBYING
description: The Reagan Administration, facing strong opposition from across the political spectrum, has temporarily withdrawn proposed rules designed to limit the use of Government funds for lobbying.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Gary Danielson, a Detroit Lions quarterback, has turned down an offer from the Arizona Wranglers of the U.S.F.L. in favor of one from the Lions. But according to Coach Monte Clark, Danielson may be traded. ... Mercury Morris, the former Miami Dolphins running back, lost a bid to remain in the Dade County Jail pending his appeal of a 20-year sentence for cocaine trafficking. He was ordered transferred to a Florida state prison.

title: NEIGHBORS FAVOR A LANDLORD INSPUTE IN BOROUGH PARK
description: The demise of a 600-unit apartment complex in Brooklyn has pitted the 30 remaining tenants against the surrounding community as well as the landlord in a dispute over the landlord's efforts to empty the buildings.

title: Senator Audrey P. Beck Of Connecticut Is Dead
description: State Senator Audrey P. Beck, an expert on state fiscal matters, was found dead today in a wooded area of Willington in eastern Connecticut. She was 51 years old.

description: Victor Chapin, vice president of John Schaffner Associates, a literary agency, and a former actor and author, died of a heart attack on March 4 in his Manhattan home. He was 64 years old.

title: 3 SALVADORANS ARE HELD IN KILLING
description: El Salvador's Defense Minister announced today that three soldiers had been arrested and handed over to civilian authorities as a result of an investigation into the shooting of a 21-year-old American citizen.

title: Dr. Mary Sherfey, Psychiatrist And an Authority on Sexuality
description: Dr. Mary Jane Sherfey, a psychiatrist and writer on female sexuality, died of a heart attack Feb. 20 at her home in Rusk, Tex. She was 65 years old.

title: 31 Hurt in Japan Air Crash
description: A twin turbo-prop airliner landing in light snow on Hokkaido island crashed short of the runway and split in two today, injuring 31 people, the police said. There were 47 passengers and seven crew members aboard.

title: QUADREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
REAGAN PRAISES ACTION ON SOCIAL SECURITY BILL
description: President Reagan commended Congress today for its swift action on legislation to shore up Social Security and said he hoped to sign a bill before April 3.

title: A SPRINGTIME SPORT
description: Sports of The Times

title: S.M.U. Is Subject Of New Inquiry
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has notified Southern Methodist University, whose two-year football probation expired at the end of last season, that it will be subject to a preliminary investigation into further potential wrongdoing in its football recruiting.

title: DR. MARY C. VIERNSTEIN
description: Dr. Mary Cowan Viernstein, a psychologist at Johns Hopkins University Hospital in Baltimore, died Wednesday of peritonitis at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 48 years old and had homes in Manhattan, East Hampton, L.I., and Baltimore.

title: 'TRENCHCOAT,' A COMEDY
description: Margot Kidder plays a gumshoe in the Sam Spade mold in ''Trenchcoat,'' which opened yesterday at the National and other theaters. As turnabouts go, this one works better than might be expected. Miss Kidder is smart and snappy in the role of Mickey Raymond, whose father wanted a boy and whose usual job is that of a court stenographer. The film follows her to Malta for a two-week vacation, during which she plans to try her hand at writing a detective novel. ''Malta Wants Me Dead,'' it's going to be called.

title: OPEC Still Divided On Output Quotas
description: OPEC's struggle to reach an agreement on oil production ceilings remained mired in differences today. But there was new evidence that most of the 13 member countries were in agreement on a price cut of $5 a barrel.

title: BY CHARLES AUSTIN
description: Officials of the National Association of Evangelicals said yesterday that evangelical Christians meeting in Orlando, Fla., this week were too divided on the question of a nuclear freeze to pass a resolution on the topic, despite President Reagan's strongly worded speech to the group.

title: N.B.A. Pledges A Firm Stance
description: The National Basketball Association's Board of Governors, meeting for the first time since the players set an April 2 strike deadline, voted unanimously today to reject any contract settlement that would not alleviate what it called the league's ''serious financial problems.''

title: FIRST CITY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $3.1 million...C-Including an extraordinary gain of $11.7 million and a gain of $33.3 million on the sale of Bache Group Inc stake

title: SOTHEBY'S BOARD DECIDES TO RESIST TAKEOVER BID
description: Sotheby Parke Bernet, the world's largest auction house, which lost money last year for the first time in decades, is girding for a takeover battle that its officials expect to begin later this month.

title: REAGAN MAKES COUNTERATTACK IN E.P.A. FIGHT
description: President Reagan today criticized what he called ''unfounded allegations'' of Administration mismanagement of the environment and assailed ''environmental extremism'' and lobbyists.

title: Harley Davidson
description: The Japanese International Trade and Industry Ministry is considering plans to extend financial and technical help to the ailing Harley Davidson Motor Company of the United States, ministry sources said. The plans are being considered in an attempt to avoid proposed United States measures to raise import tariffs on Japanese motorcycles with large engines, they said.

title: Article 027271 -- No Title
description: An error at a Social Security office in Baltimore has meant that nearly $88 million in wages paid to Nebraska's 10,000 state employees in 1980 have not been posted to their pension accounts.

title: 1. RETHINKS LANDMARKS
description: New York City's landmarks preservation law should be reformed to restore a better balance between economic development and preservation goals. I say this with some appreciation of the importance of both goals to the life of the city. My firm prosecuted the successful hardship proceeding involving the right to demolish a designated landmark, the Mount Neboh Synagogue, and represents Fisher Brothers, the developer who has proposed a new structure to replace Lever House. However, I declined to represent a potential developer of the proposed office building on the landmarked St. Bartholomew's Church site.

title: Boutique Owner Stabbed to Death
description: The owner of Arabella's Boutique in Greenwich Village was stabbed to death yesterday during an apparent robbery, the police said. Police officers responding to a radio call of a robbery in progress found the victim, Roberta Kaplan, in the shop at 135 West Third Street, near the Avenue of the Americas, at about 1 P.M.

title: MAGNETIC CARS AREN'T WHAT SUBWAYS NEED
description: To the Editor:

title: MARTINS SEEN SUCCEEDING BALANCHINE
description: As George Balanchine enters his fifth month of serious illness in Roosevelt Hospital, the company he co-founded, the New York City Ballet, is expected to decide shortly on naming his successor as artistic director.

title: Canadian Jobless Up
description: The Canadian seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose to 12.5 percent in February, from 12.4 percent in January and 8.9 percent in February 1982, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today. The February rate compares with a record 12.8 percent in December.

title: Letter: On Medical Costs; Let Health Consumers Choose
description: To the Editor:

title: Lightning Blamed In Fire And Blackout in Dover
description: A two-hour blackout affecting about 90 percent of the capital city tonight and a three-alarm fire that damaged a natural gas distribution plant, were caused by lightning, officials said.

title: RANGEL ENJOYING NEW SWAY IN HOUSE
description: At dawn the other day, Representative Charles B. Rangel boarded an International Telephone and Telegraph corporate aircraft at Dulles Airport and flew to North Carolina to deliver a speech on interest rates.

title: Tenn.-Chattanooga 77 Western Carolina 75
description: Willie White scored 31 points to lead Tennessee-Chattanooga (25-3) to an overtime victory in a semifinal game of the Southern Conference tournament.

title: Peete's Move Explained
description: Calvin Peete's lawyer said today that the reason for the golfer's sudden withdrawal from the Honda Inverrary Classic last Friday was that he was being harassed by a process server.

description: B-Net income; results for the latest yr reflect a net writeoff of nearly $2 million an adjustment in the carrying value of an office furniture plant which has been for sale and a decision to close manufacturing facilities in York, PA

title: THE ISRAELI FOREIGN MINISTER IS IN U.S. WITH 'NEW IDEAS'
description: Israel's Foreign Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, flew into Washington today for high-level talks bearing what Israeli officials said were ''new ideas'' for the deadlocked negotiations on the withdrawal of foreign forces from Lebanon, which a high American official said were nearing ''a point of decision.''

title: A 5-NATION VENTURE TO BUILD JET ENGINE
description: Industrial companies from five nations today announced the formation of a corporation to develop a line of jet engines. The engines would be for use in a 150-seat airliner currently in the design stages.

description: B-Including tax credits of $18,000 for the qr and $63,000 for the yr...C-Net income after an extraordinary tax charge of $16,000

title: SHARP RANGERS HALTED BY SUPERB GOALIE
description: Tonight the Rangers played their best game in weeks, perhaps in months, yet they lost to the Edmonton Oilers, 3-1.

title: 15 Seized in Sicily Protest
description: Italian police arrested 15 demonstrators today, including 12 foreign women, who tried to block entry to the Comiso air base where NATO plans to deploy low-flying weapons, known as cruise missiles, next year, police sources said. The protesters were charged with holding an unauthorized demonstration and obstruction after they lay down in the road early this morning in an effort to prevent workers from reaching the base.

title: 1 Detroit Complex
description: The Renaissance Center hotel, office and store complex on Detroit's riverfront has won final approval for a financial rescue plan. The directors of the Ford Motor Company approved an agreement allowing lenders to become majority owners of the complex in return for erasing a $220 million mortgage and assuming another $13 million in liabilities.

title: British Steel Chief Seeks Link in U.S.
description: Ian MacGregor, chairman of the British Steel Corporation, confirmed he is trying to establish ''a closer relationship with a steel producer in the United States,'' according to a British Broadcasting Corporation report. He was reported as saying in Glasgow that such a move would help to guarantee employment at Scotland's Ravenscraig integrated steel plant.

title: No Headline
description: Tool Import Limit Urged

title: Miss Petito Plans Wedding in April
description: Margaret Rose Petito, an account executive with WABC Radio in New York, and Thomas MacKay Belden, an assistant treasurer with the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, plan to be married April 30.

title: THE FARM SURPLUS YIELDS A PECK OF TRADE FRICTION
description: Under pressure from a free-spending farm lobby, the Reagan Administration and Congress have been struggling to find some way to sell this country's grain and dairy surpluses abroad without risking a full-scale trade war with the European Economic Community.

title: Copenhagen
description: To the Editor: It was interesting to read the article by Fletcher Knebel on Copenhagen (Travel, Feb. 13), especially since my family and I have spent the last 20 summers in the Danish capital and its environs. It is indeed a ''cozy'' country.

title: Elizabeth M. Crawford To Marry in Late May
description: Mr. and Mrs. David M. Crawford of Easton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Margaret Crawford, to Gregg K. Spencer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Baisel E. Spencer of Eugene, Ore. The wedding is to be in late May.

title: Judge Delays Linking Draft And Tuition Aid
description: There was a certain economy of action and purpose last year when Congress passed, and the President signed, a law requiring male students who apply for Federal tuition aid to disclose whether they had registered for the draft, and prohibiting aid to students who had not. At one stroke the Administration addressed two goals - restricting education aid and enhancing military preparedness.

title: DAVIS TRIAL JURY TO SET AWARD
description: It took Al Davis two years and two trials to move his Raiders from Oakland to Los Angeles and the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum. He was finally able to do so after a six-member jury in Los Angeles decided last May that the National Football League had violated antitrust laws by preventing the team from moving.

title: I.B. SINGER AS TRAVELER
description: Israel Shenker's most recent book is ''In the Footsteps of Boswell and Johnson.'' ISRAEL SHENKER talks to I. B. SINGER

title: Killer of Five Gets Life Terms
description: Maris Karklins, who called himself a ''hit man for God'' in a taped confession, was sentenced Friday to five life terms in prison for killing a rural family.

title: Tax Rebellion
description: At first there were grumbles in Hardenburgh, N.Y., as tax-exempt groups began buying scenic Catskill Mountain tracts. Soon more than half the property in the town was tax-exempt, and the 236 residents were reeling under an unwieldy tax burden.

title:
FORUM;
A PLEA FOR IMMEDIATE WRITE-OFFS
description: THE average American business that wants to modernize its m anufacturing process is faced with a discouraging array of d isincentives. These disincentives - including the rate of d epreciation - are the result of a woeful lack of foresight by g overnment over the past 20 years.

title: MAKING MUSIC FOR CUNNINGHAM
description: Music and dance have always been allies but, over the centuries, they have been allied in many different ways. One of the most unusual alliances is that of John Cage, the composer, and Merce Cunningham, the choreographer, who this season are celebrating their 40th year of collaboration.

title: A TAX ON HEALTH IUNSURANCE IS THE WRONG REMEDY
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Question:My wife and I are planning a driving trip through England, Scotland and Wales for two to three weeks this August. Is there any organization that provides routing services for driving through foreign countries, and that might also provide help in estimating driving times and distances? - T.G.S., Cherry Hill, N.J. Answer:The American Automobile Association, which is composed of local clubs that vary in services and membership fees ($13 to $47 a year) can offer the services you want through its reciprocal agreements with British and European automobile clubs.

title: SPIRIT OF THE DANCE CAPTURED ON CANVAS
description: SCULPTURE paintings by Dorothy Gillespie are about as near in spirit to dancing as art could possibly be. A sizable installation of the artist's recent work at Adelphi University's Alumni House offers a good understanding of her attempt to create an art that dwells on movement and gives the appearance of being vibrantly alive.

title: Halas Back in Hospital
description: George Halas, the 88-year-old owner of the Chicago Bears and one of the founders of the National Football League, has been readmitted to Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago for treatment of an undisclosed ailment.

title: THE AMERICAN PRIORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW TO CHOOSE A WILDERNESS CAMP
description: Thousands of youngsters from the New York area will explore the wilderness this summer, trading sidewalks and subways for footpaths, pedals, paddles and saddles. While there is an abundance of camps and trips for those with a taste for adventure, parents, too, may find themselves on unfamiliar territory in helping their children choose the right program.

title: GRAND NATIONALS BRIDGE PLAY MARKED BY CLOSE COMPETITION
description: Some of the lowest scoring in the history of national bridge championships marked the semifinal stage of the Grand National Pair Championship here Friday.

title: Stephen Vincent Mara Wed to Nancy Cassidy
description: Nancy Ellen Cassidy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Cassidy of Larchmont Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stephen Vincent Mara, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wellington T. Mara of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Kenneth Moore performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of SS. John and Paul in Larchmont.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: PHOTOGRAPHY For the last three years Len Jenshel has pursued, like the Great Jay Gatsby, his own peculiar passion amidst the mansions and ''cottages'' of the very, very rich. However, Mr. Jenshel has a more detached view of the beauty to be found there than did F. Scott Fitzgerald's classic overreacher.

title: A BELGIAN ORCHESTRA AND FIVE SOLOISTS ARE RECITALISTS
description: The Belgian chamber orchestra I Fiamminghi, who made their New York debut at Town Hall early Sunday afternoon, combine a translucent sonic beauty with a strict sense of ensemble discipline, despite the fact that they play without conductor. Although the group has a musical director - the violinist Rudolf Werthen -on stage, the 11 performers give the impression of an autonomous and self-motivated collective.

title: RETURN TO SHANGRI-LA
description: Present and former correspondents of The Times were asked to select places they would like to return to for a vacation, and places they have never been to but have longed to visit. Here are their choices.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN SMALL BUSINESS;
IN JOBS, SMALL IS BEAUTIFUL
description: How many new jobs are created by small business? A new study, completed last month by the Brookings Institution, indicates that businesses with fewer than 100 employees created 51 percent of the nation's new jobs between 1976 and 1980.

title: HOSPITAL EX-AIDE ACCUSED
description: JERSEY CITY THE Newark office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation is reviewing financial records of the debt-ridden Jersey City Medical Center to determine whether any of its employees were involved in illegally diverting nearly $1 million.

title: DON'T EVER ASK AN ACTOR TO EXPLAIN
description: Perhaps it's best not to probe. There are those among us, myself included, who are unable to resist plowing through every kind of theatrical memoir, from full-scale biography to as-told-to pasteup jobs, looking for a little clue that will help explain how an actor or a director arrived at a particular detail we very much liked. These books, as you know, come out 10 to a week, and they are positively crammed with mentions of kindly friends, with the guest lists of dinner parties, even with contractual terms and gloating accounts of how much overtime the male star collected because his leading lady was always late.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: AKEY element in New Jersey's solution to the hazardous-waste disposal problem - siting new treatment and incineration plants - has itself become a problem.

title: U.S. OFFERS ISRAEL PLAN ON WAR DATA
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has proposed a new arrangement with Israel to share intelligence findings from the war in Lebanon, according to Reagan Administration officials. Last month Mr. Weinberger rejected a proposal by Israel to share the information.

title: ON THE ROCK, SPAIN LOOKS NICE - BUT JUST FOR A VISIT
description: The border between Spain and Gibraltar is an unprepossessing, 70-yard-wide strip of tarmac, customs sheds and wire-mesh fences, but to the residents of the Rock it is a divide between everything that is decent, clean and safe and the great unknown.

title: COURT TAKES THE GLOW OFF THE TENTH AMENDMENT
description: The Tenth Amendment was the constitutional frog that turned into a prince. A kiss by the Supreme Court, in the form of a 5-to-4 decision called National League of Cities v. Usery, lifted the amendment from decades of scorn and neglect in 1976 and armed it for battle in the service of states' rights. The case eventually became the battle standard of the ''new federalism.''

title: WHEN MY MOTHER BECAME MY CHILD
description: ILOOK down on the small head against the pillow, the slender little body that barely lifts the blankets, the one hand sticking out that clutches a doll by the leg.

title: 11 Are Questioned In Dormitory Fires
description: Eleven people were questioned today for leads to the arsonist who has touched off six fires at a university dormitory here.

title: Care for Elderly: Further Aspects
description: ''Agency for Elderly in Dispute on Funds'' (Feb. 20) was a wellbalanced article, and we appreciate the author's objectivity. However, there are some important aspects that did not surface.

title: 'THREE MUSKETEERS'
description: Rudolf Friml's musical ''You're in Love'' had its premiere at the Hartman Theater (then the Stamford Theater) in November 1916. Tickets were 50 cents to $2 and the show was advertised locally for its ''snappy songs and pretty girls.''

title: A TAX ON HEALTH BENEFITS IS THE WRONG REMEDY
description: To the Editor:

title: ANTIQUES
description: SHEDDING LIGHT ON A VIENNESE DESIGNER Throughout the decade-long revival of the Wiener Werkstatte, the Vienna workshop that produced early 20th century modern designs from 1903 into the 1930's, Koloman Moser's work has been overshadowed by that of the workshop's other co-founder, Josef Hoffmann. Virtually unknown outside Austria to all save specialists and collectors of the style, Moser's geometric and curvilinear design contributions, which ended with his departure from the workshop in 1907, may have been more important than has been realized.

title: Los Alamos
description: To the Editor:

title: A FANCY BOTH BITTER AND SWEET
description: No matter how other eating habits fluctuate, the public appetite for chocolate always seems insatiable. And, as is the case here, one good recipe often begets another.

title: No Headline
description: Lendl Gains Final; Gerulaitis Defeated

title: REVLOUTION AND THE INTELLECTUAL IN LATIN AMERICA
description: On his way from Mexico City to Stockholm to receive the 1982 Nobel Prize in Literature, and again on the way back, Gabriel Garcia Marquez stopped over in Cuba to see his close friend and political mentor, Fidel Castro. The Colombian novelist is a frequent traveler to Havana, but these two visits took on special significance: He was emphasizing his political identification with Cuba at the moment of his greatest literary glory.

title: Aide Says Military Cuts Could Imperil Security
description: William P. Clark, President Reagan's national security adviser, has told former Cabinet officers and business leaders who have been calling for less military spending that their proposal could jeopardize national security.

title: Devils Win at Montreal
description: Jeff Larmer and Steve Tambellini scored two goals apiece tonight, sparking the Devils to only their third victory in their last 18 games, a 7-3 decision over the Montreal Canadiens.

title: Miss Spoor Will Marry On Aug. 20
description: Mr. and Mrs. T. Richard Spoor of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Jeffersonville, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Stephanie Field Spoor, to Peter Narvesen Jennings, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Burton Jennings of Springfield, Vt., and Lake Sunapee, N.H. An Aug. 20 wedding is planned.

title: 'BABY-SITTING' OF MENTALLY ILL IS TERMED COSTLY
description: A new study says a ''baby-sitting'' requirement at many hospitals is costing the state more than $1 million a year and may be discouraging timely medical treatment for patients from New York State mental institutions.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE BRANDEIS/FRANKFURTER CONNECTION: The Secret Political Activities of Two Supreme Court Justices. By Bruce Allen Murphy. (Doubleday/ Anchor, $12.95.) Well researched but frequently melodramatic, this study begins by showing how Justice Louis D. Brandeis secretly kept the Harvard Law School professor Felix Frankfurter on retainer for 20 years so that Frankfurter might advance causes that Brandeis couldn't advocate from the bench, and it ends by raising the question of what standards of behavior we should expect Supreme Court Justices to adhere to. Our reviewer, Arthur Schlesinger Jr., called it valuable, fascinating and somewhat schizophrenic.

title: IN JERSEY, 400 MOURN A REPORTER SLAIN IN SALVADOR
description: More than 400 relatives, friends and neighbors gathered at a memorial service today for John J. Sullivan Jr., a freelance journalist who disappeared more than two years ago while on assignment in El Salvador.

title: Andrew J. Stein Marries Lawyer
description: Lynn Forester, an associate with the New York law firm of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett, was married yesterday to Andrew J. Stein, Borough President of Manhattan. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony in his study at Temple Emanu-El.

title: ALASKA'S TEEMING WILDLIFE
