description: BARRY LOPEZ, the author of ''Winter Count'' and ''Of Wolves and Men'' (Scribner's), is working on a book about the Arctic.

title: Flynn Gold Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. David L. Gold of Mahwah, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Flynn Gold, to Robert Lloyd Neilson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Neilson of Huntington Beach, Calif.

title: ST. PATRICK'S PLUS 3
description: Tommy Makem and Liam Clancy, the Irish folk singers, will present a concert next Sunday evening - St. Patrick's Day plus three - in Clifton.

title: BY MALACHI MARTIN
description: The heavy curtains of far-distant time part upon an unlikely stage whose name is Ur. Today, Ur is a desert scrubland with miserable ruins jutting from terrain of sand and mud. It is about 120 miles northwest of the Persian Gulf, in the country we now call Iraq. Unlikely or not, however, very nearly 40 centuries ago, here began a journey that transcended history, and whose arc etched a crescent of hope and faith so indelibly that it determined the motive and course of events for centuries down to this day and far beyond the borders of the nations that were in its path - places we know as Iraq, Turkey, Syria, Lebanon, Israel, Egypt, Jordan.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Spotlight on First Lady ''It's going to be fun,'' Nancy Reagan told aides the other day before videotaping a guest-starring appearance, as herself, on the episode of NBC's ''Diff'rent Strokes'' that will be broadcast Saturday evening at 8.

title: THE DOUBLE FIRE
description: We've seen the brains blown from the skull of a Vietnamese and a truck overturn near the Washington Monument when its driver got a bullet in his head. We've seen the sad man leap and the drowning man lose hold of the life preserver. And last week, television viewers in Jacksonville, Ala., saw a drunken man set fire to himself. The scenes were alike in their horror, but the last was different in one particular. Those who filmed that blaze were not just witnesses to tragedy, they were also its stage managers.

title: ANY AIRPORT IN A STORM
description: AVERY CORMAN is the author of the novels ''Oh, God!,'' ''Kramer vs. Kramer'' and ''The Old Neighborhood.''

title: Deborah S. Oppenberg Plans August Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Oppenberg of Syosset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Sue Oppenberg, to Richard Lee @Koenigsberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Koenigsberg of Lido Beach, L.I.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Los Angeles last Sunday incorrectly described the ef- fect of high waves on the Malibu home of Robert Webber, an actor. The home was damaged.

title: FOR NEW PACIFIC NATION, A THIRD-WORLD ROLE
description: Vanuatu, a string of lush volcanic islands, this week became the first of the newly independent Pacific island nations to join the third-world organization whose conference ended here today.

title: Caroline P. Kurtz Planning to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Martin Kurtz of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Paula Kurtz, to Michael Keith Schiffman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Schiffman of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for Aug. 7.

title: Mary-Jane Moskowitz Plans Wedding in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman D. Moskowitz of Port Washington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary-Jane Moskowitz, to Henry M. Dachowitz, son of Rabbi Pincus Dachowitz of Brooklyn and the late Seyma Sacksner Dachowitz. A May wedding is planned.

title: SEASON BEGINS FOR THEATER APPRENTICES
description: SUSAN WILLIAMS had to wade through the snow in front of the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam to help put up the posters announcing the shows for the theater's upcoming season. Miss Williams, who comes from Newtown and who graduated from Wesleyan University in 1980, recently began her job as press intern for Kay McGrath, the public relations director at the Opera House.

title: IF NOT SEQUELS, THEN PREQUELS
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders Win; 50th for Bossy
description: The Washington Capitals no longer look at the standings in late March, grimace, and book vacations for early April. They're going to the playoffs for the first time in their nine National Hockey League seasons.

title: A LAND WITHOUT SOLID GROUND
description: SALVADOR By Joan Didion. 108 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $12.95.

title:
ART;
A NEW BREED OF PRINTMAKERS
description: NEW ENGLAND and the Southwest are kindred places. In both regions nature is imposing and elemental, and the long history of each is entwined with a lot of romantic lore and myth. Thus it is fitting that the West should have come East for the Connecticut College Print Invitational, at the New London school's Cummings Arts Center (through Friday).

title: HUMANITIES GRANTS GET A NEW SYSTEM
description: William J. Bennett, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, has halted the practice of personally awarding unmonitored grants because, he said, they have ''the possibility of being misused.''

title: NUCLEAR PLANTS TOLD TO TEST SYSTEMS FOR SAFETY
description: For the second time in two weeks, the Government is telling nuclear power plants around the country to test for a possible failure in their safety systems after breakdowns at reactors in California and New Jersey.

title: THEATER: 'STARBURN,' PUNK ROCK
description: As playwright and director, Rosalyn Drexler and John Vaccaro are not known for their self-restraint, but even for this pair the musical ''Starburn'' could be considered excessive. The show at Theater for the New City is a punk-rock musical about a plot to kill and dismember a critic. Taking place in various times and states of mind, the work deals with, among other things, tranvestitism, sadomasochism and a Martian invasion. Some of the evening is enjoyable, but it helps to be tuned in to this patented brand of rough-house Ridiculous theater.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
ARE YOUR READY FOR SPRING?
description: EVERY year at this time, the word ''resurrection'' seems so fitting. What a fresh chance we're given as our wintry decline is stemmed, flagging energy renewed, spirit restored. I've felt it as far back as memory serves me, but only recently with such fervor. In these vintage years the wine of life has a fuller taste. I savor it eagerly.

title: SOME SUGGESTIONS FOR ENRICHING YOUR TRIP
description: In the end, what is most important of all is figuring out what you want to do. Here are a few dicta, to be freely rejected, offered mainly as food for thought. Most of these are designed to get you to talk to people, especially the sorts of people whom tourists don't usually seek out:

title: Capital Park Sleeping Upheld
description: A group's attempt to dramatize the plight of the homeless by sleeping overnight in a park facing the White House has been upheld by a Federal appeals court as an exercise of free speech.

title: ROLAND P. BEATTIE
description: Roland P. Beattie, retired president of Field & Beattie, a defunct New York City commercial illustration concern, died Friday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J., He was 85 years old and lived in Murray Hill, N.J.

title: A SENSE OF MISSION IN FAMILY PLANNING
description: ONE day in the mid-60's, on a trip to Chile, Mary Lindsay paid a visit to a major hospital in Santiago. ''One-third of the beds were taken up with botched abortions,'' she said. ''That was probably the single thing that pushed me toward thinking I'd better push for this.''

title: RESILIENT COMMUTERS COPE AND ADAPT
description: COMMUTERS in the county who have long coped with rail service of varying conditions learned quickly last week, not without discomfort, to cope with similarly varied bus and highway conditions. By midweek, many of the 85,000 rail riders had established new patterns.

title: ERNST MAYER, AN ORNITHOLOGIST, GETS LINNAEAN SOCIETY MEDAL
description: Ernst Mayr, professor of zoology emeritus at Harvard University's Museum of Comparative Zoology, an internationally known ornithologist, has been awarded the first Eugene Eisenmann Medal for Excellence in Ornithology by the Linnaean Society of New York.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
description: After pleading guilty to conspiracy in the sale of 30,000 pounds of marijuana in metropolitan New York, Eleonore B. Kessler of Melville, L.I., was sentenced in May 1982 to a year in prison and the largest fine in Nassau County's history - $1 million.

title: Without Trains, The Way to Go Takes Thought
description: Commuters in the metropolitan area usually just feel as if they have two strikes against them. Last week they really did. More than 600 Metro-North conductors and trainmen walked off their jobs before the Monday morning rush, joining 600 fellow members of the United Transportation Union who struck N.J. Transit the week before.

title: No Headline
description: Robert Morris Defeats L.I.U.

title: FREE-TRADE ISSUE HOLDS UP ISRAELI-LEBANESE TALKS
description: Negotiators say the most important issue holding up an agreement between Israel and Lebanon is not the question of specific security arrangements along their joint border, but whether that border will be open to free trade.

title: GULOTTA ADS STIR DEBATE
description: THE Hempstead Development Authority is sponsoring a $120,000 television advertising campaign that is supposed to promote Hempstead as a good place to do business.

title: ARTICLE ON KEARNY DRAWS CRITICISM
description: As an employee with 43 years of service with Western Electric, I feel obliged to correct the record.

title: How Thin the State Payroll?
description: To keep his proposed budget from running into the red, Governor Cuomo sent out pink slips to 7,587 state employees last week. But even before the workers were cut from the payroll, Mr. Cuomo's aides and legislative leaders were talking about how many of them could be put back on.

title: Schmidt's Knee Healing
description: Mike Schmidt, the third baseman of the Philadelphia Phillies, can start practicing again within a week, said Dr. Phillip Marone, who performed arthroscopic surgery on Schmidt's right knee last Monday.

title: D.H. Johnson Is Wed To Kathryn Halbower
description: Kathryn Halbower, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. David Halbower Jr. of Fort Worth, Texas, was married in Manhattan yesterday to David Harrover Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. David O. Johnson of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. John Wade Payne performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Christian Church.

title: FOREIGN CARS: GOOD SENSE BREAKS DOWN
description: WHILE driving along the Cross Westchester Expressway in our neat little foreign car, my wife stepped on the brake pedal, which glided smoothly down to the floorboard without altering in any way the speed of the car. Swerving to avoid a looming disaster, she frantically pumped the pedal, coaxing the car to safety. The master hydraulic brake cylinder had gone after 45,000 miles. The dual brake system that was supposed to prevent brake failure had evidently gone with it.

title: WHERE EAST MEETS WEST
description: The region within 50 air miles of the city of Nagasaki - half the size of Connecticut but blessed with more than 700 islands and a shoreline of 2,500 miles - is not only unsurpassed to my mind in its varieties of natural beauty, but also rich in a history common to both Japan and the West. As the gateway through which both Chinese culture and Western civilization were introduced into Japan, Nagasaki became the window to the outside world: Soon after Japan was discovered by European explorers in 1543, a long procession of missionaries and traders appeared from the West, and by the early 17th century the Portuguese, Dutch, British and Russians had established trading firms and settlements on the hills overlooking Nagasaki Harbor. The entire area was so marked long ago by alien dress, food, language, architecture, religions and customs that today it retains many vestiges of this early contact with foreigners.

title: Sally Davies Wed To A.M. Halsey
description: Sally Miller Davies, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Edward Davies of Atlanta, and Andrew March Halsey, son of Mr and Mrs. Ralph Wetmore Halsey Jr. of New Haven and Noank, Conn., were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents in Noank. The Rev. R. Francis Johnson, an Episcopal priest and dean of faculty at Connecticut College, of which the couple are graduates, performed the ceremony.

title: SOVIET IS MAKING MORE USE OF CAM RANH BAY
description: American naval officers say the Vietnamese port of Cam Ranh Bay, which was built up by the United States during the Vietnam War, has become a fulltime naval operating base for the Soviet Pacific Fleet.

title: SCHOOLS LURE MIGRANT CHILDREN
description: MULLICA TOWNSHIP PICTURE postcards from Puerto Rico brighten the walls of the trailer behind the Elwood primary-middle school here in the heart of the Pine Barrens. The cards and a constant stream of men and women coming to the trailer are evidence that more and more migrant farm workers in New Jersey are choosing to have their children go to school, even if it means forgoing the money they could get by having them work in the fields.

title: SENATE REMAINS VIDEO-SHY
description: WASHINGTON THE Senate, which appeared for a while to be on the verge of tiptoeing into the electronic age, is deadlocked again on the question of whether to televise its proceedings.

title: 19 Food Outlets Cited by City As Violators of Sanitary Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 19 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, the department named three that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and five closed for failing to do so.

title: MERCHANTS OPPOSE THRIFT SHOP IN CONNECTICUT CITY
description: In this small industrial city, saddled with the highest unemployment rate in the state, everyone agrees something is amiss on Main Street. What no one agrees on is whether a Salvation Army thrift store is the solution or more of a problem.

title: A SHARPER EYE; On Air Traffic
description: When the Federal Aviation Administration last week unveiled a new plan for analyzing and correcting air traffic control errors, it looked like a pre-emptive strike. The announcement came within a week of a National Transportation Safety Board report that, Government sources said, will urge the F.A.A. to do just what it said it would.

title: Miss Wells Wed To W.W. Martin
description: Aileen Elizabeth Wells, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald A. Wells of Old Lyme, Conn., was married in New York yesterday to William Wesley Martin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wesley W. Martin of New York. The Rev. Andrew Mullins, assisted by the Rev. Charles H. Griswold of Old Lyme, performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Church.

title: CITY'S SANITATION CHIEF SAYS BUDGET CUTS MEAN DIRTIER STREETS
description: New York City's Sanitation Commissioner says his department will have to let the streets get dirtier in order to balance its budget. ''The so-called hidden or invisible cuts quickly affect service delivery,'' the Commissioner, Norman Steisel, told the City Council last week. He said he had cut street cleaning instead of vehicle maintenance, even though the effects of the latter would not have been immediately apparent.

title: STATIONS BECOME FOCUS OF REDEVELOPMENT
description: PASSENGERS on commuter railroads in the metropolitan area will see s ome new sights around their stations within the next three or four y ears - luxury hotels, apartment buildings, office blocks, retail c enters and modern transportation hubs for buses, taxis and l imousines as well as trains.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;
A BRUISED OPEC BATTLES IN BRITAIN
description: A fragmented OPEC again failed to agree on price cuts and production quotas. After a second weeklong round of talks in London, the Iranians were bickering with the Saudis who were bickering with the Nigerians who were bickering with everyone. But they seemed to be heading toward an ''understanding'' to knock down prices by $5 a barrel, to $29. Most analysts seemed confident the price would fall even further, giving recession-weary consumers what economists said would be tantamount to one swift and giant tax cut.

title: Equity Library
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Cross Acts On Blood Risk
description: When an infant developed a severe immune deficiency last year after getting blood transfusions from a man who had AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, alarm spread about the safety of blood bank supplies. Now, in response to a Public Health Service recommendation, the American Red Cross says it will tell groups at high risk of contracting AIDS that they should not donate blood at all.

title: CRIME
description: In THE CONDUCT OF MAJOR MAXIM (Viking, $14.75) the British author and ex-R.A.F. flier Gavin Lyall takes his hero, Harry Maxim (who made his first appearance in ''The Secret Servant''), through a series of adventures that has him working for British intelligence even though he nominally has a desk job at 10 Downing Street. It is an absorbing and well-written book. Mr. Lyall has respect for language and for dialogue, much of which is spiced with upper-class wit or languid irony. There are no cliches. Characters are carefully shaped; plotting is logically worked out; backgrounds are authentic.

title: Funds Rise for Conservation
description: State, county and municipal governments appropriated $185.6 million, a record, for soil and water conservation in the current fiscal year, the Agriculture Department's Soil Conservation Service says. The figure reflects a $16 million increase over the fiscal year 1982, the agency said. The funds are being used primarily to complete soil surveys, finance conservation and flood prevention projects and pay for conservation district operations.

title: APPROVAL IS SEEN FOR NONPRESCRIPTIVE CONTRACEPTIVE
description: The Food and Drug Administration is soon expected to approve a new nonprescription contraceptive for women. The new product is a soft, disposable polyurethane sponge permeated with a spermicide. It does not have to be fitted by a physician, and one size can be used by all women.

title:
GARDENING;
CONTAINER-GROWTH PLANTS MAY BE TRICKY
description: JUST how quickly we will be able to go about the business of spring planting will depend on the weather during the remaining weeks of March. The month came in pretty much like a lamb, but who can tell whether it will remain that way or turn leonine as the days go by. Even the television weathermen have been hedging on their forecasts after experiencing this winter's unusual weather.

title: FIRE: IT CAN HAPPEN TO YOU
description: EVERY year, nearly 8,000 Americans succumb to the deadly effects of fire. Untold thousands of others incur injuries ranging from minor to catastrophic. Lives are ended or, at the very least, disrupted. The litany of pain and suffering goes on and on.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, exhibition, at St. Petersburg, Fla. Ed Lynch, who pitched long relief and short relief for the Mets last season, is trying to break into the starting rotation and will start. (Radio -WHN AM, 1050; 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Montreal Expos, exhibition, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. (Radio - WABC, 770; 1:30 P.M.) Basketball Nets vs. Portland Trail Blazers, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:05 P.M. This is Portland's only visit to the Meadowlands this season. (Television -SportsChannel, 7 P.M. Radio - WVNJ AM, 620; 7 P.M.) Knicks vs. Celtics, at Boston. For the first time since the 1977-78 season, the Knicks have beaten the Celtics twice in the same season. (Television - Channel 9, 1 P.M.) College Playoffs: Atlantic Coast Conference championship, at Atlanta (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M. and ESPN 10 P.M. tape delayed). Metro Conference championship, at Cincinnati (Television - Channel 2, noon). Southeastern Conference championship, at Birmingham, Ala. (Television - Channel 2, 2 P.M.) High School: Public Schools Athletic League championship at St. John's Alumni Hall, Union Turnpike off Utopia Parkway, Jamaica, Queens. Division A game at 3 P.M., Alexander Hamilton vs. Springfield Gardens. Hamilton was the champion two years ago. Springfield Gardens has never been in a final before. Printing, the only undefeated team in the city, meets Walton for the boys' B title at 11 A.M. The girls' title game will be played at 1 P.M., between John F. Kennedy and August Martin.

title: Harvard Captures Title
description: Harvard outhustled Providence tonight and defeated the Friars, 4-1, for the Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I championship before 12,049 at Boston Garden. It was Harvard's third Eastern title but the first since 1971.

title: K.P. Lonesome Wed To Robyn D. Mahone
description: Robyn Dale Mahone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lee Mahone of the Bronx, was married yesterday to Keven Pierre Lonesome, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur C. Lonesome, also of the Bronx. The Rev. Jeffrey Merkel performed the ceremony at Trinity Evangelical Lutheran Church in New York.

title: E.P.A. INQUIRIES CENTER ON FOUR ISSUES
description: As Congressional subcommittees press investigations of alleged wrongdoing at the Environmental Protection Agency, and as some begin inquiring into the actions of the Justice Department and the White House as well, they are centering on four main subjects.

title: FOR GOODWIN, JOY IS SCISSORS AND A NET
description: Billy Goodwin had no idea that winning the championship game of the Big East conference tournament would feel like this. There were 15 seconds to play, and St. John's was ahead of Boston College by 8 points, and Chris Mullin had just been fouled, and much of the sellout crowd at the Garden was already beginning its celebration of the team's first conference-tournament championship.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Extension Classes: A Springtime Array

title: A COMMON SADNESS
description: LETTERS FROM A FATHER AND OTHER POEMS By Mona Van Duyn. 63 pp. New York: Atheneum. Cloth, $11.95. Paper, $6.95.A GLASS FACE IN THE RAIN New Poems. By William Stafford. 126 pp. New York: Harper & Row. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $6.95.TRUE STORIES By Margaret Atwood. 103 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. Cloth, $13.50. Paper, $4.95.

title: PARIS: REVAMPED CLASSICS ENLIVEN THE FRENCH STAGE
Pamela Woodworth to Wed Professor
description: The engagement of Pamela Cheyney Woodworth to C. Christopher Maxwell has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Newell B. Woodworth of Princeton, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Peter Maxwell and Sarah Headly Maxwell, both of Philadelphia.

title: CARTER, IN ISRAEL, SAYS ARABS MOVE TOWARD PEACE
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that there had been ''a great move toward moderation'' in the Arab world in the last three years.

title: BOTH RIGHT AND LEFT PUT THEIR FAITH IN FIREPOWER
description: During his Central American tour, Pope John Paul II received the loudest ovations when he gave voice to the plight of the region's ''silent majority'' that is caught in the crossfire of political extremes. The Pope said answers must be found not through violence but through dialogue ''without outside interference.''

title: STATE TO OFFER PLAN ON OCEAN DUMPING
description: TRENTON OFFICIALS of the state's Department of Environmental Protection are preparing a comprehensive plan to phase out ocean dumping near shore. The department does not have direct jurisdiction over ocean dumping, which is within the purview of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. Even so, it is among those being sued by the National Wildlife Federation and a New Jersey affiliate for alleged failure to develop standards in the state for land-based alternatives to ocean dumping.

title: Moral Hunger
description: When Jacob Needleman, a professor of philosophy at San Francisco State, went to California to teach in 1962, he was struck by young people's interest in religious thought. ''I realized,'' he later wrote, ''that the moral vacuum of our culture'' was driving them to reach out for new ideas; he sensed ''a raw hunger for transcendence.''

title: ST. JOHN'S BEAT BOSTON COLLEGE IN FINAL, 85-77
description: The St. John's basketball players ''walked with kings'' in Madison Square Garden yesterday, according to their coach, Lou Carnesecca, because they won the Big East conference championship by beating Boston College, 85-77, and gained a record 27th victory this season.

title: HOLLYWOOD The film industry has always concentrated on movies that will attract the widest possible audience. But for the first time, many of the studios are thinking small. As a result, European and independent American filmmakers now have a better opportunity than ever before of having their movies viewed by an audience in this country.
description: Today, at a time when the average movie costs $11 million to make, another $6 million to market, and when it must sell $35 million worth of tickets to be profitable, studios are searching for additional sources of revenue by distributing movies they previously would have spurned. Thus, Columbia is the proud distributor of ''Parsifal,'' a four-and-a-half-hour movie version of the Richard Wagner opera, directed by the controversial West German Hans-Jurgen Syberberg. Twentieth Century-Fox is delighted that its ''Eating Raoul,'' a black comedy about cannibalism, has earned $2.5 million at 132 theaters. And United Artists spent only $400 to create the advertising materials for ''Lianna,'' a film about a wife who falls in love with a woman, which broke 11 house records in its first nine days at the Embassy 72d Street theater on Manhattan's Upper West Side.

title: INDIAN PAINTING AND SCULPTURE IN SOMERS
description: CONTEMPORARY art by or about Indians is hardly an unknown quantity. There are names such as Fritz Scholder's that have long been prominent in the Northeast, and there are galleries in the area that deal regularly in Indian work, if not so wholeheartedly as their counterparts who are nearer its sources in the West and Southwest. All the same, the art itself remains problematic and, for nonpartisan reviewers, as full of critical booby traps as that by any other ethnic group or political minority.

title: COUNTY SPECTACLE ABOUT TO BLOOM
description: THE Tricentennial Spring Garden and Flower Show, which its sponsors believe will be among the most beautiful celebrations of the county's 300th birthday, opens Thursday at the County Center in White Plains.

title: A NEW EXPRESSIONISM IS EMERGING IN DANCE
description: Oscar Wilde's remark that ''All art is at once surface and symbol'' would find little favor in the dance world in recent decades. The major thrust of American choreography, at least since the late 1950's, has been away from symbols and toward a formalist view that becomes, for want of better terms, dance for dance's sake.

title: STIPANOVICH, THE TURMOIL PAST, PLACES SUCCESS IN PERSPECTIVE
description: parlor owner, has lived an uncommon life. Stipanovich is a 21-year-old senior and basketball center who will lead the highly ranked Missouri Tigers into the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament this weekend. He lives alone in a one-bedroom apartment on the second floor of a building complex a short distance from the Missouri campus. It is an apartment decorated perhaps not much differently from the tradition of many college students, other than that there's an empty hanger hooked onto a vent near the ceiling for the convenience of the 6-foot-11 1/2-inch resident.

title: EASTERN AIRLINES AND MACHINISTS REACH AGREEMENT
description: A tentative agreement was reached Saturday night between representatives of Eastern Airlines and its largest union, the International Association of Machinists, averting a midnight strike, a Federal mediator said.

title: THE POET WHO CAME TO DINNER
description: ROBERT BROWNING A Life Within Life. By Donald Thomas. 334 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $18.75.

title: Talks on U.S. Bases In Greece Interrupted
description: There were indications today that negotiations on the status of four United States military bases in Greece may have become snagged.

title: STATE SEEKS TO CURB COMPULSIVE BETTING
description: TRENTON WITH nine casinos, four race tracks and lottery counters in neighborhood stores, the opportunity to gamble is within easy reach of everyone in New Jersey.

title: METRO-NORTH: PICKETS STAND FIRM ON UNITY
description: Lawrence Dee has been working on the railroad for 30 years. And to Mr. Dee, the strike he and other Metro-North trainmen and conductors are engaging in against the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is about that - work.

title: Wedding in June Is Being Planned By Joan Dineen
description: Mrs. James J. Dineen of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Joan Dineen, to Christopher Weld Gould, son of Dr. and Mrs. James W. Gould of Claremont, Calif., and Cotuit, Mass. Miss Dineen is a daughter also of the late Captain Dineen, who served with the Moore McCormack Lines.

title: TALKS ADVANCE ON WASTE CLEANUP
description: WHILE ground water contaminants are believed to be advancing toward public wells that serve 30,000 Uniondale residents, the State Attorney General's office is conducting negotiations with the Purex Corporation to clean up the site. In 1981, the state charged in a suit that Purex was allowing hazardous substances 2,400 times higher than the acceptable level for drinking water to contaminate the company's Mitchel Field location.

title: 28TH YEAR FOR MARCH OF IRISH IN YONKERS
description: YONKERS IF it doesn't rain today, then Father John Foley's prayers will have been answered. Each year, Father Foley, pastor of Christ the King Church in Yonkers, gives an invocation asking that the weather be fair for the yearly Yonkers St. Patrick's Day Parade. ''The big joke is that in 1977, when he was grand marshal of the parade, Father Foley promised us good weather,'' recalled James J. Landy, chairman of the parade committee. ''It poured. It was the worst weather day we ever had.''

title: HIJINKS DOWN UNDER
description: JUST RELATIONS By Rodney Hall. 502 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $16.75.

title: COMEDY DISKS ARE GOOD FOR A LAUGH
STATE CONSIDERS BIRTH- DEFECTS REGISTRY
description: POSSIBLY nothing haunts a mother-to-be more than the fear that her baby will not be normal. That fear becomes a nightmarish reality for 2 to 3 percent of the 96,000 New Jersey women who give birth each year.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A SERIES of pleasant surprises occurred recently in the life of Lewis Love, chairman of the science department at Great Neck South High School. First, he realized that the woman selected to be the first female astronaut, scheduled to go aloft in the next United States space trip, was Mary Cleave, a student of his in the early 60's.

title: MORE FREEDOM FOR THE F.B.I. CAUSES SOME CRITICS TO WORRY
description: Justice Department officials say they foresee no significant increase in domestic security inquiries as a result of new investigative standards issued last week. But clearly, in some areas, the department's revised guidelines would permit an expansion of activities by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: HAIG, OUT OF OFFICE, IS NOT OUT OF SIGHT
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr. has rarely kept his thoughts to himself, and since his departure from the Reagan Administration as Secretary of State, he has been operating true to form.

title: Only He Knows What Is Best for the U.S.
description: Charles Scheiner's ''A Case for Holding Military Portion of Tax From I.R.S.'' (Opinion page, Feb. 20) is not helpful in clarifying a vital issue facing all Americans, the issue of national security.

title: Coe Betters An Indoor Best
description: Sebastian Coe lowered his worldindoor best in the 800 meters with a time of 1 minute 44.91 seconds today and helped England to a 72-70 victory over the United States in a dual track and field meet. Coe's previous best was 1:46, in 1981.

title: A SENSIBLE TAX ALTERNATIVE
description: GOVERNOR O'NEILL proposed a $3.5 billion budget for the 1983-84 fiscal year to the General Assembly on Feb. 9. The budget amount is approximately $345.5 million more than this year's estimated expenditures or a 10 percent increase.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: IRMA AND JERRY By George Selden. Illustrated by Leslie H. Morrill. 207 pp. New York: Avon/Camelot. Paper, $2.50. (Ages 10 and Up)

title: THE FIGHT OVER SHOREHAM IS ALSO A FIGHT FOR PUBLIC OPINION
description: IN the continuing controversy over whether the Shoreham nuclear power plant should go into operation, public relations specialists and lobbyists have become almost as ubiquitous as nuclear physicists and technical experts.

title: Alexandra Blye Pagon Wed to John S. French
description: At St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Whitemarsh, Pa., Alexandra Blye Pagon and John Sargent French were married yesterday by the Rev. Jerry Fisher, assisted by the Rev. Thomas Lee McClellan.

title: Another View Of Walker Case
description: To the Sports Editor: I would like to take issue with Charlie McClendon for his comments (''The Herschel Walker Case: Some Lessons About Agents,'' The New York Times, Feb.27).

title: MUSIC: HILDA HARRIS IN RECITAL
description: Singing a first-rate vocal recital is so much more complex, so much more demanding intellectually and stylistically than opera that it is a wonder anybody makes the effort nowadays.

title: Kuhn Is Confident
description: Bowie Kuhn didn't sound like a lame-duck baseball commissioner the other night in St. Petersburg, Fla., where he was honored by the Caribbean Confederation. ''What the future brings - and one can never be sure what the future does bring - it will take extraordinary circumstances to remove me from you,'' Kuhn said. Kuhn's contract with baseball ends in August, and the owners have failed to renew it.

title: Sydney Lawford Is to Marry
description: The engagement of Sydney Maleia Kennedy Lawford to James Peter McKelvy has been announced by Miss Lawford's parents, Patricia Kennedy Lawford of New York and Peter Lawford of Los Angeles. Mr. McKelvy, who is known as Peter, is a son of Nancy Muniot of Oxford, Md., and William Sheldon McKelvy of Gloucester Point, Va.

title: BLACK LEADERS TO PLAN NATIONAL '84 PLATFORM
description: A group of black leaders who met here into the early hours today reached no conclusion about running a black Presidential candidate in 1984. But the group laid the groundwork for the first black national platform.

title: THE SECRET OF THE FAMILIAR EVERGREEN
description: The anxious can barely weather winter, flinching at each forecast, fearful that the snow will be as deep as predicted. What if the oil burner quits? What if the pipes freeze? What if the roof collapses? The 11 P.M. news can fuel an all-night worry.

title: MR JEFFERSON'S WORLD
description: The genteeling of Thomas Jefferson has obscured the man. The polished politeness of his imitators that we are used to now has none of Jefferson's fervor for the new. His eye was not polite. It was elegant, romantic and as revolutionary in its time as his political vision.

title: BERNARD Z. SEGAL
description: Bernard Z. Segal, a real-estate lawyer, died of a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 73 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Peter White And Lee Fox Plan to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Fox of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Norfolk, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mr. Fox's daughter, Lee Freeman Fox, to Peter Markley White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert O. White of Darien, Conn.

title: A GENEROUS CHINESE NEWCOMER
description: NEW Chinese restaurants in southwestern Connecticut have often tended in recent years to seem like offshoots of one another, with similar dishes, even menus that look as though they were printed in the same place.

title: PRESERVATIONISTS SEEK A FRESH IMAGE
description: NEW HAVEN WHAT do you do when many of the people you meet think you are trying to prevent progress? Members of groups that promote the preservation of historic buildings and sites in Connecticut decided recently that they have to change their image if they want more support for their cause from neighbors and governmental leaders.

title:
ART;
STRONG WORKS MARK JURIED SHOW
description: NOW that the Parrish Museum has discontinued its juried show, the Huntington Township Art League's annual Long Island Artists Exhibition, held at the Heckscher Museum in Huntington, has emerged as the region's premier competitive showcase.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
HELP! I'M AN ACCIDENT WAITING TO HAPPEN
description: THE other evening while tooling along a stretch of Old Country Road somewhere in Nassau County, I experienced a rare and mildly pleasant surprise. I was not cut off abruptly by a car entering the traffic flow at a snail's pace from a driveway. Thus I did not have to careen into the left lane to avoid a collision.

title: DANCE: 'STORY BEACH'
description: Some dances can be too much of a good thing. One such dance was Bebe Miller's two-act ''Story Beach,'' which Bebe Miller and Dancers presented Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: 2 Former Landlords Convicted Of Scheme to Burn Buildings
description: Two former landlords have been convicted of Federal racketeering charges for conducting a scheme in which 14 apartment buildings in Harlem and the South Bronx were burned down to collect insurance.

title: FRENCH LEFT EXPECTS LOSSES IN RUNOFF
description: The Socialist and Communist coalition Government expects to lose more cities Sunday in the final round of the nationwide municipal elections.

title:
LEISURE;
FRESH STRAWBERRIES AND RASPBERRIES FOR THE BACKYARD GOURMET
Man Is Held in Queens In 13 Armed Robberies
description: A 24-year-old suspect in a series of robberies, mostly at latehour businesses in Queens, was seized Friday night by detectives staked out near his home, and charged with 13 of the holdups, the Queens District Attorney's office announced yesterday.

title: Squash Trophy Is Stolen As Tourney Finals Start
description: The finals of the biggest amateur squash tournament in the country started at the Lincoln Squash Club on West 62d Street yesterday, but the three-foot-high silver cup that is the symbol of the event was missing.

title: U.N. ART COLLECTION, LIKE THE U.N., KEEPS GROWING
description: Like the United Nations membership, the diverse permanent collection of art here has tripled in size in the more than three decades that the international complex has been on the East River.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SPRING doesn't arrive until next Sunday, but the family tree, on my wife's side, was already in full blossom the other night when we visited relatives in Lawrence. Three of the couples there were citizens of the Five Towns, and they were sketching a history of the place, which for them went back to the recent past, when they moved in.

title: VACATION BREAK FOR IRISH CHILDREN
description: LAST summer, as Connecticut children were boarding buses for camps, taking tennis lessons and cultivating the fine art of Pac-Man, some Northern Irish children were cycling through a maze of army tanks and roadblocks, lobbing petrol bombs at barbed-wire targets and playing war games in burned-out Belfast flats.

title: ONCE AGAIN, AN N.Y.U. PROJECT DRAWS FIRE IN 'VILLAGE'
description: NEW York University's plans to replace some of its Greenwich V illage residential properties with a law-school dormitory and a cademic space, displacing 31 local residents, has stirred community o pposition.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SUMMER GIRLS, LOVE BOYS And Other Short Stories. By Norma Fox Mazer. 243 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $11.95. (Ages 12 and Up)

title: Big East Tournament Comes Home
description: Ever since the new Madison Square Garden opened in 1968, the spirit of college basketball has rattled around in the new arena, not quite comfortable with its new surroundings. This week it found peace.

title: Cleanshaven, Shirts Tucked In
description: As members of Prof. Eugene Rostow's International Law Seminar we cannot condone the inaccurate description given of the students in the class (''A Comfortable Homecoming,'' Feb. 6). None of the students were unshaven, nor were any of us unkempt in appearance.

title: EASIER CHEAPER WAYS
description: Here are a few tips that might make your trip easier and cheaper. STUDENT CARDS: The International Student Identity Card (I.S.I.C.) is without question worth getting. It offers medical insurance up to $1,000; qualifies you for trips organized by universities (some of the best are advertised on university bulletin boards); allows you to take student charter flights; and gives you discounts on admission to most national museums in Europe. The card costs $6.50 in the United States; in France, you can get it for less than $3. You will need a certificate of student status (a signed and sealed letter from the registrar will do); a passport-size photograph with your name printed on the back and proof of birth date and nationality. Cards are available in the United States through the Council on International Educational Exchange, 205 East 42d Street, New York 10017 (212-661-1414), and 312 Sutter Street, San Francisco 94108; Educational Travel Center, 438 North Frances Street, Madison, Wisc. 53703; and Harvard Student Agencies, Harvard University, Thayer Hall B, Cambridge, Mass. 02138.

title: OPEC STILL SEEKS ACCORD ON A PRICE CUT
description: A conference of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries adjourned tonight after a daylong session without an agreement that would clear the way for the first price reduction in its 23-year history. But officials said significant progress had been made.

title: CONSUMER RATES
POLICE 'CLOSE' TO A SOLUTION OF SLAYING IN THE SNOW
description: Carlos Senquez, who lives in New Britain, Conn., was on his way to visit relatives, along with several members of his family, when his car stalled in the snow in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn on the night of Feb. 12.

title: No Headline
description: Bandits Defeat Panthers

title: A MATTER OF TIMING
description: After deciding to enter society, I was invited to the Niebelhunkers' for dinner at 8:30. It was 8:30 precisely when I rang the doorbell.

title: RESTORING THE HARD WORK OF PROPER WRITING
description: FROM Chappaqua to White Plains, from Armonk to Pelham, schools are responding to the pleas of parents and employers alike: teach students to write, to put facts or feelings in proper - and properly spelled - English. During the last decade, trendy efforts to avoid stifling ''creativity'' have replaced the simple hard work of rewriting and editing.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC
description: Christoph von Dohnanyi is ending his stint this season at the New York Philharmonic with a solidly Central European program. And as a German conductor, he is quite rightly presenting a work by one of Germany's leading composers, Hans Werner Henze.

title: A PRESERVATION POLICY
description: Spurred by a 25 percent investment tax credit, according to the United States Treasury Department, $800 million was spent last year nationwide reconstructing historic temples, churches, mansions and other old buildings. By 1985, such spending is expected to rise to $2 billion.

title: Alison Betts Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Allan W. Betts of Manchester, Vt., and Hobe Sound, Fla., formerly of Oyster Bay, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Whitney Betts, to Robert Evans DeWitt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. DeWitt of Granger, Ind. A June wedding is planned.

title: BENEATH LIFE'S FACADE; Why Pandas?
description: Many endangered species inspire far more concern than love. The sight of a California condor doesn't provoke the urge to hug, and no one ever smiled foolishly at a bald eagle.

title: Florida Prisoner Pleads Guilty In Slayings of 2 More Women
description: Gerald Eugene Stano, who has told the police he killed 31 girls and young women in Florida, pleaded guilty Friday to the murders of two waitresses.

title: WHERE TO GO FOR HELP
description: Pregnant women who believe they have been exposed to something that causes birth defects can be evaluated by the Teratology Service Program, part of Rutgers Medical School's Division of Medical Genetics in New Brunswick. (Teratology is the study of how environmental factors affect the developing fetus.)

title: Susan V. Opotow Wed to a Banker
description: Susan Victoria Opotow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Opotow of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Stephen Peng Chang, son of Mr. and Mrs. Tsuan-nien Chang of Riverdale, the Bronx. Family Court Judge Ruth Jane Zuckerman performed the ceremony at the Shun Lee West restaurant in New York.

title: MONDALE VISITS HACKLEY
description: IN his first New York State appearance since announcing he would seek the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination, Walter F. Mondale visited the county Wednesday to address students at the Hackley School in Tarrytown.

title: Namibian Ex-Soldier Jailed
description: West Africa, March 12 (Reuters) - Timothy Simasiku, a former black soldier in the defense force of South-West Africa, which is also known as Namibia, has been sentenced to 18 months in jail for passing classified information to Zambia,

title: LIFE ON WOMEN'S TOUR: GLAMOUR IS HARD TO FIND
description: Pam Shriver, the fifth-ranked player in women's tennis, will be in New York this month to compete in a Virginia Slims tournament, beginning March 23. At the request of The New York Times, she compiled this diary to reflect life on the women's tour and the dominance of her doubles partner, Martina Navratilova. By PAM SHRIVER AROUTINE week of practice was interrupted by the big snow storm thath it Baltimore. I still managed to practice every day, climbing t hreefoot drifts of snow to get to the club. Getting my mind preparedt o play is the most important thing, and if it means getting to the c lub by dog sled, I would have.

title: Post's Women Beaten In N.C.A.A. Tourney
description: The C.W. Post women's basketball team was eliminated by Canisius, 71-59, from the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II East regional today.

title: VICHYSSOISE
description: To the Editor:

title: KARATE CONTESTS
description: More than 200 participants and 500 spectators are expected to turn out beginning at 9 A.M. today for the 12 Annual Mas Oyama's Kyokushinkai Karate Tournament in the Fairview Greenburgh Community Center, at 32 Manhattan Avenue in Greenburgh.

title: NOT ALWAYS HARMONIOUS
description: HOROWITZ A Biography of Vladimir Horowitz. By Glenn Plaskin. Illustrated. 607 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $19.95.

title: A MEETING OF BIOLOGICAL AND PHILOSOPHICAL MINDS
description: IS scientific thinking different? The Princeton psychologist George A. Miller reports that when he proposed a scholarly talk on this question, he was reminded of the old Henny Youngman joke that begins, How's your wife? The irresistible answer in both cases is: Compared to what?

title: Military Analysis
description: The Army and the Air Force are developing a new operational strategy aimed at countering the Soviet Union's numerical superiority in men, guns, tanks and aircraft. The strategy stresses maneuverability, flexible leadership and advanced weapon systems. If adopted by the Pentagon - and officers here are confident that it will be - the strategy, called Airland battle, would break dramatically with current doctrine. Since the end of World War II it has centered on attrition, or the destruction of enemy resources through superior firepower.

title: Sun Shining on Race
description: Weather permitting, the Carolina 500 will resume today at the North Carolina Motor Speedway in Rockingham. The reason for the caution flag on the event's prospects is that six times in a row, and seven of the last eight times, rain or snow has postponed a scheduled Grand National stock car race at the speedway. Today, the National Weather Service is calling for bright sunshine and temperatures in the 60's.

title:
DINING OUT;
ON THE BANKS OF THE OLD RARITAN
description: THE city of New Brunswick is undergoing a renewal on a grand scale. Once-empty stores are reopening or being transformed for other uses, Rutgers University is turning the school's art gallery into the city's first art museum and a large, splashy Hyatt Regency Hotel has been built to accommodate the influx of visitors (business and otherwise) that the city expects any day now.

title: Bangladesh Cholera Deaths
description: The death toll in a three-week cholera outbreak in Pirojpur, a southern coastal area, rose to 110 today, doctors said.

title: E.P.A. Dispute: Chief Leaves, Issues Remain
description: Though the President gamely tried to put a good face on it, last week was marked by casualty and capitulation in the battle over the Environmental Protection Agency. After months of turmoil, Anne McGill Burford resigned as Administrator of the agency and Ronald Reagan surrendered to Congress the toxic waste cleanup records he had risked her neck for in the first place.

title: Melinda G. Murray Engaged
description: The engagement of Melinda Gray Murray to Robert D. MacDougall Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. MacDougall of York, Pa., has been announced by Alison Deacon Gray of Weston, Conn., mother of the future bride. A June wedding is planned.

title: INSTITUTE FOR SEVERELY DISABLED TO CUT PROGRAM
description: A Bronx institute that educates children with multiple handicaps has decided to abandon its summer program this year to dramatize the plight its students will face when they become 21 years old, officials of the school said.

title: 2 ELECTED TO STATE BOARD OF REGENTS BY JOINT SESSION OF THE LEGISLATURE
description: The State Legislature, meeting in a joint session, has unanimously elected two new members to the State Board of Regents.

title: Designer Detente
description: After searching the melancholy soul of Russia, French designer Pierre Cardin has concluded that dining at his famous Maxim's restaurant might do the average cheerless Muscovite a world of good.

title: CYPRUS NEEDS A UNIVERSITY, BUT GETS TALK
description: Nicos Zittis, a Greek Cypriot, is trying to get a scholarship or a loan to study electronics at an American university.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN SMALL BUSINESS;
A PUSH FROM THE STATEHOUSE
description: When Knowledge Systems Concepts Inc., a Rome, N.Y., company specializing in artificial intelligence applications, started in business last June, its assets consisted of little more than the expertise of its three founders - an electrical engineer, a computer expert and a psychologist.

title: Social Security: Moving Along
description: Congress went far last week toward enabling the Social Security System to bail faster than it sinks, at least for a while. President Reagan and legislative leaders praised the bipartisan cooperation that resulted in the passage of a bill in the House of Representatives and was expected to lead to approval of a broadly similar measure in the Senate this week.

title: SWAMPING AN OPPONENT
description: A straight line is not the shortest distance between two points - one must often take the opponent across the river and into the trees and back again and even through many such circuits before he can be coaxed out of the game.

title: VOLKSWAGEN LEARNS THAT A RABBIT IS NO BEETLE
description: DETROIT NOEL PHILLIPS, the president of Volkswagen of America Inc. knows the fundamental problem facing his company: Rabbits cost more than Toyotas, Nissans, Hondas and Mazdas.So Volkswagen, with up to now only limited success, is pushing quality over thrift, and looking for a niche in an American market where it once had a cavern.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CONTEMPORARY MUSIC

title: PASSAGE TO MALABAR
description: For any traveler, certain journeys hold a remembered enchantment that bears little relation to the particular monuments visited or beauty spots enjoyed. Some other quality seems to inform such voyages, coloring even the most prosaic details of everyday life with its peculiar magic.

title: Nkomo Flees For His Life
description: Joshua Nkomo, once the grand old man of Zimbabwe nationalism, last week completed the long slide from patriarch to official pariah. Fleeing what he said were Government-inspired attempts on his life and a treason trial, Mr. Nkomo took refuge in Botswana, where the welcome was apprehensive.

title: Sandra Dana Is Betrothed
description: Eleanor W. Dana and Charles A. Dana Jr., both of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sandra Ladson Dana, to Robert James O'Donnell Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Donnell of Haverford, Pa. A fall wedding is planned.

title: LOU REED: HERO OF HIS NEW DISK
description: Lou Reed, the founder and voice of the Velvet Underground and the godfather of punk rock, never seemed very comfortable with the rather more prosaic facts of his background - a comfortable middleclass upbringing on Long Island and literature studies at Syracuse University. In fact, much of the tension that has made his records and songs compelling, and often unsettling, derived from the apparent dichotomy between his more or less conventional roots and the succession of bizarre roles he has chosen to play.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: 'A Time for Reckoning'

title: UNDERSTANDING THE DEADLY AIDS
description: According to the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, the medical costs for an AIDS sufferer range from $50,000 to $100,000.

title: THE WEST GERMANS VOTE THEIR HOPES
description: West Germany's Christian Democrats have always liked to think of themselves as a ''Volkspartei,'' or people's party, a broad coalition of businessmen, blue-collar workers and farmers that speaks for the entire country. In last Sunday's milestone general election, the Christian Democrats took a giant step toward translating aspiration to reality - and thus assumed a heavy burden of hope.

title: YUCATAN'S CHICHEN ITZA: A HALLIBURTON 'MARVEL'
description: ADAM CLYMER is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Times.

title: THE DEVIL AND P & G
description: Procter & Gamble took on the Devil last summer. Its weapons: not crosses and mumbled incantations, but lawsuits and a fierce public relations blitz.

title: OPEC Members Struggle to Avoid A Breakup
description: No bazaar is likely to see more furious haggling than the London hotel where the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries spent all last week arguing over what price and production cuts would insure OPEC's survival in the midst of a world oil glut.

title: ART WORLD TO HONOR ITS OWN
description: FOR the sixth consecutive year, the Connecticut public will have an opportunity to buzz that old saw, ''I may not know much about art but I know what I like.''

title: Cooking Up a Satellite Sale
description: Loath to relinquish an idea that accords with fiscal policy and political philosophy, the Reagan Administration is again trying to pare down the Government's weather services. Last year, the plan was to close weather stations.

title: WHEN HAIR TURNS THIN
description: A headful of thick hair is one of nature's blessings; its loss a signal for men and women alike to start in on lotions, salves, vitamins, massage - even implants. Help, in a medical sense, is available but still limited; dermatologists these days can reverse or slow down some forms of hair loss. But the adversary is as resilient as the common cold, and in most cases about all the doctor or anyone else can do is spare one the false hopes and free spending that the ''cures'' encourage.

title: Heidi Jean Flack to Marry Robert Craig Jacob in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Flack of Suffern, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Heidi Jean Flack, to Robert Craig Jacob, son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Jacob of Shelburne, Vt.

title: SEEKING A COMEBACK IN HIS EARLY 20'S
description: IT was a hot summer evening last August, and Frank Viola of the Minnesota Twins will never forget it. The 22-year-old pitcher from East Meadow experienced what might have been for some the fulfillment of a childhood dream as he pitched his team to a 5-0 victory over the 39-year-old veteran Tommy John and the New York Yankees at Yankee Stadium.

title: Soccer Stars Chosen
description: Tabare Ramos and George Gelnovatch, two members of the national team of the United States that will take part in the Youth World Cup in Mexico this summer, head a list of 11 high school soccer players in the tristate area selected on an all-America team by Adidas. New York and New Jersey led with four players each. Others selected from the area were: Christian Peat, James Garrant, Greg Meares, Dave Intrabartola, James Gallina, Martin McCormick, Bill Colavecchio, Mark Noonan and Guy Welton.

title: HOLLYWOOD: THIS WAY IN
description: ''Perrier is passe,'' says Peter Morton. ''It's being replaced by a low-sodium Swedish mineral water, Ram-Losa. Jordan red wine is 'in.' So are low-salt diets and yoga.''

title: MAYOR REJECTS NEW U.S. PROPOSALS IN GLEN COVE DISPUTE ON RUSSIANS
description: The State Department has made new proposals in an attempt to end Glen Cove's ban against the use of its beaches, tennis courts and golf courses by Soviet diplomats. But Mayor Alan M. Parente has rejected the plan.

title: RANGERS STOP FLAMES BY 4-1
description: Glen Hanlon said he thought the bottom had dropped out of his career when, last Tuesday, he gave up four first-period goals and was removed from the Rangers' net in Vancouver.

title: POET OF THE BOGS
description: Excerpts from ''Poems 1965-1975'' by Seamus Heaney. Copyright c 1966, 1972, 1975 by Seamus Heaney. From ''Field Work'' by Seamus Heaney. Copyright c 1976, 1979 by Seamus Heaney. By permission of Farrar, Straus & Giroux Inc.

title: LONDON: HARE AND CHURCHILL CREATE A STIR
description: Benedict Nightingale writes frequently on theater in London. LONDON David Hare's ''Plenty'' received distinctly uneven reviews when it opened at the National Theater in 1977, and the arrival on the same stage of the first full-length play he has written since then, ''A Map of the World,'' has been marked by even sharper ups and downs of critical opinion. But its author hasn't meekly submitted to the grapeshot. On the contrary, Mr. Hare has turned on the hunters, publicly pronouncing them and their standards ''dismal.''

title: IS MAPPLETHORPE ONLY OUT TO SHOCK?
description: Much of Robert Mapplethorpe's work - which is featured in no fewer than three gallery exhibitions at present, as well as in a newly published book - is undeniably and intentionally distasteful. The norms of polite nudity are transgressed; religious, racial and sexual taboos are flouted; a kind of chic, narcissistic exhibitionism is flaunted. Even his elegant color photographs of cut flowers have the potential to shock; the clinical austerity of his vision denies their organic nature. His style is akin to what William Gass, author of ''On Being Blue,'' observed of the ''Rubaiyat'': ''Like a pair of polished shoes, (with) just the right world-weariness and erotic sheen.''

title: Maureen B. Barna to Wed Alan D. Haring in May
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Barna Jr. of Vestal, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Maureen Bernadette Barna, to Alan Douglas Haring, son of Isobel Haring of New Castle, Del., and David Haring of Wilmington, Del. The wedding is planned for May.

title: IT'S A SPRINGTIME OF DISCOVERY AS THE DODGERS MAKE CHANGES
description: VERO BEACH, Fla. MIKE MARSHALL is the tall, angular one, the one over there with the short dark hair. Greg Brock is a little smaller; he has dark blond hair and a matching mustache. He's the one over there at first base. He's the one who's taking Steve Garvey's place. Marshall is replacing Ron Cey, but he's playing right field, and Pedro Guerrero is moving to third base.

title: CLOTHES OF A DIFFERENT COLOR
description: Children's clothes - fun, comfortable and practical - have been given a touch of sophistication for spring and summer with the color black. For toddler or teen-ager, play or party, outfits in black - sometimes combined with white, sometimes with splashes of red - are no longer for grownups only. -Opposite page, left: Running shorts, $7.50, and T-shirt, $8. Sizes 4-7. By Kaynee. At Cerutti, 807 Madison Avenue. Woodward & Lothrop, Washington. Younkers, Des Moines, Iowa. A black stripe runs down the side of these jogging pants, which come with a matching, zipper-front jacket. Sizes 4-6, $24. By Bull Frog Knits. At Bloomingdale's. Cerutti. Macy's. Bambergers, New Jersey. Lacing separates the black and red in these cotton sateen shorts. Sizes 2-4, $16; 4-6, $17. By Gee Kids. At Bloomin' Babies, 844 Lexington Avenue. Little Bits of the Sixties, 1186 Madison Avenue. Malawi and The Mighty Mole, 187-22 Union Turnpike, Queens. Lester's, Greenvale, L.I. Younger Set, Long Beach, L.I. Auntee Barbara, Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: WNYC's Format
description: To the Editor:

title: POP: THE MCGARRIGLES
description: While Kate and Anna McGarrigle, the acclaimed Canadian sisters who write and sing their own material, have been praised for the timeless quality of their music, in performance their disinterest in the moment often involves a quaint disregard for the conventions of the contemporary pop concert. The McGarrigles' show at Carnegie Hall on Friday was a case in point.

title: EAVESDROPPING BILL FOSTERS A DEBATE
description: LEGISLATIVE committee hearings on bills often bog down in the minutiae generated by special-interest lobbyists on issues of little concern to the public. But a recent hearing called by the Judiciary Committee fostered a spirited debate on the right of privacy versus the power of the state.

title: Cardinal Cooke's Irish Quandry
description: The powers of persuasion that helped St. Patrick bring Christianity to Ireland 1,500 years ago might have been useful in New York City last week. As the St. Patrick's Day Parade drew near, tensions mounted over whether it would be a cultural celebration or a rally of support for the Irish Republican Army.

title: DEBATE SET IN PHILADELPHIA
description: After some angry accusations, the Democratic mayoral candidates, W. Wilson Goode and Frank L. Rizzo, have agreed to a televised debate next month. The two accepted an invitation Friday from the League of Women Voters for the one-hour debate, starting at 8 P.M. April 19. On Thursday each candidate accused the other of being afraid of such an encounter. Mr. Rizzo wanted the debate a week before the May 17 primary, while Mr. Goode indicated a preference for late March or early April.

title: DOING MORE WITH LESS
description: The 1,350 square feet in a converted factory building on Park Avenue South was ''a typical small loft,'' according to Robert Bray and Michael Schaible of Manhattan-based Bray-Schaible Design Inc. The square space, with its garlandlike sprinkler system and visible plumbing lines, had been divided into two rooms. ''Simply mundane'' was Bray's initial assessment.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Ancient Coin Sale to Feature Roman Rarities
description: Lover of ancient coins are in for a special treat next week when Numismatic Fine Arts Incorporated of Beverly Hills, Calif., conducts it annual action sale of Greek and Roman rarities. The sale includes some exceptional material, especially in the area of Roman bronzes, and promises to be of Roman bronzes, and promises to be the finest auction of ancient coins in years.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: KATHLEEN SMITH'S husband died 11 years ago. He fell in their Tuckahoe house and was pronounced dead of a heart attack eight hours later.

title: Salesman Wins in Tax Case
description: A jury has acquitted an insurance salesman who failed to file income tax returns for four years and who tearfully testified that he thought paying taxes was voluntary. Raymond Garland, 44 years old, of Sycamore, earned $16,000 to $33,000 a year from 1976 through 1979. At the trial, he quoted from the 1971 tax booklet, which states, ''Each year, American taxpayers voluntarily file their tax returns and make a special effort to pay the taxes they owe.''

title: REAGAN PLAYS THE ISSUES IN MORE THAN A SINGLE KEY
description: WASHINGTON THE cry came from the heart and seemed simple enough when it was sounded two months ago by Interior Secretary James Watt at a pep rally of hundreds of Administration patronage appointees: ''Let Reagan be Reagan!''

title: OUTSIDE BUYERS HARASSING CO-OP TENANTS
description: CHET GOTTFRIED of Kew Gardens, Queens, and Oren Root Jr., who lives in Manhattan, have different landlords, but they share similar p roblems. They are both tenants in rent-stabilized apartments in buildings t hat were converted to cooperatives under noneviction plans. Their t roubles began when the shares allocated to their apartments were s old to outside purchasers.

title: GUNBOAT DIPLOMACY UPDATED FOR THE 80'S
description: It's a rare day when the United States military isn't on the march somewhere in the world. In South Korea, the first shots were to be fired today in Team Spirit 83, a month-long war game worthy of Hollywood. The cast includes nearly 70,000 American military personnel, three dozen Navy ships and 118,000 Republic of Korea troops. Meanwhile, a force that will grow to include 36 warships, among them three aircraft carriers, began assembling last week in the Caribbean. British and Dutch frigates are due to join in three weeks of training maneuvers, the most extensive held in the area in years.

title: RECITAL: BISHOP-KOVACEVICH
description: At Stephen Bishop-Kovacevich's recital at the 92d Street Y on Thursday night, the American-born pianist now living in Britain gave the works by Beethoven and Schubert on the program an almost scrubbed quality. No attitudes were struck, no sentimentality indulged in.

title: Poet of the Bogs
description: As surely as the Irish still risk perishing in their troubles, they must make new poetry. And the most lyrical in years is coming from Seamus Heaney - ''Seamus of the Bogs,'' to cite the sort of blurb line he mistrusts in his current popularity, which is well established in Ireland and fast unfolding in America.

title: Socialists Slip In Local Voting
description: Don't panic, France's Socialist leaders told each other last week, but some couldn't help being anxious. The Socialists lost 16 cities in the first round of municipal elections and six of President Francois Mitterrand's Cabinet ministers were defeated in local voting that was regarded as reflecting national feelings.

title: COAL AND SALT: A HAPPY MIX FOR THE WEST?
description: For decades, the Western states along the Colorado River have had a vexatious water problem. Because the Colorado is fed by natural salt springs, the river's salinity becomes so high that its water damages crops, corrodes pipes and falls far below drinking quality.

title: Dance Institute Benefit Scheduled for May 23
description: Jacques d'Amboise, star of the New York City Ballet, has announced that the fifth annual ''Event of the Year,'' a benefit for his National Dance Institute, will be held at the Felt Forum on May 23 at 8 P.M.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN SMALL BUSINESS;
MAKING IT THROUGH THE RECESSION
description: BOSTON The recession has hit American industry hard, but small businesses appear to have come through it in better shape - at least in terms of jobs -than large businesses.

title: DANCE: BALLETFORE, OF THE ENGLISH SCHOOL
description: The evening promised much when the curtain went up on Balletfore on Wednesday at Marymount Manhattan College. To start, the six dancers gathered for ''Dances from 'Les Sylphides,' '' sharing the stage with the pianist, created an attractive period stage picture. The small size and frame of the stage and the care with which the dancers struck their poses brought back happy memories of such chamber ballet troupes as Manhattan Festival, Mercury and Terpsichore Ballets, and of the commitment of Eliot Feld's American Ballet Company. The company also offered a chance to watch ''English school'' ballet dancers trained in the style taught by the venerable Margaret Craske, who attended the performance. And the selection of ballets seemed ideal.

title: Voice of the Public Wanted on Transit
description: I wish to express my support and endorsement of the well-reasoned article by Assemblyman Arthur J. Kremer, ''Revamping M.T.A.: Regional Boards Could Be Its 'Right Arm' '' (Opinion Page, Feb. 20). There is one more ingredient that should be added to the proposal and that is a requirement for public participation.

title: 3% Law Defended
description: To the Editor:

title: FAIR ISLE: SWEATERS THEIR KNITTERS WEAR
description: LISA de MAURO is a writer who lives in New York. By LISA de MAURO

title: Weinberger on the Ramparts
description: Theodore H. White and The New York Times do a great service in giving us a better understanding of Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger, and his compelling rationale for a strong United States defense (''Weinberger on the Ramparts,'' Feb. 6).

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SAN DIEGO
description: ROBERT LINDSEY is chief of the Los Angeles bureau of The Times.

title: Frankfurt Airport Accident
description: A Kuwait Airways airliner grazed a Pan American jet today as they were waiting to take off at Frankfurt Airport, causing extensive damage to both planes but no injuries, officials said.

title: Article on Kearny Draws Criticism
description: Martin Winkler's Opinion Page article of Feb. 27, which was addressed to the ''people of Kearny,'' should have been addressed, rather, to the employees of Western Electric because his thoughts were directed to them.

title: A PAIR OF PIPERS ENTHRALL SCHOOLCHILDREN
description: AUDIENCES have judged Larry Cole and Bill Ochs in parks and taverns, on television and on Broadway. Now, having left Broadway to tour New Jersey's elementary schools with a program of Scottish and Irish music called ''Road to the Isles,'' they face the most demanding audience of all: schoolchildren.

title: ALLIANCE IS FORMED
description: CRANFORD OFFICIALS representing 16 trade unions and environmental and health organizations have formed what they call the state's largest and potentially most powerful labor-environmental alliance.

title: HERE COME THE DEMOCRATS
description: Martin Tolchin covers Congress for The Times. Senator Alan Cranston, his gaunt face caked with television makeup, sat alone in the forward section of the chartered United Airlines 727, gazing idly out the window. He was all but oblivious to the airborne party that swirled around him, as members of the media mingled with his campaign staff and supporters, aided by an ample supply of Bloody Marys. The plane's public-address system blared a tape recording that a reporter had brought along as appropriate to the occasion: Willie Nelson's ''On the Road Again.''

title: SAVING FACE AND CLEANING UP
description: THE disposal of toxic waste was never of much concern to the platoons of plant managers in this once bustling industrial town about 45 miles outside Chicago. Thousands of tons of chemically saturated sludge were discharged casually into the viscous, discolored Des Plaines River. Vats of hazardous acid and tanks of liquid carcinogens were poured into steel drums and routinely turned over to ''midnight haulers,'' who more often than not cared little about where the waste ended up.

title: SUIT CHALLENGES ILLINOIS DEATH ROW CONDITIONS
description: Illinois has opened a second death row to house an overflow of condemned prisoners, and conditions at both places are under legal challenge.

title: HELPFUL HINTS FOR DIRECTORS
description: The Hudson Heights section of Jersey City, across the Hudson River from Manhattan at 14th Street, is a commuter's dream. Close to the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels and served by a host of bus lines, and a mile from a PATH station, it offers the convenience of living near Manhattan, but at lower prices.

title: Future Events; Manhattan Merrymaking
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Asian-American Evening March 15 - The Pan Asian Repertory Theater, now in its sixth season, will be the beneficiary of an international evening, with Cao Guisheng, Consul General of China in New York, as guest of honor, at the China Institute in America. Two hundred fifty merrymakers will attend a party to aid the theater group of 25 actors who will don some 200 authentic Oriental costumes to perform the play ''Teahouse'' at the 28th Street Playhouse. It runs from March 17 through April 9. Tickets to the play are $8 and $10. Tickets for the entire evening, which includes cocktails, a buffet of Chinese food and Oriental music by a four-piece chamber group, are $50. Call 260-0180.

title: Carry-on Baggage
description: To the Editor: Richard Condon in ''Tropical Tweeds,'' (Travel, Feb. 6) shared the ''Discimus Agere Agendo'' motto by which many travelers have suffered ... we learn to do by doing, which is to say, ''now I know why some of my fellow passengers' carry-on's are so heavy.''

title: Fame Remains But Name Escapes Us
description: Howard Stassen - wasn't he from the same state as Hubert Horatio Hornblower? Of course, the one-time ''boy wonder'' of the Republican Party and American politics referred to by Patricia Seremet in her recent Opinion article (''A Young Candidate Bows Out,'' Feb. 27) was actually Harold Stassen.

title: WEINBERGER ON THE RAMPARTS
description: Theodore White refers to the fact that Russian missiles are bigger and heavier than ours and states: ''They now outweigh us in such megatonnage by 5,000 to 3,000.''

title: 3 GAMBLERS TELL OF LIFE ON THE BRINK
description: WHEN John L. hit bottom and it seemed he could sink no lower, his wife tricked him into attending a Gamblers Anonymous meeting - a last-ditch effort to save their marriage.

title: A NEW LOOK FOR 'MOTHER OF US ALL'
description: Virgil Thomson once stated, ''I will have nothing to do with opera, except as poetic theater.'' Indeed, his three operatic works, ''Four Saints in Three Acts,'' which had its premiere in 1934, ''The Mother of Us All'' (1947) and ''Lord Byron'' (to a text by the poet Jack Larson), presented at the Juilliard Theater in 1972, bear testimony to a musical and dramatic sensibility that continually eschewed rigid operatic conventions. It is no doubt for this reason that Mr. Thomson's operas lend themselves to a wide variety of interpretations and theatrical concepts.

title: Postpartum Plastic Surgery
description: Regarding ''The Problems of Pregnancy'' (by Deborah Blumenthal (Feb. 13), two problems were not mentioned in this otherwise excellent article.

title: Understanding The Deadly AIDS
description: Robin Marantz Henig's article, ''AIDS: A New Disease's Deadly Odyssey'' (Feb. 6), is clear, concise and serves as a fine source of information on this tragic illness for the public.

title: Miss Huddleston Wed To Boston Psychiatrist
description: The marriage of Margaret M. Huddleston to Dr. Jerome L. Missel took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. Brian Kopke performed the ceremony.

title: Miss August to Wed Dr. Philip Sullivan
description: Dr. and Mrs. Burton August of West Nyack, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Betsy Sue August, to Dr. Philip Wright Sullivan, son of Janet Wright Sullivan of Providence, R.I., and the late George William Sullivan Jr. The wedding is planned for June.

title: TWO OPPOSE UCONN FIELD HOUSE
description: CAN the state afford to spend as much as $15 million to upgrade athletic facilities at the University of Connecticut at a time of budgetary cutbacks, some of which affect education?

title: METS WIN AS SEAVER GOES TRHEE INNINGS
description: After runaway defeats in their first three exhibition games, the Mets finally followed their scriptwriters' story line today: With Tom Seaver pitching and the board of directors watching, they mounted a pair of five-run innings and whipped the St. Louis Cardinals, 10-5.

title: New York Liberals Act To Reunify Their Party
description: The Liberal Party's State Committee moved yesterday to unify under the leadership of the Rev. Dr. Donald S. Harrington, the state chairman.

title: ARTISTS IN RESIDENCE ENHANCE UPCOMING COUNTY CONCERTS
description: WHILE it is a source of increasing satisfaction that so many worldrenowned artists include cities in the county among their touring ports of call, we can also take pride in the extraordinary number of performers who not only make music in the county but also make their homes here.

title: HINDEMITH HAS HAD A POST-MORTEM REPUTATION PROBLEM
description: There exists in classical music a curious phenomenon that we might call the post-mortem provisional eclipse - a composer who, famous in his lifetime, falls precipitously from fame at his death and only later reclaims his rightful position in the pantheon.

title: SOME NUCLEAR PARTNERS FEEL THE STRAIN OF RISING COSTS
description: When a nuclear plant is switched on, the cost of its construction often means that electric rates go up. Thus as Millstone 3 nears completion in Waterford, Conn., the residents of Lyndonville, Vt., hard by the Canadian border more than 200 miles to the north, are facing increases because their municipal utility owns 0.0487 percent of the plant. Higher electric rates will also be in order for residents of Fitchburg, Mass., and those in a large part of Maine, whose local suppliers also own a piece of the plant.

title: Ailing Sea Mammals Treated At Coast Center and Released
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Children crowd around a green plastic tub that is the sickbed of one of the new patients at the California Marine Mammal Center, a harbor seal.

title: OFFICIALS CRITICIZE CUTS ON RESEARCH
description: Officials of five state psychiatric research institutes have called on Governor Cuomo to reconsider proposed budget cuts that would close one institution and impose extensive staff reductions at the others.

title: 600 IN COUNTY TAKE PART IN DRILL AT INDIAN POINT
description: VERPLANCK THE second full-scale Indian Point emergency drill took place as scheduled last week with about 600 people in the county taking an active role in the daylong event. For many it was a day of pretending, in a serious vein, that a major accident at the nuclear plants had reached an emergency stage. For others it was a day of official observation, to see if the ''players'' - who ranged from plant operators to officials to health workers - knew what to do.

title: '10 TO MIDNIGHT'
description: If ''10 to Midnight,'' the new Charles Bronson film that opened yesterday at the Rivoli and assorted neighborhood houses, is not among the worst of its kind, then it is because its kind is among the worst of any kind.
