title: Americans Leave Hanoi With Data on War Dead
description: Four Americans returned from Vietnam today carrying ''tentative information'' on 12 Americans killed during the Vietnam War, a United States Embassy spokesman said.

title: MUSIC: ANDRES SEGOVIA PLAYS AT LINCOLN CENTER
description: All those who were fortunate enough to be in Avery Fisher Hall last night will be able to tell incredulous listeners in years hence that they heard Andres Segovia give a technically fluent, mesmerizing recital when he was a month past his 90th birthday. The hall was packed with the great Spanish guitarist's admirers, of course, and the audience overflowed into stage seats for what, by any measure, was one of the season's notable occasions.

title: The Boiler Connection
description: Question: According to the landlord, our building is not rent stabilized because it has only three apartments. We are, however, connected to two adjoining buildings by common heat, electrical and gas systems. Despite the fact that the buildings have separate entrances, don't the unified systems make us one nine-unit building? ... G.M., Manhattan.

title: BISTROS
description: You go to a bistro to eat and drink - not because of the table linen, not because of the lighting, not to impress, not to pitch woo, not to spend a lot of money and certainly not to preen in the company of the would-be great. You go to eat food that remembers its peasant origins: copious, hearty and old-fashioned.

title: Jane Irene Merino To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman Merino of Coconut Creek, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Irene Merino, to Robert Jay Morais, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Morais of West Palm Beach, Fla., A May wedding is planned.

title: INVESTMENTS IN JAMAICA'S HOUSING
description: ''Everything is 15 years behind,'' Morton Pickman, who owns four apartment houses in Jamaica, Queens, said in a tone of regret. Anyone who owns property in downtown Jamaica must wish that the ambitious redevelopment effort under way there had started sooner and been finished 10 or 15 years ago - in time perhaps to soften or offset the effects of the downturn in the 1970's.

title: MY ROME
description: I settled in Rome long ago in 1967 because I found myself returning there again and again, staying longer and longer. I think what attracted me most was the immediate touch of antiquity on everyday life. If you live in central Rome you have only to walk down the street and you come to a fountain by Bernini in which children are playing or a Michelangelo embassy or some fine 15th-century building with today's washing hanging out.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MARCH 13, 1983
description: International The U.S. stepped up its efforts to break the deadlock over talks on the Lebanese situation. Secretary of State George P. Shultz met with Lebanon's Foreign Minister, Eli Salem, and was to confer today with Israel's Foreign Minister, Yitzhak Shamir. Meanwhile, President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon was sending former Prime Minister Saeb Salam to Wasington with an undisclosed personal message to President Reagan. (Page 1, Col. 6.)

title: No Headline
description: HOUSTON BEATS TEXAS CHRISTIAN FOR S.W.C. CROWN

title: GETTING IN GEAR FOR THE VOYAGE
description: E. J. DIONNE Jr. is a correspondent in the Paris bureau of The Times.

title: Central America: More Millions
description: Pope John Paul II was hardly back in the Vatican last week, having drawn the world's attention to the poverty and strife of Central America and the Caribbean, when President Reagan announced a further United States investment of $298 million in the region.

title: SEARCH CONTINUES IN DAKOTA KILLING
description: Nearly a month after two United States marshals were killed in a shootout near here, Federal agents continue to scour the snowswept prairie of central North Dakota for a 63-year-old farmer and antitax fanatic who has vowed he will not be taken alive.

title: ART THAT COMMENTS ON THE FATE OF THE EARTH
description: The sci-fi vision of a plague of babies, raining down from the heavens onto a plain old house in Anywhere, U.S.A., is not one to warm the cockles of the heart. One, two, even three babies at a time are tolerable, but not a couple of dozen, particularly when they are nasty little brutes more than twice life-size and come in poisonous shades of mauve and blue. This is the fantasy fleshed (you should pardon the expression) out by Sandy Skoglund, a painter and photographer, in an installation called ''Maybe Babies'' at the Leo Castelli Gallery, 420 West Broadway (through March 26).

title: VLADIMIR ASHKENAZY'S DUAL LIFE EXPANDS HIS RANGE
description: In his current swing through America, Vladimir Ashkenazy has been showing us both old skills and new. Next Saturday night at Carnegie Hall he will play the piano - the activity on which his reputation is based. But he has been conducting as well, on this tour both in Philadelphia and Cleveland. Four new recordings for London represent Mr. Ashkenazy's new dual life in music, and all are in their separate ways remarkable.

title: New York Makes A Dent in Crime
description: One of the most persistent urban ills - crime - seems to be responding to treatment in New York City. After several years of sometimes sharp increases, the Police Department said last week that reports of serious incidents dropped 5.1 percent in 1982.

title: Carol J. Shappiro Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Shappiro of Passaic, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Joan Shappiro, to David Michael Wainland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Wainland of Yonkers. Miss Shappiro is secretary to the publisher of Vogue magazine in New York. Her fiance is an electronics engineer with the Federal Aviation Administration Technical Center in Pomona, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: SALVADORANS PLAN 2-TRACK CAMPAIGN TO DEFEAT REBELS
description: El Salvador's armed forces, prodded by the Reagan Administration, are planning a major drive to destroy guerrilla base camps and to separate civilians from the guerrillas, according to Salvadoran and United States officials.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SUGARING TIME By Kathryn Lasky. Photographs by Christopher G. Knight. Unpaged. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co. $10.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: Circumvention
description: To the Business Editor: Earlier this year, the Federal Reserve Board gave the BankAmerica Corporation permission to acquire the Charles Schwab Corporation. As a result, a commercial bank can now engage in retail brokerage services.

title: SAN FRANCISCO ROLLS OUT RED CARPET FOR CONVENTION SITE PANEL
description: The site selection committee for the Democratic Party's 1984 convention was wined and dined here this weekend as members began a national tour to study facilities and financial offers of the five cities competing for the Presidential nominating session.

title: FRESH INSIGHTS INTO STANDARD WORKS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently on music and musicians.

title: LIBRARY MUSICALES
description: Libraries aren't just for reading; these days, especially on Long Island, they double as centers of all cultural trades. Today, music takes over the stacks, with a varied schedule of free concerts on tap throughout the Island. For example, at 1:30 P.M. Bob Campi, baritone, sings and talks about opera at the Jericho Public Library on Merry Lane; Dennis Lee, pianist, performs at 2:30 P.M. at the Lowenstein Public Library in Long Beach, at 111 West Park Avenue, and the violinist Marjorie Kransberg, winner of the Great Neck Symphony's 1981 Young Artists Concerto Competition, plays at the Great Neck Library, Bayview Avenue, at 3:15 P.M.

title: DANCE: URIS BAHR GROUP AT RIVERSIDE CHURCH
description: Victoria Uris and Jill Bahr are choreographers with an interest in collaboration. That's unusual enough in itself. But given the fact that Miss Uris, formerly a Paul Taylor dancer, is a modern dance choreographer and Miss Bahr works in a ballet-influenced idiom, the collaboration seems even more unlikely. It worked, however, in the debut performance of Uris/Bahr and Dancers on Thursday at Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: COMING TO TERMS WITH A CONTRACTOR
description: TO many homeowners, the arrival of spring also means the arrival of ''fixup time'' around the house - and in many cases this will mean hiring a contractor to do roofing, painting and carpentry or to make other major improvements and repairs. Unfortunately, such arrangements can all too often lead to unexpected, and usually unnecessary, exasperation and expense, and sometimes result in unpleasant lawsuits.

title:
GARDENING;
CONTAINER-GROWTH PLANTS MAY BE TRICKY
description: JUST how quickly we will be able to go about the business of spring planting will depend on the weather during the remaining weeks of March. The month came in pretty much like a lamb, but who can tell whether it will remain that way or turn leonine as the days go by. Even the television weathermen have been hedging on their forecasts after experiencing this winter's unusual weather.

title: Angler for All Seasons
description: DOZENS of friends of Lee Wulff, champion of the trout and the Atlantic salmon and the world's best-known sport fisherman, gathered at the Angler's Club in Manhattan Friday night to pay him homage.

title: SCHOOL BUS STEP QUESTION: WHO'LL TAKE THE NEXT STEP?
description: Since last November, a couple of dozen newly delivered school buses, each costing about $27,000, have been languishing in school garages across New York State, awaiting a decision by manufacturers and state and local officials on what to do about the bottom steps: they're too high.

title: 'ON APPROVAL' A DELICIOUS PERIOD PIECE
description: Public television's ''Masterpiece Theater'' does an unusual turn this evening, on WNET/Channel 13 at 9, with a one-night stand entitled ''On Approval.'' Instead of the usual multi-part series, more often than not a dramatization of a novel, the showcase of imports is offering a production of a three-act play by Frederick Lonsdale. Of course, this being a membership-drive period for publictelevision stations, the intermissions between the acts provide convenient opportunities for imploring viewers to send in money. Even the urbane Alistair Cooke gets into the act. Dressed in a tuxedo and seated at a piano for this occasion - he is a fairly accomplished amateur jazz pianist - he segues into the first intermission with a comment on ''the Administration,'' presumably President Reagan's, and the assertion that says, in effect, ''if you like this kind of program, from now on you're going to have to pay for it.'' Mr. Cooke's heretofore impeccably neutral facade is unexpectably ruffled.

title: Rosberg on Pole
description: Keke Rosberg's first-day qualifying time held up today, putting his Williams car on the pole for Sunday's Brazilian Grand Prix, the opening race of the Formula One season. The Finnish driver clocked 1 minute 34.52 seconds on the 3.125-mile course, which nobody could top today.

title: 4th Man Held in Rape On Barroom Pool Table
description: The fourth man accused of taking part in the rape of a woman on a barroom pool table was taken into custody today and held in $50,000 bail.

title: Modified 'Freeze' Clears First Test
description: The Senate might reject it and President Reagan, a White House spokesman vowed, would certainly ignore it. Nonetheless, a resolution that in essence urges Washington and Moscow to start turning their Abombs into plowshares may be adopted by the House this week.

title: A Long String Is Attached To Jobs Bill
description: By week's end, only William O'Connell, president of the U.S. League of Savings Institutions, seemed to be maintaining his cool about the rider holding up Senate passage of a recession-relief jobs bill.

title: R.D. Baum, a Physician, Marries Sandra B. Busch
description: Sandra Beverley Busch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Busch of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Richard David Baum, son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Baum of Passaic, N.J. Rabbi Burt Segal performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel.

title: In Translation
description: To the Editor:

title: SEVEN DAYS OF DECISION: WHY MRS. BURFORD QUIT
description: Spirited and seemingly optimistic, Anne McGill Burford stated in front of aides on Wednesday evening, March 2, that she intended to fight to remain the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: DETROIT CENTERCHANGES HANDS
description: At its grand opening five years ago, it was hoped that Detroit's gleaming Renaissance Center hotel and office complex would spark a wave of new downtown growth. But the $356 million development proved to be an only child and a sickly one, and last week its parent, the Ford Motor Company, gave it up for adoption.

title: CONNIE DESMOND
description: Connie Desmond, who broadcast Brooklyn Dodger baseball games in the 1940's and 1950's with Red Barber, died last Thursday in Toledo, Ohio. He was 75 years old. Mr. Desmond is survived by his wife, Virginia; a sister, Bette; a son, Jim; a daughter, Cathy, and three grandchildren.

title:
ANTIQUES;
PRE-1840 ITEMS TO BE SHOWN
description: FOR many collectors, the pleasure of attending the annual Old Wethersfield Antiques Show begins as soon as they turn off the highway. To get to the show, visitors drive along mood-setting roads lined on either side by restored 17th-century, 18th-century and early 19th-century homes and other old village structures.

title: THE PUBLISHER WITH AN URGE TO CONDUCT
description: Some 20 years ago, Gilbert Kaplan, who was to become the founder, president and editor-in-chief of ''Institutional Investor,'' a financial magazine, heard the late Leopold Stokowski conduct Gustav Mahler's Symphony No. 2 (''Resurrection''), and the experience made a profound impression upon him. He had no training as a professional musician, but as time went on, Mr Kaplan came to feel that he had to conduct the vast and difficult work. In 1979, he decided to proceed.

title: The Poles Fan a Flickering Flame
description: Solidarity, the outlawed independent union that embodied the hopes of millions of Poles for freedom, has a hardier life than the military-led Government bargained for when it sought to snuff out the organization with martial law and replace it with officially sanctioned unions.

title: Clarice Rote Plans May Marriage to Michael Starr
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Rote of Greenwich, Conn., and Santa Fe, N.M., of the engagement of their daughter, Clarice Margaret Constance Rote, to Michael Morrill Starr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Parrish Starr of Bernardsville, N.J., and Mill Reef, Antigua, West Indies. A May wedding is planned.

title: GUARANTEES AND HOW THEY WORK
description: WHEN you are selling your house, how much is it worth to you to be g uaranteed a buyer? Would you be willing to pay 10, 15 or maybe 20 p ercent of the sale price?

title: SEMINARY MAKING WAY FOR A SUBDIVISION
description: WHEN the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark purchased Darlington, t he 1,100-acre country estate of George Crocker, the railroad scion, i n 1926 the price was $478,488.41.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 24 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 2 4 28 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 3 2 18 MISTRAL'S DAUGHTER, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $15.95.) The art world of the 20's and the fashion industry of the 80's. 4 3 18 2010: ODYSSEY TWO, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) A continuation of the tale begun in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' 5 6 5 FLOATING DRAGON, by Peter Straub. (Putnam, $15.95.) An unspeakable horror invades a suburban commuter town. 6 9 4 ELLIS ISLAND, by Fred Mustard Stewart. (Morrow, $15.95.) Five young immigrants and the fortunes that await them in America at the turn of the century. 7 5 28 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $15.95.) A continuation of the saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization begun in ''The Clan of the Cave Bear.''

title: BY SHIRLEY HAZZARD
description: Each year the travelers set out in millions to score and circle the globe - soaring and roaring over seas and continents, weaving through landscapes and towns, scarcely slackening pace in temples, museums and shops, scaling mountains, scouring catacombs, crossing deserts and glaciers; intersecting one another, unseeing, at stations and airports as in some immense and intricate dance.

title: THE 'FOLLY' OF THE MX MISSILE
description: Adm. Stansfield Turner, U.S.N., retired, Director of Central Intelligence from 1977 to 1981, is a consultant and lecturer on international affairs.The United States has reached a watershed in its nuclear defense strategy. President Reagan and Congress are trying to decide what to do about the MX, the new intercontinental ballistic missile that is larger, more expensive, more powerful and more accurate than anything in our military arsenal. The issue, however, goes beyond the costs and proficiency of a new weapons system. The question is whether deploying the MX would enhance our security or detract from it.

title: KEAN SEEKING TO MATCH FLORIO ON E.P.A. ISSUE
description: TRENTON GOVERNOR KEAN stood on the steps of the Capitol in Washington last week and called for the resignation of Anne McGill Burford as head of the Federal Envionmental Protection Agency.

title: VICHYSSOISE
description: To the Editor:

title: MY PARIS
description: Changes in Paris? Like all European capitals, the city has of course undergone certain changes, the most conspicuous being the appearance of herds of tall buildings beyond the ancient gates. Old districts like Passy, peculiarly gripping in their dinginess, are almost unrecognizable today with their new apartment houses and office buildings, most of which would suit a Mediterranean port better than Paris. It's no easy thing to impose color on the dogged northern gray, the native Parisian grisaille, flinty, foggy, dripping and for most of the year devoid of any brightness. The gloom will have its way with these new immeubles, too, you may be sure of that. When Verlaine wrote that the rain fell into his heart as it did upon the city (referring to almost any city in the region) he wasn't exaggerating a bit. As a onetime resident of Paris (I arrived in 1948), I can testify to that. New urban architecture will find itself ultimately powerless against the grisaille. Parisian gloom is not simply climatic, it is a spiritual force that acts not only on building materials, on walls and rooftops but also on your character, your opinions and judgments. It is a powerful astringent.

title: AT RUTGERS, THE GLORY THAT WAS HAARLEM; NEW BRUNSWICK A new museum with a great deal of potential is the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Museum on campus at Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey, in New Brunswick. The spaces are both distinctive and unpretentious. The permanent collection is rich in domains - above all that of the French 19th-century print - that are not often so well and so thoroughly studied. The public is young and lively. What could be more auspicious?
description: For its inaugural show, the museum chose to present ''Haarlem: The Seventeenth Century.'' The guest curator is Dr. Frima Fox Hofrichter, herself a recent Rutgers alumna, the consultant is Dr. Egbert Havekamp-Begemann of New York University, and the subject is ideally apt for a town that has had close Dutch ties since the year 1766.

title: CINEMATIC DRAMA AT MCCARTER
description: PRINCETON CHEKHOV wrote comedies, not dour dramas, we're told all too often, although what we see, even more often, is quite the contrary. In the McCarter Theater Company production of ''The Three Sisters,'' which runs through next Sunday, Nagle Jackson, the director, has taken the comedy part seriously.

title: The Nonaligned Spread the Blame
description: Extending hospitality last week to leaders of 101 countries professing nonalignment, India garlanded New Delhi with flowers and removed street beggars and monkey tamers. But Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's efforts to steer the organization away from the anti-American tilt favored by her predecessor as chairman, Cuba's Fidel Castro, met only partial success in a final resolution that stressed the third world's urgent need for financial help.

title: NORTH CAROLINA UPSET BY 91-84
description: With 10 seconds remaining in overtime, Dereck Whittenburg hugged Coach Jim Valvano and lifted him off the floor. Whittenburg had reason to be happy. Because of his clutch play, North Carolina State upset North Carolina, 91-84, today in the semifinals of the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament. Toward the end of overtime, Whittenburg scored 11 of the Wolfpack's 13 points in a span of 1 minute 46 seconds.

title: B. and B.
description: To the Editor:

title: Legally Illegal
description: A group of California doctors, unnamed, were reported to have raised $2.5 million last December to buy three brothels in Winnemucca, Nev. A broker who represented the doctors defended the deal as ''one that makes a lot of sense financially.''

title: 30 ON ITALIAN JUDICIAL PANEL MAY FACE CHARGES
description: Thirty of the 32 members of a council that oversees Italy's judiciary have been informed that they are under investigation for suspected embezzlement of public funds.

title: BEHIND THE FACADE OF FLORENCE

title: Ultimate Tax Dodge
description: It's not that Raymond Garland minded paying taxes - he just felt he shouldn't have to help the Government collect them. When a Chicago jury agreed last week, finding Mr. Garland not guilty of failing to file Federal tax returns for several years, the prosecutor said the verdict was ''beyond belief.'' The judge, who had cautioned jurors that they could find him not guilty only if he had a ''good faith, reasonable belief'' in his defense - that it was up to the Government to collect what he owed, and not up to him to volunteer it - said Mr. Garland was ''very lucky.'' Mr. Garland, incidentally, said he wouldn't be filing this year either.

title: Freedom Rider's Victory
description: Walter Bergman gets around in a wheelchair these days because he tried to travel by bus 22 years ago, and a Federal judge ruled in Michigan last week that the Government is responsible. Mr. Bergman contended in a suit that Federal investigators knew that a busload of Freedom Riders would be attacked by Ku Klux Klansmen in Alabama and did nothing to prevent the assault. He and others were beaten by a mob as they attempted to test compliance with court ordered integration of interstate transportation. Mr. Bergman, now 84 years old, said the beating left him permanently crippled. Damages will be set separately.

Mr. Torrey says the shock of the news hit him so fast and hard that he didn't even think to ask which of his two daughters was dead.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: GROUP CHARTER FLIGHTS
description: Travel by chartered jetliner has become an increasingly significant fixture on the American vacation scene. It isn't to everyone's taste, and when something goes wrong, the dreams of several hundred passengers can quickly turn to acute distress. But with each added year of experience, charter operations in general become smoother and offer some of the best travel bargains around. In short, charter travel, predicated on cramming a plane with the fullest load possible and thus minimizing the price each passenger must pay, has made it possible for hundreds of thousands of Americans to afford vacations that, previously, were far beyond their means.

title: WHY PAY FOR MORE WATTAGE THAN YOU'RE LIKELY TO USE
description: ''Is it true,'' a reader wants to know, ''that you need at least 100 watts for good sound? That's what a reliable hi-fi dealer told me.'' Well, for one thing, there's a seeming contradiction in terms, for no reliable hi-fi dealer would say any such thing flatout as a general principle. Offhand, it sounds more like a sharpie conning a customer into spending some extra money. But then again, the dealer may be responding quite properly to the circumstances and requirements of this particular customer: the size of his living room, his listening habits and musical predilections. Since none of these variables were specified - or even alluded to - in the query, I have no way of telling whether my correspondent was given proper advice or about to be bilked. All of which points up the fact that power ratings continue to perplex many listeners, aside from tempting eager dealers to hike the sales ticket for the unwary. The price of equipment rises sharply with increased wattage, so that added power - among other things - means greater dealer profits. But of course there is no point in paying for wattage you're never likely to use. So, at the risk of revisiting familiar ground, it may be well to review the basic guidelines for finding the hi-fi power rating suitable for any particular person and place.

I'm sure that the Stratford toll booth was deliberately chosen because of light commuter traffic at that location.

title: WEST VA. WINNER IN FINAL
description: Greg Jones led a 6-0 spurt late in the second half today, enabling West Virginia to pull away to an 86-78 victory over Temple that gave the Mountaineers their first Atlantic 10 tournament championship.

title: RAISING CAIN
description: Not content with straightening out the English-speaking world on the use of language, this department is branching out into issuing ukases on biblical allusions.

title: GRANT SPURS HISTORICAL GROUP
description: THE folks at the Huntington Historical Society are breathing a bit easier this week. Their ambitious plans to expand the society's programming and physical plant got a boost when the National Endowment for hte Humanities gave the group a $128,562 challenge grant.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: WHEN people move with their jobs, they often cart along the accoutrements of their professional lives. One of the more unusual has to be those belonging to Dr. Saroja Bharati, new head of the department of pathology at the Deborah Heart and Lung Center in Browns Mills. She and her colleague, Dr. Maurice Lev, arrived in New Jersey several months ago from Chicago, along with 2,000 preserved human hearts in jars and buckets.

title: AFRICA'S EDEN IN A DESERT
description: In fantasies for or by children, it is not uncommon to be transported suddenly, as if through a trapdoor, from a place that is forbidding and frightening to a world that is blessedly green and tranquil. The Okavongo Delta is a little like that: a pristine expanse of wetland wilderness surrounded by some of the most arid and difficult terrain in Africa south of the Sahara. Discovering the delta is like unwrapping a piece of fine porcelain that has been packed in straw or excelsior or rough burlap.

title: JOIE DE VIVRE OF MONTREAL
description: For a 150 years Montreal was the only world-class Canadian city. When Toronto was a place where a snail was something you stomped on in the garden and where wine and legs, both frog and female, were viewed with puritanical horror, Montreal was dishing them all up with elan. It was the financial center, the fur center, the gastronomic center, the center. That it is no longer unchallenged is not so much because of its own falling star as because of the rising stars of others. But for anyone who has ever lived there or spent time there, Montreal, with its mountain and rivers and history and ethnic mixture, will always be a special city: cosmopolitan, flavorsome, polyglot, vital, unique as a fingerprint.

title: Marriage Planned By Miss Schrader
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Cutler Schrader of Hingham, Mass., formerly of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Bear Schrader, to James Michael Bedell, son of Mary C. Miller of Tempe, Ariz., and James L. Bedell of Flagstaff, Ariz.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: AYOUNG couple from the Morris County community of Montville, Richard and Coleen Gamsby, have always been mindful of the environment. They've built birdhouses near their home and put out hay, apples and pears for the whitetail deer that roam the 16 acres of swampy woods behind the dog kennel that they own and operate. Their five hens produce the family's eggs and their wood stove is fueled by old logs and fallen trees.

title: LEARNING TO LIKE THE BUS
description: LAST Monday morning, on the first day of the strike that shut down the railroad in Connecticut, between 3,500 and 3,600 people were transported on 66 buses from 11 train stations to the Pelham Bay Park subway station in the Bronx for the ride into Manhattan.

title: 'TENDER MERCIES' STANDS OUT IN A FINE OFF-SEASON CROP
description: The season is out of joint. This is the time of year when distributors usually get rid of all of those movies they don't think are worth releasing in the prime moviegoing times of Christmas and the midsummer months. Yet there have been more new films of interest in the last few weeks than I can remember in any comparable period in a number of years.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: WOODSIDE
description: IN THE Breffni beauty salon on Roosevelt Avenue in the Woodside s ection of Queens, amid the scent of hair spray and the cheerful l ilt of Irish brogues, elderly women chat about the old country and a bout young nieces and nephews who will be coming over from Ireland t o take part in New York's St. Patrick's Day festivities this week.

title: REAGAN, IN TALK ON EDUCATION, CALLS FOR ENDING DEPARTMENT
description: President Reagan today charged that the Department of Education had soured the nation's ''love affair with learning'' and should be abolished in favor of a return to the basic elements of education.

title: HANDLING ELEVENTH-HOUR TAX SNAGS
description: WITH the deadline for filing tax returns just a month away, most p eople are scurrying to tie up loose ends so they can get their r eturns in on time. While most of the paperwork involves r ecapitulating (or embroidering upon) the details of one's financial l ife during 1982, there is still time for one perfectly legal m aneuver that can save self-employed people who failed to set up a K eogh retirement plan by year-end a bundle on their taxes. Below are d etails on how Simplified Employee Pension plans work, as well as a dvice on how to handle some other knotty tax problems -such as lost W 2 forms and other financial records -that often pop up at the last m inute.

title: WHERE THE EXPERTS CHOOSE TO EAT
description: Of all the restaurants you have visited, which ones would you recommend to travelers? Nine leading food writers offer their guidance

title: Arms: Morality And Materiel
description: While President Reagan last week denounced Moscow as ''the focus of evil in the modern world,'' Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger concentrated on a more tangible kind of Soviet power, asserting that the Russians were bent on ''world domination.'' The Pentagon released an updated assessment of Russian conventional and nuclear military forces, packed with what were said to be hurriedly declassified intelligence gleanings. The booklet described Russian efforts to launch monster missile-firing submarines and orbiting laser beams, in addition to new airplane types including a manned strategic bomber. It said little, and in some cases nothing, about comparative American strengths.

title: EXPERT SEES LITTLE DANGER IN PERMITTING CON ED TO BURN COAL
description: An expert on the health hazards of air pollution testified Tuesday that the Consolidated Edison Company's plan to burn coal instead of oil in three of its New York City generating plants would have no significant effects on health.

title: FEAR AND CONFUSION IN COURT PLAGUE ELDERLY CRIME VICTIMS
description: An 89-year-old woman sat in a wheelchair next to the witness stand in State Supreme Court in Manhattan and, during questioning over two days, pleaded with the judge and the defense attorney to let her go home.

title: DEMETRIUS LIVES ON IN IRELAND
description: SOME long-forgotten military planner called it Operation Demetrius in honor of the warrior-king of Macedonia, who, it was said, ''conquered but never ruled.''

title: JAZZ CONCERT: 17-PIECE BAND AT BLUE NOTE
description: A 17-piece jazz band jointly led by the drummer Jimmy Madison and Angel Rangelov, a Bulgarian composer and arranger, began a series of Monday night appearances last week at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street. The performance indicated that the group may be able to set itself apart from the cloud of similarity that covers most contemporary big bands.

title: OFFICE FOR THE AREA OPENED BY DELBELLO
description: AS workmen put the finishing touches on his new office in White Plains, former County Executive Alfred B. DelBello dropped in last week and talked about his new role as the state's Lieutenant Governor.

title: MOVES ON CAPITOL HILL IRK CHINA
description: China today condemned as violations of its sovereignty two resolutions before the United States Congress referring to its relations with Taiwan.

title: WAGING A TRADE WAR OVER DATA
description: EACH day, from offices and construction sites in 100 countries, e mployees of Dresser Industries tap into the company's central c omputers in the United States. Through a complex network of t erminals and satellites, the data base spews forth a torrent of u pto-the-minute design information, financial data, personnel files a nd inventory listings - all crucial to operations of the giant oil a nd gas equipment maker.

title:
GARDENING;
CONTAINER-GROWTH PLANTS MAY BE TRICKY
description: JUST how quickly we will be able to go about the business of spring planting will depend on the weather during the remaining weeks of March. The month came in pretty much like a lamb, but who can tell whether it will remain that way or turn leonine as the days go by. Even the television weathermen have been hedging on their forecasts after experiencing this winter's unusual weather.

title: BELGIUM'S CHOCOLATE PASSION
description: As night falls and street lamps glow along the foggy boulevards of Belgium's capital, crowds of people make their way home from work, stopping along the way to shop for the evening meal that usually ends with chocolate. The sweets are bought in supermarkets where entire aisles are devoted to candy bars, in neighborhood bakeries that almost invariably have their own confectionery counters and in tinseled downtown shops that sell the filled chocolates known in Belgium as pralines and devoured year round, not just on Valentine's or Mother's Day.

title: A CLASH OF SWORDS WILL END SEASON
description: FOR the Hartman Theater season's final production, a 55-year-old operetta adapted from a 139-year-old novel, which takes place 356 years ago, will be revised rather than revived - with contemporary orchestrations, all-out swordplay and an accent on youth.

title: O, GREECE
description: There are two sights the traveler in Europe never forgets. One is that first glimpse of Chartres Cathedral from five miles away, solitary and seeming to sail the wheat fields like a leviathan. The other is the Parthenon just after sunrise. Athens is slate gray with dusk and smog; high above it, pricked by first light, the columns soar, dwarfing even the Acropolis itself. No photograph can prepare the visitor for the actuality; it sandbags the senses. The heart is seized. And far off behind the temple and beyond Piraeus, the Aegean is molten silver.

title: G.M. Is Recalling 491,000 Cars
description: The General Motors Corporation says it is recalling nearly half the Chevrolet Chevette and Pontiac T-1000 models built from 1980-82 to repair a carburetor problem that could lead to engine fires.

title: RESEARCHERS WORK ON STICKY POTATO THAT TRAPS INSECTS
description: Plant breeders at Cornell University are trying to develop potato plants with sticky hairs that trap insect pests, causing them to starve to death.

title: NO KNOWN ADDRESS
description: IT all began on a whim, the way so many important things in our lives start. When the lease on my apartment expired, I moved in temporarily with a friend, another middle-aged, divorced executive, while I searched for a new place. One night, I arrived home to find a note telling me he had been called out of town. For a reason I will never understand, I had selected that particular day to lose the extra set of keys he had given me.

title: Elazar Demeshulam Marries Miss Fein
description: The marriage of Lorie Lynn Fein, daughter of Mrs. Robert K. Ruskin of New York, to Elazar Demeshulam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Demeshulam of Nahariya, Israel, took place in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday. Rabbi Asher Murciano performed the ceremony at the Fairview Country Club.

title: Karen Weiss Is Married
description: Karen Judy Weiss, a senior at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University, was married yesterday to Frederic H.J. Hirsch, a lawyer for the Motion Picture Export Association of America.

title: A LOVING FACELIFT
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission had nothing but praise and congratulations for the plans to redo the facade of the building at 740 Madison Avenue, between 64th and 65th Streets. The commission, in a letter to the 740 Madison Avenue Corporation, which owns the structure, said the redesign of the lower floors and repair of the crumbling stonework above ''unifies the visual appearance of the building and greatly enhances its protected original features.''

title: DRUNKEN DRIVING CASE DIVIDES TOWN
description: On Mother's Day 1978, Debbie Irwin, then 19 years old, was heading home from Springfield with her family when an automobile driven by Donald Fuller careered around a curve on Route 32, rammed into her Toyota and shattered her life.

title: TITLE ALL BUT MISS MCKINNEY'S
description: Capping a spectacular week of skiing in which she won three races in a row, Tamara McKinney today virtually clinched the women's overall World Cup championship.

title: Karla W. Lawrence Is Wed to Richard A. Keating
description: Karla Winberg Lawrence, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Lawrence of West Islip, L.I., was married yesterday to Richard Alan Keating, son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard P. Keating of Ridgewood, N.J. The ceremony was performed in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Anthony Dalla Villa.

title: BILLIONS OF DOLLARS AND NEW IDEAS
description: Following are excerpts from ''Hazardous Waste in America,'' by Dr. Samuel S. Epstein, Lester O. Brown and Carl Pope, published by Sierra Club Books, San Francisco. IMPROPER disposal of hazardous wastes is now America's No.1 e nvironmental problem. Although this problem only recently captured p ublic attention, it has resulted from decades of negligence and l ack of foresight.

title: A PAINTER IN THREE DIMENSIONS
description: WESTFIELD REINVENTING the wheel was only part of Albert Green's struggle to become a potter. In the late 1940's, not only were professional potters' wheels commercially unavailable for an artist's studio, but so were books, courses and sources of supplies.

title: A POLISH DIRECTOR SCANS SOCIETY'S MORAL CONFLICT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Annette Insdorf's latest book, ''Indelible Shadows: Film and the Holocaust,'' will be published in May by Random House.

title: BENEATH LIFE'S FACADE; Electronic Leash
description: In Albuquerque, as elsewhere, overworked probation officers are unable to keep up with minor offenders the judge wants supervised. The solution, inevitably, is high-tech.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: 5 Rescued After Boat Sinks Off Montauk Pt.
description: Five men were rescued today after rough seas battered and sank their fishing boat off Long Island, the Coast Guard said.

title: A CLASH OF INDIVIDUAL AND STATE
description: WILL the theme of a play written in 442 B.C. prove timely or tedious to local audiences? That's a question facing the ever-enterprising Studio Theater in Lindenhurst where a version of Sophocles' Greek tragedy "Antigone" - which the director Jeanne DeVito said could take place "anywhere" and is set in "no period" in a version French playwright Jean Anouilh adapted during World War II - is in rehearsal for Friday's opening. (It will run through April 16.)

title: DELHI PARLEY ENDS WITH U.S. ASSAILED
description: A five-day conference of 101 third world nations and organizations ended here today with the issuing of declarations that ranged from Cuban- and Palestinian-backed denunciations of the United States to appeals for disarmament and economic cooperation.

title: Natural Gas Woes
description: To the Business Editor: ''Natural Gas: A Winter of Discontent'' (Feb.6) raises many interesting points. But in focusing on Northwest Central Pipeline, you ought to address the fact that while Northwest acquired the Cities Service Gas Company, Occidental Petroleum retained the Cities Service gas reserves, enjoying a pretax gain of $152 million.

title: WHEN NATION BUILDING AND TRIBALISM CLASH
description: To the Editor:

title: Norway to Open Border With the Soviet Union
description: Norway will reopen its border with the Soviet Union, which has been closed for nearly 20 years, to local traffic, according to a Foreign Office spokesman.

title: REAGAN AND THE COURT
description: In considering who should be President from Jan. 20, 1985, until Jan. 20, 1989, it may be useful to remember that whoever occupies the White House during these last years of the 1980's is likely to nominate a majority of the members of the Supreme Court of the United States.

title: STAR ROLES FOR THE OTHERWISE SUPERNUMERARY ONION
description: ONIONS are both the most widely used and the most overlooked of our vegetables. They are indispensible as flavoring agents, yet seldom given starring roles in the kitchen. We use them in soup, stews and sauces, in salads and sandwiches. Yet we rarely think of serving them on their own.

title:
DINING OUT;
A BIT OF SHANGHAI IN HARTSDALE
description: IT may be hard to believe, but another restaurant offering Chinese cuisine has opened on Central Avenue. And, proving once more the versatility of Chinese cuisine, much of its characteristic cooking, that of Shanghai, is new to the county.

title: THE FIGHT OVER SHOREHAM IS ALSO A FIGHT FOR PUBLIC OPINION
description: OPINIONS differ on how influential a broad coalition of Long Island groups has been in bringing Peter F. Cohalan, the Suffolk County Executive, the County Legislature and other elected officials around to the view that the Shoreham nuclear power plant should not open.

title: LIBYANS' PURCHASE OF HOME REVIEWED
description: ENGLEWOOD THE State Department has decided that the purchase of a house here by the Libyan Government falls within the purview of the Foreign Missions Act.

title: METAMORPHIC MAGICIAN
description: FROM THE FIRST NINE Poems 1946-1976. By James Merrill. 362 pp. New York: Atheneum. Cloth, $20. Paper, $10.95.THE CHANGING LIGHT AT SANDOVER Including the Whole of The Book of Ephraim, Mirabell's Books of Number, Scripts for the Pageant, and a New Coda, The Higher Keys. By James Merrill. 560 pp. New York: Atheneum. Cloth, $25. Paper, $12.95.JAMES MERRILL Essays in Criticism. Edited by David Lehman and Charles Berger. 329 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $22.50.

title: A Ride to Test The Fearless
description: Coney Island's parachute jump may be but a fond memory (though its skeleton still stands), but for thrill seekers who might like to equal its sensations, the opportunity is at hand.

title: Boxer Is Indicted
description: Tony Braxton, the middleweight boxer, has been indicted, according to the Camden County Prosecutor's office in New Jersey, in connection with a shooting incident along a city street last summer. A grand jury charged Braxton with aggravated assault with a deadly weapon, possession of a gun for unlawful purposes and possession of a gun without a permit. He is scheduled to fight Curtis Parker of Philadelphia tomorrow, and boxing officials said the indictment would not affect the bout.

title: JAZZ: QUINTET AT VANGUARD, IN LATIN TIME
description: The quintet that the Cuban saxophonist Paquito D'Rivera has brought into the Village Vanguard for a week's run through today is a brilliantly polished, tightly knit ensemble that gets jazz back to its basic condition of being hot. Mr. D'Rivera's combination of strong Latin rhythms and jazz sensibility is tremendously compelling, not only as a setting for his own solos on alto and soprano saxophone but also as a colorful, volatile musical unit.

title:
CAMERA;
A BEGINNER'S GUIDE TO USING VIDEO CAMERAS
TENSION BUBBLES IN THE BUREAUCRACY
description: In the view of some authorities, the resignation last week of Anne McGill Burford as head of the Environmental Protection Agency raised the question of whether President Reagan's promise to reduce the burden of Government has led some of his lieutenants to ignore the lawful mandates of Congress.

title: VERMONT LEADERS SPLIT ON BUDGET'S PROSPECTS
description: Gov. Richard A. Snelling, a Republican, and the Republican-dominated Legislature are disputing the outlook for the state's economy and revenue.

title: Fritz Busch
description: To the Editor:

title: WESCHESTER JOURNAL
description: DR. Louis J. Camuti, who died in 1981 at the age of 87, was a veterinarian who lived for many years in Mount Vernon. He was, however, no ordinary veterinarian: his practice was limited to making house calls to cats. He drove to patients throughout the New York City area in a car with license plates that read CAT. He was also something of a celebrity, a dapper, witty man who wrote two books (''Park Avenue Vet,'' a reference to his many clients on Manhattan's Park Avenue, and ''All My Patients Are Under the Bed''), gave frequent interviews and loved to tell anecdotes about how he had ''tried all my life to put the cat on a pedestal.''

title: COLLEGE REPUBLICANS OPEN A DRIVE AGAINST STUDENT ACTIVIST GROUPS
description: The College Republican National Committee has started a campaign against a group of student organizations throughout the country that advocate such things as environmental and consumer protection and safety in the workplace.

title: NATURAL FRIEND
description: W.H.HUDSON A Biography. By Ruth Tomalin. Illustrated. 314 pp. Distributed by Harper & Row. Winchester, Mass.: Faber & Faber, $19.95.

title: GOSSAGE ON ROAD TO $1 MILLION
description: Rich Gossage stands on the threshold of becoming the first $1 million-a-year relief pitcher. How does he feel about that prospect?

title: HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE
description: Exactly half a century ago Ely Culbertson returned to New York from London amid a flourish of trumpets, not all of them self-blown. He and his team-mates, Josephine Culbertson, Theodore Lightner and Mike Gottlieb, had defeated the top-ranked British team by a large margin to win the first Schwab Cup, a trophy donated by a celebrated steel magnate.

title: Dr. Jean Hytier Is Dead at 84; Expert on French Literature
description: Dr. Jean Hytier, professor emeritus of French at Columbia University and an authority on French literature, died Friday of lymphoma at his home in Manhattan. He was 84 years old.

title: CAMPUS 'FREE SPEECH'
description: On Feb. 15, a standing-room-only audience of students and the public came to hear the United Nations delegate, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, deliver the first of the annual Jefferson memorial lectures on the University of California's Berkeley campus. Before they left, they watched the First Amendment take a bad beating.

title: WHO DECIDES WHEN A JUDGE IS OUT OF ORDER?
description: Who should judge a judge - his colleagues on the bench or the public? That is the issue underlying the misconduct proceedings against Alan I. Friess, the former Criminal Court judge who once asked spectators and litigants to vote on which of two men in a harassment case he should believe and on another occasion tossed a coin to determine how long a pickpocket should spend in jail.

title: CENTRAL AMERICA UNREADY FOR MASSIVE AID
description: To the Editor:

title:
ANTIQUES;
DRUMTHWACKET 'REJECTS' TO BE SOLD
description: PRINCETON THE furniture that the Governor of New Jersey did not want in the state's executive mansion will be auctioned this week. The furniture was bought for the public rooms of the mansion, Drum-thwacket, by the Morven-Drum-thwacket Corporation, which was formed by the New Jersey Historical Society with the support of a citizens' committee.

title: ASSORTED STORIES
description: THE MAN WHO SOLD PRAYERS By Margaret Creal. 198 pp. New York: A Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book/

title: SUSAN E. WEYAND TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. John E. Weyand of Needham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Elizabeth Weyand; to William George Rhines Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rhines of Weston, Conn. A January wedding is planned. ''level playing field'' for the competition within the financial

title: Reagan Names Chapin To Committee on Arts
description: President Reagan has appointed Schuyler G. Chapin, dean of the school of arts at Columbia University, to the President's Committee on the Arts and the Humanities. Mr. Chapin is a former general manager of the Metropolitan Opera. In another announcement Friday, the White House said Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House of Representatives, had nominated Susan L. Davis, a New York advertising executive, as a committee member.

title: MY LONDON
description: I am not London born, but I have spent a large part of my life as a London perambulator, footing it from the unfashionable south to the north since I was a boy. In those years I felt myself to be a sort of Indian hunter, following a maze of brickish jungle paths from one native village to the next across mysterious frontiers, the most exciting one being the ancient Thames. I grew up kippered by smoke and fog from sulfurous Bermondsey to the lighter mists of high-minded Hampstead, with the tales of my Cockney mother in my head.

title: Carlyle
description: To the Editor: Travelers anticipating a visit to 24 Cheyne Walk, London -home of Thomas and Jane Welsh Carlyle and ''The House Where Jenny Was Kissed'' (Travel, Feb. 20) - can turn to the works of Virginia Woolf for a fascinating and irreverent glimpse of the meaning Cheyne Walk held for its two formidable Victorian inhabitants. In ''Great Men's Houses,'' one of six essays on The London Scene recently reissued by The Hogarth Press (London, 1982), Virginia Woolf takes the reader on a tour of Cheyne Walk to draw some remarkably contemporary conclusions.

title: 'GODOT' WORTH THE WAIT
description: TARRYTOWN EVERY theatergoer has to happen upon Samuel Beckett's ''Waiting For Godot,'' the play that, very simply, changed the way it was possible to perceive a play. It had its premiere in Paris in 1953; it was first seen in New York City in 1956.

title: Nicolette, on 71 for 209, Leads by 6 Shots
description: Every so often the fortunes of the pro golf tour churn up an unheralded struggler to the top of the field. Today one of them, Mike Nicolette, completed the third round of the Bay Hill Classic with a six-stroke lead.

title: Dangerous Mail
description: After a dog had put a letter carrier in the hospital, the postmaster in Asheville, N.C., adopted a system of color-coded mailbox stickers to alert his carriers: red stickers for ''dangerous'' dogs, yellow for ''other.''

title: N.Y.U. Names Director Of Institute of Fine Arts
description: James R. McCredie, an archeologist and classical scholar, has been named director of New York University's Institute of Fine Arts. Dr. McCredie first joined the institute faculty in 1963, just after receiving a Ph.D. in classical archeology from Harvard University. In 1970, the year he was appointed professor, he resigned to become director of the American School of Classical Studies at Athens.

title: Robin Howe to Wed Kiliaen Townsend
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel S. Howe of Farmington, Conn., and Sakonnet, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Howe, to @Kiliaen Van Rennselaer Townsend Jr., son of Mr. Townsend of Atlanta and the late Mary-Campbell Everett Townsend. An August wedding is planned.

title: Topics; Beneath Life's Fa,cade; The Interview Cure
description: The fun, or horror, of a press conference is that almost anything can happen. As in an unscripted drama, the chief actor can forget his proper lines, lose his head, or spectacularly depart from the norms of decorum.

title: FRANK FERREE
description: Frank Ferree, who spent more than 40 years helping the poor along the Mexican border and was twice nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize, died Thursday at Valley Baptist Medical Center in Harlingen. He was 86 years old.

title: TERROR AND A WOMAN
description: THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL By John le Carre. 430 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: HARDCORE ROCK: 2 BANDS
description: Hardcore couples the speed and harshness of punk-rock with its own ritual: slam-dancing. At the Brooklyn Zoo, which presented two California hardcore bands Thursday, slam-dancers greeted the headliner, Black Flag.

title: No Headline
description: 76ERS WIN BY 95-86 WITH A SEASON LOW

title: Arrests in Jerusalem
description: Jewish militants arrested early Friday morning had planned to take over the Temple Mount in Jerusalem where major Moslem shrines stand over the remains of King Solomon's Temple, the police said.

title: TO FIGHT TEEN-AGE PREGNANCY
description: Old ideas never die. Unlike old soldiers, they don't even fade away. It is in the service of an old idea that two Federal district judges have ruled against a regulation that Governmentfunded family-planning clinics notify parents of teenagers who obtain prescription contraceptives.

title: STERLING TO TRY AGAIN WITH A NONASPIRIN DRUG
description: For Sterling Drug Inc., the makers of Bayer aspirin, the recall of Johnson & Johnson's Tylenol last September presented an unexpected opportunity. Sterling had for years been trying unsuccessfully to break Tylenol's grip on the pain reliever market, and this sudden moment of vulnerability must have seemed just the right time for Sterling to try again.

title: Church in El Salvador Backs Early Elections
description: The Roman Catholic Church in El Salvador today supported the Government's decision to hold early elections in December and said it would oppose efforts ''to achieve peace through military means.''

title: Robertson Wins; Beardsley Hurt
description: Andy Robertson, a little-known member of the New York Road Runners Club, was a surprise winner in the third annual Manufacturers Hanover/Brooklyn Half Marathon yesterday.

title: GENERAL MILLS POST IS SEEN FOR RETAILER
description: Michael J. Boyle, the former president and chief executive of the Petrie Stores Corporation who departed after less than two-and-a-half months in those posts, is expected to be named executive vice president in charge of specialty retailing and furniture manufacturing operations of General Mills Inc.

title: U.S. ATTORNEY SAID TO ACT ON HIS OWN IN NOT PRESSING BURFORD CASE
description: The Justice Department says that neither the department nor the White House instructed a United States Attorney to disregard an order from the House of Representatives to prosecute Anne McGill Burford, then head of the Environmental Protection Agency, for contempt of Congress.

title: LYNCH CHALLENGES YOUNG MET PITCHERS
description: Ed Lynch, after pitching three innings against the St. Louis Cardinals today, issued a challenge to the young Mets' pitchers: He's looking for a starting job.

title: Paper Goods Output
description: Production of paper and paperboard, an important economic indicator, rose in the first two months of the year, the American Paper Institute said yesterday. Louis F. Laun, the group's president, said paper production rose 3 percent in January and February from a year earlier, while paperboard output rose 6 percent.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Friday in Business Day about oil and gas leases on Federal land for Santa Fe International, a Kuwait-owned company, incorrectly identified a Jewish organization and one of its officials. They were the American Jewish Committee and Alfred H. Moses, chairman of the organization's executive committee.

title: A SWITCHBOARD THAT IS JUSTLY FABLED
description: They look neither legendary nor remarkable, but simply middle-aged and neatly dressed. They sit at the switchboard for eight hours each day -more during international crises and snowstorms - and, with a practiced note of friendly firmness in their voice, answer each phone call, ''White House.''

title: CUOMO HOLDS A TIGHT REIN ON DECISIONS
description: In a variety of ways, Governor Cuomo has placed decision making in his new government largely in the hands of one person: Mario M. Cuomo.

title: N.C. STATE BEATS VIRGINIA FOR TITLE
description: If you looked at the records, the talent and the history, it seemed obvious North Carolina State had no business winning the 30th annual Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament. Obviously, the Wolfpack never looked.

title: B.A. DEGREE WORTH $329,000 IN EARNINGS
description: A bachelor's degree is worth $329,000 in extra lifetime earnings for today's young men and $142,000 for women, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: AMID SALVADORAN TURMOIL, A BLOW FOR DEMOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: FIVE-YEAR-OLDS NEED A FULL DAY IN SCHOOL
description: To the Editor:

title: Arab Delegation Plans Visit to London Friday
description: King Hassan II of Morocco has handed over the reins of a twice-postponed Arab League peace mission to Britain to King Hussein of Jordan, the Government said today.

title: TV: 'M.A.D.D.,' DRAMA FIGHTS DRUNKEN DRIVING
description: THE acronym marches on. We've had innumerable productions with letter collections such as ''S.W.A.T.'' or ''F.I.S.T.'' or ''M*A*S*H.'' Tonight at 9 on Channel 4, there is ''M.A.D.D.'' The explanation is thoughtfully contained in the subtitle: ''Mothers Against Drunk Drivers.''

title: 2 Egyptians Removed In a Cabinet Shuffle
description: Two Egyptian Cabinet members implicated in the corruption scandal of Esmat el-Sadat, the half-brother of the late President Anwar el-Sadat, have been removed from office.

title: Poison Found in Game
description: An ant poison that contaminated milk on Oahu last year has been found in game on the island of Lanai at levels unacceptable for human consumption, according to state officials. Levels of the pesticide heptachlor were found in three barred doves and one gray francolin near the Lanai airport. Trace amounts of the pesticide were found in a deer and four game birds on the island.

title: ATTENBOROUGH TOPS DIRECTORS' POLL
description: The Directors Guild of America has named Sir Richard Attenborough, who has acted in and directed films for 42 years, as the best motion-picture director of 1982 for his film biography ''Gandhi.''

title: DR. ROLAND I. GRAUSMAN
description: Dr. Roland I. Grausman, a surgeon for many years at the Hospital for Joint Diseases in Manhattan, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan.

title: REGIMES UNFIT FOR U.S. RESCUE
description: To the Editor:

title: MAYOR KOCH'S EVEN HAND ON JUDGESHIPS
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; How Analysts View the Dow
description: IS the correction finally closing in on the stock market like some cold, gray fog after all that sunshine? ''It's quite possible that the correction has started,'' Greg A. Smith, research chief at Prudential-Bache Securities, said Friday. ''I don't foresee any amazingly deep decline ahead for stock prices, but there are enough reasons around now to touch off a downturn.''

title: CRITICS CITE BANKS' AID IN ELECTIONS
description: Political action committees representing the banking industry, which is seeking repeal of a new law requiring that taxes be withheld on interest and dividend payments, contributed more than $3 million to the campaigns of most members of Congress, according to Federal Election Commission records.

title: 8 Guilty of Tax Fraud Through Use of 'Church'
description: Eight men, seven of them former Braniff Airways pilots and the eighth the self-proclaimed ''pope'' of the Basic Bible Church, were convicted in Federal District Court here of using the church as a tax dodge.

title: N.I.T. Selections Made
description: Fordham and Iona were among 32 teams named last night for the 46th National Invitation Tournament, which begins Wednesday. The first three rounds will be played on the campuses of the competing teams or at neutral sites.

title: WHAT MARX HID
description: On March 14, 1883, Karl Marx died in London. Today, a century later, the man and his ideas continue to arouse intense passions. To true believers, Marx is the messianic father of scientific socialism-concepts called Marxism or Communism. To many others, he is the prophet of an insidious doctrine of class conflict, revolution and economic egalitarianism. Proponents and opponents alike acknowledge his importance and the impact of his philosophy on our era.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Altschuler's Symphony

title: High-Flying Sparrow
description: A commodity whose price has risen dramatically in slightly more than two years is Rory Sparrow. A month ago, the Knicks sent $600,000 and Scott Hastings, a 6-foot-10-inch rookie center, to the Atlanta Hawks in exchange for the 6-2 point guard. On Dec. 19, 1980, the New Jersey Nets had acquired the former Villanova star from Scranton of the Continental Basketball Association for $5,000. So it seems that Sparrow's value in pro basketball terms has increased more than $600,000.

title: Disturbance Breaks Out In Black Area of Miami
description: At least 100 youths began throwing stones and bottles at the police in an unincorporated area near the Liberty City section of Miami Sunday night after officers broke up an outdoor party, officials said early today.

title: Nationwide Blackout Reported in El Salvador
description: A nationwide blackout struck El Salvador Sunday night, apparently caused by a rebel bomb that toppled a high-voltage transmission line, a power company employee said.

title: GREENWICH VILLAGE NEIGHBORS MOURNING A SLAIN SHOPKEEPER
description: Four daffodils were placed in the ring of the lock that held the steel door closed. The shop's owner, Roberta Kaplan, worried by a rash of robberies, had put in the door and an alarm system only a few weeks ago.

title: UNCERTAINTY ON MONEY DATA
description: The importance assigned by the financial markets to changes in the nation's money supply has varied widely in recent years and is still in a state of flux.

title: Benton & Bowles Adds To Beverage Account
description: Benton & Bowles, since 1981 an agency for some of the alcholic beverages marketed by the Joseph Garneau Company, on Friday became the beneficiary of a desire by the Brown-Forman Distillers subsidiary to consolidate its advertising.

title: SHAREHOLDER RESOLUTION RULE
description: When Frances Tyson, a 70-year-old New Mexico resident who owns some Procter & Gamble stock, asked the company to put a resolution on nuclear energy into its proxy materials, she got a visit from two P.& G. representatives.

title: A SOVIET PUSH ON OIL EXPORTS
description: With the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in disarray and worldwide oil prices falling, the Soviet Union, the world's largest oil producer, is scrambling as hard as any other exporter these days to protect itself.

title: SECRETARIES' POLL ON COMPUTERS
description: Computers have become an integral part of many offices, and secretaries by and large like it that way. But they do not like the eye strain and headaches that they say go along with the use of some electronic equipment. These opinions come from a national survey on ''The Evolving Role of the Secretary in the Information Age.''

title: 2 Speed Skaters Add Gold Medals
description: Dan Wood of Lake Placid and Carol Moore of Flushing, Queens, each took double gold medals in the open men's and open women's speedskating events in the final day of the Empire State Games today.

title: CHARLES G. BEAVERS JR.
description: Charles G. Beavers Jr., chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Brubaker Tool Corporation of Millersburg, Pa., died Saturday of cancer at his home in Manhattan.

title: Friendly Slopes
description: Everybody does better on their home turf including, apparently, the United States ski team if you look at the skiers' performances in the past week at Waterville Valley, N.H., and Aspen and Vail in Colorado. That's one reason why team officials and others concerned with holding competitions on this side of the Atlantic were disappointed when the opening World Cup races for December 1983 were moved out of United States territory.

title: No Headline
description: NUGGETS WIN 10TH STRAIGHT

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Getting Ready for Millennium

title: STARS DEAL GENERALS SECOND DEFEAT, 25-0
description: The Philadelphia Stars, a team that acquired most of its players before it hired its head coach only eight weeks ago, routed the New Jersey Generals, 25-0, today in the first United States Football League game at Veterans Stadium.

title: Recorded Deeds; SILENCE INDEED
description: Lots of luck to the American Civil Liberties Union in its attempt to discern the New Jersey legislative mind. Gathering evidence for its suit against the state's disguised school prayer law, the A.C.L.U. is asking what certain legislators stated publicly about their purpose in requiring a ''minute of silence'' every school day.

title: MARJORIE GUTHRIE, SINGER'S WIDOW, 65
description: Marjorie Mazia Guthrie, who began her career as a dancer but who, in the last 15 years of her life, devoted herself to creating an awareness of Huntington's chorea - a disease that killed her husband, the folk singer Woody Guthrie - died of cancer at her home yesterday. She was 65 years old, and lived in Manhattan.

title: Treasury Back After a Hiatus
description: After a three-week hiatus in note and bond financing, the Treasury returns to the market this week with three days of auctions. In addition, dealers expect the Treasury to announce plans Tuesday to sell more than $13 billion of four-, seven- and 20-year securities during the week of March 21.

title: INTERMOUNTAIN POWER PLANS LARGE BOND ISSUE
description: The already heavy volume of new tax-exempt bonds will increase this week with the marketing of a $750 million bond issue of the Intermountain Power Agency. Some investment bankers said the size of the issue might be increased to as much as $1 billion, which would make it the largest public issue of tax-exempt bonds ever.

title: '82 GIFTS TO CHARITY A RECORD, BUT RATE OF INCREASE SLOWED
description: In the midst of a severe recession, individuals, companies and foundations gave nearly $60 billion to charity last year, more than ever before.

title: WRITER OF BOOK ON DRUGS ON TRIAL FOR SMUGGLING
description: On the Friday before last, an orange typing-paper box arrived unannounced at the offices of the Scott Meredith literary agency in New York, its delivery an act of friendship by Norman Mailer. In it were 300 pages of a first novel by an aspiring writer named Richard Lowell Stratton, who has been working on the book in his cell here in the Cumberland County Jail. The title: ''Drug War.''

title: SOUTH AFRICA RIGHTISTS UNITE IN KEY VOTE
description: A far-right party has withdrawn from a key by-election in South Africa, creating a unified right-wing challenge to the ruling National Party that could endanger its plans to bring nonwhites into the national Government.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aeroflex Laboratories Inc., Plainview, L.I., has formed a new Electronic Systems division, to be headed by Murray Schwartz.

title: Bridge: Grand National Title Won By 2 From New York Area
description: Players from White Plains and Poughkeepsie were in the news here Saturday night when they won one major national title at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, and came within a hair of winning another.

title: 'Woman of Year' Closes
description: ''Woman of the Year,'' the Broadway musical that opened March 29, 1981, with Lauren Bacall in the lead, closed after its matinee yesterday, the 770th performance.

title: BOTH SIDES WARN OF A LONG STRIKE
description: The first negotiations since the strike against the Metro-North Commuter Railroad began a week ago broke off last night after only three hours. Both sides said they were still far apart on the issues, and agreed that it could be a long strike.

title: FRENCH LEFTISTS LOSE MORE CITIES BUT AVERT ROUT
description: The Socialist and Communist coalition in France lost more cities in the final round of national municipal elections Sunday.

title: NICHOLAS CIVELLA, SAID TO LEAD KANSAS CITY'S CRIME 'FAMILY'
description: Nicholas Civella, the reputed head of the Kansas City crime family, died Saturday of complications caused by cancer, his lawyer said today. He was 70 years old.

title: MUSIC: CAMERATA WOODWINDS
description: THE Camerata Woodwind Quintet, an ensemble in residence at Western Illinois University, consists of the flutist Gerald Carey, the clarinetist George Townsend, the oboist James Brody, the bassoonist Robert Koper and the hornist Roger Collins. At Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday afternoon, they proved a polished and spirited group, with a collective tone that is smooth and diaphanous. Mr. Collins actually manages to make the horn sound sprightly, while Mr. Koper produces a dark tone that is cultivated and Mephistophelean.

title: U.S. Steel Sees '83 Cash Drop
description: The United States Steel Corporation is projecting a substantial negative cash flow from its steel operations in 1983, it said in its annual report.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: NEW DEAL

title: CHANDLER RETAINS BANTAMWEIGHT TITLE
description: Jeff Chandler, who seems to fight only as hard as necessary, fought brilliantly today in scoring a unanimous 15-round decision over Gaby Canizales to retain the World Boxing Association bantamweight title.

title: Lendl Toppled
description: Peter McNamara of Australia upset Ivan Lendl, 6-4, 4-6, 7-6, today in the final of the $315,000 Belgian indoor Grand Prix tournament.

title: Mark's Pressure On Franc
description: The French franc is coming under extreme pressure against the West German mark on currency exchange markets following the Socialists' defeat in municipal elections March 6. Yesterday, the Socialist and Communist coalition received further setbacks in the final round of municipal elections, but it avoided an overall defeat.

title: CAR-CONTENT BILL STALLED IN CONGRESS
description: One of the most contentious proposals before Congress last year would have required as a condition for selling cars in the United States that up to 90 percent of the vehicle components be made here as well.

title: Turkish Leader Says Ban On Party Chiefs Stands
description: President Kenan Evren said today that party leaders banned from politics after the 1980 coup would not be allowed to reactivate their parties when Turkey eventually returns to parliamentary rule.

title: TRYING TO MAKE COEDUCATION WORK BETTER
description: There were 200 teachers and administrators and almost as many stories. Dr. Eva I. Kampits's story was about what happened when men joined a psychology class at Pine Manor, the women's college outside of Boston where she is academic dean.

title: Six Are Reported Slain In Fighting in Assam
description: At least six people were killed today in a new outbreak of fighting between immigrants and natives of India's northeastern state of Assam, the authorities said.

title: BRIEFING
description: To PAC or Not to PAC

title: REQUIRED READING
description: 'That Cordial Spirit'

title: Petty Triumphs, Ending Drought
description: Richard Petty ended today a 42-race string without a victory by winning the Carolina 500 Grand National stock-car event.

title: Commodities; New Twist for Options
description: THE stock-index market entered a new phase Friday when the Chicago Board Options Exchange introduced the first options that are not based on any of the existing popular share averages. In addition, they are not predicated on any underlying futures contracts.

title: Making Haste to Make Few Jobs
description: By common agreement, the first priority of the 98th Congress was to act on the recession. Senators and representatives, Republicans and Democrats, all had favorite bills to invent instant jobs and, beyond that, to attack deep-seated, structural unemployment. To fend off the big spenders, even President Reagan composed a quick plan, quite similar to the Democratic bill he had blocked with a veto threat in the lame-duck session only a month before. And now the President offers a long-term plan, too. All are baking hasty pudding.

title: Randi Feinberg Weds Dr. Paul Neustein, Surgeon
description: Randi Cara Feinberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Feinberg of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday in Brandeis, Calif., to Dr. Paul Neustein, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Neustein of Linden, N.J. Rabbi Joseph Talushkin performed the ceremony at the House of the Book on the grounds of the Brandeis-Barden Institute, a nonprofit Judaica educational and intellectual organization.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Pittsburgh Pirates (split squad) at Fort Lauderdale, 8 P.M. The fans up North get their first glimpse of the Yankees on television.

title: 10 to Be Added May 9 To Theater Hall of Fame
description: Ten people have been elected to the Theater Hall of Fame at the Uris Theater by drama critics and editors from around the country.

title: WIDE POWER GIVEN ON CLASSIFIED DATA
description: Federal agencies will have broad power to review and approve books, magazine articles and the texts of speeches prepared by their employees and former employees under President Reagan's new order protecting classified information.

title: Index; International
description: South Africa's right unites in a key vote A3 China's party leader cites ''se- vere setbacks'' A3 Weinberger says Soviet seeks re- treat of U.S. into a ''fortress'' A4 Cardinal in Chile censures re- gime A5 Around the World A6 Israel considers cracking down on violence by Jewish settlers A6 King Hussein briefs Carter on Mideast peace efforts A6 Government/Politics Democrats divided over aiding mayoral candidate in Chicago A11 Washington Talk The fabled White House switch- board B6 The Calendar B6 Briefing B6 Required Reading B6 General Around the Nation A12 Bachelor's degree estimated to be worth $329,000 in earnings A12 Talks try to avert transit strike in Philadelphia A12 U.S. aide said to act on own in not pressing Burford case A13 200 discuss how to make coeduca- tion better B1 Archives document dignity and suffering in Warsaw Ghetto B2 New talks are held in the Metro- North commuter-rail strike B3 Four teen-agers killed as car goes out of control in the Bronx B3 An average weekend in New York City: 11 people murdered B4 Reagan order on classified data gives wide review powers D12 Style Relationships B7 Grief with dignity in hospice for infants B7 SportsMonday Baseball: Martin and Steinbren- ner calm amid Yanks' miscues C4

title: FLOCKING TO COLUMBIA
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: TV: CABLE VENTURES INSIDE CONGRESS
description: SPAN, the cable network, offers news unexpurgated, unedited, trivia mixed in with the great issues of our time. Its centerpiece is live coverage of sessions in the House of Representatives, where the members talk wisely and foolishly, often at length, and sometimes in the grip of great passion. C-Span presents a feast for political junkies and a masterly civics lesson as well.

title: Miss McKinney Leading
description: Tamara McKinney will have to wait until this week's competition is completed to become the first American to win the women's World Cup overall championship. Serge Lang, the founder of the World Cup, said today from San Francisco that under the criteria for breaking a first-place tie, Erika Hess of Switzerland remained in contention.

title: Recorded Deeds; CAPITAL NOTION
description: If only J. P. Morgan were around to hear what they're talking about these days in Hartford's City Hall, a handsome French Revival structure in the town where he was born and buried. He'd be interested because he gave the land on which it stands, along with the adjacent land and equally hand-some building (neo-Italian Renaissance, that one) which houses a wing of America's oldest public museum, the Wadsworth Atheneum, and also because in his lifetime he showed a certain flair for financial tricks.

title: Magazines Increase Total Ad Pages Again
description: In February, for the second straight month, the member magazines of the Publishers Information Bureau showed increases in ad pages over the comparable month of 1982. This is considered particularly important because 1982's total pages were down 2.6 percent from 1981.

title: The U.N. Today; March 14, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Mrs. Kirkpatrick in Israel
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations, arrived today to attend the third international conference on Soviet Jews, to be held in Jerusalem. She told reporters at Ben-Gurion Airport that President Reagan had sent her as his representative ''because the plight of Soviet Jewry is important to the people and the Government of the United States, who fervently believe in the right of peoples to emigrate.''

title: A Correction
description: Because of a typographical error, a letter by Prof. Ithiel de Sola Pool about rooftop SMATV dishes, published March 10, made reference to the Fifth Amendment. It should have been the First Amendment.

title: GRIEF WITH DIGNITY IN A HOSPICE FOR INFANTS
description: When he died, sometime after noon on a Friday last August, a nurse gently folded the tiny body of Adam Herrera inside a white blanket and handed the baby to his father. ''You know,'' says Art Herrera, who still cannot recall the moment without tears, ''it was the first time we held our son when he wasn't hooked up with wires and tubes to some machine.''

title: NETS TOP TRAIL BLAZERS, 109-104
description: The Nets overcame a one-man attack in the first three quarters by Jim Paxson, a Portland Trail Blazer who scored a game-high 32 points tonight, and came away with a 109-94 triumph before 12,576 spectators at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: CARDINAL IN CHILE CENSURES REGIME
description: Chile's highest ranking Roman Catholic official accused the military Government today of ignoring Vatican appeals by threatening to expel three priests accused of running a ''politically oriented'' soup kitchen for the poor.

title: Springfield Gardens Takes City Crown
