description: Springfield Gardens used its muscle down the stretch to defeat Alexander Hamilton, 86-83, for the Public Schools Athletic League basketball title yesterday.

title: A VINTAGE YEAR FOR LOOIE?
description: A COUPLE of decades ago, a freshman basketball player at Molloy High in Queens came home and told his older brother about the diminutive varsity coach who made players shoot over a raised broom to get the proper arc on their shots.

title: SHULTZ AND SHAMIR CONFER ON ENDING LEBANON DEADLOCK
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel met for four hours today with Secretary of State George P. Shultz. But American officials said Mr. Shamir had made no significant new proposals for breaking the deadlock in negotiations on an Israeli troop withdrawal from Lebanon.

title: BALLET: DAYTON TROUPE IN THE BRONX
description: THE development of American ballet has been largely the story of dancers trained in various parts of the country by a core of very good teachers.

title: CONGRESS'S INTENT HELD AS VIOLATED
description: Many Democrats on Capital Hill, joined by some Republicans, believe the Reagan Administration's actions on environmental laws have violated the intent of Congress and contradicted a broad national consensus in favor of antipollution measures.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 14, 1983: MONDAY Bunker Hill Inc Sec Interco Inc Capital Cities Com MONY Mtge Investors Federal Paper Board Roper Corp TUESDAY CPC Intl Upjohn Co House of Fabrics WEDNESDAY Amer Nat Resources Stone & Webster Carolina Pwr & Lt Vestaur Securities THURSDAY Air Prdts & Chems Public Serv N H Alexander & Alex'r Russ Togs Cincinnati G & E Stevens (J P) & Co Fruehauf Corp Transamerica Corp Kaiser Cement Umet Properties FRIDAY CTS Corp Tidewater Inc Southeast Banking

title: Books Of The Times
description: CANOPUS IN ARGOS: ARCHIVES. Documents Relating to THE SENTIMENTAL AGENTS in the Volyen Empire. By Doris Lessing. 178 pages. Knopf. $12.95

title: Brazilian Takes Grand Prix Race
description: Nelson Piquet of Brazil, driving a turbo-powered Brabham, thrilled the hometown crowd by winning the Brazilian Grand Prix auto race today, the year's first Formula One event.

title: EUROPE FIGHTS FOR ELECTRONICS SHARE
description: Europe's consumer electronics industry is groping for a strategy to handle the twin threats of a recession-induced sales slump and Japanese inroads into a shrinking market.

title: A.T.& T.'S PRODDER
description: To the Editor:

title: YANKS CALM AMID CONFUSION
description: A sign of the times: The Yankees messed up two suicide squeeze plays and a double steal and missed a bunch of signs today, and neither Billy Martin nor George Steinbrenner exploded.

title: KNICKS DEFEAT CELTICS, 122-110
description: A strange sound echoed through the Boston Garden today. The capacity crowd of 15,320, the 105th straight sellout, soundly booed the Boston Celtics several times during their 122-110 loss to the Knicks.

title: 2,000 POLES ATTEND ILLEGAL PROTEST RALLY AT GDANSK SHIPYARD
description: More than 2,000 Poles defied the authorities today by holding an illegal rally at the workers' monument by the gates of the Lenin Shipyard in this Baltic seaport.

title: MUSIC: ZIMMERMANN WORK
description: DESPITE the fact that Mozart's ''Haffner'' and Beethoven's ''Eroica'' symphonies were also played, the main event on the Brooklyn Philharmonic's weekend program was the United States premiere of Bernd Alois Zimmermann's Violin Concerto. At the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Saturday night, the orchestra, directed Lukas Foss, sounded underrehearsed and somewhat frantic in the Mozart, but sharpened its collective focus considerably for the Zimmermann.

title: People
description: * Penelope Queen has been named senior vice president, research director at Dancer Fitzgerald Sample Inc., and Robert Gaffney has joined the agency's direct marketing subsidiary, DFS Direct, as senior vice president, creative director.

title: Six Seasons From Gehrig
description: SHORTLY after Steve Garvey had arrived here for spring training, the San Diego Padres' manager, Dick Williams, was talking to him about the National League consecutive-game record that the 34-yearold first baseman is approaching. Barring an injury, illness or a rainout, Steve Garvey will tie Billy Williams's streak of 1,117 games when he returns to Dodger Stadium on April 15, and he will break it the next night.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: How did the expression Texas Leaguer originate in baseball?

title: Green Party Member, An Ex-Nazi, to Resign
description: Admitting that he was once a Nazi storm trooper, the oldest official of the Green Party said today that he would resign the seat he won in Parliament last week.

title: NORMAN DANIEL FRANK
description: Norman Daniel Frank, retired president of Steinhardt & Kelly, produce merchants in New York City, died Saturday at Doctors Hospital. He was a resident of Manhattan and was 87 years old.

title: ST. JOHN'S IS SEEDED NO. 1 IN EAST FIELD
description: The Big East, which in four years has developed into one of the nation's best basketball conferences, placed five teams, headed by St. John's, in the 45th annual National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. The Redmen received the top-seeded position in the East Regional in the selections announced yesterday, and they will begin play in the second round Sunday in Hartford.

title: Campaign Commences For Searle Sweetener
description: Just as du Pont advertises Lycra fiber so that consumers will buy apparel made with it, G.D. Searle & Company, the Chicago pharmaceutical concern, is going to promote its NutraSweet, a new low-calorie sweetener being used by the food industry. And the print and TV advertising will do this by advertising the brand name products using it.

title: Bucks 117, Cavaliers 82
description: MILWAUKEE (UPI) - Sidney Moncrief, after scoring 15 points, and Marques Johnson, after getting 14, sat out the fourth quarter as Milwaukee's reserves pumped in enough points to give the Bucks their third straight victory and their biggest margin of the season.

title: STRIKES: SHARING ANXIETY
description: WHEN Metro-North's commuter trains came to a halt last week, an e xecutive in Chappaqua, N.Y., packed a bag, kissed his wife and c hildren goodbye and left home for an indefinite stay with relatives i n the Bronx. ''I'll see you when the strike is over,'' he told his f amily.

title: NICOLETTE, IN PLAYOFF, GETS FIRST VICTORY
description: Mike Nicolette today won the first PGA Tour event of his five-year career on the first hole of a playoff with Greg Norman. His $63,000 purse in the Bay Hill Classic surpassed his $62,832 in career winnings before today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Circus Benefit for AIDS

title: SPINKS-BRAXTON: A CONTEST
description: MAYBE Marvelous Marvin Hagler will fight Thomas Hearns this year, or maybe Larry Holmes will meet Michael Dokes. But there are no doubts, the Professor said, that the fight of the year will be Michael Spinks against Dwight Braxton Friday night in Atlantic City.

title: VOZNESENSKY PLANS MONUMENT TO WORDS IN PARIS
description: PARIS The Russian poet Andrei Voznesensky has an idea that involves a golden sphere suspended in midair with letters from all the world's languages fluttering above it.

title: Montagu-S.E.C. Accord
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said it had reached a settlement with Montagu Investment Management Ltd. on charges that the London firm had failed to report its stake in the Canal-Randolph Corporation, a Pennsylvania timber leasing and ski resort development company.

title: OUTDOORS: THE COLD-WATER FISH WITH A DELICATE BITE
description: SOME East Coast saltwater anglers are braving the wintry winds of March in quest of the winter flounder, a cold-water species whose appearance in western Long Island Sound often occurs close to St. Patrick's Day.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: EXCERPTS FROM TRUMAN'S 1911 AND POTSDAM LETTERS TO BESS WALLACE TRUMAN
description: Following are excerpts from letters written by Harry S. Truman to Elizabeth Virginia Wallace in 1911. He was recovering from a broken leg suffered while working at his grandmother's farm in Grandview, Mo. Miss Wallace was living 10 miles away in Independence. April 24, 1911 Dear Bessie: To think that I have had some really respectable falls and came off without a scratch and then have a sucking calf knock me down and actually break my leg. Tis indeed a disgrace. But perhaps I can live it down.

title: PSA SETBACK DELAYS GROWTH
description: A marketing plan was in place. Former Braniff International employees had been interviewed for jobs. New cloth for uniforms - and some new airplane seats - had already been purchased.

title: Kuwaitis Criticize Ban
description: Abdulaziz Hussein, chief Government spokesman, said today that Washington's ban on oil and gas exploration in the United States by Kuwaiti-owned Santa Fe International was ''probably political.'' Energy Secretary James G. Watt said Thursday that the company would be barred from leasing Federal land onshore to drill for oil or natural gas until Kuwait changed ''discriminatory policies'' aimed at United States companies. Santa Fe International has no connection with Santa Fe Industries.

title: HISTORIAN DEFIED NAZIS TO DOCUMENT THE HOLOCAUST
description: As the 40th anniversary of the Warsaw Ghetto uprising nears on April 19, a Yiddish research center is commemorating a very different rebellion waged at the same time by a Jewish scholar armed with little more than faith in the redemptive power of history.

title: WEINBERGER SAYS SOVIET SEEKS RETREAT TO 'FORTRESS AMERICA'
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the Soviet Union was fostering turmoil in Central America to make the United States retreat into a ''fortress of America.''

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.22 An index of yields for long-term A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer. Aa Utility Bonds*12.18 Salomon Brothers' estimate for new long-term issues.

title: FOUR TEEN-AGERS KILLED IN BRONX AS CAR CRASHES
description: Four teen-agers were killed early yesterday when the car in which they were riding went out of control on the Mosholu Parkway in the Bronx and slammed into a concrete retaining wall, the police said.

title: CARTER SEES HUSSEIN IN JORDAN
description: Former President Jimmy Carter met today with King Hussein of Jordan, who briefed him on Arab efforts to achieve a Middle East peace formula that would recognize Palestinian rights, the official Jordanian press agency said.

title: TALKS HELD TO AVERT TRANSIT STRIKE IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Transit negotiators met today in an effort to avert strikes that by Tuesday could cripple Philadelphia's transportation system and deliver heavy blows to regional business.

title: PUPILS WHO ARE LEFT BACK GET CHANCE AT HIGH SCHOOL
description: Faced with thousands of failing schoolchildren who would be spending their fourth year in seventh grade next fall, New York City school officials have developed a plan that would allow these students to attend high school classes in September.

title: Workers Told to Reject Airline's 'Final' Offer
description: Eastern Airlines' offer of a 32 percent pay raise by November 1984 to avert a strike by its 13,500 machinists is ''final,'' the company's president, Frank Borman, said today. But union leaders told workers to reject Eastern's proposal.

title: Retired Lumber Official Joins Financing Group
description: After handling $2.5 billion of financial deals for the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, from acquisitions to equity offerings, Harry J. Kane retired in January as the lumber company's executive vice president-financial. Now he expects to be involved in financing again - maybe $1.5 billion worth.

title: ARGENTINE 'AMNESTY'
description: An amnesty law being prepared by Argentina's military Government will, if enacted, seriously violate the legal system and bear ominous consequences for the future of democracy in Argentina.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Pickle Dynasties

title: VENEZUELA QUOTA CALLED OPEC SNAG
description: Senior oil officials from the 13 OPEC nations said here late tonight that only one obstacle remained to an agreement on the first price cut in the group's history: acceptance by Venezuela of a production quota lower than what it insists is needed to pay its international debts.

title: Pale Is Better
description: As college basketball is staging tournaments to determine conference, regional and national championships, fans can expect to see photographs and television pictures of fanatical students who express their allegiance to their teams by painting their faces with their school colors. The ''warpaint'' is a common phenomenon at emotionally charged college basketball games.

title: Air I, a New Carrier, Switching to TBWA
description: Air I, a St. Louis-based airline that after a year's delay is ready to go into operation April 1, has just switched ad agencies, assigning its business to TBWA Advertising, New York. Making this announcement gave particular pleasure to William Tragos, founder and chief executive officer of the international agency, since he is a St. Louis boy and notes with pride the names of Anheuser-Busch and Ralston Purina, a couple of St. Louis stalwarts, on his client list.

title: Commerce, Chance and the Court
description: In 1976, a bitterly divided Supreme Court struck down Federal minimum wage and overtime laws that were supposed to protect employees of states and localities. If Congress could impose such financial burdens, the Court said, ''there would be little left of the states' separate and independent existence.'' One of the four dissenters gibed that the only principle at stake was ''a sovereign state's right to pay a substandard wage to the janitor at the state capitol.''

title: ISRAEL CONSIDERING CURBS ON SETTLERS
description: After years of tolerating political violence by Jewish settlers in the occupied West Bank, the Israeli authorities are considering whether to crack down.

title: 1,300 LETTERS OF TRUMAN'S MADE PUBLIC
description: Almost 1,300 letters from Harry S. Truman to his wife, Bess, spanning a half-century from the time he was a struggling 26-year-old farmer until six years after he left the Presidency in 1953, have been made public. Some of the letters, held by the Harry S. Truman Library in Inde- Excerpts from letters, page B5. pendence, Mo., include frank descriptions of such world leaders as Joseph Stalin and shed new light on political and diplomatic history.

title: SCANDALS OF ITALY ENTANGLE ITS FLAGSHIP NEWSPAPER
description: When Alberto Cavallari, editor of the Milan daily Corriere della Sera, asked in a front-page editorial last month, ''What would Italy be without this Corriere?'' he was perhaps indulging in overstatement. But that he could raise his question at all and not be accused of excessive self-importance in the backbiting world of Italian journalism is a measure of the 107-year-old newspaper's reputation as a national institution.

title: NKOMO SAYS HE WANTS SAFETY PLEDGE
description: Joshua Nkomo, the Zimbabwean opposition leader, arrived in Britain today and said he would return home only if representatives of the Government of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe personally guaranteed his safety.

title: CHINA PARTY CHIEF CALLS FOR MARXIST FLEXIBILITY
description: The Chinese Communist Party leader, Hu Yaobang, said today that the world Communist movement had suffered ''severe setbacks'' in the last three decades, and he called for flexibility in interpreting Marxist theory.

title: THAT DOUBLE STANDARD
description: Of course, there is still a double standard. For some, it stems from ideology. But all the huffing and puffing at the 101-member nonaligned conference here over how to phrase the verbose declaration makes it clear enough why others go along.

title: A WEEKEND'S TOLL IN NEW YORK CITY: 11 MURDERS
description: For 11 New Yorkers this weekend, death came by bullet, by knife, by baseball bat and by hammer. The number killed was not a record; it was close to average in a city that had 1,675 murders last year and 1,832 the year before.

title: ADVERTISING
description: After 15 years, Progresso Quality Foods is leaving Creamer Inc., and is assigning its Italian specialties to Jordan, Case & McGrath.

title: MONDAY, MARCH 14, 1983
description: International Israel's ideas for ending the deadlock in the negotiations on a troop withdrawal from Lebanon were described in detail by Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir at a meeting in Washington with Secretary of State George P. Shultz. But after a meeting that lasted nearly four hours, American officials said Mr. Shamir had produced no significant new proposals for ending the impasse. (Page A1, Column 6.) The Socialist-Communist coalition in France was set back again in the final round of municipal elections, but avoided an overall defeat that would have undermined the Government's authority. Returns showed that, although the left lost offices in 14 additional cities this week, all of its national leaders involved in individual races won. (A1:5.)

title: CONCRETE PRICES FOR JOBS IN CITY STUDIED BY STATE
description: The State Attorney General's office is investigating charges of a price-fixing conspiracy affecting the entire New York City concrete industry.

title: MUSIC: SCRIABIN'S 'FIRE'
description: SCRIABIN planned to transform the universe with his ''Mysterium'' - a composition that would make of his music a new religion. The audience would be devotionally robed in white, worshiping at the composer's own temple. The event would dwarf Wagner's music dramas. Sound and light and taste and touch and smell would combine to stop the movement of time itself. Scriabin died in 1915, having finished only some sketches for his revelatory musical gospel. World War I would have outdone his spectacle in any case.

title: CAPTIVATING GRACE IS THIRD TO HALO DOTTY
description: The brightest hope of the Aqueduct winter meeting faded yesterday when Captivating Grace finished a poor third to Halo Dotty in the $54,900 Level Best Stakes for 3-year-old fillies.

title: No Headline
description: First S.E.C. Crown to Georgia

title: Mill Revamping Pleases Reynolds Metals Officer
description: Much has changed since 1978, when the Reynolds Metals Company began a $125 million modernization of its McCook, Ill., aluminum sheet and plate plant. No one could foresee then that the computer-controlled facility would come on line in 1983 operating at less than 50 percent of capacity, with 40 percent of the work force laid off.

title: Susan Hauser Married to Dr. Murray Rosenzweig
description: Susan Hauser, an assistant dean of Yale College, was married yesterday to Dr. Murray J. Rosenzweig, an associate professor of radiology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Rabbi Richard Israel, director of the Boston Hillel Council, performed the ceremony at the bride's home in North Haven, Conn.

title: Nervous Nellies at the Gates
description: It has become a persistent pattern for the State Department to bar our doors to guests with unwanted political affiliations. The latest instance is especially offensive. A visa has been denied to Mrs. Salvador Allende, widow of the Chilean president who was slain in 1973. The contention is that her making a speech in San Francisco would be ''prejudicial to United States interests.''

title: EMPLOYEES TO BUY HUGE STEEL WORKS IN $66 MILLION PACT
description: An agreement has been approved in Weirton, W.Va., to allow workers to purchase the huge Weirton Works of the National Steel Corporation, transforming it into the largest employee-owned company in the United States.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My face is my passport.'' -Joshua Nkomo. (A3:1.)

title: LEWIS DENISON
description: Lewis Denison, an actor and director who specialized in the staging and production of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, died yesterday of pneumonia at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 79 years old and lived in Glen Cove.

title: BULLIES IN THE PULPIT
description: An unprecedented battle has been joined between the President of the United States and many of the religious leaders of the nation.

title: 42 Arrested Near Rotterdam
description: The police arrested 42 members of an antiwar group today after they broke into a United States Army building under construction in this town near the port city of Rotterdam.

title: ONE LAST CHANCE FOR SAMPSON
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. THE evening after his final home game as a college basketball player, Ralph Sampson sat with several old friends from high school and college in a back room at the Red River Rib Company, a restaurant just up the road from the University of Virginia campus. The waitress brought nachos and potato skins and salad, and more nachos and more potato skins, and those were just the appetizers before the ribs. Four days before the start of his last Atlantic Coast Conference tournament, Ralph Sampson was a very hungry player.

title: JARTRAN IS CONFIDENT, BUT IT FACES HURDLES
description: The road to financial recovery for Jartran Inc., a truck and trailer rental company, has been rough, but company officials insist that the company will make a comeback.

title: DEMOCRATS SPLIT ON SUPPORT FOR REP. WASHINGTON IN CHICAGO
description: Two weeks after his upset victory in the Democratic mayoral primary, Representative Harold Washington has received mounting support from national Democratic leaders, but the Democratic political establishment remains divided over supporting him.

title: MONDAY, MARCH 14, 1983; Companies
description: National Steel will sell its Weirton Works to its employees for $66 million under an agreement reached by the company, the unions and the employees of the West Virginia plant. It would make the steel plant the largest employee-owned company in the nation. (Page A1.)

title: JAZZ: MODERN AT BLUE NOTE
description: MORE than most jazz groups, the Modern Jazz Quartet, with its delicate chamber-jazz qualities, has usually seemed designed for a concert hall atmosphere rather than the hurly-burly of a nightclub. And the quartet has appeared, in its very selective attitude toward clubs, to concur.

title: Washington Watch; U.S. Dunning Is 'Not Nasty'
description: WASHINGTON EVERY month the dunning notices go out from the Comptroller's Office at the Commodity Credit Corporation to the Government of Poland.

title: Bulgarians Will Build A Port for Nicaraguans
description: Bulgaria has signed a threeyear $165 million trade and assistance agreement with Nicaragua's left-wing Government that includes construction of a deep-water port on the Atlantic.

title: CHINATOWN GANG LEADER IS SLAIN
description: A 33-year-old man described by the police as the leader of a Chinatown gang was found shot to death yesterday in the Pell Street office of a Chinese fraternal organization. The police said they were investigating whether the killing was part of a new round of gang violence.

title: MARTINA NAVRATILOVA IS WINNER
description: Martina Navratilova, unbeaten this year, won her fifth tournament yesterday with a 6-4, 6-0 rout of Chris Evert Lloyd before a crowd of 13,000 at Moody Arena in Dallas. It was their first meeting of 1983.

title: NOW, TAX OIL IMPORTS
description: ''Defense is of much more importance than opulence.'' Adam Smith, founding father of market economics and free trade, made this observation in defense of an import tariff to safeguard British security. Smith's text is a good guide to the oil import policy America should follow at a time when oil prices have fallen and promise to decline even further.

title: KOHL'S PARTY WINS A STATE ELECTION
description: A week after its sweeping victory in national elections, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's conservative Christian Democratic Party won a majority of legislative seats today in the northern state of Schleswig-Holstein.

title: RANGERS GET A LIFT IN MORALE FROM VICTORY OVER THE FLAMES
description: At first glance, the Rangers' 4-1 victory in Calgary Saturday night was fairly insignificant - an isolated triumph, small compared to the four straight losses that preceded it, and smaller still in light of the team's 8-17-9 record on the road this season.

title: STAGE: 'DOMESTIC ISSUES' BY CORINNE JACKER
description: WHATEVER you feel about what went on in the United States during the 1960's, chances are that you feel something. It says a great deal - none of it good - about Corinne Jacker's new play, ''Domestic Issues,'' that it rakes over that volatile decade without arousing a single emotion of any kind. Try as Miss Jacker may to reopen some of the deepest wounds and debates of the Vietnam War era, her play is so becalmed that it might as well be about night fishing in Nova Scotia.

title: Advertising; Parker Pen Job Widens For Ogilvy
description: THE Parker Pen Company, which last summer moved the responsibility for its domestic advertising and some of its Far East advertising to Ogilvy & Mather, last week threw in the rest of the non-Communist world. That increases the company's billings and its distributors' billings in this agency from $5 million to about $20 million.

title: Accounts
description: * Drake Business School to Levy, Flaxman & Associates.

title: ALEX FAULKNER
description: Alex Faulkner, The Daily Telegraph's chief correspondent in the United States for 35 years until his retirement in 1974, died Saturday in London, the newspaper announced. He was 77 years old.

title: TELEPHONE & DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
SAFECARD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
News Summary; TUESDAY, MARCH 15, 1983
description: International The first cut in OPEC oil prices in the organization's 23-year history was agreed upon by its 13 members in hopes of regaining control over the world petroleum market. The key cut is a 15 percent reduction - to $29 a barrel, from $34 - in the price of Saudi Light crude and production quotas for all OPEC members except Saudi Arabia. (Page A1, Column 6.) President Reagan stressed to Israel the ''urgency'' of its agreeing on terms for a withdrawal of all its forces from Lebanon, according to an Administration official. Mr. Reagan made the statement to Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir, who also met with Secretary of State George P. Shultz for five hours. (A1:3.)

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OFF THE SHELF

title: The Sore-Arm Season
description: It may be called spring training, but for some pitchers trying to find their stuff after a winter layoff, it's the sore-arm season. Among the ailing hurlers are Pete Vuckovich of the Milwaukee Brewers and just about the entire Atlanta Braves' rotation.

title: 12 COMMUTER RAIL UNIONS STRIKE IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Twelve striking unions shut down this area's commuter trains this morning, but negotiators for the city's much larger transit division averted a strike that would have diverted 450,000 riders to already heavily traveled streets.

title: BLACK ORIENTED RADIO A KEY IN CHICAGO'S ELECTION
description: When Representative Harold Washington decided to seek the Democratic nomination for Mayor, he said he would need three things to win: a big increase in the number of blacks registered to vote, a three-way contest and a heavy turnout.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Quest for Beauty

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Setback in Court On 'Silence' Suit
description: A Federal judge refused today to compel New Jersey lawmakers to explain their motives for enacting a law - over Governor Kean's veto - that requires public-school students to observe a minute of silence each day.

title: West Bank Settlements Are Illegal, Carter Says
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that Israel's settlements in the occupied West Bank were illegal and an obstacle to Middle East peace.

title: THE CITY
description: Former State Senator Vander L. Beatty of Brooklyn, facing trial on election-fraud charges, has asked that the office of District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman be removed from the case and that a special prosecutor or the state's Attorney General, Robert Abrams, be named to handle it.

title: Football May Get Another League
description: The United States Football League must be a success. It has already spawned an imitator. A group of businessmen met last weekend in Palm Springs, Calif., to start the International Football League, which plans to begin operation next spring in 12 cities, including New York.

title: LONDON RECALLS MARX ON CENTENARY OF DEATH
description: On March 14, 1883, the best known of all the habitues of the great domed Reading Room of the library at the British Museum died in London.

title: Woman in Georgia Loses Custody of Son Again
description: Kathleen Blackburn, whose white son was taken from her after she gave birth to a daughter by a black man in 1981, lost her latest fight for the boy today when a judge awarded custody to her former husband.

title: SOVEREIGN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Women First
description: Katherine Switzer broke the sex barrier in the Boston Marathon in 1967 and led the fight to get a women's marathon in the Olympics. But this time, she is not fighting for equality.

title: PABST BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Thelma Sharp, Headed Civil Service in Jersey
description: Thelma Parkinson Sharp, former president of the New Jersey Civil Service Commission, died Saturday at the Mater Dei Nursing Home. She was 84 years old.

title: No Headline
description: Talking Business with Magowan of Safeway Stores Food Chain's Growth Plans

title: EMPIRE-CROWN AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
National Public Radio Releases 35 Employees
description: National Public Radio said today that a budget cut of $2,775,000 in the second half of the year has compelled it to release 35 employees immediately and to cancel a new five-hour arts program, ''The Sunday Show.''

title: No Headline
description: A-ARMS CUT IN EUROPE URGED

title: PAYLESS CASHWAYS (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
2 NETWORKS ALTER POSITION ON SYNDICATED RIGHTS
description: Representatives of two of the three major commercial networks said today they would be willing to accept a compromise on the power to sell television series to individual stations after the programs had run on the networks.

title: PURITAN FASHIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
THE PRICES AND COSTS OF TELEPHONE SERVICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Atari Home Computers To Wells, Rich, Greene
description: Well, it finally happened. Atari, the Warner Communications subsidiary that makes video games and computers, has finally officially switched its home computer business to Wells, Rich, Greene from Young & Rubicam, as marketplace rumbling had said it was about to do last month.

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
MICHIGAN RESIDENTS SEEK INVESTIGATION OF DIOXINS
description: Some Michigan environmental groups are increasing their demands for official action against dioxin poisoning in light of what they regard as pervasive evidence of pollution by chlorinated dioxins and other toxic chemicals.

title: CONSOLIDATED CIGAR ENTERS NEW PHASE
description: When Alex N. Brainard joined the Consolidated Cigar Company 11 years ago as president, he did not smoke cigars. But now he does, and yesterday, with one in hand, he explained why more men ought to be smoking cigars in another decade or so.

title: Fluor to Reduce Capital Spending
description: The Fluor Corporation said that for this year it would reduce its capital spending to $250 million, from $526 million in 1982.

title: CONCERT: BACH BY ALDWELL
description: EDWARD ALDWELL is one of those musician-scholars whose music-making rises above mere intellectual power and erudition. Mr. Aldwell, a theoretician and a Bach scholar, teaches at the Curtis Institute and the Mannes College of Music, but he is also a pianist, and Sunday night at the Abraham Goodman House he gave the second of his three New York concerts this season devoted to Bach.

title: PIERCE, S S, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: B-Net income which includes a gain of $1,897,000 or $1.54 a shr from a fire insurance settlement; results reflect a non-recurring charge from the sale of Lehman Brothers Inc paint division

title: VISTA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1981 full yr earnings included $264,279 from equity in net loss of 50 percent owned co; the company said that pretax earnings include for 1981 nonrecurringincome of $804,312 from the disposition in the third qr of a plant which had been occupied

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about Lever Brothers in Business Day on Saturday incorrectly reported the ownership of a soap called Monchel. It is a Procter & Gamble product.

title: Chinatown to Get More Policemen
description: The Police Department increased the number of uniformed officers and detectives assigned to Chinatown yesterday after the weekend slaying of the leader of a Chinese gang, the Flying Dragons.

title: TV: '5 AMERICAN GUNS'
description: ''FIVE AMERICAN GUNS,'' produced by Home Box Office, is a docudrama whose authenticity is guaranteed by its principal actors, all of whom were involved in the incidents that we see. The real protagonists, however, are the guns. Despite the title, there were six, not five, and they were all used to shoot people. ''Five American Guns'' will be seen on HBO at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: A FACTORY PARKING LOT IS A 'BUY U.S.' BASTION
description: Richard Moe attempts to live a life as free of Japanese products as possible in this day and age. There is the matter of the Sony television set, but he purchased that 12 years ago and explains that ''we have all done things in the past we aren't proud of.''

title: Required Reading Of Taxes and Mail
description: Senators Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee and Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, in remarks to the Senate on the outpouring of mail seeking repeal of withholding taxes on interest and dividends, March 11, 1983:

title: BRIEFS
description: * AGS Computers Inc., Mountainside, N.J., said it had acquired Microamerica Distributing Co., a Needham, Mass., microcomputer products distributor; terms were not disclosed.

title: Rebels in Angola Offer Prisoner Trade
description: Angolan insurgents said today that they had captured 64 Czechoslovaks and 20 Portuguese and offered an exchange to obtain the freedom of convicted British mercenaries imprisoned by the leftist Government in Luanda.

title: STAKE IN SUPERIOR REPORTED
description: Bear, Stearns & Company, the investment banking house, has purchased between 2.5 million and 3 million shares of the Superior Oil Company within the last two weeks, Wall Street arbitragers said yesterday.

title: SPANISH CHIEF'S 100 DAYS: PEACE THE KEY
description: Seven years of democracy have already spawned the tradition that 100 days in the life of a new administration is a time for taking stock.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: THE treatment of foreign students by American colleges and universities is in a state of chaos created by ignorance, prejudice and the absence of planning. Concern over national security and foreign competition threaten to reduce American willingness to admit foreign students, and conditions are made worse by anarchy in Federal policies and parochialism in state legislatures. At the universities themselves, many administrators are embarrassed to acknowledge the presence of large numbers of foreign students, even though their graduate departments often depend for their very existence on those students.

title: FOR MEMORY, THE CASSETTE IS A POOR CHOICE
description: BACK in the ancient mid-1970's, when the personal computer first began emerging from the primordial electronic swamps of Silicon Valley, one of the numerous undefined directions of its evolution was the form external memory would take. Today you will see three basic types as you look around for a computer: ROM cartridges, cassette tapes and floppy disks. Which one you choose will greatly affect the usability of your personal computer for a long time to come.

title: EGYPTIAN SWORN IN FOR CABINET POST
description: A new Minister of Supply was sworn in today after two Egyptian Cabinet members were dismissed for being implicated in a corruption scandal involving the half brother of the late President Anwar el-Sadat.

title: SURVIVAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SFM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SENATE BUDGET COMMITTEE PASSES $13.5 BILLION AGRICULTURE MEASURE
description: The Senate Budget Committee approved a $13.5 billion appropriation today for agriculture in the next fiscal year, $700 million more than President Reagan proposed in his 1984 budget.

title: DRIESELL INQUIRY OPENED
description: The chancellor of the University of Maryland said today that he would conduct ''a thorough review'' of charges that Coach Lefty Driesell had tried to pressure a student into withdrawing accusations that caused a player to be dropped from the basketball team.

title: Kodak Entries
description: The Eastman Kodak Company introduced a new office copier and a continuous forms feeder, with deliveries to start late this year. It said the Ektaprint 200 copier-duplicator, designed for the medium- to high-volume market, can can make 4,200 copies an hour and offers two-sided copying and an in-line finisher. The continuous forms feeder operates at 4,200 copies an hour with Ektaprint copiers and 5,500 an hour with Kodak's duplicator, it said.

title: A Comrade of Walesa Scrutinized by Italy
description: The Italian authorities are investigating the possibility that one of Lech Walesa's Solidarity colleagues was involved in a Bulgarian plot to kill the Polish union leader in Rome two years ago, the Italian news agency Ansa reported today.

title: Stars 6, Canucks 3
description: Dino Ciccarelli scored twice to pace Minnesota, which closed to 4 points of first-place Chicago in the Norris Divison.

title: Anybody's Tournament
description: E ven though the N.C.A.A. tournament is down to its Final Fifty-Two, say this for it: at least all the teams will be playing real college basketball from now on to determine the national champion. No 3-point field goals. No shot clock. No obvious favorite, either. More so than in recent years, it's anybody's tournament.

title: Charlotte Curtis; Champagne and Pasta
description: ceilinged white rooms with white furnishings, enormous paintings and windows spacious enough to accommodate a view of their swimming pool, their gardens and miles of Lake Worth, and they are quiet people.

title: Ad Age Lists Top 10 According to Size
description: The biggest excitement in the annual billings issue of Advertising Age due out tomorrow will be the ranking of agencies according to revenues. In it, thanks to its acquisition of the William Esty Company, Ted Bates Worldwide has bounced the J. Walter Thompson Company out of second place, into which it was nudged two years ago, when Young & Rubicam moved in and took its long-held first-place slot.

title: BRITISH CONCERN TO BUY U.S. SECURITIES BROKER
description: Garban Ltd., a major broker of United States Treasury securities, will be acquired by Mills & Allen International P.L.C., a Londonbased company, under an agreement announced yesterday.

title: NIGHT BIRDS IN THE SPOTLIGHT
description: THE annual spring and fall bird migrations, involving continentspanning feats of navigation that are still unexplained, have long fascinated and puzzled ornithologists. And what has made the puzzle even more complicated is the fact that most of the bird species migrate at night when it would seem to be even harder for them to navigate and more difficult for others to observe.

title: Brink's Case Gets A New Judge
description: Judge David S. Ritter of Orange County Court was formally assigned to the Brink's robbery and murder case today, replacing Justice Robert J. Stolarik of State Supreme Court in Rockland County as the presiding judge.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Al Unser Jr., the 20-year-old son of the three-time Indianapolis 500 winner, has entered the race on May 29. His father's entry is expected soon. ... George Halas, 88, owner of the Chicago Bears who was hospitalized last week, has been suffering from jaundice brought on by blockage of bile ducts, according to his doctors, who say both conditions have been corrected. ... The Chicago Bulls have won barely a third of their games, and it was taken for granted that General Manager Rod Thorn would be let go at the end of the season. But Thorn says there is ''a possibility'' he'll be signing a new two-year contract soon.

title: EQUITABLE OF IOWA COMPANIES reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
WD-40 CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
News Analysis
description: When critics say the Reagan Administration may have underestimated the cost of its long-range military spending plan, Defense Secretary Caspar W.

title: Reagan Names New Officials
description: President Reagan nominated David H. Martin, a lawyer from Bedford, Va., today to head the Office of Government Ethics. The President also said he would nominate Harry O'Connor of Playa del Rey, Calif., who produced Mr. Reagan's radio broadcasts, for the board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, and William F. Pickard, owner of six McDonald's restaurants in Detroit, for chairman of the African Development Foundation board.

title: AMERICAN TO BASE FARES ON MILEAGE
description: American Airlines, in a sweeping attempt to simplify fares, announced a plan yesterday to replace thousands of different fares with four basic ones tied to the distance traveled.

title: PENN ST. SET FOR 'CLASSIC'
description: Penn State and Nebraska, which finished first and third in the two wire-service football polls for 1982, were named today for the first Kickoff Classic game at Giants Stadium in the Meadowlands the last weekend in August.

title: Joseph A. Erickson, 87, Dies; Led a Federal Reserve Bank
description: Joseph Austin Erickson, former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, died Saturday at the age of 87.

title: Pakistan Landslide Kills 84
description: The death toll in a weekend landslide at Phupan in the Himalayan foothills has risen to 84, a Government spokesman said today. The landslide hit the village, about 150 miles north of Islamabad, early Saturday morning.

title: Joseph B. Robison, 70; Civil Liberties Lawyer
description: Joseph B. Robison, director emeritus of the commission on law and social action of the American Jewish Congress, and an authority on civil liberties and religious freedom, died Sunday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 70 years old, and lived in Manhattan.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aeronca Inc., Pineville, N.C., has elected to its board Lieut. Gen. James T. Stewart, Air Force, retired.

title: ROCK APPEARS TO BE FIRST KNOWN VISITOR FROM MARS
description: BROWN chunk of rock, a meteorite found on the ice of Antarctica four years ago, has sent a shock wave of excitement through the laboratories of planetary science. Its drab appearance belies its apparently exotic provenance. The rock very likely comes from Mars.

title: Heavy Artillery Fire Reported By Iran Along Iraqi War Front
description: Iran's official press agency reported today that heavy artillery exchanges had been going on along the Persian Gulf war front since Sunday. It said the Iranians had hit an Iraqi tank, destroyed a bridge and killed at least nine Iraqi soldiers.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Times to Raise Prices
description: The New York Times plans to increase the suggested retail prices of its weekday and Sunday issues in the New England-Middle Atlantic corridor outside the New York metropolitan area, the paper's circulation department announced yesterday. Effective April 3, the price of the Sunday paper will rise to $1.50, from $1.25, and the weekday paper will go to 50 cents, from 30 cents.

title: LET THE MOB CONTRIBUTE
description: I'm a little puzzled about what New Jersey is doing with its casinos. It seems the state is trying to bar members of certain families - the police call them organized-crime families -from playing the slots and otherwise spending their money in the gambling halls of Atlantic City.

title: 2 Israeli Soldiers Hurt By Stones of Protesters
description: Two Israeli soldiers were injured today as scattered stone-throwing disturbances continued in East Jerusalem and several towns in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, a military spokesman said.

title: SELLING, RETAILING'S LOST ART
description: The nation's retailers are sure that an economic recovery will bring more shoppers into their stores. But they are less sanguine about whether those customers will buy anything.

title: AEG Unit Has Contract
description: AEG-Telefunken A.G. said today that its subsidiary AEG-Kanis A.G. had won a $100 million contract jointly with M.A.N.-GHH Sterkrade G.m.b.H. to supply equipment for gas turbines for the Soviet Union.

title: BRADEMAS ASSESSES HIS GOALS FOR N.Y.U.
description: In June 1981, John Brademas became the 13th president of New York University. Since then Mr. Brademas, a former United States Representative from Indiana and majority whip in the House, has taken steps to develop new academic leadership, expand student financial aid and strengthen offerings in the arts and sciences; last week, the university announced the launching of a $100 million capital fund drive. Mr. Brademas recently discussed his 20 months at N.Y.U. with Edward B. Fiske, education editor of The Times. Following are excerpts from that interview.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Trekking by Taxi

title: A FREEZE REWARDS MOSCOW
description: Proposals for an immediate halt to the testing, production and deployment of nuclear weapons have gained international attention just as President Reagan's multiyear program for strategic nuclear modernization has begun. Yet a nuclear freeze would hurt America's ability to regain a credible deterrent posture that has been allowed to atrophy for 15 years. A freeze would be bad arms control.

title: Bern's City Hall Bombed
description: A pipe bomb exploded today outside Bern's City Hall, causing no injuries and little damage. Officials said no one had taken responsibility for the explosion.

title: Michelle Rosewoman And Univision Perform
description: When Michelle Rosewoman and Univision started a piece on Saturday at Soundscape, there was no telling where it would end. Miss Rosewoman was variously a blues pianist, a ballad singer and a free improviser, while Univision - including trumpet, two tubas and drums - became a brass chorale or an oompah band.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why is it necessary to excavate to find the ruins of ancient civilizations? How do they get buried?

title: Koestler Is Said to Have Left $600,000 for Psychic Studies
description: The writer Arthur Koestler, who was found dead with his wife on March 3 in an apparent double suicide, left about $600,000 to promote university study of psychic phenomena, The Sunday Telegraph reported.

title: JAZZ: A SEXTET AT SWEET BAZIL
description: HALF of the sextet of the trumpeter Ahmed Abdullah was strings - bass, cello and violin - when the group played Sunday at Sweet Basil. That lineup gave the proceedings a woodsy, almost rustic sound, and the gruff tone of the strings neatly complemented Mr. Abdullah's clear trumpet phrases.

title: Bank of China Loans
description: The Bank of China has lent the equivalent of more than $80 million to 54 Chinese-foreign joint ventures since 1980, the official New China News Agency reported today.

title: PENTAGON CALLS SOVIET ARMS A THREAT TO CENTRAL AMERICA
description: A ranking Defense Department official told Congress today that the Soviet Union had stepped up its arms deliveries to Cuba and Nicaragua in the last year and warned that Soviet efforts in Central America threatened to turn the region into ''another Eastern Europe.''

title: REX-NORECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FUJI TO BUY LOAN UNITS OF HELLER
description: The Walter E. Heller International Corporation announced yesterday that it had ended its agreement to sell its two commercial lending units to the Security Pacific Corporation of California and that it had agreed to sell them instead to the Fuji Bank of Japan for a higher price.

title: PASSPORT TRAVEL INC reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
description: The results include the operations of Group Travel Services purchased in 1980, Nelson Travel Service in 1981 and Roundtrip Travel in May 1982

title: MET MUSEUM SEEKS ENDOWED CHAIRS
description: In hot pursuit of its recently announced $150 million capital campaign goal, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is soliciting endowments to pay the salaries of department chairmen and embellishing the chairmen's titles with the donors' names.

title: Mexico, Following OPEC, Lowers Its Oil Prices
description: Mexico tonight followed the lead of OPEC and lowered the price for its light Istmo crude oil by $3.50 a barrel, to $29.

title: All-Americans Named
description: Ralph Sampson, the Naismith Committee's choice as college basketball player of the year, found out who his fellow all-Americans were when the committee of 275 coaches and sportswriters completed the team. They are Michael Jordan and Sam Perkins of North Carolina, Dale Ellis of Tennessee and Pat Ewing of Georgetown. Sampson, Jordan and Perkins also made the United Press International all-America team with John Paxson of Notre Dame and Keith Lee of Memphis State. ... Ed Badger, who had five mediocre seasons as coach at Cincinnati and wound up this year with an 11-17 record, the school's worst in 37 years, was dismissed. ... Two other coaches - Thomas McLaughlin of the University of Massachusetts, and Dick Harter of Penn State - resigned.

title: PRESIDENT PRESSES ISRAEL ON URGENCY OF LEBANON PACT
description: President Reagan emphasized to Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir today the ''necessity and urgency'' of Israel's agreeing on terms for the withdrawal of all its troops from Lebanon as the first step in the complete pullback of foreign forces from that country, an Administration official said.

title: Woman on Rikers Hangs Herself
description: A 22-year-old woman yesterday became the first female inmate of the Women's House of Detention on Rikers Island to commit suicide when she hanged herself with a sheet in her cell, a city corrections official said.

title: SUPER FOOD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 12
description: The 1982 shr earnings reflect a 5 percent stock divd paid Dec 15

title: Bill Rates Advance Slightly; Six-Month Issue 8.264%
description: Treasury bill rates rose slightly at the weekly auction yesterday of three-and six-month Government securities. The average discount rate on the 90-day bills inched up to 8.256 percent from 8.205 percent last week, while the companion six-month issue rose to 8.264 percent from 8.171 percent.

title: Chinese Premier Voices Dissatisfaction With U.S.
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China was quoted today as having said that he was not satisfied with relations with the United States and had no immediate plans to accept President Reagan's invitation to visit Washington.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: METS' TRYOUT PLEASES JAPANESE CATCHER
description: He is a five-time all-star catcher. But the Mets, who may have a catching crisis, don't expect their new, burly receiver, Yoshiharu Wakana, to make the club.

title: Patients' Rights
description: TO SCIENCE TIMES: I applaud Dr. Lawrence K. Altman for his insightful essay ''Hospital Patients Can Suffer Twice When Staff Adds Insult to Injuries'' (Feb. 22), describing the way we vulnerable patients are often treated in hospitals. It is assumed that we must trade our dignity and individuality for access to modern medical technology. But this tradeoff is neither necessary nor desirable. We do not check our human and legal rights at the hospital door. Dr. Altman calls for ''consumer activism,'' encourages patients to exercise their right to complain and suggests ombudsmen in hospitals, whose job is to ''listen.''

title: MUSIC: THE CINCINNATI SYMPHONY
description: THE Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra has been led by many important conductors during its 138-year history. A partial list would have to include Anton Seidel, Eugene Ysaye, Fritz Reiner, Leopold Stokowski, Max Rudolf and Thomas Schippers. The current leader is Michael Gielen, now in his third season as music director. The first question before the house last night at Carnegie Hall was the usual one where occasional visitors to New York are concerned: How is the orchestra faring under the new regime?

title: German Recovery Seen
description: The decline in the West German economy should bottom out gradually in 1983, but over the whole year real gross national product will show no growth, Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale said today. It said in its latest economic report that first-half G.N.P. will be down 1 percent, but could rise in the second half by 1 1/2 percent.

title: Adviser Dropped
description: George Kanter, who is in boxing's import-export business, bringing foreign fighters here (most notably, Jean-Pierre Coopman, to fight Muhammad Ali) and sending American boxers to Europe, has lost his place on Don King's payroll and his space in Murray Goodman's office as a result of bringing Lucien Rodriguez of France to meet Larry Holmes on March 27 in Scranton, Pa.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS SPY A BUDGET OPPORTUNITY
description: As House Democrats begin drafting a budget for the next fiscal year, Representative Leon E. Panetta of California summed up their mood this way: ''We're finally getting the ball after two years of playing defense.''

title: The U.N. Today; March 15, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Council for Namibia - 3 P.M.

title: BIRDS LEAVE PACIFIC ATOLL MYSTERIOUSLY
description: Virtually all the adult birds at Christmas Island have mysteriously abandoned the mid-Pacific atoll, leaving thousands of nestlings to starve to death, the National Science Foundation reported Monday.

title: ORROX CORP reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a loss of $2,292,000 from curtailment expense of the company's Satcom operations for the qr and yr; the 1981 net loss includes a tax credit of $49,00

title: ELECTING BOARDS FOR CITY SCHOOLS HAS POLITICAL AIR
description: Politicians have become more involved this year in New York City's district school board campaigns than in any of the previous five elections since 1970, according to politicians and educators.

title: STATE SENATE LEADER REJECTS SALES TAX ON PROFESSIONALS
description: The leader of the Republicans in the State Senate today rejected a proposal by Assembly Democrats to extend the sales tax to professional fees, including those of lawyers, architects, engineers and accountants.

title: HOW NOT TO 'ATONE' FOR JAPANESE-AMERICANS' INTERNMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: G.& W. Declines 12.4%; Profit Reported by Pabst
description: Gulf and Western Industries reported yesterday that earnings declined 12.4 percent in the fiscal second quarter, while revenues slipped 1.5 percent.

title: F.T.C. to Lose Antitrust Chief
description: Thomas John Campbell, chief of the Federal Trade Commission's Bureau of Competition, the agency's antitrust unit, today announced his intention to resign and join the faculty of the Stanford University Law School.

title: Books Of The Times
description: THE DARK SIDE OF GENIUS. The Life of Alfred Hitchcock. By Donald Spoto. 594 pages. Illustrated. Little Brown. $20.

title: MERRILL RESHAPING ASIA LINK
description: Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday announced a restructuring of its Asian partnership with Fung King Hey. The Hong Kong businessman, as part of the deal, plans to sell half of his 4 percent holding in Merrill Lynch, currently valued at about $65 million.

title: RUSSELL ASSERTS HIMSELF
description: W hen David Russell's basketball career at St. John's has ended and his contribution is measured, his development as an assertive figure on a basketball court may eventually be traced to the end of the 27th game of his senior season, the 114th of his career. Something unusual happened in a St. John's huddle near the end of what eventually became an overtime loss to Villanova at the Spectrum.

title: STANWOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
Mondale and Mitterrand Meet To Discuss East-West Issues
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and President Francois Mitterrand today discussed East-West relations and the proposed European deployment of new United States nuclear missiles, officials said.

title: ROSEN'S NEWSLETTER IS CHANGING OWNERS
description: The Rosen Electronics Letter, well known to semiconductor and personal-computer mavens, is about to change hands. Benjamin M. Rosen, 50, who founded the newsletter nine years ago, plans to sell Rosen Research Inc. to Esther Dyson, 31, who has been working at the New York-based concern since last August. The price is still being negotiated, she said. Rosen Research owns the newsletter.

title: BDM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ALOYSIUS F. SCHAEFFNER
description: Aloysius F. Schaeffner, former senior partner of the law firm of Patterson, Eagle, Greenough & Day, died Saturday at his home in Garden City, L.I. He was 82 years old.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: WITH the beginning of the European fall collections in Milan last M onday, some American retailers hoped that the latest crop of c lothing would produce a new style emblematic of a new decade, in m uch the same manner that the New Look emerged in 1947, symbolizing a nd informing a whole decade of postwar attitudes. The less d emanding said simply that a new style for a new season would do. Ther ealistic asked for clothing that did not look like instant markdown m aterial. But the word early in the week was that many retailers in M ilan could find neither a new cosmic look nor a new seasonal style a nd, worse, that Italy lacked luster.

title: MARIETTA PLANS SALE OF 4 CEMENT PLANTS
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to sell four cement plants to the Blue Circle Industries Group of Britain and Cementia Holdings A.G. of Zurich for more than $150 million cash plus inventories.

title: RATINGS ILLUSTRATE APPEAL OF FOOTBALL
description: F or several hours on Sunday afternoon, the television sports viewer could have hardly asked for anything more exciting. On NBC, North Carolina State's 81-78 upset victory over Virginia and Ralph Sampson in the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament title game enthralled Al McGuire, the former coach and current analyst.

title: Stuntman Scales Tower
description: Hundreds of people gathered below the 75-story Texas Commerce Tower, cheering and honking horns as a Los Angeles stuntman swung himself to the roof tonight, completing an 18-hour, 993-foot climb. Wearing a white tuxedo, Ron Broyles, 29 years old, began the climb at 4:30 A.M. and finished at 10:44 P.M. He was arrested on the roof and charged with criminal trespassing.

title: Bus Stop Stopped
description: It sounds obvious when Rose Dergeof, who lives in the little town of Hartford, Wis., says ''Bus service is vital for us.'' Just a few years ago, the views of Mrs. Dergeof and her neighbors would have assured continued service from Trailways. The big bus company would have needed permission from state regulators to drop its Hartford stop, and such permission would have been nearly impossible to obtain. Not any more.

title: SIMPSONS-SEARS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: CITY ORDERS HALT ON WORK AT 5 EAST SIDE 'SLIVER' SITES
description: City officials called a halt yesterday to work on five ''sliver'' buildings -tall, narrow apartment houses that tower over their residential neighbors.

title: Idea Rejected
description: A move, led by Sam Schulman of the Seattle SuperSonics, to employ ''replacements'' in the event of a National Basketball Association players strike April 2 was narrowly defeated at a meeting of N.B.A. owners in Los Angeles last week. Schulman, supported by Angelo Drossos of the San Antonio Spurs and Jerry Buss of the Los Angeles Lakers, suggested the league use players cut earlier by N.B.A. teams or current players from the Continental Basketball Association and European circuits. However, according to several owners, the Schulman plan was rejected by a narrow margin.

title: TUESDAY, MARCH 15, 1983; Energy
description: The OPEC nations agreed on a price cut for the first time ever. The new accord calls for a cut of 15 percent, to $29 a barrel, in Saudi Light crude, the key to OPEC's price structure. It also lowers the group's production quota to 17.5 million barrels a day, down a million, for the rest of the year. The first test of the pact is likely to come over Britain's North Sea prices. (Page A1.) Mexico cut its prices, too. (D23.) Under the accord, analysts say, Saudi Arabia has lost much of its once-crucial flexibility. (D22.)

title: SPEX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GEMCO NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes loss from discontinued operations of $170,000 and loss of $577,000 from disposal of discontinued operations...C-Ne t income

title: Sudan Reports Discovery Of Arms Cache for Coup
description: The authorities have seized 70 tons of arms, ammunition and explosives that Libyan agents smuggled into the Sudan last month in an effort to topple President Gaafar al-Nimeiry, the Sudanese press agency reported.

title: Layoff at Storage
description: The Storage Technology Corporation, Louisville, Colo., said it would lay off 500 people from its 8,135-worker Colorado operation, effective March 25, citing weak demand for disk data storage products.

title: OFFSHORE BANKING PERILS CITED IN A SENATE STUDY
description: The staff of a Senate subcommittee has found that the use of offshore banks and other facilities has become so pervasive that it ''undermines the integrity of American banks'' and defies the ability of United States law enforcement authorities to enforce the laws.

title: SUPERIOR INDUSTRIES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Demonstrations' Decline

title: FLAMES, WITH EDWARDS, TROUNCE DEVILS
description: The loudest cheers at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight came when the public-address announcer gave the result of the Rangers' 8-2 victory over the Flyers across the Hudson River.

title: RAIDERS TRIAL IN 2D PHASE
description: A reunion of sorts took place in United States District Court today, when the six jurors who last May found the National Football League guilty of violating antitrust laws gathered to begin the second phase of the trial.

title: HANLON EXCELS IN RANGER ROMP
description: The things Glen Hanlon had to fear never materialized last night. Bad goals did not sail into his net. The Madison Square Garden crowd did not boo him. And he did not lose.

title: RICHTON INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMMUNIQUE BY OPEC
description: Following is the text of a communique in English released today by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. The 13 nations agreed to lower the price of Saudi Arabian Light crude to $29 a barrel, from $34; this benchmark oil has a specific gravity of 34 degrees, as reckoned under the guidelines of the American Petroleum Institute, and is exported from Ras Tanura.

title: Britain Fills Ship Post
description: The British Government today appointed Graham Day, a 49-year-old Canadian, as chairman and chief executive officer of state-owned British Shipbuilders, effective in September. He is now with Dome Petroleum Ltd.

title: Gannon's Lucky Day
description: On Thursday night, Terry Gannon said, he will sit down to a dinner of corned beef and cabbage and hope that the luck of the Irish will stay with him through the Pepperdine game the next day. The former schoolboy star from Joliet (Ill.) Catholic High School joked yesterday that a leprechaun must have been sitting on his shoulder, guiding his movements, in the 81-78 victory over Virginia that helped North Carolina State win the Atlantic Coast Conference title and move into the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament and a first-round game against Pepperdine at Corvallis, Ore., on Friday.

title: OPEC STATES AGREE TO CUT OIL PRICES FOR THE FIRST TIME
description: Hoping to regain control over the world oil market, the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed today to cut prices for the first time in the group's 23-year history.

title: Intermountain Terms Are Listed by Salomon
description: Terms of one of the largest tax-exempt securities offerings ever, $798 million of Intermountain Power Agency bonds, were announced yesterday by Salomon Brothers, the investment banking firm that plans to sell the issue to the public Thursday.

title: A FREEZE BENEFITS US BOTH
description: Would passage of the House resolution calling for a verifiable United States-Soviet freeze on nuclear weapons undercut President Reagan's ability to negotiate sound treaties limiting and reducing strategic and intermediate-range nuclear systems?

title: DOCUTEL-OLIVETTI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ETHICS COMMISSION'S LEGACY: ANSWERS TO PAINFUL QUESTIONS
description: A presidential commission that has been wrestling with some of the most troubling ethical issues confronting modern medicine will go out of business this month, leaving behind advice that is bound to be influential in helping citizens, doctors, scientists and political leaders find morally acceptable answers to painfully difficult questions.

title: FIRST COLUMBIA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dating Earthquakes
description: Using flakes of charcoal thought to have been deposited by ancient forest fires, scientists have been able to determine the approximate dates of three prehistoric earthquakes along the western front of the Wasatch Mountains in Utah.

title: MURRAY M. HOWELL
description: Murray Maynard Howell, co-founder of Vermont Castings Inc., one of the world's largest manufacturers of wood stoves, died Sunday at the age of 38 after a long fight against cancer. A memorial service will be held Thursday in Hanover, N.H. Mr. Howell, born in Cleveland, attended the University of Pennsylvania and worked for corporate property investors in New York before coming to Vermont and starting the stove operation in 1975.

title: CLOSE ENCOUNTER FOR AN ASTEROID
description: The cigar-shaped asteroid Geographos will swing within 8.3 million miles of Earth Wednesday, making a close encounter it will not repeat for 25 years, an astronomer said Monday.

title: FEDERAL TROOPS TOLD NOT TO MARCH IN NEW YORK'S ST. PATRICK'S DAY
description: The Defense Department has barred Federal troops from marching in Thursday's St. Patrick's Day Parade in New York. It cited the furor over the selection of an ardent supporter of the Irish Republican Army as grand marshal.

title: A JUDGE'S RESPONSE TO A PROSECUTOR'S 'TRIFLES'
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 IN RADICAL GROUP JAILED IN SHOOTING
description: Two fugitive members of a radical West Coast group who were seized in the investigation into the Brink's robbery and killings in the New York City suburbs have pleaded guilty in the death of one of the group's members.

title: Brooklyn Outlet to Sell Half-Price Play Tickets
description: The Fulton Mall Theater Center, a half-price ticket outlet sponsored by the Theater Development Fund, will open at noon today in Brooklyn's Albee Square Triangle, Fulton Mall at De Kalb Avenue.

title: No Headline
description: VW Ends Pickup

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Personal Touch

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an Italian press scandal incorrectly identified a close associate of Licio Gelli, head of a secret Masonic lodge. The associate was Umberto Ortolani, a financier.

title: Federals Fall To Express
description: Mike Rae threw two touchdown passes to Ricky Ellis in a 35-second span of the second quarter tonight to spark the Los Angeles Express to a 20-3 victory over the Washington Federals in the United States Football League.

title: Stocks Off 3.29; Drop Is Broad
description: The stock market declined broadly yesterday and showed little reaction to the news that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had finally agreed on a plan to cut oil prices and set production levels.

title: PIZZA INN (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MICROS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
A Disappointed Coach
description: Coach Bob Dukiet, whose 22-5 St. Peter's team was snubbed by the National Invitation Tournament selection committee, said yesterday, ''Obviously, we were disappointed,'' But he said he was not complaining, because ''it would sound like sour grapes.''

title: Chess: Kasparov Wins 5th Game And Leads Belyavsky, 4-3
description: Gari Kasparov took a 4-3 lead over Aleksandar Belyavsky in their quarterfinal match in Moscow for world championship candidates. Kasparov, a 19-year-old Soviet grandmaster, won the fifth game and maintained his one-point advantage with draws in the sixth and seventh games. Belyavsky, a 29-year-old Russian co-champion, has three games left in which to recover. The 10-game match goes to the first player to get 5 1/2 points.

title: BECK-ARNLEY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a tax benefit of $383,000

title: Bridge: 32 Teams of 89 Surviving In Vanderbilt Tournament
description: The Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship continued here this afternoon at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals with 32 teams of an original entry of 89 surviving.

title: O'NEILL PROPOSES TO END TOOLBOOTHS ON TURNPIKE
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill proposed today removing the tollbooths on the Connecticut Turnpike at Stratford, Norwalk and Branford starting in the spring of 1984.

title: STAGE: BUNRAKU PUPPETS APPEAR AT JAPAN HOUSE
description: IN performance, the Bunraku Puppet Theater of Japan alters one's perception of the uses of puppetry in drama. On Saturday, an ensemble representing the virtuosic Osaka Bunraku company began a one-week engagement at Japan House, as part of a three-city American tour.

title: ILL-PROTECTED PORPOISES
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE BLOCK, JUST A TASTE OF INFLUENCE
description: Lunch at the White House with a junior aide to Edwin Meese 3d went for $80. Lunch at The Washington Post with the publisher sold for $65. An evening of political talk with local pundits brought less than half as much as a pair of season tickets to the Washington Redskins.

title: 2 BUYERS HALT PLANS FOR MERGER
description: The Associated Merchandising Corporation and Frederick Atkins Inc. said yesterday that they had terminated their merger plans. The union, proposed in January, would have created a combined group with $15 billion in purchasing power. The two organizations are separately owned by some of the country's largest department store chains and independent retailers.

title: NEW FOCUS ON CHEMISTRY OF JOYLESSNESS
description: IT'S not a matter of being miserable, necessarily, but rather an inability to be happy, an inability to have fun on a vacation, to be exhilarated by a personal triumph, even to enjoy common sensual pleasures.

title: Volkswagen Workers Ratify Pact With No Pay Increases
description: United Auto Workers members at Volkswagen of America's stamping plant here have ratified a contract that provides cost-of-living allowances but no basic pay increases.

NEW SOVIET RITUALS SEEK TO REPLACE CHURCH'S
description: Religion, Karl Marx said, is the opium of the people, so it seems only logical that his heirs, in their struggle against it, would turn to substitute drugs.

title: TIERCO GROUP INC reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
BLACK UNION FLEXES MUSCLES IN SOUTH AFRICA MINES
description: The scene in a hall adjacent to one of the hostels for black mineworkers at the President Brand gold mine here on a recent evening could hardly have existed even a year ago in the fervid imagination of the most optimistic labor organizer.

title: PACIFIC GAMBLE ROBINSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss; the yr-ago net income and shr earnings figures have been restated for the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 for foreign currency translation

title: RESIDUE OF CHEMICALS IN MEAT LEADS TO DEBATE ON HAZARDS
description: The residues of as many as 500 to 600 toxic chemicals may be present in this country's meat supply, according to the Food and Drug Administration. But how much of a danger this presents to humans is debatable, in part because only 60 residues are monitored by the Government and in part because of diverging opinions on the possible hazards.

title: JOB BILL STILL STALLED BY FIGHT ON BANK WITHHOLDING
description: An attempt to repeal the tax-withholding requirement on interest and dividend income continued today to snarl Senate efforts to pass an emergency recession relief bill.

title: The Earliest Silk
description: TO SCIENCE TIMES: We were disappointed to find in Science Times (Science Watch, Feb. 22) a picture of a Chinese bronze object with the caption ''Traces found on a Chinese blade suggest use of silks in 1300 B.C., 1,000 years earlier than previously reported.'' People in the Oriental field and textile historians have known for more than 40 years that the Chinese of the Shang or Yin Dynasty were already working silk with complex methods by 1300 B.C. This was first reported in 1935 by Dr. Vivi Sylwan, a Swedish scholar and textile expert.

title: 'Squeal Rule' Injunction Put in Permanent Form
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan issued a permanent nationwide injunction yesterday blocking new regulations to require federally subsidized clinics to tell parents when minors received prescription contraceptives.

title: TEAM AMERICA BACKED BY NEWCOMER TO SOCCER
description: When Robert K. Lifton got a call from Howard J. Samuels, president of the North American Soccer League, asking him how he would like to own a soccer team, Mr. Lifton says his first reaction was to hang up.

title: An Ill Wind for Weather Satellites
description: The Reagan Administration is proposing to sell the nation's four weather satellites and one land-surveying satellite to private industry. Just possibly, industry will run the system more efficiently. More likely, the National Weather Service will be impaired and the public will pay more for lower-quality forecasts.

description: Echoes of the 70's

title: 2 DANGEROUS DOCTRINES
description: President Reagan has now proclaimed and presumably bases his policy upon two dangerous doctrines:

title: Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., (Radio - WABC, 770; 7:15 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. Atlanta Hawks, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street.

title: INDEPENDENCE HOLDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revs for the latest qr and 6 mos includes a gain of $16,051,000 from the sale of the Rutherford B. Hayes Building

title: Coast Bank Closed
description: The Newport Harbour National Bank, Newport Beach, Calif., has been declared insolvent and closed by the Comptroller of the Currency. The authorities arranged for the Trans American National Bank of Monterey Park, Calif., to acquire it and for it to reopen immediately. The bank, declared insolvent Friday, had assets of $40 million and deposits of $40 million.

title: UDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29

description: The Justice Department has ended its investigation of the PTL Club and has found no evidence the South Carolina-based religious organization misused solicited contributions, department officials said today.

title: THE BEST ITALIAN DESIGNS BRIGHTEN FASHION SCENE
description: With the memorable Fendi show likely to go down in history as one of fashion's most shining hours, the Italian fall and winter collections have scored high marks with viewers here. The general caliber of the clothes has improved as an austere sophistication replaces last season's sex-kitten look. It is as if designers have grown up and realize that their customers have matured as well.

description: The Justice Department said today that it would conduct a full investigation into allegations that the United States Government assisted Klaus Barbie, a twice-convicted Nazi war criminal, to escape to Bolivia after World War II.

description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed a new proposal with a Federal judge to resolve a dispute over who may use the Bell name and trademarks after the Bell System is broken up next year.

title: WILLIAM S. GRAY Jr.
description: William S. Gray Jr., a vice president and chief financial officer of the Union Carbide Corporation, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 58 years old.

title: NO-HITTER FOR GUIDRY, MURRAY
description: All spring, Billy Martin has been asked what he learned from his two previous tenures as the Yankees' manager. Tonight he gave the answer.

description: Louis Nine, an Assemblyman from the Bronx for 13 years, died of cancer yesterday at his home in the Bronx. He was 60 years old. Mr. Nine specialized in legislation to provide housing for poor and middle-income families and to increase employment opportunities for minority groups.

description: Senator Gary Hart of Colorado described to the Senate today a military reform budget that he said would reduce the Reagan Administration's military spending plans by more than $60 billion by 1988 but produce better weapons and forces.

title: MUSIC: AZNAVOUR AT LUNT-FONTANNE
description: CHARLES AZNAVOUR opened at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater last night with undiminished passion and artistry. He is, as we have known for many years, not a dashing boulevardier but a man of the streets who sings with fervor about great love, false friends, lingering sorrow and memories that outlast relationships. Because he writes his own music and lyrics, he is a poet as well as a performer - and he is definably French.

title: FOR PUBLISHING, THE CITY, REMAINS 'THE MECCA'
description: So many publishing houses lined Fifth Avenue years ago that the stretch from 13th to 23d Street was dubbed ''Paternoster Row,'' after London's well-known publishing district. New York long ago became the pre-eminent publishing city in the world, and these days book publishers are scattered across Manhattan. The city's influence has extended beyond book publishing to magazines and journals, bookstore sales and book clubs.

Never from opening day until last fall did the plant shut down, and then, on Oct. 1, the assembly line stopped: a casualty of inflation, unemployment and the sharp competitive edge of such foreign car makers as the Japanese.
