description: A new transfer of political power is about to take place from the military Government to opposition political leaders. The shift will occur Tuesday, March 15, in 10 of Brazil's 23 states where opposition candidates won election as Governor in November. Those were the first gubernatorial contests to be held in 17 years. Most of the country's most powerful states are involved in the changeover - Rio de Janeiro, Sao Paulo and others in the developed south-central part of the country.

title: ARAFAT'S OPEN DOOR
description: In the six months since the Palestine Liberation Organization left the besieged city of Beirut, the need for unity has prevented the organization from taking bold initiatives in the peace process. Indeed, many news reports of the Palestine National Council meeting in Algiers last month gave the impression that the need for unity has largely paralyzed the organization. Yet, as an observer at the meeting, I found that in fact the P.L.O. would welcome a role in the peace process - and is more eager than ever before to find a political solution in the Middle East.

Washington is the city where the American survivors of the Holocaust would want to express gratitude for their new lives.''

The cardigan, for example, may be worn over a blouse for a going-to-work attitude or may be buttoned up and worn on its own. This set, in white or red mercerized cotton, has cablestitching on the cardigan's sleeves and down the front of the strapless camisole. John Quincy Adams Productions will print, distribute and sell the magazine. Public Broadcasting Communications Inc., a subsidiary of Channel 13, will still control content.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, exhibition at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Jay Howell, who will be the starting pitcher for the Yankees, was impressive in his last outing, pitching four no-hit innings, striking out four and walking two. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC-AM, 77; 7:15 P.M.) Mets vs. Boston Red Sox, exhibition at Winter Haven, Fla. 1:30 P.M. Mark (The Bird) Fidrych, still on the comeback trail, will start for the Red Sox. The Mets will start Craig Swan, who was routed by the Chicago White Sox in his last outing during a 20-5 loss.

title: F.D.I.C. URGES CUT IN INSURANCE LIMIT
description: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that he would propose legislation under which any bank deposit of more than $100,000 might be partially lost when a failing bank is merged into a healthy institution.

title: HOUSE TO VOTE ON FREEZE PLAN
description: Democratic and Republican leaders predicted today that the House would reverse itself Wednesday and adopt a nuclear freeze resolution, but they disagreed on the impact of that expected vote. Meanwhile, a key Senate sponsor predicted that the measure would be rejected by the Senate.

title: Attorney General Names Head of Barbie Inquiry
description: Attorney General William French Smith named Allan Ryan today to head an investigation into the relationship between Klaus Barbie and the United States Government.

title: DAME REBECCA WEST DIES IN LONDON
description: Dame Rebecca West, the versatile British woman of letters whose seven decades of literary output ranged from reportage to political commentary, essays, history and novels, died yesterday at her London home. She was 90 years old.

title: U.S. Divorces Fell in '82; First Decline in 20 Years
description: The number of divorces granted in the United States declined last year, the Government reported today. It was the first drop reported in that figure in two decades.

60-MINUTE GOUMET
description: SCALLOPS, now widely available on the East Coast, will be in season into April, which still allows us a short while to enjoy their goodness. title: 8 NATIONS PROPOSE A WAY TO BREAK THE EAST-WEST IMPASSE AT MADRID
description: Arguing that detente itself was at stake, eight neutral countries proposed a series of compromises today to break the East-West deadlock that has dogged the conference on security and cooperation in Europe, now in its third year.

description: The space agency confirmed yesterday that a small meteorite found in Antarctica a year ago was a piece of the Moon. It is the first time that the specific origin of a meteorite has been established.

description: A late rally, led by some of the blue-chip and technology issues, gave the Dow Jones industrial average a solid gain yesterday. The overall stock market, however, advanced only slightly in continued sluggish trading.

description: International Syria objects to Israeli goals in the negotiations with Lebanon, Syrian officials indicated. As Mr. Taruskin pointed out in his detailed notes, these works are far from the mainstream of even the ''authenticity'' movement, displaying a musical tradition that took its models from Western Europe but that often developed them into something quite different.

title: Bombing Suspect Gives Up
description: Former Police Chief Milton Schepp of St. George, missing since he was charged with the 1981 car bombing of a reputed underworld figure, Paul Leisure, surrendered to the St. Louis police Monday, officers said. Mr. Schepp, 44 years old, was released on $44,000 bond. He is scheduled to be arraigned Thursday.

title: Part of the Past

title: REAGAN, DON'T RUN UNTIL '84
description: Ronald Reagan should forget about running for reelection in 1984 - at least until 1984. If he doesn't put the election, and the advice he is getting about positioning himself for the race, out of his mind, he is likely to follow in Gerald R. Ford's footsteps and defeat himself with pre-campaign campaigning.

description: United Airlines said yesterday that it would adopt a fare plan, announced Monday by American Airlines, that ties coach fares in many of its markets to the distance traveled.

title: Prices Rise in Light Trading; Auction Bid Change Set
description: Prices of fixed-income securities moved up moderately yesterday in light trading and yields declined. Dealers said that much of the buying again came from traders who had sold short earlier and wanted to cover their positions before the Treasury announced the terms of its end-of-the-quarter re-funding offerings due next week.

description: THE Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is very much chastened. It has cut prices for the first time in its history, lowered the ceiling for oil production by its members and proclaimed its ''belief and confidence that OPEC remains the major force for oil market stability, beneficial to both consumers and producers.''

title: THE RUSSIAN TEA ROOM GOES HOLLYWOOD
description: LOS ANGELES AS a tourist walks through the revolving door embossed with the RTR logo, a familiar lunch-hour panorama comes into view. The waiters in their Russian Cossack uniforms scurry among the well-dressed guests. Quickly surveying the restaurant, one catches a glimpse of a man resembling Sam Cohn, the film and theatrical agent. At another booth is a woman who appears to be the public relations agent Marion Billings. And isn't that Dudley Moore chatting with Natassia Kinski and Armand Assante over Champagne and caviar?

title: KING LEADS KNICKS TO 6th IN ROW
description: Bernard King and Sly Williams, noted for their creative style of play, were at their creative best last night. With King going to the basket at full speed, sometimes while being triple-teamed, and Williams free-lancing, the Knicks overwhelmed the Atlanta Hawks at Madison Square Garden, 119-97.

title: APPEALS COURT ORDERS END TO DELAY ON ETHYLENE OXIDE RULES

title: Coach Steps Down
description: In his eight seasons as head basketball coach at Brigham Young, Frank Arnold ran up a respectable 137-94 record, and his team tied for first place in the Western Athletic Conference this year. But the Cougars' 15-14 overall record this season was not up to the standards Arnold set in 1980 and 1981 when his team went 24-5 and 25-7, and the pressure on Arnold to live up to his expectations was apparently great.

description: Free admissions, weekly fireworks and removal of a security fence were some of the changes Westchester County announced today for the 1983 season at Playland Park in Rye, which opens on a daily basis starting May 23.

description: I.B.M. Japan Ltd. announced a small business computer that can serve as a stand-alone, Japanese-language word processor or be linked to a central mainframe computer.

title: Retired Art Expert Reported Missing
description: Gordon B. Washburn, a former art museum administrator and retired director of the Asia Society Gallery in New York, has been missing from his Manhattan home since last week, the police reported.

title: ACTION ON JOB BILL SNAGGED IN SENATE
description: Senate leaders worked feverishly tonight to forge an agreement that could free the emergency job bill from a parliamentary tangle that has thwarted the legislation for almost a week.

title: Bank in Scarsdale Robbed of $9,000
description: A man with a pistol robbed a Scarsdale National Bank branch at the train station just before 7 A.M. today, escaping with $9,000 along a bicycle path that runs parallel to the tracks and the Bronx River Parkway.

title: Profits Fall at De Beers
description: De Beers Consolidated Mines said today that profits fell 24.9 percent last year, to the equivalent of $519 million, from $691 million in 1981. The recession has depressed sales, especially in the crucial American market.

title: Delivery Lag Seen On Surplus Cheese
description: New York will receive only about four of the eight million pounds of surplus cheese promised by the Federal Government for April and May for distribution to the needy, state officials said today.

description: ON THE EVE

title: DEMOCRATS OFFER BUDGET THAT CUTS MILITARY GROWTH
description: The House Democratic leadership outlined a proposed Government budget tonight for 1984 that would increase military spending by 4 percent, less than half the 10 percent rise sought by President Reagan, and would raise $30 billion extra in revenue through unspecified tax increases.

title: St. Louis Group Bids for the Blues
description: A group of St. Louis investors, led by James J. Kerley, vice chairman of the Emerson Electric Company, offered today to buy the St. Louis Blues for $8 million.

title: John W. Burke, Served In U.S. and State Posts
description: John W. Burke, a former assistant United States attorney and special assistant state attorney general, died Thursday morning, apparently of a heart attack, on his way to work at a Wall Street law firm. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Chrysler Expects $100 Million Profit
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it expects a pretax operating profit of at least $100 million in the first quarter of 1983, compared with a pretax loss of $89 million in the similar period last year. Chrysler made the prediction in an amendment to a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Perjury Charges In Donovan Case
description: Two former labor union officials were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on perjury charges stemming from their grand jury testimony during last year's investigation of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan's activities as a construction executive before entering government.

title: 2d Jail Suicide In Two Days
description: A 31-year-old inmate of a Bronx jail yesterday became the second suicide in a city jail in two days when he hanged himself with a sheet from the ceiling of his cell, a city correction official said.

title: HENRY STERN LOOKS TO PARKS JOB WITH ENTHUSIASM
description: Henry J. Stern is, if nothing else, enthusiastic. After nine years as a City Councilman at Large, he will become City Parks Commissioner on April 1 at twice the salary and, to hear him tell it, easily twice the fun.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: The Chinese Government said today that Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang ''at the moment has no specific plan to make his visit to the United States this year.''

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SILENCE, AND POETRY, ON OIL
description: As events would have it, when OPEC finally settled on a new production ceiling, output quotas and the first price cut in its 23-year history, the man at the podium to begin the news briefing was Mallam Yahaya Dikko, head of the Nigerian delegation and, in public, possibly the least communicative of the various delegates.

title: PRIVATE PENSION PLANS LIKELY TO RAISE RETIREMENT AGE, EXPERTS SAY
description: The move to change the age at which retired people are eligible for full Social Security benefits may prompt many private pension plans to raise their age of retirement as well, according to pension experts.

title: Barbara Bel Geddes Has Open-Heart Operation
description: Barbara Bel Geddes, the genteel matriach of television's ''Dallas'' family, underwent ''life-saving'' open heart surgery today after a massive heart attack, a spokesman said. Her condition was not immediately given.

title: QUANEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
TIME FOR SPRING LAMB, BUT DOES IT EXIST OR NOT?
description: SEVERAL butchers in the New York metropolitan area are announcing that spring lamb has come on the market. Others say it will not be available for a few weeks, while still others maintain that they sell it all year round. And some butchers insist that it does not exist anymore.

title: Big East Honors Mullin
description: Chris Mullin of St. John's was named today the Big East Conference's basketball player of the year for the 1982-83 season. Lou Carnesecca, who leads St. John's into the National Collegiate Athletic Association playoffs with a 27-4 record, was chosen the league's coach of year.

description: Council for Namibia - 3 P.M.

title: 'WIZARD OF OZ': A TV SUCCESS STORY
description: America will be off to see the wizard again Friday night - for the 25th time in the last 27 years. Perhaps the most extraordinary record on television belongs to the 1939 film ''The Wizard of Oz.'' No other single program has ever been repeated on network prime-time television 10 times, much less 25 times. And very few other television programs have been as successful. Each of its first nine years in a row, more than 49 percent of the television audience watched Judy Garland whirled by a cyclone to a magical land to meet a wizard who is a humbug. And only once has the movie been out of the top 20 shows of the week as measured by the Neilsen ratings.

title: DR. CLARKE WILLIAMS, A NUCLEAR PHYSICIST AND NEUTRON EXPERT
description: Dr. Clarke Williams, a nuclear physicist and former deputy director of the Brookhaven National Laboratory at Upton, L.I., died yesterday at his home in Bellport, L.I., after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: 2 NEW CHIEF RABBIS SELECTED FOR TERM OF 10 YEARS IN ISRAEL
description: Two new Chief Rabbis of Israel were elected in Jerusalem today for 10-year terms to replace religious leaders who had wanted to continue in the offices they assumed in 1972.

title: News Analysis
description: After almost two years in power, French Socialism is looking for its second wind, and the place where it seems to think it can regroup is at the center rather than further on the left.

title: Two Letter Bombs Received in London
description: A letter bomb mailed to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was intercepted and safely defused today just hours after another letter bomb exploded in the United States Navy's European headquarters in London, the police said.

title: DRIESELL AVOIDS INQUIRY ISSUE
description: The University of Maryland basketball team left today for the start of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament hampered by the absence of its best defensive player and a controversy involving the conduct of its coach, Lefty Driesell.

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL DEFENDS ACTIONS BY JUSTICE DEPT. IN CONTEMPT CASE
description: Under sharp questioning today by Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee, Attorney General William French Smith repeatedly maintained that there was no way to prevent conflicts between the executive and legislative branches like the battle over access to Environmental Protection Agency documents.

title: NETS WIN AS DAWKINS HITS 10 OF 11
description: The play that unfolded with 4 minutes 31 seconds left was a reflection of how the Nets scored a 109-90 victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight at Byrne Meadowands Arena.

title: Politics Lures McMillen
description: Tom McMillen of the Atlanta Hawks has long been interested in politics. A volunteer in many campaigns in his native Maryland, the 6-foot-11-inch forward has raised money for Democrats on both the state and national levels and has been seen as a potential candidate for office some day.

description: Aldege (Baz) Bastien, general manager of the Pittsburgh Penguins of the National Hockey League, died early today after his car collided with a motorcycle on a suburban highway. He was 62 years old.

description: A top official of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that two recent equipment failures within three days at the Salem 1 nuclear power plant in South Jersey were the most significant occurrences involving reactor safety since the Three Mile Island mishap in Pennsylvania in 1979.

description: The newspaper Le Monde said today that the Soviet Union had refused to accredit the paper's designated Moscow correspondent because he was too knowledgeable in Eastern European affairs.

title: The Sixth Deadly Sin
description: Centuries after theologians classified anger as the sixth of the seven deadly sins, psychologists gave it a new definition. Anger the deadly became anger the pollutant - a corrosive smoke best vented by an open mouth.

Andrea Jaeger withdrew yesterday from a $150,000 tournament in Boston because of continuing problems with an injured right ankle and left knee.

title: HOUSING STARTS ARE UP BY 2.9%
description: Surprising even their own trade group, American builders began work on new houses and apartments in February at an annual rate of 1.76 million units, the highest level since 1979, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Whaler Rumblings
description: In hopes of making the Hartford Whalers a Stanley Cup contender next year, the club's corporate parent plans to recruit some new talent - for the front office. According to Donald C. Conrad, an executive vice president of Aetna Life & Casualty, the Whalers' largest stockholder, the search is on for ''a czar'' who will have full executive authority over the team and hold the new title of president. To give the new man a clear field, the post of director of hockey operations, now held by Larry Pleau, will be abolished.

title: Oiler on Probation
description: J.C. Wilson, a defensive back for the Houston Oilers, pleaded guilty today to driving while intoxicated and driving with a suspended license and was sentenced to $1,000 in fines and two years probation. Jimmie Duncan, Harris County Criminal Court at Law Judge, accepted Wilson's pleas and sentenced him to a year in prison, suspended in lieu of two years probation, and a $500 fine on the drunk driving charge. Wilson was arrested Jan. 12.

title: POOL-BATHROOM SHAPES UP AS THE NEW AMENITY
description: THE open-plan bathroom, which made its first appearance at the beginning of the fitness craze several years ago, is on the way to becoming a basic amenity for some. Long hidden behind closed doors, the bathroom is now dropping its modesty and opening out into a spacious bath-dressing-exercise area.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MARCH 17, 1983
description: International The chief of the Soviet General Staff, Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, suggested that if the American medium-range missiles planned for deployment in Europe were used against the Soviet Union, Moscow would retaliate directly against the United States. The marshal, in an interview, generally struck a moderate posture. He said that once nuclear war begins it cannot be limited and controlled. (Page A1, Column 5.) Five Salvadoran defendants were upheld by an Appellate Court judge. He ruled that the trial of five former National Guard members accused of the murder of four American churchwomen in 1980 could not proceed until a lower court provided more evidence in the case. (A6:1-3.)

title: Wind Damages Guatemala
description: Winds with gusts up to 50 miles an hour struck the city today, blacking out most of the capital and destroying ramshackle hillside homes, the authorities said. President Efrain Rios Montt declared a nationwide state of emergency.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN a ceiling is in such poor condition that it is practically beyond repair - badly cracked and peeling in large sections or bulging and falling in places - then one of the most permanent and attractive ways for the do-it-yourselfer to solve the problem is to install ceiling tile or a suspended ceiling.

title: ANCIENT CRAFT OF PRINTING COMES HOME
description: JOHN V. FLEMING has a huge living room with a high ceiling but not much furniture - only a grand piano, two couches and a lamp. What take up the most space and make his living room different from all the others on University Place in Princeton, N.J., are the two old printing presses and five wooden cabinets filled with metal printer's type. Like Gutenberg and Benjamin Franklin, he is a printer. Like many latter-day lords of small presses, he prints for pleasure, not profit, on equipment that has been discarded by commercial print shops, sold at auctions and squeezed into homes.

title: HOUSE ROLL-CALL ON G.O.P. MOVE TO MODIFY FREEZE RESOLUTION
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 215 to 209 by which the House or Representatives today defeated an amendment by Representative Mark D. Siljander, Republican of Michigan, to modify the nuclear freeze resolution by giving the President the option to negotiate a freeze or a reduction in armaments. A ''yes'' vote is for the amendment. Voting ''yes'' were 57 Democrats and 152 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 204 Democrats and 11 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes those not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, yes; Erdreich, yes; Flippo, yes; Nichols, yes; Shelby, yes. Republicans - Dickinson, yes; Edwards, yes.

title: CARRIERS BACK AMERICAN ON SIMPLIFIED FARE PLAN
description: Most of the nation's major airlines yesterday came out in support of a plan by American Airlines to tie fares to the distance traveled. Trans World Airlines and Continental Air Lines said that they would apply the new fare structure to their entire route systems. This extends the markets that would be affected, because the two carriers fly some routes not served by American.

title: Growth Slows In Soviet
description: The Soviet Union's rate of economic growth slowed in February after a strong showing in January. Figures published today by the Central Statistics Board showed that industrial output in the first two months of the year increased 5.6 percent from the level of a year before.

title: KOCH OPTIMISTIC AS HE EVALUATED CITY'S ECONOMY
description: Mayor Koch expressed optimism on New York City's economy yesterday and pessimism on the city budget. The city suffered less from the recession than the rest of the nation, he said in the semiannual report to the United States Treasury required under the law by which the Federal Government guarantees city borrowing.

title: Carnesecca Coach of Year
description: Lou Carnesecca, who guided St. John's to a 27-4 record and the Big East Conference championship, has been selected as coach of the year by the Basketball Writers Association of America.

title: STAGE: 'BUNDLE OF NERVES' REVUE AT TOP OF THE GATE
description: IN contrast to many other shows of its ilk, ''A Bundle of Nerves,'' a new musical revue at the Top of the Gate, has a consistency of attitude if not of quality. As the title promises, almost all of the songs deal with anxieties - about eating, drinking, flying, sex, aging and dying. Watching the show, I was increasingly aware of another phobia: fear of boredom.

title: EX-HOUSE EMPLOYEE CLAIMS REP. DELLUMS GOT DRUGS FROM HIM
description: A former doorkeeper for the House of Representatives has told a Federal grand jury here that he sold marijuana and cocaine to Representative Ronald V. Dellums, according to Federal officials familiar with the inquiry.

title: ALASKA'S OIL DREAM CLOUDED BY EXPECTED DROP IN OUTPUT
description: Measured by the wind-chill factor, the temperature was 86 degrees below zero, driving snow made it impossible to see more than a few feet, and even the ravens seemed to be huddling from the cold. It was a typical March day at Prudhoe Bay, America's biggest oilfield.

title: ATOM FREEZE PLAN STALLED IN HOUSE BY G.O.P. MEMBERS
description: House Republicans stalled action tonight on a nuclear freeze resolution after 13 hours of debate, as House Democrats failed on several efforts to speed consideration of the measure.

title: U.S. EVALUATES BENEFITS OF PRICE CUT BY OPEC
description: A Treasury official told Congress today that OPEC's 15 percent cut in oil prices could increase the output of goods and services in the United States by four-tenths of 1 percent and reduce consumer prices by nearly one percentage point.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Tuesday about May 3 school board elections in New York City incorrectly quoted Assemblyman Leonard P. Stavisky. He said that school board lines had not been revised since 1970 but had periodically been approved without change by the New York State Legislature.

title: Dutton Publisher Leaving
description: John Macrae 3d, the publisher of E.P. Dutton, will become editor in chief of Holt, Rinehart & Winston, the trade book publishing unit of CBS. Mr. Macrae joined Dutton as editor in chief in 1968, following in the footsteps of his grandfather and uncle, both of whom had been publishers at the book company. He will fill a vacancy at Holt created when Donald Hutter resigned last fall to join Simon & Schuster. Mr. Macrae said that he expected to report at his new job in about a week. Dutton has not yet named a successor.

description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block, reluctantly carrying out a Congressional plan to hold down dairy surpluses, announced today that a special assessment on milk production would go into effect next month.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ralph Sampson, the Virginia center, was named player of the year for the third straight year in a poll of sportswriters conducted by United Press International. Only two other players, Oscar Robertson of Cincinnati and Bill Walton of U.C.L.A., won the award three years in a row. ... Walton, now with Clippers, expects to have surgery after the season to relieve pressure on his right foot. ... Anne Donovan of Old Dominion was selected by the Atlanta Tipoff Club to receive the first Naismith Award as the women's college basketball player of the year. ... Roman Gabriel, the quarterback coach of the Boston Breakers, has a new quarterback to coach. His son, Robin, a 6-foot-5-inch former starter at the University of New Mexico, was signed as the team's third quarterback. ... Mary Decker Tabb won the third Jesse Owens International Award as the world's top amateur athlete.

title: BRAXTON QUESTIONS TACTICS OF SPINKS
description: In the same manner that offensive linemen who get away with illegal holding consider themselves smart football players, boxers who bend the Marquess of Queensberry rules take a certain pride of authorship for what others might consider ''dirty fighting.''

title: Ultramar to Buy Pittston Petroleum
description: Ultramar P.L.C. said its American subsidiary, Ultramar America Inc., had signed a conditional letter of intent to buy Pittston Petroleum Inc., a subsidiary of the Pittston Company of Greenwich, Conn.

title: HOUSE TURNS BACK EFFORT TO MODIFY ATOM FREEZE PLAN
description: The Democratic-controlled House tonight narrowly rejected a Republican effort to significantly modify a resolution calling for a ''mutual and verifiable freeze and reductions in nuclear weapons'' between the United States and Soviet Union.

title: CONCERT: MEHLI MEHTA
description: Mehli Mehta made his New York conducting debut on Tuesday night in Carnegie Hall and proved that his son Zubin actually followed his own talented baton.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS SEARCH OFFICE OF WRITER FOR U.S. NEWSPAPER
description: The security police today searched the residence and office of Allister Sparks, a correspondent of The Washington Post and The London Observer. Mr. Sparks said later that they had told him they were looking for evidence that he had illegally quoted the wife of the imprisoned leader of the outlawed African National Congress.

title: HELP FOR TENANTS ON RENTERS' RIGHTS
description: ANEW privately published pamphlet is available to tenants who feel they have legitimate lease-overcharge claims in New York City. The pamphlet, called ''Qualifying for a Rent Reduction,'' is a commonsense guide through the maze of legal procedures involved in pursuing a claim. It supplements already-existing tenant resources, including the Conciliation and Appeals Board's telephone-tape service and the city printing office's rent-stabilization policy book.

title: 3 Seized in Holdup
description: Two men found hiding in the trunk of a car and the woman who was driving were arrested yesterday in connection with a holdup at Michael Anthony Jewelers, 46 West 46th Street, the police said. A third man was sought.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allis-Chalmers Corp., Milwaukee, said it had sold its Simplicity Manufacturing Co. division to Wesray Equipment Inc., a subsidiary of Wesray Corp., Morristown, N.J.; terms were not disclosed.

title: SUPERMARKETS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: The latest fourth qr results benefited from a pre-tax LIFO credit of $1.4 million against a larger $2.3 million LFIO credit which negatively affected yr-to-yr earnings comparisons for the qr

title: STRIKE IN SPAIN PITS MATADORS AGAINST THEIR HELPERS
description: In Castellon and Valencia and Madrid and throughout Spain on recent Sundays, there has been no death in the afternoon.

title: ACCOUNTANTS DISCUSS PENSION RULE REVISIONS
description: More than 250 accountants from major corporations packed the pension seminar of the National Association of Accountants yesterday to learn about the potential impact of newly proposed accounting rules.

description: No yr-ago shr earnings figure was disclosed; net income figures are after extraordinary items

description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Dexatrim Magazine Campaign
description: UNTIL now, Compton Communications' advertising for Dexatrim, a weight-reduction aid, has been built on testimonials from users. The approach has been successful, helping the Thompson Medical Company product push to the top of its class and to double sales of the class in three years. Now a second prong is being added to the attack - the recommendation of pharmacists.

title: 15 Killed in Calcutta as Trains Crash at a Main Rail Junction
description: At least 15 people were killed and more than 200 injured when a commuter train crashed into another at a busy railroad station today, authorities said.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT ISLANDERS BY 2-1
description: Except for looking at the calendar, there was no way to tell that the Rangers and Islanders were not engaged in a playoff game last night.

description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $549,000 for the qr and $967,000fora the 6 mos...C-After income of $236,000 from discontinued operations for the qr and a gain of $494,000 from discontinued operations

title: SENATORS PLAN VOTE IN AN ARMS POST DISPUTE
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee is expected to vote on Tuesday on whether to make public two documents that are said to raise questions about remarks made by Kenneth L. Adelman, President Reagan's nominee to be the nation's chief armscontrol official, and Edward L. Rowny, the chief strategic arms negotiator.

title:
Topics;
Revealing Truth
description: The nation's banks are waging all-out war against tax withholding on interest and dividend payments. They are stuffing anti-withholding fliers in their customers' monthly statements, along with postcards for them to sign and send to their senators demanding votes for repeal.

title: Contract for Daewoo
description: Daewoo Shipbuilding and Heavy Machinery Ltd. won a $110 million contract to build a gas compression platform for the Arabian American Oil Company, Daewoo officials said today. The contract was given through Brown & Root Inc. of the United States, which is the prime contractor.

title: Delta's New Terminal
description: The Delta Air Lines terminal being built at La Guardia Airport will cost about $100 million, Delta's president, David C. Garrett Jr., said yesterday.

title: A BALLET MASTER IN CHIEF
description: Peter Martins first tried his hand at directing a ballet company in 1977, when he headed a little group of soloists from the New York City Ballet that gave occasional performances during a strike by the company's orchestra. ''A director,'' he said then, ''has to find a way to make all the dancers happy without compromising his own ideas.'' Now the 36-year-old Danish-born dancer and choreographer will help guide the entire New York City Ballet, which he joined in 1970. Since George Balanchine's hospitalization five months ago, Mr. Martins has been a key member of the small group that has been running the company.

title: ARCHITECTURAL IMITATION: IS IT PLAGIARISM
description: FOR some architects, imitation may be the sincerest flattery, but for others it is plagiarism. Over the last few years, several legal cases, threats of suits and published accusations within the architectural community have turned the sensitive but vague subject of design influence into an issue discussed outside the drafting room.

title: HERS
description: IN his essay ''Three Good Women,'' Montaigne writes of women who committed suicide with their husbands. Only in the case of Paulina, wife of Seneca, did the attempt fail. But, says Montaigne, such failure does not diminish her honor, virtue and devotion, ''showing by the pallor of her face how much of life had flowed away through her wounds.''

title: INTERCOLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $553,000 from the sale of real estate; shr earnings reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid Jan 20

title: Plan for Atomic Waste Issued
description: An independent research group, warning that shipping radioactive wastes on highways was unsafe and unnecessary, has recommended that special casks be used to expand storage of the wastes at nuclear power plants until safer shipping methods were developed.

title: SANDSTONE FACADES : A GUIDE TO REPAIRS
description: Sandstone and brownstone buildings decay easily - the surface may rub off, large sections of stone may separate and be lost or the facade may become cracked or blistered.

title: PROTESTS BACKED AT CONFERENCE ON SOVIET JEWS
description: Delegates to the World Conference on Soviet Jewry exhorted each other today to step up demonstrations, letterwriting campaigns and other public action on behalf of those who want to leave the Soviet Union.

title: Atari Assignment
description: Another announcement has been made by Warner Communications' Atari and this time we learn that Needham, Harper & Steers has also got a bit of the action - two new unidentified video game cartridges scheduled for introduction later this year. The West Coast company also formally identified for the first time the business that Wells, Rich, Greene had before its new home-computer assignment. It was the Sesame Street Library, the Child's Video Game Catridges and the computer keyboard for the Atari video game machine, all of which are due out later this year.

title: AUTODYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
5 U.S. MARINES AND 9 ITALIANS WOUNDED IN LEBANON
description: Units of the multinational peacekeeping force were attacked here Tuesday night and today, and nine Italian soldiers and five United States marines were wounded.

title: Arthur Goldberg Urges A Visa for Mrs. Allende
description: The Justice Department said today that it had received a letter from Arthur J. Goldberg, who served on the Supreme Court from 1962 to 1965, urging that the widow of President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile be granted a visa to enter the United States. The State Department denied her one March 3 on the ground that her presence would be ''prejudicial to United States interest.''

title: The Ides of El Salvador
description: Seldom has an important request been so ineptly defended as the Reagan Administration's bid for $60 million, then $110 million, in new aid for El Salvador. It tried to blame a fascist legacy on Soviet arms, overstated the military perils and scornfully dismissed the yearning for a political strategy that suits the available means.

title: New Publisher At Bon Appetit
description: Harry Myers, recently named group publisher at Knapp Communications, has brought in Robert S. Phelps, a former associate at the Meredith Corporation, to be publisher of Bon Appetit magazine.

title: THE BOOM IN MUNICIPAL BONDS
description: Local governments, which are struggling to keep their budgets in balance, have found that, despite their problems, they still have access to the capital markets.

title: G.M.-Toyota Deal Studied
description: James C. Miller 3d, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, told the Senate Commerce Committee today that the F.T.C. had begun an ''intensive investigation'' into the joint venture of the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation to build a small car in the United States.

title: Thorpe Controversy
description: Since Jim Thorpe's Olympic medals were restored last year, members of his family have been campaigning to have the athlete's body removed from a mausoleum in Jim Thorpe, Pa., and reinterred in Oklahoma, where he was born. To help the campaign, Thorpe's youngest son, Jack, the chief of the Sac and Fox Indian tribe, visited the town, a union of the former communities of Mauch Chunk and East Mauch Chunk that raised $10,000 to build the tomb after Thorpe's death in 1953.

title: EQUINOX SOLAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
WHEN REPERTORY IS A STAGE PROP
description: The life and pianistic exploits of Vladimir Horowitz are much on our minds today, especially with Glenn Plaskin's newly published and much talked about biography ''Horowitz.'' Why does the reputation of this eccentric Russian virtuoso keep growing?

title: Texaco Report On '83 Production
description: Texaco Inc. said it expects its oil production to continue to slip this year, but sees natural gas output rising after falling for several years.

title: NORDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Trucker Charged In Turnpike Crash
description: A truck driver surrendered today on charges stemming from the Connecticut Turnpike crash that killed seven people on Jan. 19.

title: Chemical Producer Appoints Executive
description: George D. Kennedy, president of the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation, a major producer of fertilizer, will be named chief executive officer at the company's annual meeting in October. Richard A. Lenon, who is currently chief executive, will continue as chairman.

title: VICORP RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 6
REFORM RABBIS CHANGE RULE ON WHO IS A JEW
description: In a decision running counter to centuries-old Jewish law, a group of American Reform rabbis have declared that children of all mixed marriages involving Reform Jews should be considered Jewish if they so desire.

title: SAN DIEGO PICKS 2 IN A MAYORAL VOTE
description: Maureen O'Connor, a well-to-do former City Council member, and Roger Hedgecock, a County Supervisor, topped 20 candidates in the San Diego mayoral primary election Tuesday to qualify for the runoff election May 3.

title: TV: WENDY HILLER IN 'MISS MORISON'
description: PUBLIC television's ''Mystery!'' series takes an unusual turn tonight with a production called ''Miss Morison's Ghosts,'' which can be seen on WNET/13 from 10 P.M. to 12:15 A.M., including timeouts for fund-raising activities. With Sir John Woolf as executive producer for Britain's Anglia Television, the film was made about two years ago and constructed in three acts. It is based on actual events that began in Oxford in 1901.

title: JAZZ VOCALIST: SYLVIA SYMS
description: THE programs in John Gruen's ''Five Ladies of Jazz'' series at the Metropolitan Museum of Art feature an onstage conversation-interview with the performer before her set. In the best part of an otherwise tedious half-hour talk on Monday, the singer Sylvia Syms insisted, ''I am so grateful for lyricists.''

title: New Comex Chairman
description: The Commodity Exchange in New York elected Oscar Burchard chairman yesterday. Mr. Burchard is president of the Ore and Chemical Corporation, a major metals trader. He succeeds David T. Johnston, senior vice president for E.F. Hutton.

title: KNICKS TROUNCE BUCKS FOR 7th STRAIGHT
description: On the road and at home, first against the weak teams and now against the strong ones, the remarkable turnaround of the Knicks goes on. Tonight, they achieved a a 105-93 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: 2 Lost Girls Found in Woods
description: Two young sisters, lost overnight in woods in a mountainous area, were found huddled in a fallen tree at daybreak today, cold but unharmed. The youngsters, Melinda Simmons, 4 years old, and her sister, Kelly, 3, were reported in good condition at a local hospital. About 400 volunteers participated in the 12-hour search in subfreezing temperatures.

title: FROG IN THE CHINA CLOSET
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: In reading Marilyn Bethany's piece, ''Accessories: They Can Make or Break a Room'' (March 10), I was appalled to realize that I would be viewed as infra dig by our most fashionable interior designers.

title: Griswold Chief Named
description: Out in Cleveland, Patrick J. Morin, 44, who once worked in the New York office of Griswold-Eshleman, has been named chief executive officer in addition to the president's title he has had since 1979. In his new role he replaces Richard E. Garbracht, the agency's 51-year-old chairman, who resigned. Mr. Morin joined the agency in New York, having previously run his own direct marketing firm. Before that he worked for J. Walter Thompson and Grey Advertising.

title: RICHMOND TANK CAR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BARNES CALLS LIFE IN DRUGS 'SHALLOW'
description: Leroy (Nicky) Barnes testified in a Manhattan narcotics trial yesterday that he began cooperating with the authorities after realizing in prison that his friends had double-crossed him and that he had led a ''shallow'' life as a wealthy heroin dealer.

description: Early in this century, an American specialist in linguistics wrote of Australian English that it ''represents the most brutal maltreatment which has ever been inflicted upon the mother tongue by the great English-speaking nations.''

title: Carborundum Co.
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) announced it would close two of its Carborundum Company bonded abrasives manufacturing plants, in Niagara Falls and Logan, Ohio, with a loss of 900 jobs. The company, which said it was also closing or selling bonded and coated abrasives operations in Canada, Europe and Latin America, said it expected a $75 million write-down, including operating losses before shutdowns or sales.

REAGAN REAFFIRMS GOAL FOR LEBANON
description: President Reagan told a high-level Lebanese delegation today that he would not retreat from his goal of bringing about the withdrawal of all foreign troops from Lebanon.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CHICAGO (AL) - Placed Fran Hirs- c hy, pitcher, on the disabled list and as- s igned him to Glen Falls of the Eastern L eague. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Signed Steve C arlton, pitcher, to a four-year contract. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Traded George B jorkman, catcher, to the Houston Astros f or Jeff Meadows, pitcher. YANKEES (AL) - Sent six players to t heir minor league camp for re-assign- m ent: Curt Kaufman, Scott Patterson, D ennis Rasmussen and Stefan Wever, p itchers; Edwin Rodriguez, infielder, and S cott Bradley, catcher.

title: FACTORY USE GAINS FOR A THIRD MONTH
description: Manufacturers increased their factory use for the third consecutive month in February, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. A big gain in auto output was a main factor.

title: Rozelle Counters Raider Money Loss
description: Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, testified in United States District Court today that the Raiders did not necessarily suffer financial losses in 1982 because the team was unable to move from Oakland to Los Angeles until only two months before the start of the 1982 season.

title: James J. Flynn Jr., 72, Dead; Former Perth Amboy Mayor
description: James J. Flynn Jr., who was Mayor of Perth Amboy, N.J., from 1950 to 1970, died yesterday at his home there. He was 72 years old. Mr. Flynn, a funeral director, was elected Middlesex County Coroner in 1938 and Mayor in 1950.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: WHETHER there is anything left to invent as far as chairs are concerned is a question that, much recent history suggests, should be answered in the negative. Not hundreds but thousands of chairs have been designed in the 20th century, and no small number are attempts to reinvent the wheel - tired struggles to force a new conception onto an old problem, with little to recommend them except their newness.

title: YANKEES' HOWELL IS CONFIDENT
description: If Jay Howell wins a job with the Yankees this spring, he will not be a 27-year-old rookie. Yet he has pitched only small parts of three seasons in the majors, and 27 is rather old to be starting a major league career.

title: Wild-Card Loser
description: After Kathy Jordan saw her ranking on the Women's Tennis Association computer improve to 16th this week, she was elated. The top 16 players were to receive invitations for the $350,000 Virginia Slims of New York tournament starting next Wednesday at Madison Square Garden.

title: 3.2% Rise Shown In Major Crimes
description: Less than a week after reporting that the New York City crime rate fell 5.1 percent last year, the Police Department said yesterday that there had been a 3.2 percent increase in major crimes last January over January 1982.

title: DANCE: 'QUARTET' FOR FIVE BY CUNNINGHAM TROUPE
description: IF anyone had said even last week that Merce Cunningham would choreograph one of the most emotionally stirring and scary works on the dance stage, he or she would have been drummed right out of the avant-garde international.

title: Spain to Buy Harriers
description: Spain will buy up to 12 Harrier fighter planes made jointly by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and British Aerospace P.L.C. for an aircraft carrier under construction, a spokesman for McDonnell Douglas said today. Delivery of the vertical-takeoff fighters will start in 1986 at a price of $30.8 million each, he said. The package includes eight planes and an option for four more.

title: 5 Bodies Are Recovered In Texas Gas Explosion
description: Firefighters and sheriff's deputies today recovered the bodies of a woman, her three children and a workman who died in the explosion of a propane gas pipe.

title: Chapin Given Arts Medal
description: Schuyler Chapin, dean of the School of the Arts at Columbia University and former general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, has been awarded this year's Medal of Honor for Music from the National Arts Club. Mr. Chapin will receive the award at a dinner on March 23. Also receiving awards that evening will be seven winners of the club's 26th annual music scholarships. The National Arts Club was founded in 1898 and sponsors various philanthropic programs.

title: Intermountain Offering Raised to $900 Million
description: A new offering of $798 million of Intermountain Power Agency taxexempt bonds has been increased to a record $900 million because of strong demand for the issue, Salomon Brothers, which heads the underwriting group, said yesterday.

title: COAST BANK PLANS BOND EXPANSION
description: The Security Pacific Corporation, which has steadily raised its stake in nonbank financial services, said today that it plans to acquire two independent brokers of municipal and corporate bonds.

title: Baldwin Loan Extension Seen
description: Eight to ten lenders, led by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, have granted the Baldwin-United Corporation a 12-day extension on $440 million in short-term loans due last Monday, banking sources said. The funds were part of Baldwin's financing for its $1.2 billion purchase of the MGIC Investment Corporation last year.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Montreal Expos, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Shane Rawley, both a short and a long reliever for the Yankees last season, will again start an exhibition game. So far this spring, he has given up 14 hits and eight runs in five innings. (Radio - WABC, 770; 7:15 P.M.) Mets vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at St. Petersburg, Fla., 1:30 P.M. (No radio or television).

description: Henry Kissinger plans to discuss the Vietnam War in a class at Georgetown University. Before he does, he has to show his lecture notes to officials at the State Department, the Defense Department, the Central Intelligence Agency and the White House, and delete any thoughts they decide are secret.

description: The Senate fought to a standoff today on the question of tax withholding from dividend and interest income, and as a result, a $5.1 billion emergency jobs bill remained mired in the legislative mud.

New Citibank Mortgage Offer
description: Citibank announced yesterday that it had begun to offer fixed-rate mortgages on homes and cooperative apartments, with maturities up to 30 years.

description: A dispute of nearly 20 years over whether to renew the deteriorating West Front of the Capitol by an extension or by restoration flared anew today as a House subcommittee began examining the options.

title: Chaminade Gains
description: Tim Dunham scored 25 points to lead top-seeded Chaminade to an 82-65 victory of Saginaw Valley State (Mich.) tonight in the second round of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics tournament.

title: DANCE: WORKS BY 3 CHOREOGRAPHERS
description: ANNABELLE GAMSON, Phyllis Lamhut and Don Redlich have a number of things in common. The three, who shared a concert Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater, owe allegiance in varying measure to the style of Mary Wigman, the German Expressionist choreographer whose work is probably the least known in America of all the modern dance pioneers. Each is a dancer of compelling, seasoned maturity, whose choreography is always interesting and often provocative. And the three have assembled a group of dancers who are nearly as striking performers as they.

description: An authoritative Congressional study has concluded that Federal regulations governing toxic waste disposal do not assure ''protection for human health'' from ''massive annual accumulations of hazardous waste.''

description: Michael J. Vastola has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the Lionel Corporation, the toy retailer that has been operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings since February of last year.

description: According to a current Dublin joke, St. Patrick didn't really drive the snakes out of Ireland - he merely drove them across the border into the six counties of Northern Ireland, where their descendants remain today divided in bitter sectarian warfare.

title: Market Place; Hopeful Year For Footwear
description: DURING the five years ended with 1980, shares of the Stride Rite Corporation, the leading producer of children's high-quality shoes, traced a flat line on the stock chart. In the last year, however, the price has nearly tripled.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
SOLVING KEY PROBLEMS
description: IF you are likely to lose keys, if you fumble in the dark to open the door and if storing keys can be a problem, some new products will come to your aid.

title: FAILED BANK'S AUDITOR DEFENDS DATA
description: An official of the auditing firm that gave the United American Bank of Knoxville, Tenn., a clean bill of health barely a month before it failed said today that his auditors had no way of knowing the bank was shifting some bad loans to other banks controlled by the Butcher family.

title: Topics; Revealing Truth; On the Barbie Trail
description: By initially refusing to investigate the Klaus Barbie case, Attorney General William French Smith was unimaginative but not entirely unreasonable. History and national honor demanded a study of charges that American intelligence agents used and sheltered this notorious German war criminal after World War II.

title: Braniff Gloomy As Talks Fail
description: Without a ''miracle,'' Braniff International will never fly again now that attempts at a joint venture with Pacific Southwest Airlines have fallen through, Braniff's chairman says.

title: SOVIET MARSHAL WARNS U.S. ON ITS MISSILES
description: Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, chief of the Soviet General Staff, suggested today that if the American medium-range missiles planned for deployment in Europe were used against the Soviet Union, the Russians would retaliate directly against the United States. For the most part, the marshal, in a rare interview with a Western correspondent, struck a moderate posture, in particular by modifying his previous position and saying that once nuclear war began it could not be limited and controlled. He said: ''The idea of nuclear war has never been tested. But by logic, to keep such a war limited will not be possible.''

title: Custer Acquisition
description: The Custer Resources Corporation, a Denver concern, said it had agreed in principle to acquire CNR Resources, the United States subsidiary of Canadian Natural Resources Ltd., for about $105 million. The sale includes about 110,000 net acres of leases in 16 states and more than 450 wells, most of them in Texas, it said.

title: AMERICAN SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Concerns Sue U.S.  Over Nuclear Unit
description: The companies that own the Barnwell, S.C., nuclear fuel reprocessing plant, which was built in the 1970's and was never licensed to operate, filed a lawsuit in Washington yesterday seeking $500 million in damages from the Federal Government.

title: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
ASSOCIATED RISES 24.3%
description: Four of the country's leading retail chains yesterday reported earnings gains for the fourth fiscal quarter ended Jan. 29. Federated Department Stores had a 9.7 percent rise; the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, 24.3 percent; the F.W. Woolworth Company, 72.4 percent, and May Department Stores, 16.6 percent.

title: CENTRAL AMERICA'S REAL PERIL
description: The threat to democracy in Central America is neither Communism nor poverty. Today, as in the past, the danger is militarism.

title: 15 States Paced Jobless Trend
description: Fifteen states, led by Michigan, Alabama, Ohio and Illinois, had unemployment rates averaging 10.5 percent or higher last year, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Drug Income Cited by U.S.
description: Foreign banks and American banks abroad are receiving billions of dollars in deposits from drug deals, the Commissioner of the United States Customs Service said today.

title: PRIME MINISTER OF IRELAND ASSAILS ANY WHO MARCH TO SUPPORT I.R.A.
description: Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald said today that Americans who plan to march Thursday in New York's St. Patrick's Day Parade behind an Irish Republican Army supporter as grand marshal have been misled about the true nature of the paramilitary group.

title: Carter Visits Syria
description: Former President Jimmy Carter arrived here from Saudia Arabia today and was expected to meet with President Hafez al-Assad.

title: INDIANS PRESS TRUDEAU ON RIGHTS UNDER NEW CHARTER
description: Canada's Indians and Eskimos have been trying for two days to tell Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau that God gave them the land that became Canada, and that it will always remain theirs. Mr. Trudeau was not entirely convinced.

title: Frances M. Schmidt, 70, Dies; Ex-Columbia University Aide
description: Frances M. Schmidt, retired director of development and alumni affairs at the Columbia University School of Social Work, died of congestive heart failure Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Kean Is Touring Israel for 9 Days
description: Governor Kean left the State House today for a nine-day tour of Israel, which will include a Holocaust memorial service in Jerusalem and a possible meeting with Prime Minister Menachem Begin.

title: CANADIAN MANOIR INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After special gains of $188,150 for the latest yr and $121,480 for the 1981 yr

title: MAYOR BYRNE SETS WRITR-IN CAMPAIGN FOR CHICAGO VOTE
description: Mayor Jane M. Byrne announced today that she would become a write-in candidate in the April 12 mayoral election. The Mayor's announcement threw the city's once all-powerful Democratic Party into disarray. And it drew immediate criticism from other local and national Democratic leaders who are supporting Representative Harold Washington's effort to become the city's first black mayor. Mr. Washington defeated Mrs. Bryne and Richard M. Daley, the Cook County State's Attorney, in the Democratic primary last month.

title: SMOOT-HAWLEY LIVES
description: Free trade is economic motherhood. Protectionism is economic evil incarnate. The Smoot-Hawley tariff brought on the Great Depression. Never should government interfere in the efficiency of international competition.

title: SPEX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CITY U. REPORTS 10% RISE IN FRESHMAN APPLICANTS
description: Freshman applications to the City University of New York are up 10.2 percent over last year, the largest such increase since the university imposed tuition in 1976.

title: STAGE: 'TOP GIRLS' GETS A NEW AMERICAN CAST
description: THE new American cast in Caryl Churchill's ''Top Girls'' at the Public's Newman Theater has a tough act to follow. Their predecessors were the team of seven English actresses who originated this difficult, provocative comedy at London's Royal Court Theater last year and performed it for several months at home before traveling to New York for a limited engagement. Perhaps inevitably, the new cast as yet lacks the splendid ensemble spirit of its predecessor. What we get instead is a collection of highly variable individual performances, over a range that runs from the inspired to the competent to the wrongheaded.

title: Technology; The Flexibility Of Digital TV
description: DIGITAL electronics, which has been responsible for the wonders of computers, might soon be used in television sets as well, providing receivers with many new features: Viewers could watch several channels at once or freeze a particular picture frame and zoom in for close-ups. The sets could also provide crisper pictures and eliminate ghosts, the double images that plague reception, particularly in large cities.

description: B-Includes a tax credit of $716,000...C-Net loss after a provision of $1,543,000 for loss on discontinued operations

title: Article 038867 -- No Title
description: With Tuesday night's preliminary round out of the way and the field down to 48 teams, the 45th and richest National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship gets under way in earnest Thursday night. Eight of the 16 first-round games will be played then at four sites, and the remaining eight will be Friday night.

title: COOKE: THE QUIET LEADER OF NEW YORK'S CATHOLICS
description: Only hours after he became Archbishop of New York in 1968, Terence Cardinal Cooke was attending a church reception in his honor when news came that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. had been slain. The tragedy in Memphis thus became the focus of his first day as the leader of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

title: NEGOTIATIONS STALLED IN 2 RAIL WALKOUTS FOR REST OF THE WEEK
description: Negotiations in the 16-day strike against N.J. Transit's nine railroad lines broke off yesterday in Newark because of a deadlock on economic issues.

title: NEW BOOK GUIDE NOVICE AND EXPERT
description: FEW gardeners have time to study all of the gardening books that are published. But that's hardly a reason to stop stocking bookshelves with reference volumes that can provide inspiration or help when needed.

title: The Mature Sly Williams
description: A t this time last year, the Knicks were a disaster. So was Sly Williams, who was about to be suspended and fined for the third time for inexcused absences, whose National Basketball Association career appeared to be in jeopardy. But now the Knicks are a team again, and Sly Williams has a career again. The two are as intertwined as the white cords that swish when he scores.

title: A PLAN TO GET FAILING PUPILS INTO HIGH SCHOOL CALLED BADLY DESIGNED
description: A new program in New York City for promoting failing students to high school was criticized yesterday as being poorly planned and likely to hurt the very students it is intended to help.

title: EX-E.P.A. OFFICIAL TELLS OF 'PRO AND CON' LIST
description: Louis J. Cordia, an Environmental Protection Agency official who was asked to resign Tuesday, said today that he had prepared lists with ''pro and con assessments'' of hundreds of agency officials and prospective officials in 1981 for the Reagan Administration.

title: 2 BOMBS FOUND HIDDEN IN STORES IN NORTH JERSEY
description: Two powerful homemade bombs have been found hidden in stores in shopping malls along a two-mile stretch of Route 46 in Passaic County since last week.

title: D'Arcy-MacManus
description: Chet Lane, who worked for Alvin Hampel, the chairman of D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/New York, at both Benton & Bowles and earlier at Young & Rubicam, has joined him again as executive vice president/ creative director, a new position.

title: RAYROCK RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After special gains of $188,129 for the latest yr and $450,289 for the earlier yr

title: Infidelity and Rage
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Well, I imagined my husband in the arms of another woman and my heart didn't ''go belly up like a dead fish'' (Hers, Feb. 24). My dispassion may astonish Barbara Ascher as much as her accepting the naturalness of violent sexual rage astonished me.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION:
description: Barbara Ascher's column on infidelity accepts violence as a result of disappointment in a love relationship, or at least finds it understandable. Has she asked who suffers from such violence? More often than not it is women. In the interest of love does she really condone behavior that has been a major contributor to the suppression of women? JOHN R. CLARK Chestnut Hill, Mass.

description: Q. I have an old bathtub with some stains. I don't want to reenamel it, but I have heard that stains can be removed with muriatic acid solution. Do you recommend this?

title: NEW 2-YEAR NOTES YIELD 9.66%
description: The Treasury auctioned $7.75 billion of 9 5/8 percent two-year notes yesterday at an average price of 99.938, to yield 9.66 percent. At the previous monthly sale of two-year notes, on Feb. 16, the average yield was 9.71 percent.

title: Fleet Cabdrivers Authorize a Strike
description: Fleet taxi drivers voted yesterday to authorize a strike, according to Benjamin Goldberg, president of Local 3036 of the Taxi Drivers Union.

U.S. Routs Japan
description: Bill Gilligan scored five goals as the United States ice hockey team routed the Japanese national team today, 12-3, for its second victory in a four-nation series.

title: 3 Killed in Philadelphia Fire
description: Three people, including two children, were killed and six people were injured early today in a house fire in North Philadelphia, the authorities said.

title: U.S. Bars Inquiry On Rosenbloom
description: The United States Justice Department will not pursue an investigation into the drowning of Carroll Rosenbloom, a county official said today.

title: Credit Protest In Argentina
description: The vice president of Argentina's central bank, Alberto Ayerza, has resigned to protest the subsidized credits that will be introduced as part of a new Government economic package, central bank sources said today.

Chaminade Wins N.A.I.A. Opener
description: The most memorable event in Chaminade's basketball history occurred when it upset Virginia, 77-72, earlier this season.

title: Perkins Asserts Himself
description: Ray Perkins sees himself as a more down-to-earth football coach than his venerated predecessor at Alabama, the late Paul (Bear) Bryant. That became apparent this week when the tower that Bryant had used to oversee practice sessions was removed, causing a minor traffic jam and some consternation in Tuscaloosa.

title: BY SALLY BEDELL
description: A fictional film about nuclear terrorism scheduled to be shown on NBC next Sunday night has raised a protest from Reuven Frank, the president of NBC News, prompting the network to insert an unusual number of disclaimers to prevent viewers from being alarmed.

title: Davis Savors a Short Season
description: By the time Mike Davis received his degree from the University of Maryland, his basketball career had already taken him from his hometown of Jacksonville, Fla., to Shaw College in Detroit, to Mercer County Junior College in New Jersey, to College Park, Md. Then, in 1978, there was an offer to go to Italy for a tryout with a professional team. ''I went just for the chance to be in Rome for 10 days,'' Davis said. ''I wound up there for four years.''

title: SENATE STARTS DEBATE ON RESCUE PROPOSAL FOR SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The Senate, putting aside the job bill that has paralyzed it for five days, began consideration today of a plan to assure the financial solvency of Social Security.

title: FILM ANIMATION SERIES SET
description: The Astoria Picture and Television Foundation will present a series on the early years of film animation on March 25 and 26. The series has been organized by Donald Crafton, associate professor of art history at Yale University and curator of the Yale Film Collection.

title: Warning Drafted To Bobby Knight
description: Bobby Knight's status as coach of the 1984 United States Olympic basketball team continues to unsettle some members of the United States Olympic Committee.

title: A Parade for Pipes, Not Drums
description: It's hard this year to hail the parade for St. Patrick as a sign of spring and to join with the Irish in their time-honored celebration. The choice of Michael Flannery, an active supporter of the brutal Irish Republican Army Provisionals, to serve as Grand Marshal symbolizes the view of the parade sponsors that there's nothing smiling or gentle in their thoughts of home.

title: Smith Ends Streak
description: It was a tough decision, but Randy Smith of the San Diego Clippers voluntarily ended his National Basketball Association record streak of consecutive games because he wanted to extend his career.

title: JOSEP L. SERT, 80, ARCHITECT, WAS HARVARD DEAN OF DESIGN
description: Josep Lluis Sert, the Spanish-born architect who served for 16 years as the dean of the Graduate School of Design at Harvard University and became one of America's most influential architects, died Tuesday of cancer in Barcelona, Spain. He was 80 years old.

title: CITY DEFERS CUT OF 4 FIRE UNITS A SECOND TIME
description: The Koch administration has deferred again for at least a month its plan to cut four firefighting command units on April 1, Deputy Mayor Nathan Leventhal said yesterday.

title: Chicago Board To Trade Oil
description: The Chicago Board of Trade will begin trading crude oil futures on March 30, after the expected approval by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission on March 29, an exchange spokesman said today.

title: Gallup Poll Finds Rise In Approval of Reagan
description: Public approval of President Reagan's handling of his job increased significantly last month for the first time in more than a year, according to the Gallup Poll. Key factors in the rise were enhanced support of Mr. Reagan from Republicans and independents.

title: IONA ADVANCES IN N.I.T. 90-76
description: Madison Square Garden is 18 miles from Iona College, but it became one step closer tonight after the Gaels won their first-round game of the National Invitation Tournament by beating St. Bonaventure, 90-76.

title: New Dean Is Selected At Wharton
description: At 48, Russell E. Palmer maintains that he is looking for ''something very challenging and something very different.'' Thus, Mr. Palmer, chief executive of the Touche Ross International unit of the worldwide accounting firm, has accepted a seven-year appointment as dean of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation said it had ordered 60 diesel locomotives from the General Electric Company for $66 million. Conrail said the 3,700-horsepower engines will be produced at General Electric's Erie, Pa., plant.

description: Luciano Pavarotti, making his first appearance at La Scala in three years, was booed and whistled at by some fans in the last act of Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' Tuesday night.

title: Oil Issues Lead Market Lower, With Dow Off 8.52
description: Prices on the New York Stock Exchange ended slightly lower yesterday, with the oil service and energy stocks posting the biggest losses. Turnover climbed to 83.6 million shares from 62.4 million on Tuesday as institutional interest expanded.

title: Lakers 104, Suns 95
description: Los Angeles, led by Earvin (Magic) Johnson's 25 points, won its fifth straight. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who had only 7 points with 3:45 left, scored 5 more before the finish, extending his streak in which he has scored in double figures to 437 regular-season games.

LePatner, a lawyer and professional affiliate of the New York City Chapter of the American Institute of Architects, the client has paid only ''for the right to build from those plans on one occasion.''

title: SALVADOR JUDGE DELAYS TRIAL OF 5 IN NUNS' SLAYING
description: A Salvadoran judge has ruled that the trial of five former National Guard members accused of the murders of four churchwomen from the United States cannot proceed until a lower court provides more evidence in the case.

Kodak paid a wage dividend of about $246.4 million last year to about 92,600 employees.

''What am I doing here?'' asked Pauline Trigere, the fashion designer, above center.

description: For three years, the St. Mary Magdalen Church here was slowly going broke, and the pastor, the Rev. Ralph Colicchio, could not understand why.

title: SPONSORS EXPECT MANY MARCHERS AT IRISH PARADE
description: Despite defections after the choice of a supporter of the Irish Republican Army as grand marshal, the sponsors of today's St. Patrick's Day Parade predicted that the event would be the largest and least rowdy in years.

title: Soviet-Chinese Talks
description: Deputy Foreign Minister Qian Qichen, the head of a Chinese delegation that has been holding talks on improving relations with the Soviet Union, has left Moscow for a four-day trip to Soviet Uzbekistan, the official press agency Tass reported. His Soviet counterpart, Deputy Foreign Minister Leonid F. Ilyichev, made a similar trip outside Peking during the first round of talks last October in China.

title: Fastball Is Gone, but Fidrych Sees Hope
description: He still circled the mound twice after a bad pitch, talking to himself and squeezing the baseball hard. But Mark Fidrych, once the most-heralded rookie in baseball, knows there are some things, such as a lost fastball, that cannot be retrieved.

title: The Economy
description: Housing starts rose by a sharp 2.9 percent in February to an annual rate of 1.76 million units, the highest level since 1979, the Commerce Department reported. The size of the increase surprised even the builders' trade association. The figure is the latest indication of the growing strength in the housing sector, which is providing much of the impetus for the economic recovery, analysts said. They attributed the increase to lower mortgage interest rates and pent-up housing demand. (Page D1.)

title: Films of the Hubleys
description: ''Hubley Animation,'' part two of a three-part retrospective on the animated films of John and Faith Hubley, will be shown from 6 to 8 P.M. in Room 404 at the New School, 66 West 12th Street.

title: Economic Scene; What to Do About Oil Now
description: NOW that oil prices are coming down and the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is struggling for its existence, what should be the policy of the United States and other Western countries: Do everything possible to break OPEC and drive oil prices down further, or work for improved cooperation between oil-exporting and oil-importing countries in the interest of greater stability of prices and energy supplies?

title: ILLINOIS ST. LOSES, 51-49
description: Robert Tatum, a freshman, made a 15-foot shot at the buzzer tonight to give Ohio University a 51-49 upset victory over Illinois State in an opening-round game of the Mideast Regional. In the second round Saturday, Ohio (23-8) will play the regional No.3 seed, Kentucky (21-7).

title: Stearns May Be Out Until Middle of May
description: John Stearns today finally accepted the prognosis that he will not start the regular season as the Mets' catcher and will miss the first month of action. He is unlikely to play until mid-May.

description: Amtrak began efforts today to stop honoring the tickets of strikebound New Jersey rail commuters riding its trains because of union threats to picket Amtrak facilities in New York, New Jersey and Philadelphia.

title: WORDS
description: IT did not take quite so long to assemble ''The Great East River Bridge'' exhibition that opens tomorrow at the Brooklyn Museum as it did to build the bridge that is its subject, but the show is a singular accomplishment nonetheless. It is clearly the definitive event to mark the centennial of the Brooklyn Bridge - short of the celebrations that will occur on and around the bridge itself May 24, the anniversary of its opening.

title: Scandal Brings Resignation Of Turin's Communist Mayor
description: The Communist Mayor of this industrial city resigned today, taking moral responsibility for a bribery scandal that has cracked the party's reputation for honesty.

title: Ernie Royal, Trumpeter, 61; Played in Many Jazz Bands
description: Ernie Royal, a trumpet player who was featured in a number of major jazz bands and who also played in the pit bands for several Broadway musicals, died of cancer Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. Mr. Royal, who was 61 years old, lived in Teaneck, N.J.

title: Garden Sale Discussions May Resume
description: A spokesman for Gulf and Western Industries, Jerry Sherman, confirmed yesterday that the conglomerate had discussed the possible sale of Madison Square Garden and its professional hockey and basketball teams to George Steinbrenner. But a Wall Street source reported that the talks took place a year ago and, despite meetings since then, were unsuccessful.

title: Silver market facing a test.
description: SALES of silver next week and next month at three of New York's auction galleries are expected to show the health -or lack of it - of the market in period silver. The bulk of all three sales is of the sort of moderate-quality decorative silver that dropped in price or found no buyers at all after silver bullion, having soared from $6 an ounce in January 1979 to $50 an ounce in January 1980, plummeted to $10 an ounce two months later. The coming auctions will also offer silver from private collections, some of it with royal pedigree and not seen on the market for some time.

title: AIDING FRANC COSTS FRANCE $3 BILLION
description: France lost about $3 billion of foreign-exchange reserves in the week ended last Thursday as it struggled to support the declining franc and avert another devaluation, according to figures issued today by the nation's central bank. The loss is one of the largest ever experienced in a single week by the Bank of France.

description: Italian members of the multinational peacekeeping force exchanged fire with unidentified gunmen here today in four separate incidents, and one soldier was slightly wounded.

A Potlatch Closing
description: The Potlatch Corporation said it expected to close permanently its Potlatch, Idaho, sawmill on April 1 because of depressed economic conditions. The mill, which has been closed indefinitely since Aug. 14, 1981, had a rated annual capacity of 41 million board feet. ''Future uncertainties in the demand for wood products and in the availability of timber are major considerations in this decision,'' Potlatch said.

description: The Jazz Forum's World Bass Festival, featuring groups led by bassists, will present the Dr. Art Davis Quartet, with the violinist Billy Bang, tonight and Reggie Workman and Top Shelf tomorrow. The loft club is at 648 Broadway at Bleecker Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; admission for all three is $8.
