title: Udall to Address Parley On Environment of 80's
description: Representative Theodore Weiss, the Manhattan and Bronx Democrat, will sponsor a daylong community conference called ''Environmental Politics in the 1980's,'' beginning at 12:30 P.M. on Sunday at Ferris Booth Hall of Columbia University.

title: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for QTr to Feb 28
MORE IS NOT SAFER
description: Why does President Reagan link supporters of a nuclear freeze to ''those who would place the United States in a position of military and moral inferiority''? Why does he suggest that the freeze movement is bent on ''simple-minded appeasement or wishful thinking about our adversaries'' that will result in ''the betrayal of our past and the squandering of our freedom''?

title: PREMIER INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jean Miller Spadea Dies at 79; Fashion Illustrator in the City
description: Jean Miller Spadea, a fashion illustrator who was associated with Bonwit Teller and Saks Fifth Avenue in the 1930's and 40's and later had a syndicated news column, died of pneumonia Saturday at Venice (Fla.) Hospital. Mrs. Spadea was 79 years old and lived in Englewood, Fla.

title: ART: SAUL AND GROOMS, COMMENT FROM THE 60'S
description: PETER SAUL was born in California in 1934, Red Grooms in Tennessee three years later, and both got their start as visual comedians on the New York scene around 1960. This makes them proto-Pop artists, although neither pressed on to the secondary phase. Instead, they remained at the movement's rim, each developing his own idiosyncratic style.

title: Pentagon Arson Suspected
description: Two small fires broke out today at the Pentagon and Federal officials said they suspected arson. Roger Stewart, a spokesman for the General Services Administration, which oversees the building, said there were no injuries and damage was minimal.

title: Car Demand in Japan
description: Domestic demand for cars in Japan is expected to rise 1.9 percent, to 5.4 million units, in the fiscal year beginning April 1, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

title: Fred Rose, a Canadian Jailed As Soviet Spy, Dies in Poland
description: Fred Rose, a Communist member of the Canadian Parliament who was convicted of spying for Moscow, has died in a Warsaw hospital, his wife said today. He was 76 years old.

title: Chase Bank Promotes 11 of Its Top Executives
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday promoted three senior vice presidents to executive vice president and eight vice presidents to senior vice president.

title: RIGHTS GROUP HEAD SLAIN IN EL SALVADOR
description: The president of the Human Rights Commission of El Salvador was killed last Sunday while investigating reports that the army was using chemicals against civilians, the organization said today.

title: PHIL SELLERS REMEMBERS A BETTER TIME
description: Phil Sellers, now a basketball player only on Sunday mornings, stretches out on a couch in the housing project apartment in which he grew up and where he has returned to live for a while. He has just come in from work.

title: OSCAR BRAND FINDS PUBLIC IN MOOD FOR 40'S PROTEST
description: THE musical mood at the Cookery this month is a throwback to the days 40 years ago when Barney Josephson, who owns the restaurant at University Place and Eighth Street, opened Cafe Society on Sheridan Square as a cabaret mixing political satire and jazz. The three boogie-woogie pianists Albert Ammons, Meade Lux Lewis and Pete Johnson, would be rumbling on their keyboards while Big Joe Turner shouted the blues, and minutes later Josh White would pick his guitar as he accompanied himself on ''Free and Equal Blues'' or the union song ''Joe Hill,'' or Billie Holiday would sing the antilynching song she introduced there, ''Strange Fruit.''

title: CARTER SAYS SYRIA ISN'T PUPPET
description: Former President Jimmy Carter dismissed as ''ridiculous'' today the recent suggestions by senior Reagan Administration officials that Syria had become a puppet of the Soviet Union.

title: OFF IRAN, OIL WELLS BLOW OUT
description: Blown-out oil wells in the war zone between Iran and Iraq have spewed nearly 10 million gallons of oil into the Persian Gulf, threatening water supplies throughout the region, an oil pollution monitoring service says.

title: MILLER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes a net charge of $214,000 from writedown of assets from discontinued operations for the qr and 9 mos...C-Net income

title: TO SOUTHERN AFRICA'S AGONY, ADD TWO ARID YEARS
description: For the second successive year, drought has parched the lands of southern Africa, and it has imposed itself capriciously, sparing some and breaking others. It has coincided with other woes, too, that blur the shallow imprint of political independence in nations still reliant in others ways on distant and fickle forces in the industrialized world.

title: CARSON PIRIE SCOTT & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: B-Includes a gain of $6,066,000 from the sale of a shopping center investment

title: West Virginia Falls To James Madison
description: Seven free throws by Charles Fisher in the final 50 seconds helped James Madison upset West Virginia by 57-50 tonight in the opening round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association East Regional.

title: Player's Fate Undecided
description: E.J. Junior, the St. Louis Cardinals' linebacker who had been sentenced to two years in prison on a cocaine conviction, had that sentence softened yesterday by a circuit court judge in Tuscaloosa, Ala. The judge, Claude Harris, converted the sentence to three years' probation and ordered Junior to devote part of his time to working with youth groups such as the Boy Scouts.

title: ALL THAT GAS, AND NO MARKET
description: There is seldom anything poignant about an oilproducing facility. But the words scrawled on a giant ball valve at the central compressor plant situated above the vast Prudhoe Bay oilfield tell of a dream deferred: ''To future gas plant 1986-plus.''

title: U.S. ENVOY IN ISRAEL PRESENTS IDEAS ON SAFEGUARDING BORDER
description: The United States Ambassador to Israeli, Samuel Lewis, delivered detailed proposals to Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir today for safeguarding Israel's northern border once Israeli forces leave Lebanon, a senior Israeli official said.

title: LAMSON & SESSIONS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an unfavorable adjustment of $500,000 associated with a loss provision for discontinued operations and unfavorable adjustments of $2,304,000 relating to valuation reserves and other yr-end matters for the qr and a favorable adjustment of $774,000 for the yr from prior yrs' loss provision for discontinued operations...C-After a favorable adjustment of $1,148,000 associated with these matters mentioned above

title: Raise the Odds Against OPEC
description: ''I have a strong feeling that this will work out and that OPEC will be in the driver's seat.'' - Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani

title: Chautauqua Official Agrees to Join Cuomo
description: The Chautauqua County Executive, John Gerace, said today that he had accepted an offer to become State Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets. Mr. Gerace has been offered the job although no formal announcement has been made, the Governor's office said.

title: GURU OF BIG OREGON COMMUNE FACING DEPORTATION
description: When the Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh goes out for an afternoon drive in one of his shiny Rolls-Royces, his followers wonder how much time the Indian guru has left here to tool around these scrubby desert hills.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Time's Running Out

title: 'WILD STYLE,' RAPPING AND PAINTING GRAFFITI
description: THE 1983 ''New Directors/New Films'' series, sponsored by the Film Society of by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the department of film of the Museum of Modern Art, begins modestly and in good faith tonight with the showing of Charlie Ahearn's ''Wild Style'' at the 57th Street Playhouse at 8:30.

title: AS SMITH GOES...?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW CLAIMS BY JOBLESS WIPE OUT EARLIER DROP
description: New claims for unemployment benefits rose to 501,000 in the first week in March, erasing an apparent healthy economic sign form the week before, the Labor Department reported today.

title: OLD AND NEW ON THE CITY'S ORIGINAL WATERFRONT
description: THE party broke up about 200 years ago, but on Sunday you can catch its tail end: piles of dirty napkins, crumbs on the floor, half-finished glasses of wine, a broken clay pipe and - thoughtlessly left behind - a tricorn on the wall. This is how the Long Room at Fraunces Tavern Museum looks today. The recreated chamber, where Washington said farewell to his officers, has been furnished to resemble a tavern moments after the departure of a drinking party, with all the attendant jumble.

title: TV SHOW SYNDICATION: NETWORKS WANT THEIR MONOPOLY BACK
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: First Case

title: DRUG SUSPECT CHOKES TO DEATH ON PACKETS
description: A suspected drug dealer choked to death last night at a Queens police station when a plastic bag with with 12 small packets of white powder became lodged in his throat, the police said.

title: Alexander Bloch Dead at 101; A Composer and Conductor
description: Alexander Bloch, violinist, composer, teacher and a conductor of orchestras in New York, Washington and Florida, died in Manhattan on Wednesday. He was 101 years old.

title: Marquesa, 'First True Love' Of Edward VIII, Is Dead at 88
description: The Marquesa de Casa Maury, described as the ''first true love'' of King Edward VIII before he gave up his throne for Wallis Simpson, died Wednesday at her home in Chelsea, London, The Times of London reported today. She was 88 years old.

title: No Headline
description: Capitals Beat Bruins, 2-1

title: WHERE TO EAT EFTER THE TOUR
description: Anyone seeking daytime nourishment after touring Lower Manhattan has a limited choice. Most restaurants in the area are closed weekends, or open only for dinner. Fortunately, there are a few exceptions, ranging from excellent to fair, in casual or formal settings and at a wide range of prices. The choice is greater on Saturday than on Sunday, when corner hot-dog stands and the restaurants of nearby Chinatown should be considered. There are no dress requirements, and no reservations or credit cards are accepted unless otherwise noted.

title: Oil Trucks Explode In Fire in Bronx
description: A three-alarm fire swept through a Bronx oil company garage housing fuel trucks early yesterday, causing the trucks to explode and sending the roof of the structure crashing down on the vehicles, authorities said.

title: MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
MOTIVE NOT GIVEN IN WARNING CALL
description: A pipe bomb was removed from a hardware and appliance store here today, the third explosive device found in a store in Passaic County in 10 days, the authorities said.

title: TWO-WAY MESSAGES
description: The voters of France and West Germany have delivered their message: a stern warning to President Francois Mitterrand from the French, and carefully balanced support for Chancellor Helmut Kohl from the Germans.

title: ARTRA GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,896,000 for the qr and $649,000 for the yr...C-After income of $236,000 from discontinued operations...D-Net income includes income of $1,153,000 from discontinued operations; the yr-ago results have been restated to reflect operations discontinued in 1982

title: Semiconductor Deficit
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that it lost $18.5 million in its third quarter, ended March 6.

title: Three Navy Jets Lost In Exercise at Sea
description: Three jet fighters were lost in two separate accidents early today in a Navy training exercise, a Navy spokesman said. One airman was killed and another was missing.

title: Time Has Come
description: Collegiate sports information directors have been known to resort to a variety of methods to publicize the feats of their athletes. One of the most popular is making up mock magazine covers of nationally known publications.

title: Accord ends ethics dispute.
description: A CIVIL damage suit filed five years ago by the New York State Attorney General against Michael Kan, former assistant director of the Brooklyn Museum and now deputy director of the Detroit Institute of Art, has been settled out of court. The case has been hailed by the Attorney General's office as a breakthough in establishing standards of behavior for museum officials.

title: SILENCE OF KILLERS
description: THE feminist cause will not be well served by ''A Question of Silence,'' a Dutch film that tells of three women who stomp, kick and pummel to death a male shopkeeper. The incident is triggered when one of the women tries furtively to steal some merchandise. The manager sees her and is all set to chastise her, when two other female patrons, who don't know the first woman and don't know the manager either, defiantly pocket some merchandise to show their solidarity. At this, the manager breaks into a cold sweat, and no wonder. Moments afterward, he is beaten to a pulp.

title: White House Adding
description: Gun-Check Building

title: GROUP PLANNING A NEW BUILDING AT WEST 76th ST.
description: The New-York Historical Society wants to construct an apartment building behind and, perhaps, partly above its museum and library on Central Park West.

title: AMERICAN IN SWITZERLAND IS ACCUSED OF SPYING
description: An American who worked as a cocktail waitress at a hotel here has been ordered to stand trial on charges of spying for Libya, the authorities said todya.

title: BRIEFING
description: Public Broadcasting Woes

title: Union Offer Of Pay Cut For Kaiser; Acquisition Talks Advance
description: A union official at the Kaiser Steel Corporation said last night that under certain conditions, workers at the company's Fontana, Calif., steel plant might be willing to take pay cuts of about onethird to keep the plant open. Kaiser announced on March 4 that it would close the plant if it could not find a buyer or a partner for the plant.

title: 2 CALIFORNIA THRIFT UNITS TO MERGE
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation, parent company of the nation's second-largest savings association, is to acquire Financial Federation Inc., owner of another large thrift unit, for $184.8 million in stock, the two companies announced late today.

title: Cisco, Tex., Aide Held In Murder of Wife
description: The Mayor pro-tem of Cisco, wanted in the shooting death of his 27-year-old wife, was arrested Wednesday at the Dallas-Fort Worth Regional Airport, the authorities said.

title: ARMS MEMO: TWO DEMOCRATS BARRED?
description: Senate sources disclosed today that an internal arms agency memorandum recommended that two members of Congress be kept away from arms talks in Geneva. Senator Paul E. Tsongas, a Massachusetts Democrat, said the growing controversy over the document had prompted the majority of the Senate Foreign Relations committee to move for its public disclosure.

title: SCHOOLS TRY FOR 2 STATE TITLES
description: Since its formation in 1976, the New York State Federation of Secondary School Athletic Associations has tried to agree, with mixed results, on how to sponsor a statewide basketball tournament that would determine a single state champion.

title: LA. TECH ROMPS
description: Janice Lawrence scored 22 points tonight to help to-ranked Louisiana Tech, seeking its third straight national collegiate women's basketball championship, rout Middle Tennessee, 91-59. The victory, in the first round of the Midwest Regional, improved Tech's mark to 28-1.

title: CARROLL PURSUES AN ELUSIVE GOAL
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. W hen it happens, Billy Carroll keeps telling himself, he will not make a fool of himself. He will not fall to his knees, he will not spike the puck, he will not throw kisses to the crowd. He will treat it as just another goal.

title: HEALTH EXPERT FINDS HAZARD OF RADIATION WORSE THAN FEARED
description: Dr. Edward Radford, an epidemiologist at the University of Pittsburgh School of Public Health, said at a news conference yesterday that new evidence suggested the risk of cancer from exposure to low-level radiation was 10 times worse than generally accepted by the nuclear power industry.

title: Hyman Fine, a Musician, 89; Conducted Several Orchestra
description: Hyman Fine, who conducted orchestras for stage shows and silent movies and pioneered on radio, is dead at the age of 89.

title: Interest Rates Rise Slightly; One-Year Bill Yields 8.427%
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday for Treasury bills and other issues due in less than 10 years. Securities dealers said that modest to light investor demand encouraged them to reduce prices at a time when the supply of new Treasury issues is heavy.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Argentines Say They Sent Letter Bombs

title: Three Share Lead By a Shot at 68
description: Amid blustery winds, Jay Haas, Mark Hayes and Curt Byrum shot 68's today and shared the first-round lead in the $400,000 New Orleans Open golf tournament.

title: Contempt, and Confusion, of Congress
description: If President Reagan gave executive privilege a bad name by invoking it in the battle over Environmental Protection Agency documents, how well has the House of Representatives handled its countervailing power to punish uncooperative officials for contempt of Congress?

title: REAGAN IS REPORTED TO CONSIDER MAKING A NEW PROPOSAL ON MISSILES
description: President Reagan has scheduled a meeting Friday with members of the National Security Council to consider three options for a new American negotiating proposal in the mediumrange missile talks in Geneva, senior Administration officials disclosed today.

title: No Headline
description: C. Yates McDaniel, 76, Dies; Reporter in U.S. and Abroad

title: Soviet Economist Held In Asylum, Father Says
description: The father of a Soviet economist said today that his 36-year-old son has been held in a psychiatric hospital for two years for writing a tract criticizing the way the economy is run.

description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock exchange

title: & FAMILIES OF CAMBODIAN REFUGEES FLEE BROOKLYN IN SEARCH OF SAFETY
description: Seven Cambodian families who fled war and starvation in their homeland and crowded refugee camps in Thailand to take up new lives in New York have fled again, this time from robbers, muggers and young toughs on the streets of Brooklyn.

description: Council for Namibia - 10:30 A.M.

title: FROM LONDON, A KOOK FIT FOR A PRINCESS
description: This is a center where fashion still retains its personal touch. It is not presented in tents or high-tech halls by platoons of immaculately groomed models. It doesn't make major statements, and it doesn't try to revolutionize the world.

title: BALANCE COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for QTr to Jan 31
Boeing Gets Order
description: Japan Air Lines said it had ordered two 747-300's with stretched upper decks from the Boeing Company for $199 million. The aircraft, each powered by four Pratt & Whitney engines, are scheduled for delivery in November and will bring to 48 the total number of 747's that J.A.L. has purchased. The carrier said it would use the planes for its routes between Tokyo and San Francisco and Los Angeles.

title: Atari Plans Entry In Communications
description: Atari Inc., the leading maker of video games, said yesterday that it was preparing to enter the home telecommunications market through a newly formed division called Ataritel.

title: Aston-Magna to Play
description: Music by Bach, Biber, Buxtehude and Mozart will be included tonight at 8 in the second program this season by the Aston Magna early-music group at Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street (362-8719). On the program are Bach's Concerto in D minor for two violins, with Jaap Schroder and Stanley Ritchie as soloists. Tickets, $10, available at the Merkin Hall box office.

title: Danish Jobless Rate Up
description: Denmark's unemployment in January increased to 319,300 people, or 12.2 percent of the labor force, the Government reported today. It was the highest since World War II.

title: TRAFALGAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $19,000 for the qr and $74,000 for the 9 mos...C-After income from discontinued operations of $100,000

title: Bethlehem Rejects Lackawanna Plan
description: Walter F. Williams, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said the company could not accept a cost-cutting proposal offered by the unions for the Lackawanna plant and would carry out its plan to end basic steelmaking at the plant this year.

title: Waterfield Hospitalized
description: Bob Waterfield, who starred as a quarterback, defensive back and kicker in the National Football League, was listed in guarded condition in the intensive care unit of St. Joseph's Hospital yesterday with an undisclosed ailment. Waterfield, 62 and a member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame, was admitted to the hospital March 11, according to a hospital spokesman, Rhoda Weiss. She said Waterfield's family had requested that no further information be released, including the reason for his hospitalization.

title: Swissair's Net Falls 29%
description: Swissair said today that earnings fell 29 percent last year, to $18.79 million, from 1981's $26.51 million.

title: EUROPEANS ALSO QUEST FOR SOLVENT SOCIAL SECURITY
description: As the United States Congress moves to shore up the American Social Security system, West European governments and politicians are still debating ways of bringing solvency to their more expensive and, in some cases, more generous systems at a time of economic stagnation.

CUTS WEIGHED IN SALVADOR AID REQUEST
description: The Reagan Administration, faced with Congressional resistance to the proposed increase in military aid to El Salvador, is considering a reduction in the $110 million package, according to Government officials.

3 BY BOSSY
description: After going scoreless for more than 150 minutes over three games at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the Devils scored five goals in a span of 26 minutes tonight against the Islanders. But the Islanders still won, 9-5, before a crowd of 13,594.

title: ST. KITTS INDEPENDENCE SET
description: The Caribbean territory of St. Kitts-Nevis will gian independence form Britain on Sept. 19, Prime Minister Kennedy Simmonds told the House of Assembly on Wednesday. This will end 16 years of associated statehood with Britain for this twinisland nation.

title: STAGE: 'RAMON IGLESIA' IMMIGRANTS ADJUSTING
description: ''THE HOUSE OF RAMON IGLESIA,'' at the Ensemble Studio Theater, is a play that many young writers have to get out of their system but that few deliver as gracefully as Jose Rivera does here. It's the play about a bright, Americanized son's tortured efforts to break away from his tradition-bound parents - a break that can't be made until the assimilated hero learns to accept the ethnic heritage that he has spent his life trying to suppress. Though Mr. Rivera's recounting of this conventional, perhaps autobiographical story contains no dramatic surprises, his writing is vigorous and honest.

title: Bethlehem Rejects Plan to Save Jobs
description: Bethlehem Steel today rejected a union proposal to cut labor costs and save 7,300 jobs at its plant here and said it would stop basic steel-making here this year.

title: SENATE PASSES JOBS DELAYING WITHHOLDING ISSUE
description: The Senate broke a weeklong stalemate today and approved a recession relief bill containing $5.2 billion to provide jobs and humanitarian aid for the unemployed.

title: Dream in the Making
description: Stanley Floyd, the championship sprinter, reportedly wants to forsake a chance to make the United States Olympic team and try out for a pro football team, according to his agent, Steve Olschwanger.

title: THREE WAYS TO LESSEN THE FAIRNESS OF TRIALS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Wearing and Eating Of the Green H& H Bagels distributed a thousand dozen green bagels from its two M anhattan bakeries. Nina Elfman's fingers turned green selling c arnations at the corner of Vesey and Church Streets.

title: Standing in Line For Marathoners
description: Each year, thousands of runners are shut out of competing in the New York City Marathon either because they are not among the first 8,000 who have entered the race or are not drawn in the lottery for the remaining spots.

title: DANCE: 3 SHARING A PROGRAM
description: ANNABELLE GAMSON, Phyllis Lamhut and Don Redlich have a number of things in common. The three, who shared a concert Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater, owe allegiance in varying measure to the style of Mary Wigman, the German Expressionist choreographer whose work is probably the least known in America of all the modern dance pioneers. Each is a dancer of compelling, seasoned maturity, whose choreography is always interesting and often provocative. And the three have assembled a group of dancers who are nearly as striking performers as they.

title: 'ROAD TO CHINA'
description: PROBABLY without intending to, the producers of ''High Road to China'' have made an action-adventure comedy in which everybody and everything -and thus the film itself - seem to have been spun off from other, better films, particularly Steven Spielberg's ''Raiders of the Lost Ark.''

title: ART: 'HABITATS,' A SHOW BY 21 AT THE CLOCKTOWER
description: ''THE region where a plant or animal normally grows or lives'' is the definition given by one respectable word source, the New World Dictionary of the American Language, for ''habitat,'' or, more tersely, ''the place where a person or thing is ordinarily found.'' A much looser interpretation is made by ''Habitats,'' the current show at the Clocktower, 108 Leonard Street (through April 9). Here the word has been stretched to fit the work of 21 artists and architects exploring ''the concepts of volume, enclosures, interiors and fantasy.''

title: SAN ANTONIO STEPS OUT OF TEXAS SHADOWS AND LEAPS FOR A HIGH-TECH FUTURE
description: After decades of sputtering starts, unrealized dreams and lying in the shadow of Dallas and Houston, San Antonio is marshaling itself toward becoming a high-tech boom town of the closing century.

title: Top Banks' Third World Loans Detailed
description: The nation's 10 largest banking companies had $43.7 billion at risk to financially troubled developing countries at the end of 1982, more than half again the value of their equity, according to figures contained in their recently released annual reports.

title: Commuters Stranded, in Washington
description: If New York's commuters and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority can't stand up to the rail conductors' union, why should the Feds play the heavy? With that federalist slogan, the White House has thus far rationalized its failure to intervene in the Metro-North commuter rail strike. It is not, however, a good enough answer for a situation the Federal Government helped to create.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review Wednesday of the Equity Library Theater's production of ''Where's Charley?'' incorrectly attributed the choreography of Charles Abbott's dancing. It was done by Dennis Grimaldi.

title: GENERAL TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-After loss from discontinued operations of $3,025,000 includes charge of $30,800,000 for plant closings and loss of $6,006,000 from the company's shr of Frontier Airlines losses

title: Norstar Purchase Of Bank Stake Set
description: Norstar Bancorp Inc., Albany, agreed to buy Bank of Commerce's publicly held capital stock - 32.4 percent of the total - at $34 a share, or a total of about $16.7 million, the companies said.

title: ASA LTD reports earnings for As of Feb 28
DANCE: 'QUARTET' FOR FIVE BY CUNNINGHAM TROUPE
description: IF anyone had said even last week that Merce Cunningham would choreograph one of the most emotionally stirring and scary works on the dance stage, he or she would have been drummed right out of the avant-garde international.

title: Board at Howard University Reinstates Newspaper Editor
description: The board that oversees Howard University's student newspaper has reinstated Janice McKnight as editor of The Hilltop, a university spokesman said.

title: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $62,513 for the qr and $244,000 for the 9 mos

title: BRAXTON-SPINKS A UNITY FIGHT
description: Dwight Braxton, who has been fighting all his life but boxing for less than five years, will meet Michael Spinks, who has had to battle his emotions lately, in a 15-round bout Friday night to reduce to one the number of world light-heavyweight champions.

title: FEDERAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BETTER OFF? U.S. DATA DON'T TELL
description: During the 1980 Presidential campaign, Americans were asked: ''Are you better off now than you were four years ago?'' Curiously, our national income accounting system does not permit a meaningful answer. That system must be changed if it is to track the true path of our economic well-being.

title: SOVIET REBUTS 'FOCUS OF EVIL' SPEECH
description: A leading Soviet expert said today that any American compromise proposal for deployment of a reduced number of United States medium-range missiles in Western Europe would be a ''propaganda trick'' and would be rejected.

title: Scaled-Down Braniff Plans
description: A scaled-down Braniff International Corporation will probably forgo airline operations to concentrate on real estate, contract maintenance services and pilot training, officials say.

title: Six Plead Not Guilty In Rape at Barroom
description: Four men charged in the gang rape of a woman in a bar and two others indicted as accessories pleaded not guilty today at their arraignment in New Bedford Superior Court.

title: U.S. Diplomat Leaves Soviet
description: The United States Embassy said today that Richard W. Osborne, a first secretary, had left the Soviet Union. Last week the Government newspaper Izvestia said he had been caught working with a device for the transmission of intelligence via a communications satellite.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Doing Good, Doing Well
description: If everything had gone normally, Ksenia Owsianyk's fall on Dec. 30 would by now have cost the taxpayers about $12,000. She would be housed, resentfully, in a nursing home. And Fredricka Williams might be on welfare. But everything did not go normally.

title: Mild Quake Hits in Montana
description: A mild earthquake shook a large section of western Montana early today but caused no damage or injuries. The earthquake was felt east of the divide in Great Falls, Helena and Butte, and west of the divide from Kalispell to Missoula.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Some few, but vocal, Americans believe the differences between Irishmen can only be solved by violence and intimidation.

title: Washington State Gains
description: Craig Ehlo scored 18 points, and a reserve, Aaron Haskins, had 13 as Washington State beat Weber State, 62-52, in a first-round game of the West Regional tonight.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MARCH 18, 1983
description: International An Israeli-American military dispute came to light in a letter made public by the Pentagon. In the letter, the commandant of the Marine Corps, Gen. Robert H. Barrow, complained to Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger that Israeli forces in Lebanon ''persist in creating serious incidents'' and have ''harrassed, endangered and degraded'' American marines and soldiers. (Page A1, Column 6.) Moscow issued a warning on missiles. The Communist Party newspaper Pravda said that any American compromise proposals for a reduction in the number of American missiles deployed in Europe would be rejected as ''propaganda.'' The article also cautioned that failure to ''make appreciable progress'' on weapons control this year would make a new round of the arms race unavoidable. (A12:3-5.)

title: Money Fund Assets Down
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds dropped $1.52 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to $185.8 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: DISCOVERING THE NEW FILM DIRECTORS
description: The people who run the ''New Directors/New Films'' festival compare it to a voyage of discovery - the feeling of seeing something before anybody else does that makes it your own forever.

title: Mattel Reports a Loss
description: Mattel Inc. said yesterday that it lost $20.2 million in its fourth quarter, ended Jan. 29, compared with a profit of $16.7 million in the period a year before. Sales fell 22 percent, to $242.1 million, from $310.6 million. Mattel had said in December that it expected a loss in the quarter because of the general retailing slump, expenses for new product introductions and stiff competition in the video game business, which entailed heavy promotional expenses.

title: Low Car Rates Investigated
description: Advertisements of unusually low auto interest rates - some saying there is no interest charge at all - are being investigated by the Federal Trade Commission to determine whether they are defective or violate Federal credit laws, the agency said today.

title: A Dream Comes True
description: ''It was always my dream,'' Billy Don Jackson was saying the other day, ''to run out on the field before thousands of people in a major league pro stadium, throw my hands into the air and say: 'I'm here. I made it.

title: Theft Conviction Upheld For Ex-Illinois U. Official
description: An Illinois appeals court today upheld the conviction of a former University of Illinois official who stole $600,000 and spent most of it on entertainment and women he met at a suburban Chicago nightclub.

title: Man Said to Lie in Donovan Case
description: A man from Binghamton, N.Y., has been charged with lying to Federal agents when he said that Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan had had business and social ties with organized-crime figures before taking office, Federal officials said last night.

title: Friday; KAFKA AT COOPER UNION
description: To celebrate Franz Kafka's 100th birthday, writers, composers, painters and others are gathering today and tomorrow at Cooper Union, Third Avenue and Seventh Street, and inviting everybody, free. They will perform or recite works by Kafka or inspired by him, or talk about him. Among the participants will be John Cage, Hortense Calisher, Theodore Solotaroff, Stanley Kunitz and Robert Motherwell. The event starts at 9 A.M. and ends tomorrow with an 8:15 P.M. session that will include Orson Welles's 1962 film of ''The Trial,'' starring Anthony Perkins. There's also a Kafka-inspired exhibition, with Carl-Fredrik Reutersward drawings to illustrate ''The Trial.'' Information: 254-6300. CARVING FROM CHINA ...

title: RUTGERS SET FOR REGIONALS
description: Tom Young was the coach of the Rutgers basketball team that won 31 consecutive games during the 1975-76 season.

title: Official Feud
description: The United States Olympic Committee and The Athletics Congress are feuding. This time, the dispute involves T.A.C. plans to use the University of California at Santa Barbara as a staging and training base for United States track and field athletes before next summer's Olympic Games in Los Angeles.

description: The Polish authorities said today that they had arrested the leaders of two days of ''illegal demonstrations'' in Gdansk at the beginning of this week.

FRIDAY, MARCH 18, 1983; Companies
description: Great Western Financial is to acquire Financial Federation for $184.4 million in stock, the two companies announced. The merged institution, with $15.8 billion in assets, would have California's largest network of savings and loan branch offices. (Page D1.)

title: 2 Frigates Collide in Atlantic
description: Two guided-missile frigates collided Tuesday in the Atlantic in a training exercise, but no injuries were reported, the Navy said. The U.S.S. Antrim and U.S.S. Flatley, both based in Mayport, received only superficial damage in the accident 160 miles north of Puerto Rico.

title: PENTAGON CLEARS OUTPUT OF BOMBERS
description: The Pentagon announced today that it had approved full-scale production of the light bomber version of the Navy's F-18 Hornet but deferred for at least a year a decision on how many planes to purchase.

title: U.S.-Angola Talks Are Ended in Paris
description: Negotiators from the United States and Angola have ended three days of talks on American recognition of the Marxist African country and a peaceful settlement of the conflict in South-West Africa, also called Namibia, diplomatic officials said today.

title: CABARET SINGER: RUPERT HOLMES
description: WITH their clever word play, urbane sensibility, and expert musical craft, Rupert Holmes's best songs connect Broadway and Tin Pan Alley with contemporary pop-rock in a way that suggests that these musical cultures are not mutually exclusive. At Dangerfield's, where he opened a two-week engagement on Monday, Mr. Holmes has mounted an engaging program of his lighter songs.

title: Jewish Settlers in West Bank Are Told Not to Shoot Arabs
description: The Israeli general in charge of the occupied West Bank urged Jewish settlers today to refrain from shooting Arab youths who threw stones at their vehicles, an army spokesman said.

CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Shr earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock splits in June 1982 and Dec 1982

title: Davis Aide Testifies
description: An executive of the Los Angeles Raiders testified today in the damages phase of the team's antitrust case against the National Football League that the Raiders lost millions of dollars in television and radio revenues during the time the team was prevented from moving from Oakland.

title: B. Mitchell Reed, 56; Disk Jockey 30 Years
description: B. Mitchell Reed, a disk jockey in Los Angeles and New York for three decades, died Wednesday of heart problems at his home in West Los Angeles. He was 56 years old.

title: A persuasive producer and his 'Success.'
description: WILLIAM RICHERT, whose ''Success'' opens today at the Lincoln Plaza, lived as a child in 30 cities. ''My father was totally in love with my mother, who was this Irish lady who thought he was boring,'' he says. ''So she'd pack the kids, leave town in the middle of the night, and he'd quit his job and follow us.''

title: Stocks Edge Down As Trading Slows; Dow Up 0.97, To 1,116.97
description: Stock prices dropped moderately yesterday as growing concern over the outlook for oil prices and profit taking weakened the list in slower trading.

U.N. Pressing Afghan Effort
description: Diego Cordovez, the United Nations mediator for Afghanistan, will resume his efforts April 11 to achieve a withdrawal of Soviet troops from that country, a spokesman for Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today. The meetings, to be held in Geneva, are expected to last until April 22.

title: 2 REPORTS FOUND BY WHITE HOUSE IN E.P.A. CLASH
description: The White House said tonight that two Environmental Protection Agency reports had just been found that discussed the Stringfellow toxic waste dump in California, the focus of charges of political interference by agency officials.

title: Economy Up 3% in Japan
description: Japan's economy, aided by strong consumer spending, grew by a better-than-expected 3 percent last year, the Government announced today.

title: AIRLINE CHIEF REBUFFED ON BID TO ADDRESS UNION
description: The president of Eastern Airlines, Frank Borman, asked permission to speak to members of the International Association of Machinists here before they vote on the carrier's contract offer, but the union turned him down.

title: A.T.& T. Service
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company began offering a high-speed digital transmission service intended primarily for highvolume business and government communications users. The service, High Capacity Terrestrial Digital Circuits, can transmit voice, data or facsimile and can also be used for video transmissions. It will move 1.5 million bits a second, the company said, meaning that a 76-page newspaper would take 10 seconds to transmit.

title: VIETNAM REPORTS PUZZLE AMERICANS
description: Two studies conducted abroad have reached conflicting conclusions on whether Agent Orange, the herbicide used in Vietnam, caused birth defects for children of non-Vietnamese troops who fought in Vietnam.

title: News Analysis
description: The decision by Mayor Jane M. Byrne to continue her re-election bid as a write-in candidate has thrust to the forefront of the mayoral campaign an issue that Representative Harold Washington, the

title: Maryland Winner On Last Shot, 52-51
description: Len Bias, a 6-foot-8-inch freshman, made a 15-foot left-handed jump shot with three seconds remaining tonight to give Maryland a 52-51 victory over Tennessee-Chattanooga in a Midwest Regional first-round game of the 45th National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: TRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
U.S. MARINES' CHIEF CRITICIZES ISRAELIS
description: The commandant of the Marine Corps has complained to the Secretary of Defense that Israeli forces in Lebanon have persistently ''harassed, endangered and degraded'' American marines and soldiers there.

title: Lionel Sells Stake
description: The Lionel Corporation, which is operating under protection of the Federal bankruptcy law, said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its holdings in Dale Electronics to the Acme-Cleveland Corporation for $43 million, subject to the approval of Acme's board, the Bankruptcy Court and the Federal Trade Commission. Dale, in which Lionel owns 2.95 million shares, or 82 percent of those outstanding, is not involved in Lionel's bankruptcy.

title: ROLE FOR NANCY REAGAN; TALE OF NUCLEAR THREAT
description: WE'VE recently had Speaker Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill Jr. of the House of Representatives sidling up to a bar in the situation comedy ''Cheers.'' Tomorrow night at 8 on Channel 4, we can watch Nancy Reagan show up on an episode of ''Diff'rent Strokes.'' The First Lady will be visiting pint-sized Arnold (Gary Coleman), who has written an explosive essay on drug use in his school. Drug abuse is one of Mrs. Reagan's widely publicized concerns, and she will be seen going with Arnold to the school for a candid talk with the students. The show was taped only last week and was not available for review. Story of Terrorism In the Atomic Age

title: New American and old Provence style.
description: CONSIDERING how difficult it is to create a handsome restaurant and then serve good and interesting food, it's a pity to see those goals achieved only to be destroyed by inept service. But that is the story at the two-month old Jack's, the second-floor restaurant in the new luxury hotel called 1022 Lexington Avenue.

title: The Actors Studio proves it practices what it preaches.
description: THE Actors Studio, where actors learn to live their roles, believes in polishing a work. In fact, it just withdrew one of its rare public performances, by one of its veterans, Estelle Parsons, on the eve of previews scheduled to start yesterday.

title: GAP IN TOTAL TRADE SETS A U.S. RECORD
description: The broadest measure of American foreign trade registered a $6.1 billion deficit in the fourth quarter, pushing the balance of payments on a current-account basis for all 1982 into deficit for the first time since 1979, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: AN UNUSUAL NUMBER OF HEADACHES
description: The image of Tara being threatened in ''Gone With the Wind'' faded from the television screen the other evening, yielding to a commercial in which a housewife mused about the national economy.

title: GOVERNOR AND ALBANY LEADERS NEARING PACT ON EDUCATION AID

title: Market Place; Discovery Fund Is Patient
description: MONEY managers often pick trendy, fast-moving stocks for their portfolios. But Patrick Kildoyle is fond of slumbering, out-of-favor issues.

title: Donovan Meets Chief Of Labor Federation
description: Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan and Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O, had lunch together today. It was their first meeting in more than two years.

I.B.M. Portable
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is planning to equip its service personnel with a small portable computer terminal that lets them report to big home-office computers by radio. The terminal is being developed for I.B.M. by Motorola Inc. I.B.M.'s plans were disclosed when the Federal Communications Commission granted it a special waiver of commission procedures. The F.T.C.'s order says the company is planning to build a special digital-radio network with transmitters in 250 cities in the continental United States, Alaska, Hawaii and Puerto Rico.

title: CHAD ASKS U.N. TO HELP REMOVE LIBYAN TROOPS FROM DESERT ZONE
description: Chad called on the Security Council today to help remove Libyan forces from the northwestern part of its territory. It also accused Libya of ''repeated acts of aggression.''

title: ART: THE SEA AND STARS AS SEEN BY VIJA CELMINS
description: TO portray the sea and the stars as they have not been portrayed before is an enormous ambition. To pick up stones in the New Mexico desert, have them cast in bronze and remake them in their own image is at the very least an unusual endeavor. In her new show at the David McKee Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, Vija Celmins does all these things with her habitual pertinacity - and with her habitual discretion, too. It would be possible to walk round this show and leave with no idea of what it is all about.

description: A landlord may not refuse a tenant permission to transfer a lease to someone else simply because the landlord has a waiting list of people he would rather rent to, an appellate court ruled yesterday.

description: Japan, concerned over the scheduled visit of an American aircraft carrier, reminded the Reagan Administration today that nuclear arms are prohibited on Japanese territory.

title: Developer Admits $2.5 Million Fraud
description: A Westchester County real-estate broker has pleaded guilty to swindling a Texas company of $2.5 million during the sale of a professional building in the town of Greenburgh in 1979. The defendant, Irving Feder, 62 years old, who owns the Vim Development Company in Bronxville, could be imprisoned for up to seven years when sentenced April 14.

description: AT the Abraham Goodman House Monday night, the violinist Charles Libove and the pianist Nina Lugovoy offered a substantial sampling of 20th-century Russian music, neatly punctuated by a Beethoven sonata.

title: White Farmer Reported Seized by Nkomo Men
description: Six gunmen said to be loyal to the self-exiled opposition leader Joshua Nkomo kidnapped an elderly white farmer, the Government said today. It added that the gunmen had left a ransom note saying two Americans and four other tourists abducted last summer were still alive.

title: S.M.U. Investigated
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association is investigating reports that two high school football stars spurned their firstchoice colleges and signed with Southern Methodist after an S.M.U. booster offered one a car and the other money. The N.C.A.A. does not comment on active investigations, but a spokesman for S.M.U. confirmed yesterday that the association had begun a preliminary investigation last week. The investigation was touched off by complaints from rival coaches.

title: HOUSE ACTION ON ARMS FREEZE POSTPONED 2 WEEKS
description: President Reagan won some more breathing space for his arms policies on Capitol Hill today as House Democratic leaders postponed consideration of a nuclear freeze resolution for two weeks. House Republican leaders said the delay could halt the measure's momentum.

title: ROYAL PALM BEACH COLONY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
'PARZIVAL' STAGED BY AND FOR THE DEAF
description: At the beginning of ''Parzival,'' the medieval German poem, a boy is in a deep, quiet forest. He is kept in seclusion by his mother, who fears that if he sees a knight, he will be tempted to become one and will eventually die in combat. One day, however, some knights pass through the forest, and Parzival is indeed enthralled. He follows them and eventually becomes a knight, but he must face many severe tests - encounters with beasts, knights and women - before he becomes a truly strong man.

title: A SLEAZE FILM FESTIVAL AT 8TH STREET PLAYHOUSE
description: THERE may have been lurid, tawdry, no-account film festivals in the past, but none with the temerity to advertise as boldly as the Eighth Street Playhouse's Sleaze Festival. It's billed as a collection of ''films not seen outside of drive-ins in the Deep South.'' Actually, that's not fair. Some of these films have turned up on television, some have been seen as midnight shows, some may have appeared in out-of-the-way theaters on the wrong side of town. But they haven't been gathered together in either the quantity, or the dubious quality, that's in evidence here.

title: A TALE OF 2 SCHOOL DISTRICTS AND THE PROGRAMS MONEY CAN BUY
description: When Wayne Seyfert, a Lawrence High School science teacher, visits Lawrence elementary schools, he always takes along some fun things - like fossils or frogs' hearts - and he never forgets to bring his very kindest voice.

title: Sacramento Utility Sells $70 Million of Bonds
description: The Sacramento Municipal Utility District, whose bonds are known as ''Sac Muds,'' sold $70 million of Aa-rated bonds to underwriters led by Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., which said that the issue was all sold in the first day of sales.

title: REAGN URGES 3 BILLS TO TIGHTEN COLLEGE AID
description: President Reagan today made official proposals that would require students receiving Federal grants to pay a larger share of their college costs. The proposals, disclosed weeks ago, have been received coolly in both the Senate and the House in recent days.

The pianist Jay McShann, who led one of the great Kansas City blues bands in the late 30's, and the blues shouter Joe Turner, a prominent part of Kansas City nightlife before he made his New York debut at Carnegie Hall in 1938, are singing and playing together at the Third Avenue club through Sunday with strong support from Major Holley, bass, and Joey Baron, drums.

title: STOP PICKING ON THOSE WHO WERE BORN IN '61!
description: To the Editor: Having been born in 1961 is turning out to be rather unfortunate. When President Carter decided to reinstate draft registration in 1980, he began with men born in 1960 and 1961.

title: MEXICO IS A DOMINO

title: MET OPERA: 'WALKURE' LED BY SILVIO VARISO
description: When it was new in 1967, Herbert von Karajan's production of ''Die Walkure'' gave the Metropolitan Opera its first look at the austere style that dominated Wagnerian productions in the decades following World War II. This approach, originating in Wieland Wagner's stagings at Bayreuth, was followed by others, including Mr. Karajan. He made his Metropolitan debut in this ''Walkure,'' which was supposed to be the first chapter in a Karajan ''Ring.'' As it happened, a strike intervened with the project only half finished and the Met's ''Ring'' had to proceed without the Karajan presence.

Several years ago, he spent the summer at Pleasantville, N.Y., wearing a T-shirt, sitting outside and working in the crowd-control business. The crowds were not difficult to control.

title: Expelling the Messenger

By publishing his alarm, Mr. Mosher made the wrong kind of waves in a bitter sea, and Stanford has now expelled him for allegedly illegal and unethical conduct.

But proclaiming a crisis is good strategy if it can finally force the city to manage its jail problems better.

description: International Israel accused the United States of not honoring an agreement on delineating military patrol zones in the Beirut area. Israel gave ''strict instructions'' to its forces to avoid incidents with United States marines in Lebanon, a senior Pentagon official said. The official said the instructions followed the announcement Thursday of a letter from the commandant of the Marine Corps, Gen. Robert H. Barrow, to Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Others were not so sure. ''Bullfighting,'' one matador said, ''has lost a lot of its luster.''

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The subway train stops at 149th Street and Third Avenue in the South Bronx, and a young woman gets off. She looks no older than 16 and is wearing a maternity T-shirt that says ''Act of Love'' across the front. The act of love bulging below the lettering is six months along. Behind her are a couple carrying a baby and a stroller. The baby is 6 months old. She is 17. He is 19.

title: No Headline
description: Iran to Set Oil Discounts

title: Harvard, Friars Win in Hockey
description: Harvard and Providence won the first games of their weekend N.C.A.A. quarterfinal hockey series last night at their home rinks. Greg Chalmers scored with 1 minute 29 seconds left to give Harvard a 6-5 victory over Michigan State at Cambridge, Mass., in the first game of a two-game total-goal series.

title: SATURDAY, MARCH 19, 1983; The Economy
description: Six companies and six executives were accused of conspiring to fix the price of copper tubing over a six-year period. The companies named in the indictment were Phelps-Dodge, Revere Copper and Brass, Revere Copper Products, Cerro Copper Products, Reading Industries and Cambridge-Lee Industries. Their sales of the tubing were said to have exceeded $360 million in 1980, making the case the Administration's largest so far in terms of revenue. (Page 31.)

title: COOLIDGE HAD THE RIGHT IDEA
description: The Reagan Administration's proposal to turn over a big chunk of the United States Weather Service to private enterprise suggests that we may be entering a new, more imaginative era in our thinking about the appropriate allocation of functions between the public and the private sectors. The toughest case may be foreign policy.

title: METRO AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PHIPPS MAY HAVE A HORSE FOR THE DERBY
description: John Nerud, who trained Dr. Fager and now directs the fortunes of Tartan Farm, once warned owners to be careful about naming their race horses. ''If you get one that can really run, you're going to feel like a fool if he's got a name like Alfredo or Turkey Neck.''

title: Chilean-I.M.F. Accord
description: Chile has reached a preliminary agreement with the International Monetary Fund to modify the conditions that the fund attached to a $875 million loan it granted the country last January, Economy Minister Manuel Martin said today. He declined to give any details about the modifications that had been agreed to.

title: REAGAN AND AIDES PONDER NEW POSITION ON MEDIUM-RANGE MISSILES
description: President Reagan and his senior diplomatic and military advisers conferred today on whether it was time to alter the American position in the medium-range missile negotiations with the Soviet Union, Administration officials said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Rite of Spring

title: U.S. Steel in Talks On Importing Steel
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the leader in the steel industry's fight against imports, said today that it was negotiating to buy semifinished steel on a long-term basis from the British Steel Corporation.

title: Debt Repaid by Chinese
description: China has repaid $5.1 billion of highinterest debt incurred for imports of heavy industrial equipment ordered in 1978, just before its economic retrenchment, the New China News Agency said today. The rates ran from 15 to 18 percent, it added.

title: PRICE PLOT ON TUBING IS CHARGED
description: A Federal grand jury returned a felony indictment today charging six companies and six executives with conspiring to fix the price of copper tubing over a six-year period, the Justice Department announced.

title: CBS PLANNING TO END 'FACE THE NATION'
description: Within the next six months, CBS News will replace its 19-year-old Sunday morning interview program, ''Face the Nation,'' with a new half-hour discussion series moderated by Lesley Stahl, the CBS White House correspondent, CBS News officials said yesterday.

title: BOARD SUSTAINS LEVER BUILDING AS A LANDMARK
description: After an intense struggle, the landmark status of Lever House, the steel-and-glass Park Avenue office tower, was upheld yesterday by the Board of Estimate in a 6-to-5 vote.

title: Tickets and a Car
description: There are, alas, only 40 taxicabs in all of Albuquerque, N.M., and that fact presented a major obstacle to a financial windfall sought by two of the city's certified public accountants. Dennis Caplan and Cynthia Reinhart wanted to sell six tickets they had won in a lottery for the April 2-4 finals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: HIGH-TECHNOLOGY JOBS GOING OVERSEAS AS U.S. COSTS RISE
description: The decision by Atari Inc. last month to move 1,700 assembly jobs from California to Asia has raised questions of whether high technology will revive the American job market.

title: MAN GIVEN 2 LIFE SENTENCES IN KILLING OF FEDERAL JUDGE
description: Charles Voyde Harrelson was sentenced today to two consecutive life terms in prison in the assassination in 1979 of Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr.

title: FOOTHILL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: FOR ALBANY, THE BUDGET'S THE CENTER OF ATTENTION
description: Governor Cuomo called this the season of hard choices. It was his way of describing what others know more prosaically as the annual process of assembling the state budget. But while the choices may have been hard, they were made this year with a speed that has not been seen here in a number of years.

title: Bridge: Root's Team Is Far Ahead In Final of Vanderbilt Play
description: The foursome headed by Bill Root of Boca Raton, Fla., built up a huge lead of 72 international match points against one led by Eddie Kantar of Los Angeles in the first 16 deals of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship final here this afternoon.

description: Robert F. Bradford, a Governor of Massachusetts in the late 1940's, died today at the age of 80.

description: Nobody likes being No. 2. It bothered Malcolm Wilson, but he was too gentlemanly and self-effacing to say anything about it. Mary Anne Krupsak said so instantly and openly. Mario Cuomo waited a little longer but then exploded into a full-fledged No. 2 grumble.

title: ADRIAN S. FISHER, 69, ARMS TREATY NEGOTIATOR
description: Adrian S. Fisher, a leading arms control negotiator and former dean of the Georgetown University Law Center, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 69 years old.

description: About 3,000 people may have been killed in election violence last month in India's northeastern state of Assam, the state's Chief Minister, Hiteswar Saikia, said today.

description: The Israeli Defense Minister, Moshe Arens, told Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger today that Israeli forces in Lebanon were under ''strict instructions'' to avoid incidents with American marines, a senior Pentagon official said.

title: Gunman Wounds Queens Officer
description: A plainclothes police officer was slightly wounded last night in a shootout with a gunman in Jamaica, Queens, the police said. The officer, 23-year-old Edward Infante of the 103d Precinct anticrime unit, was treated for a wound in the right arm at Queens General Hospital and released, a police spokesman said.

title: MOSCOW TO SCREEN U.S. TV NETWORKS' VIDEOTAPES
description: Correspondents for American television networks have been told by Soviet authorities that videotapes will be screened at the airport here before permission is given for shipment to or from the West.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If we were to calculate the real back pay in this case, they'd have to take Brooklyn College and City College and auction them off to pay the damages.'' - Judith Vladeck, a lawyer in a discrimination suit against the City University of New York. (27:1.)

title: SPACE SHUTTLE DEFECTS FIXED AND LAUNCHING IS RESET FOR APRIL 4
description: The engine leaks on the space shuttle Challenger have apparently been fixed, the satellite cargo has been dusted off and so the craft is now scheduled to begin its maiden flight April 4.

title: Hayes Tied at 136
description: Mark Hayes chipped in a birdie from 60 feet on the final hole today and tied Bill Rogers for the lead at 136 after two rounds of the $400,000 New Orleans Open golf tournament.

But nothing Bill Cartwright, Sly Williams and Louis Orr accomplished could match Ernie Grunfeld's output in the final 59 seconds of their 106-100 victory over the Washington Bullets at the Capital Centre. It was the Knicks' eighth straight triumph.

description: A board being set up to oversee a joint production venture between General Motors and Toyota will decide whether laid-off members of the United Automobile Workers union will get first rights to jobs there, G.M.'s chairman, Roger B. Smith, said.

description: Stanford picked up a third relay victory to maintain its lead in the team standing today at the second annual National Collegiate Athletic Association women's swimming and diving championships.

description: Lines are a way of life here. For rationed gasoline Sudanese drivers, who are allowed to fill their tanks only once a week, sometimes line up for as long as two days, sleeping in their automobiles.

title: DOCTORS ASSAIL RULES ON HANDICAPPED INFANTS
description: The American Academy of Pediatrics asked a Federal court today to overturn regulations aimed at guaranteeing food and medical attention for severely handicapped newborn babies, contending that the rules could actually cause harm to the infants.

title: ISRAEL SAYS U.S. DID NOT HONOR PACT ON PATROLS
description: Israel accused the United States today of failing to honor an agreement on delineating military patrol zones in the Beirut area.

title: Turkish Financial Law
description: Turkey's National Consultative Assembly, the quasi parliament appointed by the military Government, has signaled its acceptance of a draft law giving sweeping powers to the Cabinet over the country's financial sector. A final vote on the measure, which would allow the Cabinet to alter, abolish or renew by decree most of the laws governing banks and financial institutions, is expected next week.

title: SCREEN: FIVE ANECDOTES ABOUT PUERTO RICO
description: ''And God Created Them'' is the work of Jacobo Morales, a Puerto Rican actor, writer and director of very apparent wit and ability. Made on a $200,000 budget and boasting no particular technical polish, this collection of ironic, often funny vignettes manages to be entirely disarming. ''And God Created Them'' will be shown this evening at 8:30 and tomorrow at 3:30 at the 57th Street Playhouse, as part of the New Directors/ New Films series.

title: Salvador Questioning Role of Slain Activist
description: Salvadoran Government officials said today that a human rights activist killed Monday was fighting alongside guerrillas, but colleagues of the dead woman denied the charge.

title: Concert in Brooklyn
description: A concert including works by Haydn, Honegger and Ibert will be presented tomorrow at 3 P.M. in the auditorium at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Maclean's Ashes Buried
description: The ashes of Donald Maclean, who was cremated last week in Moscow 32 years after he defected from Britain, have been buried in the family plot in a churchyard in Penn, a village 20 miles northwest of London, inside an urn decorated with a hammer and sickle.

title: Holders Approve Pabst Asset Sale
description: Shareholders of the Pabst Brewing Company have approved the acquisition of part of the company by the G. Heileman Brewing Company.

title: ALBANY, FUND THE LIBRARY PROPERLY
description: In the next few weeks, the Legislature will shape New York State's budget for the coming year. As mayors, unions and other advocates stake their claims, the needs of the New York Public Library - one of the state's smallest dependents - should not be overlooked. Since its charter from the state pledges it to provide free public service, the library depends heavily - indeed, almost entirely - on the public treasury.

title: KING HUSSEIN IN BRITAIN FOR TALKS
description: King Hussein of Jordan led an Arab League delegation to Britain today to ask Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her Government for help in the creation of an independent Palestinian state.

title: The Labeled Americans
description: Why does so much writing that describes American citizens sound like the work of displaced food critics? ''Germanic stubbornness laced with Gallic charm,'' say, is in the same genre as ''veal brightened with thinly-sliced lemons.'' But the celebrant of veal piccata is appealing to the palate; the slinger of ethnic adjectives is, however inadvertently, kowtowing to ignorance.

title: Hughes Tool Loss
description: The Hughes Tool Company, Houston, said it would have a firstquarter loss in contrast to net income of $67.4 million a year earlier, as a result of currency devaluations in Venezuela. The company said, however, that it would have an operating profit and a positive cash flow for the quarter.

title: Rock Island Sale

McFarr. The Chicago and North Western had rented the track for three years. The Soo Line Railroad Company had bid $88 million for 672 miles of Rock Island track.

title:

WHEN TEATIME WAS SPECIAL
description: IN early Connecticut, as in all the colonies, tea was the most important beverage. In the 18th century, teatime signified a late afternoon meal. When guests arrived, the proper and ceremonial service of tea called for the use of one's best porcelain, silver and linen.

title: NORWEGIAN 'THE STORY OF KAMILLA'
description: ''Betrayal: The Story of Kamilla'' is less interesting for itself than for its promise of greater things to come from Vibeka Lokkeberg, the young Norwegian woman who wrote and directed it and plays - beautifully - a leading role.

description: THE economics of international sports have become so gigantic that it now appears that only wealthy first-world nations, totalitarian second-world nations and speculating third-world nations can dare bid on a spectacle like the World Cup or the Olympics.

Instead, he'll shed his ''civvies,'' as Mr. Vereen puts it, pull on a pair of tights and travel back to the past of his youth in performances with the May O'Donnell Dance Company at the Joyce Theater in Chelsea.

description: The review by Florence Fabricant of Porterhouse II on Feb. 13, in my judgment as a patron for more than 30 years, is unconvincing, unclear and unbelievable.

title: SCHOLARS SET SAIL ON A MURKY VERDIAN SEA
description: The most important music publication of the year is not, hard though it may be to believe, that admirably exhaustive biography of Maestro Ricco Opolento, the titan of the podium who used to conduct Bach's B-minor Mass using only his left eyebrow. Nor is it the equally weighty (5 pounds, 3 ounces) study of the art of Melissa Altissa, the celebrated Transylvanian coloratura whose highest notes are said to induce tachycardia in bats. Books such as these, which come flooding out each season, serve definite purposes - they make wonderful door stops, for instance. Sometimes they also add an infinitesimal some-thing to the sum of human knowledge. We true fans swallow such volumes voraciously, exactly as other readers gulp down murder mysteries or best-sellers by discredited statesmen. But so few books about music or musicians can be taken seriously, except as exercises in historical fiction or career promotion, that the occasional worthwhile publication stands out like a swan on a duck pond.

title: CLASH OF SWORDS ENDS HARTMAN SEASON
description: FOR the Hartman Theater season's final production, a 55-year-old operetta adapted from a 139-year-old novel, which takes place 356 years ago, will be revised rather than revived - with contemporary orchestrations, all-out swordplay and an accent on youth.

GARDENING;
ORIGINS OF OUR FRUITS AND VEGETABLES

title: WATTLE I DO?

Those are the responses you get - even on Mindanao-Deep background - from sensitive White House aides when you bring up the subject of wattles. On this word, in the eternal race between photocopier and papershredder, the shredder has won out; the ban on its use at the center of power goes beyond ''executive privilege'' to the depths of primitive taboo.

title: SEPERATION OF POWERS? YOU MUST BE KIDDING, SAYS CHINA
description: Only months before China's last imperial dynasty collapsed in 1911, it sold bonds to foreigners to finance a railroad to complete a 562-mile north-south link between Peking and Canton and reach an equal distance westward toward Chongqing (Chungking). The Nationalist Government paid the interest periodically until 1939. Now the 72-year-old bonds, once considered worthless, have emerged as the latest irritant in Washington's strained relationship with Peking.
