description: Officials of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway said today that they planned to widen an eight-mile stretch in Westchester and Rockland Counties.

title: ON THE MOVE TEACHING DANCE
description: WHAT do the Suffolk County football champions of Bellport High School, the choreographer Gwen Verdon and students from the Cleary School for the Deaf have in common? They are all participating today in ''Prepare to Move,'' a day-long workshop sponsored by the Brookhaven Theater Dance Guild at the gymnasium of the State University at Stony Brook.

title: Pressures and Postures Over Missile Talks
description: In an increasingly edgy domestic and diplomatic climate, President Reagan met last week with his top security advisers to discuss how and when the United States might meet the Soviet Union halfway on missile deployment in Europe. But even before the meeting convened, Moscow as good as told Washington that halfway was nowhere.

title: SMILE, YOU'RE ON CANDID RESUME
description: IF it is not yet the wave of the future, it just might be a ripple: rather than present prospective employers with written resumes, jobseekers in the county now have an opportunity to put their work histories on videotape and see the result aired on cable television.

title: EX-RATCHFORD AIDE A CAMPAIGN CHIEF
description: WHEN opportunity knocked for Peter B. Slone, it not only changed his life. It also broke up one of the most successful political partnerships in Connecticut.

title: Offbeat China
description: To the Editor:

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: RACES IN YONKERS START TO TAKE SHAPE
description: YONKERS AT a time rich in political turmoil, a soft-spoken, 58-year-old real estate man who has never sought elective office announced last week that he wanted to run for Mayor here.

title:
GARDENING;
ORIGINS OF OUR FRUITS AND VEGETABLES
description: EARLY man is thought to have been nomadic, wandering from place to place in search of food and living in makeshift shelters. When the discovery was made that discarded grain would grow to produce more grain and that certain animals could be tamed and managed to his benefit, man settled in permanent dwellings and became a farmer.

title: Susan Teare Affianced To John Logan Morris
description: Mr. and Mrs. G. William Teare Jr. of Richmond have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Elizabeth Teare, to John Logan Morris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mac G. Morris of Princeton, N.J.

title: MEXICO HAS DOMINOES OF ITS OWN TO WORRY ABOUT
description: The decision by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to cut oil prices last week was anything but good news for Mexico, which is caught in its worst financial crisis in memory and remains as dependent on oil sales as it was during the boom years.

title: FEW AWARE OF STATE FACILITIES
description: NEWARK ALTHOUGH several New Jersey hospitals have microsurgery capability, accidental-amputation victims in the state are being taken by State Police, Coast Guard or National Guard helicopters to hospitals in New York or Pennsylvania.

title: RESULTS OF HEPATITIS VACCINE ENCOURAGE HEALTH OFFICIALS
description: Federal health researchers are encouraged about the new hepatitis B vaccine's safety after finding a low rate of complications among more than 200,000 patients, the national Centers for Disease Control has reported.

title: No Headline
description: Tom Goldstein tucks Senator D'Amato's opposition to Medicaid payments for abortions for victims of rape and incest into a brief list of ''conservative positions'' the Senator still holds. The meaning of such a position is further glossed over by concluding the list with defensible aims, ''reduced Government spending, a balanced budget and deregulation.''

title: A DIFFERENT BRAND OF STEAK
description: MARGO SCHMIDT is a writer who lives in Boulder, Colo. BY MARGO SCHMIDT

title: LAKE GEORGE EVENT
description: The National Wildlife Federation is holding one of its environmental summit conferences in the Adirondacks from July 31 to Aug. 6, headquartered at the Silver Bay Association conference center on Lake George. The conferences have been held in various parts of the country yearly for 11 years. Up to 400 individuals may participate under the direction of 25 faculty members and a director.

title: Dioxin Town Residents Told Details of Buyout
description: Property owners in dioxin-contaminated Times Beach, Mo., were told today that the Federal Government hopes to begin buying their homes and businesses by mid-summer.

title: A MISSING PART IN ZIMBABWWE'S CONSTITUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ST. JOHN'S MIS AND WHY IT WORKS
description: ONE afternoon during the first month of the St. John's basketball s eason, as the Redmen were on their way to their 14-game winning s treak, Lou Carnesecca decided he had seen enough. Over the last two s easons the Redmen had somehow failed to exhibit the pettiness, j ealousy and selfishness that many coaches seem willing to tolerate w hile they hope to win a national championship. Yet for one day C arnesecca was tired of looking at them.

title: FROM BUYING GEMS TO POLISHING THESIS
description: AT the age of 61, A. Edward Friedmann of Great Neck is embarked on a new career. Since last month, he has had the title of assistant professor of economics and finance at Baruch College of the City University, where he began teaching last September.

title: Miriam Gerber Marries Dr. Bertram David Kaplan
description: Miriam Gerber, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Gerber of Lantana, Fla., was married yesterday in Memphis to Dr. Bertram David Kaplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kaplan of Germantown, Tenn. Rabbi Harry Danziger performed the ceremony at Temple Israel.

title: ASSEMBLY IN JERSEY APPROVES BILLS TO CURB FARM VANDALISM
description: The New Jersey Assembly passed a package of bills this week designed to curb the increasing vandalism that has destroyed crops, animals and equipment on farms across the state.

title:
GARDENING;
ORIGINS OF OUR FRUITS AND VEGETABLES
description: EARLY man is thought to have been nomadic, wandering from place to place in search of food and living in makeshift shelters. When the discovery was made that discarded grain would grow to produce more grain and that certain animals could be tamed and managed to his benefit, man settled in permanent dwellings and became a farmer.

title:
OPINION;
ONE WAY TO END PRISON OVERCROWDING
description: GOVERNOR CUOMO has cited the $1.8 billion gap between state expenditures and state revenues as his reason for eliminating funds for a task force on domestic violence. He asks: ''What other worthwhile programs should be cut instead?''

title: ATLANTA IN MONTCLAIR
description: The Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, with Robert Shaw conducting and the soprano Elly Ameling as soloist, will perform Friday evening in Montclair.

title: KING HUSSEIN PLANS TALK WITH ARAFAT
description: King Hussein of Jordan said today that he would meet in the coming week with Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, to discuss Middle East peace efforts.

title: SEARGENTS SAY CITY'S NEW POLICE TEST IS UNFAIR
description: Scores of New York City police sergeants are charging that a new Police Department examination that was designed to overcome racial and sexual biases was unfair to them.

title: DEBATE OVER AN 'ULTRASAFE' REACTOR SPLITS THE EXPERTS
description: The Ides of March came right on schedule for America's nuclear industry. At a meeting of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission on Tuesday, the builders and operators of nuclear plants were criticized for inadequate management, poor equipment maintenance and faulty operational procedures.

title: Miss Jensen Sets Nuptials
description: Gerda Jensen of Stamford, Conn., and Harold Jim Jensen of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Sue Jensen, to William Edgar Tienken, son of Michael Arthur Tienken and Beverly G. McGraw, both of New Canaan, Conn. An October wedding is planned.

title: THEODORA D. BODMAN
description: Theodora D. Bodman, a trustee of the Village of Old Brookville, L.I., from 1942 to 1958, died of pneumonia yesterday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
NO GREAT DEAL FOR THE U.S.
description: GENERAL MOTORS and Toyota have formed a joint venture to build cars i n California. Except for a few disgruntled competitors and the e verprickly trustbusters at the Federal Trade Commission, most e veryone seems to be toasting this marriage of East and West, a nnounced appropriately on St. Valentine's Day.

title: REYNOLDS OF METS GIVEN A MAJOR ROLE
description: Ronn Reynolds walked into the Mets' training camp in late February nursing a broken finger, wondering if he could grip a bat and thinking how nice it would be to make the jump from the Texas League to the International League.

title: THERE'S MORE TO SCENERY THAN MEETS THE EYE
description: I saw the same Fifth Avenue balcony in two different films last week, playing two different roles. One day it turned up in ''Tales of Ordinary Madness,'' as part of the Rockefeller Center office where a fast-living, fiercely independent-minded poet, modeled on Charles Bukowski and played by Ben Gazzara, goes to meet with his straitlaced New York publisher. It was here that he established his ''poetic'' credentials - and offended the publisher mightily - by swilling a couple of bottles of wine at lunchtime.

title: THE FADING OF THE FIXED PENSION PLAN
description: I f you think your right to a set monthly pension check linked to your final salary is as certain as a gold watch at retirement, think again. The future is cloudy for the typical corporate pension plan, which promises to pay retired workers a given amount each month for life. In its stead, more and more companies are establishing plans in which the employers contribute a set amount per employee each year, sometimes a percentage of the employee's salary. The amount the worker receives at retirement depends on how long he worked for the company and how much his retirement account earned. The first type of plan defines the benefit; the second type defines the contribution.

title: FORT LEE GETS A VIDEO CENTER
description: FORT LEE WHAT has been commonplace in Japan for some time can now be found in the United States, too. At the Oak Tree Shopping Center here, the Sony Corporation of America has opened a television information center similar to its high-tech consumer information centers in Tokyo and Osaka.

title: No Headline
description: ''The New Vietnam Scholarship'' is a timely presentation of the process of rethinking and reassessment that is now under way in the United States.

title: BESTSELLERS
description: Jx FICTION 1 1 THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $15.95.) An English girl caught between Israeli intelligence agents and P.L.O. terrorists. 2 1 25 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 3 10 2 THE DELTA STAR, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow, $15.45.) Los Angeles cops contend with their own city's underworld, some would-be Nobel Prize scientists and an elusive Soviet sub. 4 2 29 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 5 3 19 MISTRAL'S DAUGHTER, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $15.95.) The art world of the 20's and the fashion industry of the 80's. 6 6 5 ELLIS ISLAND, by Fred Mustard Stewart. (Morrow, $15.95.) Five young immigrants and the fortunes that await them in America at the turn of the century. 7 8 5 THE MISTS OF AVALON, by Marion Zimmer Bradley. (Knopf, $16.95.) The Arthurian legend seen through the eyes of four women who played leading roles.

title: Cornell Tops Adelphi
description: Matt Crowley got four goals and Bruce Bruno added three goals and four assists, as Cornell opened its lacrosse season with a 14-8 victory over Adelphi today. Steve Day led the Panthers with three goals and two assists.

title: A WRAP-AROUND SOLUTION
description: ''I don't love them,'' says James Amster of the developers who put up a 31-story office tower virtually next door to him. But, he added, ''you have to count your blessings'' - among them the check Cohen Brothers Realty Corporation sends him every month for the air rights to his home, Amster Yard. The yard is a cluster of low, 19th-century residential and commercial buildings on East 49th Street that was designated a landmark after the interior designer, now 75 years old, refurbished its gardens and buildings.

title: AILMENTS BOTHER 3 YANKEE HOPEFULS
description: Before a game the other night, Steve Balboni and Barry Evans sat together on a bench in the Yankee clubhouse while the other players were outside taking infield practice. Balboni held a bat in his hands; Evans held his chin.

title: 'COP TRISTESSE' AND ONE-LINERS
description: THE DELTA STAR By Joseph Wambaugh. 276 pp. New York: A Perigord Press Book. William Morrow and Co. $15.95

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: NEW MUSIC Many young performers on the ''new music'' scene compose their own works by combining techniques derived from other cultures with the improvisational attitudes of jazz and the serious repertory ambitions of the classical tradition. Ned Rothenberg, a young composer and player of wind and reed instruments, also adds a plangent temperament and a sophisticated sense of musical structure.

title: ROOT TEAM CAPTURES THE TITLE IN VANDERBILT BRIDGE TOURNEY
description: One team of experts took a major step toward international honors here last night at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, while another took the final step.

title: LIST OF SPECIES BELIEVED IN DANGER
description: New York's revised list of endangered species covers three categories in descending order of danger - endangered, threatened and of special concern. Following are the animals in the three categories: ENDANGERED Chittenango ovate amber snail Karner blue butterfly Short-nosed sturgeon Longjaw cisco Round whitefish Pugnose shiner Eastern sand darter Bluebreast darter Gilt darter Bluepike Spoonhead sculpin Deepwater sculpin Tiger salamander Bog turtle Leatherback sea turtle Hawksbill sea turtle Atlantic Ridley sea turtle Massasauga rattlesnake Golden eagle Bald eagle Peregrine falcon Eskimo curlew Least tern Roseate tern Loggerhead shrike Indiana bat Grey wolf Couger sperm Fei whale Blue whale Finback whale Humpback whale Right whale THREATENED Lake sturgeon Mooneye Lake chubsucker Mud sunfish Longear sunfish Cricket frog Mud turtle Blandings turtle Loggerhead sea turtle Green sea turtle Timber rattlesnake Osprey Red-shouldered hawk Northern harrier Spruce grouse Piping plover Common tern Eastern wood rat SPECIAL CONCERN Silver chub Gravel chub Blackchin shiner Black redhorse Longhead darter Southern leopard frog Hellbender Jefferson salamander Bluespotted salamander Spotted salamander Spotted turtle Wood turtle Diamondback terrapin Worm snake Eastern hognose snake Common loon Least bittern Cooper's hawk Black rail Upland sandpiper Black tern Common barn owl Short-eared owl Common nighthawk Sedge wren Eastern bluebird Henslow's sparrow Grasshopper sparrow Vesper sparrow Common raven Small-footed bat New England cottontail Harbor porpoise

title: JAPANESE BALK AT ARMS BUILD-UP URGED BY U.S.
description: United States and Japanese representatives have met here to discuss a pledge Japan made nearly two years ago to take over defense of 1,000 miles of sea lanes south and east of here. They agreed only to set up another study of the issue.

title: Swallows Back in Capistrano
description: The swallows again returned to their nesting sites in the ruins of the old adobe Mission San Juan Capistrano today. About 1,000 people greeted the tiny forktailed birds, which arrived at 8:44 A.M.

title: DANCE: DON REDLICH OFFERS SOLO, 'HAROLD II'
description: What a bright idea it was for Annabelle Gamson, the Phyllis Lamhut Dance Company and the Don Redlich Dance Company to share a week at the Joyce Theater. In this case, three was not a crowd. The three choreographers were in artistic sympathy, yet they were just different enough to prevent monotony from setting in. It is also to their credit that, even though the Joyce has little space for musicians, they tried to use live music whenever possible.

title: Jill Foley Wed in Florida To George D. Sullivan 3d
description: The marriage of Jill Ann Foley to George D. Sullivan 3d took place yesterday at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Siesta Key, Sarasota, Fla. The Rev. James Gloeklerperformed the ceremony.

title: WHAT'S NEW ON THE BOOKSHELF: COMPUTER BOOKS
description: The Personal Computer Book by Peter A. McWilliams. Prelude Press, Los Angeles. 300 pages, $9.95.

title: BOOK REVIEW
description: March 20, 1983 NONFICTION ADVENTURES IN THE SCREEN TRADE: A Personal View of Hollywood and Screenwriting. By William Goldman. 14 CONVERSATIONS WITH ARRAU.

title: A Jaywalking Runner
description: Julie Ispholding, who has competed in the New York and Boston Marathons, has found out that in Cincinnati running can be hazardous - to the pocketbook. She and some friends were issued jaywalking tickets last week while tuning up for a marathon.

title: SKIING IN THE SUN
description: NEW HAMPSHIRE CANNON MOUNTAIN Franconia Notch State Park Franconia, N.H. 03580 Information: 603-823-5563 Snow Reports: 603-823-7771 Lodging reservations: 603-823-5661 THE SKIING With a 2,146-foot vertical, New Hampshire's largest ski area has three chairlifts and a beginner tow at the bottom. A mile-long aerial tram gives access to a half-dozen challenging trails served by a pair of summit T-bars. There's usually skiing until about April 20. COST A weeday ticket is $16, weekends and holiday weeks $19. Students and juniors 12 and under pay $2 a day less. There is a $3 tram surcharge weekends and holiday weeks. THE TOWN Franconia is basically a small, quiet town drawing serious skiers to a handful of inns and motels. There are more than 50 miles of groomed cross-country trails. The New England Ski Museum at the base of Cannon is worth a visit.

title: ALLURE OF SMALL RAILS FELT AT L.I. CONVENTION
description: Uneven tracks and unreliable switches delayed the first voyage of a long freight train on Long Island. When it finally inched down the tracks this afternoon, it was three hours late, and its six stout diesel engines were straining to pull 26 box cars and three cabooses. Seconds later, it derailed.

title: Subway Hero
description: Reginald Andrews, who lives with his wife and eight children in a sparse apartment at 513 West 145th Street, was unemployed, in debt and on his way home from a job interview when he became a hero last Dec. 20.

title: DRY-EYED OBSERVER OF CITY LIVES
description: THINGS TO COME AND GO Three Stories. By Bette Howland. 164 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95.

title: COLUMBIA JOURNALISM SCHOOL'S FUTURE DIVIDING ADMINISTRATION AND FACULTY
description: The administration and the faculty of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism are engaged in a sharp debate over what the institution, the nation's best-known journalism school, should be doing and how it should be doing it.

title: Lisa M. Shaw Married to Philip D. O'Connell 3d
description: Lisa Marie Shaw, daughter of Sheila Marie Shaw of Paris and Dr. William Vare Shaw of Leicester, England, was married yesterday to Philip Daniel O'Connell 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Connell Jr. of Glastonbury, Conn. The Rev. Seamus Brennan performed the ceremony at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Stockton, N.J.

title:
STAMPS;
JOINT ISSUE FROM THE UNITED STATES AND SWEDEN
description: The United States and Sweden are putting out a joint commemorative issue this Thursday to mark the 200th anniversary of the signing of a Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the two countries. The firstday ceremony for both stamps is taking place at 11 A.M. at the American Swedish Historical Museum in Philadelphia.

title: Antiques Kean Derided Go Up for Sale in Jersey
description: The 57 Empire-period antiques that were banished from Drumthwacket, the Princeton mansion of the Governor of New Jersey, are up for auction, and the collection could be gone by the end of March.

title: BOXING'S 'ACCOUNTABILITY'
description: ATLANTIC CITY BOXING belongs here. The punishment fits the grime. Just as the glitter of Atlantic City's new boardwalk casino-hotels quickly fades after one block into the gloomy decay of its Monopoly-game streets, the dazzle of a big title fight often obscures the sour scams of the sweet science. But for a few hours Friday, two light heavyweights, Michael Spinks and Jim Florio, bridged boxing's two worlds. And in another few months, those two worlds may never be apart again.

title: MISS SILLS TO OPEN NEW LONDON CENTER
description: seat Art Deco-style theater at the top of New London's Captain's Walk.

title: Beth Morris Is Fiancee Of Marc J. Eichenholtz
description: The engagement of Rhoda Beth Morris to Marc Jeffrey Eichenholtz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Eichenholtz of North Woodmere, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Morris of Westbury, L.I. A late May wedding is planned.

title: WEST SIDE DRAWS MIDDLE-INCOME BUYERS
description: AQUIET and unpretentious elegance is what first strikes a visitor t o the Central Condominium at 250 West 88th Street, a recent gut r enovation of a former hotel. The sponsor is offering apartments at p rices ranging from $170 to $190 a square foot, or $119,000 to $ 133,000 for a 700-square-foot one-bedroom apartment.

title: THE RIGORS OF RUNNING FOR - AND RUNNING - CITY HALL
description: HONOLULU CONSIDER this political unknown who (1) had only three years to go in a state government job before she could retire; (2) ran against an incumbent and won; (3) hates fireworks, highly popular here, and if she could would ban them from all public areas on the Island of Oahu; and (4)just might run for Governor in 1986.

title: American Indians
description: To the Editor:

title: Air Traffic: Too Much Too Soon?
description: The bagatelle finesse of guiding stacked-up airplanes to land safely on one or two runways with split-second timing is not a skill acquired overnight. When more than 11,000 of the nation's most experienced air controllers were dismissed after striking in 1981, traffic restrictions had to be imposed.

title: Letters; A Plea to Revise State Fire Code
description: To the Editor:

title: DE GAULLE IN AN EPIC OF HIS OWN MAKING
description: DE GAULLE, By Bernard Ledwidge. Illustrated. 418 pp. New York. St. Martin's Press. $17.95.

title: STAGE: 'MUCH ADO' BY THE YALE REP
description: NEW HAVEN The year is 1919 and the scene is an elegant English country house. A croquet game is in progress on the lawn and a bandstand is ready for a celebration. In the sylvan setting, Walton Jones has staged a gentle, contemplative ''Much Ado About Nothing'' for the Yale Repertory Theater.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: MATTHEW FELDMAN, President pro tempore of the State Senate and chairman of its Education Committee, says he is worried about the future of state educational programs, such as special education, science, mathematics, urban education and computer literacy.

title: GROW WILDFLOWERS TO WELCOME SPRING
GEORGIA FIGHTING TO PROTECT ITS ONION'S HONOR
description: A month from now, growers around Vidalia, Ga., will begin producing another season's harvest of large, squat onions renowned for their sweetness and light touch upon the breath.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Last week's debut concerts divided fairly equally between soloists and chamber ensembles, and perhaps the most interesting among all these musicians was Carter Brey, a young cellist and winner of the 1982 Young Concert Artists International Auditions. The music world - which is already bursting with young cello talent - will have to make room for Mr. Brey. His recital at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday introduced a first-rate player - a musician with warm sound, an unusually firm grasp of intonation and a sensitive, well-directed passion both for his instrument and for the music before him.

title: LOVING TO WRITE
description: ROBERT GRAVES His Life and Work. By Martin Seymour-Smith. Illustrated. 609 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $22.50.

title: 3 Scenic Trails Are Approved; Legislation Approved For Three Scenic Trails
description: Congressional action has been completed on legislation designating three new national scenic trails and authorizing a study of other routes for possible inclusion in the system.

title: Good Supplies of Water Seen for Western States
description: Most of the West will have ''good to excellent'' supplies of water this summer, but streams in a few areas may have below-normal flow, the Government says in a report by the Agriculture Department and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

title: WATNED: IDEAS FOR NEW YORK CITY
description: ''Clearly, the city and the region face several years of further job losses, eroding tax bases and increases in dependent population. But it is certainly difficult to ascertain any actions the city could take to avert or mitigate this downward trend.''

title: LOCAL COMMUTERS, LEFT TO MAKE DO, POOL RESOURCES
description: OUTNUMBERED more than 10-to-1 by rail travelers who work in New York City, the 2,000 New Haven line riders who commute within Connecticut have been left to fend for themselves since the Metro-North strike began March 7.

title: 2 Americans Make Formula One Racing Bids
description: In the five years since Mario Andretti brought the world driving championship to the United States, no American has won a Formula One Grand Prix race. Andretti does not drive Formula One cars anymore, but two other Americans, Eddie Cheever and Danny Sullivan, are bidding for similar recognition in the world's top motor-racing series.

title: HE'S PRODUCING OPERA FOR A SONG
description: PRESCRIPTIONS for reviving opera on the Island vary. Some prognosticators remain pessimistic. Others find fleeting formulas for survival. Whatever the outlook, the form appears to be in the throes of one near-death scene after another.

title: A Science With Mass Appeal
description: During the past few years, hundreds of thousands of general readers have bought books about a subject that has daunted nonscientists and repelled students for generations. The subject is physics, and clues to its popularity emerge from a look at a few successful titles and from talks with the editors who acquired them.

title: BEER-FRANCHISE ISSUE CONFRONTS ALBANY
description: A MAJOR battle is on in Albany between small beer wholesalers and the regional franchisees of Anheuser-Busch Breweries. A bill before the State Legislature would make illegal the type of ''equity contracts'' drawn up recently by Anheuser-Busch and signed by the franchisees.

title: A FRESH APPROACH
description: A Fresh Approach (outside type) Paris is a city that always pays particular attention to the talents of its chefs. At the moment, much of that attention is focused on Joel Robuchon and the 'moderne' cuisine he is creating at the Jamin restaurant, a style of cooking that is less heavy but not necessarily less rich.

title: BOSTON GETS SOME UNUSUAL OPERAS
description: If New York is the busiest of America's opera centers, Boston is among the richest. Two revivals in Boston this spring - Rimsky-Korsakov's ''The Legend of the Invisible City of Kitezh and the Maiden Fevronia'' and Rameau's ''Zoroastre'' - promise the same sense of freshness and adventure that characterize Manhattan's honeycomb of small companies. But while productions here are often cramped in space and in finances and can offer only microcosmic metaphors of intended grandeur, both these Boston stagings will be relatively solid and thoroughgoing in their production values.

title: SOVIET IS ASSAILED OVER EMIGRATION
description: Delegates to the World Conference on Soviet Jewry adopted a declaration here this week calling on the Soviet Union to take four steps of liberalization: reopen the gates to emigration, release imprisoned Jewish activists, end what it called Government-sponsored anti-Semitism and stop what it described as the persecution of Jews who want to practice their faith and preserve their culture.

title: uf913
description: WILLIAM S. COOK does not mince words. ''You make sure you've got t he right people in place. You evaluate their performance very o bjectively and very coldly, and reward them if they do well and p unish them if they don't.''

title: Exit From A Dead End?
description: A two year old program to end social promotion in New York City schools may have done that only too well, producing a growing crop of students who are advancing in age but not grade level. Last week school offficials announced a plan under which thousands who are facing their fourth year in seventh grade would get the chance to attend high school, and perhaps even graduate.

title:
OPINION;
LEARNING TO DEAL WITH 'NEW REALITIES' OF HELPING CHILDREN
description: IWAS one of the 54 New Jerseyans who attended a recent three-day conference in Washington on the subject: ''Federal and State Budgets: New Realities for Children.''

title: Katherine Lynn Armstrong Wed to Steven Garrett
description: Katherine Lynn Armstrong, daughter of Rodney E. Armstrong of Lambertville, N.J., and Washington, and Phyllis H. Armstrong of Charleston, S.C., was married yesterday to Steven Charles Garrett, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Garrett of Camden, S.C. The bridegroom's father performed the ceremony at the First Baptist Church in Woodruff, S.C.

title: RELATING TO THE DISABLED
description: PEOPLE tend to raise their voices when they first speak with Sandy Seltzer - because she is blind. ''It just points up the immense ignorance of the able-bodied where it comes to dealing with the disabled,'' said Mrs. Seltzer, who lives in Mineola. She believes she is the only person on the Island who has carved a career out of teaching the able-bodied to overcome fear, discomfort and an extreme lack of knowledge in relating to the handicapped - be they family, friends, business associates, schoolmates or customers.

title: LAURIE CLAIRE WEIL TO WED
description: The engagement of Laurie Claire weil to Fred Andrew Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Smith of Brooklyn, has been made known by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Stuart Weil of Reading, Pa., parents of the future bride. A June wedding is planned.

title: U.S. SAID TO EXPAND CENTRAL AMERICAN INTELLIGENCE OPERATIONS
description: In the last two years the United States has established an extensive intelligence-gathering network in Central America to track Soviet and Cuban arms shipments and to monitor guerrilla activities in El Salvador, according to senior Reagan Administration officials.

title: MORE THAN NUMBERS TAKE THE MEASURE OF A SPEAKER
description: An old saw that regularly cuts into the conversation of audiophiles is the remark that you can't tell how a speaker sounds from its specifications. Granted, there is some truth in that, simply because the sound of music - whether ''live'' or from loudspeakers - is too complex a phenomenon to be wholly encompassed by a handful of measurements. Besides, there is the fundamental question whether sensation is ever describable, or whether the experience of sight, sound, touch, smell and taste is too private in its very essence ever to be sketched in words or measured by numbers with any accuracy.

title: Duet for a Solo
description: If the roses had thorns, Peter Martins, a principal dancer and choreographer of the New York City Ballet, didn't wince.

title: No Headline
description: Sacred Heart Is Beaten

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
SPRING: A MAGIC TAPESTRY REWOVEN
description: Within a few weeks now, Draba, the smallest flower that blows, will sprinkle every sandy place with small blooms. He who hopes for spring with upturned eye never sees so small a thing as (a) Draba. He who despairs of spring with downcast eye steps on it, unknowing. He who searches for spring with his knees in the mud finds it in abundance.

title: THE PIPE CAPITAL OF FRANCE
description: VICTOR LUSINCHI reports for The Times from Geneva. By VICTOR LUSINCHI

title:
ART;
IMAGES FORM ERA OF OPTIMISM
description: THIS is a trim exhibition - essentially sepia-toned historic photographs plus concise texts mounted on screens -that is more than the sum of its modest parts. The subject is the Crystal Palace, and the documentation sets the mind reeling and dreaming. No claim is made for the Crystal Palace's being the eighth man-made wonder of the world, but it seems in a league with the storied Hanging Gardens of Babylon, and much more egalitarian.

title: Wallace Back in Hospital
description: Gov. George C. Wallace was admitted to a Birmingham hospital this evening, the third time in less than a month. Mr. Wallace, 63 years old, was admitted to the University of Alabama Hospital for tests, and was listed in satisfactory condition. A hospital spokesman said the Governor was admitted for further tests relating to complaints about leg pains. Mr. Wallace was released Wednesday from Jackson Hospital in Montgomery, where he was treated for a reaction to medicine used to alleviate a digestive tract disorder.

title: LEM: SCIENCE FICTION'S PASSIONATE REALIST
description: BY most criteria, the Polish author Stanislaw Lem is the premier science-fiction writer alive. For over 40 years he has been writing novels, plays, short stories, screenplays, literary criticism, sociological essays and studies of cybernetics and the philosophy of chance - 35 books in all, translated into almost as many languages, a total of 11 million copies sold. But despite his prodigious output and his acclaim, he has remained a literary force at a distance. He avoids interviews and says he has given only three or four in his life.

title: Charleston Champion In N.A.I.A.
description: Stephen Yetman's two free throws with nine seconds left thwarted a comeback by West Virginia Wesleyan and lifted Charleston, S.C., to a 57-53 victory tonight in the title game of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics tournament.

title: STORM
description: ''Is your public persona what you are really like, or is that an act you put on?'' asked Emily Nussbaum, a senior at Scarsdale Alternative High School. Miss Nussbaum was one of five high school students questioning Mayor Koch of New York on the Public Broadcasting Service program ''Why in the World.'' The show, which tries to make news events understandable to teen-agers, is in its second year on 116 public television stations.

title: EAST END LURES ARTISTS ANEW
description: A CENTURY ago, artists came to eastern Long Island for the special light and the rural landscape - the stuff from which they fashioned their impressionistic visions of life. In the 1950's, no longer tied to the exterior world because they were looking within for their abstract expressions of life, they came for the isolation and cheap real estate near the burgeoning New York City art marketplace.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BROTHERS A Slavic Tale. Retold by Samuel Marshak. Translated by Thomas P. Whitney. Illustrated by Diane Stanley. Unpaged. New York: William Morrow & Co.

title: FINNS, A YEAR OF TESTING BEHIND THEM, ARE VOTING
description: Finland's voters choose a new Parliament in voting Sunday and Monday, confident that relations between their small country and the neighboring Soviet Union have survived some difficult tests in the last year.

title: WEATHER PREDICTIONS: HIT OR MISS?
description: IT'S not official until we mark the vernal equinox at 11:39 tonight, but can there be any doubt that spring is here? Tangy skunk cabbage is unfurling along the Bethpage Parkway, salmon-colored earthworms are wriggling in the puddles, and the Yankees are playing ball again.

title: ART FOR PARK DEBATED
description: THE recent assertions of the East End Arts Council on the viability of its Public Sculpture Program seem to have been premature. In spite of a headline in the January-February newsletter of the council announcing ''The River's Edge Sculpture Project Is Alive!,'' Margaret Miller's ''Five Magical Creatures,'' the second work scheduled for installation in the riverside park area in Riverhead, went belly-up at a meeting of the Riverhead Town Board last month.

title: OLD MADRID'S HOTEL VICTORIA
description: LUCY KOMISAR is a writer who lives in New York. By LUCY KOMISAR

title: WHY ARE THE FRENCH WHAT WAY?
description: THE FRENCH, By Theodore Zeldin. Illustrated. 538 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $17.95.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The moose was removed because they are not threatened, they are considered extirpated in New York State. It's illogical to have an extirpated species on the endangered list.'' - Kenneth F. Wich, director of the Division of Fish and Wildlife. (1:1.)

title: Barbara Kathy Giza Marries David Fletcher Sisson
description: At Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday Barbara Kathy Giza, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thaddeus Giza of New Canaan, Conn., was married to David Fletcher Sisson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Sisson of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. The Rev. Joseph P. Nagle performed the ceremony.

title: Kathleen Richards Marries Engineer
description: Kathleen Elizabeth Richards, daughter of Dr. Mary Richards Brandt of Tenafly, N.J., and the late Joseph Samuel Richards, was married yesterday to Gordon John Babcock, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Hamilton Babcock of Massey, Ontario. The Rev. John P. Croneberger performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Atonement in Tenafly.

title: THE WOULD-BE RESCUERS OF SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: ELDERLY U.S. JUDGE IS OVERRULED TWICE IN ONE WEEK
description: A Federal appeals court has overturned two rulings by Federal District Judge Oren R. Lewis and ordered new trials.

title: REAGAN'S UNSETTLING LIFE - OR - DEATH PREFERENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY CITY
description: JERSEY CITY has been around for a long time - long enough to acquirea reputation as a gritty manufacturing center that reached its peak i n another century. But visitors these days sometimes talk about it a s if a team of urban archeologists had just crossed the Hudson R iver and uncovered the lost city of Atlantis.

title: SOVIET REPORTING A CHINESE DETENTE
description: Soviet officials say Moscow has reached ''substantial detente'' with Peking because they do not think relations between China and the United States will ever again come close to what they view as the high-water mark of 1980.

title: Woman and a Son, 3, Are Slain in Brooklyn
description: A woman and her 3-year-old son were killed early yesterday morning when she resisted the sexual advances of man she had admitted to her Brooklyn apartment, the police reported.

title: BLACK LEADERS TURN OUT ON ISSUE OF MINORITY DISTRICT
description: ERNEST S. PRINCE, president of the Urban League of Westchester, told county legislators at a hearing on reapportionment last week in Mount Vernon that the ''war'' he thought the black community would be waging to gain minority representation on the county level was now reduced to a ''skirmish,'' if that.

title: LEOS JANACEK: THE VINIDICATION OF A COMPOSER
description: John Rockwell, a music critic for The Times, is the author of ''All American Music: Composition in the Late Twentieth Century,'' published this month by Alfred A. Knopf. he New York Philharmonic's American concert premiere of Leos Janacek's last opera, ''From the House of the Dead,'' this week is just one more indication of a Janacek groundswell throughout the musical world.

title: CUOMO WASTES NO TEARS OVER DELBELLO'S PROSPECTS
description: Is Gov. Mario M. Cuomo doing to Lieut. Gov. Alfred DelBello what Gov. Hugh L. Carey did to Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo? Mr. Cuomo and Mr. DelBello deny that the Governor has shunted his lieutenant into what resembles governmental and political limbo. But some actions and many politicians say otherwise. For example:

title: FRAUD IN SCIENCE TAINTS THE HIGH AND MIGHTY
description: For the first time in the annals of scientific crime, the Federal Government recently blamed a case of fraud not only on the perpetrator but on the society in which he worked - Harvard Medical School. Federal investigators found that lax supervision at the school had contributed to the ''ease'' with which a young researcher, Dr. John R. Darsee, faked his scientific output over two years. Last week, the National Institutes of Health sent the medical school the bill, seeking repayment of the $122,371 in Federal funds squandered on one of the bogus experiments.

title:
THEATER;
'DANTON'S DEATH' ENDURES AS POLITICAL DRAMA
description: Henry Popkin is a professor of English at the State University of New York at Buffalo.

title: BROWN OUTPACING RIVALS IN IVY LEAGUE POPULARITY
description: It is Hawaii day at the Brown University admissions office, the day for processing applications from high school seniors in Hawaii. One member of the admissions committee has donned a mumu, and the others munch pineapple and macadamia nuts as they scan a computer printout on the applicants.

title: Sheila Conklin Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. F. Edwin Conklin of Watkins Glen, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sheila Joy Conklin, to Michael Anthony Dondiego, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vito A. Dondiego of Brooklyn. A May wedding is planned. Miss Conklin is a financial analyst and assistant to the controller of the J. Henry Schroeder Bank and Trust Company in New York, where her fiance is a vice president of the international department of the Bankers Trust Company.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: House

title: NEW PROGRAM TO COMBAT DRUNK DRIVING
description: LAST Feb. 23, at 6:36 A.M., a Long Island man driving eastbound on Mamaroneck Avenue, a major thoroughfare linking White Plains with Mamaroneck, crashed through a guard rail and into a telephone pole. When police officers questioned him, he said that he had been driving on the Hempstead Turnpike and didn't know what happened.

title: DRAFT GOES THROUGH LOOKING GLASS AND PLAYERS TAKE CONTROL
description: IT was inevitable. Most analysts agree that the turning point came soon after the players assumed so solid a grip on the league's finances and policies that the annual player draft had become worthless.

title: Miss Goreau Wed To S. J. McGruder
description: Angeline Goreau, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Nelson Goreau of Quincy, Fla., and Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Stephen Jones McGruder, son of Mrs. Bud V. Price of Lakewood, Wash., and the late Clement William McGruder. The Rev. Sue Ann Steffney Morrow performed the Methodist ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel, of which she is assistant dean.

title:
OPINION;
A RED-LETTER DAY
description: ''MA'AM,'' said the polite young man, ''your car has just failed the auto emissions test.'' His voice was so calm and matter-of-fact he might have been reporting the need of a quart of oil instead of pronouncing doom. At first I didn't believe it. I hardly can now. My car failed the test. It flat out flunked. How could that be? Hadn't they said almost everybody would pass? Wasn't that practically like a promise? Why me? Why my car that I'm so nice to - always treating it to the car wash, feeding it full of super unleaded, even checking its oil? I guess you just can't buy love.

title: At E.P.A., It Goes With the Territory
description: John W. Hernandez must have known what a hot seat he was taking when he became acting Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, but he probably did not foresee how fast the temperature would rise. He had scarcely settled into Anne McGill Burford's old chair last week when the accusations of favoritism to business that helped unseat her made the White House accelerate its search for a new E.P.A. chief.

title: BANKS SPEAK LOUDLY, CARRY A BIG STICK
description: The efforts of banks, savings and loans associations and credit unions to win repeal of 1982's legislation requiring withholding of taxes on interest and dividends amount to a classic case of lobbying, and then some.

title: SKILLMAN SCHOOL: A PROJECT FOR HOPE
description: IN A classroom workshop at the modern, but modest, Training School for Boys here, a young teen-ager pounds diligently on a piece of wood, carving his name next to a girl's.

title: VOLUNTEERS VISIT JUVENILE CENTERS
description: Cautiously, the well-cared-for station wagon made its way along the burnt-out streets of Brooklyn's Bushwick section, where two of the few marquees remaining over shuttered movie theaters proclaimed, ''Jesus Is the Answer.''

description: In percent Passbook Savings 6.50 At savings institutions Tax-Exempt Bonds 9.15 Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index 6-Month Savings Certificates 9.00 Maximum rate at savings instituions Money Market Funds 7.80 Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Average Home Mortgage 13.59 Federal Home Loan Bank, national average Unsecured Personal Loans Minimum rate, 3-year maturity Chase Manhattan, New York 17.25 Continental Illinois, Chicago 17.00 Bank of America, San Francisco 19.00

title: Accuser Indicted In Donovan Case
description: There was ''insufficient credible evidence'' to indict Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan on racket-related charges last year, and now it seems that a New York businessman was insufficiently credible as a source. The businessman, Michael Klepfer, was indicted last week on perjury charges stemming from the investigation of Mr. Donovan.

title: No Headline
description: EL SALVADOR WEIGHING PLAN TO OFFER LIMITED AMNESTY TO GUERILLAS

title: Headliners; East Meets Northwest
description: He claims 27 Rolls-Royces, 300,000 followers worldwide, 800 on an Oregon ranch of 64,000 acres, control of the nearby town of Antelope and investments in a residential hotel, a bakery and a nightclub in Portland.

title: No Headline
description: The most important lesson of Fox Butterfield's article on Vietnam is that the situation was not ''black and white.''

title: Reagan Assails Rivals' Budget
description: President Reagan said today that the Democrats' budget proposal would halt the progress he says his Administration has made and would ''wreck our economy.'' He said in his weekly radio speech that Medicare, the Federal health care program for the elderly, ''would be driven into bankruptcy'' under the Democratic proposal.

title:
ABROAD AT HOME;
MR. SCHULTZ'S MOVE
description: The Reagan Ad- ministration's Middle East policy has arrived at the moment of truth. Officials know that after the anticlimactic outcome of an event in which they had invested much time and hope: the visit to Washington by Israel's Foreign Minister, Yitzhak Shamir.

title: DWINDLING JOB MARKET ALARMS GRADUATES IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Anxiety about getting and keeping jobs pervades the graduating classes of the colleges and professional schools in the New York metropolitan area this year, according to placement counselors and students. Many labor officials and job recruiters say the anxiety is well founded.

title: Carol McCleary, Gregory Keating Will Be Married
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jack Eugene McCleary of Hidden Hills, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Anne McCleary, to Gregory Cornelius Keating, son of Cornelius F. Keating of New Canaan, Conn., and Elizabeth Ball of Amherst, Mass. An August wedding is planned in Pacific Palisades, Calif.

title: Yonkers Library Is Recommended
description: I was distressed to read in this section (March 6) that Sarah Lawrence College would present a program on ''Women's History Week'' at the White Plains Library.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Nkomo Backers Accused Of 4 Zimbabwe Killings

title: SALLIE MAE AT 10-PROFITABLE AND COMPETITIVE
description: ALMOST one-third of all students and their parents, who are in debt f or college education, now have a single, somewhat benevolent, c reditor named Sallie Mae. The Student Loan Marketing Assocation, w hich begins its 10th year this May, has grown into a $7 billion o rganization, but it is still relatively unknown to those who b enefit from its programs.

title: Eileen Gibney Is Wed To an Opthalmologist
description: Eileen Denise Gibney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard X. Gibney of River Edge, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Bruce A. Karmel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Karmel of Valley Stream, L.I.

title: MRS. O'ROURKE BUSY ON COOKBOOK
description: THE phone rings incessantly, but Alice Theresa McKenna O'Rourke is reluctant to take it off the hook. ''You owe it to the people who elected you,'' the wife of County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said, ''to remain accessible.''

title: Old Dominion Women Beat St. John's, 86-63
description: Helen Malone, a senior guard, scored 13 of her 25 points in a 21-6 spree early in the second half that broke the game open and carried Old Dominion an 86-63 victory tonight over St. John's in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I women's East Region quarterfinals.

title: Sprinkler Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: First Ladies' Collection
description: Fashion and history are mingled at the Museum of our National Heritage in Lexington, Mass., where an exhibition called ''First Lady Gowns,'' consisting of gowns worn by the wives of Presidents, will be on display through Aug. 28.

title: NO HOOTS, FEW HOLLERS ON STRUCK LINES
description: This side of the air traffic controllers walkout, transportation strikes have rarely seemed as unpopular and ineffective as those against two major commuter rail systems serving New York City. As the strike against N.J. Transit enters its fourth week and the strike against Metro-North enters its third, the work stoppages have managed to annoy 160,000 commuters, to arouse their antipathy, but not to seriously disrupt them.

title: HERS SINCERELY, HARRY S. TRUMAN
description: THIS is an age when public personalities touch private lives through an electronic medium that often seems bent on turning all human events into docudramas. So the discovery of handwritten letters from a President to his wife spanning half a century takes on the poignance of something unrefined, and therefore rare. Almost 1,300 "Dear Bess" missives from Harry S. Truman, formally opened at the Truman Library this month, reveal as much about simple devotions of the heart as about great affairs of state.

title: GREECE MOVES TO CUT POWER OF PROFESSORS
description: The reign of the professors is ending in Greek universities as a result of an educational revolution pressed by the Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou.

title: North Carolina Trounces Madison, 68-49
description: North Carolina, the defending national champion, overcame some erratic play early and pulled away to a comfortable 68-49 victory today over James Madison in the second round of the East Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

title: NORMAN PARKINSON
description: Charlotte Curtis is an associate editor and a columnist for The New York Times. By Charlotte Curtis orman Parkinson is one of the British royal family's favorite photographers. A witty sophisticate who has been taking pictures of Queen Elizabeth II since she was in pinafores, he is a welcome guest at Balmoral, Windsor or wherever the Queen happens to invite him along. (He was not aboard on her recent trip to the West Coast.) When not in her company, or off somewhere with his favorite, her mother, the 69-year-old lensman, known as ''Parks'' to friends throughout the civilized world, may be found in the purlieus of the rich and influential, there to charm and amuse as well as to take pictures.

title: STUDENTS TAKE A STEP BEYOND
description: AS part of his science course at Ardsley High School, Peter Zinman, a 15-year-old sophomore, discusses his project on the development of bacteria in foods with his ''mentor,'' Dr. Richard Lechowich, a microbiologist at the General Foods Research Division in Tarrytown.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: PARTIES need planning and this one was no exception. There were the cardboard shamrocks to cut out and the cake with the emerald buttercream frosting to bake and the recorded jigs and folk tunes to be selected. There was a guest list to make up and invitations to mail.

title: NOW ALCOHOLIC'S FAMILY IS TREATED, TOO
description: In the late 1950's, everyone thought Louise was the very model of a young woman. Despite being the oldest daughter of an alcoholic father, she graduated with honors from high school, married her high school sweetheart, landed a good job as a secretary and quickly worked her way up to executive secretary. She and her younger brother took care of her parents - she acting as confidante to her mother, he ''pulling my father out of bars.'' She left her job finally to have her first child, a daughter.

title:
OPINION;
OF YOUTH, MARINES AND NUCLEAR PERIL
description: FIRST of all - he's too young to be a Marine. Just to illustrate how young he is let me tell you about the bagel. It seems like yesterday, but it must have been a few years ago, when I first left him alone to babysit for his little sister. That Saturday night my husband and I went to the Goodspeed Opera House in Haddam, which is about an hour from our home in Bloomfield. My son said that they would have bagels and cream cheese for dinner.

title: DISTRICT SHARES WRITING PROJECT
description: MONTROSE WHEN public attention focused a few years ago on a reported decline in student writing ability, the Henrik Hudson School District decided to re-examine its approach to teaching writing. The results of its three-year writing project, which will be presented in May at a conference in Albany sponsored by the State Education Department's Bureau of English and Reading Education, were shared earlier this month with more than 200 teachers and administrators during a daylong conference at the high school here.

title: Ecuadorean Currency Devalued by 27 Percent
description: The Government devalued the sucre by 27 percent against all major currencies today and announced other measures to help the country overcome an economic crisis.

title: Buffalo Bill Rides Again
description: Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show is coming back. In honor of the 100th anniversary of the extravaganza that was probably a precursor of the modern rodeo, the entertainment that was first organized by the Indian scout will be re-created in June in the town that bears his name - Cody, Wyo.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Fewer and Possibly Better

title: Oklahoma Will Play Indiana
description: The difference between Knight and Newell is like night and day. The difference between their basketball teams may be far less.

title: TILTING IN ISLIP
description: Plenty of wind sweeps across Edward Bacon Jr.'s property in West Islip, L.I. It fronts on the Great South Bay and has a creek and a canal on two other sides. Why not, he wondered, make use of the wind by putting up a 120-foot-tall windmill to generate electricity? But his neighbors and about 100 local real-estate agents protested strenuously, facing the Islip Zoning Board of Appeals with an increasingly common dilemma: Should the national goal of energy conservation outweigh concerns about property values, safety and esthetics?

title: Title Fight a Draw
description: Colin Jones and Milton McCrory fought to a draw today in a 12-round bout for the vacant World Boxing Council welterweight championship.

title:
OPINION;
TIME FOR EDUCATION 'SUMMIT'
description: THE State of Connecticut is a small glass house where so many of the challenges facing us as a nation can be observed and studied. One such challenge now taking place throughout the country that augurs well for the future of education is the demand for higher academic standards.

title: FOR AFRICANS, A LITTLE HELP FROM U.N. FRIENDS
description: For 30 miles along the Atlantic coast here, a thick belt of conifers, planted atop high dunes with the aid of a United Nations agency, has kept the desert from engulfing fertile depressions where farmers grow manioc, onions, potatoes and melons.

title: Margaret D. Monroe to Wed D.A. Zellinger May 7
description: Mr. and Mrs. Andrew P. Monroe of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Dickinson Monroe, to David A. Zellinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Zellinger of Ballwin, Mo.

title: 3 Spring Casualties
description: Spring training has ended early for at least three other players, although their problems are related to injuries. Joe Sambito, the left-handed reliever for the Houston Astros who missed most of last season after an operation, underwent more surgery yesterday on his left elbow.

title: 23 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY CITY AS VIOLATORS OF SANITARY CODE
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 23 food establishments last week for violations of the health code.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: GOVERNOR KEAN recently issued New Jersey's 46th annual proclamation in support of National Wildlife Week, which begins today. He used the occasion to tell a group of schoolchildren from Colonia that one day they would be responsible for holding natural lands in trust and preserving them - and the wildlife that lives on them - for future generations.

title: DIRECTORS JOIN THE S.E. HINTON FAN CLUB
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Stephen Farber is a freelance writer based in Los Angeles. LOS ANGELES The novelist S.E. (Susan Eloise) Hinton has lived in Tulsa, Okla., for most of her 34 years. But these days she cannot help seeing her home town as a giant movie sound stage. Three of her four books have been filmed in Tulsa in the last year and a half.

title: PROSPERITY OF TEXAS BEGINS TO FADE AS PRICES FOR ITS OIL TREASURE FALL
description: The plunge in world petroleum prices, which promises to speed economic recovery in most other parts of the country, is sending tremors of trepidation through Texas and the rest of the American oil region.

title: FARMERS' MARKETS ON THE INCREASE
description: THERE is nothing finer than fresh-from-the-farm flavor. And if Kathy Teveris is right, there will be three to five more places where consumers can buy fresh produce this summer. There were 20 markets last year.

title: Citibank vs. Kenen
description: To the Business Editor: Professor Kenen's ''A Bailout Plan for the Banks'' (March 6) proposes an International Debt Discount Corporation. Such an idea is based on false premises and would be unworkable.

title: Phyllis Schwartz to Marry J.F. Nessen
description: Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Schwartz of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Phyllis Anne Schwartz, to Joshua Fuld Nessen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice N. Nessen of New York and Weston, Conn.

title: MOSQUE IN CAIRO MARKS ITS 1,000TH YEAR
description: Only a year younger than Cairo itself, Al Azhar Mosque and University held a celebration Friday to mark a thousand years of teaching and devotion to the precepts of the Moslem faith.

title: Catherine Patteson Wed To Christopher Hutchins
description: Catherine Kent Patteson, daughter of Mrs. Edward B. Stellmann Jr., and Jack M. Patteson, both of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Christopher Miller Hutchins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Amos Francis Hutchins Jr. of Ruxton, Md. The Rev. William Baxter performed the ceremony at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church in Owings Mills, Md.

title: EXILE'S RETURN
description: The editor of Howard University's student newspaper returned to her post last week, by invitation of the paper's oversight board.

title: OFFICIAL JERSEY GAZETTEER IS COMPLETED BY U.S.
description: It may not displace the dictionary or telephone directory as a favorite reference source, but the official United States Government listing of New Jersey place names has been released.

title: NEVER UNDERESTIMATE THE POWER OF A PIN
description: The pin, unlike the two other basic tactics - the fork and the Xray - need not force an immediate gain of material to be effective. The pin of a piece to the enemy king, if it cannot be lifted, can produce a long-term immobilization of the opponent's position and thus serve as the key to carrying out a strategy of infiltration.

title: A MOST SPECIAL CARDINAL
description: The story would not be an easy one for the reporter to check out. But the priest who told it insisted that life was full of material beyond simple verification. His account was this: When Pope John Paul II began considering Jean-Marie Lustiger for nomination as Archbishop of Paris, he found the decision extremely difficult and hesitated about it for several weeks. Troubled, the Pope woke frequently during the night, and prayed for assistance and clear vision. Finally, the choice made itself. Divine guidance? the reporter asked, pencil poised. The priest offered no direct reply. ''What you could say,'' he explained, ''was that the Pope needed to come to this decision before God.''

title: BALLET: MAHLER 3D BY HAMBURG GROUP
description: Nothing less than Gustav Mahler's Third Symphony, as ambitious a paean as any to nature and to divine love, was the subject of the Hamburg Ballet's newest American premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Friday night. For the choreographer John Neumeier, it is his greatest and most deserved success in New York to date.

title: Jean H. Bronson to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. Nathaniel R. Bronson 2d of Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Henderson Bronson, to Cameron Frederick Conway, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Conway of Morristown, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: STUDY OF YIDDISH GIVEN NEW SUPPORT IN SOVIET
description: The Soviet Government has been taking unusual steps to encourage the study of Yiddish, according to Western specialists who observe Jewish cultural trends in the Soviet Union.

title: THREE FOR LUNCH
description: WE have noted and readers have commented on the fact that many restaurants that serve perfectly acceptable food at night seem to give their luncheon trade short shrift.

title: STUDENTS GET GUIDE TO 'REAL WORLD'
description: HACKETTSTOWN KEVIN MELLIFONT has no complaints about the classical education he received at St. John's University in Queens, but there have been times when he would have liked a little guidance into the ''real world'' of business.

title: A GARDEN OF TILES
description: IN 1976 Brenda Bertin, who was then working as an editor of science books, accompanied her engineer husband, Georges, to Iran, where he had been transferred to work for two years. She expected their stay in Isfahan, an art center, to be interesting, but never dreamed that it would have so profound an effect on her career.

title: OPERA: THREE WORKS AT MANHATTAN MUSIC SCHOOL
description: New York's operatic life is rich not just because of its two major professional companies, but also because of the extraordinary variety offered by the smaller companies and those affiliated with the city's conservatories of music. The John Brownlee Opera Theater at the Manhattan School of Music has proven one of the most fecund sources for lively, exotic opera productions, and this week the school is offering a more lively and exotic bill than usual.

title: List Delegates' '84 Preference On Ballot, G.O.P. Chief Asks
description: George L. Clark Jr., the Republican state chairman, is backing New York legislation that would require the Presidential preference of Republican convention delegate chadidates to be shown on voting machines in next year's Presidential primary.

title: Eastern Airlines Union Rejects Contract Offer
description: Eastern Airlines' largest union rejected what the airline had called its ''final'' contract offer by a margin of almost 4 to 1, labor leaders said today.

title: Even New Dawns Have Gray Areas
description: Economists are perpetual worriers. But then it seems they always have something to worry about. Now that recovery from back-to-back serious recessions is indisputably here, their concern is how robust it will be.

title: American Music
description: To the Editor:

title: School Scandal
description: Community School Board 3 on Manhattan's Upper West Side was shaken in February 1982 by charges that its chairman, Jerry Evans, had misused board funds for personal limousines, liquor and petty cash. Some $1,000 was believed to be missing.

title: FURNITURE MOVES TO CENTER STAGE
description: GREENWICH THE Elements Gallery here is looking more like a furniture showroom than a crafts gallery these days. The glassware, jewelry, pottery and textiles that usually predominate are playing second fiddle to the tables, chairs, desks, cabinets, standing mirrors and music stands included in ''American Furniture Makers,'' an exhibition that runs through March 26. It presents the work of 24 woodworkers who have achieved recognition with their original designs.

title: 4 Killed in Ft. Dix Blast Are Identified by Army
description: Army officials have identified the four soldiers killed in the explosion Thursday on a demolition range at Fort Dix, N.J. The explosion, which occurred as the men were preparing to destroy defective munitions in a remote section of the base, also injured two other soldiers and scattered unexploded detonators from artillery and mortar shells over a wide area.

title: The Talk of North Little Rock
description: Several years ago, residents say, this city got fed up with being called Dog Town. So the Chamber of Commerce decided to give the humiliating nickname a proper funeral. To make it official, they purchased, at great expense, a marble tombstone, declaring, ''Here Lies Dog Town.''

title: A NEW SETTING AT RUTGERS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK LAST year, the State Museum in Trenton took its collection out of the closet and installed it in new premises slotted into the building for the occasion.

title: SATIRIST WITH A CAMERA
description: The British film director Lindsay Anderson has long made a hobby of collecting newspaper clippings, and several years ago he came across an article that would inspire his critically-acclaimed new film, ''Britannia Hospital.'' The article concerned a demonstration, staged to protest the admittance of private patients to Charing Cross Hospital, and it caused a surrealistic image to flash aross the director's mind. He knew, instantly, he had a movie.

title: OLSON PRODUCES FOR HARVARD
description: The hero of the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Association Division I hockey playoffs last week spent the 1980-81 season trudging through the rain forests of South America, picking exotic plants and soaking them in formaldehyde. It's a story that could only happen at Harvard.

title: ON THE PARTICULAR PLEASURE OF SEEING A LEGENDARY FLOP
description: Like everyone who caught the theater bug at an early age, I always made a point of saving Playbills. Not just my Playbills, mind you, but the entire world's: between a matinee and evening performance during adolescence, I would skip dinner in order to tour Times Square garbage cans and scoop up the programs of all the plays I had not seen. People who share this affliction surely know how near and dear those Playbills become as the years pass by. That's why we weep unabashedly over the scene in Moss Hart's memoir ''Act One'' in which the author's angry father torments his elderly, theater-loving aunt into ''dropping her beloved programs from trembling hands all over the floor.'' It's as if Hart's father had sacked a holy shrine.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO KEEP SCHOOL IN PANAMA
description: The United States wants to continue training Latin American soldiers at its School of the Americas here, despite a clause in the 1978 Panama Canal treaty that says the school must close next year.

title: HONORING AN INSPIRATIONAL HISTORIAN
description: When a work of architectural history appears with the name of Henry-Russell Hitchcock on its cover, there is much excitement in the scholarly community but relatively little surprise, for since 1927 Mr. Hitchcock has written or co-authored 25 books, virtually all of them what he himself might, with justified immodesty, call ''standard works.'' For more than half a century this flamboyant, bearded presence has been one of America's most energetic and prolific architectural scholars, producing books and essays on subjects as distinct as the German Renaissance, Victorian architecture and Frank Lloyd Wright.

title: MURDER
description: To the Editor:

title: SPRINGTIME IN THE HILL TOWNS OF THE APPALACHIANS
description: JOHN ED PEARCE is a writer with the magazine of The Courier-Journal in Louisville. By JOHN ED PEARCE

title: CROP PAYMENT PLAN IS DRAWING GOOD RESPONSE
description: Participation in the new payment-in-kind plan for farmers, the Government's last chance to reduce costly surpluses of grains and cotton this year, now appears to be greater than the Reagan Administration had hoped.

title: TRADITION IN A CONTEMPORARY VEIN
description: JUST as early-spring flowers begin to pop up here and there, works by a fresh generation of artists are being featured this month. And although ''Young Emerging Talent'' at the Sheila Nussbaum Gallery in Millburn is distinctly different from ''The Tallit as Sculpture'' at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Metropolitan New Jersey in West Orange, both demonstrate respect for tradition - either cultural or religious - as a support for a contemporary viewpoint.

title: Matthew Hale, Lawyer For Senate Committee
description: Matthew Hale, chief counsel to the Senate Banking Committee from 1955 to 1967, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in Westport, N.Y. He was 73 years old.

title: Remembering the Party Of Vic Materne
description: I was interested in the article ''The One-Woman Welcome Wagon'' (Opinion Page, Feb. 27) recalling the early days in the town of Mount Pleasant by Virginia Franklin . But she made one major error in her reminiscences when she wrote: ''A Democrat by virtue of her Brooklyn rearing, she gravitated naturally on arrival to her new town's Democratic Supervisor, Vic Materne; nor was she a whit less devoted after Mr. Materne was caught in some sloppiness about the tax money and sent off to Sing Sing for a spell.'' In fact, Mr. Materne was a Republican, not a Democrat.

title: Can a Lease Be Inherited?
description: Question: My aunt died a year ago. In her will she left me, her only surviving heir, all her assets. She lived in a rent-stabilized apartment in New York City for 20 years. Is it true that her lease becomes an asset of the estate and can be assigned by the estate to me with the landlord's approval? If the landlord does not accept me, can I ask that the lease be assigned to someone else? ... A.L., Glen Cove, L.I. Answer: The New York Estate Powers and Trusts Laws, Section 13-1.a, says a lease is an asset of the estate. Section 236 of the Real Property Law gives an estate the right to assign the lease with the landlord's consent. The law gives the landlord 10 days to ask for additional information about the tenant.

title: THE TRAVAILS OF OFF-PEAK TRAVELERS
description: THE special bus service and other alternative travel plans set up to accommodate the 90,000 commuters from the county and southwestern Connecticut during the strike against the Metro-North Commuter Line have been geared toward the typical 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. commuter, who lives in the suburbs and works in the city. But reverse commuters and those who commute during off-peak hours have been experiencing more problems getting to and from work.

title: HANG HEAVY PICTURES AND MIRRORS WITH AN EYE TO SAFETY
description: ALTHOUGH an ordinary hammer-in type picture hanger - the kind with a nail that goes through the top of a hook and then into the plaster or wallboard at a downward angle - may be adequate for hanging a small mirror, and many medium to large size pictures, these hangers are not really suitable for a large wall mirror or a sizable painting with a really heavy frame. These picture hangers depend for their holding power on the ''tear strength'' or ''crack resistance'' of the plaster or wallboard into which the nail is driven, and this cannot be relied upon to support heavy loads.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: CONVERSATIONS WITH ARRAU By Joseph Horowitz 317 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: If Rocks Came From the Moon And Mars, How?
description: After several years of laboratory tests, scientists last week confirmed that a meteorite found in the Antarctic in 1982 is a piece of the Moon. For the first time, scientists had pinpointed a meteorite's place of origin. That, however, left astronomers with a daunting challenge - explaining how the meteorite got here.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: TOUCHSTONES Letters Between Two Women, 1953-1964. By Patricia Frazer Lamb and Kathryn Joyce Hohlwein. 330 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $14.95.

title: Data Update
description: *4*VALUE OF CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTS *4*(Residential, in millions of dollars) January January 1982 Change New York 208.1 81.7 + 154% New Jersey 140.2 59.6 + 135% Connecticut 51.0 59.6 + 120% *4*Source: F.W.
