title: No Headline
description: As counsel to the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on security commitments in 1969-70, I read Fox Butterfield's article with interest. He quotes Col. Harry G. Summers's reference to a plan to send American forces across the DMZ and Laos to cut the North Vietnamese infiltration routes.

title: FOREIGN STOCKS MAY SHINE TOO
description: NOW is the time for investors to slice off some of their profits f rom Wall Street and invest abroad, say portfolio managers of mutual f unds that specialize in overseas markets. Japanese, Dutch and West G erman stocks have moved up and may be at the start of a prolonged b ull market. Even Australia and Spain, after being shunned by foreigni nvestors, are favorites of some top money men.

title: REORIENTATION; Empty Term of Art
description: People used to say ''new and improved'' ...''the latest thing in'' ...''up to the minute.''

title: NOT THAT GREAT A WALL
description: To the Editor:

title: STANFORD RIGHTS CLASS DROPPED AFTER BLACK PROTEST
description: Protests by black students at Stanford University have led to cancellation of a course on racial discrimination and civil rights that would have been taught by two leading civil rights lawyers.

title: 'SLIVER' OWNERS CRY FOUL
description: OWNERS of potentially profitable narrow ''sliver'' apartment b uildings in Manhattan whose construction was banned last week d escribed the city's action as financially ''disastrous'' and ' 'catastrophic'' for them.

title: ROOM FOR IMPROVEMENT
description: WASHINGTON Afrantic search for a cleaner than clean environmental administrator, an abrupt decision to let a trusted national security lieutenant return to private industry, charges that top White House officials have been less than scrupulous about their outside financial dealings - these and other woes last week raised the question of whether President Reagan has had more than usual difficulty with his appointments.

title: WHO SHOT LORD ERROLL?
description: WHITE MISCHIEF, By James Fox. Illustrated. 299 pp. New York: Random House. $15.95.

title: SENATE RULES RIPE FOR BENDING
description: It was a tense moment during the Senate debate of the $5.2 emergency jobs bill that passed last week, 81 to 16. After proposing a rider repealinng last year's tax withholding on dividends and interest, Senator Rober W. Kasten Jr., a first-term Republican from Wisconsin, signaled he might use an unusual parliamentary maneuver to force a vote on his amendment. Majority leader Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee rose in a fury. If the senators manipulated their own rules, he warned, "this place will be a jungle."

title: ROBERT ANDERSON PLAY
description: Long Wharf's Stage II, the lower priced quasi-experimental theater slightly to the left of Long Wharf's Stage I on Sargent Drive, New Haven, will offer a second new play by an established American playwright this season when ''Free and Clear'' by Robert Anderson opens at 8:15 P.M. March 30. Nightly previews begin Tuesday.

title: WINTER'S LAST WET GASP BRINGS RECORD AND FLOOD
description: The last storm of winter in the New York metropolitan area churned out to sea yesterday, leaving behind a record rain in the city, minor flooding in Connecticut, New Jersey and Westchester County, and a heavy runoff that raised low water levels in upstate reservoirs.

title: COMPROMISE PROPOSED IN CHRISTO ISLAND-WRAP
description: Under a compromise proposed Friday, a conservation group would monitor an attempt by Christo to cover 11 islands in Biscayne Bay with pink plastic.

title: EL SALVADOR, AFTER AIMBABWE AND VIETNAM
description: In the halls of Congress, no less than in the hills of Central America, the struggle over El Salvador's future has reached a dangerous and costly standoff. The Administration seems without a strategy - beyond its hope that more military aid and a few more advisers can reverse the situation. Congressional critics, unconvinced of the propriety or the prospects of escalating our involvement, appear strong enough to deny President Reagan a free hand but lack the power to impose an alternative policy. To break the logjam, there are calls for negotiations. But what kind of negotiations? About what kind of settlement?

title:
GARDENING;
ORIGINS OF OUR FRUITS AND VEGETABLES
description: EARLY man is thought to have been nomadic, wandering from place to place in search of food and living in makeshift shelters. When the discovery was made that discarded grain would grow to produce more grain and that certain animals could be tamed and managed to his benefit, man settled in permanent dwellings and became a farmer.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE ouster of John T. Gregorio of Linden from the State Senate cuts the Democratic margin there to 20 votes, one shy of the number needed for passage of legislation. As a result, the Democrats will have to turn to the Republicans, who control 19 votes in the 40-member chamber, to have anything of a controversial nature adopted. Or they can wait until new elections are held in Mr. Gregorio's 20th Legislative District, which includes parts of Middlesex and Union Counties. Once a vacancy has been declared by the Senate, an election to fill the seat must be held within 37 to 45 days.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Mets, exhibition at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 1:30 P.M. Rick Ownbey will start for the Mets. The Yankees are undecided on their starter. (Television - Channel 11, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 1:15 P.M. and WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.). Basketball Nets vs. Bucks at Milwaukee, 8:30 P.M. The last time the clubs played, Sidney Moncrief scored 31 points and Bob Lanier won the game on a jumper in the final seconds. The Nets lead the series, 2-1. (Television -Channel 9, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WVNJ 620, 8:30 P.M.).

title: THE CORPORATE TAX: UNEVEN, UNFAIR?
description: IT started off as a Congressional battle about a new withholding law that has the banking industry in a froth. But the debate last week - with its stunning revelations about the low tax rates banks pay - quickly revived a larger argument about the unevenness and unfairness of the Federal corporate income tax.

title: TALKS ON BASES IN GREECE RESUME AS TENSIONS RISE
description: Amid tension between Greece and the United States, talks on the future of American bases have resumed after a week's pause.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLANDERS
description: THEY form a small city or a large army - 25,000 Long Island children who will be among the 30,000 boys and girls attending day camps on the Island next summer.

title: PUTTING LIFE INTO 'LIVE FROM THE MET'
description: This Wednesday's ''Live From the Met'' presentation of Richard Wagner's ''Tannhauser,'' on WNET/Channel 13 at 8 P.M., carries a familiar credit. The director is Brian Large. The number of people skilled in directing opera for television is extraordinarily limited. The field is dominated by two men: this country's Kirk Browning, and England's Mr. Large, who works at least 40 hectic weeks a year shuttling between such major opera institutions as London's Covent Garden, Milan's La Scala and New York's Metropolitan. He is already completely booked for television projects through 1986.

title: THE SHAPE OF ITS FUTURE SPLITS EAST VILLAGE
description: from Third Avenue to Tompkins Square Park. Yet t he street reflects the many differences - some subtle, some glaring - within the community it bisects, the area commonly known as the E ast Village.

title: RID CHAPTER OPENS
description: CONCURRENT with the county's campaign against driving while intoxicated, another effort has been started toward the same goal. The first Westchester chapter of RID, Remove Intoxicated Drivers, has gone into operation, joining about 29 others in the state and 130 nationwide.

title: BILL SEEKS CHANGE IN GRANTING AWARDS FOR HYPERTENSION
description: IT has become one of the annual legislative rituals at the State Capitol in Hartford. A parade of police officers and firefighters, many of them in full-dress uniform, pile out of cars and buses and fill the Hall of the House to protest attempts to change the statutes on heart disease and hypertension awards.

title: APOLOGY TO U.N. DELEGATE IS ORDERED OVER HECKLING AT BERKELEY
description: The Regents of the University of California have ordered that a letter of apology be sent to Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations over an incident at the Berkeley campus.

title: Stuck by A Sliver
description: Five East Side developers who prided themselves on their narrow vision got stung last week. New York City officials ordered them to abort construction of tall, slim apartment houses known as ''slivers.''

title: RIPLES FROM REYNOLDS CHANNEL
description: DOTTED with swamps with ''Neverland'' names like Parsonage Island and Ingraham Hassock, Scow Island and West Crow, it runs off into Sea Dog Creek and Cinder Creek, and if one studies the United States Coast Guard Nautical Chart, it's easy to envision Captain Kidd burying his treasure not far from the waterway known as Reynolds Channel.

title: No Headline
description: Fox Butterfield is to be commended for presenting new information on the extremely important questions of ''America's longest war,'' in the apt phrase of George Herring. But I urge more attention to the history of the Vietnamese themselves in drawing conclusions to those questions.

title: New Pocket Books Editor
description: William R. Grose, editor in chief of New American Library, has been named editorial director of Pocket Books, a division of Simon & Schuster. Marty Asher, Pocket Books' current editor in chief, will become head of the company's new trade paperback imprint.

title: MT. KISCO AND CITY: FOREVER NEVERMORE
description: FOR 75 years, the village of Mount Kisco has thought of itself as ''the country bumpkin that took the city,'' according to John Crary, the Village Manager. The reason, he explained, involved a 1908 agreement with New York City in which the city promised to treat village sewage ''forever'' in exchange for 135 acres of apparently useless land.

title:
ART;
A COMMERCIAL ARTIST WHO REVELS IN DREAMS
description: Sarah Moon is a French fashion photographer far better known in Europe than in America. For more than a decade, her work has regularly appeared in British, French and Italian magazines, and on calendars and other advertiser giveaways that have become collector's items. A few of her photographs have been seen here in group shows and photography exhibitions. But the current exhibition of 80 prints at the International Center of Photography, Fifth Avenue at 94th Street, through April 3, is her first major showing in this country, and it is welcome, for Sarah Moon is one of the truly original visionary artists of our time.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATICS STALL CONECTICUT TAX PROPOSALS
description: Legislative leaders suffered a sharp setback this week when Democratic Representatives balked at passing the first installment of higher state taxes to erase part of Connecticut's deficit.

title: Miss Wasserman Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Louis Wasserman of North Bellmore, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Joanne Gail Wasserman, to Glenn Stuart Ethe, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Ethe of Wantaugh, L.I. A fall wedding is planned. The bride-to-be is an assistant portfolio manager at Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins, and her fiance is a certified public accountant with M.F. Weiser & Company, both in New York.

title: THE IRISH ON PARADE CAN'T CLOSE THE RANKS
description: When Michael Flannery was elected grand marshal of this year's St. Patrick's Day Parade, he brought with him a determination to celebrate, if not spread the violent views that once led to his imprisonment by the British in Ireland. That he celebrated them in his courtly march up Fifth Avenue last week was obvious; that he spread them was uncertain; but that he made a nation pause to ponder them was unquestionable.

title: BASEBALL 'SUPERSTAR' IN ANOTHER SENSE
description: IN a day and age when all too many college ''superstar'' athletes are graduating as semieducated multimillionaires, the case of Bob Ryder of New Rochelle stands out.

title: OVERTURES MADE TO RUCKELSHAUS TO HEAD E.P.A.
description: William D. Ruckelshaus, who served as the first Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has been asked to return to the post and help ease the agency's crisis, White House officials said today.

title: No Headline
description: The gist of the ''new scholarship'' seems to be that the war could have been won if the United States had been more ruthless and more determined. Yet at the same time, apparently the only purpose behind the war among Presidents from Kennedy to Nixon was to avoid the political embarrassment of withdrawal. Does it not shock any of the new scholars that 57,000 Americans and several million Vietnamese, Laotians and Cambodians should have died for so trivial a goal?

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: Housing starts, showing unexpected strength, rose 2.9 percent last month to an annual rate of 1.76 million units. It was the fastest pace for home building since 1979 - but one that's not likely to last. Economists expect new-home starts to slow to around 1.5 million for the year. And Henry Kaufman, the Salomon Brothers guru, warns that recent sharp gains in home prices - the median price jumped to $75,500 in January - could soon offset falling mortgage rates and threaten housing's comeback.

title: SUNDAY, MARCH 20, 1983
description: International France took a tough stand on European currency valuation and warned that it was prepared to withdraw from the Common Market's monetary system unless the finance ministers agreed to redefine the value of their currencies to its satisfaction. Under the currency system, 8 of the 10 Common Market countries maintain fixed exchange rates between their currencies. France made its threat in Brussels, where the Common Market countries are meeting to deal with a currency crisis that threatens to demolish their old fixed-rate system. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: Albany Rejoices In New Harmony And Early Budget
description: Governor Cuomo passed the first major test of his leadership last week. He and leaders of the legislature agreed on a 1983-84 budget that would keep layoffs down and the state's credit rating up - and might even be signed by the April 1 deadline for the first time in three years.

title: SELLING AMERICA IN THE MARKETPLACE OF IDEAS
description: Alarmed by Soviet leader Yuri Andropov's peace offensive in Europe, President Reagan recently established a Cabinet-level group under the chairman-ship of the national security adviser William P. Clark to ''coordinate . . . national security public affairs matters of Presidential interest.'' He also called home our Ambassador to Ireland, Peter H. Dailey, his 1980 campaign advertising manager, to help firm up European support for the deployment of the Pershing 2 and cruise missiles.

title: Carolyn Witsell Eaton, Law Student, To Be Wed to Hugh Gibbs Taylor Jr.
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Mellon Eaton of New York and Sugar Hill, N.H., of the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Witsell Eaton, to Hugh Gibbs Taylor Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Taylor of Cundys Harbor, Me. An August wedding is planned.

title: A BIG WEEK FOR CONCERTS
description: THIS is shaping up as a big week for big concerts, with four of the major Connecticut orchestras and three large choirs in action. Let's start in the vocal department with this afternoon's performance at the State University of New York's Purchase Arts Center by the Greenwich Choral Society. At 4 P.M., the 130-voice choir under Richard Vogt will sing Bach's ''St. John Passion,'' with orchestra and six fine soloists: Stephen Oosting, David Evitts, Bruce Kramer, Elaine Linstedt, Elaine Bonazzi and John LaPierre.

title: LESSONS FROM THE SISKIYOU FOREST
description: THE KLAMATH KNOT Explorations of Myth and Evolution. By David Rains Wallace. Illustrations by Karin Wikstrom. 149 pp. San Francisco: Yolla Bolly Press/Sierra Club Books. $14.95.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
A GUARENTEE FOR LONG-TERM TROUBLE
description: CURRENT proposals to amend the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act containa certain enticing deception. While they appear to offer some i mmediate economic benefits, those benefits are at best limited and t emporary. But in the long run, an amended act would inflict s ubstantial economic and social costs to our nation and its business c ommunity. This is not a good trade.

title: The New Vietnam Scholarship
description: I found Fox Butterfield's article on ''The New Vietnam Scholarship'' (Feb. 13) both interesting and distressing -distressing because much of this scholarship seems more concerned with disproving myths and illusions of one part of the antiwar movement than with asking itself whether the war could have been won under any circumstances acceptable to the American public and in any way compatible with other, more vital, American interests abroad. Distressing also because his own reporting of some of these new views appears uncritical.

title: Mimi Hazen to Wed in May
description: The engagement of Mimi Suzanne Hazen, daughter of Mrs. Anthony Joseph Paen Jr. of Rye, N.Y., and Maynard Doran Hazen of Bal Harbour, Fla., to Kevin Francis Burke, has been announced by her parents. Mr. Burke is a son of Ellen Kelley Peters of Scituate, Mass., and Charles Joseph Burke Jr. of Newton, Mass. A May wedding is planned. Miss Hazen is an assistant treasurer with the cash management sales and consulting group of the Bankers Trust Company in New York, where Mr. Burke is a vice president in the world corporate department.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: APRIL will be moving month for the National Theater of the Deaf, as it leaves the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford for the rural town of Chester on the Connecticut River. The Theater of the Deaf has signed an agreement to buy a 100-year-old former factory building, most recently used as a Masonic Hall, on West Main Street in Chester.

title: Tory Brieant, M.L. Dunaif Are to Marry
description: Judge and Mrs. Charles L. Brieant of Ossining, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Victoria Elisabeth Brieant, to Matthew Leland Dunaif, son of Dr. Nancy Peters Dunaif, also of Ossining, and the late Dr. Samuel L. Dunaif.

title: DAUNTLESS RESTORER RESCUING 'LAST SUPPER'
description: With scalpel in hand and her eyes glued to a microscope, Pinin Brambilla Barcilon pursues what must be the longest-lasting and perhaps the most delicate operation ever carried out on a priceless treasure. Mrs. Brambilla has been saving what can be saved of Leonardo da Vinci's ''Last Supper'' for six years.

title: IN VENEZUELA, GOOD TIMES ARE GOING
description: ''La fiesta ha terminado.'' Among Venezuelans, from cab drivers to men of letters, field hands to presidential candidates, this saying, ''The party's over,'' is the most repeated in Venezuela today.

title: Ellen Anikstein Plans To Be Married in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Anikstein of Schenectady, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen M. Anikstein, to Frederic H. Baumgarten, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Baumgarten of New York and Palm Beach, Fla.

title:
MUSIC;
A LYRIC SOPRANO VENTURES INTO HEAVIER FARE
RIFTS STIR LLOYD HARBOR
description: IT'S such a lovely place, the Village of Lloyd Harbor, all gracious homes on minimum two-acre lots, a sprinkling of mansions, an abundance of North Shore waterfront and tranquillity enhanced by the presence of a village police station at the mouth of the single road in and out.

title: PAINFUL REALITIES FOR THE GAS INDUSTRY
description: The gas industry's underlying attitude toward deregulation appears somewhat akin to that of St. Augustine toward sin: an urgent conviction to give up sinful regulation - but ''not yet, oh Lord, not just yet.''

title: DR. CLARK'S HEART: A STORY OF MODERN MARKETING AS WELL AS MODERN MEDICINE
description: The world's first permanent artificial heart, a pioneering medical achievement that has extended the life of Dr. Barney B. Clark, has also proved to be a powerful financial magnet. Thus far, the plastic heart has brought in a total of nearly $6 million.

title: ASSEMBLY VOTES TO CONTINUE INTEREST DEREGULATION
description: The State Assembly has approved a bill that would keep the ceiling off interest rates on consumer loans in New York State for the next four years.

title: Cleansing Agents
description: With a modest bow to George Orwell, it was a bright cold day in March, and the clocks were striking thirteen. Employees at the White House, State Department, Defense Department, Justice Department and other Federal ministries were preparing their letters to the editor, speeches, book reviews, scholarly papers and whatnot for ''prepublication review.''

title: Marriage Finances
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''What's New With Dual-Income Couples,'' (March 6), I would like to support the statements that both partners feel better when financial decisions are made jointly and both partners have control over some money. Also, many more women than men will ultimately be responsible for managing their money alone, and the skills and expertise women acquire while married can only have a very positive payoff later. Too many widows and divorcees who were not included in managing their family's finances have suffered monetary losses and personal stress as a result. CYNTHIA BAILEY Chase Manhattan Bank New York, March 7

title: Topics; Reorientation; Mr. Yesterday
description: What was the cause of youth unrest in the 1960's? ''Look into a mirror,'' Eldridge Cleaver wrote in ''Soul on Ice,'' his famous book of prison essays. ''The cause is you, Mr. and Mrs. Yesterday, you with your forked tongues.''
To the Editor:

title: AN EARLY END TO SOME TOLLS IS HAILED
description: HARTFORD THE toll plaza on the Connecticut Turnpike at Stratford, which had been the scene of a tragic accident and a protest rally against turnpike tolls earlier this year, attracted something different last Monday night.

title: GLENCAIRN' MEDIEVAL TREASURE
description: SIDNEY C. LIPPMAN is a journalist based in Washington. BY SIDNEY C.LIPPMAN

title: POINTERS FOR WOULD-BE PHOTO CONTEST WINNERS
description: Photographic technology has come a long way in the past few years, and as lenses, cameras, and films have improved, so have the picture-taking skills of most people. The result is that many have accumulated large quantities of photographs -many of surprisingly good quality.

title: KENTUCKY AND ARKANSAS ARE WINNERS
description: Melvin Turpin and Dirk Minniefield sparked a second-half spurt that gave Kentucky a 12-point lead and carried it past Ohio University, 57-40, in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Mideast Regional today.

title: WHERE'S YOUR REAL HOME?
description: Y YOU can lose your rent-controlled or rent-stabilized apartment in N ew York City if you have another home. The city's rent laws were w ritten to protect tenants who make their permanent residence in an a partment here, not those who keep a pied a terre in the city for v isits and live most of the year on a farm in Litchfield, Conn. Nor a re the laws designed to protect city dwellers planning to make w indfall profits by renting - then subleasing - several apartments ina nticipation of the day the apartments are converted to c ooperatives. The key determinant is whether the apartment is your p rimary residence.

title: Elizabeth Hilder To Wed Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frazer Frost Hilder of Longboat Key, Fla., and Birmingham, Mich., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Rose Hilder, to W. Randolph Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Sammons Smith Jr. of Hot Springs, Ark.

title: City College Captures Title in CUNY Track
description: Terry Samuel swept the 600-meter run and the 800-meter run to lead City College of New York to the men's team title in the City University of New York's track and field championships yesterday at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn.

title: Conservative Publisher Slain in Athens Office
description: A prominent Greek newspaperman, Tzortzis Athanasiades, publisher of the conservative daily Vradyni and president of the Union of Greek Publishers, was shot and killed in his office today.

title: Cousineau Apologizes
description: Tom Cousineau, linebacker with the Cleveland Browns, has told team officials he regrets causing an embarrassing situation by being arrested while driving under the influence of alcohol.

title: BY JOHN B. FORBES
description: ON Wednesday afternoon 20 young hockey players, their coaches and a group of supporting parents will board a plane at La Guardia Airport for a trip to St. Louis and the chance to win a national championship.

title: STRAIGHT TALK WITH THE RUSSIANS
description: CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, the chief of the Peking bureau of The Times, was a correspondent in Moscow from 1973 to 1977. By CHRISTOPHER S.WREN

title: REORIENTATION; Tall Wall Tale
description: Writing about China the other day, we innocently repeated what turns out to be an old savant's tale - that the Great Wall is the only mortal structure visible from the moon.

title: Elizabeth Ann Prescott Weds E.B. Batchelder
description: Elizabeth Ann Prescott, daughter of Mrs. Rodney W. Preston of Beverly, Mass., and the late Gilbert A. Prescott, was married yesterday to Edward B. Batchelder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel L. Batchelder of Beverly Farms, Mass. The Rev. James C. Glasser performed the ceremony at the Dane Street Congregational Church in Beverly.

title: RIGHT TO DISTRIBUTE POLITICAL FLIERS IN MALLS UPHELD
description: A Supreme Court justice in Suffolk County has ruled that the right to distribute political leaflets in privately owned shopping centers is protected by the New York State Constitution.

title: OF ARMS AND ARMOR
description: Most of the privately held collections of medieval arms and armor moved a half century ago from the castles of impoverished European aristocrats to museums and the pseudo-palaces of American plutocrats. One that did not - Lord Astor's armory at Hever Castle in Kent, England, the largest and most important privately owned collection in Great Britain - will be sold by Sotheby Parke Bernet in London on May 5 in the first part of a two-day auction at which the bulk of the castle's $3.5 million collection will be dispersed.

title: RELIABILITY AND A TOUCH OF TRIESTE
description: PICCOLA ITALIA in Williston Park is small, comfortable and unpretentious, the type of place that's good to remember for a pleasant dinner if you're in the neighborhood. The menu holds no surprises and, for the most part, the preparation can be described as competent. Some delectable homemade desserts plus a list of wines that may be unique on the Island in its number of Yugoslavian selections are its distinctive features.

title: OLD SCHOONER LINKS PEOPLE OF 2 NATIONS
description: FOURTEEN sailors stood on the deck of the schooner Ernestina as she pulled into the harbor at Newport, R.I. Eight were seasoned Cape Verdean seamen; six, including a New Brunswick chemist, were experienced, but amateur, American sailors.

title: Anne Lovett Will Wed S.G. Woodsum
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lovett of Walpole, Mass., and Holderness, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Robertson Lovett, to Stephen G. Woodsum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold C. Woodsum Jr. of Northbrook, Ill. A July 16 wedding is planned at Squam Lake in Holderness.

title: More Considerations On Volunteering
description: Regarding Evelyn Jackson's article (''One Benefit of Volunteering Can Be a Job,'' Feb. 27): While Miss Jackson's motive in pointing to one particular benefit of volunteering is entirely laudable, we feel, her description of volunteering for job potential must be followed by a discussion of other aspects and other benefits of volunteering. Without such further discourse the reader might come to the conclusion, as Miss Jackson implies in some of her quotations, that, for example, employers in general ''...look at each volunteer as a potential employee''; or that volunteering ''provided more than a job -it gave them fulfillment''; - as if there could be no fulfillment for that volunteer without also getting the job.

title: Susan Truitt to Wed Peter Erik Lundberg
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Truitt of N ew Canaan, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Young Truitt, to Peter Erik Lundberg, son of Dr. and Mrs. Erik Lundberg of Mariestad, Sweden.

title: Military Analysis
description: The NATO commander, Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, says it is ''moral'' to have nuclear weapons to deter their use by the Soviet Union. He says it would be ''immoral'' for a nation not to try to deter a nuclear war.

title: New York Times Magazine; March 20, 1983
description: William Safire 14 On Language Wattle I Do? Russell Baker 24 Sunday Observer Money Bores John Vinocur 28 A Most Special Cardinal Jean-Marie Cardinal Lustiger, though Jewish-born, is much more than an ''ecumenical novelty.'' In terms of doctrine, and of style, he is the Pope's man.

title: No Headline
description: Rogers Leads by 2 Strokes

title: MORE LUXURY?
description: Does Manhattan's Yorkville section need another luxury condominium? A subsidiary of one of Spain's largest developers believes it does, and has just paid $3 million for a 7,000-square-foot parcel on the corner of First Avenue and East 84th Street that will be its site.

title: AFTER A YEAR ON THE JOB, YOUNG IS DOING FINE WITH BOTH ATLANTAS
description: WHEN Andrew Young took office a little more than a year ago as Atlanta's second consecutive black mayor, many white businessmen cringed in anticipation of four more years of what they perceived as an anti-white, anti-business bias at City Hall.

title: AMERICA'S LOVE OF SPORTS: HOW STRONG THE FEELING?
description: THAT sports is a multi-million dollar industry, affecting the daily lives of millions of Americans, comes as no surprise. Each year, the most expensive television commercial appears during the Super Bowl. Local newspapers boost their circulation by enhancing their sports sections, and the popularity of sportscasters can have a substantial impact on local television news ratings. On a personal level, Americans spend vast amounts of their leisure time and energy watching and participating in sports.

title: THE RIGORS OF RUNNING FOR - AND RUNNING - CITY HALL
description: THOUGH Capitol Hill and the White House tend to dominate the limelight, things are hopping in a number of City Halls around the country too. In Chicago, Mayor Jane M. Byrne, who lost in last month's Democratic primary, announced last week that she would mount what she admitted would be an uphill write-in campaign. She had declared that she would back Representative Harold Washington, who defeated her and Richard M. Daley, the Cook County State's Attorney General. But last week, she claimed a kind of higher calling. ''A city is very, very fragile,'' she said. ''To slip back an inch or two inches can be the end of a city. That's why I'm here.'' Critics contended that she was there to make the most of a reported reluctance among some Chicago whites to vote for either Mr. Washington, who would become the city's first black mayor, or for Bernard E. Epton, the Republican candidate.

title: 3-ACT POLI-DRAMA OPENS IN HUDSON
description: JERSEY CITY LIKE Gaul, Hudson County is divided in three parts these days, and the political wars shaping up for the June 7 Democratic primary for state and county offices would make one of Julius Caesar's campaigns look like a picnic.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: All Sorts of Fabrics For Fabrications

title: 'NEXT YEAR,' FRENCH COMEDY
description: Jean-Loup Hubert's ''Next Year If All Goes Well'' is a fragile French comedy about ... well, not about very much at all, which is its chief problem. It concerns a young career woman, Isabelle (Isabelle Adjani), and her lover, a cartoonist named Maxime (Thierry Lhermitte), as they grapple with their ambivalence concerning parenthood and the prospect of marriage. Though their domesticity is amusingly disrupted when Isabelle's parents come to visit, they otherwise seem to be getting along. Then Isabelle decides she wants a baby and Maxime decides he doesn't, and they must settle the issue by quarreling, trying out infidelity and having a lot of heart-toheart talks with their various friends.

title: White House Fends Off a Budget Defeat
description: ''Every time the President has intervened in the (Congressional) budget process, he has been wrong,'' Senator Slade Gorton, declared last week. On purely procedural grounds, many of his colleagues agree the Republican from Washington may have a point. As a matter of politics, however, the White House's moves have generally been timely and effective - as they were last week.

title: AND BEAR IN MIND
description: Other recent books that in the opinion of the Book Review staff are of particular literary, topical or scholarly interest: THE AFRICANS, by David Lamb. (Random House, $17.95.) A study of the continent today.

title: DOMESTIC STORIES
description: THE MOONS OF JUPITER, By Alice Munro. 233 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
ENTRIES INVITED FOR FALL MEDAL EXHIBITION
description: The American Medallic Sculpture Association is now accepting entries for a major exhibition scheduled for this fall at the Upper Manhattan museum of the American Numismatic Society. The exhibition, to run from Oct. 1 through Dec. 3, will coincide with the society's 125th anniversary observance and will be co-sponsored by AMSA and the ANS.

title: Correction
description: In Fashions of The Times (Feb. 27), the earrings on pages 142 and 143 were incorrectly credited. Both pairs of earrings were designed by Ben Amun.

title: COUNTY'S COMPUTER SALES ON RISE
description: FACED with the competitive prices offered by department stores, audio chains and manufacturer's outlets, independent computer dealers in the county are stressing service and are pursuing corporations, small businesses and schools as the market for personal computers continues to thrive.

title:
TELEVSION;
FROM 'SHOGUN' TO 'THE THORN BIRDS'
AUTO INSURANCE: BATTLE LINES FORM IN TRENTON
description: TRENTON NEW JERSEY motorists are No.1 in an unenviable category. With an average yearly premium of $584, they pay the highest automobile-insurance rates in the nation.

title: EAGLE EGGS MOVED IN BREEDING EFFORT
description: DIVIDING CREEK IN A PRIMEVAL swamp forest near Delaware Bay, nature was doing what it was supposed to at this time of year: A chorus of spring peepers echoed loudly, a startled grouse fluttered in the woods and indications of new life stirring were everywhere.

title: POLITICAL GAIN SEEN IN COHALAN STANCE
description: TWO new controversial subjects - the Shoreham nuclear plant and pay increases for civil servants - and an old standby, the Southwest Sewer District, are already shaping up as the chief issues in the election for Suffolk County Executive this year, one of the major elections in the state in an ''off'' year.

title:
ART;
NEW ACQUISITION AT ATHENEUM
description: THE Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford has put on view in its galleries a large and very impressive canvas by Fredric Leighton, one of the most celebrated British painters of the late 19th century.

title: Playing Up the Civilian Side Of Military Aid
description: Finding rough going in its campaign to persuade Congress on more military spending in El Salvador, the Reagan Administration last week switched tactics. Officials stressed benefits for civilians that would flow from its $110 million military aid package. Besides training 7,000 Salvadoran servicemen and equipping them with helicopters and other weapons, American officials said the program would support civic action in the countryside.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
HAY BARN MUSIC
description: The ultimate in recycling has taken place at the Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay. The Hay Barn, which used to serve the Gold Coast estate that is now part of the Long Island state parks system, is no more; it has been transformed into an intimate concert hall, and today Friends of the Arts begins a Spring Chamber Music Series in the new facility. The renowned Tokyo String Quartet does the opening-day honors with a concert at 3 P.M. of Mozart, Shostakovich and Beethoven. The Borodin Trio on April 10 and the Concord String Quartet on May 1 complete the series. Subscriptions to all three concerts cost $30; individual tickets are $12.50. For reservations, call 922-0061.CHORAL MUSIC

title: Virginia Nichols To Marry May 1
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Nichols of Rego Park, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Laura Nichols, to Timothy John Kiley, son of Patricia C. Kiley of New Canaan, Conn., and Timothy M. Kiley of Los Angeles. The marriage will take place May 1.

title: CRIMES BY MARINES ON OKINAWA PROMPT OUTCRY
description: It was a murder that shocked hardened marines and caused even pro-American Okinawans to complain bitterly about an ''occupation mentality'' among the United States military forces here.

title: HOMICIDES, VICTORIAN AND MODERN
description: THE DETLING SECRET, By Julian Symons. 225 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $14.75. THE TIGERS OF SUBTOPIA And Other Stories. By Julian Symons. 221 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $14.75.

title:
ANTIQUES;
MAKING FURNITURE AS GOOD AS OLD
description: HACKENSACK WITH the prices of new furniture and antiques rising, refinishing may seem a good investment these days. To get a line on the cost of stripping and restoring old furniture, a visit was paid to Strip 'N Browze at 86 Orchard Street here. The shop handles just about every phase of restoring antique furniture, including hand stripping, regluing, veneering, carving, inlay work, caning, rushing, custom finishing, French polishing and brass restoration, as well as new custom cabinet and Formica work.

title: CUOMO ROLE CITED IN BUDGET ACCORD
description: A new Governor who was willing to deal and a budget gap that could not be ignored were cited yesterday as the central ingredients that produced an agreement Friday night on a new state budget - the first in four years achieved before the start of the new fiscal year.

title: SERVITUDE CAN STILL NO 'MORAL HUNGER'
description: To the Editor:

title: A LANDMARK ISLE
description: Perhaps the next time the President of the United States visits the South Bronx, the official party should head for Macy Place instead of Charlotte Street. Instead of devastation, the Chief Executive could see an example of people sticking to their homes because those homes are special and have been recognized as such.

title: San Jacinto Winner
description: Carey Holland scored 22 points as San Jacinto (Tex.) rallied midway through the second half and defeated Seminole (Okla.), 73-68, tonight in the championship game of the National Junior College basketball tournament. San Jacinto finished the season with a record of 37-2.

title: Italy Tops India, 1-0
description: Italy, the World Cup champion, beat India, 1-0, today in the Nehru Gold Cup International Soccer Tournament, a 16-day event.

title: WALESA MEETS SOLIDARITY LEADERS IN WARSAW
description: Lech Walesa met in private for nearly five hours today with other leaders of Solidarity, his outlawed independent trade union.

title: FREUD WITHOUT HINDSIGHT
description: Bruno Bettelheim's recent study of Freud in English translation, ''Freud and Man's Soul,'' made me curious about the early reviews of Freud's books in The New York Times Book Review. From 1913, when they first appeared, to late 1933, the date of what might be called the first sophisticated review, The Sunday Times ran 10 appraisals of Freud's work. Some were friendly and naive, some hostile and naive, some acceptable journalism, and one, the longest, incomprehensible.

title: AN INSIDER'S GUIDE TO MOSCOW
description: JOHN F. BURNS is chief of the Moscow bureau of The New York Times. BY JOHN F.BURNS

title: HAWAII'S DOWN-HOME ISLAND
description: FLETCHER KNEBEL'S most recent novel is ''Poker Game,'' forthcoming from Doubleday. By FLETCHER KNEBEL

title: THE GOOD LIFE IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: Wendell Rawls Jr. is the chief of The Times's Atlanta bureau.It was one of those wet, weary winter days in Manhattan, giving an air of evening to the office of a somewhat harried middle-aged executive. He supposed in three-quarter jest that it was nearing the time for him to begin thinking about taking early retirement and moving to North Carolina. His colleagues, who had joined him in the conversation, agreed with both implicit propositions: Early retirement was not a bad idea, and North Carolina was a good one.

title: Labor as Management
description: Whenever an old manufacturing plant in the Northeast or Middle West is about to be shut down or cut back, there is talk about workers somehow taking charge, imposing new efficiency and saving their jobs. In the case of the National Steel Corporation's Weirton Works in West Virginia, such a scheme may become reality this spring.

title: Lie Detectors
description: To The Business Editor: ''Lie Detectors as Corporate Tools'' (Feb.13) did not take into consideration the $10 billion of annual losses suffered by the retail industry through shoplifting, employee theft and industrial espionage.

title: JAZZ
description: Modern jazz never really made room for the clarinet. Benny Goodman made it one of the most familiar of all musical instruments during the swing era, but it proved unsuited to the demands of modernism, partly because it is not a loud instrument compared to the saxophone or trumpet and partly because it is such a difficult instrument to master.

title: GLEN COVE TO RULE ON PIPE
description: GLEN HEAD DURING the last four years, two state courts decided against the proposal and the Town of Oyster Bay twice decided in favor of it. Now the City of Glen Cove will determine whether it goes through.

title: JACQUELINE LEVINE: VOICE OF 'CONSENSUS'
description: WEST ORANGE AS THE newly elected head of the National Jewish Community Relationship Advisory Council, Jacqueline Levine is the first woman to lead a major Jewish public-affairs organization in the United States.

title: HALLIN GETS 3 AS ISLANDERS WIN
description: The typical National Hockey League rookie is 18 or 19 years old, Canadian, weaned on hockey sticks and ready to reap fortunes by his mid-20's. That is not Mats Hallin.

title: Repeal Indexing
description: To the Business Editor: In the argument between Senator Dole and Representative Rostenkowski (''The Split Over Tax Indexing,'' March 6), Mr. Rostenkowski has the better of the discussion in his call for repeal of the measure.

title: CRIME
description: The first Michael Spraggue mystery by Linda Barnes, ''Blood Will Have Blood,'' never came this way. Too bad, for the second in the series, BITTER FINISH (St. Martin's, $11.95), is a fine job - expertly written, with an ingenious wine caper set in the Napa Valley.

title: MAN HIT BY TIMES TRUCK DIES
description: A man was struck and killed Friday night by a New York Times truck at 43d Street and Ninth Avenue. The victim's name was withheld pending the notification of his relatives. The driver, Raymond Yarick, was not charged in the incident, which occured at 9:30 P.M.

title: TBILISI, THE VOLGA AND SIBERIA, TOO
description: SERGE SCHMEMANN is a correspondent in the Moscow bureau of The Times. BY SERGE SCHMEMANN

title: MOOSE STAGE A COMEBACK, CREATE A TIFF
description: The unexpected return of the moose to New York State after an absence of more than 100 years has sparked a bureaucratic controversy here on whether it should be classified as an endangered species.

title: Boating-Fund Status Unclear
description: Most of the Federal funds collected from the tax on marine fuel, scheduled to be returned to the states for recreational boating purposes starting this year, have been sidetracked by the Coast Guard.

title: REPORT SEES DROP IN U.S. ROLE AT U.N.
description: A report last month by a private research organization contends that United States influence in the United Nations has declined and that part of the reason is that the percentage of Secretariat employees who are Americans has declined. The report has been challenged by some American employees here.

title: CONCERT: BEETHOVEN
description: Beethoven concerts are always a staple of our musical life, but there is nothing routine about the New York Philharmonic's all-Beethoven subscription program this week. Friday afternoon's concert in Avery Fisher Hall was a model of conceptual intelligence and sensible yet deeply musical performance.

title: Rehabilitation For the Disabled
description: '' 'How-to' Hints for the Disabled'' (Feb. 13) describes one woman's response to the insufficient help that she received in caring for her debilitated mother. It is commendable that she responded by writing her book, ''A Handbook for the Disabled.''

title: GLOBAL POP TAKES SHAPE
description: The development of a truly global popular music has been anticipated for several decades now. Rock and roll, which swept America, Europe and much of the rest of the world beginning in the 1950's, looked as if it might turn out to be the first truly global pop, and in commercial terms it was. The rock of the Beatles and their successors in the 1960's and 1970's won an even broader audience around the world, and it began to incorporate elements from a variety of musical cultures - Indian sitars and percussion, Caribbean rhythms, melodic influences from Eastern Europe and so on.

title: WHEN GNARLED HORSERADISH BECOMES SLEEK SLIVERS
description: CERTAIN foods and ingredients have become so familiar in their processed form that the notion of using them in any other fashion rarely occurs to cooks. Even recognizing the fresh version of the item in question, when it appears on the market, may be difficult.

title: SURVEY TRACKS COUNTY'S CROWS
description: A couple of hundred yards from the Let's Have a Party factory outlet, near the Nanuet Mall, several thousand crows were doing just that. Ornithologists call it a night roost for crows, but to one startled shopper from the mall, it looked more like a scene from the Hitchcock movie, ''The Birds.'' From mid-December until mid-March, crows gather in communal roosts, perching in woodlands each night and dispersing each morning to forage for food.

title: MASSACHUSETTES LURING THE JOBLESS TO COLLEGE
description: Two months after a western Massachusetts community college began a program to give free tuition to the unemployed, some 950 jobless people across the state are enrolled in tuition-free courses in electronics, data processing or even film making.

title: Assessing Senator D'Amato
description: The profile of Senator Alfonse D'Amato described a concerned, hardworking legislator, but it did not include a discussion of his effort on behalf of the Jews of the Soviet Union (''D'Amato: At Home in the Senate,'' by Tom Goldstein, Feb. 13). The Senator has been in the forefront on this issue since he first arrived in Washington, and has made it one of his priorities.

title: MICROSURGERY GAINING IN STATE
description: WORKING through microscopes that transform the grooves and ridges of a fingerprint into monumental terrains, surgeons in New Jersey are making ever more delicate repairs on body parts barely visible to the naked eye.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE WAR AGAINST THE AMAZONS By Abby Wettan Kleinbaum. 240 pp. New York: New Press/McGraw-Hill. $18.95.

title: BLACKSMITH FORGING ON AFTER 70 YEARS
description: THERE is a narrow side street on the Greenport waterfront commonly known as Bootleg Alley. Local legend maintains that its recesses were the meeting grounds of Prohibition-era rumrunners and the storerooms for contraband liquor. Just west along the waterfront is a ramshackle wooden structure so old that it has noticeably sunken into the soft ground. Attached to the structure is a sign, ''The Village Blacksmith.''

title: HEALTH INSURANCE: RAISE THE NEGLIGENTS' RATES
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENTIAL SAVVY
description: Back in 1950, the president of Columbia University was Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, a man not unknown to fame. Whenever he could, he would sortie downtown to the Links Club for a few rubbers of bridge.

title: Valerie A. Tomaino to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Valentino R. Tomaino of Red Bank, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Valerie Anne Tomaino, to Peter Anthony Ryan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel P. Ryan of New York. Miss Tomaino is a senior media planner for Kenyon & Eckhardt Inc. in New York, where her fiance is an account executive for E. F. Hutton & Company.

title: Chief Judge's Deputy Will Quit Post in June
description: New York State's chief administrative judge, Herbert B. Evans, has announced that he plans to step down in June to join a law firm in New York City.

title: 'FAREWELL,' A JAPANESE DRAMA
description: Mitsuo Yanagimachi's ''Farewell to the Land'' is an unusually tough and contemporary Japanese drama from its first scene, of a family cleaning up the debris created by a very destructive son, to its violent and troubling conclusion. The story was suggested by news items, one of them concerning a man who comes to no good after abandoning his family and moving in with another woman. But it is Mr. Yanagimachi's careful, resonant treatment of the material that distinguishes this film. The story may be partly true, and it is told straightforwardly, but ''Farewell to the Land'' is most memorable for its haunting, even hallucinatory moments.

title: MOSCOW ONCE AGAIN CLOSES GATES ON JEWISH EMIGRATION
description: About 30 Moscow Jews and a few Westerners gathered in a private apartment recently to mark Purim with poetry and amateur theatricals. The players shifted easily from Russian to Hebrew, and some members of the hopelessly cramped audience joined in the songs. Even the children readily recognized Queen Esther and the other characters in the ancient legend of how Persian Jews triumphed over a devious plot to massacre them by the wicked Haman, done up for the evening as a Palestinian guerrilla.

title: SOLIDARITY NOW A CAUSE WITHOUT REBELS
description: It was a crowd looking for a leader. All around the huge monument Solidarity erected to honor workers shot to death during riots over food prices in 1970, people gathered last week in small clumps waiting for something to happen. Most of the workers streaming out of the Lenin Shipyard, where the independent trade union movement that rocked the foundations of Communist rule was born 2 1/2 years ago, just kept on walking. But gradually, the crowd grew to about a thousand, bravely chanting ''Solidarnosc, Solidarnosc.'' Then, on a warning over a police loudspeaker, it dispersed.

title: STETHOSCOPES AND SOFTWARE
description: The Physicians Guide to Desktop Computers, by Mark Harrison Spohr, M.D. Reston Publishing Company, Reston, Va. 222 pages. $21.95.

title: TIGER-EAGLE GAME: A CONTRAST IN STYLES
description: Both teams have had to journey across the continent to do it, but the nation's highest-scoring college basketball team will confront the country's most tenacious defense in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament here Sunday.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SEVEN KISSES IN A ROW By Patricia MacLachlan. Illustrated by Maria Pia Marrella. 57 pp. New York: Harper & Row/Charlotte Zolotow. $8.95. (Ages 7 to 10)

title: The High Cost Of Consolation
description: It could have been worse. That was the chief consolation for France's governing coalition of Socialists and their Communist junior partners last week after two rounds of municipal voting brought the loss of 30 major cities.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption on a picture on page 39 of The Times Magazine Feb. 20 incorrectly identified soldiers in Berlin, El Salvador. They were members of the Salvadoran Army.

title: Carmel Rose Russo Plans To Marry Robert Santoro
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Russo of Lynbrook, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carmel Rose Russo, to Robert Santoro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Santoro of Spring Hill, Fla., formerly of Valley Stream, L.I.

title: SPRING IN THE CAPITAL
description: It's spring again in Washington - some things do run on time here. You can tell, for the star magnolia tree at the northwest gate of the White House is blooming once more, and the Gridiron Club is tuning up for its annual spoof of the resident politicians.

title: Q A
description: Question:In June I will be in Tunisia for two weeks as a volunteer on an archeological dig at Carthage. Our work day will begin at 5 A.M. After 1 in the afternoon each day, and for one full day of our two weekends in Tunisia, we are on our own. How can I get the most out of this free time? Should I stick to Tunis and the nearby beaches or, perhaps, take a day trip to Sicily? Are there any special precautions recommended? - M.S., West Hartford, Conn. Answer:Robert M. Berzok, an American who took part in an archeological dig in Carthage last year sponsored by the Earthwatch organization of Belmont, Mass., offers the following advice:

title: Villanova Also Gains
description: Houston, which loves a running, slam-dunking style, overcame the slowdown, ball-holding tactics of Maryland today and defeated the Terps, 60-50, in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: RUTGERS ART SCHOOL NEAR GOAL
description: NEW BRUNSWICK OFFICIALS at Rutgers University's Mason Gross School of the Arts say they are more than halfway to their goal of making it a firstrate professional school for theater, the visual arts, music and the dance.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
A CHANCE TO CORRECT THE CORE PROBLEM
description: ONCE again, American business will be the whipping boy when another r ound of political maneuvers over antibribery legislation takes p lace.

title: BYWAYS OF OPERA YEILD UNEXPECTED PLEASURES
description: Albums of the standard operas, those works we encounter with numbing regularity in our major opera houses, still tumble steadily into the record stores. But in many ways, the liveliest aspect of the opera recording industry these days is the attention paid to nonstandard operas.

title: Lebanon Comes To Washington
description: A visit to Washington by high-level Israeli and Lebanese officials last week may have loosened the negotiating knot that has kept 30,000 Israeli troops in Lebanon. Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel returned home saying ''we are nearer to a solution.'' How much nearer may be determined by the Israeli Cabinet today.

title: WHY EVERYONE ELSE SEEMS TO VOTE
description: In European elections, people vote in droves. This month in West Germany, 89.1 percent of the registered voters cast ballots. Turnout exceeded 79 percent Sunday in the second round of French municipal elections. Nor is the phenomenon confined to Europe; in Australia a couple of weeks ago, more than 90 percent of eligible voters got to the polls.

title: Melissa Cooper to Wed Mark Cornfeld in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Stuart Cooper of Roslyn, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Melissa Cooper, to Dr. Mark J. Cornfeld, son of Dr. and Mrs. David Cornfeld of Philadelphia. The wedding is planned for June 25.

title: RIGHT'S PANEL SAYS REAGAN OFFICIALS HAMPER ITS WORK
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights says that the White House and Federal agencies have impeded its work by withholding documents.

title: PLANS FOR NEW HUB DEVELOP IN MERIDEN
description: PEOPLE in New Haven call Joel Schiavone ''Mr. Downtown.'' Meriden officials say they may soon start using the same nickname for the 46-year-old developer.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: FIRE IN THE MINDS OF MEN: Origins of the Revolutionary Faith. By James H. Billington. (Basic/ Harper Colophon, $13.50.) Focusing on the years between the French and Russian revolutions, James H. Billington's study of revolutionary leaders challenges us ''to renew our perspective on where modern radicalism leads and what it means,'' Marshall Berman said in his 1980 review. At once erudite and dramatic, the book explores the roots of the modern belief that a just and beautiful new world will spring into being if only we can overthrow evil powers and institutions.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Result of Experience ''It has a very decent, straightforward and honest script. It simply illuminated Medgar Evers instead of making him into some deity. But it bounced around for 10 years.'' The actor Howard E. Rollins Jr. was talking about ''For Us the Living,'' an ''American Playhouse'' production in which Mr. Rollins portrays Medgar Evans - the field director for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, who was slain in 1963 outside his home in Jackson, Miss. It will finally be broadcast by Channel 13 on Tuesday at 9 P.M. Also in the cast are Irene Cara, Roscoe Lee Browne, Janet MacLachlan, Dick Anthony Williams and Paul Winfield. Ossie Davis wrote the script, based on a book by Mr. Evers' wife, Myrlie Evers, and William Peters.

title: KNICKS STREAK IS ENDED, 96-90
description: The Washington Bullets, led by Greg Ballard's outside shooting and Jeff Ruland's physical inside play, ended the Knicks' winning streak at eight games last night with a 96-90 victory at Madison Square Garden.

title: Sequel to a Slaying
description: A year and three months after a burglar fatally shot Dr. Michael J. Halberstam in his home in Washington, a Federal court held the murderer liable for $5.7 million in damages. The court assessed the damages in March 1982 against Bernard C. Welch Jr., who killed the physician, and said the money was to go to Dr. Halberstam's widow, Elliott Jones, and the doctor's two sons.
