title: SHOULD MUSEUMS BE EXEMPT FROM TAXES?
description: Just the other day it was made known that the Asia Society, whose headquarters are at 725 Park Avenue, had been denied exemption from property tax on the ground that it ''had failed to meet the definition of an educational institution by the New York State property-tax law.''

title: King of Thailand Calls Early Election
description: King Phumiphol Aduldet of Thailand dissolved the House of Representatives tonight and called a general election for April 18, two months ahead of schedule, to prevent what Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda said could be violent political conflicts.

title: Headliners; Charging Responsibility
description: Treating a troubled patient can trouble a psychiatrist, particularly when the patient tries to assassinate the President. On top of that, Dr. John J. Hopper Jr., former psychiatrist to John W. Hinckley Jr., was sued last week for $14 milllion by three men wounded in the 1981 attempt on Mr. Reagan's life. They insist Dr. Hopper ''knew or should have known'' his patient would turn violent. Dr. Hopper testified at the trial that he had no such hint and, in any event, doctors say they cannot predict ''dangerousness.''

title: ANALYZING IMAGES OF MODERN CINEMA
description: ''DOES the breakdown of the carousel signify anything?'' a student asked during a recent Thursday evening class on film at the New Community Cinema in Huntington.

title: History Given
description: On 'Wowser'To the Sports Editor: For the benefit of Dr. Charles B. Brill (Mailbox, The New York Times, Feb.27), my Oxford Universal Dictionary defines a ''wowser'' as a ''puritanical enthusiast or fanatic'' and notes that the word originated in Australia and that its first recorded use was in 1909. J. KEVIN BRANIGAN Rochester, N.Y.

title: Marilyn Walker Betrothed To Dr. Christopher Prevel
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ernest T. Walker of Zanesville, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marilyn Diane Walker, to Dr. Christopher Dean Prevel, son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Prevel of Washington.

title: SOLAR POWER FOR POST OFFICE
description: WHEN Tom Palazzotto began working for the United States Postal Service in 1959, he was assigned to a recently opened facility in Islip Terrace. The post office at that time, he said, ''already looked like it was 10 years old - the ceiling was leaking, the tiles were dropping off and the windows were coming out.''

title: AIDE SAYS FRANCE IS READY TO QUIT MONETARY SYSTEM
description: France has warned that it is prepared to withdraw from the Common Market's monetary system unless European finance ministers agree to redefine the value of their currencies to its satisfaction.

title: IN THE ARTS: THE CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE The big guns may be firing at City Center, where the Merce Cunningham Dance Company completes its spring season this week, and in Brooklyn, where the Hamburg Ballet performs through the week as part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's European ballet festival. But there's much to see elsewhere, from resonant curiosities to some promising newer faces.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: 'STUDENT PRINCE' IS STILL APPEALING
description: IN Stephen Lehew, the Coachlight Dinner Theater in East Windsor has a ''Student Prince'' with a royal tenor, a regal bearing and enough youthful ardor to pass the student part with honors.

title: Helping Needy Since 1975
description: We applaud your effort in publicizing the fact that, even in our affluent state, so many communities have found it necessary to establish private, charitable organizations providing food, clothing and shelter for the poor and the homeless (''Serving the Needs of Others,'' March 6).

title: MARCEAU'S ART MIRRORS A BYGONE PARIS
description: Marcel Marceau is not timeless. He belongs to the same generation of postwar French entertainers, and that word is used advisedly, as singers such as Yves Montand and, less well known in America, Leo Ferre. It is a generation marked by World War II, with a youth more scarred and traumatized than it cares to admit. One of Mr. Ferre's and Mr. Montand's theme songs was ''Luna Park.'' Mr. Marceau, too, imagined a similar 20th-century fairground and it is still on view as a mime number called ''The Amusement Park'' at the Belasco, where Mr. Marceau is currently performing.

title: Tenants Gain Lease Power
description: Because of an state appellate court ruling last week, it may be more difficult than ever to move from a New York City landlord's waiting list into one of his apartments. The ruling gave current tenants the right to transfer unexpired leases to qualified applicants of their choice regardless of who the landlord has lined up.

title: OWNER OF ELECTRIC CAR FIGHTS TO USE IT
description: ROLAND LEMIRE doesn't like to let technology get ahead of him. For 16 years he has been an electrical engineer at WFSB-TV in Hartford; he is an avid ham radio operator; he subscribes to a variety of technological and trade journals, and he sits down each night to work at his home computer.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: RODNEY ROOTLE'S GROWN-UP GRAPPLER AND OTHER TREASURES FROM THE MUSEUM OF OUTLAWED INVENTIONS By Chris Winn and Jeremy Beadle. Illustrated by Chris Winn. Unpaged. Boston: Atlantic/Little, Brown. $9.95. (Ages 9 and Up)

title: The Axman and Nuclear Power
description: There was a mishap last month at the Salem Unit 1 nuclear plant operated by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey. No one was hurt, but the incident is more unsettling than any since Three Mile Island.

title: Mailbox; Misinformation Burdens Runners
description: To the Sports Editor: Modern-day athletes in their struggle for survival are finding the job increasingly more complex and frustrating. The same feelings are shared by middle-aged American marathoners and their young or competitive counterparts. (''The Toll Conditioning Can Take on Athletes,'' The New York Times, March 6).

title: SOUTH PRESSING FOR WIDE CHANGES TO UPGRADE EDUCATION STANDARDS
description: Sweeping changes in education policy are being pursued throughout the South by a growing number of political leaders who assert that the ability of their states to attract growth industries hinges increasingly on the educational depth of the work force.

title: YOUNGSTERS IN NEW YORK GET TASTE OF FARAWAY COUNTRIES
description: Only a minute after the tour got started, many questions had to be answered. About 30 fifth graders sat in a semicircle around Kate Ezra, an assistant curator at the Metropolitan Museum of Modern Art.

title: L.I.R.R. WINNING OVER SOME CRITICS
description: THE bell clanged, the shiny silver doors slid shut and Long Island Rail Road train 425 edged away from the Port Washington platform, right on time. It was 8:15 A.M., that bleary-eye time of morning when commuters juggle coffee cups, crease newspapers and plug in Sony Walkmen. And when Patricia Jackson puts on her eye makeup.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE PEOPLE IN PINEAPPLE PLACE By Anne Lindbergh. 153 pp. San Diego and New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $10.95. (Ages 9 to 12)

title: Schoolgirls Honored
description: Four area high school players have been named to the annual Parade magazine all-America girls' basketball team. Vanessa Paynter of Eastside in Paterson, N.J., was placed on the second team, and Carolin Dehn-Duhr of Catholic in Paramus, N.J., on the third. Lynn Tighe of St. Peter's of Staten Island and Floretta Jackson of Wyandanch (L.I.) High made the fourth team.

title: RITA LAVELLE SUES TO FIGHT SUBPEONA
description: Rita M. Lavelle, who was discharged last month as head of the Environmental Protection Agency's toxic waste program, has told a House investigations subcommittee that she will not testify before it Monday despite a subpoena for her appearance.

title: SOVIET AND LIBYA PLAN AN AMITY ACCORD
description: The Soviet Union and Libya announced today that they had agreed in principle to sign a treaty of friendship and cooperation.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART A very proper pastime for young girls and genteel ladies of the 19th century was tinsel painting, known more formally as reverse painting on glass with foil. It involved the limning of fruits, flowers, figures, landscapes - often with the aid of stencils - on glass with transparent oils, and then the application of tinfoil.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER
description: Scan the advertisements in your travel section and one fact becomes clear: charter flights will abound this spring and summer and could pare your vacation costs sharply. So if you are planning to visit a country to which charters operate from the United States, it would be foolhardy not to examine, at least, what they have to offer and to compare their fares, conditions and services with those on scheduled flights. You may like very much what you learn, or you may conclude that the saving isn't enough to overcome certain elements of uncertainty. The term ''charter'' can evoke diametrically opposite feelings among air travelers. To some it means taking a chance: risking late changes in departure arrangements, arrivals at unexpected airports, switches in hotels, misdirected baggage, no responsible person to whom to complain, and extreme difficulty - if not impossibility - in getting recourse after returning home. There is no question that such problems do occasionally arise; in fact, almost all have been known to occur on the same trip. And when 400 people are simultaneously suffering the same plight, word of their collective misery often gets noisily around.

title: SPECIAL OLYMPIANS IN TRAINING
description: AT 2:30 Tuesday afternoons, four busloads of ''students'' arrive at Iona College in New Rochelle. Talking and laughing among themselves, they leave the buses and check in at the gym at the Mulcahy Student Center.

title: HUNTINGTON BATTLES SUITS SEEKING RENTALS
description: WHEN it was announced in February 1980 that applications would be accepted for 125 rent-subsidized a partments for the elderly in Paumanack Village, a housing complex int he Town of Huntington, people began lining up nearly 24 hours ahead o f time.

title: Jonathan Barnett And Nory Miller Exchange Vows
description: Nory Miller, a freelance writer and editor, was married yesterday to Jonathan Barnett, professor of architecture and director of the graduate program in urban design at the City College of New York. The Rev. Dr. F.Forrester Church Jr. performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: CONCERT: PRAGUE GROUP
description: The Prague Chamber Orchestra, a conductorless ensemble from Czechoslovakia, made a good case for conductors Thursday night at Carnegie Hall. One heard the kind of Central European expressive warmth to be expected but, along with it, a hazy sense of articulation, tone and intonation.

title: HOW A TEAM SAVED A SEVERED THUMB
description: HACKENSACK IT HAPPENED within the space of a heartbeat on a Saturday morning as Michael Ennis of Glen Rock used an electromagnetic drill on a steel beam.

title: L.I. MAN CONVICTED IN HEROIN PLOT
description: A 23-year-old Long Island man was convicted last night in a narcotics trial that included the first public testimony of Leroy (Nicky) Barnes as a prosecution witness.

title: AN OIL MINISTER'S POEM STOLE THE SHOW
description: PARIS AFTER all was said and done, it was Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, the diminutive 37-year-old oil minister from the United Arab Emirates, who captured the OPEC spotlight last week. It was his poem, distributed during the closing hours of the cartel's cantankerous London meeting, that seemed to cause more hard feelings among his colleagues than the discord over prices.

title: Debra Estes Engaged To William Ewing Jr.
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Manson P. Estes of Bridgewater, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debra Denise Estes, to William Milne Ewing Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ewing of New York. The wedding is to be on April 23.

title: Caroline K. Rennolds to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Kerr Branch Rennolds of Richmond have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Kent Rennolds, to Jeremiah Milbank 3d, son of Mr. Milbank Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Andrea Hunter Milbank.

title: Midlife Crisis
description: Say what you will about life as a big-time drug dealer, the intellectual assessment offered by one of the biggest last week was a revelation. ''Shallow,'' said Leroy (Nicky) Barnes to a Manhattan jury. Mr. Barnes, who is serving a life sentence, was testifying for the prosecution against Nicholas Sperling, a Long Island man charged with conspiracy to sell heroin. Mr. Barnes's evidence has led to the indictment of five high-level heroin dealers. He said he is cooperating because he realized he'd been double-crossed and that his drug trade had hurt the Harlem community.

title: BRITAIN'S ARTS AND ARTISTS HEAD FOR NEW YORK
description: LONDON David Lloyd-Jacob's head was, appropriately enough, in the clouds when he had the idea for ''Britain Salutes New York.'' It was 1980, and, as chairman of Amcon, the American subsidiary of Consolidated Gold Fields, he seemed to be permanently in trans-Atlantic flight. Up there, like many a lesser man, he got to thinking - with the result that a city-straddling festival of some 190 events, from performances by the Royal Ballet to a major retrospective of Henry Moore's sculpture at the Metropolitan Museum, from the Monteverdi Choir to the first American showing of Laurence Olivier's TV ''Lear,'' will begin in New York on April 13 and bubble on into the summer.

title: SUMMER SOLUTION
description: Summer clothes should be cool, comfortable, washable and inexpensive. ''And always pretty,'' says Harriet Winter, the designer behind the Mrs. H. Winter label.

title: ELLER'S DRUG FIGHT HIS '5TH SUPER BOWL'
description: DESPITE Carl Eller's massive 6-foot 6-inch, 250-pound frame, one can still glimpse traces of the shy, awkward teen-ager he was. His long career as an all-pro football player has not erased his memory of being a youngster who found it difficult to fit in, whose troubles began when he found, in a bottle of liquor, the courage to walk across a high school dance floor.

title: LOOPED ON THE LINE TO PETUSHKI
description: MOSCOW CIRCLES, By Benedict Erofeev. Translated by J.R. Dorrell. 188 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co./Writers and Readers Publishing Cooperative. $12.95.

title: WATER USE PLANNED FOR CAMDEN AREA
description: CAMDEN STATE and local authorities have set into motion a plan to increase this area's diminishing water supply. Camden, southern New Jersey's largest city, is on the Delaware River but, unlike Philadelphia across the river, it gets no water from the river.

title: Miss Medlock Engaged to D.. Tuteur
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Medlock of Port Washington, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Katharine Baird Medlock, to Daniel M. Tuteur, son of Prof. Franz B. Tuteur of Hamden, Conn., and the late Ruth Tuteur.

title: Jocelyn Samuels to Wed Thomas Olson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley A. Samuels of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jocelyn Frances Samuels, to Thomas Parker Olson, son of Mrs. William Mosteller of Falls Church, Va., and Richard Olson of Fairfax, Va. An October wedding is planned.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: IN Chaucer's England, a man's beard was not only a sign of fashion, but also a clue to character. Whereas a full, fluffy beard betokened a virtuous man of much good will, a patchy beard implied that the wearer was brooding, wrathful and inclined to evil deeds.

title: WILLIAM J. IVEY
description: William J. Ivey, a partner in the Wall Street law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, died of cancer Wednesday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: Experience Plays a Key Role
description: The value of playing experience under the pressure of tournament basketball was on the minds of most of the coaches who will be involved here tomorrow in the second round of the East Regional competition in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I championships.

title: UNION CITY AS A PLAYWRIGHT'S MICROCOSM
description: THE neon sign that lights up the rear of the stage reads ''La Flor de Union City'' -The Flower of Union City. It is the backdrop for Manuel Martin Jr.'s play ''Union City Thanksgiving,'' which spans three generations of a Cuban-American family that escaped the revolution, settled here and engaged in its own internal warfare.

title:
OPINION;
TIME TO CHANGE POLICIES
description: THE resignation of Anne McGill Burford as Administrator of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency was welcome news to those of us who care about the environment and have seen our laws to protect it neglected.

title: DIPLOMATIC STORIES
description: THE LONDON EMBASSY, By Paul Theroux. 248 pp. New York: Houghton, Mifflin Company. $13.95.

title: CREATING ILLUSIONS ONSTAGE
description: BRIDGEPORT WALK into the workshop of the Atlas Scenic Studio and you might be standing in the midst of what looks like the palace of a Hapsburg emperor or maybe a 19th-century London hospital.

title: MONT-SAINT-MICHEL IN WINTER LIGHT
description: ROBERT RAGAINI, when not traveling, sings radio and television commercials. By ROBERT RAGAINI

title: NOW APPEARING, HERSCHEL WALKER
description: On that day nearly a month ago, Herschel Walker, like a visiting potentate, descended in a helicopter onto a landing field and then, wearing not a pin-striped suit but a warm-up suit, was transported to the football field in a limousine. The football field in Orlando, Fla., was crawling with reporters and camera persons. Very little practice was executed.

title: Miss Dietel, D.F. Krieger Are to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Moore Dietel of Flint Hill, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Lyon Dietel, to Dennis Francis Krieger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Grant Krieger of Great Neck, L.I. The wedding is to take place July 30 at the Dietel summer home in Upper Saranac Lake, N.Y.

title: FEAR OF FLOPPY DISKS
description: Writing With a Word Processor by William Zinsser. Harper & Row, New York. 125 pages. $12.95.

title: SATURDAY FERVOR AT A HANDGUN RANGE
description: As a locksmith, Marie Wynn knows that even a good lock cannot keep out a determined burglar. And, she says, she knows what could happen when an armed robber meets an unarmed homeowner.

title: SALVADOR FUROR COMES TO A TOWN IN VERMONT
description: An international controversy came to this tiny town Friday night. Before an impassioned audience of students, housewives, farmers, churchmen and senior citizens stood El Salvador's Ambassador to the United States, Ernesto Rivas-Gallont. Dressed in a blue pin-striped suit and standing by a map of El Salvador -imposed on a map of Vermont - the Ambassador put his country's case to its critics here in the shadow of the Green Mountains.

title:
DINING OUT;
MEXICAN FOR LOCALS AND TRAVELERS
description: STYLE food has become one of the favorite casual foods of the East. The festive, fun food is popular with diners of all ages, from babies to their great-grandparents. The county's Cantina (there is a branch on Manhattan's Columbus Avenue) has been ''the restaurant in the park'' (Everett Macy County Park) for four years. If informal ski lodge-style architecture and pretty dining rooms - the main one with a lovely fireplace, stone walls and high, arched wood ceiling - make it a particularly appealing stop for locals and travelers alike. In warm weather, tables and umbrellas spill onto terraces that overlook Woodlands Lake.

title: 'PERSONALS' IN MINNEAPOLIS
description: Bill (Bill Schoppert) is an almost perfect representation of today's idealized, upwardly mobile - though forever middle-class - consumer society. He's a successful magazine publisher in Minneapolis and newly single. His wife has left him for another man and, while he's not exactly suicidal, he's lonely and at loose ends. More or less as a joke, he puts a personals ad in The Twin Cities Reader, describing himself as a ''SWM,'' 32, who is interested in, among other things, Picasso and chicken Kiev.

title: NORWALK HERALDS 2 NEW BUSINESSES
description: NORWALK THIS city's efforts to revitalize its inner city took two major steps forward in the past month with the opening of a nightclub and a restaurant in the Washington Street area of South Norwalk.

title: Janet Brown Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Travis Taylor Brown of Washington and Nonquitt, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Huidekoper Brown, to Michael Fabian Brewer, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Fabian Brewer of Chicago.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THERE wasn't much about the current state of the county in Andrew P. O'Rourke's first State of the County Address last Monday, but the County Executive, who took office in January, had a lot to say about what he saw as the county's future status.

title: RECENT SALES
Texas Sheriff Is Guilty Of Torturing Prisoners
description: The Sheriff of San Jacinto County has resigned after admitting he operated a marijuana trap on heavily traveled U.S. 59 as well as subjected jail inmates to water torture to gain confessions and testimony.

title: TRIBUTE TO A COLLEAGUE
description: IN the Hall of the House at the State Capitol, where there is usually noisy chatter and political squabbling, there was unusual quiet Wednesday morning as the legislative leaders rose one by one to pay tribute to the late Senator Audrey P. Beck.

title: E.P.A. AIDES ASSERT SUPERIOR ORDERED 2 REPORTS SOFTENED
description: Two officials of the Environmental Protection Agency say John A. Todhunter, the assistant administrator in charge of controlling toxic substances, ordered staff studies altered to make dioxin and formaldehyde appear less dangerous.

title: Elizabeth Igoe Cole Is Bride of Martin P. Finegan
description: Elizabeth Igoe Cole, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Ashley Cole of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Martin Peter Finegan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo P. Finegan of Munhall, Pa. Msgr. Harold Murray performed the ceremony at the St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE DEVIL WITH THE THREE GOLDEN HAIRS A Tale From the Brothers Grimm. Retold and illustrated by Nonny Hogrogian. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: OPEC Epoch On the Skids
description: After 10 years of prices going up up up, OPEC last week admitted there was no place to go but down. The 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed in London to cut the official price by 15 percent, dropping it from $34 to $29 a barrel based on Saudi Light crude. But in a glutted marketplace where OPEC no longer called the shots, many experts predicted a further slide to the mid-$20 range.

title: The Foggy Realm Of Philanthropy
description: As President Reagan urges Americans to give more to social, educational and cultural programs while the Government gives less, the race has quickened for philanthropic dollars. ''No one can make intelligent public policy regarding fund-raising and spending in this fog,'' said Russy Sumariwalla, executive director of the National Center for Charitable Statistics.

title: Margaret Rooney To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Timothy James Rooney of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Murray Rooney, to Robert John Galterio, son of Dr. and Mrs. Vincent Galterio of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Bonn Parties Break Off Talks on New Cabinet
description: West Germany's three coalition parties today unexpectedly broke off negotiations on forming a new government and said they would continue talks next Tuesday.

title: U.S. Refuses Visa For Ian Paisley
description: A State Department spokesman said today that the Rev. Ian Paisley, the militant Protestant leader from Northern Ireland, had been denied a visa to enter the United States because ''it was considered contrary to the public interest.''

title:
DINING OUT;
PRINCETON: A TASTE OF SCANDINAVIA
description: WHEN the Scanticon Conference Center and Hotel in Princeton opened two years ago, its only restaurant was the informal Courtyard, which received mixed reviews. Since then, this Danish-run establishment has added The Black Swan, which is described as a gourmet restaurant. Indeed it is, if that hackneyed noun can be stretched into an adjective describing very good hotel cooking.

title: 3 Deputies Stabbed In Coast Jail Melee
description: Orange County jail inmates went on a six-and-a-half-hour rampage today, injuring three deputies and one prisoner, ripping out light fixtures and plumbing, and setting fires in their bunks.

title: Holders Sue Failed Bank
description: The United American Bank of Knoxville had about $377 million in loans ''substantially or wholly'' uncollectible when it collapsed Feb. 14, a stockholders' lawsuit filed Thursday against the bank's directors said.

title: OFFICIALLY, SPRING WAFTS IN
description: Bursts of sunlight through occasional clouds, rows of tentative tulips at Rockefeller Center and the patter of jogging sneakers in Central Park offered a preview of spring in the metropolitan area yesterday.

title: A Gracious Touch
description: In response to complaints from bus riders trying to figure out where buses were going, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has decided to add a new destination sign.

title: FRANK OCEAK
description: Frank Oceak, a 40-year veteran of organized baseball who coached third base for two Pittsburgh Pirates world champion teams, died Saturday in a Johnstown hospital.

title: Books Of The Times
description: OF POWER AND PRINCIPLE. Memoirs of the National Security Adviser. 1977-81. By Zbigniew Brzezinski. 587 pages. Farrar Straus & Giroux. $22.50.

title: Weinberger in Europe To Discuss Missile Plans
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger arrived here today to consult the allies on NATO plans to deploy United States Pershing 2 and low-flying cruise nuclear missiles in December.

title: GIANT WASTE COMPANY ACCUSED OF ILLEGAL ACTS
description: The following article is based on reporting by Ralph Blumenthal and Raymond Bonner and was written by Mr. Bonner.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 21, 1983: MONDAY Esterline Corp P H H Group Horizon Bancorp Rochester Tel Jamesway Corp Sierra Pacific Pwr N B D Bancorp TUESDAY Cleveland Elec Illum Richardson-Vicks Knight-Ridder News Toledo Edison WEDNESDAY E G & G Inc Northern States Pwr Federal Co Ocean Drill & Explor Flight Safety Intl Philips Indus Johnson Controls Transco Energy THURSDAY Acme-Cleveland Federated Dept Strs Boston Edison Metromedia Inc Campbell Soup Northwestn Steel & W Commwlth Energy Sys Ralston Purina Dow Chemical Ranco Inc Equitable Gas Tektronix Inc FRIDAY Centl Hudson G & E Fay's Drug

title: The U.N. Today; March 21, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: G.E. Executive to Head Computer-Services Unit
description: The General Electric Company has named Walter W. Williams, a longtime company executive, to head its computer-services subsidiary, the General Electric Information Services Company.

title: 2 Children Found Dead in Bedroom
description: Two young Brooklyn children were found dead in their bedroom yesterday, and the police said they had apparently died of asphyxiation.

title: TREASURY DOMINATES WEEK'S ISSUES
description: New-issue activity in the credit markets this week will be dominated by the United States Treasury. It has scheduled note and bond auctions totaling $13.5 billion as well as the regular weekly bill auctions, which total $12.4 billion.

title: BL Reduced Losses in '82
description: BL, the state-owned auto maker formerly known as British Leyland, reported today that it had reduced its losses last year, raising the company's hopes of returning to profitability by 1984.

title: STRIKE GOLD EASY WINNER IN BAY SHORE
description: Finally, after 38 early Kentucky Derby preps this year that have yielded little but confusion, there is a 3-year-old colt to get excited about. Strike Gold ran up to his advance notices yesterday by running away to an easy 4 1/4-length victory in the Bay Shore Stakes at Aqueduct.

title: Loughlin, St. Anthony's Gain
description: Mark Jackson scored 11 of his 25 points in the fourth quarter and led Bishop Loughlin to a 87-78 upset victory over St. Agnes yesterday to win the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association B title at St. Francis Prep in Queens. With the victory, Bishop Loughlin took another step forward in the New York State basketball championships.

title: Drug Informer Program Pleasing Dallas School
description: School officials are happy about a new program to find drug users and sellers in schools in this suburb north of Dallas, although students have mixed reactions.

title: Steven Certilman and Terri Frank, Lawyers, Wed
description: The marriage of Terri Joy Frank, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Frank of New York, to Steven Certilman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Certilman of Woodbury, L.I., took place yesterday in the Bethel Chapel of Temple Emanuel.

title: Loss in Quarter For Air Florida
description: Air Florida System Inc. has announced that it had a deficit of $29.4 million in the fourth quarter of 1982, compared with a loss of $19.3 million in the fourth quarter of the preceding year.

title: Koch Goes Into Act On Why He Lost
description: Mayor Koch has finally explained why he lost to Mario M. Cuomo in the Democratic gubernatorial primary. He had forgotten some advice given him as a little boy, he said, ''by a lusty lifeguard at Brighton Beach.''

title: Dr. Knobler Wed To an Economist
description: Dr. Joanna Knobler, a psychiatrist on the teaching staff of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, was married yesterday to Ira Kawaller, director of the New York office of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Cantor Ellen Math of the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue performed the ceremony in the Rainbow Grill.

title: CONCERT: ASHKENAZY
description: THERE were moments in Vladimir Ashkenazy's performance of Schubert's ''Wanderer'' Fantasy on Saturday night in Carnegie Hall when the pianist cut through the well-mannered pose of the expert performer to give a glimpse into a more threatening realm. The work's motivic intonations grew ambiguous in strange harmonic settings; arpeggiations swirled about, disrupting perspective and loosening foundations. Every note was clearly articulated, every phrase defined, but the result was beyond the boundaries of rational order.

title: 'Gutter Press' Bill Is Dropped in India
description: Legislation that Indian journalists said would gag the press has been scrapped, the bill's sponsor announced today.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: Finnish Voting Starts For 1,331 Candidates
description: Finns began voting today in a two-day parliamentary election that will determine whether the opposition Conservatives can break up a center-left coalition that has governed since 1966.

title: SENATE IS LESS AND LESS LIKE A CLUB
description: For most of last week, the Senate was deadlocked. The leadership was trying to pass an emergency job bill, and Senator Bob Kasten was trying to attach a rider repealing the withholding tax on dividends and interest.

title: Barbara Lasky Is Wed M.B. Mitzner, Lawyer
description: Barbara Lea Lasky, a fashion designer and swimwear manufacturer, was married yesterday to Marvin Benjamin Mitzner, a senior associate with the New York law firm of Stein, Davidoff, Malito & Teitler. Rabbi Nisson Shulman of the Fifth Avenue Synagogue performed the ceremony in the roof garden of the Churchill, an East Side residential apartment building.

title: CHARLESTON WINS TITLE
description: Coach John Kresse had a lot of credit to pass out after his College of Charleston (S.C.) team beat West Virginia Wesleyan, 57-53, to win the the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball championship Saturday night. Some of it went to St. John's.

title: OGDEN REID ENTERS RACE TO BE WESTCHESTER CHIEF
description: Ogden R. Reid, who served for six terms as a Congressman from Westchester County, announced today that he would seek the Democratic nomination for County Executive, a post held since January by a Republican, Andrew P. O'Rourke.

title: HOW ILLNESS CAN TEST FRIENDSHIP
description: HELEN was going into the hospital next morning to have an intestinal polyp removed. It was minor surgery and she was only a little apprehensive. It would just be an unpleasant couple of days that had to be gotten through.

title: No Laughing Matter
description: It all began as a little joke. Clark Gillies, the New York Islanders' veteran left wing, was looking for a laugh one morning when he donned a protective helmet and joined his teammates on the ice.

title: Activision Splits Its Ad Assignment
description: Into the volatile, burgeoning arena of video game advertising, a new element is soon to be added, created by Tatham, Laird & Kudner, Chicago. The shop already numbers among its clients such heavyweights as Procter & Gamble, Ralston Purina and R.J. Reynolds Tobacco.

title: Market Place; The Realities Of Cuts in Oil
description: THE harsh economic realities of lower crude oil prices flowed through the stock market last week. While the Dow Jones industrial average finished without change at 1,117.74, it was a rather devastating week for energy-related issues.

title: Computer Baseball
description: When Dave Johnson was playing baseball with the Baltimore Orioles, he showed Earl Weaver a computer printout that proved conclusively, he thought, that the manager was using the wrong criteria to pick his lineup.

title: Salvadoran Prelate Criticizes Delay in Trial of 4 in Killings
description: The head of the Roman Catholic Church in El Salvador today criticized the delay in the trial of four national guardsmen accused of killing four American churchwomen in December 1980, saying ''the trial is revived only when economic and military aid is sought.''

title: GAF PLAN OFFERED BY INSURGENTS
description: The battle between the GAF Corporation and insurgent shareholders seeking control of the company intensified over the weekend, and the insurgents got some support from an investment analysis group.

title: HOME CARE MUST RANK HIGH IN HEALTH REFORM
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ROAD HOME
description: Give Us Oz

title: News Analysis
description: The latest dispute between the Reagan Administration and the United States Commission on Civil Rights, now headed by a conservative Republican, comes as something of a surprise.

title: Theaters Join Battle To Save Arts Budget
description: At the Philharmonic one night last week, music lovers learned from their programs that the Haydn was Symphony No. 88 in G major, that the Dvorak was Symphony No. 8 in G major and that the New York State Council on the Arts could get a $4.5 million budget cut.

title: Atlanta 500 Race Is Postponed
description: A steady rain forced postponement of the Atlanta 500 stock car race today, delaying for one week the pollsitter Geoff Bodine's bid for his first Nascar Grand National victory.

title: STAKES HIGH, CHINESE TENNIS DEFECTOR SPEAKS OUT
description: Hu Na, a 19-year-old Chinese tennis player who defected here last summer, says one of the reasons she decided to act was her feeling that Chinese officials were trying to coerce her into joining the Communist Party.

title: MONEY AND ALLIES
description: The European monetary crisis seems distant and of no direct concern to Americans. But it will have an important bearing on whether the fragile beginnings of U.S. recovery can gain strength, and ultimately on the alliance itself.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MILESTONE

title: Spring Tidings and Cautions
description: Through an actress impersonating a housewife on TV, the Republican National Committee has announced that ''people are going back to work because President Reagan didn't go for a quick fix.'' A letter to the editor of The Register in Santa Ana, Calif., presumably spontaneous, asserts, ''Thank you, Reaganomics. That's the way to go, America.''

title: IN NEW DELHI, A VOTE AGAINST MIDEAST PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: BALLET: NORTH CAROLINIANS
description: THE North Carolina Dance Theater got its first New York engagement off to a bold start Friday night at Brooklyn College by offering both a world premiere and a familiar ballet that is so demanding that it instantly reveals the standards of any group that attempts it. But the company met these challenges admirably.

title: MUSIC: ASTON MAGNA CONCERT
description: ASTON MAGNA'S concert Saturday evening at Abraham Goodman House juxtaposed the well known and the obscure in a pleasing manner. Under the artistic direction of Albert Fuller, who also plays harpischord, the troupe presented chamber music by Bach, Mozart, Biber and Buxtehude, and managed to combine scholarly authenticity with a refreshing verve and spontaneity.

title: ROGERS WINS BY 3 STROKES
description: Bill Rogers scored his first tournament victory in two years today by holding off a challenge from David Edwards and winning the $400,000 New Orleans Open.

title: SALEM A-PLANT SAID TO EMPLOY INEFFECTIVE TEST
description: A routine test of the emergency shutdown system at the Salem nuclear plant in New Jersey is incapable of detecting the kind of failure that occurred last month, according to a utility spokesman.

title: NEW MUSIC: A FESTIVAL OF AMERICANS AT N.Y.U.
description: THE lack of public attention given to much music being written today by university-based composers is a commonplace fact of our musical life. But two years ago, in an attempt to change that situation, the American New Music Consortium was founded by the composer Dinu Ghezzo and other composers and performers involved in contemporary-music ensembles in the United States.

title: New League Plan Stirs N.F.L.
description: The National Football League's annual convention opened today with owners, general managers and coaches converging on this desert resort community for six days of meetings and there were signs that the N.F.L. is bracing for a disturbance from within its ranks.

title: NEWSBOY STABBED TO DEATH ON ROCKVILLE CENTRE ROUTE
description: A 14-year-old boy delivering Sunday newspapers in his neighborhood in Rockville Centre, L.I., was found stabbed to death yesterday morning less than two blocks from his home. It was believed to be the community's first homicide in years.

title: South Africa Pushes Fuel Plan
description: The glut on world oil markets has not deflected South Africa from ambitious plans to lower its dependence on foreign oil.

title: Sue Governments, Don't Gouge Them
description: New York has come a long way since the Legislature scrapped the doctrine of sovereign immunity 50 years ago and allowed negligence suits against state and city governments. Too far, in fact.

title: Shari Ann Kullback Wed
description: The marriage of Shari Ann Kullback, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Kullback of West Long Branch, N.J., to Bruce Canell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Canell of Englishtown, N.J., took place yesterday at Temple Beth Torah in Ocean, N.J. Rabbi Jonathan Waxman performed the ceremony.

title: 'Colored' Church Defies Pretoria
description: The largest church for South Africans of mixed race, known here as coloreds, has announced that it will perform interracial marriages and sanction civil disobedience in certain circumstances.

title: Thrift Units In Loan Pool
description: Twenty-three thrift institutions throughout the United States are forming the Financial American Network.

title: LIBEL AFTER DEATH?
description: Not content to confine their lawsuits to the inconvenient boundaries of mortality, litigious souls have long wondered, ''Is there libel after death?'' Last January, with his opinion in MacDonald v. Time Inc. et al , Judge H. Lee Sarokin of the Federal District Court in Newark pronounced that there was.

title: Soviet Aide Dismissed For Gross Corruption
description: The Soviet leadership has dismissed the Deputy Minister of Light Engineering for gross corruption and incompetence, the Communist Party daily Pravda said today.

title: BALBONI SENT TO MINORS
description: In many ways, today's exhibition game showed what's right with the Yankees, what's wrong with the Mets, and why Steve Balboni has been sent to the minor leagues.

title: Switch at Needham
description: Needham, Harper & Steers/New York may be doing without a president, but will be getting increased attention from Keith L. Reinhard, 48, chairman of the domestic company. The former president, Joel Baumwoll, 42, has become vice chairman, director of strategic planning of the company's U.S.A. unit, which also includes the Chicago office, the largest operation, and Los Angeles, the smallest.

title: BRIEFING
description: Stockman's Return

title: Deborah Lynn Rome Married to Dr. Ronald Szabo
description: Deborah Lynn Rome, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis B. Rome of Bloomfield, Conn., was married yesterday in West Hartford, Conn., to Dr. Ronald S. Szabo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lazar Szabo of the Bronx. Rabbi Harold S. Silver performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Israel.

title: At Home on the Road
description: It's going to be a little harder to sell all those tickets in the Carrier Dome in Syracuse this week. The home team won't be there. But St. John's will be glad to assume the role of home-state favorite for anybody who wants to adopt them next Friday against Georgia. The scrappy team from Queens might even throw in a behind-the-back schoolyard pass, the way Bob Kelly did yesterday in the middle of the big push that helped beat Rutgers, 66-55.

title: 2 SENATORS URGING ARMS POLICY SHIFT
description: Two Democratic Senators have called for changes in military policy, stressing a need for higher military spending by the nation's allies, sustained but slower growth in United States spending and changes in strategic plans.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Blue Bell Inc., Greensboro, N.C., appointed H. Varnell Moore to group vice president of European operations.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MARCH 21, 1983
description: International

title: EUROPEAN NATIONS UNABLE TO REACH MONETARY ACCORD
description: Eight Common Market finance ministers failed today to agree on new values for their currencies or on other steps to fend off the wave of speculation that has engulfed their financial markets in recent days.

title: Verderosa Stops O'Grady in 4th
description: Johnny Verderosa lived up to his nickname The Heat with a relentless attack that stopped Sean O'Grady in the fourth round of their junior welterweight bout today.

title: MARINE SAYS ISRAELIS FIRE INDISCRIMINATELY
description: The commander of the 1,200 United States marines in Lebanon said today that Israeli Army units were endangering civilians and marines with indiscriminate gunfire. He said the situation was due to the Israelis' ''gross lack'' of discipline.

title: SALVADOR'S LARGEST PARTY, SPLIT ON CANDIDATE, CUTS SHORT PARLEY
description: El Salvador's largest political party, the Christian Democrats, convened a presidential nominating convention today and then suspended it to avoid having to decide between two popular party leaders.

title: OPEC Retaliation Warning
description: OPEC will retaliate immediately if Britain cuts the price of its North Sea oil by more than 50 cents a barrel, the Middle East Economic Survey said today.

title: Wisconsin Gains
description: Top-rated Wisconsin routed St. Lawrence, 7-1, tonight and advanced to the final four of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament. Wisconson plays Providence and Minnesota meets Harvard Thursday night in the semifinals at Grand Forks, N.D.

title: TRADE CHIEF QUITS FRANCE'S CABINET
description: France's Minister of Foreign Trade, Michel Jobert, resigned today, saying he had not been given enough authority to carry out his assignment to close France's foreign trade deficit.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: * Rate depicted in Long- or Short-Term Rates chart.

title: NATALIA MAKAROVA FINDS BROADWAY ROLE A DELIGHT
description: CLAD in a scanty pink silk negligee, she lounges on a satinpillowed bed, her face obscured by the raised newspaper she is reading. Slowly, one perfectly sculptured leg rises in the air, points elegantly skyward and descends with mesmerizing deliberateness. Then the other leg begins to rise.

title: AUCTIONEER'S GAVEL FINALLY MOVES LUXURY CONDOMINIUMS IN MIAMI
description: Three hundred people spent a sunny afternoon today in the shade of a big white tent listening to the patter of an auctioneer hawking luxury condominiums, many of which were sold at discounts of 30 to 45 cents on the dollar.

title: More Talks Needed
description: Since Herschel Walker's switch from the University of Georgia of the Southeastern Conference to the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League, the necessity of an accommodation between college and professional football has become clearer than ever.

title: U.S. SOCIAL TOLERANCE OF DRUGS FOUND ON RISE
description: Social scientists believe that the level of public tolerance of the use of illegal drugs is continuing to rise in all levels of American society.

title: SYRIAN ARMY SAID TO BE STRONGER THAN EVER, THANKS TO SOVIET
description: The Soviet Union has replaced all the Syrian Army equipment destroyed by Israel in the invasion of Lebanon and has rebuilt Syria's ruined air defense system, according to Western military analysts here.

title: 'CHOPIN,' COMEDY FROM ITALY
description: ''CHOPIN'' is an odd title for Luciano Odorisio's spirited comedy, which turns out not to be about the composer himself, but about a small Italian provincial city, where a new orchestra is being assembled. There appears to be considerable competition for the conductor's job, and this provides Mr. Odorisio with what little excuse he needs for a plot. For the most part, though, his film is cheerfully anecdotal, without any well-defined center but with a wit and intelligence that help hold it together.

title: Spot Oil Response to Cut
description: The international spot market for crude oil demonstrated little enthusiasm last week for OPEC's agreement to lower prices by 15 percent. Spot prices rose sharply on Monday after the agreement was announced, but fell during the remainder of the week in anticipation of further cuts in official oil prices.

title: BUCKS STOP RALLY, DEFEAT NETS, 107-92
description: As a late winter storm dropped more than an inch of snow outside the Mecca here this evening, it looked as if the struggling Nets would be buried beneath an avalanche by the Milwaukee Bucks inside.

title: Miss Turnbull Winner
description: Wendy Turnbull seized the middle of the court and neutralized the more powerful Sylvia Hanika to win a $150,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament today, 6-3, 3-6, 6-4.

title: Messenger Seized In Securities Theft
description: A 19-year-old Wall Street messenger who said Wednesday that he was robbed of four $1 million negotiable bank certificates earlier that day was arrested last night and charged with the robbery, as was a man described as ''the father of his girlfriend'' by a police spokesman.

title: Comsat Planning Stock Split
description: Directors of the Communications Satellite Corporation have voted to recommend a two-for-one stock split to shareholders at the company's upcoming annual meeting. The Comsat board has also decided to recommend an increase in the number of authorized common shares from 25 million to 40 million.

title: Nkomo Denies Followers Killed a White Family
description: Joshua Nkomo, the Zimbabwean opposition leader who fled to London a week ago contending that Government troops had tried to kill him, denied today that his supporters had murdered a white farmer and his family as charged by the Zimbabwean Government.

title: FILM BRINGS JOHNSTOWN TEMPORARY AID
description: A movie about a star athlete trying to escape from a depressed steel town is good news for this hard-luck city with the nation's highest unemployment rate. It is creating temporary jobs.

title: MARYLAND'S SLOWDOWN FAILS
description: Only one team that dared to run with the Houston Cougars this season managed to beat them. That was Syracuse, a team that really doesn't know how to slow down. The score was 92-87, Dec. 11, at Syracuse.

title: BRUINS CLINCH TITLE BY HALTING RANGERS
description: There are no wrinkles to the Boston system. The Bruins play a brand of hockey that at times can be monotonous in its thoroughness. Wings remain on their wings. Everybody checks. It is straightforward, simple and successful.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Saturday incorrectly identified Walid Khalidi, a member of an Arab League delegation that visited Britain. Mr. Khalidi is not a member of the Palestine National Council or the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: NEW ORLEANS POLICE OFFICERS BACK 7 IN A CIVIL RIGHTS CASE
description: Witnesses for seven New Orleans policemen whose Federal civil rights trial enters its third week Monday have testified that no one was beaten in an investigation into the slaying of a white officer.

title: People
description: * Eric Bogedal, Norman Carrier, and Claudia Horty appointed senior vice presidents at Jordan, Case & McGrath.

title: Twister Hits Southern Town
description: A tornado swept through Leakesville this morning, damaging or destroying houses and other buildings in a five-block area, officials said. No injuries were reported, but 30 to 35 homes were damaged or destroyed.

title: Commodities; New Entry May Spur Changes
description: THE reception accorded the Chicago Board Options Exchange's ''C.B.O.E. 100'' options has set off a chain of events that could change the trading systems used by market specialists, analysts, portfolio managers and ordinary investors in stocks.

title: OF MRS. KIRKPATRICK AND THE SPIRIT OF FREE INQUIRY
description: To the Editor:

title: Homosexuals at Harvard Protesting Navy Hiring
description: A drive by homosexual students at Harvard University to hold a campus forum about Navy hiring practices threatens the university with the loss of $3 million in Defense Department funds, a university official said today.

title: Protesters Track Train; Warheads Believed on It
description: Advocates of a nuclear freeze tracked the westward route today of a slow-moving, heavily guarded freight train they believe is carrying nuclear warheads to the Trident nuclear submarine base at Bangor, Wash.

title: MONDAY, MARCH 21, 1983
description: Internatonal

title: Car Operating Costs Up
description: The per-mile cost of operating a 1982 compact car ranged from 57.08 cents in Los Angeles to 41.68 cents in Detroit, and averaged 47.21 cents in 20 major cities last year, the Hertz Corporation said yesterday. The average rose 1.09 cents, or 2.36 percent, from 1981, the vehicle rental company added.

title: SKEPTICS IN WEST HEAR CASE FOR U.S. LAND SALES
description: Federal land managers have begun trying to persuade skeptical Westerners that the Reagan Administration's proposal to sell off millions of acres of public lands will not pose a threat to the region's economy, environment or way of life.

title: WHAT RESTAURANTS SHOULDN'T THROW AWAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Marketing Preventive Car Care
description: AS car care follows the trend set by health care - with the ''general practitioner'' at the service station being replaced by muffler specialists, transmission specialists, body work specialists, glass specialists, air conditioning specialists and more - a specialist named Jiffy Lube is emerging as the hematologist of the aftermarket, prepared to maintain those precious auto-body fluids.

title: METS TRY 5 PLAYERS IN DOUBLE-PLAY ROLE
description: Five players are part of an experiment to find the best double-play combination for the Mets this season.

title: Confession Time in Guatemala
description: When Gen. Efrain Rios Montt talks, Guatemala listens. What it heard the other day was this odd message: ''We know and understand that we have sinned, that we have abused power, and we want to reconcile ourselves with the people.''

title: TWO FAMILIES TO A TWO-FAMILY HOUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Latins to Meet On Debt Crisis
description: Latin American finance ministers and officials from foreign banks are to meet here Monday to discuss the region's acute financial crisis and the decline in fresh credits from private banks.

title: Canada Inflation Down
description: Canada's annual inflation rate fell to 7.4 percent in February from 8.3 percent a month earlier, reaching its lowest level in six years, the Government has reported. The February rate was the lowest since February 1977, when it was 6.7 percent.

title: DANCE: CUNNINGHAM'S 'COAST ZONE'
description: MERCE CUNNINGHAM'S mercifully uncluttered dances, in all their purity, are as refreshing as a summer shower - an indoor shower, however, that can be unexpectedly scalding.

title: Pro Football In Name Only
description: IF the Generals were soldiers, they would deserve to be courtmartialed. But the Generals are what is known as a pro football team, only because they are paid to play; they are not a pro football team in the sense that they are professionals at what they do.

title: YANKS MAY JETTISON COSTLY NON-HITTERS
description: The Yankees' willingness to spend money on players will never be more glaringly conspicuous than if they release three veteran players in the final two weeks of spring training. One, John Mayberry, seems virtually certain to go any day now. The others who are of uncertain status with the Yankees are Butch Hobson and Bobby Murcer.

title: STAGE: THE RETURN OF INNAURATO'S 'BENNO BLIMPIE'
description: WITHOUT question, it is one of the most arresting theatrical bold strokes to open an American play of the last decade. A huge, sweaty, slobbering fat boy, almost big enough to float through the skies in a Macy's parade, gives the audience a weird-eyed leer and announces in a pinched voice: ''I am Benno. I am eating myself to death.''

title: HOWATT RECALLED
description: The New Jersey Devils today recalled the 30-year-old left wing Garry Howatt from Wichita of the Central Hockey League.

title: HOPE AT STORAGE TECHNOLOGY
description: The Storage Technology Corporation usually has proved itself lithe and resourceful, dancing in the shadow of the computer industry giant, the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: TV: 'INTIMATE AGONY,' A STORY ABOUT HERPES
description: ADVERTISING has brought us the heartbreak of psoriasis. Now a television movie offers a look at the problems of genital herpes. This is a serious matter, of course, to victims of either affliction, but one can't help being amazed at the ability of television to market or exploit just about anything.

title: IN EL PASO, HOPE FLOATS WITH PESO
description: The recession appears to have bottomed out in much of the rest of the country, but in border cities like El Paso, their economies shattered by devaluation of the Mexican peso, the predictions are that recovery may take two years or more. And no one is betting on that.

title: Climber's Death Reported
description: An Anchorage man who made a rare winter climb to the peak of Mount McKinley died in a fall near the top of North America's highest mountain, the National Park Service have reported. The climber, Robert Frank, died March 11 after reaching the top of the 20,300-foot mountain, officials said Saturday.

title: Gunman Kills One And Wounds Five
description: A 35-year-old Brooklyn man was shot and killed by a neighbor and five other people were wounded when a long-simmering dispute erupted in violence shortly before midnight Saturday, the police said yesterday.

title: PLAN FOR A GRAND PRIX IN PARK RAISES OBJECTIONS IN QUEENS
description: A proposal to have a Grand Prix auto race in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in September is causing a stir in Queens. So far it has produced a public-relations campaign by the promoter, a spate of black buttons saying ''Stop the Grand Prix'' and a lot of animated discussion at community board meetings about whether it would be good or bad for the park and for Queens. The proposal is for a race to be held every year for the next 10 years.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You know when you're kids, on a merry-go-round, you go to Central Park.

title: PENTAGON CHIEF'S OFFICE HAS A MUSEUM QUALITY
description: There may be times, perhaps as dusk settles over the Potomac outside his Pentagon office, when Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger might sense the presence of military ghosts. For his office is not just a place of work, but a museum as well.

title: NEW TALKS SEEK AN END TO STRIKE OF METRO-NORTH
description: Negotiations continued early this morning in an effort to settle the two-week-old strike against Metro-North Commuter Railroad. The talks began last night with both sides reaffirming the positions that had led to the walkout.

title:
ASSAYING THE HOUSING REVIVAL;
Economic Analysis
description: The nation's housing market has come back to life: interest rates have dropped, sales of both new and existing homes have surged and home builders all over the country are going back to work.

title: TWO FAMILIES TO A TWO-FAMILY HOUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: SAVINGS BANKS' STATE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW FLYERS STRESS FINESSE IN BID FOR UNTARNISHED CUP
description: THEIR two Stanley Cups carry a blemish, the indentations of Dave Schultz's knuckles. That image of the Broad Street Bullies may last forever.

title: Jodi Epstein, I. B. M. Aide, Wed to Michael B. Harger
description: Jodi Ann Epstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald K. Epstein of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Scarsdale Synagogue to Michael Bert Harger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Harger of Lafayette, Ind.

title: THE ODD DECOUPLE
description: A series of sensible arms control proposals made by the Reagan Administration - to eliminate theater nuclear weapons from Europe, or to make East and West equal - is under attack on three fronts: from the Russians, from most of our allies and from doves in the U.S. Congress.

title: Georgetown, Missouri Beaten
description: Keith Lee had 28 points and 15 rebounds to lead Memphis State to a 66-57 victory over Georgetown today in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Midwest Regional.

title: INDIANA AND LOUISVILLE ON TOP
description: Louisville and Indiana, playing the way favorites should, advanced to the final 16 today in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's basketball tournament.

title: Robert Goulet Is Arrested
description: The singer Robert Goulet was arrested Friday night and charged with drunken and hit-and-run driving and assault after his car hit a sign post and two parked vehicles.

title: EAST BLOC STRESSES COMPUTERS
description: The Leipzig Spring Fair, the premier trade fair for East-West business, emphasized last week the motto ''Programmed Efficiency Through Microelectronics,'' a reflection of what Western business executives and bankers said was a coordinated effort among East bloc economies.

title: HABIB MEETS WITH 2 KEY ISRAELIS
description: Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's special envoy to the Middle East, met with Israel's Foreign and Defense Ministers today to hear the Government's reply to new American proposals on the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon.

title: 53,370 SEE GENERALS LOSE AGAIN
description: The sun came out today, and so did 53,370 football enthusiasts to see Herschel Walker and the New Jersey Generals play for the first time at Giants Stadium. The crowd, the largest in the three-week history of the United States Football League, then saw the opposing team, the Tampa Bay Bandits, run right by the Generals and win, 32-9.

title: Film on Nuclear Incident Alarms Some Viewers
description: Switchboards lit up in television stations across the country tonight as viewers sought information about a television movie depicting a vivid, but fictional, nuclear attack by terrorists.

title: Elinor Marks and Mark Gordon Exchange Vows
description: The marriage of Elinor Marks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Marks of White Plains, to Mark Gordon, son of Adele Gordon of New York and the late Roy Gordon, took place yesterday at the Tappan Hill Restaurant in Tarrytown, N.Y. Cantor Raymond Smolover performed the ceremony.

title: REAGAN CAN FORESEE SUMMIT MEETING
description: President Reagan says that he can foresee a meeting sometime this year with Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, but that there are no plans for such a session.

title: Chile Expels a Third Priest
description: An Australian Roman Catholic priest, expelled by Chile for what it said were political activities, arrived in Lima today, church sources said. The priest, the Rev. Brian McMahon, arrived on a 30-day visa after being ordered out of Chile on Saturday. He was the third foreign priest expelled in the last few days.

title: THE KNICKS' BIG MAN STARTS TO TOUGHEN UP
description: BILL CARTWRIGHT certainly didn't look mean and nasty as he held his 15-month-old curly-haired son, Jason, in his huge hands, as if the child were a fragile stuffed toy.

title: NUCLEAR FREEZE PROPONENTS ARE NO APPEASERS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE JAPANESE CHALLENGE TO FRENCH FASHION
description: The Japanese assault on traditional Western fashion is rapidly gaining ground in this city that has set the styles for women for at least three centuries. The fashions that have swept in from the East represent a totally different attitude toward how clothes should look from that long established here. They aim to conceal, not reveal the body. They do not try to seduce through color or texture. They cannot be described in conventional terms because their shape is fluid, just as their proportions are overscale. Where the hemline is placed, or where the waistline is marked is simply immaterial.

title: RIVERFRONT BUSINESS AND HOUSING FOR QUEENS OFFERED BY PORT BODY
description: The Port Authority has prepared a plan to turn 70 acres of rundown Queens waterfront into a project with thousands of apartments and millions of square feet of commercial space.

title: Gilford Analyst Foresaw Baldwin Cash Problems
description: James S. Chanos, a 25-year-old securities analyst for Gilford Securities Inc. in Chicago, uses computer analysis to look for special situations in the companies he follows.

title: Royal Couple in Australia
description: The Prince and Princess of Wales arrived today with their infant son, Prince William, for a four-week visit to Australia. After a 23-hour flight from London, they landed at the Alice Springs airport and inspected flood damage in the normally arid heart of Australia. The family will use a farm in New South Wales as their base during the visit.

title: Eileen D. Lieberman Married to Dr. Frank Cicione
description: Eileen Darl Lieberman, a senior financial analyst at Paine Webber Jackson & Curtis, was married yesterday to Dr. Frank Joseph Cicione, principal of the Kramer Lane Elementary School in Bethpage, L.I. The ceremony was performed at the Thatched Cottage, caterer, in Centerport, L.I., by Rabbi Nathaniel Schwartz and the Rev. James Wentz, a Unitarian minister from Freeport, L.I.

title: ROCK: WEATHER REPORT SINGS
description: WEATHER REPORT broke 12 years of precedent Saturday at the Beacon Theater by performing a song with lyrics. The drummer Omar Hakim and the bassist Victor Bailey sang while the keyboardist and composer Josef Zawinul sang through a vocoder (which gives electronic pitches to vocal phrases).

title: More Hiring Is Forecast
description: Employment opportunities should improve in the next three months, according to a survey of employers conducted by Manpower Inc., a leading company in providing temporary workers. A poll of 11,175 employers in 348 cities found 21 percent who said they would hire more workers in the second quarter, up from 19 percent a year earlier and the highest such figure since 1981. The number of employers who expected further cuts in staff fell to 8 percent, from 13 percent a year earlier.

title: BON AMI NOW SCRATCHES FOR SOAP MARKET SHARE
description: Third place in the soap business means little when first and second places are held by Procter & Gamble and Colgate-Palmolive. For Bon Ami, a soap that is older than most of its competition, third place means 5 percent of the $130 million powder cleanser market - and plenty of frustration.

title: HEAVY FIGHTING IN NICARAGUA REPORTED BY REBELS
description: A radio station run by rightist Nicaraguan rebels said today that heavy fighting was under way between guerrillas and Government forces in Nicaragua.

title: Afghan Chemical Arms Linked to U.S. by Soviet
description: The Soviet press charged today that the United States was training Afghan guerrillas to use chemical weapons. The Soviet Union has repeatedly denied American charges that Soviet troops in Afghanistan are using chemical weapons and that Soviet-backed forces in Indochina are also engaged in chemical warfare.

title: Children Learn to Make Zucchini Pie and Things
description: Whipping up specialties learned in their nutrition education classes, 31 children from seven South Bronx elementary schools joined forces last week to prepare lunch for parents, teachers and school officials.

title: Ethiopian Victor In Cross-Country
description: Bekelee Debele, a little-known Ethiopian, beat five former champions and several other established distance runners in capturing the world cross-country championship today.
