title: TRIAL IN CBS MURDER CASE TO BEGIN TODAY
description: Today, almost a year after a Federal witness and three CBS employees were shot to death in a Hudson River pier parking lot, the trial of Donald Nash is scheduled to begin with jury selection.

title: Great Western Sees Success on Merger
description: James F. Montgomery tried it once before and failed, but this time he plans to wrap up the deal. Mr. Montgomery, chairman and chief executive of California's Great Western Financial Corporation, parent of the nation's second biggest savings and loan, thinks the way is clear to finally acquire Financial Federation Inc.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: With a runner on third base and no one out, the batter hits a fair ball that rebounds and strikes his bat, which he has dropped in fair territory as he runs toward first. The ball stays fair and the runner on third scores. What is the ruling?

title: OUTDOORS: SHOOTING PRESERVE IS BOON FOR HUNTERS
description: BECAUSE he had been blessed with a wife and a son, and I with six grandchildren since we last hunted together for woodcock and Hungarian partridge in New York State - it was to be expected that John Falk of South Salem, N.Y., and I had a great deal to tell each other, so much so, indeed, that it was after 2 A.M. when we lurched off to bed.

title: U.S. Holds Off on Appealing Ruling on Student Aid Curb
description: The Justice Department is planning to defend the law requiring draft registration as a condition for receiving Federal student loans, but it will not immediately appeal a preliminary injunction against enforcing the law.

title: ALEXANDER FELDMAN
description: Alexander Feldman, a lawyer and wholesale news distributor, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 73 years old.

title: A LONG JOURNEY OF FEAR, A REFUGE OF HOPE FOR CAMBODIANS
description: For the moment, they have found peace. ''I am happy now,'' said Chuon Luon, one of 44 Cambodian refugees driven from Brooklyn by beatings and robberies they could escape no other way. ''I feel safe. For the last two nights, I have been able to sleep.''

title: SALES LAG FOR MET'S VATICAN SHOW
description: Midweek tickets for the ''Vatican Collections: The Papacy and Art'' are now being sold, first come, first served, at the door of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: ST. JOHN'S GAINS IN N.C.A.A.
description: At its best, the St. John's team that has now won 28 games this season, more than any other in the school's history, has been described as appearing ugly. Its appearance this afternoon in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, for most of the first half of the second-round Eastern Regional game against Rutgers, was almost beyond description.

title: OPERA: NIGHT OF OFFENBACH BY BEL CANTO
description: THE Bel Canto Opera gave us two rarities from Offenbach's seemingly bottomless fund of musical works for the stage Saturday night. Both were one-act affairs; both concerned the subject of lotteries; both used three characters each, and both mixed hasty, often cursory, dramatic craftsmanship with music of great charm and substance.

title: Porsche Team Wins at Sebring
description: A Porsche with 36,000 racing miles on it driven by Wayne Baker, Jim Mullen and Kees Nierop upstaged experimental prototypes and turbo-driven racers Saturday night to win the 12 Hours of Sebring road race.

title: OHIO STATE DEFEATS SYRACUSE
description: Ohio State, stymied during the first 20 minutes by Syracuse's stubborn zone defense, tried a change of tactics after the intermission that produced bountiful results today at Hartford Civic Center.

title: Puopola Wins Run
description: Joe Puopola of the Fairfield County Striders registered a 50-yard victory over Jim Brosnan of the Westchester Road Runners yesterday in the Bronx five-mile run through the streets of Riverdale. Puopola was clocked in 26 minutes 27 seconds. Mary Beth Evans of Barnard/Columbia took the women's gold medal in 30:14.

title: RATE DROP PERCEIVED AS DISTANT
description: Interest rates are still widely expected to decline later this year, but in the minds of traders and Government securities dealers, a significant drop is not likely in the immediate future.

title: REFRACTORY MAKER STAKES ITS SURVIVAL ON A RESTRUCTURING
description: When American steel production began a free fall in 1980, the General Refractories Company and others that make refractory tiles for lining steel furnaces had a choice: shrink or die.

title: WOMEN ARE INCREASING LEAD IN ENROLLMENT ON CAMPUSES
description: Women are going to college in ever-increasing numbers, expanding their enrollment lead over men, and the average age of college students is creeping upward, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

title: PROF. LOUIS BRENNAN, 72, DIES
description: Louis A. Brennan, professor of field archeology at the Briarcliff, N.Y., campus of Pace University, died of arteriosclerosis Friday at his home in Ossining, N.Y. He was 72 years old.

title: IN BROOKLYN, LITTLE SUCCOR FOR VICTIMS OF ASIA
description: It was a tenuous refuge. Simple things like walking down the street, accompanying a child to school, turning off the lights to one's apartment had become exercises in courage. Residents say that, even in daylight, muggings and brutality had become as commonplace as hopscotch in the summer sun.

title: WEI AND KELLER TEAMS SEEK WOMEN'S KNOCKOUT TITLE
description: Teams led by Kathie Wei of New York and Brenda Keller of Boise, Idaho, battled here today in the final of the Women's Knockout Team Championship, concluding the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals. After 32 deals, Mrs. Wei led Miss Keller by 18 international match points.

title: Washington Watch; Tax Refunds Trail '82 Level
description: SOMETHING of a mystery has developed at the Internal Revenue Service. Although some Wall Street analysts have been expecting record tax refunds this year - one predicts they will total $65 billion, up from $55 billion last year - they say they seem to be running sharply behind the 1982 level.

title: Princeton Beaten; Las Vegas Is Upset
description: Frigid second-half shooting cost Princeton a chance for an upset in a 51-42 loss today to Boston College, and North Carolina State gathered another last-second postseason victory, upsetting Nevada-Las Vegas by 71-70, in second-round West Regional games of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: I.B.M. Aims Joint Ventures at Japan
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is becoming increasingly aggressive in the battle with its Japanese competitors in their own backyard.

title: 2 DEALER GROUPS PLAN MERGER
description: Plans are being made to merge the Association of Primary Dealers with the Government and Agency Securities division of the Public Securities Association, according to officials of the two organizations. ''It is our expectation that a vote on the merger will take place in the near future,'' they said Friday in a statement.

title: VENEZUELA, ITS EYE ON OIL, FINDS ITS FARMS FALTERING
description: There is a lot of heroic statuary in Venezuelan town squares and city parks celebrating the nation's past, but the symbol of its present could well be the forlorn image of two young planters standing in their barren fields outside this farming community.

title: No Headline
description: Baseball

title: Rochelle Moss Is Married To Dr. Richard Holzman
description: Rochelle Moss, a teacher in the New York City schools, was married yesterday to Dr. Richard B. Holzman, superintendent of schools in Teaneck, N.J. Rabbi Paul Teicher performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's mother, Nettie Holzman, in Farmingdale, L.I.

title: WESTWAYGATE
description: Trade-in, livelier than ever, is looking better for New York every day -the result of almost unnoticed Congressional action that became law in January.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: 7 Painters and Sculptors Chosen for Art Awards
description: Seven painters and sculptors have been named winners of the 1983 art awards of the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters. Prizes of $5,000 each will be given to Jennifer Bartlett, Susan Rothenberg, Angelo Savelli and Michael C. Spafford, painters, and to Carl Andre, sculptor.

title: CONCERT: JOCY DE OLIVEIRA
description: TO one who has a weakness for the vaulted dome of a planetarium lit with stars, as I do, the composer Jocy de Oliveira could have played nearly any music she liked at the Hayden Planetarium on Wednesday night.

title: 223 Minutes in Penalties
description: Brad Maxwell's goal at 14:58 of the third period, seconds after play had resumed following a bench clearing brawl, gave the Minnesota North Stars a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight.

title: Stocks Gain; Dow Climbs 7.55
description: The stock market rose moderately yesterday, with some of the technology and energy issues registering the largest gains. In the overall market, advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored stocks that declined by 848 to 729. Trading volume on the Big Board contracted to 72.2 million shares, from 75.1 million shares on Friday.

title: News Analysis
description: Today's European currency realignment marked another milestone in the evolution of the economic policy of France's two-year-old Socialist Government.

title: An Uneasy Ribicoff
description: FORMER United States Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut is an elder in the Democratic party, a man of rare dignity and as staunch a supporter of its younger members as a grand seigneur is supposed to be. So it isn't that he doesn't genuinely like the array of Democrats running for President. He does, heaps praise upon them individually and considers each a friend. But what troubles him these early days of the 1984 campaign is that not one of the contenders has proposed what he considers a fully developed program for dealing with the nation's problems or a process by which the goals may be achieved.

title: BELDING HEMINWAY CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $417,000 on the sale of investments

title: Heavy Rains in Peru Cause the Death of 50
description: Heavy rains and mudslides buried at least two towns in northern Peru and killed more than 50 people, the authorities said today. At least 500 others were missing, many of them presumed dead.

title: A WAKE FOR WESTWAY
description: There is no longer any way for the proponents of Westway, no matter how well-intentioned their beliefs about the proposed megadevelopment, to separate the scandal that keeps oozing out of the project from the merits of the plan itself.

title: Ashton Phelps, 69, Is Dead; New Orleans News Executive
description: Ashton Phelps, chairman of the board of the Times-Picayune Publishing Corporation, died today at the Ochsner Foundation Hospital after a brief illness. He was 69 years old.

title: U.S. BACKS BANK SEAT FOR CHINA
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to support China's request to join the Asian Development Bank, but it is trying to prevent the expulsion of Taiwan, Administration officials said today.

title: BRANIFF TO SELL JETS TO PEOPLE EXPRESS
description: Braniff Airways announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to sell 20 Boeing 727-200 planes to People Express Airlines for $80 million and to lease to the low-cost carrier a 747-200 aircraft.

title: Foreign Trade Bills Opposed
description: The Reagan Administration today opposed legislation aimed at striking down unfair foreign competition, saying the bills were so broadly drawn they would have a chilling effect on legitimate trade as well.

title: Peacekeepers Astray
description: Devious theories abound, but no known facts can explain or excuse the spectacle of American marines and Israeli soldiers sparring in the streets of Beirut and on television screens around the world. Whatever their quarrels, both nations boast disciplined military forces. Any real disputes in Lebanon should have been settled weeks ago, at the highest levels if necessary. For the Reagan Administration now to let soldiers inflame the controversy with poisonous political speculation about Israel is diplomacy at its sleaziest.

title: FAILED JERSEY BANK IS GIVEN NEW LIFE
description: Monday is usually a busy day at the Pan American National Bank, but today seemed especially so. Eight tellers waited on a crowded lobby of customers, while upstairs a squadron of auditors, hunching over computers and adding machines, burrowed their way into the bank's books.

title: MONFORT OF COLORADO (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
description: B-Including tax credits of $1.4 million for the qr and $3 million for the 6 mos

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: HOW SAFE ARE PRESCRIPTION DRUGS?
description: ON a Thursday evening earlier this month, a Syracuse television station reported that five people had died after taking the prescription painkiller Zomax. By Friday evening, the story had been nationally reported, trading in the manufacturer's stock had been halted and the drug had been pulled off the market - though no one knew if five deaths were a high or low figure or if the deaths were in any concrete sense really attributable to the drug.

title: A NIMBLE BAILEY GETS THE BIG BASKET
description: Thurl Bailey, 6 feet 11 inches tall, is quick on his feet and has been described in one pro scouting report as having ''great arm extension.''

title: Of Swords and Plows
description: ''Jobs for Peace'' is a practical necessity, according to speakers asking the City Council yesterday to urge Congress to increase social spending at the expense of the military.

title: Utah Educator Named Thrift Agency Director
description: Dr. David W. Glenn, a University of Utah finance professor, has been named director of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

title: PAGURIAN CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I guess my immediate task, as I see it, is to stabilize E.P.A., is to reinstill in the people there the dedication to their task, to their jobs that they have had from the outset of that agency, and to get on with this enormously complicated job of cleaning up our air and water and protecting our citizens against toxic substances.'' - William D. Ruckelshaus. (A22:3.)

FIRST MATAGORDA CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-The yr-ago revs figures was not immediately available

title: A QUARTERBACK WITH HANDCUFFS
description: Situations Wanted QUARTERBACK - Awaiting offer as National Football League free agent. Passed for 162 touchdowns and 27,139 yards with San Diego Chargers; 10 seasons experience. All-Pro stature. Seeking highest N.F.L. salary.

title: NEW WAYS TO PAY THE COSTS OF COLLEGE
description: WITH college costs rising and Federal funds shrinking, it is no wonder that more parents are panicky about finding the money to finance their children's higher education. But some solutions are being offered. St. Olaf College in Northfield, Minn., gives parents the bad news that the total estimated four-year cost for a student enrolling this fall will be $36,600. But then the college has some good news.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: This city never seemed richer - in ideas, in creativity, in craftsmanship, but, most especially, in controversy and turmoil. The past week of ready-to-wear showings may go down in fashion history as the Siege of Paris, for the Japanese appear to be making inroads in what has always been a French game.

title: Consoltex Canada
description: Consoltex Canada's president, Danny Taran, and three other directors were removed from office on a motion by controlling shareholders, Vantona-Viyella P.L.C., which has a 49.5 percent stake, and the Toyobo Company, which has 23.5 percent. They had said in a circular that they had lost confidence in the officers. David Alliance, chairman of Vantona-Viyella, said after the special meeting of stockholders that Consoltex, a textile concern, would continue operating as an independent company and that no parts of it were for sale.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball

title: Anglo American
description: The Anglo American Corporation and Cie Financiere de Paris et Pays-Bas Group said they had agreed in principle to separate their two joint holding companies set up under an agreement made in 1965. Anglo American has taken the opportunity to acquire 879,100 additional shares in De Beers Consolidated Mines from Luxaf, one of the joint holding companies, thereby increasing its interest in De Beers to 34.2 percent. De Beers has increased its interest in Anglo American to 38.5 percent by buying 568,660 Anglo American shares from Luxaf.

title: E.P.A. Was Warned of Danger In Dallas Lead, Ex-Aide Says
description: Officials of the Environmental Protection Agency ignored warnings two years ago that lead contamination in two neighborhoods here posed an immediate danger, a former toxicologist for the agency says.

OPPENHEIMER & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Oppenheimer & Co is an indirect wholly owned subsidiary of Mercantile House

title: Iran's Tourists Clash With Police in Syria
description: The police clashed with Iranian tourists trying to put up pictures of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini at the new airport, witnesses said today.

description: FROM GREECE

description: Batus Plans Consolidation

title: HAPPY TO BE COACHING GIRLS
description: Sitting in his part-time office at Marlboro (N.Y.) High School in Ulster County last week, Jim Van Allen, head coach of the girls' basketball team, lit his third cigarette in 20 minutes as he contemplated an upcoming game.

title: CROWLEY MILNER & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SCIENTIST SAYS INTERFERON MAY BE LINKED TO AIDS
description: People with a deadly disease that affects the body's autoimmune system carry an unusual form of interferon, the body's natural disease fighter, according to a scientist who suggests that using the substance to treat the disease could make it worse.

title: Rates Steady in Quiet Trading; 6-Month Bills Yield 8.535%
description: Interest rates were unchanged to slightly lower in very quiet trading yesterday, as market participants prepared for Treasury note and bond auctions totaling $13.5 billion during the next three days.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in New York Day by Day yesterday incorrectly identified the lyricist of a song sung by Mayor Koch at the annual dinner of the Inner Circle. He is Maury Yeston.

title: TV: EL SALVADOR COVERAGE ON THE EVENING NEWS
description: A MONTH'S viewing of the evening news programs suggests that there are shortcomings in the treatment of El Salvador. Sometimes the programs present the news about El Salvador tardily, sometimes they get it confused and sometimes they focus on the rhetoric rather than the reality.

title: DONOVAN COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,110,000 for the qr and $4,895,000 for the yr and a credit of $756,000 for the yr from an accounting change...C-Net income including a gain of $38,000 for the qr and a loss of $791,000 for the yr from discontinued operations

title: Food Imports By China
description: China, an important buyer of grain from the United States, may reduce its imports of all farm products, according to a report to Congress.

title: Mennen Civil Suit
description: The Mennen Company said it had filed a civil suit against the Gillette Company and its advertising agency, Young & Rubicam, to enjoin the distribution and sale of Gillette's Right Guard deodorant and antiperspirant line.

title: OILERS 4, LEAFS 1
description: Wayne Gretzky scored a goal and had two assists to lead Edmonton.

description: B-Including a gain of $342,000 for the qr and 9 mos on the sale of idle facilities...C-Including gains of $95,000 for the qr and $343,000 for the 9 mos on the sale of idle facilities

title: Kenya Gets I.M.F. Loan
description: The International Monetary Fund today approved a $190 million loan to Kenya to shore up the country's ailing economy. Under an agreement with the I.M.F., Kenya has been granted a standby credit worth 175.95 million special drawing rights, the I.M.F.'s own currency, to run for 18 months.

title: WIND SHIFT RULED CAUSE OF CRASH AT NEW ORLEANS
description: The National Transportation Safety Board ruled yesterday that a violent wind shift and downdraft was the primary cause of the crash of a jet shortly after takeoff last July near New Orleans.

title: 10,000 Stand in Rain For $4.50 Cleveland Jobs
description: Thousands of unemployed workers, welfare mothers and teen-agers, some standing in freezing rain for four hours, applied today for $4.50-an-hour public service jobs.

title: People
description: * Mark Morris has been elected an executive vice president of Ted Bates Advertising/New York.

title: DRUG ABUSE IN AMERICA: WIDENING ARRAY BRINGS NEW PERILS
description: AMERICAN hotel guests in Cuzco, Peru, 12,000 feet high in the Andes, are sometimes surprised at being offered coca tea to help them adjust to the altitude. But it seems to help and they probably suffer no ill effects. Peruvian Indians have been using it for generations. ''At the other end of the spectrum,'' said Dr. Robert Byck of Yale University, an expert on cocaine, ''is a man I encountered who was spending $400,000 a year, buying cocaine by the half pound, and shooting it intravenously. He was sitting in a blacked-out cellar with an M-1 rifle, shooting at his hallucinations.''

title: ANTHONY BLISS TO RETIRE AS MANAGER OF THE MET
description: Anthony A. Bliss will retire as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera on July 31, 1985, the company announced yesterday. A search committee has been formed to select his successor.

Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA CONFIDENT
description: Martina Navratilova, who has not lost a singles set all year, drew Hana Mandlikova as her opening-round opponent in the $350,000 Virginia Slims of New York tennis championships starting tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden. The Navratilova-Mandlikova match will be played Thursday night.

title: THERE'S NO 'IF' IN THE PERSHING 2'S PERFORMANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Caracas Bid In U.S. Seen
description: Venezuela is trying to follow Kuwait and buy oil refining facilities in oil importing countries, including the United States, John H. Lichtblau, an oil industry analyst, said today.

title: EUROPEAN NATIONS AGREE TO REALIGN THEIR CURRENCIES
description: Eight European nations agreed today to realign their currencies after West Germany accepted French demands and agreed to a set of currency values that avoided the possible collapse of the European Monetary System.

title: Redfern Purchase
description: The Redfern Foods Corporation, Atlanta, said it had agreed to issue 1.2 million shares of common stock to acquire the Byers Communications Corporation.

title: Washington Pulls Back Shift on Public Housing
description: The Government, facing a concerted attack, withdrew a proposal critics said would have sharply curtailed improvements on the nation's public housing, according to a memo made public today.

title: VALENTINO SHINES IN PARIS, AMID STRONG FRENCH SHOWS
description: Fashion followers may appreciate innovation, but like anyone else they are most comfortable with the familiar. And so the throngs covering the fall and winter ready-to-wear openings recovered their equilibrium today after the culture shock induced earlier by the revolutionary showings of the major Japanese designers.

title: Newspaper Loses Appeal On Confidential Sources
description: In a major defeat for the news media, the Court of Appeals of the State of Washington ruled today that criminal defendants could force reporters to reveal confidential sources if the information was crucial to the case.

title: 12 Nations Sign Accord On Transfer of Prisoners
description: Ten West European countries and the United States and Canada today signed an agreement enabling offenders jailed by foreign courts to serve their sentences in their home country.

title: Hoax for a Soggy Day
description: The following advisory, marked ''Urgent,'' was transmitted over a news wire at 1:50 P.M. yesterday, the first day of spring: ''The National Weather Service says that for the first time in history, a 'typhoon watch' has been issued for the New York metropolitan area.'' The dispatch went on to quote ''Robert Parker,'' identified as ''a Weather Service spokesman.''

Newell Foster, Official At the Statue of Liberty
description: Newell H. Foster Sr., a former superintendent of the Statue of Liberty National Monument, died of pneumonia Friday at Bath Memorial Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in his native Newcastle.

title: LEVI CLIMBS SHARPLY; GENERAL MILLS DOWN
description: Levi Strauss & Company reported yesterday that earnings for the fiscal first quarter ended Feb. 27 more than doubled, to $35.1 million, or 84 cents a share, from $17 million, or 41 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 8 percent, to $576.4 million, from $534 million.

title: City College Picks Mandela
description: The president of City College said today that an honorary Doctor of Laws degree would be given to Nelson Mandela, a founder of the African National Congress, the banned group that seeks an end to South Africa's apartheid system. Dr. Bernard W. Harleston said he would seek the help of the State Department to arrange the direct presentation of the degree to Mr. Mandela, who has been imprisoned since 1963.

title: HOUSE WRANGLING ON BUDGET HITS HIGH GEAR
description: The 1983 budget battle moved into high gear today as the House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., and the Republican minority exchanged harsh accusations.

title: New England Pact For Quebec Power
description: New England electric companies signed an 11-year contract today for importing Canadian electricity, a plan expected to save the region hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Israel Will Reportedly Set Up New West Bank Settlements
description: The Israeli Government plans to set up 15 more military settlements in the West Bank this year and has decided to convert eight others to civilian status, the Israeli radio said today.

title: SWAN RETAINS HIS CONFIDENCE
description: Any other pitcher who would give up 28 hits and 19 runs in 11.1 innings, even though it happened in three meaningless spring games, might be worried. Not Craig Swan.

title: HOUSE AND SENATE CONFEREES SETTLE ON $4.6 BILLION EMPLOYMENT PLAN
description: House and Senate conferees agreed tonight on an emergency job bill that would provide about $4.6 billion to create employment opportunities and provide humanitarian aid for jobless workers.

title: Loan Rates Cut For Consumers
description: The Bank of New York cut its interest rates on consumer loans yesterday by from 1 to 3 1/2 percentage points. The new rates are effective tomorrow.

title: NEW IMPACT STUDY ORDERED FOR LINCOLN WEST COMPLEX
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday invalidated the city's approval of the Lincoln West luxury-housing proposal. The justice, Richard W. Wallach, said the developer could not proceed unless a new environmental-impact study was prepared and approved.

title: JUSTICES AGREE TO DEFINE SCOPE OF DEATH ROW APPEAL PROCESS
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to define the scope of the review that a state supreme court must undertake when hearing an appeal from a death sentence.

title: Bridge:; Wei Team Captures Crown In the Women's Knockout
description: The Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League ended here Sunday night with the Women's Knockout Team title going to a star-studded group headed by Kathie Wei of New York.

title: MEN-ONLY SCHOLARSHIP FUND IS VOIDED FOR SCHOOL DISTRICT
description: A New York State appeals court ruled yesterday that a private benefactor could not establish a college scholarship fund restricted to men if the fund was to be administered by a public-school district.

description: B-Net loss; the company is operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal BankruptcyCode

title: ROZELLE PUTS STRIKE COST AT $200 MILLION
description: The 57-day players strike that shortened the 1982 National Football League season to nine regular season games cost the league $200 million in lost revenues, Pete Rozelle, the N.F.L. commissioner, said today.

SOFTWARE WITH RELIGIOUS THEMES
description: BACK in my youth, when we read science fiction rather than lived it, I was deeply influenced by a short story called ''The Nine Billion Names of God,'' by Arthur C. Clarke.

title: Reagan Asks Soviet Pullout
description: President Reagan, in a written and tape recorded statement for what is New Year's Day in much of Southwest Asia, urged the Soviet Union today to ''end the bloodshed'' in Afghanistan, which its troops entered in 1979.

title: COSMIC 'BRIDGES' SUGGEST QUASARS ARE NEARER EARTH
description: RECEIVED astronomical wisdom holds that nothing yet seen in the universe is farther away than the peculiar objects called quasars. Now, however, special processing of telescope photographs is providing ammunition for dissenters who think quasars may not be so far out after all.

title: ASSOCIATED MAY BUY DISCOUNTER
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, which owns Lord & Taylor, Caldor and other leading retailers, is negotiating to acquire Loehmann's Inc., the large, women's fashion discount chain, trade sources said yesterday.

title: BANKING ISSUE DELAYS SENATE SOCIAL SECURITY ACTION
description: The Senate's effort to complete work today on legislation to restore financial health to the Social Security system became entangled in another effort to make adjustments in the tax-withholding plan for interest and dividends.

title: Coast Symphony To Tour the U.S.
description: The San Francisco Symphony will make an 11-city tour of the United States, it was announced today by Dianne Feinstein, Mayor of San Francisco.

title: Peking Objects to U.S. Plan To Widen Taiwan Arms Sales
description: China said today that it had objected to the United States over plans to deliver a record $1.58 billion worth of arms to Taiwan in the next two years.

title: HARVARD TO DIRECT WILLIAMS BEQUEST
description: The playwright Tennessee Williams changed his will in December to empower Harvard University to administer the bulk of his $10 million estate instead of the University of the South, officials of the Tennessee school said today.

title: Teen-Ager Found Guilty In Idaho Jail Slaying
description: A 17-year-old inmate was convicted today of first-degree murder in the jailhouse beating of Christopher Peterman, a teen-ager jailed for failing to pay $73 in traffic fines and court costs.

title: U.S. PANEL CALLS FOR PATIENTS' RIGHT TO END LIFE
description: A Presidential commission proposed yesterday that mentally competent patients be allowed to halt medical treatment that keeps them alive without any hope of curing or ameliorating their condition.

title: ALL RAIL STRIKERS GUARANTEED JOBS
description: In what he said was his final offer in the 16-day-old strike against the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that he would guarantee the jobs of all 622 striking union members.

title: Comings and Goings
description: An elbow problem may cost John Candelaria his opening-day pitching assignment for the Pittsburgh Pirates. Candelaria has been suffering from tendinitis in his left elbow and left training camp late last week to consult with an orthopedic specialist.

title: City College to Honor jailed Apartheid Opponent
description: Breaking a policy of not granting honorary degrees to people who can't pick them up in person, City College will award an honorary Doctor of Laws degree in June to Nelson Mandela, the opponent of apartheid who has been imprisoned, under life sentence, in South Africa since 1963. Mr. Mandela, 65 years old, is a lawyer and founder of the African National Congress Youth League.

title: Truman Award to Mrs. King
description: The annual Harry S. Truman Public Service Award will be be given to Coretta Scott King, selected by the Truman Award Commission to receive the honor for her and her late husband, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The award will presented May 6 at the Truman library and museum here.

title: Ashland-Exxon
description: Ashland Oil Inc. said it planned to buy about 132 retail gasoline stations in Ohio and Kentucky from the Exxon Corporation.

title: U.S. Favoring More Growth
description: A senior United States official said today that ''sound domestic policies'' were needed to achieve the ''sustained global growth'' that alone would overcome the serious strains on the international financial, trade and monetary systems. He especially cited the problems of large debts among developing nations.

title: QUEST MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; the yr-ago net includes a tax benefit of $14,906

title: N.C. State Placed On Probation
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today put North Carolina State on one-year probation for football recruiting violations that occurred during the 1981-82 school year.

title: Shell Sees Decline
description: The Shell Oil Company will probably report a drop in earnings for the first quarter from those of a year earlier, John Bookout, president, said. In 1982's first period, Shell earned $345 million, or $1.12 a share, on revenues of $4.79 billion. Mr. Bookout told a news conference at the annual meeting of the National Petroleum Refiners' Association that the earnings decline would probably be due primarily to problems in the refining and marketing segments of Shell's operations. He added that exploration and production earnings would be damaged by the slide in crude oil prices.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD UP 9.3 MILLION SHARES
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 7.5 percent, or 9.3 million shares, in the month ended March 15, to 133.8 million shares. Last year the short interest totaled 85.7 million shares.

title: Pryor's Commitments
description: Aaron Pryor's World Boxing Association junior welterweight title defense on April 2 is in jeopardy after a Common Pleas court ruling yesterday that kept in effect Pryor's contract with his manager, Buddy LaRosa.

title: NEW YORK: THE WORLD FINANCIAL MARKET
description: It was an unusual assortment of people who met in the boardroom of the Bankers Trust Company last fall, and the purpose of the meeting was as exotic as the gathering - to develop gold and diamond deposits in Guinea in West Africa.

title: Q&A
description: Q. How can you protect yourself if an elevator falls? Some people say to jump up and down, giving yourself a 50-50 chance of being in the air when the car lands. Would that help?

title: Col. William J. Walsh; Led New York Regents
description: Col. William J. Walsh, retired, who served as Chancellor of the State Board of Regents in the 1940's and as executive assistant director of the New York City Selective Service Administration from 1940 to 1942, died Sunday at the West Palm Beach-Martin County (Fla.) Hospital. He was 84 years old, and had homes in Hobe Sound, Fla., and Greenwich, Conn.

PIANIST: MAURIZIO POLLINI PLAYS
description: THE pianist Maurizio Pollini opened his particularly uncompromising Friday night concert in Avery Fisher Hall with Beethoven's ''Diabelli'' Variations. Mr. Pollini's performance had a strong sense of structural unity, yet remained wonderfully elastic - from the gentle but forthright exposition of the theme through the pianistic carillon that he unleashed in one memorable later moment of the work.

title: Paying Back the Park
description: ''I was jogging last April,'' recalled 47-year-old Jane W. Present, ''and I'm a terribly old person so I was going rather slowly, but I passed an awful lot of people. Suddenly, I realized that if everyone who used Central Park on one weekend paid $1, we could raise a fortune.''

title: ISRAELIS TO SHARE LESSONS OF WAR WITH PENTAGON
description: Israel agreed today to share with the United States information on Soviet military equipment and tactics gained from the Lebanon war without insisting on a new intelligence-sharing accord, American and Israeli officials said.

title: RAPHAEL TAPESTRIES IN SISTINE CHAPEL
description: Raphael returned to the Sistine Chapel today in a homecoming that was 456 years overdue and that will last only a week. Few among the steady flow of visitors knew that the eight great tapestries hung at eye level along the chapel's walls were the design of Raphael and had not hung there since 1527.

title: Stars Win, 17-10
description: Kelvin Bryant of Philadelphia rushed for 176 yards and scored a touchdown tonight as the Stars' defeated the Birmingham Stallions, 17-10, in a United States Footbal League game. Less than 13,000 spectators turned out at Legion Field. Bryant's touchdown made it 17-7 and came on a 1-yard plunge after Allen Harvin dashed 67 yards with the second-half kickoff to set up the Stars (3-0) at the 21 of the Stallions (1-2).

title: 3 SENATORS URGE CUT IN SALVADOR AID REQUEST
description: Three senators joined today in proposing a sharp reduction in the military aid for El Salvador requested by President Reagan and called for ''unconditional discussions'' with the Salvadoran rebels.

The tension between proponents of a nuclear arms freeze and advocates of modernization of the United States' strategic forces seems to be intensifying as increasing numbers of Americans focus on these issues. The friction is aggravated by a widespread perception that arms control negotiations with the Soviet Union are stalled and by questions about the direction and focus of programs for modernizing our strategic forces.

title: G.E. Telephones
description: The General Electric Company announced its entry into the consumer telephone business, introducing a line of phones ranging in price from an extension phone with a suggested list price of $44 to a cordless phone for $200. title: CAPTIVE BREEDING MAY BE LAST HOPE OF 'SEA COW'
description: MANATEES, the seafaring mammals once thought to be mermaids, may soon go the way of dinosaurs and woolly mammoths unless their only enemies human beings -become their active protectors.

title: DIRKS GETS HIS DAY IN COURT
description: Raymond L. Dirks finally had his day in the Supreme Court today against his adversary of a decade, the Securities and Exchange Commission. While the legal outcome will not be known for months, the immediate result was an hour of some of the better theater the Supreme Court has produced this term.

title: Curbs Urged for Dealers In Treasury Securities
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York is pushing a proposal to impose capital requirements on major government securities dealers. The requirements would reduce the risk of trading in Treasury securities, Edward J. Geng, the bank's senior vice-president, said today.

title: NO BREAKTHROUGH IS SEEN IN SOVIET-CHINESE TALKS
description: The chief Chinese delegate at the Soviet-Chinese talks on improving relations met today with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko amid indications that the discussions had produced no breakthroughs on the issues separating the two nations.

title: Who Were the Conodonts?
description: The recent discovery in Scotland of a fossil animal inside which were found formations of conodonts, the tiny tooth-shaped microfossils whose origins have mystified paleontologists for more than a century, may help scientists determine the kind of creature to which the conodonts belonged. The conodonts were found in the body cavity of an unidentified eel-shaped animal about two inches long.

title: Top Comsat Officer Is Stepping Down
description: John D. Harper, a longtime industrialist who has been chairman of the board of the Communications Satellite Corporation since 1979, will step down and be succeeded by Dr. Joseph V. Charyk, now president and chief executive. Dr. Charyk, an expert in satellite technology who has been with the company for two decades, will continue as chief executive, Comsat said yesterday. Mr. Harper's retirement will be effective May 20.

title: Nomination by Reagan
description: President Reagan today nominated Alfred Kingon, a New York financial editor, as Assistant Secretary of Commerce for International Economic Policy. Mr. Kingon is editor in chief of publications for Macro Communications Inc., which includes The Financial World. He has also worked as a security analyst and research director for financial institutions.

description: Exaggerated Reports

title: Investors in Pact For Cedar Point
description: Cedar Point Inc. said it agreed in principle to be acquired by a private investor group for $40 a share. Based on about 3.6 million Cedar Point shares outstanding, the transaction would be valued at about $144 million.

title: Chess: Kasparov Tops Belyavsky And Advances to Semifinal
description: Gari Kasparov took the eighth and ninth games to win his quarterfinal match in Moscow for world championship candidates with Aleksandar Belyavsky. Kasparov, a 19-year-old Soviet grandmaster, scored a 6-3 victory over Belyavsky, 29, a Russian co-champion.

title: Contract Talks Are Resumed By Eastern Airlines and Union
description: Negotiators for Eastern Airlines and its largest union resumed talks today in hopes of preventing a strike that airline officials say would be a catastrophe.

title: ENERSERV PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dun & Bradstreet
description: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation said it had agreed to buy the McCormack & Dodge Corporation, a closely held application software company in Needham Heights, Mass., for $50 million. Additional payments are to be made over the next few years, based on performance. McCormack & Dodge, which has a broad range of products for accounting applications, has a customer base of 1,400 and eight offices in the United States, three in Canada and one in Britain.

title: N.B.A. and Union Meet 7 Hours
description: Faced with an April 2 strike deadline, negotiators for the National Basketball Association and its players union met in Manhattan yesterday for seven hours, the longest bargaining session thus far.

title: RAINFALL CAUSES TRAFFIC TIE-UPS AMID FLOODING
description: Heavy rains and high winds brought flooding, traffic jams and utter irritation yesterday to the already sodden metropolitan area. The downpour - measured at 1.09 inches as of 3 P.M. - pelted land and rivers that were already saturated and swollen from the unusually heavy rainfall of the last few weeks.

title: FISCAL AIDES ACT ON THE SPECIFICS OF STATE BUDGET
description: State fiscal experts met today to work out the details of a budget agreement reached by Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders, amid some uncertainty about exactly what had been agreed to.

title: Talking About Weather
description: This is the first day of spring but Chicago is covered with snow and expecting more. From Salt Lake City to the Midwest, winter went out with a last blast of snow, including eight inches as far south as the Oklahoma Panhandle.

title: Winfield Glad to Share Load
description: Dave Winfield looks at Don Baylor and Steve Kemp - the two hitters behind him in the Yankees' batting order - and says it would be just fine if Billy Martin's theories proved true.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review yesterday incorrectly gave the title of Zbigniew Brzezinski's new book. It is ''Power and Principle.''

title: Cocaine in Wings of Plane
description: The Federal authorities say they have arrested a Massachusetts couple after finding 341 pounds of cocaine inside the wings of a small plane.

title: MAYOR BYRNE DEVELOPING STRATEGY TO MAKE CHICAGO A WRITE-IN CITY
description: By her own estimate, Mayor Jane M. Byrne would need 700,000 votes to win as a write-in candidate for re-election on April 12. To get them, she would have to capture a significant majority of 845,000 white and 95,000 Hispanic voters estimated to be in the city as well as siphon off a portion of the estimated 655,000 black voters.

title: Lightning Hits Jet in Ireland
description: A Northwest Orient Airlines jumbo jet from Boston with 230 people aboard was hit twice by lightning as it landed in 60-mile-an-hour gusts at Shannon Airport on Ireland's west coast today, but no one was hurt, the airline reported.

title: DESTROYING A FOREST MAY HELP IT
description: FEW practices are more dismaying to environmentalists than clearcutting a forest. Every tree, large and small, is removed; then a tree crop of one single species is planted, supposedly reducing species diversity drastically.

title: GENERALS TO STAY INTACT
description: When Chuck Fairbanks, the coach of the New Jersey Generals, came to work this morning at Giants Stadium, he ran across Ernie Adams, the pro personnel director of the Giants.

title: COMPUTONE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the merger with Infotecs Inc on Sept 30, 1982 on a pooling of interests basis

title: WHO SHOULD GET THE GLORY FOR INVENTING THE COMPUTER?
description: HISTORY is rife with rival scientists fighting one another for the honor of being credited with a major discovery. Galileo, who first turned the telescope on the heavens and discovered the moons of Jupiter, scorned competitors who ''attempted to rob me of the glory.'' Newton and the mathematician Leibniz dueled in print over which of them first invented the calculus.

title: CONCERT: THE MELOS QUARTET
description: THE Melos Quartet's only New York concert of the season Friday night at the Metropolitan Museum was somewhat diminished in attendance by rain, but the audience - if all the ticket-holders had attended, they would have well filled the stage - greeted the group's all-Beethoven program warmly.

title: MRS. KING STILL TAKING BOWS
description: Introduced as ''fabulous'' and ''still the one and only'', Billie Jean King received a long and hearty welcome as she made her entrance last Thursday night at Boston University. The fans really whooped it up for her. Some chanted, ''Bill-ie, Bill-ie.'' Others screamed, ''We love you Billie Jean.'' And one man, sitting close enough to touch her as she walked onto the court, clenched his hands together and raised them over his head in salute.

title: TODAY'S LUNCH? SHH. TOP SECRET
description: ''Top secret is meaningless,'' President Richard M. Nixon confided to White House associates in 1971. He noted that 100 million World War II documents were still needlessly classified, and that even the White House menu was top secret.

title: BARTLETT PINKHAM
description: Bartlett Pinkham, retired senior vice president of Allen & Company, a New York investment banking concern, died yesterday at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 89 years old.

title: Europe's Crisis Was America's, Too
description: That Common Market cliff-hanger last weekend concerned currency revaluations in Europe only, but the world's jittery financial markets could do without such shock waves.

title: E.P.A. AIDE'S MEMOS STUDIED BY HOUSE
description: A special Presidential assistant met last summer with the head of the Environmental Protection Agency's program for cleaning up toxic waste dumps and discussed several governor's races, according to materials disclosed today by a House investigations subcommittee.

title: Italian Trade Deficit
description: Italy's overall balance of payments deficit narrowed slightly in February to a provisional $210 million from $212.5 million in January, the Bank of Italy said today. The February deficit was sharply less than the deficit of about $900 million recorded in the same month last year.

title: Mullin's Inspiration
description: A week ago Sunday, the day after St. John's won the championship game of the Big East Conference basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden, Chris Mullin and his friend Bob Antonelli stopped at the Mullin home in Brooklyn. They ate dinner, and they watched videotapes of the games against Villanova and Boston College.

title: WHITE HOUSE GIVES BACKING TO ROWNY
description: The White House expressed support today for Edward L. Rowny as the United States negotiator in the strategic arms talks with the Soviet Union, saying attacks on him in Congress were unjustified.

title: TITAN GROUP INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After gain on restructuring of debt of $1,873,000...C-Net loss

title: OHIO-SEALY MATTRESS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Includes $81,000 or 2 cents a shr received from the company's licensor for agreeing to vacate a hold-separate order entered in a 1979 lawsuit

title: Croeso to Miss Race at Latonia
description: Latonia Race Course officials said today that Croeso, winner of the Florida Derby, was injured in a weekend workout in Florida and would not run in the $200,000 Jim Beam Spiral Stakes on Saturday.

title: SOVIET EMIGRE'S HELPER
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Technology Stock Outlook
description: TECHNOLOGY stocks have doubled in price since the bull market began in August. Since then, major market indicators have scored a creditable, but less heady, gain of 45 percent.

title: RETURN OF FIRST E.P.A. CHIEF
description: William D. Ruckelshaus takes command of the Environmental Protection Agency for the second time armed with a wealth of experience in Washington's political jungle but burdened by extensive involvement with industries his agency regulates.

title: FAR WEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
English Sailor Dies In Accident
description: Rob James, one of England's foremost sailors, died today off the South Devon coast after falling off his 60-foot trimaran. He was 36 years old.

title: The First Democratic Budget
description: President Reagan calls it a ''truly dangerous'' plan, ''a dagger aimed straight at the heart of America's rebuilding program.'' The language is so fervent you'd think he was talking about some new Soviet military proposal. No such thing; his target is the Democratic budget plan just voted by the House Budget Committee.

title: COMCAST CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
POLICE OFFICER HURT IN A BOMB EXPLOSION PLANS TO SUE THE CITY
description: One of the New York City police officers injured by a bomb believed to have been set by a Puerto Rican nationalist group last New Year's Eve plans to sue the city for $100 million, his lawyer said yesterday.

title: Kea Improved
description: The condition of Ed Kea, the hockey player who suffered serious head injuries in a minor league game earlier this month, has been upgraded from critical to serious.

title: G.M.-TOYOTA DEAL: GOOD FOR THE COUNTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: SETBACK FOR ARTIFICIAL HEART RECIPIENT
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark has developed a fever and his kidney functions are deteriorating, doctors said today as they tried to determine whether the artificial heart recipient is suffering from an infection.

title: Texas Bonds Set At 7.2% to 8.15%
description: A $50 million issue of Aaa-rated Texas bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 7.2 percent for bonds due in 1991 to 8.15 percent for bonds due in 1997. The underwriters, led by the Bankers Trust Company, said bonds due in 1998-2001 were placed with an investor and were not publicly reoffered.

title: GENERAL DISTRIBUTORS OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including a special gain of $1,381,000

title: IONA ELIMINATED BY NEBRASKA
description: Stan Cloudy's 24 points helped to lift Nebraska to an 85-73 upset victory over Iona in a second-round game of the National Invitation Tournament tonight.

title: COMPREHENSIVE CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $231,000

title: Empire of America Sells Unusual Fannie Maes
description: Empire of America, a nationwide savings and loan association based in Buffalo, yesterday offered $345 million of mortgage pass-through certificates guaranteed by the Federal National Mortgage Association through Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., the sole underwriter.

title: LOBBYISTS FIGHT TO RETAIN SPECIAL MEDICARE AID FOR SOME HOSPITALS
description: Lobbyists for the hospital industry are fighting to retain a provision of the Medicare law under which the Government paid owners of profit-making hospitals a guaranteed rate of return equal to 19 percent of their investment last year.

title: A NEW STYLE FOR L.I. PROM
description: It may seem a bit early to be getting ready for the prom, but that is what they are doing at Kennedy High School. ''We're talking about a radical change this year,'' explained Gregory Hymowitz, a senior. ''We started in February.''

title: Poland Again In Debt Talks
description: Representatives of leading Western creditor banks began a new round of discussions today on rescheduling Poland's debts falling due in 1983, an official of Bank Handlowy, the Polish foreign trade bank, said today. But the aide declined to give details.

title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for QTr to Feb 27
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. StatementNo 52 regarding foreign currency translations

title: DANCE: CAROLINIANS' NEW YORK DEBUT
description: THE North Carolina Dance Theater from Winston-Salem, which made its New York debut over the weekend, comes across as still another of the strong regional ballet companies developing throughout the United States. And yet it has special features that distinguish it from most other such troupes.

title: Law to Ban Bets On Baseball Stalls
description: The State Senate Judiciary Committee decided today to delay action on a bill that would prohibit betting on games of the new Las Vegas Stars franchise of the Pacific Coast League.

title: U.S. High Court Backs Jean Harris Conviction
description: The Supreme Court today left intact Jean Harris's murder conviction in the 1980 shooting of Dr. Herman Tarnower, author of ''The Complete Scarsdale Medical Diet.'' Without comment, the Court refused to hear arguments that 59-year-old Mrs. Harris had been denied a fair trial.

title: COUNTERPROGRAMS: A NETWORK TACTIC
description: Counterprogramming is a mild-sounding word that, in network television, means ratings warfare. When one of the major networks has scheduled a particularly valuable program - that is, something likely to draw very high ratings - the other two networks often redesign their programming to combat it. They schedule something special in the same time slot, hoping to cut a slice from their competitor's anticipated high ratings.

title: UNIFLITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
TV: STORY OF MEDGAR EVERS
description: PUBLIC television's American Playhouse offers one of its more impressive presentations tonight at 9 on Channel 13 in ''For Us, the Living,'' a 90-minute drama that focuses on the final years of the civil rights leader Medgar Evers before he was slain in June 1963. The screenplay, written by Ossie Davis and J. Kenneth Rotcop, was adapted from a book written by the widowed Myrlie Evers and William Peters.

title: BOMAINE CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $798,000 and a writeoff of intangible assets of $1.7 million...C-Including a tax credit of $898,000

title: ARDEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $64,000 for the latest yr and $1,044,000 forthe previous yr

title: AMERICAN ECONOMY SEEN UNAFFECTED BY REALIGNMENT
description: The realignment of currency values in the European Monetary System -the third in the last 13 months -should quiet the foreign-exchange markets for the time being, bankers in New York said yesterday. They added that the realignment should have little direct impact on the American economy or the cost in this country, for example, of West German automobiles or French wines.

title: Another Chance For Jim Craig
description: Jim Craig, the 25-year-old goaltender who played for the United States Olympic team in 1980, yesterday agreed to a contract with the Minnesota North Stars, and may play for that National Hockey League team before this season ends.

title: U.S. SEES 4% GROWTH FOR G.N.P.
description: The nation's economy is growing at a 4 percent annual rate in the first quarter of this year, the Commerce Department estimated today, the broadest indication to date that the recovery is under way.

title: Leisure and Technology Picks New Chairman
description: Michael L. Tenzer, named chairman yesterday of Leisure and Technology Inc., is betting that a recovery in the housing industry will come soon.

title: Superior Oil Changes Bylaws
description: Directors of the Houston-based Superior Oil Company, rumored as a takeover candidate for many months, have amended the company's bylaws to make it more difficult to call a special meeting at which a bid might be presented.

title: Watchdogs Are for Barking
description: The Civil Rights Commission proves its worth every time a President tries to do it in.

title: Lufthansa's Profit Up
description: Deutsche Lufthansa A.G. today reported a rise in 1982 net profits to $39.5 million, from $2.3 million in 1981, and attributed it to lower fuel costs and reduced overall expenditures on all operations.

title: Latin Production Off
description: For the first time in many decades, production in Latin America and the Caribbean declined last year, according to the Inter-American Development Bank. The production decline in the region was an average of 1 percent, the bank said today. Although production figures are not available for before World War II, officials said they believe it may have been the first decline since the Depression.

title: A. Dudley Harrison, Engineer And Official of Gas Utility, 78
description: A. Dudley Harrison, retired senior vice president of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, died Friday at his home in Garden City, L.I. He was 78 years old.

title: Italian Bank's Warrant Offer
description: Nuovo Banco Ambrosiano today announced a free offer of 150,000 warrants to shareholders of the former Banco Ambrosiano, now in liquidation. Giovanni Bazoli, president of the new bank, gave details at a news conference.

title: U.S. Prison Survey Ties Drug Use to Crime Act
description: A third of the country's state prison inmates were under the influence of an illegal drug when they committed the crime for which they were jailed, a Justice Department survey reported Sunday.

title: Brink's Case Defendant Is Jailed for Contempt
description: A defendant in the Federal case involving the 1981 Brink's robbery and murders in Rockland County was sent back to jail for contempt of court yesterday for refusing to provide samples of her hair and handwriting.

title: Zimbabwe Leader Urges A Stronger Army
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe said today that Zimbabwe's army must be strengthened to defend the nation against South Africa, the national news agency Ziana reported.

title: HARPER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
8 Iraqi Soldiers Die as Copter Falls Near Italy Military Sites
description: Eight Iraqi soldiers were killed today when their Soviet-made helicopter crashed into a mountain near here in the vicinity of important military sites, Italian television reported.

title: THE LAST OF 10 MEN IN 1982 ESCAPE IS APPREHENDED
description: The last of 10 convicts who broke out of a Queens jail last September was captured early yesterday in Washington, where he was living in a luxury apartment complex, New York State officials reported last night. They said he had planned and financed the escape.

title: 2 MAYORAL FOES IN CHICAGO TRADE CHARGES IN TV DEBATE
description: The legislative and income tax records of the two major candidates in Chicago's mayoral race emerged as prominent issues today after the first and only scheduled public debate between the two men.

title: SELIGMAN & LATZ INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PARET TRAGEDY: A SHARED BURDEN
description: In his second year in the penitentiary, Alberto Paret began asking probing questions about his father, Benny, who had been welterweight champion of the world. He had died on April 3, 1962, two months before Alberto was born and nine days after being knocked out in a championship fight with Emile Griffith. Alberto was his second son; Paret had hoped the child would be a daughter.

title: MAN OF PEACE AND OF WAR
description: On Nov. 10, 1975, Israel's chief delegate to the United Nations went to the rostrum of the General Assembly and tore up a copy of a resolution that had just been adopted that defined Zionism as ''a form of racism and racial discrimination.''

title: Itel Says Court Backs Its Plan Conditionally
description: The Itel Corporation, the capital equipment leasing company that has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act for two years, said yesterday that the bankruptcy court in San Francisco had signed a conditional order confirming Itel's reorganization plan.

title: A PRINCE WHOSE 'MISSION' IS UNICEF
description: It is not your usual front hallway. Mounted on the floor beneath an enormous crystal chandelier is a six-foot-square marble slab bearing the black and green royal seal of the House of Saud.

title: JAMESWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: Results for the latest yr include a gain equal to 2 cents a shr for the latest yr and a loss equal to 36 cents a shr for the previous yr due to LIFO inventory accounting; results for the latest yr also reflect store closing costs equal to 10 cents a shr

title: HOLOCAUST WOMEN: A STUDY IN SURVIVAL
description: JOLLY ZELENY was being transported by train from Hamburg, Germany, to the concentration camp at Bergen-Belsen when the railroad tracks were bombed. She was in a car containing only female prisoners; on another track she could see a train carrying men. Four decades later, she remembered the contrast vividly.

title: BULGARIAN AGENTS DESCRIBED AS READY TO DO MOSCOW'S BIDDING
description: The following article was also reported and written by Mr. Gage.

title: American Bancorp Tie
description: American Bancorp said today that the Federal Reserve Board had approved the proposed consolidation of it and Central Penn National Corporation into a new multibank holding company to have its headquarters here.

title: MOUNTAIN STATES FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss; the latest yr includes valuation reserves and gains on sales of mortgage backed securities and loans of $2,786,000

title: VULCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest periods include nonrecurring gains of $1,355,376 for theqr and $626,371 for the yr from the sale of assets; yr-ago results reflect a charge of $157,423 for the qr and a gain of $114,058 for the yr from the sale of assets

title: CORRECTION
description: An article and headline in some copies of yesterday's Sports Pages incorrectly identified the coach of the girls' basketball team at Marlboro (N.Y.) High School. He is Jim Van Allen.

title: JOB BILL STALLED BY LAST-MINUTE DISPUTE IN SENATE
description: A $4.6 billion compromise recession relief bill stalled short of final passage in the Senate late tonight in a last-minute dispute over how to distribute the money to hard-pressed parts of the country.

title: THE PARALYSIS IN VENEZUELA
description: The Venezuelan economy, once the most robust in South America, has entered its second month of paralysis, waiting for the Government to formulate a strategy to offset falling oil profits and renegotiate its foreign debt.

title: Extension Seen On Baldwin Loans
description: The financially hard-pressed Baldwin-United Corporation may shortly be given until June 30 to repay some $800 million in short-term debts, banking sources said yesterday.

title: Ftorek Out 4-6 Weeks
description: The Rangers learned yesterday that Robbie Ftorek will be out for four to six weeks with a second-degree sprain of the medial collateral ligament in his left knee. Ftorek was injured Monday night in the 4-2 loss to the New Jersey Devils.

title: DANCE: KENNETH KING
description: MARIANNE MOORE once titled a poem ''The Mind Is an Enchanting Thing.'' That could also serve as the overall title for the program that Kenneth King and Dancers/Co. presented Sunday night in the Kitchen. Officially, it consisted of five pieces: ''Prologue: Annexialics,'' ''Lucy Alliteration,'' ''Scream at Me Tomorrow,'' ''Flextime'' and ''Dance Motor.'' But these items were run together without pause, so that the evening became a long celebration of the creative mind at work and at play. And just as the mind can change, so Mr. King's choreography kept constantly changing in tone.

title: IRAQI COPTER STIRS A FUROR IN ITALY
description: The Italian Government showed embarrassment today over the accidental disclosure Monday that an Iraqi military helicopter had been flown here for installation of advanced electronic equipment.

title: U.S. Signs Tuna Pact
description: The United States has signed a tuna treaty with Costa Rica and Panama, the Government announced today. The treaty will not go into force until five coastal nations sign it.

title: Chock Full Seeks A New President
description: The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation has begun looking for a new president and chief operating officer, the company told stockholders.

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
VALEX PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
On-Job Training
description: Met-watchers in St. Petersburg, Fla., have been curious about the husky 6-footer who has been working out with the club every day. He has been taking infield practice and batting the ball with such vigor that there was some suspicion that he might be a secret weapon for the Mets.

title: MAKING 'THE OUTSIDERS,' A LIBRARIAN'S DREAM
description: The dedication that flashes on the screen at the end of Francis Coppola's new movie reads: ''The film 'The Outsiders' is dedicated to the people who first suggested that it be made - librarian Jo Ellen Misakian and the students of The Lone Star School in Fresno, California.''

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: DANA P. VAUGHAN
description: Dana Prescott Vaughan, dean emeritus of art and architecture at Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, died of cancer Monday in Clearwater, Fla. He was 84 years old and lived in Clearwater and Orford, N.H.

title: PLAN TO BOLSTER SOCIAL SECURITY GAINS IN SENATE
description: The Senate, heeding vigorous lobbying by the Reagan Administration, voted today not to consider an amendment concerning the withholding of taxes on interest and dividends, clearing the way for passage of a plan to provide financial stability to the Social Security system.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum RateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ROLE OF NUTRITION IN ATHLETICS: FACTS AND FADS
description: CAPT. WILLIAM WATKINS, on leave from the Army to train for the 1984 Olympics as a cyclist, takes vitamin E because he thinks it ''helps my recuperative powers,'' calcium and potassium supplements ''because I perspire a lot,'' and vitamin C for colds and a multivitamin supplement because, he says, ''I'm a superstitious athlete.''

title: CHINA OFFERS INCENTIVE TO RAISE PRODUCTIVITY
description: To encourage productivity by introducing an earnings incentive, the Chinese Government has decided to tax all state-owned enterprises on what they produce and split the profits. At present, the Government takes all the profits.

title: AM General Gets Army Contract
description: The Army chose the AM General Corporation, a unit of the American Motors Corporation, to produce a new family of light vehicles that will serve a variety of purposes from missile carriers to ambulances.

title: SNUFF, TRADITION THAT STILL PERSISTS
description: Taking snuff was the epitome of elegance 150 years ago, complete with its own social ritual. In modern times it has been associated with eccentric minorities such as dons and maiden aunts. But now it looks as if it may enjoy new popularity - for health reasons.

BEVERLY HILLS SAVINGS ASSN (CALIF) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary income of $215,000 or 18 cents a shr for the qr and yr...C-Net loss

title: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Results for the latest fourth qr reflect a writedown of inventories and accounts receivable of approximately $1.2 million

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1. The Wearing Is Easy

title: ST. JOHN'S FACULTY REBUKES PRESIDENT
description: The faculty council at St. John's University in Queens voted yesterday to reproach the president, the Rev. Joseph T. Cahill, for removing the Asian studies program from the Liberal Arts College and the Graduate School and making it a separate entity more directly under his control.

title: BANKS GRANTED SANCTUARY IN NEW YORK RESERVATION
description: Calling Dennis Banks ''a man who would be a credit to any community,'' the chiefs of the Onondaga Nation announced today that they had granted him sanctuary and the chance to live on the reservation south of Syracuse.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MARCH 23, 1983
description: International

title: New Job for City's Lobbyist
description: The first woman to hold the position of New York City lobbyist yesterday became the latest official to leave the Koch administration. Margaret L.W. Boepple, director of legislative liaison, will become the City University vice chancellor for university relations, a new position.

title: Unsecured Credit Pact With Lionel
description: The 13 corporate members of the Lionel Corporation's creditors' committee have agreed on a reorganization plan involving unsecured credit, Lionel said.

title: FLEET OF SMALLER MISSILES TO BOLSTER MX DEBATED
description: In an effort to save the politically endangered MX missile program, a Presidential commission has discussed a plan to build a separate fleet of small, mobile missiles. But such a proposal could expand rather than stifle skepticism about the survivability of any land-based missiles.

title: DANCE: VEREEN IS GUEST WITH O'DONNELL TROUPE
description: MAY O'DONNELL is one of the great ladies of contemporary dance, and in recent years she has had a great success with a young group of dancers upon whom she has set her early modern-dance pieces from the 1940's and l950's as well as her very recent choreography.

title: A GRAND JURY VOTES NOT TO INDICT GERULAITIS ON COCAINE-PLOT CHARGE
description: A Federal grand jury voted yesterday not to indict Vitas Gerulaitis, the tennis star, in a case involving a conspiracy to buy $20,000 of cocaine.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DISTANT WATER. The Fate of the North Atlantic Fisherman. By William W. Warner. 338 pages. Illustrated. Atlantic-Little, Brown. $17.95.

title: Spot Market In Gas Urged
description: The Transco Energy Company, a major pipeline enterprise, is taking an unusual step to halt the sharp decline in its customers' use of natural gas. Transco, which supplies 80 percent of the gas bought by retail distributors in New York, proposes what would amount to a spot market for gas that might bring lower prices.

title: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 23, 1983
description: The Economy

title: Raschi on Mound, Simon at Short
description: A shortstop named Neil Simon faced a pitcher named Vic Raschi in a baseball game at Lowry Air Force base in Denver during World War II. ''It was the first time I ever saw a curveball - I mean, a real curveball,'' said Simon.

title: TO GET CHEAP NATURAL GAS TO THE CONSUMER
description: To the Editor:

title: BORG'S OLD LINES BOUNCE BACK
description: What a difference a year has made in the traditional businesses of Borg-Warner. Last year the company increased the tempo of diversification, acquiring service companies and divesting itself of manufacturing concerns, in an effort to reduce its dependence on autos and other mature, cyclical industries.

title: WAR AND SWEETS
description: Disclosure that the Russian army is already equipped with an accurate pie-delivery system is no surprise to those of us in the military-pastry complex.

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Richard Price Reaches Crossroads in 4th Novel
description: At 22, he wrote his first novel - a violent, obscene comic saga of street gangs in a Bronx housing project in the early 1960's - and saw it published the next year to reviews hailing him as a major new talent. ''The Wanderers'' was also made into a movie, and Richard Price, who still thought of himself as a lower-middle-class kid from the Bronx trying to decide whether to go to law school, was launched as a budding literary lion of the streets.

title: Ex-Tax Aide in Massachusetts Pleads Guilty in Bribery Case
description: Stanley J. Barczak, a former Massachusetts tax examiner, pleaded guilty today to a bribery-conspiracy charge stemming from last summer's politically explosive investigation of the state tax collecting agency.

title: POLAND SAYS DISSIDENTS PLAN PROTESTS FOR MAY
description: Poland's Interior Minister told Parliament today that the authorities had halted the ''process of disintegration of the state'' in the 15 months since martial law was imposed. But he said dissidents still planned protests early in May.

title: San Diego Record Is Set On Arrest of Aliens
description: The reinforced United States Border Patrol contingent in San Diego County arrested 2,442 illegal aliens Sunday to set a new single day record, it was announced today.

title: Drug Agents Seeking 82 Indicted in Florida
description: Drug enforcement agents in six states began arresting 82 people today after the Government unsealed indictments stemming from an 18-month undercover investigation into Florida's marijuana trade.

title: POSITIONS CALLED 'FIXED' AS METRO-NORTH TALKS HALT
description: Talks broke off last night in the 16-day-old strike against the Metro-North Commuter Railroad. The mediator in the dispute said, ''It could be a long strike.''

title: S.E.C. Examining Aetna Accounting
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company said the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun a formal investigation into the company's decision not to make adjustments for tax loss carry-forward accounting.

title: INTERNATIONAL MOBILE MACHINES CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Nancy Reagan to Be On Two-Part TV Program
description: Nancy Reagan announced Monday that she would be the host of a two-part public-television program, ''The Chemical People,'' as part of a $2 million project to encourage community efforts to combat teen-age drug and alcohol abuse.

title: Pentagon Announces Plans For Sale of Missiles to Israel
description: The Pentagon today proposed the first sale of United States arms to Israel since the invasion of Lebanon last summer strained relations between the two countries.

title: SMALLEY IS NAMED YANKEE SHORTSTOP
description: Roy Smalley returns to the Yankee lineup against the Orioles on Wednesday night after recovering from an appendectomy, and has been given the starter's role at shortstop.

title: FAFCO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PLASTIC HEART PATIENT'S CONDITION WORRIES DOCTORS
description: Physicians caring for Dr. Barney B. Clark, the artificial heart recipient, said yesterday that his kidneys were deteriorating further, that he still had a fever for which they could find no source and that they were concerned about his recovery.

title: Index; International
description: ''What soldiers?'' a tactful town in Salvador says A2 Nicaragua says 2,000 rebels entered country from Honduras A3 Nicaragua seizes Coca-Cola plant, calling manager a rebel A4 Poland's Interior Minister says protests are planned for May A5 French Cabinet resigns and new Government named A6 Around the World A7 Crash of Iraqi helicopter embarrasses Italian Government A8 Bulgarian agents described as ready to do Moscow's bidding A12 Government/Politics House Democrats win a key initial vote related to their budget A17 Smaller, mobile missiles discussed by Reagan commission A23 Koch swears in eight judges and defends record on minorities B3 D'Amato recommends Keenan for Federal judgeship B3 Cuomo said to abandon efforts to revise school-aid formula B4 Prosecutors given evidence in Co-op City bribery inquiry B24 High Court rules generic drugs must be approved by F.D.A.
