title: 'JOHN DOE' PROFESSOR IS SUBJECT OF PAPER CHASE
description: A man who led a double life as a professor on two college campuses kept documents indicating that he had previously assumed at least 13 identities in four countries, the authorities said today.

title: U.S. Wins, 13-2
description: Don Waddell, Mike Fidler, Phil Verchota and John Harrington scored two goals each to lead the United States to a 13-2 victory over Yugoslavia in the Group B World Ice Hockey Championships today.

title: KEENAN IS PROPOSED FOR U.S. JUDGESHIP
description: John F. Keenan, the criminal-justice coordinator for New York City, was recommended today by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato for nomination as a United States District Court judge in the Southern District of New York.

title: Bally Purchase
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Health and Tennis Corporation of America for $137.4 million to be paid over five years. The exact amount of the purchase is to be reduced to the extent to which Bally buys capital stock of Health and Tennis subsidiaries, and is subject to Health and Tennis's attaining an undisclosed level of future earnings. Health and Tennis operates 280 fitness centers in 21 states, the District of Col mbia and in Ontario.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Five months after he suffered a cerebral hemorrhage that has left him paralyzed on his right side, Normand Leveille, a 19-year-old forward for the Boston Bruins, left a neurological hospital in Montreal to begin therapy at a rehabilitation center there. . . . Joe Sambito, the Houston Astros' pitcher who underwent elbow surgery on Saturday said he may face further surgery that could cause him to miss the entire 1983 season. But the left-handed reliever, who hasn't pitched since last April, still hopes to return to the lineup after the All-Star Game break in July. . . . According to Dr. Paul Jacobs, the Milwaukee Brewers' team doctor, Pete Vuckovich does not need surgery to repair a small muscle tear in his pitching arm, but it's ''too early to tell'' if the right-hander will be able to pitch this year.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BAMBOO

title: World of Catalan Comes for a Visit
description: In the city's Hispanic mix, the Spanish-born number only about 25,000, according to Spain's consulate, which could not guess the number from Catalonia. But Catalan Week in New York has brought the Mayor of Barcelona, 42-year-old Pasqual Maragall, to talk about the Mediterranean coast celebrated for troubadours, poets and such artists as Picasso, Gris, Miro and Dali.

title: Progress Reported in Talks Held by Eastern Air and Union
description: The chairman of the National Mediation Board reported progress today in contract negotiations aimed at averting a strike by machinists against Eastern Airlines.

title: Israeli Settlements Criticized By Common Market Leaders
description: European leaders strongly criticized Israeli settlements on the West Bank today and said the time had come for Israel to show that it was ready to negotiate seriously for Middle East peace.

title: KING AND KNICK DEFENSE HALT 76ERS
description: Bernard King staged a Madison Square Garden spectacular last night before a capacity crowd of 19,591. So did the Knicks' defense. Playing against the 76ers, the team with the best record in the league, King took 18 shots and missed only two - one in the first period and another in the third. He scored 33 points, and had 8 rebounds, 4 steals and 4 assists in leading the Knicks to an 89-76 victory that snapped the 76ers' seven-game winning streak.

title: THE ATTACK ON THE POPE: NEW LINK TO BULGARIANS
description: The authorities in Western Europe have information that supports testimony given to them by a Turkish assassin, Mehmet Ali Agca, that when he tried to kill Pope John Paul II on May 13, 1981, he was acting at the behest of Bulgarian intelligence agents.

title: Steeler in Disguise
description: The patient who entered a Shreveport, La., hospital for surgery earlier this month was registered as ''Thomas Brady'' and his medical condition was likened to ''tennis elbow.'' But the name was an alias, his doctor revealed yesterday, and the ailment was an analogy.

title: WATT SAYS STATUS OF RUCKELSHAUS AT E.P.A. SURPASSES PREDECESSOR'S
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt said today that President Reagan's nominee to head the Environmental Protection Agency, William D. Ruckelshaus, would have greater access to the President and more freedom of action than his predecessor, Anne McGill Burford.

title: Role in Reed Case Defended by S.E.C.
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the agency had been reluctant to bring insider charges against Thomas C. Reed, a special assistant to President Reagan for national security, because of uncertainty over whether trading options on the basis of insider information was illegal.

title: NICARAGUA CHARGES AN INVASION BY 2,000
description: Nicaragua charged today that as many as 2,000 insurgents had entered the country from Honduras, and it asked for an urgent meeting of the Security Council.

title: TOKHEIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
U.S. TO EXAMINE DOW'S AREA TO SEE IF CLEANUP IS REQUIRED
description: Federal and Michigan environmental officials are trying to determine if the Dow Chemical Company's plant in Midland, Mich., and surrounding parts of the city are so contaminated with dioxin that the area should be placed under the Federal cleanup program.

title: Trial of Nkomo Deputy Opens Despite Threats
description: The treason trial of the top aide to Joshua Nkomo, the Zimbabwean opposition leader who fled to London, opened today despite threats to kill seven hostages unless he is freed.

title: THEATER: 'TEAHOUSE,' CHINA OVER 50 YEARS
description: ''TEAHOUSE,'' in its American premiere at the Pan Asian Repertory Theater, is an ambitious group portrait of China over a period of 50 years. Written by the late Lao She, known in America for his novel ''Rickshaw Boy,'' the play was first presented by the Peking People's Art Theater in 1957. The story begins at the turn of the century and ends in 1948 during a time of revolutionary upheaval. As the author observes, empires have fallen but nothing has essentially changed. Actual slavery has been replaced by bondage to the state, the country is still beset by poverty and factionalism, and corruption accompanies the growth of civilization. Pragmatism is the only path to survival.

title: Habib Confers With Gemayel; Israeli Offer Is Called a Topic
description: Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, met today with President Amin Gemayel to discuss the negotiations on withdrawal of foreign forces.

title: MUSIC: JOHN CHEEK, SCHUBERT
description: FOR all this city's varied musical life, Schubert song cycles appear seldom among us. But we have heard two in the last few weeks - first Christa Ludwig's ''Winterreise'' at the Metropolitan Opera and, Monday night at the 92d Street Y, John Cheek's ''Schwanengesang.''

title: SHULTZ SAYS U.S. TOLD SALVADORANS TO 'CLEAN-UP' THEIR RIGHTS RECORD
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, seeking to defuse opposition to increased military aid for El Salvador, told a Senate subcommittee today that Salvadoran leaders had been warned to ''clean up'' their human rights record or lose all American support.

title: Human Kindness
description: Not long ago milk was called the perfect food, and children were told to finish it with their spinach. Spinach lost out early, but milk's drop has been long and slow.

title: MOVIE SYSTEMS (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
No Headline
description: Venezuela's state-owned oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela, may buy the Lake Charles, La., refinery owned by the Occidental Petroleum Corporation's Cities Service subsidiary, the Venezuelan oil company's refining coordinator, Angel Behrends, said.

title: Economic Scene; Fixed Rates May Be Better
description: THE intense negotiations in Brussels among finance ministers has finally produced a realignment of eight European currencies, with the West German mark rising 5.5 percent and the French franc dropping 2.5 percent. What was all the excitement about? After all, in the floating world outside the European Monetary System, exchange rates change continually without provoking much interest outside the markets.

title: 'Gandhi' Wins 5 Awards From British Academy
description: The film ''Gandhi'' won the 1982 British Academy Awards for best picture and swept four other honors, including best actor for Ben Kingsley and best director for Sir Richard Attenborough.

title: Defense Wish-Lists and Hit-Lists
description: Many members of Congress want defense spending to grow by 4 or 5 percent after inflation, not by the 10 percent provided in the President's $245-billion budget. But tossing off percentages is the easy part; Congress now needs to decide, lacking the Administration's cooperation, which specific weapons systems to cancel.

title: PROSECUTORS GIVEN EVIDENCE IN CO-OP CITY BRIBERY INQUIRY
description: The State Commission of Investigation said yesterday that it had turned over to local and Federal prosecutors evidence of systematic bribery of state and Co-op City inspectors in an emergency-repair program at the Bronx housing complex.

title: SHONEY'S INC reports earnings for 16 weeks to Feb 20
description: B-After a nonrecurring charge of $144,546...C-Including a nonrecurring gain of $817,496 and a gain of $2 million on the sale of stores

title: Ciccarelli Draws Three-Game Ban
description: Dino Ciccarelli, the Minnesota right wing, was suspended today without pay for three games by the National Hockey League for his part in a brawl during the North Stars' game against the Chicago Black Hawks Monday night.

title: DOROTHEA S. FOOTE
description: Dorothea Scudder Foote, a member of a prominent New Jersey family and the wife of Edward A. Foote, former deputy assistant United States attorney general for the Antitrust Division, died Monday of a heart attack at her home in Washington. She was 73 years old.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS SHOW THEIR STRENGTH IN KEY TEST VOTE ON BUDGET
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., and the Democrats today won by a comfortable margin an initial vote on the Democrats' proposed Federal budget for the fiscal year 1984, which starts Oct. 1.

title: Ivan Vinogradov, 92; Soviet Mathematician
description: Ivan M. Vinogradov, a leading Soviet mathematician, died Sunday in Moscow at the age of 92, the Soviet press agency Tass reported yesterday.

title: VAGABOND HOTELS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
U.S. FARMERS AGREE TO TRIM PLANTING
description: American grain and cotton farmers have agreed not to plant more than 81 percent of the land they normally use for those crops under a new program aimed at reducing surpluses and increasing depressed farm prices, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: MRS. LLOYD READY DESPITE CASE OF FLU
description: Having practiced only twice in the last 10 days, Chris Evert Lloyd had more than Martina Navratilova on her mind for tonight's start of the $350,000 Virginia Slims of New York tennis championships at Madison Square Garden.

title: FEBRUARY DURABLES ORDERS OFF
description: Orders for durable goods, a key indicator of the industrial side of the economy, fell 4 percent in February, snapping a three-month string of increases, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Rates Move Modestly Higher
description: Questions on Fed Intention

title: Market Place; Nutri/System Losing Streak
description: HAROLD KATZ owns the Philadelphia 76ers, the team with the best record in professional basketball. Entering last night's game with the Knicks in Madison Square Garden, the 76ers showed 57 wins and nine losses. Moreover, the 76ers are given a good chance to be the first team in the National Basketball Association to win 70 games in a single season.

title: Kuwait Lease Denial
description: The Kuwaiti oil minister, Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, said today that a recent United States Government decision banning Kuwait from leasing Federal Government land to drill for oil or gas was illegal. ''The decision from our point of view is illegal,'' he told the Kuwaiti Parliament, ''but we will work to rectify the situation.''

title: The U.N. Today; March 23, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Council for Namibia - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Biogen N.V. Up to 23 1/4 In First Day of Trading
description: Biogen N.V., one of the most closely followed of the new biotechnology companies, closed at a bid price of 23 1/4 yesterday after its first day of public trading, up 25 cents from its initial offering price of $23.

title: GAP STORES INC, THE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Kahn Determined
description: Because the townsfolk wouldn't install lights in the local stadium, Roger Kahn has abandoned plans to start a minor league baseball team in Cooperstown, N.Y., as an expansion club in the New York-Pennsylvania League. But the author did not give up his notion of operating a baseball team and writing about the experience. He has purchased a share of the Mets farm club in Columbia, S.C. Mr. Kahn, who wrote ''The Boys of Summer,'' will be president of the club, part of the Class A South Atlantic League, and plans to be actively involved in its daily management.

title: CUOMO ABANDONING AID REVISION AIMED FOR POORER SCHOOL DISTRICTS
description: Governor Cuomo today abandoned efforts to revise the state's school-aid formula this year to help poorer districts, aides to the Governor said.

title: 'JEANNE DIELMAN,' BELGIAN
description: LIKE its blunt title, Chantal Akerman's ''Jeanne Dielman, 23 Quai du Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles,'' deals in unadorned facts. It's about the looks and sounds of ordinary things and people, which it records with such precise, unsettling clarity that it has the effect of finding threats in mundane objects and doom in commonplace characters.

title: Erie County Notes Get a Top Rating
description: Erie County, N.Y., which is increasing its borrowings in the commerical paper market to $75 million, from $50 million, has received the highest rating, F-1, from Fitch Investors Service.

title: SCREEN: INDONESIAN 'DAWN'
description: ''THE DAWN,'' written and directed by Arifin C. Noer, is a patriotic, sentimental, very long movie that means to be an Indonesian ''Birth of a Nation.'' The setting is Jakarta in 1945, just after the Japanese surrender to the Allies in Tokyo Bay, when Indonesian nationalists were preparing their war of liberation, first against the Japanese and then against the Dutch.

title: THE EDUCATION OF ANDREA JEAGER
description: For the last year, Andrea Jaeger had been looking forward to rooming with her older sister, Suzie, at Stanford University next year. It would have been the only time the sisters would be in college together.

title: MELDING TRADITION AND SPORTSWEAR
description: In a city with dozens of designers well-known for women's clothing, no more than a handful count in the men's fashion business. Among them are Nino Cerruti, Francois and Marithe Girbaud, Marcel Lassance, Jean-Charles de Castelbajac, Daniel Hechter, Christian Aujard, Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Cardin. To this group can now be added the name of Lucien Foncel, who designed the men's clothing of Cerruti for eight years before establishing his own studio in 1979.

title: Marks & Spencer Picks Chief Executive Officer
description: Britain's leading retailer, Marks & Spencer P.L.C., has promoted Lord Rayner, a longtime company official, to chief executive officer. The promotion will be effective April 1, when Lord Sieff of Brimpton steps down after 11 years at the job.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: SOMETHING that has always fascinated me about food is that certain flavors seem indigenous to one region or country. The herbs and spices found in curries - turmeric, coriander, cumin, ginger and the like - are identified with India. The food of the Mediterranean region would be almost unthinkable without the taste of tomatoes and garlic.

title: MILLER ACCUSES MOFFETT OF TRYING CENSORSHIP
description: Marvin Miller, the former executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association and now a consultant to the organization, last night accused his successor, Ken Moffett, of ''attempted censorship'' in trying to prevent Miller from sending player representatives a letter asserting that he was not being consulted on major issues.

title: The Talk of New Rochelle
description: Double parking in downtown New Rochelle had become habit forming in years past. It made little sense, residents reasoned, to pay to park in lots when business activity along Main Street was so slight that double parking caused few tie-ups.

title: High Court Backs Area Pricing
description: The Supreme Court, in a unanimous ruling today, made it easier for companies to defend themselves against charges of illegal price discrimination when they set different prices for customers in different geographic areas.

title: Landmark Razing Delayed by Court
description: The razing of the former Mount Neboh Synagogue, a city landmark, was delayed yesterday for more than a month by a state appeals court that had granted a preliminary injunction on Monday against demolition.

title: POP-SOUL: DARYL HALL, JOHN OATES
description: DARYL HALL and John Oates's brand of pop music is about as stylistically comprehensive as any pop being made in America today. An impeccably crafted pastiche of pop-soul melodies, partly synthesized instrumental voices and rock rhythm, it is distinguished by a cool romanticism and an elegance of detail that occasionally flirts with the arty.

title: Mr. Reagan Turns a New (Old) Leaf
description: ''He's the right man for the right job at the right time,'' President Reagan said in naming William Ruckelshaus to head the Environmental Protection Agency. Two years ago would have been an even better time, but not to quibble: Mr. Ruckelshaus is a superb choice to restore to the E.P.A. its reputation for integrity, impartiality and competence.

title: GEORGE KRAMER
description: George Kramer, chairman of the Northeast International Corporation of Elmsford, N.Y., manufacturer of insulating washers for watches and such equipment as dialysis machines, died of a heart attack Monday at White Plains Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Officials Say Neighbor Joined in Rape of Girl
description: A 40-year-old man ''apparently got in line and participated'' when he discovered four boys raping a 12-year-old girl in a shed in his backyard, the authorities said today.

title: WINE TALK
description: SOME years ago, the story goes, Philippe de Rothschild, the owner of Chateau Mouton-Rothschild in Bordeaux, was entertaining a notably aggressive wine writer - we'll call him George - at the chateau. A steward appeared for instructions on lunch. ''What shall we drink?'' Baron Philippe said, more to himself than to anyone else.

title: N.F.L. SEES CONFLICT IN BID BY DEBARTOLO
description: The National Football League owners today expressed what Commissioner Pete Rozelle described as ''solid opposition'' to the possibility that Edward J. DeBartolo Sr. would buy an expansion franchise in the United States Football League for 1983.

title: REPUBLIC NATIONAL'S EXPANSION
description: Not long after the Republic National Bank was founded in 1966, it became apparent that the fast-growing financial institution could not be accommodated for long in its Manhattan headquarters, a 10-story landmark office building on Fifth Avenue between 39th and 40th Streets.

title: OPERA: VIRGIL THOMSON, 'THE MOTHER OF US ALL'
description: ''THE MOTHER OF US ALL'' is one of the most entertaining and yet most pertinent operas composed in our century. Although it has never enjoyed a staging by either of New York's major houses, this charmingly pungent work by Virgil Thomson and Gertrude Stein is a masterpiece whose full value has probably yet to be realized.

title: INDIAN STORY OF A VILLAGE WRESTLER
description: THERE is a simplicity bordering on the primitive to P. Padmarajan's ''There Lived a Wrestler,'' and it gives the film an innocent appeal. The action takes place in a minuscule Indian village where very little ever happens, and the title character is, as one villager puts it, ''an elephant sent from heaven.'' He appears one night by the riverbank, as the few young men of the area hunt for frogs, which are considered a great delicacy. He announces that he is a wrestler. Soon the villagers are feeding him all their best frogs and everything else in sight, in hopes of fattening him up for what they hope will be a money-making wrestling match.

title: GEARHART INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HE DEFENDS RECORD ON RACE
description: Mayor Koch swore in eight new judges yesterday and chose the occasion to defend his record on judicial appointments of women and members of racial minorities as ''one of the nation's best.''

title: AT A WEST 57TH STREET CORNER, THE GREAT PASTRAMI WAR
description: THE lines of battle have been drawn across part of West 57th Street for what dedicated though uncertain eaters predict will be a major delicatessen conflict in New York. Already it is being referred to in communiques as the imminent Great Pastrami War.

title: ALICE M. ROBINSON
description: Alice M. Robinson, director of Specialized Consultants in Nursing, which provides educational programs in nursing administration, died of a heart attack Friday in her Manhattan apartment.

title: MAKING CARS IN JAPAN: A LESSON IN EFFICIENCY
description: Freshly painted body shells of Mazda 626 cars move in stately sequence along an overhead conveyor from the drying ovens to the main floor of the Toyo Kogyo Company's ultramodern assembly plant here.

title: NEW ORLEANS DISPUTES FUTURE OF PARK ON SITE OF TREME, WHERE JAZZ DUG IN
description: If jazz was not born in the neighborhood, it is the place where it came to live. That is what the neighborhood people say about the Treme section of New Orleans, just outside the French Quarter, where the great black musicians here developed their art.

title: WALDBAUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
A Poised Walker
description: In the face of what seems a disappointing three games as the highly publicized running back for the New Jersey Generals, Herschel Walker remains cool.

title: NEW GOVERNMENT NAMED
description: The French Cabinet resigned Tuesday night and President Francois Mitterrand immediately reappointed Pierre Mauroy as Prime Minister. Hours later, Mr. Mauroy named a 15-member Cabinet that represented a shift toward the political center by the 22-month-old Socialist Government.

title: MASSEY-FERGUSON LOSS $94.4 MILLION IN QUARTER
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. reported yesterday that its loss in the fiscal quarter widened to $94.4 million (United States) because of the depressed farm equipment market.

title: RELIABLE INVESTORS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: The 1981 net loss includes a loss of $19,611,575 from the disposal of certain operations

title: Early Save Sets Tempo For Resch
description: Glenn (Chico) Resch is the most overworked goaltender in the National Hockey League, but when the Devils play the Rangers, Resch digs down deep and comes up with enough energy to frustrate New Jersey's rivals with spectacular saves.

title: Jersey Seeks a Lifting Of Truck Ban by U.S.
description: New Jersey filed a Federal lawsuit today that seeks to block a proposed ban against truck traffic on a Pennsylvania road through the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area.

title: A MIME POEM FOR MARCEL MARCEAU
description: LOUIS PHILLIPS

title: ISLANDERS' BID FOR FIRST ENDED BY BRUINS
description: It became obvious early last month that only one thing could have moved the Islanders ahead of the firstplace Flyers in the Patrick Division:

title: SUNDANCE OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Koch Wins Title
description: Bill Koch of Eugene, Ore., beat Jim Galanes of Anchorage by 8.5 seconds Monday to win the senior men's National cross-country skiing championship.

title: NATURE OF JOB IS CENTRAL TO CONTEST FOR SCHOOLS CHIEF
description: Underlying the intensely political contest for Chancellor of the New York City school system is a basic question about the job itself: Does the task of running the nation's largest public school system demand an educator with solid academic credentials or an administrator with practical political experience?

title: SHARE SALVADOR POWER
description: The debate about El Salvador is unlikely to be resolved as long as both President Reagan and his liberal critics reject the one solution that offers any chance of success: power sharing before the elections. Liberals propose a dialogue between the Government and democratic groups associated with the guerrillas. But like the Administration, they shy away from the fundamental issue: the restructuring of armed power. Any dialogue that does not address the question of who controls the guns is bound to result in a sham.

title: PASSOVER TRADITION IN AMERICAN SOUTH
description: A WEEK or two after the Mardi Gras celebration in Mobile, Ala., Zelda Schwartz, owner of the Schwartz Kosher Delicatessen - the only strictly kosher deli within a hundred miles - places her Passover orders.

title: HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MARINDUQUE MINING & INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
2 Women Add New Glory To a Distinguished Record
description: In the last six months the ''Belles'' have been ringing in the tournament world: Carol Sanders of Nashville and Betty Ann Kennedy of Shreveport, La., who are known by that name to their teammates and friends, have been adding fresh luster to distinguished careers.

title: LOCAL PHONE RATE RISES SEEN SPUR FOR SUBSIDY
description: Rising local telephone rates, which may climb even more sharply next year after the American Telephone and Telegraph Company divests itself of its operating companies, could bring pressure on the Government to provide subsidies to low-income customers, a House panel was told today.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have seen numerous references lately to a Louisiana dish called dirty rice. Can you tell me what it is and why it is so named?

title: Preserving Buildings, At Least on Film
description: Last November Mayor Koch signed into law Councilman Henry Stern's proposal that all buildings scheduled for demolition be photographed for posterity.

title: A REDUNDANT EFFORT TO HUMANIZE MARX
description: To the Editor:

title: COURT SAYS GENERIC DRUGS MUST GET U.S. APPROVAL
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that generic drugs cannot be sold without Food and Drug Administration approval, even though their active ingredients duplicate those found in drugs already sanctioned by the agency.

title: HEAD INJURIES AND THE 'SILENT EPIDEMIC'
description: ALICE was a B-plus student through her first three years of college. During the winter recess of her senior year, while she was driving during an ice storm, her car ran off the road and hit a tree. Alice banged her head on the steering wheel but never lost consciousness. She was treated for bruises and discharged from the hospital within a day, apparently all right. But upon returning to classes, she began to have difficulties. Suddenly her A's and B's were coming out C's. She had trouble remembering what she'd read and she was irritable and distractible.

title: SALAD IDEAS YOU CAN WARM UP TO
description: AS much as we all appreciate the need to consume a daily ration of roughage, specifically salad greens and crisp vegetables, there are certain damp and blustery days when the idea of a chilled, crunchy salad is about as tempting as a Popsicle. We yearn for only warm food, as insalubrious as that might be, vowing to attack the salad bar like a jack rabbit as soon as weather permits.

title: ESMARK TO LIMIT STOKELY STAKE
description: Esmark Inc., the big Chicago-based diversified company, disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had agreed not to increase its 6.1 percent stock interest in Stokely-Van Camp Inc., the food products company, for a six-month period that began March 11.

title: EX-MAYOR OF WEEHAWKEN INDICTED ON 6 CHARGES OF CORRUPTION
description: A former Mayor of Weehawken was indicted today as part of an investigation by Federal authorities into political corruption in Hudson County.

title: COCA-COLA SEIZED IN MANAGUA
description: The Nicaraguan police have occupied the Coca-Cola plant here, charging that its manager is now an insurgent leader based in Honduras.

title: Better Than a Budget in Albany
description: New York should have a state budget acceptable to the financial community by next week. It has something even more important already, a spirit of cooperation between the new Governor and the seasoned leaders of the Legislature, Warren Anderson, the Republican Senate Majority Leader, and Stanley Fink, the Democratic Assembly Speaker.

title: CONCERT: NEW ARTS TRIO AT ALICE TULLY HALL
description: THE New Arts Trio's concert Monday night at Alice Tully Hall, presented by the Naumburg Foundation, was a long, generous, curiously unfocused, yet still very appealing affair.

title: RICHARD PRICE REACHES CROSSROADS IN 4TH NOVEL
description: At 22, he wrote his first novel - a violent, obscene comic saga of street gangs in a Bronx housing project in the early 1960's - and saw it published the next year to reviews hailing him as a major new talent. ''The Wanderers'' was also made into a movie, and Richard Price, who still thought of himself as a lower-middle-class kid from the Bronx trying to decide whether to go to law school, was launched as a budding literary lion of the streets.

title: Grain Output Peak Is Seen
description: World grain output will reach a peak this year and then decline as production is cut back to use up existing surpluses, the chief of the International Wheat Council said today.

title: A Greek Radical Group Says It Killed Publisher
description: A clandestine radical organization took responsibility today for killing a Greek publisher, and police sources said the same group might have been responsible for the slaying of the C.I.A. station chief in Greece in 1975.

title: Batten, Barton Executive Shift
description: Bruce Crawford, president and chief executive of BBDO International, has relinquished the chairmanship of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, the domestic operation. As a result, J. Thomas Clark, 46 years old, gets to be United States president.

title: Klansman Says Informer Shot '65 Rights Worker
description: A Federal informer, Gary Thomas Rowe, was identified today as the man who fatally shot Viola Gregg Liuzzo, a white civil rights worker, while she rode in a car with a black man 18 years ago in Alabama.

title: Organ Pollution
description: In a recent poll to determine the predilections and propensities of sports enthusiasts in America, hockey was ranked 24th among games people most like to watch.

title: THE TRIANGLE FIRE AND A LIFETIME OF UNION SERVICE
description: Pauline Newman came to New York from Lithuania as a child, and as a child she went to work. It was 1901, and a cousin got her a job in a garment factory, cutting the threads from blouses when the sewing machine operators were through with them. She grew up on the loft floor, hidden in packing boxes when the inspectors came to call, but in 1909, after a strike, she was persuaded to continue the fight as an organizer for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

title: THOMAS SCHETTINO, EX-ASSOCIATE JUSTICE OF TOP JERSEY COURT
description: C. Thomas Schettino, a former associate justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court, died Monday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 75 years old and lived in Summit.

title: BASING OF MX IN MINUTEMAN SILOS EXPECTED AS PANEL'S INTERIM PLAN
description: The President's Commission on Strategic Forces has indicated it will recommend that, as an interim measure, the MX intercontinental missile be deployed in improved Minuteman missile silos, Republican and Democratic leaders in Congress said today.

title: MARVIN G. SAINES
description: Marvin G. Saines, an executive in the field of classical music recordings, died Sunday in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 59 years old. Mr. Saines, a resident of White Plains, had been president of Discount Record Shops, head of the Masterworks Division of Columbia Records and, at his death, in charge of classical recordings for Moss Music.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan is aware that his proposed budget for 1984 would be defeated in both the Senate and the House of Representatives, White House officials say. But he has decided to abandon, at least temporarily, the bipartisan tone he has used so far this year in seeking an alternative.

title: Brokerage Payments Set
description: A court-appointed trustee said today that he was ready to pay claims on about 3,000 cash accounts frozen since February's collapse of the Toledo brokerage firm of Bell & Beckwith.

title: Soviet's Top Defense Official Returns to Moscow Suddenly
description: Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov, who flew to Budapest this morning for talks with Janos Kadar, the Hungarian leader, returned unexpectedly later in the day.

title: 9 Soviet Law Officers Are Sentenced for Graft
description: Nine senior law enforcement officers have been sentenced for graft in the Soviet Union's northern Caucasus region of Krasnodar, the newspaper Sovetskaya Rossiya reported today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American General Corp., Houston, has elected John D. Hogan senior vice president-investments.

title: Advertising; Lorimar Buying K.& E.
description: KENYON & ECKHARDT, the ad agency for an important number of television network advertisers, is about to become a subsidiary of Lorimar, a major supplier of programming to those same networks. It is the first merger of its kind.

title: Bullets 121 Jazz 98
description: Jeff Ruland scored 25 points to lead the Bullets. The Bullets remained five games behind Atlanta in the battle for the final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference as the Hawks defeated the Indiana Pacers. After trailing by as many as 8 points in the first period, the Bullets outscored the Jazz by 10 points in each of the next two periods to take a 90-76 lead entering the fourth quarter. A 7-point string pulled Utah to within 96-87, but Washington responded with 5 straight points to rebuild a 101-87 lead.

title: ROCCO M. LAGINESTRA
description: Rocco M. Laginestra. a senior vice president of the RCA Corporation and special assistant to Thornton F. Bradshaw, chairman of RCA, died of cancer Monday at his home in Franklin Lakes, N.J. He was 56 years old.

title: PENTAGON REPORTS CUTS IN WEAPON COSTS, BUT ONLY ON PAPER
description: The Pentagon today released a document meant to show that the lifetime costs of major weapon programs had declined for the first time in 10 years.

title: Coast Thrift Unit Sets Conversion
description: The California Federal Savings and Loan Assocation, the third-largest savings and loan in the country, with assets of $11 billion, said yesterday that its depositors and borrowers approved a plan to convert from mutual to stock ownership.

title: WHAT'S GOING ON?
description: The Center for Defense Information is a think tank in Washington that keeps a box score on the wars, rebellions, and other violent uprisings going on in the world. Its latest report reminds us of some things we're inclined to forget:

title: Careers; Personnel For Future Specialties
description: IN a period of rapid technological change, one problem is to identify future trends, according to Arden L. Bement, vice president of technical resources for TRW Inc. A related problem for corporations, trying to find qualified personnel, is financial support of training at universities.

title: RANSBURG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
LOUGHLIN TRIUMPHS AND CAPTURES TITLE
description: Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn continued to play impressively last night by defeating a taller Long Island Lutheran team, 65-55, for the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association-Alliance of Independence Schools B Division title at Bishop Ford High School in Brooklyn.

title: Hogstedt Upsets Denton
description: Thomas Hogstedt, a 19-year-old Swede who was the United States Open junior champion in 1981, upset fifth-seeded Steve Denton in a first-round match of the $365,000 Cuore Tennis Cup tournament today.

title: New Lloyd's Suspension
description: Ian Posgate was suspended today from the ruling council of Lloyd's of London, the insurance exchange. The former leading underwriter had been suspended in January from working at Lloyd's, but he remained on its governing committee. Mr. Posgate had managed syndicates for the Alexander Howden Group, a British unit of Alexander & Alexander Services of New York, a major international insurance brokerage.

title: LILLY INDUSTRIAL COATINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Associated In Pact to Buy Chain
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation plans to acquire Loehmann's Inc. for $96 million under a letter of intent signed yesterday by the two companies.

title: Nissan Leading Toyota in U.S.
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation is leading its Japanese rival, the Toyota Motor Company, in United States car sales so far this year, company reports show.

title: Leo Morgan, TV Producer; Did 'Caesar Comedy Hour'
description: Leo Morgan, who produced the ''Sid Caesar Comedy Hour'' on national television for eight years in the 1950's, died Sunday in Baptist Hospital.

title: DEPRIVING DEPRIVED CHILDREN
description: President Reagan wants to convert into vouchers the program that funds special opportunities for educationally deprived children. He apparently believes that this program, known for many years as Title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act and now as Chapter 1 of the Education Consolidation and Improvement Act of 1981, is another bloated, ineffective remnant of the Great Society. But recent studies, including one by President Reagan's own Secretary of Education, Terrel H. Bell, demonstrate that Chapter 1 is enormously successful and is improving the educational achievement of millions of disadvantaged children.

title: MERRILL TO STOP MAKING MARKET IN SOME STOCKS
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. said yesterday that it would stop making markets in certain exchange-listed stocks because the technology for execution of the orders was not efficient and the rules slowed the process.

title: THEATER: A REVIVAL OF 'SOMETHING DIFFERENT'
description: ALTHOUGH Carl Reiner's ''Something Different'' is not a play but an extended sketch, it does have its merits as a grab bag of cockamamie jokes. First produced on Broadway in 1967, this comedy shares the oddball sensibility of Mr. Reiner's rudest, most anarchic creations - the 2,000-Year-Old-Man routines he did in collaboration with Mel Brooks and his uproarious film comedy of 1970, ''Where's Poppa?''.

title: Norstar Bancorp Bid
description: Norstar Bancorp, a bank holding company, has won approval from the Federal Reserve Board and New York State banking officials to proceed with its acquisition of the Northeast Bankshare Association of Portland, Me., Norstar said today. The acquisition is still subject to approval by the Maine superintendent of banks.

title: BRIEFING
description: No Room at the Inns

'WHAT SOLDIERS?' SAYS TACTFUL TOWN IN SALVADOR
description: For two months, no Government soldiers have dared to come near this town, which sits perched among rugged mountains in northern Chalatenango Province five miles from the border with Honduras.

MUSIC: PASTICHES BY BROQUE OPERA
description: MUCH of the credit for the Broque Opera's sparkling presentation of two 18th-century operatic pastiches must be given to Marie King, who imaginatively divined and directed the productions. But those who made their way to Greenwich House Sunday afternoon were rewarded with an entertainment that was on a generally high level of wit and musical competence.

title: Swimming Money
description: Except for a few low-purse long distance races on lakes and rivers and the chance for some commercial endorsements by Olympic champions, there is no big money in big-time swimming: The sport is strictly for amateurs. That may change, however, if an Australian group has its way.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Du Pont Co. announced plans to consolidate a segment of its Polymer Products division with a division of Conoco Inc., forming a new business segment to be based in Houston.

title: STONEWARE BAIN-MARIE
description: FEW kitchen utensils are so simple in design and function yet potentially so expensive as a bain-marie, or water bath. The most elegant versions, made of copper with porcelain inserts, are cosmetic luxuries, considering that the implement is used primarily for melting butter, making sauces and keeping them warm.

title: SEAVER GOES 7 IN 8-0 ROMP BY METS
description: See Tom pitch. See Tom hit. Hear Tom complain that he should have done better. Tom Seaver gladdened the hearts of hundreds of Met fans here by pitching seven shutout innings against the Boston Red Sox today. He even reached base twice, once on an error and once on a single. But there was little joy in his voice despite this vintage performance.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: THE diversity and stylistic ferment of contemporary popular music make the critic's job an exciting one. The widespread impression that this is a dull, quiet period in pop's evolution is mistaken but understandable; the restrictive formats and racial biases of most of today's radio programming make it difficult if not impossible to keep up with the latest trends and developments by taking a spin around the dial. And with very few exceptions record stores will no longer play a disk for a prospective customer.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Saturday incorrectly reported what a State Department official said about arms shipments to guerrillas in El Salvador. The official did not mention Algeria as a direct source of such shipments.

title: WASTE DISPOSAL ISSUES FALL
description: Most stock prices finished with minor changes yesterday in stepped-up trading. Much of the interest was centered on the stock of Waste Management Inc., which dropped sharply for the second consecutive session.

title: LIBEL DECISION AGAINST COAST PAPER IS LIFTED
description: A judge today reversed a default judgment in a $60 million libel suit against a newspaper and two reporters who had refused to reveal sources in an article that linked a former Iranian hostage to drug trafficking.

PRESIDENTS AND CHURCHGOING, A SENSITIVE SUBJECT
description: As a President who does not hesitate to invoke the divinity of Jesus and even identify it with his policy in the East-West struggle, Ronald Reagan has come under closer scrutiny lately because he is not a regular Sunday churchgoer.

title: M & T MORTGAGE INVESTORS (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
N.B.A. and Players Recess Talks
description: Negotiators for the National Basketball Association and its players' union met for five more hours yesterday at a Manhattan hotel, then recessed the talks until tomorrow afternoon. The two sides, trying to head off a threatened strike for April 2, have met for more than 16 hours since last Friday.

title: Can Summer Be Far Off?
description: A welcome hint of summer tempered the icy spring yesterday as the Hampton Jitney rolled into Manhattan. Driving the sleek silver bus was Wayne Duncan of Sag Harbor, a 25-year-old biology graduate who aspires to dental school.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Felix Brenninkmeyer, the 35-year-old former merchandising vice president of Ohrbach's Inc., has been named president and chief executive officer of 12-store New York-based specialty apparel chain.

title: Perkins Changes Mind
description: Ray Perkins, the Alabama football coach who said several months ago that he didn't want the post of athletic director as well, was named to the position yesterday. . . . Billy Taylor, the former Giants' running back who failed to win a spot with the Boston Breakers earlier this year, and another former Giant, the linebacker Dan Lloyd, will be given tryouts with the Washington Federals of the United States Football League. Lloyd had attempted a comeback with the New Jersey Generals, but gave it up when the Generals tried to trade him to the Birmingham Stallions just before the season.

title: HOSPITAL MANAGEMENT EXPERT
description: Raymond Paton Sloan, an authority on hospital management, died of a stroke Sunday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 90 years old. Mr. Sloan was a brother of the late Alfred P. Sloan, a founder of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, and had been a member of the center's board of managers for more than 20 years.

title: NORMAN B. OBBARD
description: Norman B. Obbard, former executive vice president of the United States Steel Corporation's international division, died of a heart attack Monday at St. Francis Hospital in Pittsburgh.

description: President Reagan has made a preliminary decision to propose to the Soviet Union an interim agreement limiting but not eliminating intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe, according to Administration officials and diplomatic sources.

title: Rules on Infants Take Effect
description: Federal rules designed to assure that handicapped infants are not permitted to die from lack of food and medical treatment went into effect today after a judge turned aside a bid to halt them.

description: Joel R. Kramer is the new executive editor of The Minneapolis Star and Tribune, the Cowles Media Company flagship that is being reorganized with young top executives from its outposts. Mr. Kramer, 34, was appointed executive editor Monday by the publisher, Roger Parkinson, 41, who also was his publisher at The Buffalo Courier-Express.

title: STATE SENATE CONFIRMS STERN FOR U.D.C. WITH NO DISSENT
description: William J. Stern was confirmed today by the State Senate as head of the Urban Development Corporation. The nomination was approved on a voice vote and without dissent following a controversy that contributed last week to a temporary delay in his confirmation.

title: LABORITE ELECTED ISRAELI PRESIDENT
description: In a rebuff to Prime Minister Menachem Begin's governing coalition, Parliament today elected Chaim Herzog of the opposition Labor Party as the next President of Israel.

title: Floods Reportedly Kill 260 in Peru and Bolivia
description: Floods and mudslides set off by two days of rains destroyed villages and inundated farmlands in northern Peru and Bolivia, killing at least 260 people and leaving hundreds more missing, officials said today.

title: TV: WNET PRESENTS 'TANNHAUSER' BY THE MET
description: ONE of the most gorgeous and gloriously romantic productions in the Metropolitan Opera's repertory is the ''Tannhauser'' first mounted by Otto Schenk in 1977. The scenic designs by Gunther Schneider-Siemssen are both breathtakingly grand and painstakingly subtle. The sheer scale certainly offers a challenge to any small telelvision screen trying to convey it to a mass audience. But public television's ''Live From the Met'' series, on WNET, Channel 13 tonight at 8, succeeds handsomely in doing just that.

title: MOSCOW REPORTS RIGHTING A CASE OF INJUSTICE
description: Yuri V. Andropov's drive to root out official malfeasance gained a new hero today when the Minister of the Interior offered what amounted to a public apology to a 29-year-old merchant marine mechanic who had been the victim of a five-year vendetta by the police.

title: EXECUTIVES ARE OFFERED A CITY GUIDE TO HOUSING
description: In an effort to help businesses whose middle-management employees say they have no interest in being transferred to New York City, a leading local business group has listed 61 neighborhoods as good communities for executives and their families.

title: Brazil Seeks To Spread Loan
description: Brazilian officials were planning to meet with 40 medium-sized international banks at a conference here of the Inter-American Development Bank in an effort to convince them to purchase portions of a $4.4 billion loan that the world's largest banks already have made to Brazil.

title: HOUSE ROLL-CALL ON THE BUDGET
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 229 to 196 by which the House of Representatives today approved the 1984 budget blueprint backed by the Democratic leadership. A ''yes'' vote is a vote in favor of the leadership plan. Voting ''yes'' were 225 Democrats and 4 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 36 Democrats and 160 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes those not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, yes; Erdreich, no; Flippo, yes; Nichols, yes; Shelby, no. Republicans - Dickinson, no; Edwards, no.

title: COMMUNITY PROJECT PRODUCES FERTILIZER
description: GARDENERS in the greater New York area have a new source of organic material to improve their soil. It's called ZooDoo, a composted product that takes its name from manures ''donated by refined Bronx Zoo animals for healthier and prettier flowers.'' Pictured on the two-pound plastic bags are an elephant, hippopotamus, giraffe, goat and other herbivores.

title: IN THE NEW CLOCKS, DESIGN, NOT TIME, IS OF THE ESSENCE
description: MOST new clock designs amount to little more than a modified face on a modified case. But over the last decade a new type of clock has appeared in which design, as much as time, is of the essence. These are the designer clocks in which new graphic, kinetic, sculptural, sound and light features have assumed a strong importance, sometimes at the expense of clarity. Most of these clocks are handsome; some are difficult to read. They range in price from moderate to expensive.

title: An Appeal of an Appeal
description: The Georgia Tech Athletic Association said it would appeal last week's decision by a state appeals court, which overturned a lower court decision and found that Pepper Rodgers, the former Georgia Tech football coach, was entitled to compensation for an array of special benefits - including broadcast and summer football camp fees, insurance premiums and use of a new Cadillac - he lost when the association dismissed him as coach in 1979, two years before his contract expired.

title: WARSAW OUTLINES THREE-YEAR PLAN
description: The Government called on Poles today to work harder as it presented to Parliament a three-year austerity plan for dealing with the country's economic ills.

title: COURTS IN CONTEMPT
description: An 80-year-old Federal judge in Alexandria, Va. Oren R. Lewis, has just been sternly criticized in two appellate decisions. His errors were ''glaring,'' the Court of Appeals said; in one case he had ''predetermined the outcome.''

title: 11 Cabinet Members Resign in Mauritius
description: The left-wing coalition Government of this Indian Ocean island faced a crisis today after 11 Cabinet ministers resigned.

title: N.B.A. Money
description: Teams in the National Basketball Association owe between $80 million and $90 million in deferred payments to current and former players, according to figures given by the league to the players association.

title: VIRGIL THOMSON'S FAITH IN HIS OPERAS
description: VIRGIL THOMSON'S opera ''The Mother of Us All'' is currently playing in a church on West 46th Street through April 9, courtesy of the Music Theater Group of the Lenox Arts Center. It has been rapturously received, as it almost invariably is when people get a chance to see it.

title: U.S. EXPECTS FARM PROGRAM WILL LIFT GRAIN PRICES
description: The Agriculture Department, on the basis of surprisingly widespread participation in its new payment-in-kind and acreage reduction program, said today that prices paid to farmers for wheat and corn late next fall were expected to rise above their currently depressed levels.

title: HOME BEAT
description: THE special space - with its spiral stair, fireplace and bowed window -gave Tricia Foley, far right, and Tony Vincent the incentive to open the English Way, a small shop full of items that Miss Foley admitted she ''had always loved and collected in flea markets and secondhand shops.'' ''They're not antiques, just pretty things,'' added Mr. Vincent of the table linens ($3 to $200), Lloyd Loom chairs ($125 to $350), earthen-ware jelly molds ($20 to $50), blue and white china ($5 to $300) and, of course, teacups and saucers ($20 to $150 for a two- or three-piece set). The store, at 115 East 60th Street, is open Tuesday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: NO. 1 IN PRO SQUASH IS A LIFE ON THE GO
description: Several hours before a recent exhibition, Mark Talbott completed telling his life story of how he had reached the No. 1 ranking of the World Professional Squash Association at age 22; how he had taken advantage of his talents to see the world; how he had driven through much of North America in a pickup truck attached to a tiny, wooden Aframe structure with a shingled roof - ''like a little doggy house'' - that had once been part of a squash racquets court.

title: GOLDIN CRITICIZES CITY HANDLING OF REALTY AUCTIONS
description: Almost 3 of every 10 commercial properties that New York City auctions off for nonpayment of taxes slip back into default because the new owners also fail to pay taxes, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: WHAT ONLY A WOMAN CAN DO
description: To the Editor:

title: Tighter Money Seen
description: The president of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, Harry Taylor, said today that the United States Federal Reserve appeared to have tightened monetary conditions in the United States slightly in response to the growth of money above the Fed's target. Such modest tightening would briefly interrupt the general downtrend in interest rates, he said.

title: INSTITUTE WHERE SCHOLARS LIVE ON FOOD FOR THOUGHT
description: Spring arrived this week, and at the Institute for Advanced Study, the season seemed lost in thought. Even in a place well known for producing fresh ideas, it has been an especially fertile and, at times, esoteric academic year. Dr. Robert Sleigh, for example, a philosopher from the University of Massachusetts, is here for a year reassessing the work of Baron Gottfried Wilhelm von Leibniz, a 17th-century German philosopher and mathematician who believed the universe was the result of a divine plan.

title: TRICENTROL'S CHIEF QUITS IN DISPUTE
description: Graham J. Hearne, chief executive officer of Tricentrol, one of Britain's largest oil and gas exploration companies, resigned yesterday after the nine other board members unanimously agreed to appoint two new managing directors. In effect, they will take over Mr. Hearne's responsibilities.

title: Heart Recipient, 28, Dies
description: A man who last month received a new heart today became the first patient to die after being treated with a drug designed to prevent the body from rejecting a transplanted organ. Kenneth Ingram, 28 years old, of Gatesville, Tex., died this morning at St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital, a spokesman reported. Tests were being carried out to determine the cause of death.

title: Two Children Die In Jersey City Fire
description: Two children died Tuesday in a tenement fire that left another child seriously burned, the police said.

title: Liberties Union Presses Case for Legal Services
description: The American Civil Liberties Union, criticizing budget cuts for the Legal Services Corporation as ''deeply political,'' urged Congress today to ignore President Reagan and rebuild the legal aid program for the poor.

title: GALLUP GIVES EDGE TO MONDALE, GLENN
description: If the 1984 Presidential election were being held today, either former Vice President Walter F. Mondale or Senator John Glenn would defeat any of the leading Republicans, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: Abortion Policy Review Follows 4 Live Births
description: Officials at Madison General Hospital said today that abortion policies were under review because four aborted fetuses were born live at the hospital in 10 months.

title: TALKS ON SALE OF SARDI'S TO BAUM UNDER WAY
description: Negotiations are under way for the sale of Sardi's, the restaurant that has been a popular meeting place for theater people since it opened in 1921.

title: BIG 3 AUTO SALES UP BY 6% IN MID-MARCH
description: The nation's Big Three automobile manufacturers today reported a 6 percent increase, on a daily selling rate basis, in new car sales in the March 11-20 period compared with the same 1982 period.

title: GUATEMALA LIFTS ITS STATE OF SIEGE
description: President Efrain Rios Montt today lifted the state of siege he imposed last July and announced he would turn power over to an elected civilian government.

description: The top Environmental Protection Agency official in Chicago said today that the agency's deputy administrator intervened last year in behalf of a chemical manufacturer concerned about a bill pending in Wisconsin.

title: FOR $5,000 A YEAR, WELCOME TO THE SPEAKER'S CLUB
description: ''As a member of the Speaker's Club, you will have many opportunities to meet personally with the Democratic leadership and committee chairmen of the House of Representatives and share with them your interests and concerns,'' promises an invitational brochure. ''In the nation's capital or at club events throughout the United States, you and your family will enjopy the relaxed intimacy of social events with Speaker O'Neill and his Congressional leadership colleagues.''

title: EDWARD REYNOLDS
description: Edward Reynolds, a former administrative vice president of Harvard University and a retired brigadier general, died Tuesday in Emerson Hospital after a stroke.

title: INDEX IS STABLE IN NEW YORK
description: Consumer prices, pulled down by a record decline in gasoline prices, fell two-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Labor Department said today.

title: FOR WHOM AMERICA IS NO PLACE TO VISIT
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Given 42 1/2 Years In Bronx Attacks
description: A judge, deploring the lack of a death penalty, sentenced two Bronx men to a minimum of 42 1/2 years each in prison yesterday in a slaying, an attempted slaying and two robberies.

title: EAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Swedes Report Seeing 2 Alien Subs Near Base
description: Officials said today that there had been two sightings of foreign submarines in Swedish waters near the Karlskrona naval base.

title: TEXTS OF DOCUMENTS MADE PUBLIC BY SENATE PANEL
description: Following are the texts of four documents made public today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in connection with President Reagan's nomination of Kenneth L. Adelman to head the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. The deletions in the documents were made by the committee. Adelman Memo to West

title: 76ers 104, Bucks 101
description: Moses Malone made two free throws with 5 seconds left in overtime to insure the victory after Marques Johnson, who led the Bucks with 24 points, made a 3-point field goal to cut the 76ers' lead to 102-101 with 22 seconds left.

title: WASTE HAULER'S BUSINESS ACTS FAULTED
description: The following article is based on reporting by Raymond Bonner and Ralph Blumenthal and was written by Mr. Blumenthal.

title: Halliburton Deal For Power Plant
description: The Halliburton Company announced it had agreed in principle to buy 75 percent of the capacity of a power generating station in Texas in an attempt to settle a suit involving the South Texas nuclear project.

title: CARMELO BARBERO
description: Deputy Defense Minister Carmelo Barbero died of a heart attack today, the official Philippine News Agency reported. He was 67 years old. Mr. Barbero, a survivor of the Bataan death march, was appointed Deputy Defense Minister in 1976 and served in the House of Representatives from 1965 until 1972, when President Ferdinand E. Marcos declared martial law.

title: NATO MINISTERS ENDORSE U.S. POSITION ON MISSILES
description: Supporting the American position, Western defense ministers agreed today that the elimination of all medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe should remain the prime objective of arms talks in Geneva. But they also upheld the idea of a flexible negotiating posture.

title: Topics; Television Trials; Courts on Camera
description: When lawyers for Claus von Bulow filed their appeal from his conviction for attempted murder, they complained broadly about the fairness of his celebrated trial in Newport, R.I., last year. Significantly, they did not complain about one of the trial's most interesting features: gavel-to-gavel coverage by television.

title: MURPHY, G C, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
Freddie Mac Certificates Produce Yield of 12.02%
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation sold $127.5 million of mortgage participation certificates during the past week at an average yield of 12.02 percent, unchanged from the previous week.

title: BILTRITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SIERRA RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Baseball Bets Banned
description: Under pressure from baseball's commissioner, Bowie Kuhn, officials in Nevada, where sports gambling is generally legal, have agreed to ban betting on a minor league team being shifted to Las Vegas from Spokane, but will do it through regulation rather that statute. According to State Senator Jim Bilbray, the Nevada Gaming Control Board is drafing a regulation that would ban gambling on the team, the Stars of the Triple-A Pacific Coast League.

title: U.S. CALLS NICARAGUAN CHARGE OF IMMINENT INVASION A MYTH
description: The United States said in the Security Council today that charges by Nicaragua that it faced imminent invasion from Honduras and American-backed insurgents were a myth.

title: 'Magazine Buff' Starts Dobbs Ferry Quarterly
description: A one-time reporter and columnist for Advertising Age who also edited two other trade publications and describes himself as ''a magazine buff'' has gone out and started one of his own.

title: Celtics 114, Hawks 102
description: Robert Parish scored 27 points and Larry Bird added 25 to help snap Atlanta's four-game winning streak.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of George Kramer yesterday gave his age incorrectly and misspelled the names of two survivors. Mr. Kramer was 76 years old and among the survivors were a sister, Rose Fiegel, and a brother, Edward Kayett.

title: Sliver Laid to Rest
description: The final nail in the coffin of the sliver was hammered in yesterday by the Department of Buildings. Slivers are those tall, skinny structures that dwarf their neighbors.

title: TURNAROUND AT LEVI STRAUSS
description: In 1981, when the first signs of a subsequent, two-year profit slide began to appear, Levi Strauss & Company responded by setting up an in-house venture-capital fund.

title: TV: MORE 'MYSTERY'
description: PUBLIC television's very uneven ''Mystery!'' takes a dive, beginning at 9 tonight on Channel 13, with a three-part series called ''The Limbo Connection.'' Actually, the first episode, which carefully sets up the plot, is tolerable. But the two others, contrived and outlandish, are rarely more than irritating.

title: Soviet Details Trade Figures
description: The Soviet Union improved its overall trade position last year by reducing its deficit with the West and Japan and increasing its surplus in trade with the developing countries, according to Government figures released today.

title: N.C. STATE AND BOSTON COLLEGE EXCITED
description: The spring weather turned wintry with strong gusts blowing snow today as three Eastern teams and the West's lone survivor prepared for the semifinals of the West Regional in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: LED RABBINIC SCHOOL OF JEWISH SEMINARY
description: Rabbi Saul Lieberman, head of the Rabbinical School of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America in Manhattan, died while asleep yesterday aboard an El Al airliner bound for Israel. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: JANE BYRNE ENDS HER WRITE-IN BID TO STAY IN OFFICE
description: Mayor Jane M. Byrne abruptly ended her week-long write-in candidacy for re-election tonight, hours after she was rebuffed in her efforts to pursuade the Chicago Board of Elections to simplify write-in voting procedures.

title: Portugal's Devaluation
description: The Bank of Portugal today increased the escudo's monthly crawling peg devaluation to 1 percent from three-fourths of 1 percent. This amounts to a total devaluation of 2 percent, the bank said, following this week's realignment of currencies in the European Monetary System.

title: PINIELLA, AT 1 FOR 15, RELYING ON PATIENCE
description: When you're a 39-year-old Yankee and hitting .067 in spring training, and your shoulder hurts so much you can't swing a bat without wincing, it should be time to worry.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Timely Reminder

title: CONNER HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
AMES DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
TRIZEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The yr-ago revs figure was restated

title: Veryzer Seeking Regular Job
description: In baseball's world of cult worship, Tom Veryzer doesn't have a fan club. ''At least I don't think I have one,'' he said. ''When I was in Cleveland somebody would write and say could I organize a fan club for you and be president. I don't know if it works the same way in New York.''

title: P.L.O.'S CROSSROADS
description: As Yasir Arafat and King Hussein of Jordan prepare to meet in Amman, the Palestine Liberation Organization faces the most important and dangerous crossroads in its 19-year history.

title: ILL-FITTING CAP ON A PROFESSOR'S TENURE
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GIANTS OF INDUSTRY

title: CHILE RAISES TARIFFS AND DEVALUES PESO
description: The Chilean Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet Ugarte, under pressure from the International Monetary Fund, doubled tariffs, raised taxes and devalued the peso today as part of an emergency economic program.

title: THE PEOPLE SUPPORT CURBS ON MALPRACTICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Britons Fancy Football
description: Ever since millions of Britons stayed up to watch the Super Bowl on television and apparently liked what they saw, British promoters have been falling all over themselves to persuade a couple of National Football League teams to play an exhibition game in Wembley Stadium just outside London. The latest to consider such a game are the St. Louis Cardinals and the Minnesota Vikings.

title: Bulgaria Says Defector Was Only a Mechanic
description: The Bulgarian Embassy in Rome said today that a Bulgarian defector, reported to have said his country was behind a plot to kill Pope John Paul II in 1981, was neither a diplomat nor a secret agent. It added that the defector's allegations about Bulgarian involvement in any such plot should be reconsidered in this light.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
GADGETS FOR AUTOS
description: A CAR cigarette lighter outlet is a handy source of power. In addition to flashlights, several car-related appliances can be operated from the outlet or in connection with it.

title: Tandy Aims At Schools
description: The Tandy Corporation introduced a new computer education program for elementary and secondary schools, in part of a continuing race among microcomputer manufacturers to secure a foothold in the education market.

title: THURSDAY, MARCH 24, 1983
description: The Economy

title: SPARENESS GAINS NEW MEANING IN A QUARTET OF CITY APARTMENTS
description: ENTERING an interior by Michael Formica can be a disorienting experience. Windows are bare or covered with tattered cotton; floors are uncarpeted; walls are bereft of artwork. Sometimes a bare bulb hangs from the ceiling. The paint appears if it is peeling from the walls. There are bedrooms without beds, dining chairs with no table in sight and a garden seat that looks like a three-dimensional line drawing.

title: OLSON FARMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: B-After extraordinary gain of $602,000 or 56 cents a shr from tax refund related to antitrust damages paid by the company in 1977 for the qr and yr

title: AMERON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
ROSE EXPERT AND PATHOLOGIST
description: Dr. Cynthia Westcott, a plant pathologist and rose expert, died of a heart ailment Tuesday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. She was 84 years old and lived in Croton-on-Hudson.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Up until now we have increasingly based our strategy of deterrence upon the threat of retaliation. But what if free people could live secure in the knowledge that their security did not rest upon the threat of instant U.S. retaliation to deter a Soviet attack; that we could intercept and destroy strategic ballistic missiles before they reached our own soil or that of our allies?'' - President Reagan. (A20:6.)

title: OPERA: VIRGIL THOMPSON 'THE MOTHER OF US ALL'
description: ''THE MOTHER OF US ALL'' is one of the most entertaining and yet most pertinent operas composed in our century. Although it has never enjoyed a staging by either of New York's major houses, this charmingly pungent work by Virgil Thomson and Gertrude Stein is a masterpiece whose full value has probably yet to be realized.

title: Everything but the Figs
description: Alain Senderens, the three-star Parisian chef who is preparing a weeklong series of dinners at the Parker Meridien Hotel, arrived from Paris at Kennedy Airport with some mighty unusual baggage:

title: CAVALIERS TOPPLE KNICKS
description: Everything pointed to a Knick victory tonight. They were one of the hottest teams in the National Basketball Association with 23 victories in their last 29 games, including nine of 10. They had beaten the Cavaliers 18 consecutive times since Dec. 27, 1979. Cleveland, with the second worst record in the league, had lost six in row. But the Cavaliers won, 84-81, at the Coliseum.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: AUTHOR FINED FOR DEFAMATION
description: A French civil court convicted the British writer Graham Greene and three French publications of defamation today. The case involved statements Mr. Greene made about a man who had married the daughter of one of Mr. Greene's friends.

title: HOLDING OF DRUG SUSPECT RULED AN ILLEGAL ARREST
description: A divided Supreme Court ruled today that while narcotics officers who suspect an airline passenger of carrying illegal drugs may stop and question him briefly, more prolonged questioning can constitute an illegal arrest.

title: BILL TO SEEK LIVE TV FOR OTB
description: A bill authorizing live telecasts of horse races into New York State's offtrack betting parlors and into new betting theaters operated by race tracks in the state could reach legislators by the end of May, according to the author of the measure.

title: ILLEGAL TOXICS DISPOSAL DENIED
description: The president of Waste Management Inc. today denied recent accusations by former employees and Illinois officials that the company had violated state and Federal laws in disposing of toxic chemicals at several of its waste dumps.

title: 500 Celebrate Golden Jubilee
description: It was a little like the Ark. Two by two, wearing Mr. and Mrs. badges (no first names for wives), they came to the party, sharing nearly 40,000 years of marriage among them.

title: Bradford Suit On Executive
description: The Bradford National Corporation, a big bank and corporate services institution, has filed a suit in New York Supreme Court against the Security Pacific Corporation.

title: News Analysis
description: In asking for an ''intensive'' national effort to create an effective defense against nuclear attack, President Reagan is apparently seeking to begin a sweeping, longrange change in national strategic doctrine.

title: Jobless Rate In Europe
description: The number of unemployed in the Common Market dropped slightly in February, to 12,345,500, while the unemployment rate remained at 11.1 percent of the work force, the organization's statistical agency said today.

title: CLABIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $164,000 for the qr and $750,000for the yr...C-Net loss after a loss of $467,000 from discontinued operations...D-After a loss of $1,738,000 from discontinued operations

title: Money-Saving Move In Trash Collection
description: At 7 A.M. yesterday, 24 rear-loading garbage trucks pulled out of the Sanitation Department's Brooklyn West 6 garage at 127 Second Avenue. For eight hours, they moved through the Carroll Gardens, Cobble Hill, Gowanus, Park Slope and Red Hook sections, collecting more than 12 tons of garbage each.

title: Bridge: Long Event Takes Its Toll On One's Skill and Energy
description: Fatigue can play funny tricks on players at the end of a long event. One player fell victim to this in a strange way at the conclusion of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals in Honolulu Sunday night.

title: British Steel May Buy in U.S.
description: The British Steel Corporation is discussing the purchase of an American steel plant so it can import more steel into the United States than is currently allowed, Scottish Secretary of State, George Younger, said today.

title: 1982 Output Off in Mexico
description: Mexico's production declined last year. The Banco de Mexico reported Tuesday that the gross national product fell two-tenths of 1 percent, after adjustment for inflation, from 1981.

title: Required Reading; Water, Water
description: Representative Jack Fields, Republican of Texas, inserting in the Congressional Record a report of the Department of Interior's United States Geological Survey, March 16, 1983:

title: Runner Out Till June
description: The injury that forced Dick Beardsley to drop out of the Brooklyn Half-Marathon at the nine-mile mark earlier this month was not so serious as originally reported, but it will keep him out of competition at least until late June, he has told his agent, Mike Demperio. Beardsley, whose cast was removed on Tuesday, said that his left Achilles' tendon was weak and strained, but not torn, as had been reported. But it will be a month before he can run again, Beardsley said, and even longer before he can compete.
