title: COASTAL INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including a gain of $3,283,000

title: Stage-Struck Producer
description: His business career began at 13 as a dog-walking tycoon. ''I employed up to 20 kids,'' Bryan Bantry recalled yesterday. But he was ''awed,'' he said, about being one of three producers of ''You Can't Take It With You,'' the 1936 Kaufman and Hart Pulitzer Prize-winning play previewing next week at the Plymouth Theater, with Jason Robards, James Coco, Elizabeth Wilson and Colleen Dewhurst.

title: BALLET: JULLIARD ENSEMBLE REVIVES TUDOR'S 'SOIREE'
description: THE Juilliard Dance Ensemble's program on Monday night at the Juilliard Theater combined old works with new. One old work, Antony Tudor's ''Soiree Musicale,'' was even a rarity. Created in London in 1938, it has been revived only occasionally in New York.

title: Eastern Airlines Reaches Accord With Machinists
description: Eastern Airlines and the union representing machinists reached tentative agreement today on a new contract, five hours before a midnight strike deadline.

title: MITTERRAND'S PLAN: BUY FRENCH AND WORK HARDER
description: President Francois Mitterrand renounced efforts tonight to solve France's economic problems through isolation from its allies, but issued a patriotic appeal to the people of France to buy French, travel French, work harder and save more.

title: RACE IN CHICAGO
description: ''Chicago GOP Inflaming TV Tubes,'' headlines the Washington Post. ''Candidate for Mayor Bludgeons Opponent in Media Campaign.''

title: RANGERS TROUNCE RED WINGS
description: The Rangers, playing with what Ed Mio called ''a skeleton club'' because of injuries, trounced the Detroit Red Wings, 7-1, tonight with a revised lineup.

title: OCCIDENTAL SELLS PART OF CITIES
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, in a move to reduce its $4.1 billion of debt, announced today that it was selling the refining and marketing operations and certain gasoline inventories of its Cities Service Company subsidiary for $567 million.

title: SEOUL'S LUCKY CREDITORS
description: To the Editor:

title: A New License for Censors
description: President Reagan's new directive for the handling of national security information greatly expands the number of past and present officials who must run the censor's gantlet before discussing important issues in public. But it makes the nation not one whit safer. It only increases the danger that questions of war and peace won't be debated as fully as they might be.

title: Advertising; Needham Bolsters Its Lineup
description: YOU can't get a hit unless you get a time at bat, and you don't get to bat without being invited to play. And so it is in the agency game. To be able to come up with a home run ad campaign, you must first have a client. Frequently, to get one you must be invited to compete with other heavy hitters. That requires a bit of a reputation.

title: SUPRADUR MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $200,563 for the qr and a gain of $132,272 for the yr for foreign currency translations...C-Including a gain of $483,883 for the qr and a loss of $257,648 for the yr for foreign currency translations; all results reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Standard No 52 regarding foreign currency translations

title: INTELLIGENCE AIDES DEBATED REAGAN'S SHOW OF SATELLITE PHOTOS
description: President Reagan's use of aerial reconnaissance photographs today to illustrate Soviet military expansion in the Caribbean region represented a compromise among his national security advisers about the disclosure of classified information, according to intelligence officials.

title: NIKE PINS HOPES FOR GROWTH ON FOREIGN SALES AND APPAREL
description: Nike Inc., whose waffle-soled running shoes have become familiar sights on America's athletes and would-be athletes, is pinning its long-term growth hopes on penetrating foreign markets and becoming a major sportswear marketer.

title: COALITION IN BONN AGREES ON POLICIES
description: After two weeks of negotiations, the three parties that make up West Germany's conservative coalition announced broad agreement today on domestic and foreign policies for the next four years.

title: SHOPS THAT SELL REPLACEMENT SHADES
description: A WIDE selection of soft and hard shades is available at department stores. Shades can also be found at neighborhood lamp and shade shops, many of which offer additional services on lamps and shades. Most shops that carry shades also carry lamp hardware. Here is a sampling of smaller establishments.

title: Q&A
description: Q. We have rough wood paneling on the wall, and wherever a picture or other decoration has been hung the wood has faded around it. Is there anything we can put on the wood to bring the color back?

title: Correction Officer Seized as Robber
description: A New York City correction officer, hired seven weeks ago, was arrested yesterday on charges of robbery and unlawful imprisonment, authorities said.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Shr earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid Feb 2

title: CONCERT: THE BOSTON CAMERATA
description: THERE is an enormous amount of liturgical music in the air during the Christian holiday seasons. But although Jewish holidays often roughly coincide with Christian festivals, we hear relativley fewer concerts of Jewish music. There are reasons for that, the main one being that Jewish liturgical music is almost exclusively an oral tradition carried on to this day in synagogues.

title: STAGE: GURNEY'S MIDDLE AGES' OPENS
description: TO be privileged, we're often told, is to be free: those born to wealth and social status have a head start in finding the happiest and most productive path through life. But the writer A.R. Gurney Jr. good-naturedly insists on reminding us that it isn't necessarily so. In plays like ''The Dining Room,'' ''What I Did Last Summer'' and now ''The Middle Ages,'' he says that even that most privileged of Americans, the upper-middle-class WASP, can be as trapped as anyone else. For Mr. Gurney's characters, living well is not the best revenge - it's the last and weakest defense.

title: Ballet Stars to Appear In Paul Taylor Benefits
description: Suzanne Farrell, Peter Martins and Mikhail Baryshnikov will join the Paul Taylor Dance Company in benefit galas during its season at City Center, from April 5 through May 1. Miss Farrell and Mr. Martins will perform ''Duet'' from ''Lento'' on opening night. Mr. Baryshnikov will perform ''Images'' on April 12.

title: Reagan Supports World Cup Bid
description: President Reagan said yesterday that the United States would be ''a superb choice as host for the 1986 World Cup,'' and pledged support to the United States Soccer Federation's efforts to obtain the event.

title: PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: B-Including tax credits of $606,000 for the qr and $1.6 million for the yr...C-Net income...D-Including a tax credit of $75,000 for the qr and yr; results for the latest periods reflect a provision of $2.2 million for the qr and yr for thedisposition of certain operations; results for the previous yr reflect a provision of $1.3 million for the disposition of certain operations and a nonrecurringcharge of $1.2 million

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum RateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Private Concerns Settle Suits in Oil Spill in Gulf
description: Sedco Inc., an oil drilling concern, agreed Tuesday to pay $2.14 million to settle lawsuits by fishermen, resorts and others affected by a destructive 1979 oil spill, according to an attorney for Sedco.

title: I.M.F. to Assist Zimbabwe
description: The International Monetary Fund approved today a $384 million financial package to help Zimbabwe. The assistance consists of an 18-month, $324 million standby arrangement that Zimbabwe can draw on as necessary.

title: Saad Muhammad Stopped in Third
description: Erik Winbush stopped Matthew Saad Muhammad, the former World Boxing Council champion, at 1:53 of the third round of their scheduled 10-round light-heavyweight bout tonight. Referee Zack Clayton stopped the fight after Winbush, 31 years old, landed unanswered combinations.

title: Reagan Said to Soften Approach to Embargoes
description: President Reagan, at a meeting of the National Security Council, acted today to defuse a potentially explosive East-West trade issue by agreeing to permit companies to honor existing contracts most of the time when trade restrictions are imposed, Administration officials reported.

title: RATES FALL FOR ALL MATURITIES
description: Interest rates for short- and long-term securities declined yesterday. Traders were encouraged by the emergence of good investor buying at this week's auctions of Treasury notes and bonds.

title: Rail Unions Reject Request
description: Leaders of 12 commuter rail unions, asked by a judge to accept a 30-day cooling-off period, voted unanimously today to continue their nine-day-old strike against the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority. The authority's 12 rail lines serve an estimated 40,000 riders daily.

title: Lilco Rating Is Lowered
description: Standard & Poor's said yesterday that three ratings on Long Island Lighting Company issues had been lowered because of the lack of an evacuation plan for the company's $3.2 billion nuclear power station at Shoreham.

title: Steel Strings for Salvador's Aid
description: With ineffable timing, a judge in El Salvador has invoked technical reasons to postpone the trial of five former National Guardsmen accused of the rape and murder of four American churchwomen in 1980. This nose-thumbing seems to have been too much even for the Reagan Administration, which now concedes the awfulness of what passes for Salvadoran justice. Embodying this concession in law is the least that Congress can do.

title: MISS AUSTIN AVERTS SETBACK AT GARDEN
description: This has not been Tracy Austin's most satisfying winter. But last night she saved a match point in a third-set tiebreaker against Virginia Ruzici and won an exciting 2-hour-45-minute match in the opening round of the $350,000 Virginia Slims of New York tennis championships.

title: William Zale Dead in Texas; Built Large Retail Company
description: William Zale, a Russian immigrant who helped build a small town jewelry shop into a $500 million retail corporation with 1,600 stores worldwide, died Tuesday. He was 79 years old.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE RELEASES MEMOS IN ADELMAN DISPUTE
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee made public four documents today that are said by several senators to show that Kenneth L. Adelman, President Reagan's nominee to head the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, misled the committee in testimony.

title: 'I HAD TO BOTTOM OUT'
description: One by one, the familiar names will be introduced Gordie Howe, Bobby Hull, Bobby Orr, Phil Esposito, to name four who will be appearing in the Masters of Hockey game between the United States and Canadian all-star teams at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight. And then he will be introduced, the coach of the United States team, Derek Sanderson, until recently a disaster of hockey. Now he's trying to rebuild the life he wasted as an alcoholic. Trying to write a book about it, too.

title: Glenn to Seek Presidency
description: Senator John Glenn will declare his candidacy for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination April 21 in his hometown of New Concord, Ohio, his campaign office said today. The former astronaut already has a large campaign staff operating here.

title: Ames Acquisition
description: Ames Department Stores Inc. agreed in principle to acquire KDT Industries, a retailing concern that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last August. Ames said it had also signed a management agreement for an Ames subsidiary to take over KDT's 42 King's stores.

title: MOVIE FOR NEW LE CARRE THRILLER SET
description: John le Carre's new spy thriller, ''The Little Drummer Girl,'' will be made into a movie for Warner Bros. by George Roy Hill, director of ''The Sting'' and ''Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid.''

title: SIX TOP OFFICIALS DISCHARGED BY NEW U.D.C. CHIEF
description: On his first day of work after being confirmed by the State Senate to head the Urban Development Corporation, William J. Stern today dismissed or accepted the resignations of six top officials of the agency.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Expos Seek New Home
description: The Montreal Expos, locked in a dispute over an Olympic Stadium lease, were given permission by the National League today to explore alternative sites for home games this season. John McHale, the Expos' president, said at a news conference that the alternatives could mean ''other sites, or perhaps playing some home games at the site of visiting clubs.''

title: CARROLS DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $774,671 for the qr and $1 million for the 9 mos and tax credits of $45,000 for the qr and $827,000 for the 9 mos; shr earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split effective in Feb

title: Couple at Arizona Rest Stop Robbed, Injected With Drug
description: A man and a woman robbed a couple in a recreational vehicle and then injected them with a substance that left them unconscious, the Mohave County Sheriff said today.

title: CITICORP'S SATELLITE CHALLENGE
description: On April 1, a clerk in a Long Island office of Citicorp will make history by picking up the phone and dialing a Citicorp office in California.

title: Ranch Houses? Where?
description: ''Look at that,'' says Ed Logue, a restless, impish man who has rebuilt cities. The scene is the South Bronx, that notorious symbol of urban desolation, on Boston Road near 163d St. He points through the windshield to three Queen Anne-style frame row houses. All are occupied, painted, in good repair. ''Now,'' he says a second later, ''look at that.'' He points to the next building, the burned brick hulk of an elevator apartment house. It's a scene that teaches two lessons about the South Bronx - and about the life and death of cities.

title: Coal Find in Illinois
description: Scientists from the Illinois Geological Survey have discovered a large coal deposit that may have low to moderate levels of sulfur. A geologist, Russell Jacobson, said on Tuesday that the discovery in Jackson and Perry Counties might stimulate more exploration for low-sulfur coal in the vast bituminous reserves in Illinois.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: THOUGH most traverse rods will work for years without attention, they sometimes get out of adjustment so the curtains or drapes they support do not open evenly. Alternatively, the rods may become difficult to operate or they may jam. In most such cases repairs and adjustments are fairly simple to make, but you must be at least moderately familiar with the way the rods work.

title: REPUBLICAN IS FAVORED FOR HOUSE SEAT OF ASTRONAUT WHO DIED
description: In January, a week before he was to be sworn in as the first Representative from Colorado's new Sixth Congressional District, Jack Swigert, the former astronaut, died of cancer.

title: AMPAL-AMERICAN ISRAEL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Harris to Sell Unit
description: The Harris Corporation announced that it had signed a definitive contract to sell its $400 million printing equipment business to a new company organized by Clayton & Dubilier Inc., a New York investment firm. The Melbourne, Fla., company said it expected to receive about $250 million from the sale, which is scheduled to be closed within 30 days.

title: Escalating Salaries
description: Jack Donlan, the executive director of the National Football League's Management Council, told club officials that the average player salary in 1982 was $104,800, a 16.5 percent increase over the 1981 average.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MARCH 24, 1983
description: International

title: TIPS ON SELECTING A FLOOR REFINISHER
description: A NEW tenant on the Upper West Side took one look at her water-tortured floorboards, reached for the phone book and began calling floor refinishers. For 50 cents a square foot, the company of her choice promised, her floors would be transformed.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny Beverage Corp., Baltimore, has elected to its board William D. Houser, vice president of Comsat General Corporation.

title: BEACH LOSS IN NEW YORK AREA WORST IN YEARS
description: From Jones Beach east to Shinnecock Inlet on Long Island, from Sandy Hook south to Cape May along the Jersey Shore, this winter has been one of the most destructive to beaches in the metropolitan area in years.

title: BARNEY CLARK DIES ON 112TH DAY WITH PERMANENT ARTIFICIAL HEART
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark, the recipient of the world's first permanent artificial heart, died last night at the University of Utah Medical Center, 112 days after the plastic and aluminum device was implanted in his chest.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: A WOODLAND WALK
description: Woodland Walk, Wave Hill, 675 West 252d Street, Bronx, 212-549-2055.

title: SENATE APPROVES PLAN ON SOLVENCY OF SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The Senate, with bipartisan support, tonight approved after 40 hours of debate a plan designed to assure the solvency of Social Security for the next 75 years.

title: ALLEGHENY LAND & MINERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday incorrectly reported the details of the new program of acreage reduction and payment in kind announced by the Department of Agriculture. A corrective article appears on page A19.

title: POPE TO VISIT 8 PLACES ON HIS POLISH TOUR
description: The Vatican announced today that Pope John Paul II would visit eight places in Poland during his trip to his homeland from June 16 to 22. The list does not include Gdansk, the birthplace in 1980 of the independent trade union Solidarity, which was outlawed last year.

title: Out at Home
description: Juan Marichal, elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in January, won 243 games in his 16-year major league career, most of them with the San Francisco Giants. Since his retirement from baseball in 1975, he has been active in youth community sports programs in his native Dominican Republic.

title: A 'PAPER TIGER' FOR THE I.R.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: KOCH PRESSES TICKET TAX
description: Depsite the fact that Governor Cuomo has dropped his proposal for a sales tax on theater admissions, Mayor Koch is going ahead with his own plan for a tax on tickets to live performances and movies.

title: The Coach's Wife Is True to Form
description: Mary Carnesecca won't, of course, be going to Syracuse for the East Regional semifinals and final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's basketball tournament this weekend, and she won't be heading for Albuquerque, N.M., either, in the event St. John's makes the Final Four.

title: Gas Leak Routs 150 in Nassau
description: More than 150 people were evacuated from their homes Tuesday night after a valve blew off a main natural gas line at an excavation site at Lincoln and Hillside Avenues, spewing gas throughout the area, the Nassau County police said.

title: News Analysis
description: With their victory in today's vote on the budget, House Democratic leaders completed the transition of power that began with the election last November and established their effective control over the House of Representatives for the first time since President Reagan took office.

title: A.M.C. TO OFFER $100 MILLION IN STOCK
description: The American Motors Corporation, saying it does not expect to show a profit in the next two years, announced today that it will issue 15 million new shares of stock in coming weeks to generate $100 million for new products.

title: FLOWERING TREES FOR CITY GARDENS
description: BY planting a small flowering tree, city gardeners with limited space can get the most for their money, since these plants provide a three-dimensional framework all year, and four seasons of change.

title: SUNDRY NEWCOMERS CHANGE THE FACE OF AUSTRALIA
description: Seated in the lounge of their mosque beneath colorful pictures of Mecca, the group of Turkish immigrants waited for the night shift to start at a nearby automobile factory and talked about their adopted country.

title: Pate Is Sidelined
description: Jerry Pate, who won the Tournament Players Championship last year, has withdrawn from this week's tournament and will probably not play golf again before July because of a lingering shoulder injury.

title: MAGIC CIRCLE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
DEMOCRATIC BUDGET IS ADOPTED BY HOUSE, 229-196
description: The House of Representatives tonight approved a Federal budget that was drafted by the Democrats. By a vote of 229 to 196, the Democrats and the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts, scored a solid victory despite the defection of some conservatives. These same conservatives in alliance with the Republicans gave President Reagan budget victories, which were defeats for Mr. O'Neill and James R. Jones of the Budget Committee, in 1981 and 1982.

title: DANCE: FRANCOIS KLAUS IN HAMBURG'S 'MAHLER'
description: LAST night's performance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music demonstrated that ''Mahler's Third Symphony'' is surely the finest work by John Neumeier that the Hamburg Ballet has yet shown us.

title: CHANNEL 13 DIAL RESCUE ATTEMPT SAID TO UNRAVEL
description: A new arrangement to rescue The Dial, the financially ailing magazine of listings and articles about public television published by WNET-TV, the major public television station in the New York metropolitan area, has come unraveled, sources at Channel 13 said yesterday.

title: French Unit Buys Interest in Syncor
description: The Syncor International Corporation said today that it had signed an agreement for the health care division of the Atomic Energy Commission of France, Office des Rayonnements Ionisants, to buy a 30 percent interest in Syncor for $24.2 million.

title: INTERNATIONAL CLINICAL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Yr-ago results have been restated

title: Arguments Heard In Moon's Appeal
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan yesterday reserved its decision after hearing arguments on the appeal of the tax-fraud conviction of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon of the Unification Church.

title: Israelis Shoot and Wound 3 In Clash on Lebanon Highway
description: Israeli soldiers shot and wounded three Lebanese civilians today when several hundred demonstrators blocked the coastal road between Tyre and Beirut, military sources said.

title: Chapman Energy
description: Chapman Energy Inc., a Dallas oil and gas exploration and production company, said it had acquired a 23 percent interest in Giant Piper Exploration Inc., a Canadian-based oil and gas exploration company. Under the transaction, approximately 3.16 shares of Giant Piper will be exchanged for each share of Chapman Energy.

title: Phone Officers Named
description: D.C. Staley, who will be chief executive officer of the company to be formed when the New York Telephone Company and the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company become a single unit, announced the appointment yesterday of six vice presidents for the combined entity.

title: DOW SOARS BY 17.90 TO 1,140.87
description: Favorable inflation news helped the stock market post impressive gains yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average soaring 17.90 points, to close at 1,140.87.

title: MUSIC: SAXOPHONE NED ROTHENBERG
description: IS there anyone in the world who cares more than Ned Rothenberg about what a saxophone can do? Listening to this avant-garde exponent of the instrument play his own compositions for it at Symphony Space on Tuesday night, one imagined that Mr. Rothenberg might think of himself as being alone in the universe with the saxophone as his only comfort and means of expression.

title: TRAVELING THE PATH OF DE TOQUEVILLE
description: If it's Wednesday, it must be Pittsburgh, or Little Rock, Ark., or Tampa, Fla., or Spartanburg, S.C. The travel schedule of Ambassador Bernard Vernier-Palliez, who manages the French diplomatic establishment in Washington from a honey-hued, 50-year-old chateau on Kalorama Road, puts him at least one up on the proverbial American tourist in Europe.

title: ABC Plans to Acquire Small System Services
description: The American Broadcasting Companies said it is going to acquire Small System Services in Greensboro, N.C., a private publishing company in the computer field.

title: Aladdin Casino Faces Auction
description: Managers of the teamster union's pension fund, owed $32 million by the Aladdin Hotel-Casino, have begun foreclosure procedures that could put the Las Vegas resort on the auction block April 7 if back payments are not made.

title: DeLorean Delay On Reorganization
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge granted the DeLorean Motor Company until April 25 to reorganize the company after he was told that a group of investors wanted to buy the company's remaining assets and resume production.

title: A SPECTER HOOVERING OVER F.B.I.
description: When the Federal Bureau of Investigation issued a statement last November supporting President Reagan's charge that Communists were manipulating the nuclear freeze movement, Representative Don Edwards protested to the F.B.I. Director, William H. Webster. Mr. Edwards is chairman of the House Subcommittee on Civil and Constitutional Rights, which has oversight jurisdiction over the F.B.I., and he reminded Mr. Webster how swift J. Edgar Hoover had been to find subversives wherever there was dissent - and how far Mr. Hoover had gone to penetrate and disrupt their organizations. ''Let us learn from history and not repeat our mistakes,'' Mr. Edwards warned.

title: HERS
description: MANY of us have known the Person Who Wouldn't Go Away, whether it was a persistent boy in eighth grade, a nostalgic old flame or just a guy who took a liking to us and liked and liked and liked beyond all reason. And those of us raised never to hurt feelings or step on toes suffered a strange, almost benevolent torture. We became the victims of someone else's determined heart.

title: COST INDEX UNCHANGED IN THE NEW YORK AREA
description: The Consumer Price Index for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area was unchanged in February on a seasonally adjusted basis. Increases in prices for food, medical care, home furnishings, auto insurance and women's apparel were largely offset by declines for energy and airline fares, according to Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, Regional Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Between February 1982 and February 1983, he said, consumer prices in the area rose 5.3 percent.

title: Missouri Governor Signs Bill to Aid Times Beach
description: Gov. Christopher S. Bond today signed an emergency appropriations bill setting up a $4.5 million state fund to assist in the Federal Government's plan to buy out the dioxin-contaminated town of Times Beach from its residents.

title: ALBANY REACHES ACCORD TO PASS CONSUMER BILLS
description: Banks in New York State would be required to clear customers' checks more quickly under a bill agreed upon by leaders in both parties of the Legislature.

title: A NEW FORMALITY AT SAINT LAURENT
description: Because Yves Saint Laurent's fashion openings are usually toward the end of a new season's showings, he bears a singular responsibility. His collection serves as a touchstone in more ways than one. If it is considered good, then the entire season is considered a success. The trends he supports or establishes are regarded as the hallmarks of the season.

title: NO REQUEST FOR CANADA ARMS TEST, BUSH SAYS
description: Vice President Bush said today that the United States had not asked Canada to allow testing of the low-flying cruise missile over its territory.

title: JONES AND LOUISVILLE MAKING LONG RUN
description: The McCray brothers from Mount Vernon, N.Y. - Rodney and Scooter - are the big men inside who usually get the points, the rebounds and the attention. Milt Wagner and Lancaster Gordon are the swift guards who can slam-dunk like 7-footers. But many basketball people insist the man who makes the Louisville basketball team so good is Charles Jones, the unheralded 6-foot-8-inch center.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Technology; Fast Retrieval Of Documents
description: ONE of the lesser-known areas in the office of the future is micrographics, especially the use of computers to pluck copies of documents from rolls of microfilm and display them on a screen. This sector of the information storage and retrieval industry is expected to grow by 8 percent to 10 percent or more annually.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Industries, New York, announced that it is negotiating the possible acquisition of Bahama Precious Metals Inc., a Nassaubased company that recovers and refines precious metals from scrap; terms were not disclosed.

title: ALTAMIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Transcript of speech, page A20.
description: President Reagan, defending his military program, proposed tonight to exploit advances in technology in coming decades so the United States can develop an effective defense against missiles launched by others.

title: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Jet's Landing Gear Collapses
description: The landing gear on a Frontier Airlines 737 jet collapsed on touchdown today at Natrona County International Airport, officials said. One of the 95 people aboard was slightly injured in the evacuation. Both of the airliner's engines were on fire when the aircraft skidded to a stop, but the flames were quickly extinguished, officials said.

title: News Analysis
description: Mayor Koch once again finds himself in a dispute with New York City's black and Hispanic communities, this time over his nomination of Robert F. Wagner Jr. as the next Chancellor of the New York City public school system.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bob Horner of the Braves is being shifted back to third base from left field, and Jerry Royster, a defensive specialist who had been trying out a third, has lost his place in the starting lineup because of a poor batting performance. . . . Tom Herr, the Cardinals' second baseman, said he would probably not be able to play by opening day. Herr had surgery on his right knee in the offseason, then injured his left knee the second day of spring training.

title: Market Place; Look at Waste Management
description: WASTE MANAGEMENT INC., which has held center stage this week on the New York Stock Exchange, jumped 5 3/8 points yesterday, to 47, after plummeting a total of 18 1/4 points Monday and Tuesday on volume exceeding 5.3 million shares. Yesterday, the stock led the mostactive list again on a turnover of more than 2.1 million shares.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: GREEK FUNERAL BECOMES RALLY
description: A funeral procession today for a slain newspaper publisher, Tzortzis Athanasiades, turned into a major protest demonstration against the 17-month old Socialist Government.

title: Ecuador at a Standstill Because of Union Strike
description: A general strike called by Ecuador's major unions brought the country to a standstill today, Labor Minister Vladimiro Alvarez Grau said.

title: Flu Outbreak Kills 3 At Maine Nursing Home
description: Three residents of a Portland nursing home have died as a result of a type B flu outbreak, which the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta lists as the first of that type in the country this year.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Briefing column on the Washington Talk page yeterday incorrectly described the cancellation of the Tidewater Conference that was to have been held this year by Republicans. The meeting was canceled by a staff aide of the National Republican Senatorial Committee late in February, when it was headed by Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana.

title: VARIABLE ANNUITY LIFE ELECTS NEW PRESIDENT
description: Joe D. Heusi, 40, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Variable Annuity Life Insurance Company. It is one of the nation's largest commercial life insurance companies specializing in tax-deferred annuities for teachers and employees of tax-exempt organizations.

title: 7 NEW ORLEANS POLICEMEN END THEIR DEFENSE
description: Defense lawyers rested their case today in the 13th day of the Federal civil rights trial of seven white New Orleans police officers accused of abusing four witnesses in an investigation into the slaying of a fellow policeman.

title: AMERICAN CONTROLLED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Squash Tourney Starting
description: The 32 finalists in the Rolex United States Open squash racquets championship will begin play today at the Yale Club and the Manhattan Squash and Racquet Club.

title: SALVADOR AID BACKED IN SENATE
description: President Reagan's request for more military aid to El Salvador won its first victory in Congress today as a Senate appropriations subcommittee approved $60 million to be diverted from military assistance elsewhere.

title: By 'MASTER HAROLD' STUNS JOHANNESBURG AUDIENCE
description: ''Master Harold . . . and the Boys,'' Athol Fugard's confessional drama about a white adolescent's initiation in the uses of racial power, has come home to South Africa, and it left its multiracial audience at the opening night performance here on Tuesday visibly shaken and stunned.

title: FRENCH PARTNER TO BUY BRITISH SHARE IN BECKER
description: The New York securities firm of A.G. Becker-Warburg Paribas Becker Inc. said yesterday that its Government-owned French partner had agreed to buy out the firm's British partner.

title: Wallace in Hospital for Pain
description: Gov. George C. Wallace, who has been suffering pain spasms associated with his paralysis, met with aides in his hospital room today as officials said there was no significant change in his condition. Governor Wallace, 63 years old, was listed in ''satisfactory but improving'' condition, according to his press secretary, Billy Joe Camp.

title: CITY SUPPORTS BILL IN ALBANY EXTENDING J-51 TAX BREAKS
description: New York City agreed tonight to a bill proposed by the Cuomo administration that would extend the city's principal tax-incentive program for developers, according to a senior city official. However, the bill would restrict significantly the circumstances under which those tax benefits could be granted.

title: NETS MATCH SEASON-HIGH TOTAL AND WIN
description: The Nets have quickly adapted to the loss of Otis Birdsong. They matched their season high in points and seven of their players scored in double figures in a 124-104 victory tonight over the Utah Jazz at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Bruce Bowden, Ex-President Of Mellon Bank, Is Dead at 74
description: A. Bruce Bowden, a former president and vice chairman of the Mellon Bank, died Friday at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 74 years old.

title: Jail Inmate Reappears From Ceiling Hideout
description: An unexpected guest dropped in while two police officers were eating dinner: an inmate who had spent three days in the crawl space above the jail ceiling.

title: CONCERT: MAHLER AT THE MARYMOUNT
description: THE New York Mahlerites's evening of music and dance at the Marymount Theater Sunday night walked around the edges of the Mahler repertory without really saying much about it. A congregation of musicians, singers, dancers and commentators gave us Mahler the arranger, Mahler the arranged and Mahler the poet. There was also music Mahler might have written but didn't, music written for Mahler's widow by someone else, and - most far-fetched of all - examples of music Mahler hated.

title: SHADE CAN BE NEW, EVEN IF LAMP ISN'T
description: MADE lampshades are available in so many sizes, shapes and styles that choosing one is considered among the most difficult decorating decisions. The look of a room can often be freshened by the simple change of replacing lampshades.

title: STOKELY-VAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
Bell Affiliate Offer Gets AAA Rating
description: The South Central Bell Telephone Company received the highest rating - AAA - from the Standard & Poor's Corporation for the $250 million of notes and bonds it plans to sell in the near future. The rating agency has not yet announced new ratings for other affiliates of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Japan's Vehicle Output
description: Production of vehicles in Japan rose in February to 892,688 from 800,444 in January and 879,496 a year earlier, owing to increased domestic sales and exports, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers' Association said today. The February total consisted of 580,031 cars, up 3.5 percent from the 1982 month; 306,274 trucks, down 2.3 percent, and 6,383 buses, up 7.8 percent.

title: S.&P. Downgrades Metromedia Debt
description: Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday announced a downgrading for Metromedia Inc.'s subordinated debentures to a speculative grade of BB+ from the investment grade of BBB.

title: U.S. Wins, 6-2, In Hockey Event
description: The United States hockey team defeated Rumania, 6-2, today and moved into first place on the third day of the world group B championship.

title: 'DIRTY DISHES'
description: MOVIE housewives have been breaking down with some regularity recently, but none has done it quite so comically as Armelle (Carole Laure), the increasingly anxiety-ridden Parisian wife and mother in Joyce Bunuel's 1978 French comedy, ''Dirty Dishes'' (''La Jument Vapeur'').

title: Prince Thibault d'Orleans, 35; Son of the French Pretender
description: Prince Thibault d'Orleans, youngest son of the Count of Paris, Pretender to the French throne, died of a heart attack in a hunting camp in the Central African Republic, his friends said today. He was 35 years old.

title: 2 Men Found Slain Near Stolen Taxi
description: The bodies of two men with bullet wounds in the back of their heads were found early yesterday morning near an abandoned taxi in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Market Place; 5 Aerospace Issues Favored
description: ONE problem the average investor often faces with a stock portfolio is that different issues respond to different sets of circumstances. The investor may own some stocks that respond favorably to lower interest rates, others that benefit from higher commodity prices and still others keyed to a technological breakthrough or the success of a new product.

title: Houston Thrives With Inside Game
description: It was time for lunch at the fraternity house, and the members were famished. ''How big is the biggest steak you've got?'' asked Akeem Abdul Olajuwon, who, at 7 feet, is the tallest member of the Phi Slama Jama fraternity, otherwise known as the nation's No.1-ranked team, Houston.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Customer's Stake in Power Plants
description: When a new power plant is under construction, who should bear the financial risk? Common sense points to the utility's creditors and stockholders. After all, when Kellogg is building a new factory, the customers aren't expected to pay the mortgage with a surcharge on Raisin Bran.

title: Ford's Cash Position Drops
description: The Ford Motor Company said in its annual report today that its cash and marketable securities had declined 24 percent at the end of last year, to $1.6 billion, from $2.1 billion a year earlier.

title: Peking Gets New Mayor In Party Shake-Ups
description: China announced a new Mayor for Peking today and provincial leadership changes in a shake-up aimed at rejuvenating the country's elderly bureaucracy.

title: COLLEGE REPUBLICANS VS. CAMPUS DEMOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: BILL WOULD LET THE STATE SEIZE CRIMINALS' ASSETS
description: Legislation to deny criminals ''the fruits of their ill-gotten gains'' will be introduced in Albany next week, Attorney General Robert Abrams said yesterday.

title: Rutgers Asks State For More Funds
description: Rutgers University's president today called for an extra $6.3 million to help reduce tuition increases and improve high-technology training.

title: VIRGINIA, N.C. STATE ADVANCE TO FINAL
description: North Carolina State and the University of Virginia will play here Saturday for the championship of the West Regional in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. The winner Saturday will move on to Albuquerque, N.M., for the semifinal and final rounds, April 2 and 4.

WHITE HOUSE UPSET BY GUARDS' SCANNING OF HISPANIC LEADERS
description: White House officials reacted with embarrassment today after the Secret Service required a group of Hispanic Republican leaders to pass through a hastily erected metal-detection device before their visit with President Reagan.

title: A CALENDAR OF MUSIC FOR THE EASTER HOLIDAY SEASON
description: Following are some of the musical presentations planned for the Easter season at churches and concert halls in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted. Today Church of St. Mary the Virgin (Episcopal), 145 West 46th Street. ''O Quam Gloriosum Est Regnum'' Mass and ''Ave Maria'' by Victoria, works by Palestrina and Couperin; Quentin Lane, music director and organist. At 6 P.M. Information: 869-5830. Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts, Bedford Park Boulevard West, Bronx. ''O Sacrum Convivium'' by Giovanni Croce, ''Hodie Christus Natus Est'' by Palestrina, Missa Brevis by Britten; Vienna Choir Boys. At 8 P.M. Tickets, $8, $10 and $12. Information: 960-8833.

title: WEINBERGER SAYS ABM PACT MAY ULTIMATELY NEED AMENDING
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said here today that President Reagan's proposal on Wednesday to look for new ways to defend against missiles ''was fully consistent'' with the antiballistic missile treaty signed with the Soviet Union in 1972.

title: Met Winners Sing
description: Eleven winners of the annual Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions will perform on Sunday at 2:30 P.M. at the Metropolitan Opera House in Lincoln Center.

title: Kevin Kline is due back in the park for 'Henry V.'
description: KEVIN KLINE will be returning to Central Park this summer. And so will Shakespeare. Together at last, on a New York stage. Mr. Kline, who had a triumph in the park two years ago as the swashbuckling Pirate King in ''The Pirates of Penzance,'' will star in Joseph Papp's production of ''Henry V,'' which will give free performances in the park from June 24 to July 24.

title: Lifetime Commitment
description: Meade H. Esposito was in colorful form yesterday trying to squelch repeated rumors that he might retire after 15 years as Brooklyn's Democratic leader.

title: Fouts Deadline Set
description: Their negotiations haven't been going anywhere in private, so the San Diego Chargers and their free-agent quarterback, Dan Fouts, have taken their contract talks public. Fouts, who is reportedly seeking $1 million a year, said he would be prepared to sit out part of next season if that's what it takes to get the Chargers to meet his price.

title: Former Argentina Chief Testifies on War
description: Former President Leopoldo Galtieri testified today before a military commission investigating the extent of his responsibility for Argentina's defeat in the Falkland Islands war.

title: 'THE MISSISSIPPI,' NEW SERIES, STARTS
description: TONIGHT at 10, CBS starts a weekly series called ''The Mississippi.'' The star is Ralph Waite, who has had the role of the father on ''The Waltons'' for the better part of a decade. This new project is a Ralph Waite Production, and the actor is also one of the supervising producers.

title: Gray Smoke Over the Vatican
description: That Soviet agents had a hand in the attempted assassination of John Paul II in 1981 no longer seems a wild surmise. A web of fresh detail supports the Italian Government's suspicion that the would-be killer, Mehmet Ali Agca, acted in concert with Bulgarian intelligence agents.

title: Dr Pepper Drink
description: Dr Pepper Inc. said it would begin marketing next month a sugared version of its no-caffeine soft drink Pepper Free, now available only in a sugar-free form. The no-caffeine segment of the soft-drink industry is expanding faster than the industry as a whole, Richard Armstrong, Dr Pepper's president, said in making the announcement. He said that when regular Pepper Free is introduced, the company will expand distribution of both its no-caffeine sodas so that they are available to 75 percent of its distributors.

title: Matthew G. Forrest, 77, Dies; An Architect of Naval Vessels
description: Matthew G. Forrest, a naval architect who participated in the design of many Navy vessels and the liner United States, died Wednesday at the Hunterdon Medical Center in Flemington, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived in Califon, N.J.

title: THE CRUCIAL POSITIONING OF A HEALTH INSURANCE 'TAX CAP'
description: To the Editor:

title: AAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
KEY LEGISLATORS AGREE ON MONEY TO AID SHELTERS
description: Key legislators have agreed to a plan by Governor Cuomo to provide $12.5 million for the construction or rehabilitation of housing for the homeless, legislative aides said today. The Governor's plan is $8 million more than last year's appropriation for the homeless.

title: MAILER TAKES THE STAND FOR WRITER IN DRUG CASE
description: For seven years, by his own account, Richard Lowell Stratton dwelt in the stealthy and uncertain world of international drug smuggling, gathering material for a book, he says, from the company of men called the Three-Eyed Weasel or the Barn Swallow.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 12
'DUGAN RETURNS'
description: IT'S a measure of Neil Simon's ingenuity that ''Max Dugan Returns,'' a film whose premise is more than a little unsavory when you stop to think about it, manages to be a complete crowd pleaser anyhow. Mr. Simon's original screenplay is fast and buoyant, and Herbert Ross's direction shows off the abundant jokes to their best possible advantage. There are certainly some questionable ingredients to the story, but you're not likely to notice them while the film is under way. You're likely to be laughing.
