description: Companies

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CHRONICLE OF A DEATH FORETOLD. By Gabriel Garcia Marquez. Translated from the Spanish by Gregory Rabassa. 120 pages. Knopf. $10.95.

title: Advertising; National Journal Has New Goals
description: THE National Journal, a weekly published in Washington, is as serious in the magazine field as Peak Freans are in the land of cookies. And if you don't believe it check the annual subscription price, $455. You can't get much more serious than that.

title: Plea to Keep Cavs
description: A campaign has been launched by two disk jockeys in Cleveland to keep the Cavaliers of the National Basketball Association from moving.

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS A $4.6 BILLION JOB BILL
description: President Reagan signed into law a $4.6 billion emergency job bill Thursday night, after the House of Representatives gave its final approval.

title: MAYOR OFFERS AID AND HAND TO HOMELESS
description: Mayor Koch went around the Lower East Side Wednesday evening trying to talk homeless and mentally disturbed people into giving up a life on the streets for a hot meal and a warm bed in one of the city's shelters.

title: Tuscan Picks Venet For 2 TV Assignments
description: Tuscan Dairies of Union, N.J., an accomplished agency hopper, returned to Venet Advertising in December after an absence of about four years with a creative-only, six-month assignment to introduce two new products. Both are TV jobs.

title: BUMBLING MISSILE DIPLOMACY
description: Luckily, Moscow has also made some mistakes in the battle for European opinion on the missile issue. The Russians in effect joined Washington in trying to turn West Germany's recent elections into a referendum on deployment. They lost because it was primarily a bread-and-butter election, but also because they were too strident, too crude in their threats at the end.

title: Walden Pell, 80, Dies; Priest and Headmaster
description: The Rev. Walden Pell 2d, the first headmaster of St. Andrew's School, Middletown, Del., died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Elkton, Md., after a brief illness. He was 80 years old.

title: CHURCH PANEL GIVES NO RULING ON HOMOSEXUAL GROUP
description: Theologians who were asked to help decide whether a denomination formed primarily for homosexuals was eligible for membership in the National Council of Churches reached no conclusion in a report issued yesterday. The theologians said council rules ''could be interpreted to allow for either a positive or a negative vote on this matter.''

title: Cleanup Complaint Made At Three Mile Island
description: An engineer for the Bechtel Corporation was suspended indefinitely with pay today after he complained to Federal officials that dangerous shortcuts were being taken in the cleanup of the crippled Three Mile Island nuclear plant.

title: BERKEY PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-including income of $31,000 for the quarter and a loss of $226,000 for the year nad extraordinary gains of $275,000 for the quarter and $330,000 for the year. c-Net loss after a loss of $185,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary charge of $238,000. d-including incoem of $2,042,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $1,106,000.

title: Article 057154 -- No Title
description: People Express Airlines won tentative approval yesterday from the Civil Aeronautics Board to fly between Newark and London, and the C.A.B. endorsed the carrier's plan to charge $149 one-way. That's less than half the lowest fare now available on trans-Atlantic flights.

title: SECRETARY SHULTZ: QUESTIONS, ANSWERS, THOUGHTS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who has a little shirt-sleeves cubbyhole back of his fancy office, was asked to reflect there the other day on the problems of leadership in Government, business and universities. Q. You've run the Labor, Treasury and State Departments, the Bechtel Corporation and served at the University of Chicago. How would you compare these jobs?

title: Boy Who Killed Father Is Released on Bond
description: A 16-year-old high school junior convicted of voluntary manslaughter in the shooting death of his father was freed on $50,000 bond today pending his appeal.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: China seeking a way to art

title: Sporting Fare: Food for Thought
description: ''Putting mustard on it'' and ''plum ball'' are not just gustatory descriptions; they also apply to the world of sports. The first deals with a baseball pitcher who is throwing hard, the other is a racquetball term for a cinch shot.

title: One-Day Draft
description: The National Football League announced today that its college draft, scheduled for April 26 and 27, would be shortened to a one-day session, beginning 8 A.M. April 26.

title: Activity Is Heavy In Housing Bonds
description: Local governments and securities firms are rushing to beat a possible deadline for selling a type of housing bond that provides individual investors with up to $100,000 of insurance from the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

title: COMEDY: ROBERT KLEIN
description: ROBERT KLEIN flailed about at the world last night, potshooting at Nazis, the offensive line of the New Jersey Generals, automobile manufacturers, the Paris Opera, public television, Johann Sebastian Bach, the ballet, electronic preachers, his wife's singing career, the Yankees, striking actors and Hawaiian Punch. And he didn't miss once.

title: NIELSEN, A C, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
News Analysis
description: When the Rev. Sun Myung Moon was indicted for tax evasion in December 1981, he stood on the steps of the United States Court House at Foley Square and declared: ''I would not be standing here today if my skin were white and my religion were Presbyterian. I am here today only because my skin is yellow and my religion is Unification Church.''

title: HOLME'S CHALLENGER TREATED ROYALLY
description: Harry Rescigno, one of Scranton's finest, is normally assigned to the vice squad. This week, Mayor James B. McNulty has assigned him to look after a 31-year-old French meter reader who will be trying to win the World Boxing Council's heavyweight championship Sunday here from Larry Holmes.

title: GENERAL DEFENSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Year-Ago results have been restated for discontinued opeations and for a 5 percent stock dividend paid Jan.25, 1983 and a 50 percent stock dividend paid March 15, 1983.

title: WAKE FOREST TOPS SOUTH CAROLINA, 78-61
description: Danny Young scored 17 points, and Alvis Rogers and Delaney Rudd had 14 apiece as Wake Forest defeated South Carolina, 78-61, in the National Invitation Tournament quarterfinals tonight.

title: DANCE: MISS PENNISON
description: AMONG young modern-dance choreographers, Marleen Pennison has been one of the first to point the way toward the current rediscovery of narrative forms.

title: END THE CAMBODIA EMBARGO
description: America should lift its seven-year-old total embargo on Cambodia and begin looking at new foreign policy approaches toward Southeast Asia. The opportunity to do so is at hand. For this month, both houses of Congress are conducting hearings to determine what changes should be made in the Export Administration Act when it is up for renewal in the fall. It is this legislation that has made the embargo possible.

title: Starless Georgia Stresses Defense
description: A couple of University of Georgia coaches were hanging around courtside at the U.G.A. Coliseum this week discussing what might have been if Herschel Walker had stayed in school.

title: GOING AFTER CODFISH ON THE DAWN PATROL
description: If you can limit your weekend partying, you might wish to take part late tonight in Sheepshead Bay's first offshore codfishing trip of the spring, aboard the Ardolino family's head boat, the Amberjack.

title: 7 OF 11 BLACKS ARE CLEARED IN MONTGOMERY, ALA., BATTLE WITH POLICE AFTER A FUNERAL
description: Charges against seven of 11 blacks accused of trying to kill two white police officers in a home where blacks had gathered after a funeral were dismissed today. The four other blacks were held for a grand jury and the prosecutor said he would seek new charges against those who were cleared.

title: SCIENTISTS DUBIOUS OVER MISSILE PLAN
description: Some scientists said today that President Reagan's proposal to develop a defense against nuclear attack may never be technically feasible, but that it would be strategically ''dangerous'' if it was ever made workable. Other scientists defended the concept.

title: Decline of 8,000 Is Reported In New Jobless Benefit Claims
description: New applications for unemployment benefits declined by 8,000 in the second week of March, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Barney Clark and Lord Tennyson
description: The death of Barney Clark, 112 days after having received an artificial heart at the University of Utah Medical Center, marks the close of a courageous experiment. Was it worthwhile?

title: GOOD BUSINESS NEWS FOR AMERICA'S ARTS
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO DRIVE TO TRIM PAYROLL CONFUSES AND UPSETS WORKERS
description: Governor Cuomo's drive to pare the state work force has plunged thousands of state workers into confusion as they wait to hear if they face joblessness, a demotion or a big cut in salary.

title: Hong Kong Phone
description: The Cable and Wireless Company, operator of Britain's overseas telecommunications links, said it was buying slightly more than one-third of the Hong Kong Telephone Company for more than $200 million. Cable and Wireless, denationalized by the British Government in 1981, said it was acquiring the shares from Hong Kong Land, one of the colony's biggest companies. Hong Kong Land said the sale was in the best interest of its shareholders ''in the current circumstances of the Hong Kong property market.''

title: Wisconsin Gains Final
description: Paul Houck scored one goal and assisted on another, and Wisconsin used the splendid goaltending of Marc Behrend as the Badgers defeated Providence, 2-0, tonight in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I semifinals.

title: The Air Fare Carnival
description: Flying to Los Angeles? That will be $198 roundtrip. . . . Not until April 3? Oh, then it's $318, provided you pay seven days in advance and stay between seven and 14 days. . . . Not long enough? Well, the unrestricted fare is $499. . . . If your boss approves first class, that will be $444 one-way, and $539 if you stop en route. But hold on! Some new fares are coming over the computer now . . .

title: 'JUST-IN-TIME' SYSTEM CUTS JAPAN'S AUTO COSTS
description: Yoshiyuki Sugiura, superintendent of the Nippondenso Company's plant that produces automotive alternators here, is one of the middle-level executives who make Japan's unique kanban, or just-in-time, manufacturing system work.

title: AUTOS: THE FADING 'BUY U.S.' RATIONALE
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELIS REPORTED TO BALK AT PLAN FOR WITHDRAWAL
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that Israel had refused to accept ideas proposed by the United States last week to break the deadlock in the negotiations for an Israeli troop withdrawal from Lebanon.

title: TOIL ON MANHATTAN CO-OP PLAN PAYS OFF
description: When tenants at the Quaker Ridge, a 263-unit postwar apartment building at 201 East 21st Street in Manhattan, voted last November to dissolve their no-buy pledges and to purchase the building from its sponsor, everyone agreed that the tenants had negotiated a favorable deal for themselves.

title: PHILHARMONIC: JANACEK
description: ''THE HOUSE OF THE DEAD,'' Leos Janacek's last opera, is a timely and timeless work that sounds in many ways as if it were written last week. Composed in 1928 three months before the Czech composer's death at age 75, this grimly powerful opera is based on Dostoyevsky's autobiographical novel describing life in the Russian gulag, mid-19th-century version. Janacek's original score had its first complete United States performance last night in a concert version by the New York Philharmonic under the baton of his fellow countryman Rafael Kubelik.

title: SOUTH CENTRAL BELL ISSUE DRAWS STRONG RESPONSE
description: A $250 million financing by the South Central Bell Telephone Company, the first debt offering to be marketed by a Bell System affiliate since November 1981, is a major success, according to underwriters for the issue.

title: PROPOSED CUTS IN TREATMENT OF SEWAGE TEMRED HARMFUL
description: Cutbacks in sewage treatment proposed by New York City and other municipalities that border on New York Harbor and nearby waters would hurt water quality, a study by a tristate environmental watchdog agency has concluded.

title: WHY THE LATEST WHITNEY BIENNIAL IS MORE SATISFYING
description: SEVERAL times this week I have caught myself using a form of words not often heard in New York City - ''I did so enjoy the Whitney Biennial.'' In saying this, I did not forget that there never was yet a mixed exhibition that pleased everyone. All the way back to the Armory Show in New York in 1913 and the Salon des Refuses in Paris in 1863, there have been people who beefed. If it wasn't the artists who were in the show that they complained about, it was the artists who were left out. As in other departments of life, the very act of choosing is offensive. It is, as a veteran statesman once said, ''Every time I appoint a new minister, I make myself 19 enemies and have to work side by side with a monster of ingratitude.''

title: PUBLISHING: COMPANIES SETTING UP 'DOWNTOWN'
description: VIKING PENGUIN INC., the corporate marriage of two distinguished hardcover and paperback publishing houses, has just moved from the high-rise anonymity of 625 Madison Avenue, at 58th Street, in the heart of chic Halston-Yves St. Laurent-Ungaro country, to a rehabilitated 1886 cast-iron building, at 40 West 23d Street, in the literary terra incognita known as ''downtown.''

title: POP JAZZ
description: NEW ORLEANS'S Preservation Hall began as a hole in the wall, a dark little room in the French Quarter, where some of the city's most venerable jazz musicians, survivors of the music's turn-of-the-century Golden Age, held forth for tourists, students, scholars and others. The hall is still there, but in a sense, it's everywhere, too.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
3-YEAR PLAN FOR POLAND'S DEBT
description: Poland's Western creditor banks are ready to reschedule Poland's debt over a three-year period, an official of the Dresdner Bank said today.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A Python explores 'meaning'

title: U.S. STEEL ACCEDES TO CHARGES
description: The United States Steel Corporation has agreed to plead no contest to charges by the Pennsylvania Attorney General that it dumped toxic wastes at an illegal site in West Mifflin, Pa., a suburb of Pittsburgh.

title: BRITISH LABORITE WINS KEY BY-ELECTION
description: Britain's opposition Labor Party, which has suffered an almost unbroken series of splits and setbacks in the last four years, appeared headed tonight for its most important by-election victory since Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher took office in 1979.

title: 2 WEEK BAN ON CUBA AIRLINERS
description: Cubana Airlines has been barred from American airspace for two weeks because of two violations of traffic routings that Washington has termed a ''serious breach of air safety.''

title: Exchange Chief's View
description: The newly elected chairman of the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange Inc., Willi Roelli, is eager to increase trading in the sugar options contract introduced by the exchange last year.

title: FLATBUSH RALLYING SUPPORT TO EASE IMMIGRANTS' PLIGHT
description: Community leaders, the police and church officials yesterday announced the formation of a task force to help refugees and other immigrants, particularly Asians, who have resettled in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday 8 BUNUELS ON BROADWAY

title: No Danger Found At Waste Site
description: Air samples at the Queens site where more than 3,000 buried waste drums were recently found show there is no immediate health hazard to those who live near or work there, the Sanitation Department said yesterday.

title: Computer Unit Chairman Out
description: Advanced Computer Techniques Corporation, a computer services and consulting company, said yesterday that Darrol J. Stanley was removed from his positions as chairman and chief executive by the board of directors.

title: Cuevas Retires
description: Pipino Cuevas, the 25-year-old former welterweight champion of the World Boxing Association, announced his retirement. Cuevas, who last fought two months ago in Los Angeles, where he was knocked out in the fourth round by Roberto Duran, said in Mexico City that he had made the decision after ''consultations with my parents, my wife and my manager.'' Cuevas, a native of Mexico, held the W.B.A. crown for four years, losing it on a knockout by Thomas Hearns in August 1980.

title: OF THE DEAF, FOR ALL
description: To the Editor:

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball

title: DR. CLARK'S DEATH LAID TO FAILURE OF ALL ORGANS BUT ARTIFICIAL HEART
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark's death late Wednesday night was a result of massive circulatory collapse, shock and failure of all the organs in his body except the artificial heart, which continued to pump even after he was dead, his doctors at the University of Utah said today.

title: ART: ALFRED KUBIN SHOW A LESSON IN FANTASY
description: NOW that we're alive again to the virtues of Expressionism, the work of the Austrian artist Alfred Kubin (1877-1959) seems to take on new vitality. A fantasist of deep emotional power, and a draftsman of large talents, Kubin has never had a big press in this country, probably because he never made it as a painter. Yet for all its small scale, his graphic imagery -ranging from the haunting use of animals as ''psychic'' metaphors to jolly sketches of country life - takes as firm a grip on the mind as work in a ''major'' medium.

title: An Uplifting Visit At Shelter for Homeless
description: Music enlivened the men's shelter on East Third Street yesterday when the Barrett Sisters, a trio of gospel singers, sang for some 400 homeless men and women. The shelter, the central reception center for the city's homeless, registered more than 5,000 men and women last night.

title:
FED TIGHTENING: HOW SOON?;
Economic Analysis
description: The Federal Reserve System, which has supplied funds to the economy readily in the first quarter to hold down interest rates, may be under strong pressure soon to tighten its policy to avoid a major increase in credit costs later in 1983.

title: Driesell Charged With Sex Bias
description: A University of Maryland student has filed a sex-discrimination complaint against Lefty Driesell, the school's basketball coach, the director of the school's legal-aid office said today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A pop concert listing in The Guide, section 2A, Sunday, March 20, for Barbara Cook/ Queens Symphony Orchestra was incorrect. The concert, originally announced for Saturday, March 26, was rescheduled and performed last month.

title: 'OUTSIDERS,' TEEN-AGE VIOLENCE
description: IT'S as if someone had handed Verdi a copy of ''The Hardy Boys Attend a Rumble'' and, holding a gun to the poor man's head, forced him to use it as a libretto. Or, try to imagine a ''West Side Story'' that is set in Tulsa, Okla., in the 1960's, with no dancing or singing, but with a lot of not-super Carmine Coppola soundtrack music replacing the Leonard Bernstein score. Or, think of a remake of ''Rebel Without a Cause'' directed by someone under the delusion he's D.W. Griffith shooting ''The Birth of a Nation.''

title: The Long Trek
description: Making certain that they have an adequate supply of corn pads, 10 amateur female runners will undertake a relay from New York to Los Angeles, a total of 3,000 miles, to stimulate grass-roots support for the United States Olympic Committee and for women's distance running. This has been a banner Olympiad for women's distance running, now that the 3,000-meter event and the marathon have been added to the schedule.

title: France Signs Agreement On Uranium for India
description: India and France have signed a commercial agreement for the supply of enriched uranium to fuel India's United States-built Tarapur atomic power plant, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today.

title: Jerseyan Accused Of Murder by Auto
description: Authorities were searching today for a murder suspect they said tried to strike a 14-year-old girl with his car and then ran down a 7-year-old boy riding a bicycle on a sidewalk in Camden last week.

title: Home Resale Total Down
description: Resales of single-family houses dipped 4.3 percent in February after rising for five straight months, a real estate trade group said today. However, a spokesman said that the sales rate ''remained healthy'' and that the upward trend would resume soon.

title: News Analysis
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark's 16 weeks of survival with a device of plastic and metal pumping his life's blood gave him little semblance of normal life, but it was a history-making advance in the long research effort to develop a practicable artificial heart.

title: Court of Appeals Ousts 2 Judges
description: A Dutchess County judge and a Syracuse city judge were removed from office today by the State Court of Appeals.

title: TOWERMARC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $164,000 for the latest quarter and $116,000 for the year-earlier period. In the latest the operating income includes a nonrecurring gain.

title: 'BAD BOYS' IN JAIL
description: THE reform-school saga ''Bad Boys'' gets off to a crackling start, as it intercuts the stories of two teen-age hoodlums about to run afoul of the law. They're also about to become deadly enemies, after Mick O'Brien (Sean Penn) becomes the hit-and-run killer of a young Puerto Rican boy.

title: Article 057363 -- No Title
description: Congress this morning passed and sent to President Reagan a $165 billion plan designed to shore up the Social Security System.

title: An Unhappy Brave
description: Jerry Royster of the Atlanta Braves is not in an accepting mood about Joe Torre's managerial decision to take him out of contention for the left-field spot this season and use him instead as a utility man. Royster had felt he had a starting spot sewed up after he hit .326 during the last 10 weeks of the 1982 season and heard Torre repeatedly call him the team's most valuable player.

title: MANOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid in February.

title: Ford Offers Plan On Repeat Repairs
description: The Ford Motor Company announced a new repair warranty today under which most Ford owners would never have to pay for the same repair twice.

title: STANDUN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Art, Deco to Nouveau.
description: A SALE of Art Nouveau and Art Deco wares tomorrow at 1 P.M. at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, may provide more evidence that a recovery of the auction market in 20th-century decorative arts is under way. A year ago, following two seasons of decline in sales, the Deco and Nouveau styles, which had boomed through the 1970's, appeared to be returning to favor.

title: 4 Die in Georgia Plane Crash
description: A twin-engine airplane bearing bank checks from Florida to Atlanta today crashed in a pond, killing four people, officials said.

title: Memorial Service Scheduled For Adelaide Klein, Actress
description: A memorial service will be held at the Little Theater, 240 West 44th Street, at 12:30 P.M. on Sunday for the actress Adelaide Klein, who died of a brain tumor March 18 at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 82 years old and lived at 145 West 55th Street.

title: Japan Studies Loan Plan
description: The Japanese Finance Ministry is considering a proposal from Japanese banks that they should be allowed to supply syndicated yen loans to some Latin American countries, ministry sources said today.

title: AID BY SOLDIERS SOUGHT IN CRISIS AT ATOM PLANTS
description: County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke called on the Federal Government today to train and deploy Federal troops for nuclear power plant emergency evacuations. They would assist local police and National Guard troops, he said.

title: G.M. Plans to Sell Low-Cost Suzuki
description: The General Motors Corporation plans to offer the lowest-priced car sold in the United States beginning in the summer of 1984, a new mini-compact imported from the Suzuki Motor Company of Japan. G.M. engineers described the M-car as a four-passenger, two-door hatchback smaller than any car now built or sold in the United States. They said the car is expected to sell for about $4,500.

title: MOTHER'S DAY AT THE GARDEN
description: The sighs floated through Madison Square Garden like the flutter of wings, a contrast to the shrieks and howls that accompany the hockey and the basketball games there. It was matinee day of the Virginia Slims Tennis Championships, and many of the patrons wore fur coats and rooted softly for Evonne Goolagong Cawley.

title: SUPPLY-SIDE WINS
description: The non-inflationary economic expansion Ronald Reagan promised in the 1980 campaign has arrived. It's two years late, but it's here to stay, and so is President Reagan. He can now lay down a six-year foundation of prosperity that can easily become a good old-fashioned, worldwide economic boom.

title: Economic Scene; Seeking a New Bretton Woods
description: ECONOMIC conferences among the leaders of the major countries of the Western world, like the one to be held by President Reagan at Williamsburg, Va., over the Memorial Day weekend, inevitably arouse public expectations that something is about to be done to deal with the world's economic problems. Otherwise why hold them?

title: INJURY FOUND IN SOME STEEL IMPORTS
description: In an action that could lead to higher tariffs, this country's International Trade Commission ruled today that American producers of specialty steel had been seriously injured by rising imports.

title: West German Surplus
description: West Germany today reported a current-account surplus of $333 million (preliminary) for February, in contrast to a January deficit of $42 million (revised). Last month's trade surplus of $1.5 billion was up from $1.1 billion in January.

title: 4-Year Pact for Cashen
description: Frank Cashen said today that he had accepted a new four-year contract as general manager with the Mets in the hope that he could fulfill his goal of producing a world championship team.

title: A FATEFUL TRIAL: WITTY EX-GUERRILLA V. ZIMBABWE
description: Only one defendant still faces treason charges in the first trial of its kind that Zimbabwe has seen in nearly three years of independence.

title: Blanton Collier, Led Browns To Pro Football Title in 1964
description: Blanton Collier, who coached the University of Kentucky football team for eight years and later led the Cleveland Browns to the 1964 National Football League championship, died of cancer in a hospital here Tuesday. He was 76 years old.

title: SOVIET SEES A TREATY VIOLATION IN ARMS PROPOSED BY REAGAN
description: The Soviet press said today that President Reagan's plan for new antimissile technologies amounted to a new stage in the arms race and that their deployment would violate the 1972 treaty limiting such defensive systems.

title: Trudeau Asserts NATO Relies On Canada for Missile Tests
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, commenting on the controversy over the proposed American testing of low-flying cruise missiles in Canada, says the Government will let down its alliance partners if it refuses to permit the tests.

title: Wine tasting and a Thai twosome.
description: WINE tasting has become so fashionable a pursuit that entire restaurants are being planned around it. The device that makes such tastings possible is the Cruvinet, a dispenser that keeps wine in good condition long after the bottle has been opened. Elizabeth's, the four-month-old restaurant on Lexington Avenue between 72d and 73d Streets, is the third place in town to have such a dispenser and, like Lavin's and Tastings, has a by-the-glass or half-glass wine list that encourages customers to try a variety of wines during the course of a meal.

title: Suit by Compaq
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation, a small Houston company that makes a portable computer compatible with the popular International Business Machines personal computer, filed a countersuit in Federal court against Texas Instruments Inc. Compaq, founded largely by former Texas Instruments employees, charged that Texas Instruments had sued to harass Compaq and deter further defections. In its suit last month, Texas Instruments charged that the former employees stole trade secrets and infringed on patents. Texas Instruments declined to comment on the suit.

title: 6 FILMS BY INDONESIANS
description: 'Cinema Indonesia,' a series of six films by and about Indonesians, runs through Sunday at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, near 70th Street.

title: Sperry Contract
description: The Sperry Corporation said it had received a $324 million Navy contract to manufacture advanced technology computers.

title: SPARTAN MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $46,000. c-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $35,000.

title: INFARARED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Maurice Turet, Press Agent For Leading Broadway Plays
description: Maurice Turet, for 40 years a theater press agent associated with some of Broadway's leading productions, died Wednesday. He was 73 years old.

title: TWO CHARGED WITH FRAUD IN SALES TO ARMY COMMISSARIES IN EUROPE
description: The Government has charged two Americans with forging and inflating purchase orders for Army commissaries in Europe and is investigating 20 other salesmen and 11 companies for similar misconduct, according to Federal court records and Justice Department officials.

title: Voices of Praise
description: It was a West 72d Street party with music and champagne. In one chair at Martino's hair salon was Maude Douglas Tweedy, a voice coach for 70 years.

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
HALIFAX DEVELOPMENTS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
PRESIDENT'S FORECAST IS REVISED
description: President Reagan's top economic advisers, Administration officials said today, have reached agreement on a revised economic forecast for this year that projects higher growth and lower inflation, both at rates of slightly less than 5 percent.

title: FIRST AMERICAN 'TEST TUBE' TWINS ARE BORN ON L.I.
description: A 31-year-old Long Island woman gave birth yesterday to the first ''test-tube'' twins born in the United States, according to a spokesman for North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset where the babies were delivered.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: NOBODY was happier than John Lichtenstein the other night when the Lichtensteins, the Pascals and the Cohens gave a party in Gramercy Park. John, who is 9 years old, was playing the family Steinway, and because the three apartments on the second floor of 34 Gramercy Park East were so jammed with people, no other players could manage to get near the huge grand piano.

title: SOUTHLAND'S SUCCESSFUL MIX
description: In 1927, the founder of the Southland Corporation, Joe C. Thompson, tried selling milk and gasoline at the same store. But the innovation failed: Customers were happy to buy staples at his icehouses, but not gasoline.

title: KENTUCKY GAINS WITH LOUISVILLE
description: When Arkansas ran off 16 consecutive points in the first half tonight, Joe Kleine, the center, said he could see in the eyes of the Louisville players that they were beaten. But then, said Kleine, ''You let them back.''

title: INTERNATIONAL BANKNOTE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-net income. Results for the latest year include a net income of $4.7 million pertaining to the termination of benefit plans and a net charge of $4.4 million resulting from organizational restructuring and employee termination charges in order to reduce costs. Year-ago net income reflects an increase of about $2 million resulting from the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No. 52.

title: HETRA COMPUTER & COMMUNICATIONS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to De
GOVERNMENTS'RESERVES
description: Financial reserves held by the world's governments, the money they have set aside for emergencies, declined 1.7 percent last year, to $363 billion, the first decline since 1959, the International Moneytary Fund reported today. Exceptions to the trend were the United States, whose reserves rose 27 percent to $22.3 billion at year-end 1982, and West Germany, Switzerland and the Netherlands; France, Japan and Britain reported declines.

title: AIDES URGED REAGAN TO POSTPONE ANTIMISSILE IDEAS FOR MORE STUDY
description: President Reagan went ahead with a proposal to develop new defenses against missiles even though several White House and Pentagon aides suggested that the idea had not been carefully studied, according to Administration officials.

title: EIGHT BELL UNITS RETAIN HIGHEST S.& P. RATING
description: Two weeks after most of its credit ratings were slashed by Moody's Investor Service Inc., the American Telephone and Telegraph Company received a qualified vote of confidence yesterday from the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article March 17 on an appeal filed in behalf of Claus von Bulow contained an incorrect statement because of an error by his counsel in the appeal brief. The statement, relating to a bag containing drug supplies, should have read: ''Fingerprinting of the bag and its contents - especially the insulin needle itself - would have provided the best evidence of Mrs. von Bulow's use of the bag and the drugs it contained.''

title: Money Funds Off 1.5 Billion
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds fell $1.5 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to $184.3 billion, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The funds shrank $1.52 billion last week and $2.2 billion the previous week.

title: Mayberry Released by Yanks
description: The Yankees clarified their first base situation today when they released John Mayberry, leaving Ken Griffey as the likely regular. Neither Griffey nor any of the other Yankees expected to play first base this season has ever made more than a token major-league appearance there.

title: U.S.C. Advances; Old Dominion Wins
description: Cheryl Miller and Pam McGee scored 22 points each and Paula McGee added 18 tonight as Southern California routed Arizona State 96-59 in a semifinal of the West Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's championships.

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-including tax credits of $109,000 for the quarter and $146,000 for the 9 months. c-net loss. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: HUNGRY TIGER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 18
description: Year-Ago share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective November 1982.

title: Coast Freight Train Derails
description: A freight train derailed early today a few miles northeast of the downtown section and one car began leaking corn syrup, the police said. No injuries were reported. The derailed Santa Fe train, about three-fourths of a mile to a mile long, blocked roads and intersections in the Highland Park section of the city.

title: LEWIS, PALMER G, CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
THE DANCERS WHO BLOOM IN THE SPRING
description: AROUND this time of year, just about as infallibly as returning robins, the dance season begins to take off. There is dance activity for every taste this weekend in theaters dotted across the city. The start of the spring season offers most notably the chance for reacquaintance with an American master named Merce Cunningham at City Center and the opportunity to get to know the personable Hamburg Ballet in its United States debut at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Lunquist Paces S.M.U.
description: Steve Lundquist started his bid for three first-place individual finishes by winning the 200-yard individual medley tonight and later helped Southern Methodist set an American record in the 400 medley relay at the 60th N.C.A.A. men's swimming and diving championships.

title: REAGAN'S MIDEAST PEACE PROPOSAL 'STILL VERY MUCH ALIVE' IN JORDAN
description: Efforts to get Jordan to take part in President Reagan's Middle East peace initiative have ''taken on a new life'' as a result of private consultations over the last three days involving King Hussein, the Palestine Liberation Organization and key Arab governments, according to Jordanian officials and Western diplomats here.

title: BROADWAY HONORS SHOW-STOPPERS OF YESTERYEAR
description: In the background, Ethel Merman is belting out her inimitably brassy rendition of ''There's No Business Like Show Business.'' Around the room, elegantly clad ghosts stand frozen in time: Mary Martin in a lynx jacket, lynx bonnet and see-through baby-doll pajamas, the costume she made famous in 1938 singing ''My Heart Belongs to Daddy''; Joel Grey in tails, complete with the pink satin vest he wore in 1966 in ''Cabaret''; Barbra Streisand in beaded and ruffled purple chiffon from ''Funny Girl,'' vintage 1964.

title: DEMOCRATS ASSERT REAGAN IS USING 'STAR WARS' SCARE TO HIDE BLUNDERS
description: Congressional Democrats accused President Reagan today of using a ''Star Wars scenario'' to stir fear of the Soviet Union among the American people and distract them from ''the dismal failure'' of the Administration's economic program.

title: TRIAL IN ARMS CASE DELAYED OVER F.B.I.-BRITISH TIES
description: A trial of four men charged with plotting to smuggle weapons to the Provisional Irish Republican Army was halted yesterday because of a dispute over possible British intelligence links to the case.

title: NICARAGUAN SEES SALVADOR LINK IN REBEL ATTACKS
description: The Interior Minister charged today that the United States was trying to strengthen its hand in El Salvador by stepping up efforts to disrupt the Nicaraguan Government.

title: ASKING LESS, AND GETTING IT
description: Admissions officials at the University of Utah noticed in 1981 a striking trend. In l970, the average applicant had been taking four college-preparatory courses a year in grades 9 through 12; but by 1980 the average was down to only three such courses a year.

title: The U.N. Today; March 25, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: O.& M. International Promotes 3
description: In one of a number of high-level changes, the board of directors of Ogilvy & Mather International elected Kenneth Roman, 52-year-old president of Ogilvy & Mather U.S., to be one of its three vice chairmen.

title: FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to lDec 31
JESSE BLOCK
description: Jesse Block, who with his wife, Eva Sully, played the vaudeville comedy team of Block and Sully for 20 years, died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MARCH 25, 1983
description: International

title: Dun & Bradstreet
description: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, a compiler of business information, said employment in the United States may increase 2.7 percent this year.

title: Snippets of a City Past
description: Responses are arriving in a appeal by the United Neighborhood Houses for memories (''a paragraph or a snapshot'') of the city's settlement houses since 1886. It was in that year that the University Settlement, the first in America, opened on the Lower East Side.

title: PROXY SOLICITATION FIRM IS ACCUSED BY S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused a proxy solicitation firm of intimidating companies by mounting its own takeover efforts and then offering to cease in exchange for payment.

title: BULGARIAN HELD IN PAPAL PLOT LOSSES 2D APPEAL
description: A special court rejected a renewed appeal today for release from detention by a Bulgarian airline official accused of complicity in the attempt to kill Pope John Paul II in 1981.

title: BRIEFING
description: Strike Up the Bands

title: Boy Accused of Mailing Bomb To Mrs. Thatcher Goes Home
description: A 14-year-old London boy accused of mailing a letter bomb to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was released in his parents' custody by a court today. The boy, who was arrested at his home Wednesday, was ordered to appear in court for another hearing May 5.

title: Vatican and Sweden Resume Ties After a 450-Year Break
description: The Vatican and Sweden today resumed normal diplomatic relations, broken about 450 years ago when Sweden followed the reforms of Martin Luther, the Vatican said.

title: ACTING E.P.A. CHIEF IS SAID TO BE READY TO QUIT POST TODAY
description: John W. Hernandez Jr., Acting Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, will resign Friday, White House and Congressional officials said today.

title: HOCKEY FOR OLD TIMERS' SAKES
description: There was more balancing than checking and the only spills were self-inflicted, but a competitive game of hockey was not the point tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. It was a night for nostalgia, for trotting out old heroes and old cheers in the name of philanthropy.

title: DETAINEE IS ALLOWED TO TESTIFY
description: In a highly unusual development, a political detainee was allowed this week to offer testimony about his allegation of torture by the security police.

title: ADELMAN DENIES 'PURGE' PLAN
description: Kenneth L. Adelman, President Reagan's nominee to head the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, said today that he had no intention of ''undertaking a 'purge' or 'housecleaning' '' at the agency and disputed charges that he had misled the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: Foote, Cone Becomes Data General Agency
description: Foote, Cone & Belding, New York, is the new agency for the Data General Corporation, the Westboro, Mass., manufacturer of general computers announced yesterday.

title: BROADVIEW FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-including tax credits of $4,465,000 for the latest year and $9,245,000 for the previous year.

title: Lois Towles, Concert Pianist And College Music Instructor
description: Lois Towles, a former concert pianist, died in her sleep at her San Francisco home on March 18. She was 70 years old.

title: A Distant View
description: The worst seat for a football game, it has been said, is on the bench. Too close. You don't get any perspective.

title: Ryan to Pitch Opener
description: Nolan Ryan has replaced Joe Niekro as the starting pitcher in the Houston Astros' season opener, at home against the Los Angeles Dodgers. That's because Al Rosen, Houston's general manager, realized that Ryan needed only 15 strikeouts to surpass Walter Johnson's career record of 3,508. By starting on opening day, Rosen figures, Ryan can work off some of the 15, have a full four days' rest and break the record in front of a home crowd.

title: 9 STATES CALLED FAILURES OVER SCHOOL INTEGRATION
description: A Federal district judge ruled here today that nine states had failed to desegregate their public college systems as they were required to do by a series of court orders over the last decade.

title: Import Change By Tokyo Seen
description: The Japanese Government is expected to adopt a series of measures on Saturday that will ease import barriers, Government sources said today.

title: Rain Delays Golf
description: Heavy rains Wednesday night and early this morning forced the first round of the $700,000 Tournament Players Championship to be postponed. The final two rounds will be played Sunday.

title: Ex-NBC Chairman Aids Film Studios
description: Robert W. Sarnoff, the 64-year-old former chairman of NBC and of its parent company, the RCA Corporation, has become a consultant to a more modest entertainment enterprise: the film studios in Astoria, Queens.

title: Constantine FitzGibbon, 63, Biographer, Dies in Dublin
description: Constantine FitzGibbon, biographer of the Welsh poet Dylan Thomas and of the Irish patriarch Eamon de Valera, died Wednesday in a Dublin hospital.

title: Khans Advance
description: Sharif Khan, of Toronto, seeded No.2 in the Rolex United States Open squash championship, advanced to the final 16 with a victory over Rob Dinerman of New York, 3-2, at the Yale Club in Manhattan yesterday. Khan's brother, Charlie, of Montreal, also advanced, with a 3-1 victory over Frank Satterthwaite of New York.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Acme-Cleveland Corp. said its board had approved a conditional offer to buy 2.9 million shares of Dale Electronics Inc., or 82 percent of Dale's stock outstanding, for $43 million, from Lionel Corp., which is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Pizza Hut Item
description: Pepsico Inc.'s Pizza Hut unit said that it would introduce on Monday a smaller pizza for lunchtime customers, and that each of its 1,850 company-owned restaurants and 1,989 franchised restaurants would hire four to seven additional employees to handle an expected increase in trade. The new pizza will be a six-inch version of a deep-dish dinner pizza and cost less than $2; service time would be no more than five minutes, it said.

title: Capitals Overtake Devils
description: The Washington Capitals scored four goals, two by Bob Carpenter, over 5 minutes 33 seconds of the third period to defeat the New Jersey Devils, 5-3, tonight.

title: Impostor of Professors Said to Be a Real One
description: The man accused of taking on false identities so he teach at two Pennsylvania colleges was identified today as a longtime professor at George Washington University, apparently with legitimate credentials.

title: N.B.A. Talks Break Off
description: A disagreement over the amount of revenue to be guaranteed to the players caused yesterday's bargaining session between the National Basketball Association and the players' union to end after 20 minutes.

title: Mitterrand Completes Cabinet Reorganization
description: President Francois Mitterrand's Socialist Government completed its Cabinet reorganization tonight by naming 27 new subministers and secretaries of state.

title: Dow Rises by 5.03, To Record 1,145.90; Institutional Buying Cited
description: Stock prices finished moderately higher yesterday after Wednesday's sharp advance, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 5.03 points, to close at a record 1,145.90.

title: Article 056171 -- No Title
description: Allocation of $200,000 more for special training and assistance programs for unemployed veterans in Buffalo and three other areas with high unemployment was announced today by Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan.

title: Required Reading; A Fourth Branch
description: Representative Elliott H. Levitas, Democrat of Georgia, in remarks to the House in introducing a bill to permit legislative vetoes of rules and regulations promulgated by Government departments, March 8, 1983:

title: Dakota Indian Is Freed Of a Charge of Murder
description: A judge today threw out a murder charge against a Sioux Indian in the slaying of a white man near the Yellow Thunder Camp and barred future prosecution of the case.

title: AT EASTERTIME, A CITY FESTIVAL OF SACRED MUSIC
description: THE church was once the principal patron of composers in Western culture, but it has long since ceded that role to princes, businessmen, governments, foundations and universities. So secular has our musical culture become that we expect to encounter concerts only in concert halls; some of those halls even have their own pipe organs, thus undercutting even the need to seek out the king of instruments in its native liturgical habitat.

title: 'Giant' to Run 10 Days
description: The 1956 film ''Giant,'' starring James Dean, Elizabeth Taylor and Rock Hudson, will begin a 10-day engagement today at the Beacon Theater, Broadway at 74th Street.

title: E.P.A. SAID TO BAR TESTS AT DOW IN '81
description: Officials at the Washington headquarters of the Environmental Protection Agency intervened in behalf of the Dow Chemical Company in 1981 to prevent agency investigators from testing waste water inside the grounds of the company's plant in Midland, Mich., according to present and former officials of the agency's regional office here.

title: OXFORD FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $79,000 for the quarter and $301,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,000 for thequarter and 329,000 for the year.

title: IN HONORING THE REBBE, A CATERER DID WELL, TOO
description: The White House Office of Public Liaison, recently purged for its alleged failure to keep the President in favor with such specialized constituencies as women, racial minorities and religious groups, did something right today. So did Mermelstein the caterer from Brooklyn.

title: FIRST EXECUTIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ISRAELI-MARINE ACCORD IS REPORTED IN LEBANON
description: The United States Marine contingent here and the Israeli command agreed today ''on improved measures'' to avoid confrontations, the American Embassy announced.

title: AN UNFAIR LEVY ON SOCIAL SECURITY BENEFITS
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm never going to quit. I'll be here until I stop breathing.''

title: Interest Rates Little Changed; 20-Year Bond Yields 10.81%
description: Interest rates were narrowly mixed yesterday, with slightly higher rates for Treasury bills due in three and six months. Longer-term note and bond issues showed small changes in both directions.

title: LEGISLATORS AGREE ON INCREASE OF 1 CENT IN NASSAU SALES TAX
description: Legislative leaders reached agreement tonight on a plan to impose an increase of one percentage point in the Nassau County sales tax to help close a county budget deficit. It would raise the sales tax rate in the county to 8 1/4 percent, the same as that in New York City.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Colgate-Palmolive Co. has appointed Peter D. McLeod vice president of corporate manufacturing.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE CALLS FOR HALVING NEW SALVADOR AID
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that a request by President Reagan for $60 million more in military aid for El Salvador should be cut to $30 million.

title: Bridge: Author Tells of Deception By a Great British Player
description: There could be some argument about the most prolific writer of bridge books on this side of the Atlantic, but in Europe the honor certainly belongs to Hugh Kelsey of Scotland. He has been producing works of the highest quality for some 15 years.

title: 'BABY, IT'S YOU'
description: PLASTIC furniture covers. Baby-blue knee socks. A car with pushbutton transmission. Two teen-age girls in biology class, talking about their love life as they coolly dissect a frog. These and other well-chosen details of a 1960's adolescence are captured by John Sayles with characteristically witty precision in ''Baby, It's You,'' a love story that's as much about the era in which it's set as about the characters it follows.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: READY-TO-WEAR: ELEGANCE IN PARIS
description: The line of demarcation between couture, or made-to-order clothes, and ready-to-wear has been blurring in recent seasons, but in the fall and winter fashion openings this week it was almost obliterated.

title: Waldorf-Astoria Official Starts Consulting Firm
description: Eugene R. Scanlan, the general manager of the Waldorf-Astoria, is checking out on March 31, after 34 years at the hotel. He will be succeeded by Joseph Rantisi, who has formerly worked at the Waldorf and is currently executive assistant at the Washington Hilton.

title: GROMYKO IS NAMED A DEPUTY PREMIER
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union was given the additional job of First Deputy Prime Minister today.

title: SIMULCAST PLAN TO GIVE BETTORS A CHOICE
description: More than 100,000 bettors slide their money through the windows of New York State's 300 Offtrack Betting Corporation shops each day. In exchange for wagering with the state rather than a bookmaker, the bettors get shabby and seatless surroundings and a so-called 5 percent surcharge, which can actually be a 50 percent reduction in profit. For example, a bet that returns $2.40 for $2 at the track pays only $2.20 at OTB.

title: BILLIE JEAN KING DEFEATS ANDREA JAEGER
description: Billie Jean King surprised an ailing Andrea Jaeger, Tracy Austin was beaten, Martina Navratilova finally lost a set and Barbara Potter overpowered Wendy Turnbull during a day of stunning developments at the $350,000 Virginia Slims of New York tennis championships.

title: BLASIUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 23
description: b-including extraordinary tax credits of $126,000 for the quarter and $320,000 for the 9 months. c-including extraordinary tax credits of $100,000 for the quarter and $219,000 for the 9 months.

title: A Very Discreet Panda
description: If pandas could talk, what a tale Ling-Ling, the most prominent resident of Washington's National Zoo, could tell.

title: CITY DRAWS NO BIDS ON PLAN TO BUILD 3,600 BUS SHELTERS
description: New York City has failed to attract any bids for a contract to construct 3,600 bus shelters in the five boroughs, the city's Director of Franchises said yesterday.

title: F.A.A., FAULTING AIRLINE'S SAFETY, HALTS ITS FLIGHTS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration issued an emergency order yesterday halting for safety reasons the flights of Guy-America Airways, which has primarily been operating jets between New York and Guyana.

title: Lietzke Up by 1
description: Bruce Lietzke, who shot a round of 68 with no bogeys, held the lead after the first round today of the 10th annual Tournament Players Championship.

title: Yanks' Mistakes Irk Leaders
description: Tradition returned to the Yankees today: Bobby Murcer was back on the roster, George Steinbrenner was angry not only with the umpires, but also with the players over a sloppy, losing effort, and Billy Martin fumed at his first-base coach for a few minutes over a broken play.

title: Quake Jars North Carolina
description: A light earthquake was felt in a three-county area of western North Carolina late Thursday. No damage or injuries were reported from the quake, which measured about 3.1 on the Richter scale, according to Ann Metzger, a geologist with the Tennessee Earthquake Information Center at Memphis State University.

title: BRIEFING
description: Touching Down in Granada

title: Carry Back Is Destroyed
description: Carry Back, the winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness in 1961, was destroyed this week after veterinarians discovered he was suffering from a malignant tumor.

title: U.S. MAY REQUIRE SALEM TO BRING IN A CONSULTANT
description: The chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission told a House committee today that his agency was considering requiring the owner of the Salem nuclear power plant in New Jersey to hire an outside company to reorganize its management of the plant.

title: Green Beans Stir Bad Blood
description: May Sanchez, 29 years old, was shot in the buttocks Thursday night by the man she lived with, the police said, because she served him green beans once too often. The .22-caliber bullet caused only a flesh wound, and the alleged assailant, Daniel Francisco Lopez, was released today in $1,000 bond. Sheriff's deputies said blood and green beans were strewn around the kitchen in the home the couple shared and quoted Mr. Lopez as saying, ''Wouldn't you be mad if you had to eat green beans all the time?''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday on the Social Security bill incorrectly stated the present income ceiling for Social Security payments. It is $35,700.

title: Marx Estate Jurors Say They Are Deadlocked
description: Jurors in the trial over the Groucho Marx estate announced today they were deadlocked in the Bank of America's dispute with Erin Fleming, the comedian's longtime companion.

title: REAGAN SAYS PLAN ON MISSILE DEFENSE WILL PREVENT WAR
description: President Reagan said today that he had decided to seek development of an advanced missile-defense system because it was ''inconceivable'' for the United States and the Soviet Union to continue indefinitely to threaten each other with nuclear destruction.

title: SATURDAY NEW QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48.

title: MANNIE SEAMON
description: Mannie Seamon, a longtime trainer of the former world boxing champions Joe Louis and Benny Leonard, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85 years old.

title: PARIS SHOPPING: BOUTIQUES, FINDS
description: There are at least three ways to shop for clothing in Paris. You can do it on foot all in one day, hitting every important shop on every important street until, at day's end, with your feet expanding and contracting like the franc, you realize that shopping doesn't feel any different in French. You can do it with a car and driver, the best way to do anything in Paris. Or you can shop the way the French do - a little here, some there, but mostly whenever and wherever the spirit strikes.

title: WAS DEFENSE AND NAVY SECRETARY
description: Thomas S. Gates Jr., a former chairman of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, who served as Secretary of the Navy and Secretary of Defense in the Eisenhower Administration, died yesterday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived in Devon, Pa.

title: BID TO OUST SAN FRANCISCO MAYOR POLARIZES SPLINTER GROUPS
description: Examples abound of the strange character of local politics in this city, where the Mayor faces a referendum on ousting her from office because she opposes possession of pistols.

title: La. Tech Romps, 81-54
description: Top-ranked Louisiana Tech easily advanced to the final of the women's N.C.A.A. Midwest Regional tonight by beating Auburn, 81-54.

title: Late Returns
description: The temptations to brag are there, but everyone in television knows you cannot jump to conclusions on the basis of the overnight ratings. You have to wait for A.C. Nielsen's national ratings, which take a few more days to develop.

title: EDWARDS, A G, & SONS INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in February 1983.

title: HIGBEE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29

description: To the Editor:

title: LAST STATE BUDGET PROBLEMS SAID TO BE SOLVED IN ALBANY
description: A week after Governor Cuomo announced a general agreement on a state budget, the Governor and legislative leaders reached agreement today on nearly all the details as well.

title: INQUIRIES TO GO ON
description: A Presidential panel has authorized the Army Corps of Engineers to seek major changes in the law protecting the nation's wetlands. Page 8.

title: Walesas Are Questioned About Back Taxes
description: The revenue authorities in Gdansk questioned Lech Walesa and his wife, Danuta, separately today about gifts they received in the 16 months Mr. Walesa led the Solidarity union, a family spokesman said.

title: U.S. Aide Gloomy on Grain for Soviet
description: A senior United States agricultural official said today that the curtailment of American grain sales to the Soviet Union after its intervention in Afghanistan had done ''long-term damage to our trade'' in the Soviet market.

title: AN ARENA CLOSES
description: T he smell of the Chicago International Amphitheater clings to memory. The arena, once the site of many sports events, is situated a half block from the old, 320-acre Union Stock Yards where each morning the butchering of hundreds of thousands of head of cattle, hogs and sheep would commence. The mighty odor was enough to curl your hair.

title: E.E.C. Assails Ruling on Steel
description: The European Community Commission, the executive arm on the Common Market, today contested a United States ruling that imports of specialty steel products were harming domestic producers.

title: WAINOCO OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr. to lDec 31
description: The lates fourth quarter loss was due to a $35 million writedown of investment in the US oila nd gas proved and unproved property. The loss throughout 1982 included writedowns of $5.7 million of certain overseas operations, $1.7 million ofwell equipment inventory and $1.6 million or capitalized expenses related to a limited partnership exchange offer.

title: 'THE KILLING OF ANGEL STREET
description: ''The Killing of Angel Street,'' the Australian melodrama at the D.W. Griffith Theater, is an earnest, self-righteous attack on ruthless land developers riding roughshod over the little folks of Sydney. The film is said to be based loosely on actual events, but it so overstates its case that it's likely to give social activism a bad name.

title: DANCE: 'EVENT NO. 2,' A CUNNINGHAM COLLAGE
description: Merce Cunningham, whose dance company closes its season tomorrow, put together a tantalizing exercise in perception in his ''Event No. 2'' Thursday night at the City Center.

title: Reagan Writes Allies On Interim Arms Plan
description: President Reagan has informed leaders of the North Atlantic Alliance that he is prepared to negotiate an interim agreement with the Soviet Union on the deployment of medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe, Administration officials said tonight.

title: Soviet and Yugoslavia To Increase Trade Ties
description: The Soviet Union today reaffirmed its recognition of the independent course charted by Yugoslavia, which has a Communist Government but regards itself as nonaligned.

title: BANKS' DECONTROL BID IN STATES
description: When Congress approved the new money market deposit accounts last fall, the powerful banking lobby turned to the next barrier on its march to deregulation - the restraints against the sale of stocks, bonds and insurance products by banks.

title: SOME OF THEIR FRIENDS
description: There are things you don't expect to hear in the late 20th century, in this country, in this city. We know that bias and bigotry still exist in people's attitudes, but we like to believe that discrimination by policy - discrimination that is formal and official - is dead. So you don't expect to hear what some members of the male gentry were saying on Wednesday night in the meeting hall of the City Bar Association.

Wireless System Used In Polling of Audiences

title: Bartholomew Hogan, 82
description: Rear Adm. Bartholomew W. Hogan, retired, who served as the Surgeon General of the Navy over the last six years of a 35-year naval career, died March 17 after a stroke in Lake Wales, Fla., where he was a resident.

description: In the latest of a series of charges that have created the impression abroad that Nicaragua is under siege, the Sandinist Government said today that Honduran troops entered its territory Thursday but were driven back after an exchange of gunfire.

'THORN BIRDS' BEGIN SUNDAY, DESPITE RELIGIOUS OBJECTIONS
description: ''The Thorn Birds,'' a four-part ABC-TV series that depicts the love affair of a Roman Catholic priest, will be broadcast beginning tomorrow night despite protests from both Catholics and Jews over the timing of the broadcast.

title: U.S. PLANS TRUST INQUIRY ON AIR ROUTES TO BRITAIN
description: The Justice Department announced today that it was investigating possible criminal violations of the antitrust laws by airlines flying between the United States and Britain.
