title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 21. 1. The computer. 2. Secretary of State George P. Shultz said he had given the ultimatum to Salvadoran leaders. He was testifying before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee, seeking to end opposition to a $60 million increase in military aid for El Salvador. The subcommittee later approved the request.

title: UNICORP AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-includes a pretax gain of $680,000 on the sale of properties c-there are no comparable results because the ocmpany commenced operations in October 1981.

title: An East-West Impasse Takes an Easter Holiday
description: The conference here on European security and cooperation adjourned today for a three-week Easter recess, deadlocked over the draft of a proposed final statement described as disappointing by the United States.

title: Bias vs. Seniority in Boston
description: Two decades ago, when Congress outlawed racial and sex bias in employment, the nation was looking forward to steadily expanding job markets. When the job supply shrinks, laws against bias get caught in bitter conflict between whites and minorities over scarce employment opportunities.

title: UPDATING I.R.S. COMPUTERS
description: More than a decade of heavy use has worn the original black paint off the bulky old Honeywell console, exposing large patches of orange undercoat and gleaming bare metal. What was once an object of pride around the Internal Revenue Service now looks like a candidate for some computer museum.

title: U.S. Approves an Insecticide To Fight Fire Ants of South
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has given tentative approval to the use of a new insecticide against fire ants. The ants, which sting, are found in nine Southern states and Puerto Rico.

title: CATHOLIC BISHOPS ARE REPORTED TO REVISE ANTINUCLEAR DOCUMENT
description: The third draft of a major statement on nuclear arms by a committee of Roman Catholic bishops reflects some changes in emphasis but retains the main elements of the strong antinuclear stance that was evident in previous versions, church officials familiar with the documents said yesterday.

title: REAGAN DECLARES 'YOU BET' HE'LL STICK WITH ADELMAN
description: President Reagan emphatically defended Kenneth L. Adelman, his nominee to head the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, today and said Mr. Adelman's Senate critics were ''smaller than the person they're attacking.''

title: Books of the Times
description: TWO. By Rich- ard Grenier. 346 pages. Houghton Mif- flin. $14.95.

title: REAGAN ARMS PLAN DEBATED IN EUROPE
description: President Reagan's proposal for a new defense system against missiles drew cautious praise and considerable criticism in Western Europe today.

title: Springfield Gardens Advances
description: Springfield Gardens of Queens, trailing most of the game, rallied in the third quarter and went on to defeat St. Anthony's of Smithtown, L.I., 57-46, tonight. Springfield Gardens advanced to the Class A final of the New York State High Schools Basketball Championships.

title: STORING OIL
description: By the end of 1983, the United States should stop filling its strategic petroleum reserve. The pumping program is costly, and the money can be used better elsewhere. Moreover, in view of conservation efforts and the development of new overseas sources of oil, the reserve now holds just about enough oil to meet legal requirements.

title: Courage and Hope
description: More than six months after he was paralyzed from the neck down during a football game against U.C.L.A., Todd Hart, a Long Beach State defensive back, returned to his home in San Juan Capistrano, full of hope for the future.

title: MCFARLAND ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THREATS PROMPT A MOVE FOR BARNES'S 2 CHILDREN
description: Death threats against two young daughters of the convicted narcotics dealer Leroy (Nicky) Barnes, in retaliation for his having become an informant, have led Federal and local officials to seek to have the children placed in protective custody.

title: U.S. ABM'S HELD BACK BY PROBLEMS AND TREATY
description: Both the United States and the Soviet Union have tried to develop land-based defenses against ballistic missiles, only to find themselves constrained by technological problems and a treaty.

title: Maine U. Student Killed In 3,000-Foot Tumble
description: A blast of wind blew two University of Maine students off the ice-covered summit of 6,288-foot Mount Washington, killing one and injuring the other, as they slid 3,000 feet down the peak, officials said today.

title: ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS PROPOSES TO EASE LAW PROTECTING WETLANDS
description: President Reagan's Cabinet Council on the Environment is letting the Army Corps of Engineers seek major changes in the wetlands law while the Administration is officially seeking only minor changes, a participant in a recent council meeting said today.

title: DRIVERS FUMING IN DOUBLE-PARKING CRACKDOWN
description: For years, New Yorkers have tolerated the double-parked cars that illegally line the streets in their neighborhoods. The cars never seem to get ticketed and, in fact, many of their owners have come to consider double-parking something they are entitled to. City officials say ticketing double-parkers in residential areas has never been a priority.

title: CITY SCHOOL BOARD DISCUSSING CURBS ON POWER OF CHANCELLOR
description: New York City's Board of Education is discussing ways to limit the powers of the next Chancellor and expand its own authority over the city's public school system, the board president said yesterday.

title: COWERING BEFORE OMOO
description: Most people choose to be ignorant, and I am no exception. This is why, after 40 years of putting it off, I still haven't learned what ''contumely'' is.

title: REAGAN HAILS PLAN TO SOCIAL SECURITY
description: President Reagan praised Congress today for passing a plan that he said lifted ''a dark cloud'' from the Social Security System.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Political Alliance A n alliance of the state's leading Democrats is joining forces for United States Representative Harold Washington, the Democratic candidate for mayor of Chicago. Governor Cuomo; Representative Charles B. Rangel; the union leader Victor Gotbaum; Basil Paterson, a former New York Secretary of State; the financier Felix G. Rohatyn; City Council President Carol Bellamy; Lillian Roberts, the State Industrial Commissioner; Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and Assemblyman Angelo Del Toro appear on an invitation for lunch with Mr. Washington next Thursday.

title: STAR-GLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to lDec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $46,000.

title: MAN CHARGED WITH KILLING BOY, 7, WITH CAR AFTER MAKING A RACIAL REMARK
description: A man was ordered held in $500,000 bail yesterday on charges he murdered a 7-year-old Hispanic boy in Camden, N.J., by driving his car into him after saying the lives of minorities ''had a certain point value.''

title: PARADYNE SUBJECT OF S.E.C. CHARGE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged the Paradyne Corporation of Largo, Fla., today with violating Federal securities laws to obtain a $100 million computer contract from the Social Security Administration.

title: Gulf Canada
description: Gulf Canada Ltd. announced that its estimated capital and exploration spending in 1983 would increase to $900 million, from $840 million in 1982, and said the current year expenditures would be mainly for major projects already in progress.

title: Cornell Given Research Gifts
description: Three leading corporations are providing gifts and grants totaling $7.5 million for the new Biotechnology Institute at Cornell University, Cornell said in Ithaca, N.Y.

title: THEATER: 'JAZZ POETS AT THE GROTTO'
description: One of the more inventive ideas of the beatnik era was jazz poetry, with poets standing in front of modern jazz combos and weaving their words in and out of the music. In ''Jazz Poets at the Grotto,'' a late-night show currently at the Production Company through April 3, Greg McCaslin has recreated that time, place and mode of expression with gratifying spontaneity.

title: Graphic Scanning
description: The board of Graphic Scanning Corporation, a Teaneck, N.J., telecommunications service company, has adopted a corporate plan to separate the concern's operations into six businesses, each of which will have its own management, employees and financing, the company said. Each of the new subsidiaries will be capitalized according to its needs.

title: ANDROPOV MEETS NICARAGUAN
description: Yuri V. Andropov met at the Kremlin today with Daniel Ortega Saavedra, coordinator of Nicaragua's junta. The meeting was the Soviet leader's first announced engagement in 11 days and appeared to end the uncertainty that developed when rumors swept Moscow that he was ill. Some reports said Mr. Andropov, 68 years old, who succeeded Leonid I. Brezhnev as Communist Party leader in November, was suffering from a kidney ailment, but a senior official said it was nothing worse than influenza.

title: The Talk of Caracas
description: The Venezuelan national anthem calls on citizens to ''follow the example of Caracas,'' but if they did so today, the country would become one fed on Chinese cooking, transported in eight-cylinder American limousines and dressed in Italian designer clothes.

title: Chevron to End Jersey Oil Unit
description: Chevron USA Inc. said it would discontinue production of gasoline and heating oil at its Perth Amboy refinery by June 1.

title: VERMONT SPOILERS
description: Listen, Mr. Ambassador from El Salvador, the next time you - or just about anyone else from outside - thinks about unleashing slick propaganda in our town meetings, where hometown issues are what count, do us and the rest of America a favor. Stay home.

title: A NEWPORT FESTIVAL IN MARCH
description: Even before the well-dressed woman in the Lord & Taylor elevator said to the man beside her, in the most civil voice, ''You stepped on my foot, sir, and you didn't even say 'Excuse me,' '' it was obvious that this was going to be a classy party.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bright at the Opera

title: Jeremiah Walsh Dies; Ex-Chief of Buildings
description: Jeremiah T. Walsh, an engineer and former Commissioner of Buildings in New York City, died of cancer yesterday at Westchester Square Hospital in the Bronx. He was 51 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: PE BEN OILFIELD SERVICES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
TAX RISES INCLUDED AS FRANCE ADOPTS AN AUSTERITY PLAN
description: France's Socialist Government adopted a tough austerity package today in a bid to resolve its economic crisis. Included were a limit on the amount of money that tourists can take abroad and a ''forced loan'' that most income tax payers will have to make to the Government.

title: Eastern Air Contract Cost
description: Eastern Airlines' tentative three-year contract with the machinists' union will cost about $80 million more than the carrier had anticipated, union and company officials said today.

title: BEIRUT REJECTING NEW CONCESSIONS
description: The special United States envoy to the Middle East, Philip C. Habib, held new talks today on the withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon, as the Lebanese insisted they could make no more concessions to Israel on security arrangements.

title: Capobianco Moving To Pittsburgh Opera
description: Tito Capobianco has resigned as general director of the San Diego Opera and has been named vice president and general director of the Pittsburgh Opera effective July 1.

title: 'Pirates' Begins Run
description: Gilbert & Sullivan's ''The Pirates of Penzance'' will be presented by the Light Opera of Manhattan through April 3 at the Eastside Playhouse, 334 East 74th Street.

title: SATURDAY, MARCH 26, 1983
description: International An advanced missile-defense system was decided on, President Reagan said, because it was ''inconceivable'' for the United States and the Soviet Union to continue indefinitely to threaten each other with nuclear destruction. Mr. Reagan, at a news conference, said that the Soviet Union and the United States had become across a table, each with a cocked gun, and no one knowing whether someone might tighten their finger on the trigger.'' He acknowledged that the situation had prevented one side from attacking the other for decades. (Page 1, Column 6.) The Soviet Union does not control the American nuclear freeze movement, according to a declassified report by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The report, while saying that the Soviets do have some influence in the movement, said foreign involvement is not as extensive as President Reagan has suggested. (1:5.)

title: CONNECTICUT TOWN SELLS 7 FEET OF MUNICIPAL ART
description: Some festooned it with panty hose and shoes, or, depending on the holiday, with Easter eggs or jack-o'-lanterns. Others thought it could be converted to harness wind power. The Mayor won election, in part, on the promise to get rid of it.

title: Letter: On the Shoreham Plant; We Don't Need Another Nuclear Lemon
description: To the Editor:

title: POLICE ARREST 250 IN CHILEAN RIOTING
description: Nearly 250 people were under arrest here today after violent protests Thursday night against the military Government of President Augusto Pinochet.

title: DEVILS BEAT FLYERS ON GAGNE'S GOAL, 6-5
description: What the Devils call the ''Kid Line'' because the oldest player on it is 22, produced 9 points tonight and led New Jersey to a 6-5 triumph over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: General Dynamics Issues a Disavowal
description: The General Dynamics Corporation said it ''hasn't the slightest interest in buying the AM General Corporation,'' the subsidiary of the American Motors Corporation that manufactures special government vehicles.

title: U.D.C. Reaches Final
description: Led by Earl Jones's 29 points, District of Columbia raced to a 92-77 victory over Morningside College tonight to reach the final of the N.C.A.A. Division II tournament.

title: TANDY TO INTRODUCE 'NOTEBOOK' COMPUTER
description: As the latest entry in the expanding field of small computers, the Tandy Corporation will announce Tuesday a four-pound, $795 machine that is a text editor, bookkeeper, appointment calendar and telephone directory.

title: POPE APPEALS TO MODERN WORLD IN HOLY YEAR
description: Striking three times with a gilt-and-ivory hammer on the bronze Holy Door of St. Peter's Basilica, Pope John Paul II today ushered in an exceptional Holy Year that will last until Easter 1984. The year commemorates the 1,950th anniversary of the crucifixion of Christ.

title: Earthquake Reported in Iran
description: An unknown number of people were injured and scores of cars were trapped by landslides on a mountain road north of Teheran today when an earthquake hit the area, the Teheran radio said.

title: NO SMILES ON GENERALS' LINE
description: T hey met four years ago, during the week before a high school all-star football game at Jackson, Miss. When the North All-Stars held a live scrimmage, Kent Hull, a center from Greenwood, lined up against Wayne Harris, a nose guard from Water Valley.

title: U.S. Carrier Leaves Japan
description: The nuclear-powered aircraft carrier Enterprise steamed back to sea today, escaping a repetition of the violent protests that left hundreds of people injured during its first port call in Japan 15 years ago. In its wake, the Enterprise left a few hundred antinuclear protesters in the port of Sasebo, 600 miles southwest of Tokyo, holding an ''Expel the Enterprise'' party and jeering, ''Get out!''

title:
PATENTS;
New Packaging Method For Radioactive Waste
description: The Navy has a new plan for the disposal of low-level radioactive waste in the ocean. The package system was patented this week by Harvey H. Haynes and Robert D. Rail of the Naval Civil Engineering Laboratory, Port Hueneme, Calif.

title: THE ECLIPSE OF THE BOLL WEEVILS
description: When Representative Charles W. Stenholm gets a nasty letter from a constituent back home in Texas, the Democratic lawmaker calls the voter for a chat. Lately he has been hearing some critical comments about President Reagan's economic program.

title: UNION ALTERS STANCE
description: The National Basketball Players Association, in a reversal of a stance that marked weeks of collective bargaining, has agreed to let management impose payroll caps on each team after next season, if the owners will also establish a payroll minimum.

title: Boston Ballet Founder Relinquishes Her Post
description: E. Virginia Williams, founder of the Boston Ballet, will step down as its joint artistic director, a position she shared with the French ballerina Violet Verdy, the company has announced.

title: Former West German Leader Named Co-editor of Die Zeit
description: The former West German Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt, who was toppled in a parliamentary vote in October, will become co-editor of the authoritative political weekly Die Zeit on May 1.

title: Talbott Gains
description: Top-seeded Mark Talbott of Toronto, trying for his 12th squahracquets title this year, advanced to the semifinals of the Rolex United States Open last night with a victory over sixth-seeded Aziz Khan, 13-15, 18-15, 15-12, 15-10, at the Yale Club. Talbott will meet Mario Sanchez, who defeated Tom Page of Philadelphia, 15-3, 15-8, 10-15, 15-12. Second-seeded Sharif Khan of Toronto was ousted by fifthseeded Ned Edwards of New York, 15-10, 15-11, 15-13.

title: David Frost Weds Daughter of Duke
description: David Frost, the television personality and writer, and Lady Carina Fitzalan Howard, a daughter of the Duke of Norfolk, were married at the registrar's office in the Chelsea section of London last Saturday.

title: PUBLICKER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-includes a gain of $207,000 on sale of certain idle assts;C-net loss;d-includes a $11,337,000 charges representing the writedown of idle domestic assts & inventory to estimated net realizable value-includes a gain of $1,7454,000 on the sale of propewrty, plant and equipment, primarily, the co's Linfield, Pa, facility, a recovery of $1,285,000 from the European Economic Community for purchasing malt at prices in excess of world market rate for the period from 1973 to1981, and a gain of $1,225,000 on the settlement of an insurance claim.

title: 4th in Row for Lundquist
description: Steve Lundquist of Southern Methodist lowered his American and meet records in winning the 100-yard breaststroke title tonight for the fourth consecutive year at the N.C.A.A. swimming championships.

title: HOUSTON AND VILLANOVA GAIN
description: St. John's, the team that had set the Final Four as its goal, began a long bus ride home tonight after its season ended with a 70-67 loss to Georgia in the East Regional semifinal game at the Carrier Dome.

title: TOPPS CHEWING GUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,578,000 The share earnings give effect retroactively to a 2-dfoe-1 stock split payable April 29.

title: ELOQUENCE AT WILLIAMS MEMORIAL IS HIS OWN
description: ''I think Tenn would be glad that he had a full house,'' Maureen Stapleton said at half-past noon yesterday on the stage of the Shubert Theater, where a group of leading women from Tennessee Williams's dramatic world appeared to recall his friendship and praise him in the best possible way for a writer: his own eloquent words.

title: JAZZ FRED HERSCH, PIANIST
description: The five years that 27-year-old Fred Hersch has been in New York, he has built a steadily growing reputation as a jazz pianist in a variety of situations - in the Art Farmer Quartet, as an accompanist to singers such as Chris Connor, as a part of duos and trios and as a solo performer.

title: Lamston Clears Carl Marks Link
description: M.H. Lamston, the New York variety-store chain, said that it and key shareholders had reached a tentative agreement to sell all of Lamston's 574,436 outstanding shares to Carl Marks & Company, the investment bankers, for about $15.8 million in cash.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA WINS EASILY
description: The art of serve and volley went on display at Madison Square Garden last night. And in their own ways, Martina Navratilova and Billie Jean King again demonstrated that it is not what you do with a tennis ball that wins matches but how it's done.

title: Son of Reagan Attorney Held
description: The 20-year-old son of Roy D. Miller, President Reagan's personal attorney, was arrested today in the slaying of his mother, who was found dead Thursday night at their home in this expensive suburb of Los Angeles.

title: 15, in Policy Protest, Quit Illinois University Paper
description: Nine editors and six reporters resigned from the University of Illinois student newspaper today in protest of new academic rules requiring they maintain at least a C average to keep their jobs. They also must carry 12 hours of classes each semester under the new policy.

title: Famed Greek Communist Is Home After 35 Years
description: The 77-year-old Communist guerrilla army leader and Prime Minister during the 1946-49 Greek civil war, Markos Vafiades, returned to Greece today after 35 years of exile that followed the defeat of his partisans by the national army.

title: DESTRUCTIVE 'BUMPING' IN THE STATE'S LAYOFFS
description: Whatever the final number of layoffs in the New York State government work force, civil service will manage to accomplish them in the most destructive way possible. The method has received little attention, though it guarantees that even a small cut can create chaos in the daily functioning of many state institutions.

title: Talks Set for Monday In Metro-North Strike
description: Bargaining in the strike against the Metro-North Commuter Railroad is to resume Monday in a new effort to settle the 19-day-old walkout. Arvid Anderson, the mediator in the dispute, said he had arranged the meeting, set for 10 A.M. at the headquarters of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, at 347 Madison Avenue, at the request of leaders of the United Transportation Union.

title: An Expert's Predictions
description: It has been nearly three years since Steve Ovett set the world record in the 1,500-meter run at 3 minutes 31.36 seconds, and two years since Sebastian Coe set the record for the mile at 3:47.33. According to one authority, their days as world records may be numbered.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary Wednesday incorrectly listed three of the survivors of Marvin G. Saines. They are two sons, Philip, of Boston, and Andrew, of Manhattan, and a brother, Nelson, of New Rochelle.

title: WEBB TO BUY OUT SUN CITIES PARTNER
description: The Del E. Webb Corporation said today that it planned to acquire full ownership of Sun City and Sun City West, paying $42 million in cash and notes to the J.G. Boswell Company for its 49 percent interest in the retirement communities.

title: F.B.I. RULES OUT RUSSIAN CONTROL OF FREEZE DRIVE
description: The latest draft report by a committee of Catholic bishops reaffirms their antinuclear stance. Page 7.

title: OF DISHES AND RESTAURANTS GONE BUT NOT FORGOTTEN
description: As much as we might appreciate the increased variety of restaurants now in New York, it is sobering to realize that many of the city's classics have disappeared. Anyone who has eaten around New York long and seriously is bound to miss a number of bygone favorites. My own list, drawn at the risk of seeming ungrateful amidst such plenty, includes posh and plebian restaurants that no longer exist or are under different management and so, for all practical purposes (such as eating), are not what they were. These, then, are the dishes and restaurants I miss, not necessarily in this order:

title: Virginia Faces Familiar Foe
description: In this snow-draped city at the edge of the Rocky Mountains, two southern teams, both from the Atlantic Coast Conference, prepared today for Saturday afternoon's West Regional championship game. No matter who wins and advances to the Final Four in Albuquerque, N.M., next weekend, the A.C.C. will be represented.

title: Abortion Amendment Voted by Senate Panel
description: A proposed constitutional amendment to allow states to ban abortion was approved Thursday by a Senate subcommittee.

Patents;
Carbon Dioxide Coal Slurry
description: WASHINGTON A method of moving coal in a slurry of liquid carbon dioxide, which two companies are promoting, was patented this week. Patent 4,377,356 was granted Chakra J. Santhanam and assigned to Arthur D. Little Inc., Cambridge, Mass., which he serves as an environmental specialist.

title: California Jeweler Is Robbed Of Rubies Worth $2.5 Million
description: Two men wearing false beards and moustaches broke into a jewelry store and made off with an estimated $2.5 million in rubies, the police said today.

title: Baby Abducted at Hospital
description: A woman dressed as a nurse abducted a 3-day-old boy from his mother's arms in a visiting room at Parkland Memorial Hospital on Thursday, the police said. The mother, Gretchen Patterson, told officers that the woman had said she had to return the infant, Harold Deshawn Patterson, to the nursery.

title: PAYMENTS TO JOBLESS WOULD BE EXTENDED BY NEW LEGISLATION
description: The unemployment provisions passed along with the Social Security bill would make New York State residents eligible for a maximum of 42 weeks of unemployment benefits.

title: JORDAN IS IN FERMENT AS THE KING PONDERS REAGAN'S PEACE PROPOSAL
description: There is a quiet sense of tension and intellectual ferment here as the people of this capital await King Hussein's decision on whether he will join Middle East peace negotiations on the basis of President Reagan's proposals.

title: HONDURAS DENIED SANDINIST CHARGES
description: The Honduran Foreign Ministry denied Nicaraguan charges today that Honduran troops had crossed into Nicaragua in recent days.

title: Dow Off 5.81 Points On Rates Forecast
description: Stock prices dropped moderately yesterday with the Dow Jones industrial average ending the day at 1,140.09, down 5.81 points. The Dow average had been ahead 2.22 points at noon, but began declining after Henry Kaufman, an influential economist with Salomon Brothers, predicted that the Federal funds rate for overnight loans between banks could rise to 9 percent or 9.5 percent in the next month.

title: NEW ENGLAND WRITER GUILTY OF DRUG SMUGGLING CHARGES
description: A Federal jury today found Richard L. Stratton, a writer, guilty of conspiracy to smuggle marijuana and hashish.

title: Golfer Keeps Off The Sawgrass
description: The usual reason a golfer declares an unplayable lie is that some obstacle, like a tree, a fence or rocks, makes it impossible to play the shot.

title: TWO WOMEN SLAIN IN APARTMENT
description: Two women in their 60's were found bound, gagged and murdered in their East Harlem apartment yesterday. The apartment door was doublelocked and the apartment showed no signs of having been ransacked, the police said.

title:
PATENTS;
Buckminister Fuller's Hanging Storage Unit
description: R. Buckminster Fuller of Philadelphia, the geometrician, educator and architect-designer who is widely known as the inventor of the geodesic dome, was granted a patent this week for an indoor structure that can be hung from the ceiling.

title: IN JORDAN, LONGSTANDING SPLIT
description: Attitudes in Jordan, a land of 2.3 million inhabitants, reflect the division of its people into 1.4 million Palestinians, or those with roots west of the Jordan River, and 900,000 indigenous residents of the East Bank.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: This is the story of Joseph Miceli, who is 80 years old, lives in Flushing, Queens, and still keeps some Brylcreem and a couple of bottles of witch hazel on the shelves in his barbershop, and of how he got some bankers, some lawyers and some real-estate men all riled up, although not all for exactly the same reason.

title: 76ers' HOME STREAK ENDED BY NETS AT 24
description: Larry Brown, the coach of the New Jersey Nets, says that he has tried ''not to harp on winning or losing'' as he guides his team toward a favorable position in the National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: DePaul Wins In N.I.T.
description: Bernard Randolph led a balanced scoring attack with 19 points tonight, lifting DePaul to a 75-67 victory over Mississippi and into the semifinals of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: RUCKELSHAUS'S TIES SPLIT ENVIRONMENTAL LEADERS
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company, which William D. Ruckelshaus will leave to become Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, is generally regarded by Northwest conservationists as their most environmentally responsible timber company. But many say its record in land management, air and water pollution and use of potentially hazardous herbicides is far from perfect.

title: Officer Wounded
description: A plainclothes police officer was shot in a thigh yesterday as he wrestled with an armed teen-ager suspected of robbing a truck driver in Brooklyn, authorities said.

title: Insurer to Offer Brokerage Service
description: The New England Mutual Life Company said it would open a discount brokerage business in May, becoming the first major insurer to enter the field.

description: b-including a gain of $560,000 from the sale of subsidiary and a tax-Net loss.

title: Pincay Off Copelan
description: Laffit Pincay Jr. has never ridden a Kentucky Derby winner, but this year the odds had been in his favor. Since replacing Jerry Bailey in January, he has been the regular rider of Copelan, the early favorite for the Derby.

description: Enthusiasts in the New York metropolitan area who were unable to travel to Honolulu for the Spring Nationals last week will have a consolation prize this weekend.

title: JAPAN ANNOUNCES PLAN TO EASE IMPORT CURBS
description: The Government will put new legislation before Parliament in the next few weeks to amend at least 17 laws on standards and certification of products that discriminate against imports, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: REIT Stock Is Purchased
description: San Francisco Realty Investors went ahead with its purchase of stock in Real Estate Investment Trust of America, but it was not immediately clear how much of the Boston real estate trust it was able to acquire.

title: INTEREST RATES UP SHARPLY
description: Interest rates rose sharply yesterday because of concern among investors that the Federal Reserve is tightening credit availability or might soon do so.

title: CBS RECORDS CHIEF REPORTED GOING TO MCA
description: Reports circulated in the music industry today that Walter Yetnikoff, the executive who has overseen CBS Records' dominance of the best-seller charts during the recent years of poor record sales, had asked for a release from his contract and planned to join a competing company, MCA Inc.

title: Archbishop Igino Cardinale
description: Archbishop Igino Cardinale, the Papal Nuncio in Belgium and Luxembourg and the Vatican representative to the European Common Market, died Thursday of a blood infection in Brussels. He was 66 years old.

description: b-After a net loss of $15,385,000 from discontinued hotel and casino operations. c-Net income including net income of $6,508,000 from discontinued hotel and casino operations and a net loss of $549,000 from discontinued retailing operations.

title: NEW 'ADVENTURE' BEGINS FOR MERCE CUNNINGHAM
description: ''O.K.,'' Merce Cunningham called softly. ''Position! Ready! Go!'' Five dancers spun into motion, sprinting, leaping and cantilevering into balances. Above their heads, a crane swung into action simultaneously, following a trajectory of its own, camera and cameraman perched at its top. Filming had started on Mr. Cunningham's new ''Coast Zone,'' a film-dance that is the latest in a lifelong series of ''adventures,'' as the choreographer and performer puts it.

title: Vatican Said to Order Nun to Quit Welfare Post
description: The Vatican has ordered a Roman Catholic nun to denounce Michigan's policy of paying for abortions for poor women or quit as director of the state welfare agency, the Cable News Network reported today.

title: SATURDAY, MARCH 26, 1983; International
description: The French Government introduced a tough austerity package that includes ''forced loans'' for most taxpayers and higher taxes on liquor and tobacco. The program is intended to reduce consumer spending by $9 billion, or about 2 percent of France's annual output of all goods and services. There would also be restrictions on how much cash French vacationers could take abroad, and on the use of credit cards. The drastic proposals follow this week's franc devaluation, the third since the Socialists came to power in May 1981. (Page 1.)

title: N.I.T. Problem
description: It might seem easy on the surface to avoid religious holidays in the scheduling of sports events. It isn't, though, as the people who direct the National Invitation Tournament well know.

title: CITICORP PLANS BANK IN MAINE
description: Citicorp, the parent of Citibank and the nation's largest banking organization, said yesterday that it is planning to open a fullservice bank in Portland, Me., its first such facility outside New York State.

title: DANCE: CHARLES MOULTON AND THE KINETIC GIGGLE
description: The Charles Moulton Dance Company appeared Thursday night at St. Mark's Church, and not once did anyone in any way toss, pitch, pass or catch a ball. To be sure, one usually doesn't expect dance programs to resemble ball games. But for the last few seasons Mr. Moulton has incorporated various forms of ball passing into his choreography, turning what is usually regarded as an athletic activity into an esthetic gesture.

title: 8 St. Louis Suburbs Face Trial Over Busing Plan
description: Eight suburban school districts were ordered today to stand trial next month unless they submit, within five days, a detailed written plan to desegregate city and county schools.

title: From Poland's Unquiet Grave
description: Ignore the calendar; it's still winter in Poland. The three months since General Jaruzelski partly lifted martial law have confirmed the cynicism of his maneuver. Jail conditions are harsher; new laws justify forced labor, and the universities have been purged with a crude ''ideological verification'' drive. To call this normality is a joke in the worst taste.

title: Erich Linder, Literary Agent; Had Many American Clients
description: Erich Linder, an international literary agent who represented many American authors, agents and publishers, died Wednesday at his home in Milan, Italy. He was 59 years old.

title: Ballet Stars to Appear In Paul Taylor Benefits
description: Suzanne Farrell, Peter Martins and Mikhail Baryshnikov will join the Paul Taylor Dance Company in benefit galas during its season at City Center, from April 5 through May 1. Miss Farrell and Mr. Martins will perform ''Duet'' from ''Lento'' on opening night. Mr. Baryshnikov will perform ''Images'' on April 12.

title: KNICKS TRIUMPH OVER HAWKS
description: The big difference in the Knicks' 104-87 victory over the Atlanta Hawks tonight at the Omni was New York's second unit. It outscored the Hawk reserves, 47-18.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mike Schmidt, the Philadelphia Phillies' third baseman, who underwent knee surgery March 7, started in the field for the first time this spring. Schmidt said he was ''running at about 80-85 percent,'' but he still hit a double and a single and was flawless in the field for four innings in a game against Minnesota. ... Bill Walton, the San Diego Clippers' center, underwent surgery for removal of a bone spur from his right ankle and will miss the remainder of the season. ... Kevin Saucier, the Detroit relief pitcher who was a sensation in 1981 and then abruptly lost virtually all control last season, was cut by the Tigers.

title: WOMEN ADMITTED TO CLUB AFTER 82 YEARS
description: A private club here has reversed an 82-year-old tradition and voted to admit women as full-voting members. The University Club, situated downtown near the State Court of Appeals, had voted down the measure four previous times. Thursday night, the members voted, 223 to 85, to reverse that policy. The Fort Orange Club, a few blocks away from the State Capitol, continues to exclude women from membership and limits the times they may enter the club.

title: CONSUMER SATURDAY
description: IT has been nearly 10 years since New Yorkers were first introduced to the seductive ease of 24-hour b anking through tellerless cash machines. But since then many of them have learned firsthand the pitfalls of t his convenience, among them no doubt the hundreds of Citibank c ustomers who lost thousands of dollars through a sophisticated s windle worked at Citicard banking centers over a two-and-a-half-yearp eriod between 1980 and 1982.

title: Chicago Democratic Leaders Finally Back Their Nominee
description: The city's Democratic committeemen endorsed Representative Harold Washington for Mayor Thursday, a month after he won the Democratic primary.

title: CHARLES T. WHITE
description: Charles Trumbull White, controller of the Union Theological Seminary in New York from 1923 to 1950 and later a financial official with government and private programs to aid other countries, died of cancer Monday at Carl Vinson Hall, a retirement residence for former military officers in McLean, Va. He was 86 years old.

title: Harvester Sees New Loan Accord
description: The International Harvester Company said it would be able to renegotiate its debt agreement by Dec. 15, the date its current agreement expires.

title: Bangladesh Relaxes Ban On Political Activity
description: President Hussain Mohammed Ershad eased a ban on political activity today and proposed discussions with opposition parties that would lead to elections in 1984.

title: JOBS FOR THE NEW PARKS COMMISSIONER
description: To the Editor:

title: All Is Forgiven, Peking Tells a Tennis Defector
description: A Foreign Ministry spokesman said today that a 19-year-old Chinese tennis player who defected to the United States last summer would not be prosecuted if she returned home.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday incorrectly quoted a statement by Kenneth L. Adelman, President Reagan's nominee to head the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. Mr. Adelman, discussing a memorandum handed him by Edward L. Rowny, the chief strategic arms negotiator, said, ''Immediately after Ambassador Rowny handed me the paper, I looked at it in a very brief, cursory fashion. I never read it carefully; I never studied it.''

title: News Analysis
description: In many ways, the abruptness of Mayor Jane M. Byrne's decision Wednesday to end her write-in campaign for reelection illustrated the penchant for the unexpected and dramatic that characterized her four stormy years in office.

title: Man Waits 475 Days To Meet the Governor
description: Jonathan LaSalle finally got to talk to the Governor after waiting in the lobby for 16 months. Mr. LaSalle walked into the State Capitol in December 1981 and told a receptionist he wanted to air a grievance about a state civil service job he had lost.

title: Sweden's G.N.P. Flat
description: Sweden's gross national product was virtually unchanged in 1982 from 1981, Statistics Sweden said today.

title: Harvard Reaches Final
description: Scott Fusco had two goals and two assists and sparked a third-period rally by Harvard that eliminated Minnesota, 5-3, tonight in the semifinals of the N.C.A.A. hockey championships.

title: HOUSE VOTE ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Following is the 243-to-102 roll-call vote by which the House gave final approval Thursday to legislation to shore up the Social Security System. A ''yes'' vote was a vote to approve the bill. A ''no'' vote was a vote against it. Voting ''yes'' were 163 Democrats and 80 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 54 Democrats and 48 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, yes; Erdreich, yes; Flippo, xxx; Nichols, xxx; Shelby, yes. Republicans - Dickinson, xxx; Edwards, xxx.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think Tenn would be glad that he had a full house.'' - Maureen Stapleton, at a memorial for Tennessee Williams. (28:3.)

title: Your Money; Debt Insurance After Job Loss
description: SHERRY ROBERTS is a millworker at the Mayr Brothers sawmill in the economically depressed town of Raymond, Wash. Her husband, Ray, is a dairy farmer. When they began to plan the purchase of dining room and bedroom sets, they looked around them.

title: EXXON LOSES OIL-PRICING CASE
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the Exxon Corporation overcharged customers between 1975 and 1981 in violation of Government price controls. He directed the company to refund a total of $1.49 billion.

title: 'HOW DOES A JUDGE KEEP HIS SENSE OF HUMOR?'
description: Judges seek justice. So does society. Thus, programs are devised to secure justice. But what do judges sometimes see? Compassionate programs corrupted. Well-intentioned policies perverted. Inappropriate benefits. An epidemic of waste.

title: BELL AND U.S. IN ACCORD ON DIVESTITURE ISSUES
description: Washington, March 25 (AP) -The Justice Department and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company reached an agreement today that settled the few outstanding issues in the reorganization plan governing the breakup of the Bell System.

title: Two Neighbors Finally Meet
description: The Kentucky cities of Louisville and Lexington are only 72 miles apart. As basketball rivals, the college teams from those cities - the University of Louisville and the University of Kentucky - are worlds apart.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Last Day With Earl Wilson

title: A.M.A. DROPS CALL FOR YEARLY CHECKUP
description: New guidelines by the American Medical Association suggest that most healthy adults should have medical examinations once every five years, a change in the group's longstanding policy of recommending annual checkups.

title: No Headline
description: Bob Waterfield, Quarterback And All-Pro Star of the Rams BURBANK, Calif., March 25 (UPI) - Bob Waterfield, a brilliant quarterback in both college and professional football, died at St. Joseph Medical Center today after a long respiratory illness. He was 62 years old.

title: PRESIDENT OPPOSES ANY NEW TAX INCREASES NOW
description: President Reagan today adamantly opposed any new tax increases now, saying that they could thwart the longawaited economic recovery.

title: B. Wongar
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
WHY A COLD FRAME IS USEFUL
description: A COLD FRAME is a useful piece of equipment, yet few gardeners know how to construct or use one. They are also an energy-efficient growing structure in that they use sunlight as the sole source of heat.

title: WHO'S FOOLING WITH THE FOAL?
description: BANKER, By Dick Francis. 306 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $14.95.

title: AND NOW, LUXURY
description: For evidence that SoHo has become another high-priced Manhattan residential area, look at 426 West Broadway, just opened and billed as SoHo's first luxury residential condominium. The 35 units range in size from 550 to 3,000 square feet and are priced from $120,000 to $350,000.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Tenor, Three Pianists And Two Flute Players Are Week's Recitalists
description: The tenor Ulises Espaillat's light, sweet voice startles the listener with its freshness and purity. Mr. Espaillat, who recently won first prize in the Metropolitan Opera District Auditions in Cleveland, presented a pleasing, if somewhat undifferentiated, selection of Latin music from Spain and South America at Carnegie Recital Hall March 19.

title: CHARTS ON COMPUTER GRAPHICS ARE TRENDING UPWARDS
description: THE price of gold plunges. Editors decide that the drop is importante nough to warrant a chart, but the deadline looms minutes away. The scenario can be a recipe for disaster at a newspaper, because c harts and graphs, while they communicate mountains of information, a re notoriously time-consuming to prepare. However, the same events c an also demonstrate the way computers are reshaping careers in the g raphic arts.

title: Cuomo Gets His Budget, If Not Quite His way
description: It may be arguable that Governor Cuomo got less than he gave in budget negotiations with the legislative leaders last week, but it is undeniable that he got it faster than many thought possible. By yesterday it appeared that final legislative action on the package might be completed today, giving New York its first on-time budget in four years.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THREE White Plains men are planning to build a $16 million, eightstory, block-square blue glass office building on the site where their families once lived or worked.

title: U.S. Brings Bias Suit Against Coast Complex
description: The Justice Department, in its fourth housing discrimination case under the Reagan Administration, has charged the owners and manager of a Los Angeles suburban apartment complex with refusing to rent to Arabs, other people of Middle Eastern origin, and blacks. The lawsuit was filed Friday in Federal court in Los Angeles.

title: A Correction
description: An article on Soviet Jews in the Week in Review of March 20 omitted decimal points in reporting the percentage of Jews in the Soviet population. In 1970, Jews represented just under 0.9 percent of the total and now represent slightly less than 0.7 percent. Since 1968, the great majority of Soviet Jewish emigres have settled in Israel but in the past few years there has been a marked trend toward the United States, the emigres either coming directly from the Soviet Union or first going to Israel.

title: TRAIN PLANS ANGER OFFICIALS
description: casino to be opened in Atlantic City, will build a terminal here for planned railroad service from Philadelphia, Melvin Lehr, the state's Assistant Commissioner of Transportation, said at public meetings last week in Hammonton and Haddonfield.

title: REDUCED 'TAKE' ON OIL CURBS ALASKA'S PLANS
description: Although Alaskans resent the appellation ''blue-eyed Arabs,'' plans for the state's future have been hitched to the star of rising oil prices ever since the giant Prudhoe Bay oilfield was discovered in 1968. Now, with OPEC having agreed to cut prices and analysts far from convinced that the price slide is over, economic growth financed by a continuing flood of petrodollars is jeopardized.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
COLOR IT GREEN
description: It's never too early to think green -specifically, the green that makes suburban gardens bloom. So today at 2 P.M. when the Long Island Horticultural Society holds its monthly meeting at the Planting Fields Arboretum, the subject will be ''Back to Basics, From Seed to Planting.'' Carl Totemeier and his colleague from Old Westbury Gardens, Chip Watson, will do the honors, leading experienced and neophyte gardeners alike, step by step, to what they hope will be green thumbs. The session is at the Hay Barn of the Oyster Bay facility and is free to one and all.VIVALDI'S 'SEASONS'

title: TEST DUE ON PHONE WARRANT
description: EVIDENCE obtained for the first time in Nassau County by means of a ''telephone search warrant'' will be used, according to the District Attorney's office, in County Court in a case set for trial April 4.

title: STRIKE SPAWNS COMMUTER OPTIONS
description: LIKE thousands of other people who normally ride the commuter train from Fairfield County into New York City each day, Libby Welch never thought of getting back and forth any other way. A manager of editorial services for a retail publishing house in mid-Manhattan, Mrs. Welch, who lives in Stamford, struggled on through wheel inspections, breakdowns and constant delays believing there was not much she could do about it.

title: SOME TIPS ON ENTERING THE COMPUTER FIELD
description: EVEN though there will be nearly a 50 percent rise in jobs that require computer skills by 1990, only a minority of career choosers and changers will find they are suited for and enjoy working in a hightechnology field.

title: FINANCIAL CRISIS THREATENS BENEFITS FOR A MILLION RETIRED RAILROAD WORKERS
description: Congress, which just completed months of debate on how to assure the solvency of the Social Security System, will soon turn its attention to a crisis in the federally administered Railroad Retirement System that is endangering the benefits of a million retirees.

title: ENVIRONMENT POST SPLITS DEMOCRATS
description: A PROSPECTIVE Cuomo administration appointment has split the Island's Democratic delegation to the Legislature and produced a breach between the new Governor and one of his earliest supporters on the Island.

title: WARD ASSERTS THAT RIKERS JAIL IS NOW SUITABLE FOR DETAINEES
description: The city's Correction Commissioner, Benjamin Ward, has been testifying in Federal District Court that the House of Detention for Men on Rikers Island is suitable for housing prisoners awaiting trial.

title: STELLA TERNA
description: Stella Terna, an artist who specialized in floral painting, died of cancer Wednesday at Presbyterian Hospital. She lived in Manhattan and was 60 years old.

title: IN THE ARTS CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART One of the more interesting evolutions of late 20th-century taste is the importance now accorded to the paintings and prints of Max Beckmann, who was born in Leipzig in 1884 and died in New York in 1950. A touring show of his triptychs in Europe was widely regarded as one of the key events of the late 1970's.

title: Houston Coach Still Waiting for a Title
description: Guy Lewis can't hide his feelings behind his famous checkered towels anymore. The truth is in his eyes, his actions, his words. In his 27 seasons as the Houston coach, he hasn't wanted to win his first national title as much as he does this time.

title: Diana Whetstone Engaged to Wed
description: The engagement of Diana Robin Whetstone to Robert Hillis Chapdelaine has been announced by her parents, Joan A. Whetstone and Walter Whetstone 3d, both of New Canaan, Conn. Mr. Chapdelaine is a son of Roberta Chapdelaine also of New Canaan and Edward J. Chapdelaine of Mount Holly, N.J.

title: Welcome to Washington
description: Perhaps the instructions weren't clear at the White House last week.

title: Another Notch Of the Belt In Poland
description: Poland, admitting its economy is ''one of the biggest catastophes in world economic history,'' last week announced plans for pulling itself back toward pre-1980 levels by 1985. The Government called for longer working hours, higher prices and new taxes.

title: SHOES: A FITTING FINISH
description: Well-fitted and cared-for shoes are essential to any well-dressed man's wardrobe. Unfortunately, too many men get tripped up when buying a new pair of shoes simply because they have never learned how to determine when a shoe fits properly.

title: DRESSING FOR BED
description: After virtually ignoring men's bedroom attire for years, designers have approached pajamas, robes and underwear this season with the same adventurous spirit and sense of elegance they have strived for in their sportswear.

title: 'WEND KUUNI'
description: ''Wend Kuuni'' (''Gift of God''), a 75-minute feature from Upper Volta, and ''Suzanne Suzanne,'' a 26-minute American documentary produced and directed by James V. Hatch and Camille Billops, make up the ''New Directors/New Films'' program that will be shown at the 57th Street Playhouse today at 1 P.M.

title: Nuclear Facts, Science Fictions
description: President Reagan's desire for a missile-proof shield around America and its allies expresses the deepest longing of the nuclear age - for a place to hide. But it remains a pipe dream, a projection of fantasy into policy.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE TREATY ON ABM'S
description: Following are excerpts from the 1972 antiballistic missile treaty between the United States and the Soviet Union and a protocol that was signed in 1974 and went into effect in 1976:

title: MILITARY SPENDING IS CRITICIZED AGAIN
description: Six former Cabinet officers from both parties have asserted that the Reagan Administration has failed to justify its proposed increases in military spending with a realistic strategy for the nation's armed forces.

title: Old Dominion Winner
description: Medina Dickson and Anne Donovan combined for 49 points today as Old Dominion beat Penn State, 74-60, and advanced to the final four of the N.C.A.A. women's Division I basketball tournament.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: THEATER Ulysses S. Grant is sitting inside a large glass case on exhibition in a museum. Suddenly he begins to move and to talk, rambling through his life and battles.

title: No Headline
description: Corrections: Because of a mechanical error, a caption on page 71 of The New York Times Magazine, March 6, was omitted. Portrayed on the page were photographs of an Enrica Massei cape over an above-the-knee skirt and, in an inset, Laura Biagiotti's ribbed alpaca chemise with dolman sleeves and button detailing.

title: ABRAHAM LINCOLN, ET AL. ON LAWYER TAXES, ETC.
description: To the Editor:

title: Norway's Seters
description: To the Editor:

title: LIVING NEAR T.M.I. PLANT, AND WAITING
description: Tomorrow marks four years of frustration for the people who witnessed firsthand the worst accident in the history of commercial nuclear power. On the fourth anniversary of Three Mile Island, residents of Harrisburg and Middletown, Pa., are still waiting for help with their health and finances. Undelivered aid in one case amounts to more than $25 million.

title: S.G. Strickler Engaged To Cynthia Plumstead
description: Mr. and Mrs. James A. Plumstead of Bernardsville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Ruth Plumstead, to Steven Glenn Strickler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Strickler of Portland, Ore.

title: FOREIGN STUDENTS: BOON OR A THREAT?
description: AS MORE and more foreign students earn engineering degrees from American universities, their role in high-technology industry has become a hotly contested issue that pits engineer against engineer, educator against educator and nation against nation.

title: Teen-ager Held in Robbery
description: A 16-year-old Brooklyn boy was arrested yesterday and charged with robbery in the $1,900 holdup of the driver of a soft-drink delivery truck in Cypress Hills, Queens, on Friday, the police said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are condemned to vacations with our grandmothers in the countryside.'' - Jean Francois Denieau, complaining about France's new economic plan. (1:2.)

title: MAHLER REMAINS A POTENT LURE
description: The current popularity of Gustav Mahler's symphonies is obviously due to the music itself and the response it evokes in its listeners, but one suspects that the symphonies are also played as frequently as they are because they show off a conductor and an orchestra to advantage - that is, if they are worthy. In part this must account for the fact that visiting orchestras come into New York, at least, presenting these difficult works, with the result that sometimes one or more of them will be duplicated in performance during a season. It must also help to account for the continuing number of recordings that are issued. At hand are several new or relatively new releases of various Mahler symphonies, although there are plenty of superb recordings of the repertory already listed in the catalogues.

title: USER FEES TARGETED AS SOURCE OF REVENUE
description: SINCE it's politically imprudent to raise taxes, elected officials from county executive and town supervisor on down to village trustee are turning to user fees as a means of bringing in new revenues.

title: Clare J. Attura Weds Robert K. Kretzman
description: Clare J. Attura, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Attura of Satellite Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Robert Keith Kretzman, son of Mrs. Thomas White of Port St. Lucie, Fla., and Robert Kretzman. The Rev. Michael Perry, chaplain of Pratt Institute, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: HUNTINGTON EYES SEWER DISTRICT
description: WITH the rapid growth of the Route 110 commercial-industrial corridor in the last few years, the Town of Huntington is seeking ways to protect the drinking water and the environment from possible contamination because of unplanned waste-disposal systems.

title: Miss Moore to Wed R.P. Morgenthau
description: Mr. and Mrs. Evan Moore 3d of Charleston, W. Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Bryce Moore, to Robert Pattridge Morgenthau, son of Robert M. Morgenthau of New York and the late Martha Pattridge Morgenthau.

title: SINGH TU, $4.80, WINS WESTCHESTER MILE
description: Singh Tu, the lightly weighted and lightly regarded part of a three-horse entry trained by Allen Jerkens, ran down Master Digby in the stretch to win the $56,300 Westchester Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Seales Has Surgery
description: Sugar Ray Seales, a gold-medal boxer for the United States in the 1972 Olympics, underwent surgery yesterday for a detached retina in his right eye and will have surgery Tuesday for a detached retina in his left eye. Dr. Richard Chenoweth, the staff ophthalmologist at Good Samaritan Hospital in Portland, Ore., who performed the surgery, said the detachments were the result of punches the 30-year-old middleweight had absorbed during his boxing career. And his manager, Ed Garner, said Seales fought ''virtually blind'' and was ''punching at shadows'' for more than a year. A hospital spokeman said the operation was ''cautiously'' termed a success, and that there would be a period of recovery before functional and reading vision is known. ... Jim Watt, a 34-year-old Scot and the former world lightweight champion, has retired from boxing and says he will go into the fight-promotion business.

title: EX-MISSISSIPPI GOV. WILLIAMS, STAUNCH SEGREGATIONIST, DIES
description: Former Gov. John Bell Williams of Mississippi, a staunch segregationist who served two decades in Congress, was found dead at his Brandon, Miss., home yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

title: SCINTILLATING COWARD AT THE PAPER MILL
description: MILLBURN ALTHOUGH the evening is imbalanced - it starts with a forced smile and ends with a real tear - commend the Paper Mill Playhouse for presenting, and so splendidly, a program of rarely performed Noel Coward plays.

title:
GARDENING;
WHY A COLD FRAME IS USEFUL
description: A COLD FRAME is a useful piece of equipment, yet few gardeners know how to construct or use one. They are also an energy-efficient growing structure in that they use sunlight as the sole source of heat.

title: No Headline
description: When told by a dean that ''the most brilliant women'' admitted to a Harvard professional school ''don't do as well as they should,'' Betty Friedan proceeds to offer a ''hunch'' about the negative impact of a masculine ambiance upon feminine achievement.

title: THE WEIGHTS QUESTION
description: Donald Richardson is a freelance reporter who writes often on physical fitness. The modern health club, much like a rush-hour subway, is teeming with crowds vying for space among the many apparatuses, while mentally attempting to sift through the claims, counterclaims, information and directions offered by various professionals.

title: A LOOK AT AMERICA'S SUCCESS IN SKIING
description: IT'S almost like waking up from a dream - Phil Mahre racks up his third straight World Cup Alpine skiing title in Aspen on March 7, and then last weekend in Furano, Japan, Tamara McKinney became the first woman from the United States to win the World Cup.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE Town of Brookhaven recently created a new zoning category for horse farms that officials said would attract business and help preserve open space in the Pine Barrens watershed at the same time.

title: ROBERT H. ILLINGWORTH
description: Robert H. Illingworth, co-inventor of an ink-removal process that allows newspapers to be recycled, died last Thursday in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: RHINE REBUFF EMBITTERS THE SOCIALISTS
description: The biggest steel center in West Germany, the working-class town of Duisburg, was an unassailable fortress of the Social Democratic Party, which ran City Hall by right and dispatched deputies to Parliament as if it were a blue-collar House of Lords.

title: 1 Million Hawaiians Counted
description: The permanent population of Hawaii passed one million for the first time in December, the state statistician, Robert C. Schmitt, said this week.

title: AN OILMAN TRIES INTERSTATE BANKING
description: WHEN Frederick I. Shaffer Jr., chairman of Kansas Crude Inc., speaks before service clubs in this city of 40,000, he usually brings along his prize possession the bat that ex-Yankee Reggie Jackson used to belt three World Series-winning home runs.

title: Peter Greenhalgh Weds Miss Potts
description: Deborah Kendig Potts, daughter of Mrs. Brian Buchel of New York and Stonington, Conn., and Donald K. Potts of Hollywood, Fla., was married yesterday to Peter John @Greenhalgh, son of Comdr. Geoffrey S. @Greenhalgh, Royal Navy, retired, and Mrs. @Greenhalgh of Duffus, Morayshire, Scotland.

title: BY HOWARD GARDNER
description: PILGRIM IN THE MICROWORLD By David Sudnow. Illustrated. 227 pp. New York: Warner Books. $15.50.

title: SPAIN PRESSES TO UPDATE ARMY AND SHIFT ITS ROLE
description: The Spanish Army is being revamped under a program aimed at modernizing its training, reducing its size and shifting deployments to concentrate on defense against a possible threat from abroad rather than on internal unrest.

title: Bail Asked in Kidnapping
description: Kenneth Parnell, who abducted 7-year-old Steven Stayner in 1973 and reared him for seven years, is seeking bail on the ground that he was unjustly convicted of kidnapping, his attorney said Friday. Mr. Parnell's convicted accomplice, Ervin Murphy, sought bail in papers filed in Alameda County Superior Court Thursday. A hearing before Judge M.O. Sabraw, who convicted them, was set for April 8.

title: Fighting Racism
description: To the Business Editor: I read with chagrin that three states have passed legislation requiring their pension funds to divest themselves of holdings in companies doing business with South Africa (''Prospects,'' March 20). My chagrin stems not from any sympathy with apartheid or with the South African Government but from the fundamental irrationality of divestiture. Proponents of divestiture ought to keep the following in mind:

title: AND NOW, A PROGRAM OF SELECTED SHORT SUBJECTS
description: Back when movies were still movies - that is, when they were merely thought to be popular entertainment and we didn't have to stay at the end to applaud the credits - there was a catchall prelude to each showing known as Selected Short Subjects. The package might consist, say, of a chapter from ''Zorro,'' a Daffy Duck cartoon, a travelogue about Sweden, Land of the Midnight Sun, and an educational documentary about the Panama Canal. One advantage this scheme presented to young members of the audience was the opportunity to run up and down the aisles without annoying those who came to see the Feature Attraction.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
OLD-TIME COLLECTIONS TO BE AUCTIONED OFF
description: A public auction sale with unusual scope and appeal will take place April 8-9 when Bowers and Merena Galleries Incorporated of Wolfeboro, N.H., offers the combined collections of the Connecticut Historical Society and the late M. Vernon Sheldon. The sale will take place in conjunction with the annual convention of the Central States Numismatic Society in Dearborn, Mich.

title: SETTING THE STAGES FOR SUMMERFARE '83
description: PLANS have been announced for Pepsico Summerfare '83, a five-week festival of music, dance and theater that opens its fourth season on July 7 at the State University of New York at Purchase. Subscriptions, which start at $24 for four shows, will go on sale April 18.

title: THE EARTHLY TANG OF BOUDIN NOIR
description: PATRICIA WELLS is restaurant critic for The International Herald Tribune in Paris.

title: FORMAL SHADES, CASUAL EASE: GRAY
description: Long a classic color for suits, gray has surfaced recently in casual clothes as an alternative to the pastels of the last few seasons.

title: TRANSIT OFFICER KILLS ATTACKER IN SUBWAY, FIRING SEVEN BULLETS
description: An off-duty transit police officer fired seven shots at a knifewielding attacker and killed him on a Manhattan subway train yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Mary E. Connor to Wed Christopher J. Newkumet
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Connor of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elizabeth Connor, to Christopher John Newkumet, son of Mr. and Mrs. Blair H. Newkumet of Philadelphia.

title: They Couldn't Care Less
description: As a scientist, I can only evaluate hypotheses about the beneficial effects of companion planting by looking at research studies out with the proper numbers of controls and duplications. Preferably, field results should be repeated in other locations and other years before they are accepted as hard evidence in support of the hypothesis.

title: DECISION
description: WASHINGTON PETER and Diane Halferty paid $20,000 for a diesel-powered Cadillac Seville in 1979. Within three years, the General Motors Corporation replaced the diesel engine twice under warranty and rebuilt the transmission once, also under warranty. Just after the warranty expired, the third engine burned out and the Halfertys, two land developers in Seattle, were faced with a $4,500 repair bill.

title: Leslie Maitland to Wed A Television Producer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard L. Maitland of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Maitland, a reporter for The New York Times, to Daniel J. Werner, a producer in Washington of the MacNeil/Lehrer Report, public television's nightly news analysis program. A May wedding is planned.

title: IN AFRICA, TECHNICAL AID NEEDS GOVERNMENT AID
description: Six earnest men and a studious woman sit at a table in a trim office building in Dakar, Senegal, discussing a revamped housing authority for Senegal. They are a team from the Bureau of Organization and Methods, trained in business administration under grants from the United Nations Development Program. They matter. ''The B.O.M. has the ear of President Abdou Diouf,'' Mamoudou Torre, the Minister of Economic Planning, told a visitor. ''I don't fight it.'' Mr. Torre said that he would not push any pet project without backing from the bureau.

title: Hawaii
description: To the Editor: I was present at an occasion which deserves to be included in Robert Trumbull's ''Royal Hawaiian: Waikiki as It Was'' (Travel, Feb. 20). n 1964 I set up an itinerary dictated by some books I had read (Somerset Maugham, et al.) and some music I had enjoyed (the Bing Crosby Hawaiian period).

title: HUSBAND AND WIFE LEAD CHURCH'S MUSIC
description: RIDGEWOOD HE OVERSEES administrative details and plays the organ; she directs the choirs. Together, John Rodland and his wife, Joanne, ministers of music at West Side Presbyterian Church here, are a formidable team. Since their appointment 15 years ago, they have developed one of the most comprehensive church music programs in the state.

title: SUICIDE WATCH SET FOR RIKERS WOMEN
description: The Department of Correction, prompted by the suicide this month of a 22-year-old woman imprisoned on Rikers Island, has begun a new suicide prevention program for women in the city's detention facilities.

title: BANKERS, BROKERS, CONFUSION
description: Ten years ago, saving and investing seemed easier. Someone with money to save simply went to a bank or savings institution and put his money down. If he wanted to invest, he went to a stock broker or real estate agent. The lines were clearly drawn. A consumer wouldn't have thought of buying stocks from a company that sells tires.

title: CHANGING FACE OF JAPAN
description: It was 10:30 at night, and on the stool next to mine in the Orchid Bar of Tokyo's Hotel Okura a British businessman was sipping moodily at a snifter of brandy. He was, he explained, about to head home to London empty-handed, having failed to land a big contract because the product his company made did not meet the standards of reliability insisted upon by a potential Japanese client.

title: North Babylon Wins State Title by 81-73
description: North Babylon of Long Island held off a late surge by Springfield Gardens of Queens tonight for an 81-73 victory and the Class A title in the New York State High School basketball championships.

title: New Intrigue in Pope's Shooting
description: If the former deputy commercial attache of the Bulgarian Embassy in Paris is to be believed, and if he is indeed the former deputy commercial attache, Bulgarian and Soviet intelligence agents were behind the attempt two years ago to assassinate Pope John Paul II. The account supported statements by Mehmet Ali Agca, a Turk who has told his Italian captors that he shot the Pope at the behest of Bulgarian agents.

title:
OPINION;
NOW, 'TAXICARE'---TO HELP US PAY OUR TAXES
description: EVERY year around this time, Americans have a rendezvous with debt. Long Islanders once saved up for their old age; now they save up for April 15.

title: MURDER BRINGS A FIGHT FOR TOUGHER PENALTIES
description: The murder of a college student who was raped, shot and burned has prompted a citizens' group to lobby for a change in a Maryland law that allows killers to be paroled in 12 years.

title: Miss Walton Engaged to Congressman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Walton of Valencia, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Clark Walton, to Representative Mickey Leland, Democrat of Texas.

title: Social Security Changes Are; Sealed and Signed
description: ''It may not be a work of art,'' Representative Barber B. Conable Jr., a New York Republican, remarked. ''But it will save the nation's basic social insurance system from imminent disaster.''

title: TAX BURDEN ON CITY OFFICE SPACE IS RISING
description: THE tax cost of operating an office in New York City is going up s harply, widening the differential between what it costs to house a b usiness in the city and in urban and suburban locations elsewhere i n the metropolitan region.

title: LIE TEST EXPERT TIES '65 KILLING TO F.B.I. INFORMER
description: Two Ku Klux Klan members told the truth in testifying that Gary Thomas Rowe, an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, killed a civil rights worker in Alabama in 1965, according to an expert on lie detectors.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: BALDWIN HANSEL is not the biggest, he is not the handsomest (or prettiest, though the ladies of his species seem to admire him), he is not quite the meanest, surely not the nicest, but he is probably the smartest dog on our block because he is now the second oldest. His only senior is a small terrier who lives with the Lady From Ohio, down the block. So she has just told me.

As part of her recent Western Hemisphere tour, Queen Elizabeth II made her first visit to the tiny Cayman Islands. In terms of tradition and loyalty - to the British Crown, the Empire Crown, the Empire that was and the Commonwealth that is - it may well have been the most meaningful stop in her tour.

title: THE WRITERS AND THE WAR
ON HADRIAN'S FARTHEST FRONTIER
description: JOSEPH J. THORNDIKE Jr. is a senior editor of the American Heritage Publishing Company.

title: Chaim Grade
description: To the Editor:

title: STORY WITHIN STORY WITHIN STORY
description: ARARAT. By D.M. Thomas. 191 pp. New York. The Viking Press. $13.50.

title: Benedict Nightingale writes frequently on theater in London.
description: LONDON Spring has come early to London this year, bringing crocuses and lovers to its parks, and more than the usual number of significantsounding productions to its theaters: Shaw's ''Heartbreak House,'' with Rex Harrison and Diana Rigg; John Fowles's adaptation of de Musset's rarely performed ''Lorenzaccio,'' with a cast of 45; ''Making Tracks,'' a new comedy by Alan Ayckbourn about droll happenings in a recording studio. Yet by far the most rapturously received event of the season to date has been ''Crystal Clear,'' an 80-minute play which was stitched together by its three performers, began life in an obscure North London pub, and involves, of all forbidding subjects, blindness.

title: Free Market in Oil
description: To the Business Editor: There is a contradiction when John Sawhill writes in ''How to Cope With Oil at Any Price'' (Feb.20) that ''oil prices are not set in a free market, but rather by the relationship between the demand for the oil produced by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and its levels of production.''

title: IT'S THE REPUBLICANS' TURN TO FEEL BUDGET PRESSURES
description: In the debate that preceded House adoption of a Democratic budget last week, Republicans professed a willingness to participate in the writing of a bipartisan fiscal plan for the Government, if only the Democratic majority would cooperate.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MARCH 27, 1983
description: International Yuri V. Andropov responded to President Reagan's proposal for a United States advanced antimissile defense system with the statement that it was ''a bid to disarm the Soviet Union'' that would start the two nations on ''a runaway race'' in nuclear weapons. The Soviet leader said the United States and the Soviet Union had agreed a decade ago that no progress in limiting offensive nuclear weapons could be made unless there was ''mutual restraint'' in the field of missile defenses, and said that Mr. Reagan had shown that the United States intended to ''sever this relationship.'' (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: STAGE: JEWISH THEATER'S 'RISE OF DAVID LEVINSKY'
description: It would seem to be an impossible chore to translate Abraham Cahan's ''Rise of David Levinsky,'' about the transformation of an innocent East European Talmudic scholar into a cynical and successful immigrant American manufacturer, from the pages of the book into a staged musical, but the American Jewish Theater has done so glowingly at the 92d Street Y.

title: FINAL PAYMENTS MADE IN PEOPLES TEMPLE CASE
description: The final payment has been made in the $9.5 million settlement of Peoples Temple assets to 577 relatives of the 913 cult members who committed mass suicide or were killed in the Guyana jungle in the fall of 1978.

title: NOT JUST A DRINK
description: TO most people, wine is a drink that goes with the meal; to Alexander McNally, a meal is something you plan after you have chosen the wine, and if you don't have the right wine, you might as well not eat.

title: PENUMBRA SURROUNDS PEEKSKILL DONKEY
description: THE city of Peekskill, zoning regulations in hand, is determined that it has to go. The Rothfuss family, with growing popular support, is equally resolute that it must stay. And standing quietly in the middle of this controversey - not one to tilt at windmills - is Donkey Oatie, quietly enjoying the attention, and another apple.

title: AS GOVERNOR, CUOMO NOW BEGINS TO GET SOME RESPECT
description: When Mario M. Cuomo was elected Governor last fall, an interesting thing was noticed. While his predecessor, Hugh L. Carey, was never called anything but Governor (at least to his face) many of the leaders and followers here kept addressing the Governor-elect simply as Mario.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: BEYOND COLUMNS A AND B
description: FRED FERRETTI is a reporter for The New York Times.

title: Los Angeles's Plans Approved by I.O.C.
description: The International Olympic Committee today approved all plans for the 1984 Summer Games at Los Angeles except arrangements for shooting events, which may have to be moved to Las Vegas, Nev.

title: A FEW WELL CHOSEN WORDS
description: One of the most valuable of literary forms -and one of the most difficult - is the very brief life. Almost anyone can write a biography that goes on and on forever, and sometimes it seems that almost everyone has done it. But the short life, as it was perfected by John Aubrey in England in the 17th century - ah! the short life is something else altogether.

title: ALBANY CHIEFS ACT TO DROP JOB BOARD
description: Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders have agreed to abolish the state's most important job incentive program, administration officials said today.

title: May Wedding Planned For Karen C. Goodwin
description: The engagement of Karen Christine Goodwin to Eugene Robert Golden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Golden of Huntington, L.I., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond T. Goodwin of Garden City, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. A May wedding is planned.

title: IS A LOAN OR GIFT THE BEST WAY?
description: PARENTS and other relatives are often called upon to help a young c ouple buy their first home. Mixing love and money can lead to h eadaches and heartaches if anything goes wrong or if someone fails t o live up to the bargain. But besides weighing the emotional risks, p arents who want to help also should consider many practical q uestions.

title: WHERE TO GO FOR A SPRING WALK
description: SPRING is the time to walk in the woods. The earth is coming alive after its winter rest and there are things to see. Underfoot, paths are strewn with bronzed remnants of oaks, maples, sweet gums and birches. Only the beech tree clings to its tattered foliage. Or is it a gray ghost reluctant to leave the old season and ready to haunt the new?

title: Kathy Yensco Engaged
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Kathy Ellen Yensco, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Michael Yensco of Pleasantville, N.Y., to Robert Edward Brundage, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank James Brundage of Orchard Park, N.Y. A September wedding is planned. Miss Yensco and her fiance graduated from the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.

title: '84 YONKERS BUDGET: THE ARGUING STARTS
description: YONKERS THREE months before this city's next fiscal year and seven months before elections, municipal layoffs and political infighting have become early symptoms of strain over next year's budget.

title:
OPINION;
STATE GUIDE PLAN MUST BE UTILIZED
description: IN ITS Jan. 20 ruling against the practice of ''exclusionary zoning,'' the State Supreme Court devoted equal time to a resounding plea for regional land-use planning; that is, a comprehensive public policy that balances natural resource conservation, agriculture, economic development and housing production.

title: Clark's Wife Says He Expressed No Regrets
description: The widow of Dr. Barney B. Clark said today that despite his suffering, her husband never regretted accepting an artificial heart and ''if he was here today, he would tell you he would do it again.''

title: THE SPIRIT OF THE 80'S
description: THE trouble with the decade as a unit of measurement is that it hardly ever synchronizes with reality. For example, most of the 1960's took place in the 70's, causing that decade to lose traction in establishing its own character, especially where art was concerned.
