title: Nuptuals for Shirley Weiss
description: Shirley Weiss, daughter of Hans Weiss of New York and the late Mary Weiss, was married yesterday to Frank Torcia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Torcia of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey of Temple Judah in Manhasset, L.I., and the Rev. Louis Gioia of the St. Sebastian Faith Community, which holds services at the Christ Lutheran Church in Manhattan, performed the ceremony at the Tavern on the Green restaurant. The bride, a freelance associate television director, is currently with the American Broadcasting Company. Mr. Torcia is a vice president with the Jay Madden Corporation, a New York paper importer.

title: DELAYS ON TAPPAN ZEE FORECAST BY STATE
description: THE New York State Thruway Authority, which plans to spend $31 million to speed the flow of traffic on an eight-mile-long section of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway that includes the Tappan Zee Bridge, said last week that it hoped to minimize the effect of the construction on bridge users. But it warned of probable delays.

title: BANDOV AWAITS INVITATION
description: Boris Bandov is the only member of the Cosmos showing any interest in occupying the vacancy his teammate, Ricky Davis, created by dropping out of Team America. The new team will operate from Washington as a franchise in the North American Soccer League and as the national team of the United States.

title: A CONTROVERSIAL ART FIGURE SAYS FAREWELL
description: On July 1 of this year Sherman E. Lee retires after 25 years as director of the Cleveland Museum of Art. I know of no one in the field who does not agree that the American museum world without Mr. Lee will be a thinner and a less interesting place.

title: Trade in Data
description: To the Business Editor:

title: 'BARBERSHOP' AND ITALIAN 'TRUUUUTH'
description: ''Joe's Bed-Stuy Barbershop: We Cut Heads'' is an hourlong drama by Spike Lee, in which a portrait of the community emerges through Mr. Lee's depiction of a shop, its owner, the gangsters who'd like to muscle in on him, and his patient and supportive wife, who is herself a Bedford-Stuyvestant social worker. It's a more blunt, less folksy film than the title, which is taken from the shop's neon sign, might indicate.

title: Miss Gruninger, Charles Perkins To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Andrew F. Gruninger Jr. of Florham Park, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Elizabeth Gruninger, to Charles Heard Perkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Perkins of Cambridge and Nonquitt, Mass.

title: CANVASSERS ON ENERGY COSTS SEEKING TO REACH 15 MILLION
description: A cold, damp wind ruffled the dead grass on suburban lawns as John Eytalis pulled his red stocking cap over his ears and knocked tentatively at the door of a small house with peeling paint. The door opened a crack and a woman's quizzical face emerged.

title: FAKE-LICENSE LAW PROPOSED
description: TRENTON AN ASSEMBLY bill aimed at prosecuting the manufacturers of fraudulent drivers' licenses is being reviewed by the Judiciary, Law and Public Safety Committee.

title: Ellen Robin Joffe Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel E. Joffe of Long Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Robin Joffe, to Mark David Geiselman, son of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Geiselman of North Huntingdon, Pa. The couple are seniors at Carnegie-Mellon University.

title: PAULA MAHONEY TO WED IN JUNE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul L Mahoney of Marion, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Paula Joanne Mahoney, to Bayard Dodge, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Stuart Dodge of Princeton, N.J.

title: FROM WHEN MUSICALS WERE MUSICAL
description: THERE have been all sorts of styles in Broadway musicals of late, including the technological (''Dreamgirls''), the extravagant (''Nine'') and the environmental (''Cats''). To remind local audiences of the conventions of a golden age when musicals were musical - with hum-able scores and characters one cared about - the Theater League of Westchester, a nonprofit organization formed last summer, will present memorable moments from the Broadway musical theater in its prime.

title: Josiah Spaulding Dies at 60; Massachusetts G.O.P. Leader
description: Josiah Spaulding, a businessman and major figure in Republican politics in Massachusetts, died after suffering a heart attack Friday in Puerto Rico.

title: Between East and West
description: There is no telling what side of the net Chinese tennis star Hu Na will wind up on in her current contest. Washington has been marking time on her request last August for political asylum - the 19-yearold feared she would be forced to join the Communist Party if she returned home - and the Chinese Government has applied high-level pressure for her repatriation. The ball came back to Washington last week as the Chinese declared that if Miss Hu returned she would not be persecuted and would be allowed other trips.

title: Talbott Gains Squash Final
description: Mark Talbott, the top-ranked player in the professional squash tour and the winner of 12 of 13 tournaments this season, will meet the only player to have beaten him this season, Ned Edwards, in the final of the Rolex United States Open Squash Championship at the Yale Club in Manhattan today.

title: MANY COAST FLOOD VICTIMS LACKED INSURANCE
description: Insuring the California way of life that many people dream about is not cheap. And while those who can afford the beach-front bungalows and canyon homes can also pay the higher premiums, not all do.

title: TRYGVE ELIASON
description: Trygve Eliason, retired treasurer of Brooks Brothers, died of a coronary occlusion yesterday at Point Pleasant (N.J.) Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Manchester Township, N.J.

title: A TOAST, GENTLEMEN, TO LOOIE
description: SYRACUSE AND so we bid farewell to Albuquerque, to the Indian jewelry and the dry desert air and the chants of ''We - Are -Saint - John's'' and the Final Four that never was, and maybe never will be.

title: PRINCETON: 'EDIBLE' LANDSCAPES
description: PRINCETON THERE is more to the work of Ralph Rosenborg than recent examples of it would indicate. But that is not to depreciate the artist's show of watercolors and oils at the Princeton Gallery of Fine Art, an exhibition that spans the last 12 years and is on view through April 9.

title: Kicker Leads Stallions Over Wranglers, 16 to 7
description: Scott Norwood kicked three firsthalf field goals tonight and led the Birmingham Stallions to a 16-7 victory over the Arizona Wranglers in a United States Football League game. The crowd was estimated at 5,000 by Birmingham officials.

title: MOE BARRY RUBINFIELD
description: Moe Barry Rubinfield, retired chairman of the Berkeley Savings and Loan Association of Short Hills, N.J., died of cancer yesterday at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 80 years old and lived in Chatham, N.J.

title: Hiding From War
description: In the late 1950's, when the Government was encouraging citizens to build private atomic bomb shelters, just in case, one of the more lavish shelters was installed in a hill in Mill Neck, L.I. There, on a 15-acre estate, R. Brinkley Smithers spent $50,000 for an underground hideaway equipped to house nine people for six weeks.

title: A CURTAIN FALLS
description: For 50 years the sign above the door at 815 Madison Avenue - Ginsburg & Levy - conveyed to all antiques enthusiasts in pursuit of American furniture and European ceramics that treasures lay beyond.

title: Marcy Oleesky Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Horace Oleesky of East Meadow, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Marcy R. Oleesky, to John Sosnowski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Sosnowski of Detroit. A February wedding is planned.

title: THE GHOSTWRITER'S STORY
description: AUTHOR FROM A SAVAGE PEOPLE, By Bette Pesetsky. 198 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title: DANCE: O'DONNELL COMPANY
description: May O'Donnell's work is a trip into the past. Her dancers look, refreshingly, like the kids next door. She herself believes in the solid choreographic virtues of another age. And yet the dances performed by the May O'Donnell Dance Company on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater were as fresh as anything seen in New York this season.

title: Wedding Planned By Ann T. Larkin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Larkin of Montclair and Point Pleasant, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Therese Larkin, to Keith Joseph Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Smith of Lincoln, R.I.

title: Claudia Lucille Tufts Weds Mark Handasyde Whitney
description: Claudia Lucille Tufts, daughter of Mrs. Rosemary Wheeler Tufts of Van Nuys, Calif., and Robert James Tufts of Ventura, Calif., was married yesterday to Mark Handasyde Whitney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. P. Whitney of Boston. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Spencer Morgan Rice at Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston.

title:
GARDENING;
WHY A COLD FRAME IS USEFUL
description: A COLD FRAME is a useful piece of equipment, yet few gardeners know how to construct or use one. They are also an energy-efficient growing structure in that they use sunlight as the sole source of heat.

title: BROOKLYN RESTORATION RECALLS BLACK HISTORY
description: ON a small lot in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant section, a project i s under way that will restore four simple 19th-century wooden h ouses to their original appearance.

title: Correction
description: An item in last week's Prospects column misidentified an investment organization in the Boston area that is developing a venture capital fund to invest in community economic development projects. It is Affirmative Investments.

title: Rose Marie Cubbon to Wed R.D. Leeper 3d in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Cubbon of Oil City, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rose Marie Cubbon, to Robert Dwight Leeper 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leeper Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: COUNTY CHIEF RACE EXPECTED TO BE LONG AND COSTLY
description: A SMOOTH, modulated voice emerged last Sunday through the earthy sounds of the fund-raising breakfast for Tony Veteran. It was a radio commercial, prepared by Tony Schwartz, a media consultant, for the race that Mr. Veteran, the Greenburgh Town Supervisor, is waging for the Democratic nomination for County Executive.

title: Dede Neal, White House Aide, Is Wed
description: Anne deHayden Neal, general counsel for the office of administration at the White House, was married yesterday to Representative Thomas E. Petri of Fond du Lac, Wis. The Rev. Dr. James D. Ford, chaplain of the House of Representatives, performed the ceremony at the Georgetown Lutheran Church.

title: A CALENDAR OF HOPE AND ANGUISH
description: Dec. 1, 1982, 10:30 P.M. With Dr. Clark's condition rapidly deteriorating, doctors begin surgery to implant the artificial heart. Dec. 2. 7:05 A.M. Surgery completed. Dec. 4. Surgery ordered to correct air leaks in the lungs, a disorder not related to the heart pumping. Dec. 7. Dr. Clark suffers seizures lasting three hours. Dec. 14.

title: BIRDS IN THE HAND AND BIRDS IN THE BUSH
description: WHEN the Theodore Roosevelt Sanctuary, America's oldest national Audubon refuge, was founded in Oyster Bay 60 years ago, people had different ideas about birds.

title: ISLAND WHERE PRICES ENTICE
description: DEBORAH BLUMENTHAL writes frequently on health and beauty for The New York Times Magazine.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 2 THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $15.95.) An English girl caught between Israeli intelligence agents and P.L.O. terrorists. 2 5 20 MISTRAL'S DAUGHTER, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $15.95.) The art world of the 20's and the fashion industry of the 80's. 3 2 26 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 4 9 20 2010: ODYSSEY TWO, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) A continuation of the tale begun in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' 5 4 30 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 6 3 3 THE DELTA STAR, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow, 5.45.) Los Angeles cops contend with their own city's underworld, some would-be Nobel Prize scientists and an elusive Soviet sub. 7 11 24 FOUNDATION'S EDGE, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $14.95.) The struggle to keep civilization alive in a crumbling empire: science fiction. 8 10 7 FLOATING DRAGON, by Peter Straub.

title: ONE-DISH MEALS: A PRACTICAL WORKDAY CONVENIENCE
description: MEALS that can be prepared in one dish are a boon for people with small kitchens. They are also especially convenient for entertaining - particularly during the week, when dinners are often quickly put together at the end of a workday, with the groceries bought on the way home. The following recipes call for little preparation and they need nothing more than bread and salad to complete the meal.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE GREAT ENERGY SCAM Private Billions vs. Public Good. By Fred J. Cook. 292 pp. New York: Macmillan. $15.95.

title: STATE PONDERS NEW USES FOR SOME OLD MENTAL FACILITIES
description: From state highway 22, in lower Dutchess County, Harlem Valley Psychiatric Center looks little different today than it did more than a half century ago, when it was new. The two dozen sturdy brick buildings of the self-contained community, planned as a prison but converted to patient care, still dominate the rural landscape.

title: Singer Wed To Miss King
description: Elizabeth Ann King, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archer King of New York, was married yesterday to Charles Edward George 2d, son of Mrs. Charles Edward George of Indianapolis and the late Mr. George. The Rev. Dr. Bryant M. Kirkland performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: SUMMER TRIPS FOR TEEN-AGERS
description: JOYCE COHEN is a writer on the staff of Mademoiselle magazine.

title: MUGABE SAYS HE'LL FINISH THE WAR NKOMO STARTED
description: In the same stadium where he made a speech on the theme of national reconciliation at independence nearly three years ago, Prime Minister Robert Mugabe vowed today to ''fight and fight'' until armed resistance from partisans of his exiled rival, Joshua Nkomo, had been eliminated.

title: Louise Doctor Is Wed To Nicholas H. Cobbs
description: Louise Doctor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Stolman of Hollywood, Fla., was married yesterday to Nicholas Hamner Cobbs, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Cobbs of St. Michaels, Md. The Rev. Jurgan Liias, rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Malden, Mass., performed the ceremony at the Ritz Carlton Hotel in Washington.

title: REAL-LIFE DRESSING
description: There were no bright colors, no high fashion or flash, no high-heeled shoes. And yet, on the crowded streets around 57th and Fifth, the young woman stood out in a subtle way. In my camera's eye, she was the classic example of the successful, well-dressed working woman in America, circa 1983. There was a touch of understatement in what she wore, a strong feeling of pride. At first, she was one of thousands of women I had photographed in trying to piece together a picture of how women are handling the change of fashion in this decade, of how they are dressing for success in less attention-calling ways. Six months into my one-year project, I unexpectedly realized that the quiet yet fresh taste of one contemporary woman was showing up on many of my contact sheets. When I saw her again, I told her about my undertaking.

title:
DINING OUT;
CHINESE DINING WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: BECAUSE Chinese restaurants have long been considered one of the best bargains around, patrons have accepted, without complaint, unpretentious, sometimes garish, surroundings and the type of service that discourages leisurely dining.

title: HORSE OWNERS AND RIDERS FORM COUNCIL TO PRESS VIEWS
description: FRUSTRATED by what they perceive as official indifference to their needs, county horse owners and riders have formed a county chapter of the New York State Horse Council, a nonprofit organization founded in 1966 to provide a voice for people interested in horses and horserelated activities.

title: BRAINPOWER: A NEW NATIONAL CONCERN
description: AGAINST a backdrop of Disney World's elaborate new celebration of American history and technological achievement, President Reagan earlier this month added his voice to the many who believe America's technological superiority is waning.

title: Ins and Outs of Currency Exchange
description: A New Yorker who recently visited Brazil returned with a dozen tubes of Colgate toothpaste. She couldn't resist. At the Drogaria Popular in Rio de Janeiro she paid the equivalent of 34 cents for a 160-gram tube (about 5.6 ounces). At the Duane Reade chain in New York, a seven-ounce tube of Colgate costs $1.39.

title:
THREE COMPOSERS WHO KNEW WHAT DANCE NEEDED;
Barrymore Laurence Scherer writes frequently about the performing arts.
description: In recent years, the scores of ballet composers known as the ''Russian Three'' - Cesare Pugni, Ludwig Minkus and Riccardo Drigo - which are still commonly heard in Russia today, have been increasingly used in the United States.

title: PERIPATETIC PITCHMAN
description: I've had my eye on Lee Iacocca lately. He is the boss at Chrysler. It's hard to keep your eye off him if you have a television set, because he is so often on the screen walking through Chrysler's auto works and talking about his line of cars.

title: PROSPECTS ARE DIM FOR A RAIL ACCORD
description: NEWARK THE strike by conductors and trainmen against NJ Transit's nine rail lines enters its 28th day tomorrow. As the day drew near, there was little on the negotiating table - or the horizon - to suggest a quick settlement.

title: COUNCIL HEARTENED BY FIRST ARTS POLL
description: THE first survey of cultural practices and preferences in the county indicates that residents find arts programs in Westchester to be a viable alternative to those offered in New York City.

title: Lynne Elizabeth Montgomery Marries Girard Davidson of Annapolis Council
description: Lynne Elizabeth Montgomery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William N. Montgomery of Grosse Pointe, Mich., was married yesterday to Girard Bradford Davidson, son of C. Girard Davidson of Portland, Ore., and Joan K. Davidson of New York.

title: DALVA DIRECTS 'BLACK STALLION' SEQUEL
description: ''The Black Stallion Returns,'' directed by Robert Dalva, who was nominated for an Oscar as the editor of the 1979 ''Black Stallion,'' is just about everything that Carroll Ballard's first film was not.

title: AT MUSEUM OF CARTOON ART, DOONESBURY GOES TO THE WALL
description: RYE BROOK THE scene: the White House. The President speaks: ''Great! Stay the course!'' The director says: ''Cut! Okay, that's a wrap. Strike the set!''

title: FIRST STRIKE: A QUESTION ANSWERED IN 1945
description: To the Editor:

title: WHERE TO HEAR THE MUSIC OF EASTER
description: AS another Eastertide settles over the county, people are again drawn into houses of worship. A force that attracts them, often as powerfully as their spirituality, is the special literature of sacred music, which, having been heard once, creates a recurring appetite that seeks satisfaction year after year.

title: PRINCETON: CABBIE RECALLS ITS PAST, KIOSK HERALDS ITS FUTURE
description: PRINCETON The spry, sturdy man who calls ''Taxi?'' as you step off the train here has driven more people more miles for more years than most people ever travel. And all in the same town.

title: NOW FOR THE GOOD NEWS FROM BRUSSELS
description: Last week's currency realignment in Western Europe, following OPEC's oil price cut to $29 a barrel, was more good news for the battered world economy.

title: IT'S TUNE UP TIME FOR AUTO MECHANICS
description: BACK in the days when it was an Exxon gas station, Salonga Service sported a smiling orange tiger. The sign was taken down when the station switched to the blue-and-yellow trademark of Sunoco. And now the building is just a plain-vanilla white. The pumps are gone, a negative tribute to the ups and downs of the petroleum business, and what is sold these days is old-fashioned - and new-fashioned - mechanical repair.

title: 'HANSEL AND GRETEL' AS AN 'OPERA-BALLET'
description: BALLETIC arias? Operatic pas de deux? There will be both when the Connecticut Opera and Hartford Ballet team up in a new production of Humperdinck's ''Hansel and Gretel.''

title: PINK TERRAZZO OUT, BLACK GRANITE IN
description: Pink terrazzo paving stone may be fine for Union Carbide, but now that Manufacturers Hanover Trust has taken over 270 Park Avenue - five years after it bought the building - a new look has been ordered. The pink sidewalks are giving way to black granite, and two low fountains, each 120 feet long, are being built on the 47th and 48th Street sides of the building.

title: RARE WORKS DISPLAY OFFENBACH'S VARIED GIFTS
description: Jacques Offenbach composed at least 97 operettas and operas comiques, but no more than half a dozen at best have any kind of contemporary currency at all. Offenbach was entertaining Paris 120 years ago, and high spirits and spoofs of society, politics and mores were his stock in trade. Of all this, the late 20th-century knows next to nothing.

title: THE BOTTOM LINE IN OUR BACKYARD
description: THE clothesline, a sight that almost disappeared, has come flapping back and may soon billow forth in every yard. With increases threatened in our utility rates, March winds could set a fleet of sheets asail from Montauk to the Queens border.

title: COMPUTERS: HOT TIME FOR SALESMEN
description: THERE'S an old British saying that the battle of Waterloo was won on the playing fields of Eton. In a few years, there might be an old American saying that the b attle for small-computer sales was won in the field of marketing. A nd the winners may just be the companies that hire people trained i n dealing with the retail market, especially those with p ackagedgoods experience, and salespeople used to dealing with c omputers from the point of view of the consumer and not so much the a ttributes of the product.

title: VENEZUELA ENTERS A SEASON OF EMPTY WALLETS
description: In many Latin American societies in trouble, the crisis doesn't show. San Salvador and Guatemala City, in countries convulsed by war and terrorism, function at surprising levels of normality. In La Paz and Buenos Aires, the currency loses value overnight but people manage to put food on the table next day. Three-digit inflation and the third world's largest foreign debt haven't devalued the carnival euphoria in Brazil.

title: The $1 Will
description: Many handwritten wills drawn up without legal advice end up being challenged in court. Last Jan. 1 California became the first state to approve a legal standard will.

title: ARCHITECTS NOW CARRYING VISIONS TO GOALS
description: estate development. This i ncludes site selection, market analysis, economic feasibility and, u ltimately, the development of their own projects.

title: Michael Carroll Wed To Sharon Anderson
description: Sharon Ingrid Anderson and Michael Patrick Carroll were married yesterday in St. Mary's Abbey Church at the Delbarton School in Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Gerard Richard Lair, a Roman Catholic priest who formerly served as headmaster of the school, performed the ceremony.

title: LONG BEACH, CALIF., PROUDLY FIGHTING BACK FROM BRINK OF DECAY
description: When civic leaders here adopted a new motto for their town a few years ago, ''Long Beach, A City Alive,'' it was meant to convey more than an ordinary dose of municipal selfpromotion. Some officials decided it was necessary to remind the world that Long Beach had not succumbed to urban decay.

title: REDOING CABINETS: HERE'S HOW, BUT IT MAY NOT BE NECESSARY
description: WHEN kitchen cabinets (or built-in cabinets of any kind) begin to look grimy and worn, or when the finish begins to lose the luster it once had, most homeowners think about refinishing these cabinets - possibly as part of the next paint job inside the house.

title: A 'PERFECT MATCH': BUSINESS AND ARTS
description: MORNINGS at 5, Judith A. Jedlicka rises in her 70-year-old Huntington home to begin the journey that gets her to her desk in mid-Manhattan by 7:30 A.M.

title: IN SEARCH OF DE TOCQUEVILLE'S AMERICA
Recent Sales
FIGHTING DRUNKEN DRIVING
description: IN October 1982, two youths, 18 and 19 years old, were killed in Northport in an accident that involved a drunken driver. Later, a group of people met to talk about what could be done to combat the problem of drunken driving in the community.

title: THE TUG-OF-WAR BETWEEN ATHLETICS AND ACADEMICS
description: THE husky baritone voices echoed throughout the room and were loud enough to be heard above the din of rock music and the clanging of bar bells and other weight-training equipment. ''C'mon, Jimbo, it's light, Jimbo, let's go, Bo,'' the voices urged as Jimbo Covert, a 6-foot-5-inch, 280-pound offensive tackle at the University of Pittsburgh, steadied a bar packed with 435 pounds of iron on the back of his neck, ready to begin another series of squats.

title: OMINOUS PEOPLE DOING ODD THINGS
description: WE LOVE GLENDA SO MUCH, By Julio Cortazar. 145 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95.

title: LOW GRADES FOR CONSUMERISM
description: Consumerism is a movement born to help the average buyer make his or her way in the supermarkets, showrooms and shops, but consumers don't express much respect for what the movement has wrought so far.

title: WHEN THE DOCTOR GETS DRUNK ON THE JOB
description: When night-duty nurses called about his patients, Dr.R. often was incoherent or gave inappropriate orders. He once passed out in the hospital lobby and was put in an empty room to ''sleep it off.'' His children were in trouble with teachers, his marriage was disintegrating.

title: A WAGNER FIRST
description: Late in his life, Wagner called his second opera, ''Das Liebesverbot,'' ''atrocious, abominable, nauseating.'' The musicologist Alfred Einstein said it was ''a piece of impertinence and shameless imitation'' of other popular opera composers of the day.

title: BIG BAND STUDENTS
description: Several Fairfield County public schools will participate in the first ever High School Big Band Festival, to be held from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturday at Westhill High School in Stamford.

title: HERITAGE PLAQUES
description: Connecticut residents who want public recognition of the historical importance of their homes need not wait for some local historical society to mint a plaque especially for them. The Connecticut Historical Commission has available an all-purpose plaque for owners of homes or buildings either approved for inclusion on the National Register of Historic Places or that lie within a National Register Historic District.

title: Visiting Professor
description: Others have had checkered careers, but Paul Alan Crafton apparently played hopscotch with his.

title: MAKING A BALLET CLASSIC INTO A MODERN FAIRY TALE
description: It is Joseph Papp, the adventuresome producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, we have to thank for ''Swan Lake, Minnesota,'' an unusual and even modest television production by a new director, Kenneth Robins. The very lack of pretension in the program makes it delightful and quite moving.

title: DAMAGE REPORTS; Messages from Mars
description: After the age of reason dawned in 18th century France, the Academie Fran,caise, seeking to combat the absurd notion that meteorites fall from the sky, ordered museums to throw out their collections. Fortunately, new collections have since been assembled, and recently a treasure-trove of meteorites has been discovered - in Antarctica of all places.

title: NUCLEAR INDUSTRY: HURTING BUT HIRING
description: QUESTION: How many workers does it take to change a light bulb in a n uclear plant? ANSWER: Four. One to change the bulb, a second to measure the r adiation exposure incurred on the job, a third to keep the records o f what was done and a fourth to file the appropriate report with theN uclear Regulatory Commission.

title:
COMPANION PLANTING: PRO;
It Always Confuses Insects
description: Most gardens are home to both plant-eating insects and insecteating insects. The trick is to have enough plant eaters around to keep a permanent community of insect eaters fed. I have found that careful companion planting helps to keep the insect population in balance.

title: Chinese Nuclear Plant Pact
description: China and Britain agreed today to study Hong Kong's participation in the construction and use of a nuclear power station that China proposes to build in Guangdong Province, 40 miles east of the Shenzhen special economic zone bordering Hong Kong. It will be China's first major commercial nuclear power station.

title: Dr. Fleer, Geochemist, Married to Denis Main
description: Dr. Varda Nanette Fleer, daughter of Mildred Fleer of New York and Martin Fleer of Woodstock, N.Y., was married yesterday to Denis Main, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Main of Muncie, Ind. Justice of the Peace Clifford Yorks performed the ceremony at the Town Hall in State College, Pa.

title: Mailbox; Sports Fans, Sports Fantasies
description: To the Sports Editor: The article by John Crothers Pollock on the intensity of involvement of Americans in sports was most interesting (''America's Love of Sports: How Strong the Feeling?'' The New York Times, March 20), but it was one-sided in its interpretation. The data he presented can be reported as showing that more than one-half, 56 percent, of the country does not participate daily in some kind of athletic activity.

title: RETAILERS' PRINTOUT SHOWS DATA BOOM
description: RETAILING, the field that employs the largest number of Americans 16 million - is so vast, so segmented and so far-flung that opportunities inevitably arise as others are foreclosed. This holds true for data processing, a technical area that is increasingly indispensable to the widespread sales and inventory requirements of retailers.

title: London Store
description: To the Editor: Having read Donald Goddard's article on ''London's Stately China Emporium,'' Thomas Goode and Company (Travel, Jan. 30), I must attest to the fantastic service and courtesy of that establishment. have visited Goode's on many occasions.

title: Sports of the Times; The Marilyn Monroe of Pro Golf
description: JAN STEPHENSON remembers thinking at the time that this was the ''toughest putt'' she ever had to make. She was surveying an uphill 15-footer for a birdie on the 18th green that Sunday in Raleigh, N.C., in 1976 at a Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament. But most spectators weren't aware of that putt's significance to her. Even if she made it, she would still finish second.

title: WHERE PUBLIC POLICY AND MORALITY MEET
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
WHY A COLD FRAME IS USEFUL
description: A COLD FRAME is a useful piece of equipment, yet few gardeners know how to construct or use one. They are also an energy-efficient growing structure in that they use sunlight as the sole source of heat.

title: SEEING THE WORLD AS ARTIFICIAL
description: The most intriguing artists of our time, as of any time, are never fully comprehended by the critical theories that grow up around them. This is especially true of Laurie Simmons, whose most recent photographs are on view at Metro Pictures Gallery (169 Mercer Street) through Saturday. She has come to be associated - as has the gallery in which her work is shown - with a number of artists, recently called ''Image Scavengers,'' who recycle and reform existing imagery. Along with the likes of Sherrie Levine, Richard Prince and Cindy Sherman, Miss Simmons makes pictures that suggest that the visual universe has reached its limits, that the traditional notion of originality has become outdated.

title: SOUND OF MUSIC RINGS IN EASTER
description: THIS is the climactic season of the Christian year - the final, apocalyptic week of Lent, followed by the jubilation of Easter. To mark it, churches in New Jersey offer anthems, motets, passions, oratorios and instrumental music of all sorts.

title: STUDENTS FLOCK TO FLORIDA IN ANNUAL RITE OF SPRING
description: By day the beaches are a quiltwork of skin in shades of white, pink, red and brown. At night, hotel rooms with two double beds are packed with up to 15 college students.

title: THE PRESIDENT'S FANTASY
description: ''A vision of the future which offers hope,'' President Reagan called it. He foresaw space devices that would ''intercept and destroy strategic ballistic missiles before they reached our own soil.'' Instead of relying on the fear of retaliation to deter a Soviet nuclear attack, then, we would be safe behind an American technological shield.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: AT the State Capitol, when people talk of ''the House'' they usually mean the House of Representatives. But for a few days recently, there was a house just outside the Capitol that also drew attention. Mobile home advocates set up one of their model living units in the Capitol parking lot, hoping to change the negative image some lawmakers and others have about mobile homes and trailer parks.

title: Fat Years, Lean Years and PIK
description: Should the Government pay farmers not to grow food? In a world filled with hungry people, the notion seems bizarre. Yet America's grain farmers, prodded by the Reagan Administration, have signed on in record numbers to acreage reduction programs -including the new ''payment-in-kind'' program. Given the exceptional circumstances, that's probably just as well.

In the normal course of events when someone switches from a compact camera that uses the tiny 110 format, or when they switch from using one of the compact 35mm rangefinder cameras to one that is more versatile or sophisticated, they usually move up to the world of ''standard size'' 35mm single-lens-reflex cameras and lenses. In this 35mm category there is an enormous range of equipment availble that permits the photographer to shoot everything from extreme closeups to distorted wide-angle pictures and distant telephoto scenes.

title: SHEET-METAL INDUSTRY URGES ASBESTOS-REMOVAL LAW
description: The sheet-metal industry is urging legislative action to insure the removal of hazardous asbestos from all New York City structures built before 1972, the year sprayed-on asbestos was banned from construction.

title: ACID RAIN HARD TO QUANTIFY
description: TRENTON SCIENTISTS in the state's Department of Environmental Protection believe that the degradation of New Jersey's lakes, streams and air has been so severe that it probably is impossible to determine the extent of damage from acid rain.

title: Big Plans for Long Island City
description: The most pleasing aspect of Long Island City, Queens is what you see when you turn your back to it - Manhattan, across the East River. Now the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is moving to capitalize on those waterfront vistas by turning 70 acres of factories and warehouses into a $600 million commercial and residential project.

title: SERIOUS ISSUES UNDERLIE A NEW ALBUM FROM STYX
description: ''By order of the Majority for Musical Morality, this album contains secret backward messages,'' reads the sticker on the cover of the new Styx album, ''Kilroy Was Here'' (A&M SP-3734). Photos on the back and the inner sleeve of the album are taken from a 10-minute movie featuring members of the group. The film is an integral part of the Chicago-based rock quintet's new show, which comes to City Center for four nights, starting March 31.

title: Cook Is Ahead by 2 With 2 Rounds to Go
description: John Cook is concerned about how his right arm will hold up during 36 holes of golf Sunday. He expects to pack the elbow in ice between the two rounds.

title: FELLINI EMBARKS ON A VOYAGE OF MYSTERY
description: In front of a huge wooden replica of one side of a ship, Federico Fellini moves comfortably; he knows the surroundings so well he could almost direct with his eyes shut. He looks bulky in an elongated jacket, a long scarf, unpressed thick trousers and a porkpie hat, the brim over his eyes. Has he put on a little weight? ''No, no,'' he protests, ''it's all these sweaters.''

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title:
WEEK IN BUISNESS;
ROAD TO RECOVERY HITS BUMPY STRETCH
description: The road to recovery continues to be a rocky one, despite the Administration's new, improved forecast for the year of 4.7 percent real economic growth, fourth quarter to fourth quarter. Factory orders, which rose sharply in January, dropped 4 percent last month, while mid-March auto sales, although up a bit, remained stuck at a disappointing annual rate of 6 million units. Even the Government's flash estimate of a 4 percent annual growth rate in the current quarter seemed little cause for cheer. That gain reflected a modest slowing in the paring of business inventories - hardly the stuff that recoveries are made of.

title: EASTER CELEBRATED IN MUSIC
description: AS another Eastertide settles over the state, people are again drawn into houses of worship by a special force: sacred music, which, having been heard once, creates an appetite that seeks satisfaction year after year.

title: REAGAN DENOUNCES RIVAL BUDGET
description: President Reagan, again criticizing a House-passed Democratic budget plan, declared today that it would halt economic recovery and send the country back to an era of high interest rates.

title: LOCAL RECITALS SET MODELS FOR COUNTY
description: ''WE'VE been having marvelous audiences every time,'' Joseph Goodman said during the intermission of last Sunday's Pleasantville Music Society Concert, ''and every year we gain more supporters.'' Mr. Goodman, professor of music at Queens College, secretary of the society and last Sunday's page-turner ''par excellence,'' has every right to be proud of the society's achievement in presenting topquality artists in three recitals that could well serve as a model for other communities to emulate. At this final program of the society's sixth season, Beethoven, Mozart and Mendelssohn trios were performed before a large and enthusiastic audience by the pianist Morey Ritt, the violinist Mineko Yajima and the cellist Alexander Kougell.

title: THE REAGAN PLAN IS NOT ENOUGH
description: QUESTION: Could regulation drive up the price of a basic energy s ource despite falling demand and increased supplies? Answer: Yes. Q uestion: Would deregulation bring the price down? Answer: Yes. Q uestion: Should the natural gas industry and its customers count on d eregulation? Answer: No.

title: SANDINISTS SAY U.S. TRIES TO OUST THEM
description: A member of Nicaragua's junta said Friday night that his Government had been convinced by stepped-up attacks by rebel bands that the Reagan Administration had now decided to seek the overthrow of the Sandinist Government.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Color Complex A most sensitive issue in this nation's black community (and in parts of the Caribbean and Latin America as well) is the complexion issue: the relationship between people of African descent whose complexions vary; and, the belief of many of these people that their social and economic status is related to the darkness or lightness of their complexion.

title: Miss Chin to Wed James R. Boardman
description: Dr. and Mrs. Tsung Chin of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hsiao-lien Chin, to James Richardson Boardman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Boardman Jr. of Short Hills, N.J.

title: ALONG THE MIDWAY AT A TECHNOLOGY FAIR
description: CULVER CITY, Calif. STANDING among booths draped in blue polyester and adorned with names like Rockwell International, McDonnell Douglas and Eastman Kodak, Janis Lodwig smiled slightly as an eager exhibitor scanned her resume.

title:
OPINION;
RESOLUTION ON ARMS RACE IS DEMOCRACY IN ACTION
description: ANYONE who predicted two years ago that Congress would burn the midnight oil debating a proposal to halt the nuclear arms race surely was in sparce company.

title: BUDGET ISSUES STIR CONCERN AT PURCHASE
description: FOR faculty, administration and students on the Purchase campus of the State University of New York, the weeks since Governor Cuomo presented his state budget to the Legislature have been marked by uncertainty. The budget plan proposed eliminating 3,000 jobs in the university system, including 89 positions - 18 of them faculty - at the Purchase college. Some easing of the proposed reductions has since been made. However, college officials are still expressing concern about the direction and scope of a State University system that provides a less costly educational alternative at a time when private education is growing beyond the reach of many families.

title: THE PHRASEDICK BRIGADE
description: Vast numbers of Americans have nothing better to do than pore through old books searching for previous usages of famous phrases. (To reach ''vast numbers,'' as pollsters do, I have extrapolated from seven letters and an unsigned note slipped under my door; as newscasters say with excruciating fairness, a poll of this size reflects a potential sampling error of plus or minus 99 percent.)

title: CURRENCY-RATE LESSON
description: There are lessons to be learned now that the excitement over the frenetic effort to realign European currencies is dying down. The real message was not that the West German mark and a few other currencies were upvalued and the French franc and others devalued. Nor was the exercise unique. European currencies have been realigned before. The significance, at a time of concern over exchange-rate issues, is that governments face added pressure to find more effective ways of reducing currency instability and thus improve the outlook for domestic economies and international trade, both intertwined with the monetary system's functioning.

title: HOW TO EXPAND YOUR CAREER OPTIONS
description: ADECADE ago, aerospace engineers were reported to be driving cabs in Seattle at the same time that chemical and petroleum engineers were being eagerly recruited by oil companies. Today, the defense industry is recruiting again while the demand for chemical and petroleum engineers has slowed because of lags in the petroleum and chemicals industries. Such employment cycles frustrate the career plans both of experienced engineers and new graduates. Is the best strategy to remain in your specialty area through bad times and assume that the good ones will return? Or are some of these patterns not cyclical but irreversible declines in employment opportunities?

title: BUSINESSES GROW ON FAMILY TREES
description: Port Washington, L.I. WHEN Irwin Math set up a fiber-optics manufacturing company six y ears ago, he hired his first employee without reading her resume or c hecking her credentials. As he recalls: ''I said to my wife, 'I'm t his great technical guy who can design anything in the world but w hen it comes to running a business and paying the bills, I need y ou.' ''

title: OF OPTIONS, STOCK INDEXES AND FUTURES
description: PUTS and calls, stock options, market index futures, options on i ndex futures, market index not based on any established index. If i nvestors think they are confused by the new stock index markets, so a re many professional traders, analysts and brokers who understand t he simple mechanics of these instruments, but are still uncertain a bout how to use them profitably.

title: Prolonging Life Is Up to Patient, Panel Believes
description: For the 80 percent of Americans whose final illness is attended by hospital staff and medical technology, dying is not a private matter. But the decision to do so ought to be, a Presidential commission on biomedical ethics affirmed last week. In a report aimed at guiding patients, medical experts and hospitals, the commission asserted that attending doctors should maintain a ''presumption in favor of sustaining life,'' but they must recognize that competent, informed patients are ''entitled to choose to forgo any treatments,'' including life-sustaining ones.

title: THE APRIL FOOL
description: Chairman: The witness will take the chair and state his name. Witness: I am the April Fool. Q. The purpose of your testimony? A. I have come on my annual spring visit to defend the President's policies against the vicious opposition of the press. Q. All his policies? A. Yes, sir. Q. How very odd. Where would you like to begin? A. With outer space, Mr. Chairman, if you don't mind. I thought the President's idea of shooting down enemy nuclear missiles with laser beams and other clever devices before they blew up Washington was marvelous.

title: ASSEMBLY APPROVES TEST TELEVISING OF TRIALS
description: A bill to allow television cameras and radio equipment into courtrooms on a test basis was passed Thursday night by the State Assembly after heated debate.

title: 2 AMERICAN JOURNALISTS DETAINED IN SALVADOR
description: Two American journalists were detained here today on suspicion of having contacts with leftist guerrillas. Under the state of siege now in effect, they can be held for up to 15 days without being charged with a crime.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In today's Guide, section 2A, a pic- ture and the accompanying caption for CBS's ''One Day at a Time'' are in- correct. Because of a scheduling change by the network, the episode was shown earlier.

title: TALES OF A BACK-ROAD COMMUTER
description: IHAVE been a commuter for nearly a quarter-century now -no, not t ediously by rail each day to the city and back, but rather by car f rom a wistful little midcounty town, down the back road some 20 m iles to a more accomplished suburb on the coast from where others got o Gotham.

title: SOUND TRAVEL ADVICE
description: ANNABELLE SIMON CAHN of New Haven is a pleasant traveling companion. She never intrudes, though, given the chance, she can expound for hours the history and architectural wonders of a city. If you don't get her point the first time, she will uncomplainingly repeat the information as many times as it takes for it to sink in.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Rosalind Newman and Dancers offer the premiere of ''4: Stories'' during their engagement opening Thursday night at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater. With live narration, choreography by Miss Newman and music by Tom Marioni and Margaret De Wys, the evening-long piece combines Miss Newman's love of movement for its own sake with an interest in the American immigrant experience, and one of its three sections is danced to letters from immigrants that were published in the Jewish Daily Forward.

title: COUNTY TO MATCH CORPORATE ARTS AID
description: IN addition to renewing an $82,500 yearly grant, the county has appropriated a special $25,000 challenge grant to be matched three to one by new or increased corporate support.

title: Capitals Tied, 4-4
description: Pat Boutette scored with 19 seconds remaining tonight to give the Pittsburgh Penguins a 4-4 tie with the Washington Capitals.

title:
DINING OUT;
A BIT OF GREECE JUST OVER THE RIVER
description: CONSIDERING the variety of cuisines available in the county, it is surprising that the cooking of Greece remains unrepresented. Granted, there might appear a shishkebab here or a spanakopita there, but no serious commitment to serving up authentic Greek dishes seems to exist in these parts. Ten minutes across the Tappan Zee Bridge in Pearl River, however, is Kafenio Among the Flowers, a charmer of a restaurant that merges with a lush flower shop to give diners an idyllic setting of greens and bright blooms. Both restaurant and flower shop are run by the same family but Paul Theodore manages the restaurant side of this symbiotic pairing, one that produces some clearly two-star accomplishments, many of which are traditionally Greek.

title: ENGINEERS: A DROPOUT PROBLEM FOR THE U.S.
description: WITH the bachelor's and master's degrees in mechanical engineering t hat Peter B. Franz possesses, he could be helping the nation battle J apan for technological leadership. Instead, Mr. Franz runs a beer a nd wine store in Cheshire, Mass. After having been dismissed as heado f research and development of a textile company a few years ago, he f ound companies were not interested in hiring a 45-year-old engineer.N ow that he has started his own business, he said, he finds it much m ore enjoyable than engineering.

title: Miss Pease To Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy Thayer Pease Jr. of Wilmington, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bonnie Lee Pease, to Frank Janeway Keeler, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Martyn D. Keeler of Brookfield, Vt.

title: PRIMARY ENLIVENED
description: TRENTON THREE State Assemblywomen who want to move up to the State Senate have heightened interest in the June 7 Republican and Democratic primaries.

title: Corbisiero Sets Record
description: Tony Corbisiero of Columbia ended his college career today by winning the 1,650-yard freestyle event with an American record time of 14 minutes 46.29 seconds at the N.C.A.A. swimming and diving championships.

title: STRONG PERFORMANCES HELP 'THORN BIRDS' SOAR
description: This season's march of lavish mini-series continues. Those viewers who had the stamina - and evidently there were many - to wade through 18 hours of ABC's ''The Winds of War'' can now settle into 10 hours of ABC's ''The Thorn Birds,'' based on the best-selling novel by Colleen McCullough. The epic tale, spanning a period from 1920 to 1962, begins tonight at 8 with a three-hour premiere and will continue on consecutive evenings through Wednesday, when the threehour conclusion will be shown.

title: NEW WAYS TO MEET NATION'S CHALLENGES
description: OPTICAL ENGINEERS are developing a communications system that t ransmits telephone conversations by rapid pulses of light from a t iny laser through strands of extremely pure glass. Biomedical e ngineers are using veins made of human umbilical cords for vascular r econstruction. Robotics engineers are perfecting techniques for u sing robots to take over jobs that are boring, unsafe and unhealthy f or human workers.

title: March 27, 1983
description: William Safire 20 On Language The Phrasedick Brigade Russell Baker 26 Sunday Observer Peripatetic Pitchman David McCullough 28 The Great Bridge and the American Imagination Robert C. Christopher 40 Changing Face of Japan Prosperity is altering the very values that led to Japan's economic ascendancy. Harry Schwartz 42 Toward the Conquest of Heart Disease A series of remarkable medical and technological breakthroughs has transformed the treatment of heart disease, promising major developments for the future.

title: SOMALIS EXPECTING ETHIOPIAN OFFENSIVE
description: Nine months after the last outbreak of serious fighting in the troubled Horn of Africa, Somali and Ethiopian troops still engage in sporadic daily exchanges of artillery fire.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: LYING LOW. By Diane Johnson. (Vintage, $3.95.) '' 'Lying Low' seems to me a nearly flawless performance, a beautifully constructed, elegantly written book, delicate in its perceptions, powerful in its impact,'' Robert Towers said in his 1978 review. A mosaic of small, deft paragraphs, the novel covers four days in the intertwined lives of Theodora Wait, a former dancer who teaches ballet; her brother, Anton, a photographer; Ouida Senza, a perpetually bewildered Brazilian immigrant; and Marybeth Howe, a beautiful young fugitive.

title:
OPINION;
OUR 'LUXURY' CAR
description: IAM willing to bet that our family car would be a ''Rent-a-Wreck'' r eject. The emergency brake-release cable, which is not supposed to b e detachable, is. One power window has a burned-out motor, and this,c ombined with the fact that the air-conditioning system is in no c ondition to condition anything, makes summer driving far from a b reeze.

title: NEIL SIMON DELVES INTO HIS PAST
description: When Neil Simon was a boy growing up in Washington Heights during the Depression, his parents separated frequently, his father often disappearing for more than a year at a time. Finally they separated for good, and the family was further shattered by poverty: Neil and his mother went to live with cousins while his older brother was sent to live with an aunt. Mr. Simon has searing memories of losing his own home and having to live as a dependent guest in someone else's house.

title: A June Wedding For Miss Ferrari
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick N. Ferrari of Glen Cove, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Theresa Marie Ferrari, to Ronald H. Furman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Furman of Garden City, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: WHERE DARWIN THEORIZED, VISITORS MARVEL
description: LOU WEISMAN, a writer who lives in Westport, Conn., is the author of the recently published ''Intensive Care, a Family Love Story'' (Random House).

title: INTRODUCING BILLS TO COMBAT CRIME
description: In response to Harry Ellerton's article expressing concern about legislation to help combat crime, please note that I have introduced legislation mandating stiff sentences on criminals convicted of multiple violent crimes.

title: A DELICIOUS CHINESE SPECIALTY
description: THE star system does not always tell the whole story, and this review of Hunan River in Atlantic Beach serves as a case in point. The menu has been inspired by the culinary styles of several regions of China and is occasionally given a touch of distinctly contemporary Western originality. For the most part the preparation is decent, averaging out to one star. But at the same time, one specialty in particular is so outstanding, as good a dish as you are likely to find in any Chinese restaurant in the New York area, that a visit to Hunan River would be worthwhile just to sample it.

title: A Present Danger In Nicaragua?
description: Nicaragua tries to get help where it can. In the process, the Sandinist regime finds it difficult to avoid substantiating the Reagan Administration's essential point about Central America - that it is in danger of being taken over by forces linked to the Soviet Union. Last week, as Nicaragua fought off what it alleged was an American-backed invasion of rightists from Honduras, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the chief of the Nicaraguan junta, visited Moscow and got a pledge of political and material aid from Yuri V. Andropov.

title: TONEARMS: IS LINEAR BETTER?
description: Shades of Euclid hover over the latest doings of audio designers who are busily revamping the basic geometry of record players. It's all a matter of arcs, angles and tangents, which may be decidedly Greek to many listeners. But at the risk of stirring queasy memories of high school math, we should appraise the so-called linear-tracking tonearms that have recently been much in evidence on the fancier turntables. Especially since these models are more expensive than their conventional counterparts, it may be well to examine if and how they justify their higher cost.

title: Missouri Journalism School To Award Eight Honor Medals
description: Six journalists, a broadcasting corporation and a magazine have been selected as 1983 recipients of the Missouri Honor Medal for Distinguished Service to Journalism, the University of Missouri's School of Journalism has announced.

title: TOWARD THE CONQUEST OF HEART DISEASE
description: Harry Schwartz, writer-in-residence at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, is a former member of The New York Times's editorial board.

title: BAN ON SUNDAY SALES ENDS TODAY IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: Sunday sales in Massachusetts have been a risky enterprise since 1648, when elders of the Massachusetts Bay Colony declared, ''Whoever shall prophane the Lord's Day by doing any servill worke should be fined or whipped.''

title: Rights Official Insists on His
description: As amply demonstrated by recent dispatches from the environmental front, some Presidential appointees turn out to be disappointments. Others, like Clarence M. Pendleton Jr., the chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, simply turn.

title: THE NONTECHNICIANS STILL HAVE A ROLE
description: FIVE years ago, people with liberal arts and business backgrounds began discovering that they were welcome in the fast-developing computer industry. Despite the hiring slowdown that has affected software services and hardware manufacturers in the last year, people without a technological background are being hired by these companies, provided they have some knowledge of computers.

title: ANTIQUES THE CUPBOARD: AND EARLY HEIRLOOM
description: METICULOUSLY carved and decorated press cupboards built here in the 17th century followed as closely as possible those remembered from the halls of English manor houses. The massive cupboard provided an impressive furnishing for the most important room in the well-to-do colonial home: the top board and the open shelf areas at the sides of the upper half were used for the display of a family's fine silver, pewter and faience. The lower part, enclosed with doors, was used for storage of other valuables, including linens.

title: Diane Wilan Is Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Wilan of Fairfield, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Diane Wilan, to Joseph L. Palladino, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dominic Palladino of Trumbull, Conn. Miss Wilan is a paralegal with the New York law firm of Schwartz, Klink & Schreiber. Her fiance is attending the Graduate School of Engineering and Applied Science at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: MILITARY TO REPLACE JEEP WITH BIGGER VEHICLE
description: The jeep, the military's workhorse of World War II, is about to be replaced. Its successor, to be called a Hummer, will be a larger vehicle designed to keep pace with today's modern military. As is typical with the military, the name of the new vehicle is derived from the initials that spell out what it is designed to be: a high-mobility multipurpose wheeled vehicle. The word jeep itself was derived from the initials G.P., standing for the military's general purpose vehicle.

title: Polish Paper Says Walesa Is a Publicity-Seeker
description: A Polish newspaper accused Lech Walesa today of exploiting what it called sensational reports of purported attempts on his life.

title: E.P.A.'S RECENT PAST MAY OVERSHADOW ITS FUTURE
description: The return of William D. Ruckelshaus, the Environmental Protection Agency's first Administrator, will undoubtedly have salutory effects on the agency. For one thing, the morale of the environmental agency staff, which had been at an ebb, was restored visibly and dramatically by his mere appearance at the agency not long after his nomination was announced last week.

title: ON MADISON AVENUE, THE URBANE JOYS OF STROLLING
description: Susan Ripps, a literary agent, and her husband, Richard, a real estate man, strolled down Madison Avenue yesterday, the spring's first Saturday, because, Mrs. Ripps said: ''It makes me feel terrific. I like it.''

title: THE WEST ITS OWN ENEMY
description: DANGEROUS RELATIONS, The Soviet Union in World Politics, 1970-1982. By Adam B. Ulam. 325 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $25.

title: INTERSTATE BANKING IS GAINING IN LEGISLATURE
description: HARTFORD AS the bank lobbyists crowded around to watch, a sharply divided General Assembly committee set the stage last week for a major alteration of banking in Connecticut.

title: THE SILENT POWER OF THE N.S.A.
description: David Burnham is a reporter in The Times's Washington bureau. This article is adapted from Mr. Burnham's book ''The Rise of the Computer State,'' to be published by Random House in May.

title: COMMUNICATIONS FAILED, TOO, AT SALEM I
description: LOWER ALLOWAYS CREEK TWP. EQUIPMENT was not the only thing that failed at the Salem I nuclear-power plant here on the night of Feb. 25, according to town officials.

title:
OPINION;
'PREJUDICE IS NO PRANK
description: THE 1982 Audit of Anti-Semitic Incidents, released by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith on Jan. 11, 1982, reports that on Long Island, where Nassau and Suffolk Counties have established special units to fight such violations, anti-Semitic incidents were cut by 16.9 percent, a larger decrease than the national rate of 14.9 percent. The marked decline was attributed to numerous factors, including ''exposure of the facts about anti-Semitic vandalism leading to greater public awareness; stiffer laws against religiously motivated vandalism; and educational programs in the schools that have focused upon the evils of bigotry and prejudice.''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Hop to it! The bunnies have picture-booked for their annual Easter eggstravaganza in libraries and bookstores round the land. As usual during this limited engagement, they share center stage with an occasional chick or hen.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Dearth of Buying

title: GROUP CELEBRATES RIVER PROTECTION
description: PREPARATION for angling is no longer a matter of assembling the proper gear and finding the time to use it. That luxury belonged to a gentler time.

title: GULL OR DUCK, LARRY DOES HIS JOB WELL
description: WITH a modicum of affection, I have come to call him Larry, short for Larus argentatus, the scientific name for herring gull. In an odd fashion, Larry became a neighbor this winter, frequently visiting the tidal stream outside the west wall of my apartment that flows southward a short distance and empties into the head of Barnegat Bay. (In the 1870's, the prosperous founders of the tiny borough that I call home noticed that it was at the head of the bay and named it, of all things, Bay Head.)

title: COMPUTERS EASING HOSPITALS' PAINS
description: THE computer, which has revolutionized industries ranging from b anking to transportation, is broadening its impact on a newer t arget: the American hospital. Able to handle pyramids of paperwork a nd to complete forms with lightning speed, computers are opening a v ariety of careers in hospital administration. Paired with other e quipment that permits observation of minute parts of human organs, t hey have also given birth to a host of new titles and r esponsibilities for laboratory technicians. And as they streamline c lerical and technical abilities they help hospitals contain i ncreasing costs.

title: PLANT DOESN'T FAZE NEIGHBORS
description: LOWER ALLOWAYS CREEK TWP. IT IS 208 years since John Fenwick set up the state's first English colony here, but some people who live in this part of southern, rural New Jersey still call it Fenwick's Colony.

title: Excerpts from interview, page 14.
description: Yuri V. Andropov said today that President Reagan's new proposal for an American defense system against missiles was ''a bid to disarm the Soviet Union'' that would launch the two nations into ''a runaway race'' in strategic nuclear weapons and defense systems against them.

title: Barry Mills Will Marry Karen Dale Gordon in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Melvin J. Gordon of Chicago, Center Harbor, N.H., and Wellesley, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Dale Gordon, to Barry Mills, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Mills of Warwick, R.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Stunned St. John's Sees Dream Vanish
description: Billy Goodwin was the last player to leave. At the end of the St. John's basketball season, as the Georgia celebration raged at one end of the floor at the Carrier Dome, Goodwin walked slowly in a corner at the opposite end. He paused and turned back to face the middle of the floor, not wanting to go.

title: Resident by Law
description: Badly crippled by polio and rejected by people in Ecuador because of his deformities, 15-year-old Juan Ramirez was found by American missionaries near death in a jungle and brought to the United States. But eight years later, in May 1982, Mr. Ramirez was told by the Immigration and Naturalization Service that it would take a special act of Congress for him to remain legally in this country.

title: THE NATION
description: Chicago Mayor Jane M. Byrne -apparently deciding that going out a loser was one thing, becoming a laughing stock quite another - said last week that she was calling off her write-in campaign for reelection.

title: AND BEAR IN MIND
description: The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 1,600 bookstores in every region of the United States. And Bear in Mind Other recent books that in the opinion of the Book Review staff are of particular literary, topical or scholarly interest: THE COMPLETE POEMS, by Elizabeth Bishop. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.50.) The work of the late American poet from 1927 to 1979. THE DARK SIDE OF GENIUS, by Donald Spoto. (Little, Brown & Co. $20.) A biography of Alfred Hitchcock. DESCENT FROM GLORY, by Paul C. Nagel. (Oxford University Press, $25.) The triumphs and tragedies of four generations of the John Adams family. THE END OF THE WORLD NEWS, by Anthony Burgess. (McGraw-Hill Book Co. $15.95.) A playful novel about Freud, Trotsky and the end of the world. A GENERAL'S LIFE, by Omar N. Bradley and Clay Blair. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The autobiography of the great World War II general completed after his death by Mr. Blair. IN THE SPIRIT OF CRAZY HORSE, by Peter Matthiessen. (The Viking Press, $20.95.) A report on the American Indian Movement, by the author of ''The Snow Leopard.''

title: DEAVER CLEARED ON DIET BOOK
description: The Office of Government Ethics has determined that President Reagan's deputy chief of staff did not violate Government ethics in writing a diet book while working for the Administration.

title: Finland Stays On Safe Ground
description: The kind of left-of-center regime that has kept democratic Finland on good terms with its Soviet neighbors seemed assured for a few more years after parliamentary elections last week confirmed the Social Democratic Party as the country's dominant force.

title: INTERNALIST, EXTERNALIST
description: THE AMERICAN STYLE OF FOREIGN POLICY, Cultural Politics and Foreign Affairs. By Robert Dallek. 313 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: A SHOW OF VIOLENCE
description: PECKINPAH, A Portrait in Montage. By Garner Simmons. Illustrated. 260 pp. Austin: The University of Texas Press. $17.95.

title: NEW FELLOWSHIPS GOING TO 96 FOR STUDY IN THE HUMANITIES
description: Ninety-six college seniors and recent graduates from the United States and Canada have been named as the first winners of Mellon Fellowships in the Humanities, a newly established graduate program to foster humanistic scholarship and teaching at American universities.

title: Hong Kong Moves In For High-Fashion Sales
description: HONG KONG LATE last month, the Hong Kong Trade Development Council staged a lavish fashion show in Tokyo. As lights flashed and cameras clicked, 30 models strolled down the runway, dressed in an array of silks, furs and knits, many designed in Hong Kong and all made there. Behind the models, tourist images of the British colony flickered on outsize screens. Music was provided by members of the Hong Kong Chinese orchestra, who were flown in for the occasion.

title: WURZBURG: JEWEL BOX OF ROCOCO
description: OLIVIER BERNIER's ''Lafayette: Hero of Two Worlds'' is forthcoming from Dutton.

title:
OPINION;
HELPING TO RECYCLE: 'IT'S VERY EASY'
description: RECENTLY there was an article on recycling in the Town of Islip. As an Islip resident who's been recycling since the program began in 1981, I'd like to tell you how I manage to do it.

title: NEW YORK AREA LOOKS FORWARD TO JOB BILL AID
description: The $4.6 billion job bill signed into law by President Reagan last week will bring at least $475 million to New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, officials of the three states say.

title: PRINCETON: CABBIE RECALLS ITS PAST, KIOSK HERALDS ITS FUTURE
description: STYLE kiosk is the first visible sign of the $65 million revitalization of Palmer Square, the nine-acre downtown hub. The kiosk, which will serve as a news and information center, is designed as a gateway to welcome visitors to Palmer Square and Princeton and to function as a meeting place for townspeople, said Claudette Adams, director of marketing for the Collins Development Corporation, owner of Palmer Square.

title: Nevada Bomb Test Delayed
description: An underground nuclear bomb test scheduled for this morning was postponed by the United States Department of Energy because of what it said were adverse wind conditions.

title: MOVIE MAKER'S 'HALF A LIFE'
description: According to ''Half a Life'' (French title: Mourir a Trente Ans), Romain Goupil's autobiographical film-memoir about growing up in France in the 1960's and 70's, the 32-year-old film maker is actually two people living in invigorating disharmony within one skin.

title: 3,200 CARS SCREENED IN CHECK ON DRUNKEN DRIVERS
description: For eight hours Friday night and early today, the Westchester County police set up a roadblock on the Hutchinson River Parkway, turning a quarter-mile stretch into a booking station for drunken drivers.

title: Watt Proposes Wetlands Bill
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt, saying that the nation is losing 1,500 acres of valuable wetlands daily, has proposed doubling the cost of duck-hunting stamps and imposing entrance fees at the most popular wildlife refuges.

title:
OPINION;
NUCLEAR PLANTS AND COMMUNITIES
description: THE safety and health of communities near nuclear power plants is a prime political and social issue of the United States's nuclear-power program. The whole idea of nuclear generating stations may float or founder on the real or imagined dangers to communities as far as 50 miles from such plants.

title: THE WORLD BANKING CRISIS: PHASE TWO
description: LONDON IN the twisted, narrow streets of the City of London, where more banks are packed into a square mile than in any other city in the world, there is an uneasy feeling these days about whether the battered banking system of the West will be able to fund the slowly forming international economic recovery.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE INTERVIEW WITH ANDROPOV
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, on President Reagan's proposal to develop a defense against nuclear missiles. The interview is to appear Sunday in the Communist Party daily Pravda and was distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass.

title: BIG I.B.M. HAS DONE IT AGAIN
description: SEYMOUR MERRIN, owner of the Computerworks store in Westport, Conn.,couldn't wait to start carrying I.B.M.'s new personal computer in the fall of 1981. The product was destined for success, he felt, and would be a strong addition to any computer store's product line.

title: WORRIED BY EXILES, HAITI SEEKS ARMS
description: AU-PRINCE, Haiti - The Haitian Government, apparently worried by a growing militancy on the part of exile groups in the United States, has begun shopping for new armaments, including aircraft.

title: IN SOFTWARE TODAY, IT MAKES MORE THAN A BETTER MOUSETRAP
description: AMONG many first-time microcomputer buyers a fantasy recurs that goes something like this: ''Once I get the computer home, I will invent a software program that will be the next Visicalc or Wordstar (two top-selling mass-market computer programs that have sold in excess of 100,000 disks), go into business for myself and become a millionaire before I'm 30.''

title: AUSTRALIAN PLOY
description: Attending the Spring Nationals in Honolulu earlier this month meant a long journey for nearly all the participants, but that did not prove a deterrent. More than 4,000 players took part, and 47 states were represented, making the tournament the third-biggest in a series that began in 1958.

title: CLASSROOMS BEHIND BARS
description: ALTHOUGH all correctional institutions in New Jersey provide education for inmates, there are differences - aside from the bars - between classrooms inside and outside prisons.

title: CAMELLIAS JOIN SPRING DISPLAY
description: WHEN the camellia greenhouse at the Planting Fields Arboretum near Oyster Bay closed for refurbishment in 1980, much of the bloom went out of springtime. To the delight of flower lovers, the greenhouse, which contains one of the world's largest collections of camellias, reopened last month just as the plants were beginning to bloom.

title: Lendl Defeats Hooper,
description: Ivan Lendl struggled to beat Chip Hooper, 6-7, 7-5, 6-2, in the semifinals of the $365,000 Cuore Cup tennis tournament tonight.

title: Mazzetti Finds Happiness in the U.S.F.L.
description: Tim Mazzetti, who will be the Boston Breakers' kicker when they play the New Jersey Generals at Giants Stadium today, is one of those National Football League castaways who has found new life in the United States Football League.

title:
ANTIQUES;
FLEMINGTON'S MOLDED CERAMICS
description: NEWARK ''FULPER: New Jersey's Art Potters'' is another of those small, instructive shows at the Newark Museum that point up the state's contribution to ceramics and the decorative arts.

title: Ruckelshaus To the Rescue President Reagan announced last week that he would like William D.  Ruckelshaus to take over the Environmental Protection Agency.  Probably he would also like Mr. Ruckelshaus to get the agency off the front pages as quickly as possible. But assuming the nominee is confirmed by the Senate - and as the Deputy Attorney General who refused to carry out President Nixon's order to fire Watergate prosecutor Archibald Cox he was expected to zip through - the controversies that have swirled around the E.P.A. for nearly three months probably won't end soon.
description: Last week, a member of one of the half dozen Congressional subcommittees looking into the agency's operations charged that an E.P.A. official had improperly discussed the political effects of a toxic waste cleanup program with a Presidential aide. And it was asserted in Capitol Hill testimony that another senior agency aide had ordered E.P.A.'s Dallas office to call off a planned cleanup of soil contaminated with lead, including playgrounds and school yards.

title: GRAND STRATEGY ELUDES BLACK LEADERS
description: Nearly three dozen black leaders gathered in Atlanta recently to pursue the idea of fielding a black candidate for President. Their meeting ran into the same problem that all other such political unity meetings, a quadrennial exercise, have faced: talking about running for President is easier than doing it.

title: Lacking Credits In Desegregation
description: A Federal district judge in Washington last week issued his report card on a 10-year effort to desegregate public colleges in nine states. All flunked and all must pay the price of footdragging, said Judge John H. Pratt.

title: Employment Outlook in High Technology; The Market
description: Engineers: A New Dropout Problem for America By Andrew Pollack Cover Research and Development Brainpower Is in Short Supply By Thomas C. title: THIS REVIVAL PLAYS IT STRAIGHT-AND WINS
description: Well, hello, ''On Your Toes.'' I feel obliged to begin with a greeting because the last time I saw ''On Your Toes'' I ended with a forlorn goodbye. That was in October of 1954, on the occasion of the first revival of the George Abbott-Rodgers and Hart confection that had - in 1936 and with the help of George Balanchine - dared to incorporate a ''jazz ballet'' into the routinely foolish plot line of a standard musical comedy. That first revival seemed not very long on luster and I concluded - and reported - that the show's onetime lure had danced its last and was now scarcely more than an autumn ghost, passing idly by and just as idly waving farewell. I had my nerve.

title: THE RESULTS SPEAK FOR THEMSELVES
description: THE Department of Labor is wholly committed to the concept of a ffirmative action. In truth, we are in agreement with our critics r egarding the central objectives of affirmative action that e mployment discrimination against all Americans must be eliminated. W here we disagree, is in method.

title: South Korea Police Arrest 15 For Anti-Government Rallies
description: The police announced today the arrest of 15 student activists from three Seoul universities on charges of participating in unlicensed, anti-Government demonstrations this week.

title: THE NEW MATERIALS ARE HEATING UP
description: CARBON composites. Graphite-fiber reinforced plastics. Superconducting alloys. Zirconium oxide. Surface-modified metals. These aren't household names yet. But if materials scientists are right, these new industrial substances, all designed to replace materials that indeed are household names, will quickly become better known. And the number of materials researchers, the scientists say, should grow just as fast.

title: No Headline
description: Introducing Bills To Combat Crime Harry Ellerton's article, ''Where's the Legislation to Help Combat Violent Crime?'' (Opinion Page, March 6), is long overdue. Pointing a finger at all involved, Mr. Ellerton blames the public and our elected and appointed representatives for inaction in this matter.

title: LAST HURRAH FOR THE INTEREST FREE LOAN?
description: THE interest-free loan between family members is under attack again,b ut there is still time to capitalize on this tax-saving technique. J ust about everyone is delighted with the loan except the Internal R evenue Service, which has been attacking it for five years. Now the a gency has won its second important legal challenge, and the issue ish eaded for the Supreme Court, which will decide whether such loans r esult in taxable gifts.

title: THE GREAT BRIDGE AND THE AMERICAN IMAGINATION
description: David McCullough, whose most recent book is ''Mornings on Horseback,'' a biography of Theodore Roosevelt, also wrote ''The Great Bridge.''

title: MAKING THE MOST OF WHAT'S AT HAND
description: There are no intimations of Americana -in fact, not a single antique or even a significant accessory. And yet the room rivals the best of the busy country-style kitchens that currently proliferate. Moreover, this particular brand of charm was come by honestly - and certainly economically -simply by stripping away ineffectual ''refinements'' and courageously exploiting the quirky virtues of the exposed structure as it stood.

title: IOWANS DEBATE JOBS VS. NUCLEAR BOMB PLANT
description: The Mayor says he does not want nuclear weapons in his backyard. A union leader would welcome the jobs the weapons would bring. A City Council member agrees the benefits would be substantial. A local minister does not think the benefits are worth the consequences.

title: THE WHO, WHAT AND WHY OF REAGAN'S PREPUBLICATION REVIEW
description: To the Editor:

title: DESPITE 1967 U.S.-SOVIET TREATY, DRIVE FOR SPACE WEAPONS GOES ON
description: After the United States and the Soviet Union in 1967 ratified a treaty outlawing nuclear weapons in space, most of the world relaxed under the assumption that its newest frontier was not likely to become a battleground. But military planners and weapons technologists on both sides, never relaxing, quietly pursued visions of space wars fought with nonnuclear weapons.
