title: COURT SPECIFIES FOSTER CHILDREN'S RIGHTS IN MISSOURI
description: A judge has approved an agreement that lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union are calling the nation's first Federal judgment protecting the rights of foster children.

title: REVIVAL OF 'PAL JOEY'
description: FOR all the intrinsic unpleasantness of its characters, there have been sporadic attempts to revive ''Pal Joey,'' the 1940 Rogers and Hart musicalthat was ahead of its time but has never been much of a popular hit.

title: A FIELD WITH SOMETHING FOR EVERY BODY
description: THE sight of Lee Majors performing superhuman feats as ''The Six M illion Dollar Man'' on television every week for several years p robably stretched people's expectations of medical technology to u nrealistic levels. A ''bionic man'' is not yet on the drawing board.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: AS the trial of Vincent Taylor v. Lance Memorial Hospital for Women proceeded at the County Courthouse, James Brayton, lawyer for the plaintiff, cross-examined the hospital's nursing supervisor.

title: Miss Merrell Plans to Wed In September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley W. Merrell of Rochester, formerly of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Louise Theodate Merrell, to Thomas Snow Middleton, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Willoughby Middleton Jr. of Rochester and Nantucket, Mass.

title: L.I. POTATO IS LOSING GROUND
description: LONG ISLAND potatoes, once as well known to consumers as Long Island duckling or Long Island bay scallops, have suffered a loss of identity that some growers and farm advisers believe is adding to the ills besetting the East End potato industry.

title: IT'S A MRS. LLOYD-MISS NAVRATILOVA FINAL
description: Having dispensed with formalities, Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd will meet today at noon in the final of the $350,000 Virginia Slims of New York tennis championships.

title: U.S. Clothing Makers Groan About Imports
description: ONCE again, emotions are boiling over the imports of clothing and t extiles into the United States. While the vision of a potential o utpouring of goods from China has provoked the latest worries, the c oncern - expressed by both free traders and protectionists - is of a surge in imports from all over the world.

title: 200 SWIMMERS GO TO AID OF ENDANGERED CITY POOL
description: They came to protest, and to swim, in their bathing caps, baggy shorts and bikinis. The place was the 59th Street Recreation Center, a Tudor Gothic building between 10th and 11th Avenues that houses a pool, a gymnasium and a paddleball court. The front door sports two grimacing gargoyles on each side - one clutching a basketball, the other a baseball and bat.

title: CONSUMER RATES
SOME QUESTIONS ON HEART DISEASE AND BARNEY CLARK'S ROLE
description: ''It is a correlation of all organs that make a living being; it is not merely one heart keeping everything alive.'' At the University of Utah Medical Center, Dr. William C. DeVries was explaining the death last week of Dr. Barney B. Clark, the first recipient of an artificial heart. The device had not failed, he said. The rest of the body had. The artificial heart had achieved fame as a marvel of medical technology, and Dr.Clark as a man of courage. He had survived 112 days on the device. Without it, and with his own heart rapidly degenerating, he would have died in December.

title: Slock of Lions Gets No-Hitter
description: Rob Slock, a senior left-hander from Garden City, L.I., became the first Columbia pitcher in 68 years to register a no-hitter, as the Lions defeated Manhattan, 8-0, yesterday in the second game of a doubleheader at the winners' Andy Coakley Field.

title: French Aide Skeptical Of Sihanouk-Led Group
description: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France said today that the formation of an anti-Vietnamese Cambodian coalition under Prince Norodom Sihanouk had done nothing to end the conflict in Cambodia.

title: SOLAR MARKET SEES RAYS OF SUNSHINE
description: SOLAR ENERGY'S star is rising, so to speak, and as it gets brighter a n increasing number of jobs spring up in manufacturing, a dministration, sales and installation. The biggest breakthroughs - t hose that will make solar power competitive on a large scale with m ore conventional sources of power - have not come yet, but when theyd o the job market in this field is expected to break wide open.

title: Gemayel Reported Firm Against Israeli Patrols
description: President Amin Gemayel said today that he would never compromise his nation's sovereignty by allowing Israeli troops to patrol southern Lebanon, a private news agency in Beirut reported.

title: RISK-TAKING REPERTORY PUTS SINGER TO TEST
description: AN ever-expanding cult is singing the praises of Karen Akers. Some maintain that the singer-actress is on the brink of superstardom. Others possessively insist that her extraordinary allure and exotic presence are strictly for the cognoscenti. Whatever her direction, Miss Akers's concert debut at Carnegie Hall on Friday at 8 P.M. marks a new step in an offbeat, late-blooming career.

title: EX-STATE TREASURER OF JERSEY
description: Walter T. Margetts Jr., a former New Jersey State Treasurer, died yesterday in Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in New Vernon, N.J.

title: U.S. WEIGHS REDUCING AUTO MILEAGE RATINGS
description: Motorists who complain that their new automobiles do not get anywhere near the mileage stated in the Government's mileage ratings may have less to gripe about in the future. The Government is thinking about deflating the ratings.

title: Kathleen Barnes, Student, To Marry Mitchel R. Gray
description: Mr. and Mrs. Warren W. Barnes of Wilmington, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Erin Barnes, to Mitchel Robert Gray, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry H. Gray of South Orange, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: MARGARET PAPANDREOU WARMS TO ENVOY ROLE
description: Margaret Papandreou has been serving as an unofficial Greek ambassador, seeking support and understanding for her husband's Socialist Government abroad, especially in her native United States. But it is not always easy, she says, because Socialism is ''a taboo word'' in the United States.

title: THE N.I.T.: TEAMS AND PLAYERS DESERVE A CHANCE
description: FOR as long as I've been coaching, the National Invitation Tournament always has meant something special to me. Maybe it's because I grew up in New York, played college ball here, and began my coaching career in the city. But whatever the reason, I've always enjoyed coming back to Madison Square Garden for the N.I.T.

title: ADULTS JOIN STUDENTS IN THE CLASSROOM
description: TUCKED in among the regular teen-age students who were taking a creative writing course at Valley Regional High School in Deep River was a woman in her middle years. In a nearby classroom another woman was registered in a computer literacy course. Two more women had just joined the auto maintenance class.

title: Alexander Vitale, Lawyer, Engaged To Miss Gibbons
description: Mr. and Mrs. James T. Gibbons of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Constance Ann Gibbons, to Alexander Francis Vitale, son of State Supreme Court Justice Alexander Vitale and Mrs. Vitale of Woodbury, L.I. and Naples, Fla. A late-summer wedding is planned.

title: TWO BIENNIALS: ONE LOOKING EAST AND THE OTHER LOOKING WEST; WASHINGTON
description: Once again it's the season for biennials, those big curatorial follies in which museums marshall talent from around the country to report on the state of contemporary art. Here in Washington, no less than two biennials are holding forth: the Hirshhorn Museum's minibi, ''Directions 1983'' (through May 15), and the Corcoran Gallery's larger spread, ''Second Western States Exhibition/The 38th Corcoran Biennial Exhibition of American Painting'' (through next Sunday). In New York, the Whitney Museum's ''1983 Biennial Exhibition'' has just opened, as has the National Academy of Design's ''158th Annual Exhibition.'' Curators grumble about the time spent in organizing them; artists fear exclusion from them and, even if included, complain that the work selected represents them badly; critics feel stampeded by the onslaught of art they present. And they are often less than enlightening for viewers. Yet the hallowed biennial tradition goes on.

title: PATTERN ON PATTERN
description: With some careful thought and a keen eye for balance, color and texture, any man can wear patterned shirts with patterned neckwear in a way that projects an individual sense of style. Classic furnishings do indeed have an appeal on their own, but it is the way they are combined that adds dash to a suit or sport coat.

title: KNICKS BEATEN BY 89-81
description: Charlie Criss, at 5 feet 8 inches, is listed as the shortest player in the National Basketball Association. But last night, the 33-year-old guard played a very large role in the fourth quarter as he led the Milwaukee Bucks to an 89-81 victory over the Knicks before a crowd of 13,059 at Madison Square Garden.

title: 'DRUG PROFILE' IS LEGALLY HAZY
description: Federal and state narcotics agents at dozens of airports across the country are watching for the telltale signs: the traveler glancing around nervously, the passenger paying for tickets in cash. These behaviors and others constitute the ''drug courier profile.''

title: Selling More Serious Fiction
description: Good reviews and poor sales. The combination is all too familiar to some of America's best writers, and John Edgar Wideman remembers how he felt about it. His first three novels - ''A Glance Away'' (1967), ''Hurry Home'' (1970) and ''The Lynchers'' (1973) -were published in hard-cover by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich and praised by critics but each sold only a few thousand copies in their original editions, which are now out of print. (A Dell reprint of ''The Lynchers'' also went out of print fairly fast, and of the three only ''A Glance Away'' is available now, through Chatham Bookseller, a small New Jersey firm.)

title: ITEM IN DEMAND: CEMENT
description: based corporation with a Texas-sounding name is hoping to be high on the list of companies that stand to benefit from the five-year highway repair program.

title: CANADIAN FILM ON TV
description: The New Jersey Network last week presented the first public showing in the metropolitan area of ''Acid Rain: Requiem or Recovery?'' a motion picture produced by the Canadian Government. In a move that aroused controversy, the Department of Justice classified the film as propaganda.

title: 2 CHALLENGE A BAN ON PARKING AT HOME
description: PELHAM MANOR WHAT began three years ago as a parking dispute between this village and two of its residents has become a constitutional issue that will soon go before a Federal judge.

title: A REBEL LION BREAKS OUT
description: Some years ago, sitting in the still, afternoon darkness of the 55th Street Playhouse, then a showcase for Japanese films, I was brought to attention about halfway through a conventional if not always penetrable samurai film. Until then, the mind had been wandering. As sometimes happens in samurai films, it wasn't easy distinguishing the good guys from the bad guys. Then, suddenly, a servant rushed into the film-frame to tell his noble master, ''A rebel lion has broken out!''

title: Bonnie Kay Binkert Wed
description: Bonnie Kay Binkert, a senior editor for the McGraw-Hill Book Company, was married yesterday to Michael Edward Melody, president of the college division of the Macmillan Publishing Company, of which he is also a senior vice president. New Jersey Superior Court Justice Paul Huot performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Mahwah, N.J. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Binkert of Fort Atkinson, Wis. Mr. Melody is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Giles L. Melody of Fayetteville, Ark. Previous marriages ended in divorce.

title: ROBERTSON: STAR WITHOUT ROLE
description: It sounds strange, almost bizarre. Can a grown man be transferred out of a job, from one country to another, and never ask, ''What happened?''

title: IT IS 'BOOM TIME' IN HIGHWAY CONSTRUCTION
description: ON April 1, gasoline taxes will increase by five cents a gallon, and repairs and expansions of the nation's roadways and bridges, including many in Connecticut, will get under way on a scale unmatched since the Interstate System of highways was begun.

title: TANGLING WITH THE COMPUTER MONSTER
description: Despite all the interest in home computers, most people seem to be holding off in buying one, and not because of the price. The hesitancy, surveys show, is a fear of handling. People simply don't know how to use the technological monster once they get it home, and therein lies a challenge for computer makers,

title: COMPUTER LITERACY: A TEACHER CHALLENGE
description: GEORGINA GOWER has a master's degree in biostatistics. But she works as a computer trainer, teaching business people to use personal computers and software programs in their work. ''I wanted work offering a career path and good money, neither of which I had in previous jobs as a statistical data gatherer,'' she said recently. ''I found this an easy field to break into.''

title: Q&A
description: Risks of False Artisthood Question: My brother wants to buy a unit in a condominium zoned specifically for artists who have been certified by the city. He is not an artist, and the sponsor has not prohibited nonartists from purchasing units. If he purchases, what actions may be taken against him?... M.A.D., Manhattan. Answer: According to Irving E. Minkin, acting commissioner of the Department of Buildings, your brother could be in violation of the of Buildings, your brother could be in violatio of the building code, the zoning resolution, the multiple - dwelling law, or all three, and both he and the sponsor risk Criminal Court prosecution and fines. The Department of Buildings has moved to revoke one building's certificate of occupancy because some tenants do not have certified-artist status.

title: SUMMER ELEGANCE
description: Change in men's fashion tends to be subtle, never abrupt. From season to season - or, for that matter, year to year - designers and manufacturers prefer to ease men into a new fit, shape or color. Unlike those in ready-to-wear clothes for women, style trends in men's clothes tend to be evolutionary rather than revolutionary.

title: 17 Experts Urge a Ban On Outer-Space Arms
description: Seventeen scientists and arms experts, including two Nobel Prize winners, have urged President reagan in a petition to negotiate a treaty banning all weapons from outer space.

title: WILLIAMS SCORES 29 AS NETS WIN, 102-81
description: The Nets gave up fewer points tonight than they had in any game this season as they defeated the Atlanta Hawks, 102-81, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ Another venerable member of a generation of jazz musicians who seems to improve with age will step into the spotlight this week at the West End, Broadway at 114 Street.

title: No Headline
description: While exhorting us to move into ''the second stage,'' Betty Friedan presents as ideal a person defined by a salaried career, peripherally responsible for pregnancy and child-rearing, a person whose egocentricity is accepted and encouraged. Does she not recognize the masculine stereotype of the 1950's, a stereotype since rejected by the majority of males? GAIL W. HUNTER

title: WHERE PUBLIC POLICY AND MORALITY MEET
description: To the Editor:

title: JAMES DICKEY TO SPEAK
description: James Dickey, the author of ''Deliverance,'' will speak at Fairleigh Dickinson University's Teaneck-Hackensack campus at 8 P.M. Thursday.

title: Fidrych Back in Minors
description: After three exhibition appearances with the Boston Red Sox, Mark Fidrych has been returned to Pawtucket of the International League.

title: THE LASER FIELD IS BEAMING
description: SOME people who went to school with Jane F. Kuhl at the Georgia I nstitute of Technology thought she was being impractical to get a d egree in physics with a specialization in optics and lasers. E lectrical engineering, they said, is where the money and the good j obs are. Miss Kuhl's supervisors at Bell Laboratories in Atlanta, w here she was hired after her graduation in 1980, disagreed. Althoughs he was fresh out of the classroom, they assigned her to a team that w as working on a fusion-splicing process for optical fibers.

title: Wright State on Top
description: The senior forward Gary Monroe scored 21 of his 23 points in the second half tonight to lead No.4 Wright State of Ohio to its first N.C.A.A. Division II title with a 92-73 upset over the defending champion, District of Columbia.

title: ALSACE'S IDENTITY PROBLEM
description: There is an old tale about mule training. The trainer begins the session by picking up a huge club and hitting the mule over the head. ''Why did you do that?'' he is asked. ''Well,'' he drawls, ''first you gotta get his attention.'' That's the way I feel about Alsatian wines. I only wish I had that big club. We Americans continue to be indifferent to, and even suspicious of, the wines of Alsace.

title: A FRESH LOOK AT JOB SHARING
description: MONICA MARCHESE and Orlene Weyland work at one desk doing one job and sharing one salary. They never get in each other's way because they work on different days. The two women are participants in a concept known as job sharing. Since 1981, they have shared a job as an employment recruiter for the Connecticut National Bank.

title: TEXAS SHERIFF'S GUILTY PLEA SHUTS A ROAD TRAP
description: It was New Year's Eve, 1981, and David Pavlicek and his wife were driving through San Jacinto County to a resort lake with another couple when two sheriff's deputies ended the trip abruptly.

title: STATE SCHOOLS BECOMING LESS FREE AND EASY
description: Admission to many state universities is not so open anymore. From Massachusetts to California, public institutions that had been accepting most applicants, even if it meant teaching them basic reading and writing skills, are tightening admission standards. At the University of Florida, for example, a minimum combined score of 840 on the Scholastic Aptitude Test or 17 on the American College Test is needed for admission. The University of California system will eventually require freshmen to have taken three years of high school math.

title: Miss Van Alen, Paralegal Aide, To Be Married
description: William L. Van Alen Jr. of Newtown Square, Pa., and Mrs. Henry Reid Blynn of St. David's, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alexandra Kent Van Alen, to Richard C. Walling Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walling of Gladwyne, Pa. A June wedding is planned in Wayne, Pa.

title: Wendy Alfus Is Married
description: The marriage of Wendy Hope Alfus to Chester Mayer Rothman took place yesterday at Temple Emanu-El. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony. The bride, president of Alfus Associates, an executive search concern in New York, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Alfus of New York. Mr. Rothman, son of Joe Rothman of Chicago and the late Mrs. Rothman, is a vice president with Shearson/American Express in New York.

title: Germany's Volatile Greens
description: There is something haunting about the Greens' rejection of the new Germany and their desire to ''deindustrialize'' the country into some Arcadian land of environmental purity (''Germany's Volatile Greens,'' by James M. Markham, Feb. 13). The Greens' contempt for the modern age and desire to devolve from it are not new phenomena to German youth.

title: REAGAN TO THATCHER TO CASTRO
description: The effective political caricaturist must be simultaneously artist, entertainer and critic. Ronald Searle, David Levine, Edward Sorel and Ralph Steadman are among the handful of practitioners who measure up - and they have been fine-tuning their work for many years.

title: BY SUZANNE DeCHILLO
description: Nanuet, N.Y. SEVERAL hundred yards from a local factory outlet called Let's Have a Party, several thousand crows were doing just that.

title: Barbara Lerman to Marry John C. Golomb in May
description: The engagement of Barbara Karen Lerman to John Charles Golomb has been announced by Miss Lerman's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Max R. Lerman of East Falls, Pa. Mr. Golomb is a son of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Golomb of New York. A May wedding is planned.

title: GUIDRY GOES 5 INNINGS IN FAMILY SETTING
description: After 12 days of inactivity because of muscle spasms in his back, Ron Guidry found himself in appropriate surroundings tonight for his return to the mound against the Montreal Expos.

title: JOHN SULLIVAN: GONE, BUT NOT FORGOTTEN
description: IT'S BEEN more than two years since I last had a drink with John Sullivan, two years since I groaned at one of his bad puns, two years since we slid off bar stools on the Lower West Side and laughed through a chilly New York morning, two years since I've looked into his eyes.

title: SCULPTURE THAT'S CONSTANTLY 'CHANGING'
description: RADICAL freedoms developed later in sculpture than in painting. Once begun, however, with abstract, nonfigurative forms, unusual materials, assemblage, found objects, and lines or planes that enclose space instead of displacing it, the compulsion to explore and to justify new concepts has been a special characteristic of this century.

title: HOUSE VOTES FRUSTRATE G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON THE three Republican Representatives from Long Island, now even further in a minority position in the House, expressed their frustration last week with the way the 98th session of Congress has progressed.

title: CITY DEFERS PLAN TO CLOSE 10 PEDIATRIC CENTERS
description: The planned closing of 10 municipal children's health centers here by June 30 has been postponed and may be avoided altogether, according to the City Health Commissioner.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Feb. 27 issue, the picture credits on pages 42 and 54 were transposed. The photograph on page 42 was provided by Photo Researchers and taken by Katrina Thomas; the picture on page 54 was taken by Abigail Heyman for Archive.

title: AUTO INSURANCE: A COSTLY FIASCO
description: IT IS no secret that New Jersey motorists pay the highest insurance premiums in the United States. It also is no secret that the Legislature is having a difficult time finding a solution. Often, the solution to such a problem seems to be very simple and clear, but having that solution enacted into law is another question.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Billy Taylor, who led the Giants in rushing in 1979 and 1980, was signed by the Washington Federals and activated for today's home game against the Michigan Panthers. Taylor, released after five games by the Giants in 1981, played two games with the New York Jets and had a tryout with the Boston Breakers this season. ... Walt Tkaczuk, an assistant to Coach Herb Brooks of the Rangers, will be the first recipient of the Rangers' Alumni Association Award for outstanding service and achievement.

title: TECHNICAL WRITERS CAN WRITE THEIR OWN TICKET
description: IN 1973, Marty Saulenas gave up his three-year pursuit of a Ph.D. in philosophy to become a technical writer at Wang Laboratories, a computer manufacturer near Boston. At the time, he was only the third person hired by the company to write the instruction manuals for its machines.

title: No Headline
description: The women at Harvard are not juiceless because of masculinization. Sexism is not the problem. Technology is. During the time I was a premedical student, a medical student and then a postgraduate student, the highly competitive, highly technical environment was very dehumanizing.

title:
OPINION;
MANY YEARS AGO, TWO BOYS TURNED BRASS INTO GOLD
description: BEING able to look back on our lives can be a pleasant avocation, even when one looks back on a past that is sometimes made gentle and serene by a deceitful memory. Such was the case one cold night as angry winds scudded under the eaves of my home, at that time of night just before sleep performs its magic. It was then that I thought of a time many years ago - I was perhaps 12 or 13 years old - when I entered into a solemn partnership with a good friend, another boy, who shared my desire to slap the mean hand of the Depression.

title: ANTHONY BLUNT, FOURTH MAN IN BRITISH SPYING SCANDAL, IS DEAD AT 75
description: Anthony Blunt, a former curator of Queen Elizabeth II's art collection who in 1979 was exposed as having been the mysterious fourth man in a Soviet spying ring, collapsed and died at breakfast in his London home today. He was 75 years old.

title: BERLIOZ 'REQUIEM' IN BENEFIT CONCERT
description: PLAINFIELD ON FRIDAY evening, the Oratorio Choir of the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church here will perform Berlioz's ''Requiem: Grande Messe des Morts.''

title: ISLANDERS, ON 3-0 LEAD, TOP RANGERS, 3-2
description: The Islanders, who have made a practice of losing their grasp on things late this season, nearly did so again tonight.

title: GANDHI RELATIVE ANNOUNCES OPPOSITION PARTY
description: Maneka Gandhi, the rebel daughterin-law of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, said today that she had formed a political party aimed at mobilizing India's youth.

title: Spanking Pupils
description: The New York State Board of Regents, tackling an issue that has split educators since the founding of the Republic, voted 8 to 4 in September 1979 to seek the outlawing of corporal punishment in the state's schools.

title: CURRIED EGG HUNT
description: We are always fascinated with foods that have a ''national'' day, most of them related in one way or another to holidays. We also enjoy the challenge of what to do with leftovers involving those foods. The Thanksgiving turkey, the Christmas goose, the corned beef and cabbage of St. Patrick's Day.

title: EAST-WEST DIALOGUES THAT SHOULD NOT DIE
description: To the Editor:

title: Gimmicks Hurt Collegiate Game
description: To the Sports Editor: College basketball has no need for a shot clock or a 3-point basket. The National Collegiate Athletic Association rules committee would be wise to listen to those who want to preserve the integrity of the game.

title: Fraternity Punished in Rape
description: The University of Pennsylvania has revoked recognition of the Alpha Tau Omega fraternity for one year after investigating a report of a gang rape by members last month. The victim accused five to eight fraternity members of raping her at a party Feb. 17. Fraternity members refused to comment on the decision.

title: HAWAII
description: To the Editor: The article on the Royal Hawaiian Hotel dredged up some old memories. When I was attending a university in Vermont during the late 1930's, there was a program on radio named ''Hawaii Calls,'' which originated in Honolulu.

title: J.D. CHANKSY ENGAGED TO KATHERINE V. PHILIP
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Van Ness Philip of New York and Claverack, N.Y. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Vaughan Philip, to James D. Chansky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Chansky of Swarthmore, Pa.

title: THE NATION
description: In 1978, the Department of Energy took the Exxon Corporation to court, claiming that the company had been overcharging its customers. Last week, a Federal District judge in Washington said he agreed, and ordered Exxon to refund $895 million.

title: MAFIA PORTRAYED IN COURT AS MYTH
description: A defense lawyer in the presentencing hearings for the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and three others has sought to portray the Mafia as a myth perpetuated by Hollywood, the media and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Cuba Returns Crew Of Wrecked Sailboat
description: The eight crew members of a Fort Myers Beach sailboat team that was wrecked near Cuba while taking part in a race are safely back in Florida after 11 days in Cuba.

title: COURTING STYLE AND SPONSORS
description: Peter Bodo is a contributing editor of Tennis magazine and author of ''Inside Tennis: A Season on the Pro Tour.''I am here to tell you that the next big thing in tennis will be watches: elegant, expensive watches as thin as the credit cards with which so many of them will be purchased.

title: Wayne State Winner
description: Attila and Stefan Cogler, sons of Coach Adalar Cogler, led Wayne State of Detroit to the National Collegiate Athletic Association fencing championship today.

title: PACKING IT IN
description: For many men, the joy of getting away for a long weekend holiday often is offset by what can be the tediousness of packing and the confusion of what and how much to take. But neither has to be a chore if done properly and systematically.

title: FRANCE'S NEW AUSTERITY PROGRAM AROUSES ANGER, WORRIES AND FEAR
description: Jean Francois Denieau, sales director for a hospital supply concern, today offered his view of France's new economic plan, which includes restrictions on holiday spending abroad.

title: MUSIC HERALDS THE EASTER SEASON
description: AFTER weeks of intense preparation, Long Island churches usher in Holy Week observances today, marking the season with music. Here is a sampling of the events:PALM SUNDAYNassau County

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: A Play by Thomas Wolfe

title: Nancy L. Schwartz Is Wed To W.S. Schreier, Lawyer
description: Nancy Lois Schwartz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerrold Michael Schwartz of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Los Angeles, was married yesterday to William S. Schreier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred A. Schreier also of Scarsdale. Rabbi Arnold Turetsky performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: UNIONS ARRANGING OWN HEALTH PACTS
description: Several unions in the New York metropolitan area have dropped their Blue Cross insurance and have arranged to obtain hospitalization benefits for their members directly from hospitals.

title: Letters; Satellite Savings
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT DOES A CREATIVE IDEA BECOME INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY?
description: Superman may be everyone's hero, but legally, he belongs to Warner Brothers. It's not that Warner Brothers has a monopoly on superheroes. Rather, Superman is what is known as intellectual property. And like other, more tangible belongings, intellectual property -whether it's a famous character like Superman or the story outline of a struggling writer - can legally be used only with the consent of its owner.

title: Q&A
description: Question:In May or June my husband and I are planning to fly to Rome, where we will be staying with relatives. What kind of gifts can I buy in the United States for our relatives, things that are difficult to purchase in Italy or that are cheaper or more plentiful here? - F.A.F., Montague, Mass. Answer:A resident of New York who recently visited relatives in Italy said the gifts that most pleased her cousins and their children were items that are intrinsically American.

title: Emilie P. Forte To Wed in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Earl M. Forte Jr. of Devon, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Emilie Patterson Forte, to Alexander Nicholas Stephanoff, son of Mrs. Nicholas N. Stephanoff of Haverford, Pa., and Nantucket, Mass. and the late Mr. Stephanoff.

title: Sue Ann Dubin and David Wald Wed in Scarsdale
description: Sue Ann Dubin, daughter of Jane Binder Dubin of Valley Stream, L.I., and Howard Dubin of Long Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to David Jeffrey Wald, son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Wald of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Maurice Davis of the Jewish Community Center of White Plains performed the ceremony at the Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale.

title: MARKING 300 YEARS
description: An letter written by George Washington to Colonel Carrington in 1795; a letter from John Adams to Benjamin Rush, penned seven years earlier; Thomas Paine's handwritten notes about the defense of New York Harbor; a manuscript by James Fennimore Cooper signed in 1831, and other documents from the hands of Washington Irving, David Farragut, Ulysses S. Grant, Charles Ives and Sheldon Harnick, the contemporary Broadway lyricist, are among three centuries worth of memorabilia on view Friday through April 30 at the Greenburgh Public Library, on Tarrytown Road in Elmsford.

title: STEAMBOATING IN ONTARIO
description: KARL ZIMMERMANN, who lives in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., is a writer specializing in transportation.

title: Ronni A. Gordon Is to Wed James M. Doody on May 29
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Gordon of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Ronni Anne Gordon, to James Michael Doody, son of Kenneth Doody of Chicopee, Mass., and the late Helen Doody. A May 29 wedding is planned.

title: COMPUTER ROUTE TO THE EXECUTIVE SUITE
description: MARIO NIGRO is an exemplar for ambitious students of computers. He i s the senior vice president of operations at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, F enner & Smith Inc., the nation's largest brokerage firm. He sits on i ts board of directors and has more than 7,800 people in his charge a nd a spacious office on the 37th floor of One Liberty Plaza in l ower Manhattan. Mr. Nigro is, in fact, a paradigm for his p rofession - a one-time computer programmer who was able to break o ut of strict information processing and into high-level management o f a major corporation.

title: SOVIET MOVES TO STRAIGHTEN OUT ITS RAILROADS
description: For the second time since Yuri V. Andropov took over as the Soviet leader in November, the Kremlin has convened a meeting in attempts to improve the performance of the nation's railroads, which have become a bottleneck in the Soviet economy.

title: A COMPLAINT OVER LABOR DEPT. RULES
description: THOUGH the Reagan Administration has repeatedly claimed that it is s ensitive to the needs of women, minorities and the handicapped, the r ecent actions of its Labor Department concerning employment a ffirmative action tell a different story. The department seems to bei n the process of systematically dismantling equal employment o pportunities for women, minorities and the handicapped.

title: THE CONSERVATIVE TRADITION
description: From this remove, that is, from the permanently-press ed vantage of the late 20th century, it is not easy for us to believe that, for most of the 1700's, men wore powdered wigs, satin pumps and mantles of fur. But the paintings of that period say that it is so. To be sure, they are not the only records of that time, yet they are the most palpable images left us.

title: Meg Corroon Is to Be Married in June To Thomas I. Sheridan 3d, a Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Aloysius Corroon of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Veronica Corroon, to Thomas Ignatius Sheridan 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheridan Jr. of New York and Windham, N.Y.

title: Subtenant Rights
description: To the Editor The article entitled ''A Slip in Albany Hurts Landlords'' (March 6) did not indicate in any manner that the same mistake can also hurt rent-stabilized tenants who seek to take advantage of Real Property Law Section 226-b (the Right to Sublet Law).

title: Vuckovich Sidelined
description: Another American League Cy Young Award winner is having arm problems the year after being voted the outstanding pitcher in his league. First it was Steve Stone of the Baltimore Orioles, the 1980 winner, who retired when he could not come back.

title: AILING WORKERS' ROLE AT TRANSIT AUTHORITY FAULTED BY AUDITORS
description: The Transit Authority has lost millions of dollars by failing to use properly employees who have health problems, according to an audit by the State Comptroller's office.

title: Recession-Aid Bill Crosses The Finish Line
description: Even as many analysts were pronouncing the nation's steepest economic slump since War War II officially over, Congress last week completed action on its first legislation specifially designed to help some of the 11 million Americans who don't have jobs.

title: HOLMES IS BRINGING A BIT OF GLORY BACK TO SCRANTON
description: SCRANTON, Pa. LATELY, this has been a town to pass through on the way to somewhere else. Once upon a time, prosperity passed through here and, when the cities of America were heated by anthracite coal, it remained for almost a hundred years.

title: BOATING INNOVATION SPREADS
description: When it comes to crossing water, Tony Garcia is a man in a hurry. In the offshore power boat circuit last year, Garcia didn't finish the first five races. Then his high-voltage catamaran Michelob Light took off, winning the next four races in record style.

title: Data Update
description: * Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic. ** Comparable data unavailable becuase method of computing homeownership costs has changed.

title: INDIA 'RAT TRAP'
description: The Indian film ''Rat Trap'' presents the decline of a privileged household in very vivid terms, and with a delicate combination of sympathy and irony. The head of the household is Unni (Karamana), a man unreasonably pampered by his sisters and very nearly paralyzed by his fear of outside influences. When he grows terrified of rats, at the film's beginning, several are caught by the sisters, then brought to the river and slowly drowned. By the end of the film, the rats' plight has been closely equated with Unni's own.

title: 'EVENING PERFORMANCE,' END OF A MARRIAGE
description: In Josefina Molina's ''Evening Performance,'' two people whose long marriage is being annulled meet to discuss the situation and then proceed to talk it to death. She says: ''The children have become a burden to me - a wonderful burden, but a burden.'' He says: ''I say that love can exist at first sight.'' She says: ''I've done nothing for myself. I've done it all for others.'' And a fortune teller, who also figures briefly in the proceedings, declares: ''Marriage always leaves its mark on the children.''

title: Sitting on The Siding
description: Neither talks nor trains moved last week as strikes against the Metro-North Commuter Railroad and N.J. Transit went into their third and fourth weeks respectively. New negotiations in both walkouts were scheduled for this week, but the mediator in one of them warned that ''it could be a long strike.''

title: Wisconsin Defeats Harvard for Title
description: Pat Flatley and Paul Houston scored two goals apiece to spark Wisconsin to a 6-2 victory over Harvard tonight and give the Badgers their fourth National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I hockey championship.

title: 25 Food Outlets Cited by City As Violators of Sanitary Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 25 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. The department also named eight that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and three that were closed for having failed to do so.

title: SCIENCE FOR YOUTHS
description: STARTING with this month's issue, the newsletter ''Stamp Fun,'' which is distributed by the United States Postal Service to about 60,000 stamp clubs, will be written by a Mamaroneck author whose work is known mostly by young science students.

title: No Headline
description: The Architect's Lot As an architect, I enjoy the knowledge that we are considered an elite profession (''Content With One's Odd Lot,'' by Marilyn Bethany, Feb. 6). My satisfaction is dampened by the further knowledge that relatively few people ever have the occasion to hire an architect, and even fewer will recognize an architectural work if they walk through it.

title: ONE MAN'S MEAD
description: MARGARET MEAD AND SAMOA The Making and Unmaking of an Anthropological Myth. By Derek Freeman. 379 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $20.

title: Future Events; Music, Comedy, Dancing
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Easter Lunch and Dansant April 3 - The Damon Runyon-Walter Winchell Cancer Fund, established in 1946 by Mr. Winchell in memory of his friend Mr. Runyon, will be the recipient of all the proceeds of a spring party and a lavish luncheon with wine at the Pierre. Festivities start with a cocktail reception at 12:30 P.M. in the Cotillion Room, to be followed by a lunch, fancy desserts and coffee. Then there will be dancing to music by Emery Davis and the Meyer Davis Orchestra in the Grand Ballroom, decorated with colorful Easter plants. Added to the daytime fete will be a fashion show of Joan Vass's spring and summer 1983 collection. The fund has awarded more than $50 million in research grants and fellowships to more than 700 young scientists, providing support to 80 new researchers last year alone. Mrs. H. Donald Sills is chairman of the event, which can accommodate 350 guests. Tickets are $65 from 582-5400.

title: 100% DEFENSE? HARDLY.
description: If President Reagan gets his way, we will soon embark on a major effort to develop an exotic and technologically innovative defense against nuclear attack - one that he suggests may be so effective as ''to give us the means of rendering nuclear weapons impotent and obsolete.'' As former scientific advisors for the Department of Defense, we have to wonder about the basis for such optimism.

title: WOULD A SPACE-AGE DEFENSE EASE TENSIONS OR CREATE THEM?
description: WASHINGTON IN the 1980 campaign, Ronald Reagan scored points by attacking Jimmy Carter for zigzags in dealing with the Soviet Union. As President, Mr. Reagan himself has oscillated at times between hardline and more moderate positions. But lately, in his crusade for a $239 billion defense budget, he has given vent to his natural inclination for tough talk, sounding echoes of the Cold War.

title: The Finger Points At Weehawken
description: It sometimes seems that those whom the fates would imprison they first put in office in Hudson County, New Jersey. The list of Hudson political figures charged with corruption in recent years grew to nearly a dozen last week with the indictment of Wally P. Lindsley, a former Mayor of Weehawken.

title: FOR FREDERICA VON STADE, A LYRIC VOICE HAS NOT BEEN A HANDICAP
description: Frederica von Stade, the American mezzo-soprano, is one of our most charming and aristicratic singers. She has sung in prestigious new productions all over the operatic world for the past decade, and she enjoys an active concert career, as well. She is also singing the part of Rosina in Rossini's ''Barbiere di Siviglia'' right now at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: DAMAGE REPORTS; Double Standard
description: The Federal General Services Administration plans to buy cars with bumpers that resist damage in 5-mile-per-hour collisions, rather than industry-minimum 2 1/2-m.p.h. bumpers. That makes sense: according to the auto insurance companies, tough bumpers save on maintenance bills and downtime, yet add little to a car's weight or fuel consumption.

title: BALTIMORE'S COUNCIL IS SAID TO BYPASS VOTERS
description: At a routine City Council meeting last month, a Councilman surprised his colleagues by resigning. Within 10 minutes the Council members had filled his seat with his wife, touching off a controversy.

title: Indulgent Weekends
description: Minds and bodies that thrill to ice cream, chocolate, the lore of wine, movies, writing, physical fitness, dancing, video games and ethnic folkways can indulge themselves openly in a series of theme weekends at Hyatt hotels across the United States.

title: COLLEGE BREAK ON THE BEACH
description: Four college-age lugs with the collective brains of a surfboard head for Fort Lauderdale in ''Spring Break,'' a movie in which leering and beer-drinking are everybody's favorite pursuits. Together, they attend a wet-T-shirt contest, a Teeny Weeny Bikini contest, and other, similar galas that take on a certain sameness very quickly and that constitute the film's only real events.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ATHENS
description: MARVINE HOWE is chief of the Athens bureau of The Times.

title: Robin Trawny Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Trawny of Camarillo, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Kristin Trawny, to Stephen Harold Steinhardt of Morristown, N.J., son of Vivian Steinhardt of Milburn, N.J., and Martin Steinhardt of Verona, N.J. The wedding is planned for May. The future bride's two previous marriages ended in divorce.

title: AGENCY AND CASINOS BATTLE OVER URBAN AID FUNDS
description: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission and the casino industry are engaged in a battle over control of millions of dollars in funds the casinos will soon be required to invest in city projects.

title: MOBILE HOMES IN JERSEY SELLING TO BETTER-OFF BUYERS
description: IN 1975, an engineer named Donald Brundage was the Mayor of S pottswood, N.J., a small community south of New Brunswick. One of h is problems was what to do with a swampy stretch of municipal land t hat was zoned for industry. Industry didn't want it.

title:
OPINION;
'72 NOVA, AUTO. PS, GD COND, GOT TO SEE
description: WHAT do you do when you have three cars, only two drivers, and a new-found driveway that warns, ''Three's a crowd.'' You sell one, of course. But which one? All three, regrettably, are over the hill but all three have been uncommonly faithful, especially during the lean years. And how do you justify your planned shameful act of treachery?

title: NO-STRINGS-ATTACHED PRIZES ARE CHANGING CREATIVE LIVES
description: For Leslie Maron Silko, a novelist, it meant having the time to work on a book that she hopes will appeal less to scholars than to people perusing the racks at supermarket checkout counters.

title: Data Bank; March 27, 1983
Treasures Return To Sistine Chapel
description: The tapestries had been hanging around for more than 400 years in Tunis, Constantinople, France -everywhere, it seemed, except the Sistine Chapel in Rome, where they were meant to hang. Last week, eight of the 10 works, designed by Raphael, came home for a week.

title: THE COMPANY IT KEEPS PUTS U.S. ON THE SPOT ONCE AGAIN
description: The capital continues to be caught up in the moral dilemma over El Salvador: Should the United States provide political, economic and military support to a leadership that is threatened by a Communist-backed insurgency, but whose record in legal and civil rights practices is, in Secretary of State George P. Shultz's words, ''indefensible''?

title:
OPINION;
MALPRACTICE COSTS ARE PERIL TO HEALTH
description: IT is easy to pass off the exhorbitant and frequently onerous costs of malpractice with the public deception that ''all doctors are rich,'' or the subtler expression of annoyance, ''Well, they'll just pass on the costs.'' Even if these simplistic observations were true - and they are not - the practical consequences of the continued escalation of malpractice-insurance rates should trouble us all.

title: NAVY BLUE: TRIED AND TRUE
description: Navy blue, as the name suggests, entered men's wear as a military uniform. (''Bell-bottom trousers, coat of navy blue; I love a sailor and he loves me too,'' the land-bound ladies used to sing). Today, the color catches the eye wherever one goes - in the streets, men's clothing stores, corporate board rooms, international airports and among groups of nervous applicants waiting for job interviews. Navy blue, for better or worse, is the uniform of the civilian as much as it is of the service from which its name derives.

title: 'ANTIGONE' POSES TIMELESS QUERIES
description: THE playwright Jean Anouilh studied law, a discipline that is apparent in his reworking of Sophocles's classic, ''Antigone.'' Both the original and Anouilh's modernization tackle the philosophical questions revolving around the conflict between the rights of the individual and the needs of an ordered society. But Anouilh's legal mind has fashioned a play that is essentially a debate between young Antigone, King Oedipus's daughter, and her uncle, King Creon of Thebes. She argues for the necessary existence of moral law, while the politically expedient Creon takes a stand for the laws of state.

title: Borg's Finale in Monaco
description: Bjorn Borg, who has already announced his retirement from tennis at the age of 26, is expected to get one of the biggest ovations in the $300,000 Monte Carlo Open tournament, which begins tomorrow in Monaco. But that is because the Swedish-born Borg is the hometown favorite and chose to play his last tournament in the principality by the sea that has allowed him to keep most of his $17 million in earnings sheltered from taxes. ''I've been training hard because I don't want to spoil my finale, but I don't have the sufficient motivation to do as well as in the past,'' said Borg.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: ENGLEWOOD'S new Mayor, Steven R. Rothman, was invited to give television viewers a glimpse of his city -and himself - on ''Meet the Mayors,'' an interview program first telecast on March 17 and repeated last Monday and Wednesday.

title: BRIAN COSTELLO WILL MARRY ROSEMARIE HOLLIGER IN JUNE
description: Mr. Nad Mrs. Thomas R. Holliger of Wayne, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rosmarie Reeda Holliger, to Brian Costello, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald M. Costello of Pompton Plains, N.J.. A June wedding is planned at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title: THE PASSIONATE SOMNAMBULIST
description: VERY MUCH A LADY, The Untold Story of Jean Harris and Dr. Herman Tarnower. By Shana Alexander. Illustrated. 316 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $17.50

title: INDIAN SPICE AND FIRE
description: FOR years food trend starters have been predicting that the next foreign cuisine to be ''discovered'' by Americans en masse would be Indian. It hasn't happened yet, but if all Indian restaurants were up to the standards set by Mayur it might. Mayur, a five-month-old establishment in Fairfield, swells the ranks of Indian restaurants in Connecticut to, at last count, three.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in:; BEDFORD
description: IF the Town of Bedford in northern Westchester County has one symbol, it is probably the Bedford Oak o n Route 22, which some say is 400 years old. A few years ago, a developer filed for permission to build a house n ext to the open field where the aged tree stands alone. Concern t hat sewage might damage its roots touched off a fund-raising effort t hat amassed $51,000 from contributors as far away as California.

title: Katherine G. Kiliani and Mark S. Bliss Will Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Taylor Kiliani of Pittsburgh of the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Greening Kiliani, to Mark Sawyer Bliss of New York. He is a son of George Donald Bliss of Tarrytown, N.Y., and Barbara M. Bliss of Sandisfield, Mass.

title: ENDING THE 'SUNSET YEARS' WITH ZIP
description: The ''golden years'' and the ''senior citizen'' were words that once worked for advertisers aiming their wares at the older crowd. But one generation's euphemism is another's problem, and Madison Avenue has discovered that today's older folk like to think of the ''vital years'' ahead - not of a ''golden sunset.'' Thus, advertisers increasingly are lumping the Social Security set together with those considerably younger and are showing them all living the good and active life.

title: On the Stand Again
description: Norman Mailer seems to be better at creating characters than testifying for them. Last week the novelist took the stand as character witness for Richard L. Stratton, who was on trial in Maine. Mr. Stratton asserted that he was not participating in the drug trade, as charged, but gathering research for a novel on it. Mr. Mailer testified that Mr. Stratton was a friend and a writer. He gave simlilar testimony last year at the murder trial of another acquaintance, John Henry Abbott, who, like Mr. Stratton, was convicted.

title: Mrs. John A Galvin of East Dennis, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Patricia Maree Galvin, to Lewis John Fuiks Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fuiks of Wardsboro, Vt. The wedding is planned for Sept. 10.
description: The future bride, daughter also of the late John Galvin, is the hiring coordinator at the New York law firm of donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine.

title: EVERYONE'S TRYING TO START THE NEW 'SILICON VALLEY'
description: CHICAGO WHEN the Minneapolis-based Control Data Corporation announced last August that together with nine other corporations it was seeking a location for a hightechnology research center, it found itself in the position of a wealthy widow the day after the funeral.

title: No Headline
description: The Feminine Mystique Plus 20 Betty Friedan's ''second stage'' is what some of us were not only talking about but also attempting to do 15 years ago ... with one important exception (''Twenty Years After the Feminine Mystique,'' Feb.27). Those of us who were both feminists and mothers of young children in the late 1960's tried various forms of shared child care and demanded significant contributions of time and energy from our husbands both in child care and in housework - this in the midst of a society that had scarcely any appreciation and certainly gave no tangible support to such enterprises. What happened? Many men ''helped,'' though the women still did more of the child care and housework. Still, we did not give up the notion that real equity was the goal. Many marriages of my contemporaries could not stand the strain, but many have survived.

title: RENOVATION PAYS
description: Since 1972, a 23-story office tower and an adjoining eight-story building have stood virtually empty in the rolling hills of Pearl River, N.Y., a Rockland County community about 35 minutes northwest of New York City. Recession and a succession of owners who somehow could not find the right market for the space kept it that way.

title: Miss Stearns Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Timothy Stearns of Ware, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Kelly McGivney Stearns, to Theodore Hayward Irwin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin of Essex Fells, N.J. Miss Stearns and her fiance are recent graduates of Bowdoin College. A June 18 wedding is planned.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Votes in the Congress table last Sunday incorrectly described a vote in the House.

title: Index; International
description: Gandhi daughter-in-law an- nounces opposition party 4 Mugabe says he'll finish the war Nkomo started 6 Somalis expecting new Ethiopian offensive 7 Soviet Union moves to improve train service 13 Worried by exiles, Haiti is shop- ping for arms 16 The U.S. and 12 other nations join to fight Caribbean pollution 16 Sandinist says U.S. seeks to oust the Nicaraguan Government 17 Margaret Papandreou warms to role as Greece's envoy 21 Government/Politics Baltimore City Council accused of bypassing voters 29 Reagan denounces Democratic budget plan 36 Ex-officials say military spend- ing not linked to strategy 37 Assembly approves test of film- ing court trials 43 Jersey and casinos battle over control of investment funds 44 General Around the Nation 22 Long Beach fights back from the brink of decay 22 Court specifies rights of foster children in Missouri 23 Massachusetts ending ban on Sunday sales today 25 Iowans debate jobs versus nu- clear bombs plant 27 New military vehicle to replace the jeep 28 Lie test expert ties '65 killing to F.B.I. informer 30 Fake professor shows that schools can be fooled 31 The urbane joys of spring stroll- ing on Madison Avenue 34 Suicide prevention program begun for female inmates 35 Defense lawyer seeks to portray Mafia as F.B.I. myth 39 Health/Science U.S. to launch search-and-rescue satellite 24 City defers closing of 10 pediatric centers 48 Arts/Entertainment ''Rise of David Levinsky'' staged by American Jewish Theater 52 Music: Debuts in review 54 ''The Black Stallion Returns,'' a sequel to '79 film 54 Style Students flock to Florida in spring rite 56 Obituaries John Bell Williams, former Gov- ernor of Mississippi 40

title: Back to Earth In Lebanon
description: Negotiating anything about Lebanon has always required a large dose of patience. Last week, round 24 of the negotiations to get Israeli forces out of Lebanon produced nothing to justify the optimism displayed a few days before by Israeli, Lebanese and American officials after talks in Washington.

title: MURDER MOST FOUL AND COMIC
description: CHRONICLE OF A DEATH FORETOLD, By Gabriel Garcia Marquez.Translated by Gregory Rabassa. 120 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10.95.

title: KORCHNOI'S BLOOPERS
description: In the Hoogoven International Tournament in Wijk-aan-Zee, the Netherlands - Viktor Korchnoi's last appearance before his quarter-final world championship candidates match with Lajos Portisch -the exchallenger blew hot and cold.

title:
OPINION;
SUBURBANITES UNDER SIEGE IN RACCOON UTOPIA
description: CHAUVINISTS of country living are facing yet another offensive unheard of by city dwellers. While urban occupants of high-rise condos and luxurious East Side apartments hustle along dark boulevards, wary of muggers lurking behind the next corner, and fear for their lives in subways and gypsy cabs, settlers in the wilds of Connecticut tangle with more ferocious adversaries.

title: Pinklon Thomas Stops Ratliff in the 10th Round
description: Pinklon Thomas, an unbeaten heavyweight from Philadelphia, stopped Alfonzo Ratliff of Chicago with 24 seconds left in their scheduled 10-round bout today.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, exhibition, at Clearwater, Fla. Craig Swan will start for the Mets, hoping to improve on spring outings in which he has yielded 28 hits and 19 runs in 111/3 innings. (Radio - WHN 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays, exhibition at the Superdome, New Orleans, 2:30 P.M. Doyle Alexander is scheduled to start for the Yankees. He is 2-0 in 12 innings, and has given up five hits and two runs, both earned. (Radio - WABC 770 2:30 P.M.).

title: SEAVER PITCHES 2 INNINGS, STRAINS THIGH
description: Tom Seaver was talking about raspberries, the edible kind, and could not repress a laugh. Seaver does not laugh too often in public; the laughter starts deep inside him and rises to a high-pitched giggle.

title: FOR OLD P.S. 135, A CLOUDY FUTURE
description: AN imposing 19th-century brownstone-and-brick school building now u sed as a community center in midtown Manhattan is the subject of a l ong-simmering dispute between the city and a coalition of East Side c ommunity groups.

title: DAMAGE REPORTS; Starving Poverty Law
description: The Legal Services Corporation, which is supposed to manage the national poverty law program, is itself impoverished. Instead of keeping pace with the growing number of poor people, law offices across the country are curtailing their activities or going out of business altogether because of Federal budget cuts.

title: MONMOUTH'S ELDERLY HELP THE ELDERLY
description: FREEHOLD More and more it is the elderly who are helping the elderly at Monmouth County's senior-citizen centers. Statistics compiled by the county's Office on Aging show that elderly volunteers, 85 percent of them women, contributed 103,340 hours of time at 14 centers last year.

title: U.S. AND 12 OTHER COUNTRIES SIGN PACT TO CURB CARIBBEAN POLLUTION
description: The United States and 12 other countries took a first step this week toward combating pollution in the Caribbean, signing a treaty committing them to protect the basin's marine environment.

title: TECHNOLOGY STILL A NOVICE IN CLASSROOMS
description: IN the few years since microcomputers came on the market on a grand scale educators have been trying to meet the needs that the hightechnology field has created. They have established, in short order, specialized high-technology high schools in North Carolina and California, new graduate engineering programs in microelectronics in New York, technical-school programs in robotics in Illinois and Michigan and complex software programs in geometry for 5-year-olds in Texas. Profound changes in courses, curriculums and teachers have also taken place at institutions not traditionally known for rapid change.

title: Dozens Are Said to Die In Iranian Quake
description: Dozens of people were killed in an earthquake northeast of Teheran on Friday, the Iranian press agency said today.

title: LOUISVILLE AND NORTH CAROLINA ST. REACH FINAL FOUR
description: When Jim Master's soft, 12-foot jump shot went through the basket with one second left in regulation time, Kentucky had tied Louisville, 62-62, and Louisville could have folded. Instead, Louisville's clutching, pressing defense and recordbreaking accuracy helped it run off the first 14 points in overtime, and the Cardinals raced to an 80-68 victory.

title: WHERE PUBLIC POLICY AND MORALITY MEET
description: To the Editor:

title: Bonn Seizes Arsonist
description: A man was arrested early today after he broke into a British Army camp supply center and set fire to two military trucks, a police spokesman said. He was not identified.

title: U.S. TO LAUNCH SATELLITE TO AID IN DETECTING DOWNED PLANES
description: An American search-and-rescue satellite to be launched Monday will join a Soviet satellite that is already saving lives by detecting downed planes and ships in trouble, space officials say.

title: FOR A HAPPIER LIFE WITH THE COMPUTER
description: "'I've got computer elbow," proudly reported a friend whose office r ecently put in its first word processor. He's proud because he's l earned to use the machine, and learned to finagle lots of time on i t. But his elbow does hurt, and maybe the pain is related to his c omputer use.

title: August Wedding For Karen Perez
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Koenig of St. Helena, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Lea Koenig Perez, to Peter Paul Miller 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller Jr. of Swarthmore, Pa.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: PASSOVER, which marks the Jews' exodus from Egypt 3,400 years ago, begins tomorrow night. One of the most important items in the Passover dinner, or seder, is the matzoh, a flat, unleavened bread. It is unleavened because the Jews, in their flight, did not have time to allow their bread to rise.

title: SOVIET TOLD BY U.S. ABM PACT STANDS
description: Administration officials said today that the United States had notified the Soviet Union that the new research in missile defense announced by President Reagan would not violate or abrogate the 11-year-old Soviet-American treaty limiting each side's antiballistic missile defense.

title: NEWS OF PONTIAC'S 2-SEATER
description: PONTIAC people were in New York last week to offer some further i nformation on the two-seat Fiero that will go on sale in the fall. T he mid-engined P-car will have a steel ''space-frame'' that would bed riveable even without the plastic body, and the flexible body itselfa ttaches with only 39 clips.

title: Steven Alan Sider Engaged To Marlene Susan Posaner
description: Mr. and Mrs. Heinz Posaner of Rockville, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marlene Susan Posaner, to Steven Alan Sider, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Sider of Eastchester, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: Holman Remembers
description: The basketball community continues to shower Nat Holman with one award after another, and he must have as many honors as he has years. This evening, during an intermission in the semifinals of the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden, Holman's contributions to college basketball will be celebrated with the presentation of the Kodak/ NIT Man of the Year Award.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Toronto Blue Jays, exhibition, at St. Petersburg, Fla., 1:30 P.M. Ed Lynch, scheduled to start for the Mets, is contesting with Rick Ownbey and Scott Holman for the fourth and fifth starting spots in the rotation.

title: ARAFAT PUTS OFF MEETING WITH KING HUSSEIN
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat, delayed his long-awaited meeting with King Hussein of Jordan today and went instead to Saudi Arabia to confer with King Fahd, apparently about how to respond to the American Middle East peace move.

title: CHARGES AGAINST 7 BLACKS ARE LIFTED BUT THERE'S NO PEACE IN MONTGOMERY
description: The dismissal last week of criminal charges against seven of 11 blacks accused of beating and trying to kill two white police officers has temporarily eased racial tensions here. But it has not brought peace to Montgomery.

title: ORDERS OF MACHINE TOOLS RISE
description: New orders for domestic machine tools improved modestly in February from January, but were down sharply from those in February 1982, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association said yesterday.

title: SOVIET EXPERTS INVITED TO JOIN A CARNEGIE INQUIRY ON CRISES
description: The Carnegie Corporation, one of the country's oldest and most influential foundations, is asking leading Soviet experts to join Americans in searching for ways to avoid peace-threatening crises and the danger of nuclear conflict.

title: Antimissile Protesters Packing Jails Out West
description: About 300 activists arrested at an MX missile site packed jails as far away as Arizona today, staging hunger strikes and trying to clog the court system in protest against nuclear weapons.

title: KNICK SURGE MASKS ROBINSON'S SLUMP
description: Len (Truck) Robinson is in another shooting slump, much the way he was the first 36 games of the season. But now, with the Knicks' winning and contending for the playoffs, his lack of offense has gone almost unnoticed.

title: OPERA: MET AUDITIONS
description: THE Metropolitan Opera National Council held a concert of the finalists from its regional auditions at the Metropolitan Opera yesterday afternoon, presenting 11 young singers chosen from 2,000 who auditioned across the country.

title: Whalers 5, Bruins 1
description: HARTFORD (AP) - Greg Millen made 34 saves as the Whalers ended Boston's four-game winning streak and won for the first time in eight games. Millen made many acrobatic saves.

title: STATE CROWN WON BY BISHOP LOUGHLIN
description: After Bishop Loughlin's 102-89 victory over North Babylon for the large-school division title of the New York State basketball championships, the losing coach agreed that the better team had won.

title: Books Of The Times
description: PHY. By Andre Le Vot. Translated by William Byron. 393 pages. Doubleday. $19.95.

title: Saudi Contract Rules
description: Foreign companies awarded contracts for development projects in Saudi Arabia now must give at least 30 percent of the work to Saudi contractors and use Saudi banking, insurance and other services, the Saudi press agency said today.

title: Surge Seen In Housing
description: An interest rate war is ahead, and it could spark a ''major housing recovery'' with cheaper mortgages, according to Donald I. Hovde, an Under Secretary for the Department of Housing and Urban Development. He said banks and savings and loans are ''flushed with money'' since Congress changed banking regulations last December.

title: RALLIES BY RANGERS DEFEAT CAPITALS, 5-4
description: The Rangers rallied twice from two-goal deficits and defeated the Washington Capitals, 5-4, last night, scoring two goals 88 seconds apart early in the last period at Madison Square Garden.

title: ROSA PERSIN
description: Rosa Persin, the founder of the Uptown Gallery, which she operated from 1930 until it closed in 1949, died Friday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.

title: The Greenbelt Debate
description: B loodroot Valley, Basket Willow Swamp, the Isle of Meadows -the place names sounded far from urban at a hearing last week on the Staten Island greenbelt, proposed as the city's largest parkland.

title: Houston Travelers Aid Helping Local Homeless
description: The Travelers Aid Society here, which traditionally has focused on helping newcomers find emergency housing, is now doing the same for homeless local families.

title: GOLDIN CRITICAL OF BREAKDOWN OF CITY'S BUSES
description: New York City's buses break down four times as often as those on the streets of Los Angeles and Chicago, according to an audit released yesterday. But the Transit Authority responded that the three cities were not comparable.

title: NOT AT BEST, CHAMPION ADMITS
description: At the final bell, Lucien Rodriguez quickly lifted both arms into the air, almost as if he thought he had won the decision in his heavyweight title fight with Larry Holmes today. But the French challenger's arms rose only slightly above his head, then he quickly lowered them, as if he were afraid Holmes might notice.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Long-Term Rates Last Week (In Percent) Tax-Exempt Bonds* 9.15 An index of yields for long-term A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer. Aa Utility Bonds* 12.13 Salomon Brothers' estimate for new long-term issues Treasury Bonds* 10.71 Short-Term Rates Federal Funds* 8.75 The rate for overnight loans among financial institutions.

title: FOUNDERS TO QUIT A POST AT HEWLETT-PACKARD CO.
description: William R. Hewlett and David Packard, founders of the Hewlett-Packard Company, are stepping down from the concern's executive committee.

title: Del Monte Product Line Switches to Marschalk
description: Marschalk has been assigned all of the Del Monte specialty grocery products previously at McCann-Erickson, San Francisco, a sister agency in the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: DANCE: 'RUNE' REVIVED BY MERCE CUNINGHAM
description: MERCE CUNNINGHAM'S dances often seem cut from the same bolt of material, as if they were moments in a continuing meditation, sometimes grave and sometimes teasing, and not the result of some lightning inspiration. Interestingly enough, none of the four dances performed by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company on Tuesday in the City Center came to a formal end. The curtain went down each time on dancers moving, as if they were prepared to move all night, from one dance through another.

title: POISON SUSPECTED
description: At least 250 Arab girls in five schools in the occupied West Bank fell ill today, suffering from dizziness, headaches, fainting spells, stomach pains and other symptoms that local residents believed were induced by some kind of poison in the classrooms. Several Israeli soldiers in the area were also affected.

title: FULL DOCKET AWAITS SPRING CLEANING
description: The Supreme Court can usually be counted on to stir back to life along with the daffodils and tulip magnolia trees of Washington's early spring.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avon Products Inc. has named W. Thomas Knight group vice president-general counsel and secretary.

title: Miss Farber Marries P.J. Davis, a Broker
description: Cynthia Rachelle Farber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin G. Farber of Wyckoff, N.J., was married yesterday to Philip Jay Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Davis of Baltimore. Rabbi Martin Freedman performed the ceremony at the Preakness Hills Country Club in Wayne, N.J.

title: MAYORAL CANDIDATE FACES ANGRY CROWD AT CHICAGO CHURCH
description: Representative Harold Washington and former Vice President Walter F. Mondale were greeted with boos and jeers today as they sought to attend a Palm Sunday service at a Roman Catholic church.

title: Cable Penetration Up
description: The latest report from A.C. Nielsen is that cable televison is now used in 37.2 percent of all American homes, which means more than 31.1 million households for February 1983. That is a growth of 7.4 million households, or 28 percent, from February 1982.

title: LONG SHOTS HELP PUT N.C. STATE IN FINAL 4
description: When people speak of Dereck Whittenburg's ''high percentage shot,'' the ''high'' usually refers to the altitude of the ball.

title: Lendl Is Winner In Milan Tennis
description: Ivan Lendl edged Kevin Curren, 5-7, 6-3, 7-6, today and won a $365,000 tennis tournament.

title: IN ASSAM, THE KILLINGS ABATE BUT THE FEARS LINGER
description: Skeletons are still scattered over the dry, flat rice field where more than 1,000 men, women and children were slaughtered last month by a mob of tribespeople who attacked them with guns, spears and bows and arrows.

title: NEW YORK AREA IS RECEIVING CARP FROM TOXIN-TAINTED MICHIGAN BAY
description: Hundreds of thousands of pounds of carp from Saginaw Bay in Michigan, samples of which have been found to contain residues of the chemical dioxin, are annually shipped to markets in New York, Chicago and other Northern cities.

title: Ex-Sergeant Says U.S.  Wanted to Kill Barbie
description: A former Army sergeant says United States agents wanted to kill Klaus Barbie, the Nazi Gestapo officer, rather than turn him over to French intelligence after World War II, The Dayton Daily News reported today.

title: Child, 3, Is Killed In New Haven Fire
description: A 3-year-old boy died and two other children were critically injured early today in a fire that is suspected to be arson in a three-family house here, officials said.

title: CAMDEN NEIGHBORHOOD IS UNIFIED BY DEATH OF BOY IN A 'RACIAL' CASE
description: Integration came no more easily to the corner of this city known as Cramer Hill than to any other part of America. But over the last 10 or 15 years, come it did. Blacks moved beside Germans, Hispanic people next to the Irish, and though some people fought, others accepted, even befriended, their new neighbors.

title: Velasquez on Top
description: Jorge Velasquez rode his second stakes winner in two days today, taking Balboa Native from off the pace to a half-length victory in the $200,000 Louisiana Derby at the Fair Grounds.

title: KILLINGS DOWN IN EL SALVADOR
description: Since Pope John Paul II's visit here early this month, the number of political murders in this country has dropped dramatically, a top Salvadoran churchman said today.

title: REBOUND IN PROFITS IS DEBATED
description: Business profits, widely regarded as a ready barometer of the pulse of an economy, recently have been a cause for alarm, particularly among those who would like to see increased investment and growth.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: OIL CUTS LEAD EXPERTS TO SEEK AID
description: Less than two weeks after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries cut prices by $5 a barrel, some oil exporting nations are starting to line up for money from the International Monetary Fund and commercial banks.

title: LEGISLATURE VOTES NEW YORK BUDGET FOR FISCAL YEAR '84
description: The Legislature approved a 1984 tate budget early today calling for $220 million in added programs, but thousands fewer layoffs, than Governor Cuomo's original proposal.

title: U.S. OFFICERS REPORT A BUILDUP BY CUBA
description: United States naval officers say they are concerned by what they view as a steady expansion of Cuba's conventional military power in the last two years, with the Soviet Union as its arms supplier and paymaster.

title: 'WAR ON NICARAGUA'
description: Congress should declare war on the Government of Nicaragua and thereby preserve the Constitution.

title: AT A BORDER CAMP IN HONDURAS, ANTI-SANDINISTS ARE WARY OF VISIT
description: Nicaraguans described as insurgents fighting to overthrow the Sandinist Government in Managua appear to be operating from a camp in the hills above this hamlet near the border.

title: STEARNS ON DISABLED LIST, SEAVER AILING
description: The Mets opened the final week of spring training today with medical developments that suggested early-season trouble: John Stearns, the No. 1 catcher, was placed on the disabled list and Tom Seaver, the No.1 pitcher, was nursing a strained left thigh.

title: WATER CONTAMINATED BY PESTICIDE SPURS GROWING CONCERN IN FLORIDA
description: State officials and environmentalists are becoming increasingly concerned about the growing number of sites where ground water and drinking water have been found contaminated with Temik, a highly toxic pesticide once used by many citrus farmers.

title: JAPANESE ART OF AUTOMATION
description: With an orange light blinking and a tinny speaker blaring a John Philip Sousa march to warn the unwary, a driverless forklift truck goes mindlessly about its business of picking up loads of formed metal sheets, fresh from stamping machines, and carrying them about 50 feet to where they will start becoming Honda cars, vans and light trucks.

title: Koch Loses Bid For Skiing Title
description: Gunde Svan of Sweden won his second straight race today, a 30-kilometer event, in the finale of the World Cup cross-country ski season.

title: N.I.T. Is Now 'Fun' For DePaul's Meyer
description: Ray Meyer had taken DePaul to the National Invitation Tournament seven times between 1944 and 1966, winning it in 1945 after finishing second to St. John's in 1944, but this time his feeling was different.

title: 3 Rare Crocodiles Reported Missing From Zoo in Florida
description: Three dangerous, rare crocodiles are missing and believed stolen from a zoo pool where they were being held while a new home was built, zoo officials said Saturday.

title: Belo Set to Buy Gaylord TV Outlet
description: Officials of the A.H. Belo Corporation say they have signed a letter of intent to purchase New Orleans television station WVUE.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA ROUTS MRS. LLOYD
description: Martina Navratilova said it ''was pretty close to as good as I can play,'' and Chris Evert Lloyd did not argue. ''She really cleaned my clock,'' Mrs. Lloyd told a Madison Square Garden crowd of 13,244 yesterday, after having been beaten, 6-2, 6-0, by the top-seeded Miss Navratilova for the $80,000 first prize in the Virginia Slims of New York tennis championships.

title: ISLANDERS TRUMPH OVER PENGUINS, 4 TO 1
description: What Randy Carlyle had to say is what the Islanders - and their fans - have waited all season to hear. ''If you ask me,'' said the Penguins' defenseman, ''those are the Islanders of old.'' Admittedly, the Penguins may not be the National Hockey League's best judges of play. They are only a week away from summer vacation, having finished well out of the playoff picture. But in New York's 4-l victory over the Penguins tonight, the Islanders displayed the kind of form that had brought them three consecutive Stanley Cups.

title: MOMENT OF DECISION DRAWS NEAR ON MITCHELL-LAMA TAX BREAKS
description: The Board of Estimate is approaching a difficult decision on the monthly payments of the 46,000 Mitchell-Lama housing tenants in New York City.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: SOME LAWMAKERS MAKE HAY, OTHERS TRY HORSEPLAY AS BUDGET IS AWAITED
description: Governor Cuomo was so excited about the Senate approval of his budget at 12:40 this morning that he bounded upstairs from the second floor and strode into the Senate chamber to shake the Senate majority leader's hand.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Computervision Corp. said it had completed the acquisition of Cambridge Interactive Systems Ltd. of Cambridge, England, and its affiliated marketing organization, Applied Graphics Systems B.V. of Rotterdam, the Netherlands; terms were not disclosed.

title: News Analysis
description: They are still searching for the ''new man'' of socialism in Mozambique, and seeking to rear him, too, on the beaches of the Seychelles. The worker-peasant alliance is still, in theory, a guiding force in Angola.
