And, in the northern Nigerian town of Zaria last week, the college students of one of Africa's most capitalist nations are boning up on the class struggle at a seminar devoted to the man who started it all: Karl Marx.

title: DESPITE RECORD DOW, TURNOVER IS RESTRAINED
description: SEVERAL leading market indicators set new highs last week, but the excitement - after 7 1/2 months of rising stock prices - was somewhat restrained.

title: MAYOR SAYS U.S. SHOULD INSPECT FISH
description: With consumption of carp reaching its peak with the Jewish holiday of Passover that begins tonight, consumers have no way of knowing whether the fish they purchase contains dioxin. The origin of the carp usually cannot be determined, and no one has been regularly testing the fish for dioxin.

title: FEWER ISSUES IN WEEK
description: The Treasury market this week can concentrate on distributing last week's note and bond issues. The only financings scheduled are the regular Monday auctions of three- and six-month bills.

title: WATSON WINS RACE
description: John Watson wheeled a McLaren from near the back of the field today to an impressive victory in the Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach.

title: Washington Watch; Ocean Depots For Mariners
description: WASHINGTON THE Commerce Department, which a few weeks ago announced its intention to seek a private-industry buyer for the Government's weather satellites, has further plans for making certain services a business proposition.

title: Marceau to Lead Class
description: An advanced mime class for professional actors, dancers and mimes will be led by Marcel Marceau beginning Tuesday at the Actors and Directors Lab, 412 West 42d Street.

title: VICTOR E. ROCKHILL
description: Victor E. Rockhill, retired president of the Chase International Investment Corporation and a former executive vice president of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, died of cancer Friday at his home in Aquebogue, L.I. He was 73 years old.

title: DRUG SQUAD TELL OF SUCCESS IN USING PROFILE
description: Sgt. Skip Pearson and his smuggling squad of the Dade County police have been hot on the trail of drug smugglers at Miami International Airport for six years.

title: U.S. SAYS ANDROPOV FALSELY DEPICTED MILITARY PROPOSAL
description: The United States accused Yuri V. Andropov today of making a ''false allegation'' in contending that the Reagan Administration sought military domination over the Soviet Union.

title: ISRAEL NEEDS PEACE, NOT ADDITIONAL LAND
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Of Birthday Cakes, Real and Imaginary

title: Ozan Marsh Displays Pianism of Earlier Era
description: Ozan Marsh, who presented a piano recital Wednesday night in Alice Tully Hall, is an intriguing musician, if not entirely a convincing one. He is little known in New York, though he has an international career.

title: PRIZED ABSTRACT PAINTS U.S. PORTRAIT IN STATISTICS
description: Americans are eating more beef but fewer eggs. Church membership is up, but so is the divorce rate. About 98 percent of all American households own at least one television set. American women spend nearly $4 billion a year on cosmetics.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: In a college basketball game, a player from Team A with the ball is fouled, not in the act of shooting, and this puts Team A in the bonus situation. The referee, instead of sending the player to the foul line, mistakenly lets Team A inbound the ball and score a field goal. Team B then inbounds and also scores a field goal, at which point the mistake is realized. What is the ruling on Team A's field goal?

title: DETROIT IS WINNER
description: Detroit captured the team title at the 56th annual Golden Gloves National Tournament of Champions Saturday. Jesse Lopez of Hood River, Ore., got the biggest ovation when he won the 132-pound title despite a broken bone in his right hand.

title: Thousands March in Denmark To Protest Nuclear Missiles
description: Thousands of Danes marched here today in protest against the nuclear arms race and the planned deployment of new medium-range nuclear missiles in Western Europe.

title: HOW A YUGOSLAV COMPANY BUILT AN INTERNATIONAL MARKET
description: In 1972, Kenneth D. Kaunda, the President of Zambia, faced a crisis. He had called a conference of nonaligned nations for Lusaka, Zambia's capital, and with just four months to go, there was no place for the delegates to meet.

title: Lesotho Says Pretoria Attacked Border Post
description: Lesotho said today that an armed group from South Africa suffered about 20 dead or wounded in an attack on a paramilitary barracks on the southern Lesotho border on Saturday.

title: Sabres 6, Nordiques 6
description: BUFFALO (UPI) - Third-period goals by Andre Savard, Mike Ramsey and Dale McCourt, who scored the equalizer with less than two minutes to go, enabled the Sabres to gain the tie.

title: State's Borrowing Plans Outlined for 2d Quarter
description: Edward V. Regan, New York State Comptroller, has announced a tentative schedule of borrowings by the state and various agencies for the second quarter.

title: The U.N. Today; March 28, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Legal Subcommittee of the Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Large Diesel Fuel Spill Contained in Mississippi
description: Thousands of gallons of diesel fuel spilled into the Bowie River after a pump fell apart, but crews contained most of the oil today.

title: Final Four For No.31
description: SYRACUSE FIRST there was Kevin Williams of St. John's saying that Georgia would be no threat if St. John's played its normal game. Then there was Sam Perkins of North Carolina saying he didn't know the name of Georgia's conference.

title: WE TOLD THEM SO
description: A white elephant is stalking Europe -the specter of one of the costliest economic blunders ever made by a serenely smug group of detenteniks.

title: WALT MICHAELS SAYS HE'S RELAXED NOW
description: FOR more than six weeks, Walt Michaels had avoided the questions. But now the Jets' former coach, husky in a gray T-shirt and green pants, answered an unexpected knock on the door of his vacation home that overlooks Shickshinny Lake not too far from where he grew up in the coal miners' town of Swoyersville.

title: Bulgarians Assert West Inspired Article on Pope
description: Bulgaria's official press agency accused Western intelligence services today of inspiring a report in The New York Times that the K.G.B., the Soviet Union's intelligence service, and the Bulgarian secret service were behind an attempt to kill Pope John Paul II.

title: Just the Facts
description: W.C. Fields may not have been fond of Philadelphia, but as sports towns go, the City of Brotherly Love is the best. So says Bob McMahon of Media, Pa., who earns his livelihood as a stockbroker but whose heart and mind are in sports. McMahon amasses questions and answers and has his collaborator, Jay Leopold, a freshman at the University of Pennsylvania, run them through his computer. Their studies are a labor of love, and McMahon figures the statistics covering the last decade that they will publish in book form this spring will barely pay expenses.

title: Kerry Eberhard Marries Alfredo Brener of Mexico
description: Kerry Ardra Eberhard, daughter of Sandi Eberhard of New York, Millbrook, N.Y., and Acapulco, Mexico, and the late Frank Powel Eberhard, was married yesterday to Alfredo Brener, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pablo Brener of Mexico City. Rabbi Arthur Schneier performed the ceremony at the Park East Synagogue.

title: PRESIDENTIAL PANEL SAYS SOCIETY HAS AN 'ETHICAL OBLIGATION' TO PROVIDE EQUITABLE ACCESS TO HEALTH CARE
description: A Presidential commission said today that society had an ''ethical obligation to insure equitable access to health care'' for all Americans, even at a time of budget cutbacks and fiscal austerity.

title: SENEGALESE 'JOM'
description: IN Senegal, where Ababacar Samb Makharam's ''Jom'' was made, the Wolof word of the title means something akin to ''courage'' or ''dignity.'' The film helps define the word, which has no exact English equivalent, through a series of tales related by a griot, or storyteller. Modern characters who are engaged in a strike against a local industrialist are given courage and inspiration by the griot's historical anecdotes. All of this is presented by Mr. Makharam through vivid pageantry, and with a passion and intensity that reflect considerable jom of his own.

title: Pros Rebuffed by I.O.C.
description: The International Olympic Committee said today that it would not change present rules defining amateurism, a decision likely to effect dozens of professional soccer and ice-hockey players who had hoped to participate in the 1984 Games.

title: TO THE CITY'S HUNGRY, FROM FIRMS WITH FOOD TO SPARE
description: To the Editor:

title: Israelis Held by P.L.O.  Moved Out of Lebanon
description: Eight Israeli soldiers being held by the Palestine Liberation Organization in Lebanon have been moved to another Middle East country because the P.L.O. had information that Israel was planning a military operation to free them, an official Palestinian source said today.

title: Easter in the Desert
description: ''I'm a religious person,'' says Raymond J. Mulligan, ''and I couldn't think of letting Easter Sunday go by without an opportunity to hold a sunrise service.'' Nor did the sponsors of the Nabisco Dinah Shore Invitational golf tournament want to let the holiday be overloooked. The result is that beginning at 6:30 A.M. Sunday as many as 600 persons, including professional women golfers, amateur players, caddies, volunteers, tournament officials and early-arriving spectators, will participate in a nondenominational service that will greet the desert's Easter sunrise over the San Jacinto Mountains.

title: TWO-THIRDS OF CITY'S CABARETS VIOLATING THE FIRE SAFETY LAW
description: Three years after a fire-safety law took effect covering New York City's nightclubs, more than two-thirds have failed to comply fully with the law.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: NEW ROOM

title: TO THE CITY'S HUNGRY, FROM FIRMS WITH FOOD TO SPARE
description: To the Editor:

title: Head of Del Webb Changes Emphasis
description: For most of the two years that Robert K. Swanson has been running the Del E. Webb Corporation, the leisure-time and real estate company has had the air of an auction barn. During that period, the company raised $170 million to ease a brush with bankruptcy by selling hotels and casinos.

title: Triplet Has Heart Surgery
description: Christy Jones, the smallest of triplets born Thursday in Little Rock, was in stable condition today after undergoing surgery to repair a heart valve, officials at St. Vincent Hospital said. The babies' parents, Bruce and Dana Jones, had expected twins. They said the infants were about two-and-a-half months' premature when they were delivered.

title: The Hartford Offers Mozart and Mahler
description: The Hartford Symphony Orchestra, a child of the Depression years, came to Carnegie Hall on Friday night, grown and seeming to be in good health. Born in 1934 and nurtured early in life by Federal relief agencies, the orchestra gradually weaned itself from Government control and survived its subsequent disbanding during World War II.

title: U.S. Ties Austria In World Hockey
description: Bill Gillian scored at 11:58 of the final period to save the United States from its first setback and tie Austria, 3-3, in the Group B world hockey championship today.

title: HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL PLAYERS TASTE STARDOM
description: To experience the high point of a lifetime at age 17, may, in the long run, be a mixed blessing, but for a senior in high school playing in the state basketball championships here this weekend, it feels like winning a million dollars, landing on the moon and being a rock 'n' roll star, all at once.

title: Theft Suspect Said To Swallow Ring
description: A man charged with stealing a diamond ring from a Merrick jewelry store has also been accused of swallowing the ring while being booked at a police station, Nassau County authorities said.

title: Elvira an Ideal Figaro In Met's 'Barbiere'
description: There were some handsome new voices in the Metropolitan Opera's current production of ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia'' on Thursday night. Pablo Elvira made an ideal Figaro.

title: BROOKS'S LONELY STRUGGLE TO MAKE HIS SYSTEM GO
description: HERB BROOKS lives alone in a suburban hotel room, a dozen or so miles from the rink in Rye, N.Y., where the New York Rangers practice. At the rink, the Rangers' head coach shares with his two assistants a tiny office built like a closet at the far end of a barren, drafty second-floor room. Unless the team has an early flight for a road trip, each day's work begins for Brooks with a walk, in his skates, across the black rubber floor of that attic-like room and down a staircase to the ice.

title: The Banks' 'folly' on withholding
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Short Operas Staged In World Premieres
description: Of two short operas given world premiere stagings this weekend by Golden Fleece Ltd., David Macbride's ''The Pond in a Bowl'' was by far the more interesting. This 1980 composition, which Mr. Macbride describes as a ''love story based on Chinese poems,'' is exquisitely scored for a small chamber orchestra, soprano and tenor.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Royal Shakespeare's Return

title: SHIFTS ON SEA RESEARCH PANEL TIED TO G.O.P. UNIT BY MEMO
description: Ten scientists were dropped from a nonpartisan offshore research advisory committee after the Republican National Committee advised the Interior Department that they were not acceptable, Senate aides said.

title: Vatican Bank is Target
description: Eighty international banks that lost $300 million when Italy's largest private bank, the Banco Ambrosiano, collapsed last year are trying to recover some of their losses from the Vatican bank, according to a press report here today.

title: POSITIVE ASPECTS OF GUILT
description: THE real problem with guilt nowadays, said P.L. Travers, is that we h ave trivialized it. ''Guilt is all too easily dismissed,'' said the c reator of Mary Poppins in a telephone interview from London. ' 'People don't try for absolution - they just try to forget it, and y ou can't just forget it.''

title: John Richardson, 60, Hughes Aircraft Chief
description: John H. Richardson, president of the Hughes Aircraft Company, died today in his home after a long illness, company officials said. He was 60 years old.

title: FED'S VIEW ON RATES AWAITED
description: When the Federal Open Market Committee meets this week, it is expected to decide how far, if at all, interest rates should be raised to combat faster-than-desired growth of the nation's money supply.

title: Ophra Yerushelmi Plays Y Piano Program
description: The clear highlight of a concert Thursday night by the pianist Ophra Yerushelmi at the 92d Street Y was a collaborative effort with the radio personality Robert J. Lurtsema. The two teamed up for a defiantly hammy rendition of Liszt's rarely heard ''Leonore,'' an aptly described ''melodrama'' for speaker and piano.

title: COOK LEADS BY A STROKE WITH 71 FOR 210
description: John Cook, the 25-year-old former United States Amateur champion, led Bobby Clampett, who is only 22, by one shot today after the third round of the $700,000 Tournament Players Championship. Vance Heafner, who is 28, stood another stroke back in third place.

title: Devils Bow to Flyers
description: Ron Flockhart and Bill Barber scored 57 seconds apart in the first period to lead the Philadelphia Flyers to a 4-1 victory over the New Jersey Devils in the National Hockey League tonight.

title: Poles Seek To Defer Payments
description: Polish officials meeting here with Western creditors banks have formally proposed a debt rescheduling agreement that would defer repayment of credits due over the next several years, diplomatic sources said here today.

title: REAGAN'S WRECKAGE
description: Whether or not Ronald Reagan's economic manipulations bear fruit, he will leave America with a fundamental and devastating legacy: the wreckage of five decades of public policy aimed at creating a more equitable society. Already the consequences of his Presidency can be seen in rising infant-mortality rates, declining college enrollments, a widening gulf between the incomes of white and black families.

title: STAGE: NEIL SIMON'S BRIGHTON BEACH'
description: AFTER having seen ''Brighton Beach Memoirs,'' at the Alvin, one can only have positive feelings about its author, Neil Simon. In this flat-out autobiographical memory play, a portrait of the writer as a Brooklyn teen-ager in 1937, Mr. Simon makes real progress toward an elusive longtime goal: he mixes comedy and drama without, for the most part, either force-feeding the jokes or milking the tears. It's happy news that one of our theater's slickest playwrights is growing beyond the well-worn formulas of his past.

title: DR. MILTON HOPKINS
description: Dr. Milton Hopkins, a former editor in chief of college textbooks at Holt, Rinehart & Winston, publishers, and a Long Island historian, died of a heart attack Friday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhasset, L.I.

title: Deputy's Stepson Is Arrested In Killing of Coast Policeman
description: The 16-year-old stepson of a San Diego County sheriff's deputy was arrested today in connection with the Feb. 20 slaying of a police officer, Police Chief Bill Kolender said.

title: PRIVATE MAIL AGENCIES GROW AMID FRAUD WORRIES
description: To Michael Sapinsky, who manages the Greenwich Village building where he lives, ''it seemed ridiculous to have people mail their rent checks to the same building, and I didn't want them slipping my checks under the door.''

title: BRITISH SEE MINOR CUT IN OIL PRICE
description: Some people expect the British National Oil Corporation, as a delaying tactic, to make a minor cut this week in the price of North Sea oil. Pressure is mounting for a major price cut, but British industry and Government sources have become pessimistic about the chances for a decisive move before Easter.

title: VW Plans to Build Cars in Spain
description: Spain's 95 percent state-owned car maker, Sociedad Espanola de Automoviles de Turismo, said it had signed a joint production agreement with Volkswagenwerk A.G..

title: HOLMES RETAINS TITLE ON DECISION
description: This town always had a reputation for being tough, and today they booed Larry Holmes at his homecoming here when the heavyweight champion lumbered through 12 rounds before scoring a unanimous decision over a hopelessly outclassed Lucien Rodriguez.

title: Profiles of Peddlers, and Justice
description: In their own legalistic way, those Supreme Court Justices sure do play rough. Consider what William Rehnquist called Byron White's opinion in an airport arrest case last week: a ''meandering opinion,'' replete with ''opaque nuances,'' one that ''stutters, fudges and fumbles.'' The opinion's fine as an impressionist painting ''but the same cannot be said if it is to be judged by the standards of a judicial opinion.''

title: News Analysis
description: The state budget being passed here today will force far fewer layoffs of state workers than Governor Cuomo proposed two months ago, and why Mr. Cuomo made such a fervent issue of the layoffs has become one of the most widely discussed aspects of his first budget.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Any time you have integration, you'll have some problems. You'll have some people who hate.

title: Lost 3-Year-Old Girl Found
description: A 3-year-old girl who wandered away from home was found early today after spending 14 hours in the woods, exposed to driving rain and high winds. Searchers in a wooded area north of town heard Dimika Pettway crying shortly after midnight and rescued her.

title: Christopher D'Amboise Leaves the City Ballet
description: Christopher D'Amboise, a popular young soloist with the New York City Ballet, has left the company.

title: China Tells O'Neill Of Optimism on Ties
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., was told by a Chinese official today that there were obstacles in the way of good American-Chinese relations but that China was optimistic about the relations in the long term.

title: CHARLES F. CHRISTENSEN
description: Charles F. Christensen, a television director, writer and producer, died of cancer Thursday at Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J. He lived in Hillsdale, N.J., and was 69 years old.

title: Sperry and Oki Set Computer Venture
description: The Sperry Corporation and the Oki Electric Industry Company have agreed to produce large-scale computers in Japan through their joint venture, Oki Univac, an Oki Electric official said.

title: GEORGIA AND HOUSTON GAIN FINAL FOUR
description: At the end of the University of Georgia's greatest basketball victory, Terry Fair was in charge of the celebration.

title: POISONS THAT ARE BOOMERANGED OUT OF THE U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Transit Project Faces Review
description: Arthur E. Teele Jr., Administrator of the Urban Mass Transit Administration, has ordered a review of a $680 million rail transit project in Miami because of reports that the local transit agency failed to live up to some contract specifications.

title: FED OPEN MARKET PANEL GETTING 4 NEW MEMBERS
description: The Federal Reserve's Federal Open Market Committee, the powerful body that sets the course of the nation's monetary policy, will change its voting membership Monday in a shift that some analysts say will bring it a more pragmatic bias.

title: MONDAY, MARCH 28, 1983; International
description: Britain may delay a major cut in its North Sea oil price until after Easter. Until then, market analysts think the British National Oil Corporation will resort to a minor price cut covering only February and March production as a delaying tactic. (Page D1.)

title: UPSTATE COUPLE SHARE PULPIT AND MARRIAGE
description: People who telephone the rectory of St. Margaret's Episcopal Church here often ask, ''Is Reverend Schlachter there?'' And the answer they are likely to get is ''Which one?''

title: JERSEY AUCTION NEARLY RECOUPS COST OF ANTIQUES
description: Most of the Empire-period antiques that were rejected for Drumthwacket, the Governor's Mansion in Princeton, N.J., have been sold at auction by the New Jersey Historical Society for nearly what the society paid for them.

title: LOUISVILLE IS TALENTED BUT INCONSISTENT
description: The Louisville team that will play Houston in the Final Four next weekend in Albuquerque, N.M., can be so good that it is frightening. At times, it can play so lethargically and so absent-mindedly that it is also frightening.

title: BRIEFING
description: Clues in the Eyes

title: Generals Fall, 31-21, Fumbling 8 Times
description: The New Jersey Generals lost again today. The Boston Breakers beat them, 31-21, and this defeat, their fourth in four games, was the most painful because the Generals were ahead by 21-7 in the second quarter.

title: 12 Farmers Killed, 20 Injured In a Land Dispute in Mexico
description: Twelve peasant farmers died and more than 20 were injured in a dispute over about 250 acres of land in Mexico's southernmost state, the Government newspaper El Nacional reported today.

title: MUSEUM UNVIELS THE MYSTERY OF TIME
description: ''What is time?'' a museum staff member asked the fourth graders gathered around him. ''A clock,'' said one. ''A watch,'' said another. ''A round thing that moves,'' said a third. ''Time goes backward,'' a boy ventured.

title: Rochelle Robbins Wed to Executive
description: Rochelle Lee Robbins, widow of Dr. William Justusson of Gainesville, Fla., was married yesterday to Donald H. Steinbrecher of Woburn, Mass., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Herman D. Steinbrecher of Eustis, Fla. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony in his study at Temple Emanu-El.

title: The Next Chancellor: Black or White?
description: Who should be the next Chancellor of the New York City public schools? That's only the nominal issue. It masks another issue, one that has flamed into controversy: should the next Chancellor be black or white? And even that masks a still more important issue:

title: Jack Daniel's To Lay Off 53
description: Jack Daniel's whisky distillery will idle 53 workers, the first time in its 117-year history that the company has laid off permanent employees, a company spokesman said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Fares of the Future?

title: Kodak Moving Millions To Olympic Coverage
description: Eastman Kodak is going to be moving a few million dollars into the ABC-TV Network to get its cameras and film messages to the viewers of the network's 1984 Olympic coverage.

title: FUJI BANK IN OVERSEAS TREND
description: The Fuji Bank has a reputation as a conservative operator with its main strength in its home market. But the announcement two weeks ago that Fuji plans to acquire two commercial lending units of the Walter E. Heller International Corporation showed that traditions are changing at the bank.

title: A SUMMER'S BROOKLYN-BRIDGE
description: To the Editor:

title: TALBOTT CAPTURES U.S. SQUASH OPEN
description: Mark Talbott, the first American to be ranked No.1 in professional squash racquets, defeated Ned Edwards by 15-11, 18-16, 12-15, 15-10 in the final of the Rolex United States Open championship yesterday at the Yale Club.

title: GERMANY'S MISSILE BLUES
description: The era of bipartisanship on the missile issue in West Germany has been pronounced dead. That means an increasingly bitter debate for the rest of the year, despite Chancellor Helmut Kohl's firm election victory and President Reagan's imminent new proposal on missile deployment.

title: SALVADORAN CHIEF SAYS MAIN TASK IS TO BRING LEFTISTS INTO ELECTIONS
description: The Provisional President of El Salvador says he believes his Government's main task is to create the conditions that will bring the leftist opposition into the presidential elections scheduled for December.

title: MARVIN KONER
description: Marvin Koner, a photojournalist and advertising photographer, died of cancer yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital.

title: Baxter Travenol
description: Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. said its Travenol Laboratories unit had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration for a new process of preparing hemophilia treatment that reduces the risk of hepatitis transmission. Travenol said its Hemofil T Antihemophilic Factor, which replaces a missing clotting protein in patients with classic hemophilia, uses a heat-treatment process designed to reduce the risk of transmitting viruses, such as hepatitis, through blood. Travenol said it is the first company licensed by the F.D.A. to use such a process.

title: Louisiana Tech Gains
description: Louisiana Tech advanced to the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball semifinals today by defeating Texas, 72-58, in the Midwest Regional final.

title: Horses Die in Fire
description: Thirteen horses died last night when a fire destroyed a private boarding stable in Newark, the city's Fire Department said.

title: CREWS AT REACTOR CRITICIZE CLEANUP
description: Four engineers who have participated in salvage efforts at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant here have asserted that mismanagement of the $1 billion recovery program has wasted millions of dollars, posed new threats to safety and delayed cleanup operations for years.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: DON'T HANG THE PHONE COMPANY YET
description: The deregulation of phone service, says Eric Schneiderman, a Michigan regulator, will double or triple the cost of local service. Unless Congress acts to ease the financial pinch, he warns, millions of subscribers will be forced to give up their phones and the hardwon achievement of universal service will be lost.

title: A MOUNTAIN COMES TO THE ATKINSON STAGE
description: THERE are three characters in this play. Two of them are men. The third is the mountain. It is a menacing vertical wall of artificial ice that rises from the basement and disappears into the shadows five stories above the stage of the Brooks Atkinson Theater. The mountain fills almost the entire hole framed by the proscenium arch, from back to front and side to side.

title: POUND'S DROP LAID TO THREE FACTORS
description: The decline of the British pound in recent weeks to record lows against the mark and the dollar is rooted in the price of oil, domestic politics and the course of United States interest rates. All have had a role in driving down what has traditionally been one of the world's stronger currencies.

title: Desert Wine Wins
description: Desert Wine captured the $107,900 San Felipe Handicap for 3-year-olds today after Naevus, who finished first by a head, was disqualified for interference in the stretch at Santa Anita.

title: Japan Critical Of Tax Move
description: Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe has criticized the United States for asking the Toyota Motor Corporation, ''without the Japanese Government's consent,'' to submit information on production costs and prices in connection with its United States subsidiary's taxes, Foreign Ministry officials said.

title: HEATING-OIL SHIFT UPSETS DELAWARE HOMEOWNERS
description: When Steven Fortunato first walked through Pike Creek Valley he could envision winding streets and green lawns and the varied middle-class homes he and three other builders would erect on its rolling acres only a few miles east of here and not far from Wilmington's urban sprawl.

title: Turkey Is Said to Plan Tighter Laws for Press
description: The Government is drawing up laws to tighten restrictions on the press in preparation for a return to parliamentary government, the Istanbul daily Cumhuriyet reported today.

title: Five Killed in Airplane Crash Near Homes in Roanoke, Va.
description: A twin-engine plane crashed here today, narrowly missing a residential area and a busy highway and killing all five people on board.

title: ARCHITECTURE: I.B.M.'S GREEN GRANITE GIANT
description: WHEN plans for the green granite I.B.M. Building at Madison Avenue and 57th Street were announced in 1978, they were greeted with a general sense of approval. Too few New Yorkers understood then how severely overbuilt the East 50's were becoming, and the prospect of a 43-story tower on this prominent corner did not seem to represent much except economic progress. And the architecture itself, by Edward Larrabee Barnes, looked in model form - always an untrustworthy source for final judgments, of course - like a dignified, if conservative, design, likely to be enlivened considerably by a glass-enclosed public park at its rear.

title: Bridge: It's Tricky to Get Straight Names That Are Similar
description: A diabolical pitfall for bridge organizers and writers is provided by pairs of players - not partnerships - who have the same first and last names.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MARCH 28, 1983
description: International The U.S. accused Yuri V. Andropov of making a ''false allegation'' in contending that the Reagan Administration sought military domination over the Soviet Union. The State Department response also said the Soviet leader had distorted the intent of President Reagan's plan for research on missile defenses, and expressed ''regret'' over the ''tone and content'' of Mr. Andropov's charges. (Page A1, Column 3.) Cuba's conventional military power has expanded steadily over the last two years, with the Soviet Union as its arms supplier and paymaster, United States naval officers say. Expansion of Cuba's amphibious fleet is regarded as especially significant in view of the current instability in Central America, according to officers of the Second Fleet. (A3:4.)

title: Advertising; J. Walter's 'Bad' Year Was Good
description: TO people who are up on their advertising news, the retrospective January trade ad from the J. Walter Thompson Company with the headline ''It was a very good year'' came as a bit of a surprise. But, if you could invade the hearts and minds of the troops at the huge agency, you'd probably find it was a correct statement.

title: News Analysis
description: With Mayor Jane M. Byrne's withdrawal from a futile write-in re-election effort, the campaign for the powerful office of Mayor has become something this city has never had before: a clear-cut, two-man, two-party race between a white and a black.

title: NEW YORK GIVES CHASE
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * John F. Kraushaar has been named president of Blair Advertising, Rochester, a subsidiary of BBDO International.

title: BALDWIN AID TALKS STILL UNRESOLVED
description: As today's deadline neared for the Baldwin-United Corporation to pay $440 million of an $800 million loan to a group of banks, it appeared that talks over the weekend had failed to produce a decision on whether to extend the deadline.

title: Commodities; Trading Crude Oil Futures
description: If, as expected, the Government tomorrow approves the trading of crude oil futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade, both exchanges plan to begin operations on Wednesday.

title: RON LEFLORE'S LAST CHANCE MAY BE SLIPPING AWAY
description: CHICAGO CASE No. 831194 walked through the tinted bullet-proof enclosure of a Chicago courtroom one day last month, meeting his lawyer in front of the judge's bench. The white-haired judge read the indictment and the lawyer entered a plea of not guilty. Case No. 831194 stood silently bundled in a scarf and heavy Western-style sportcoat, his hands folded neatly in front of him. At this moment he was no more separated from his past than he was from the other defendants who were part of this quiet courtroom procession. No. 831194 soon left his lawyer, running casually for a taxicab that would take him away to his Sarasota, Fla., home and another world.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Four New in Roles In 'Die Walkure' at Met
description: Four principals entered the cast of the Metropolitan Opera's production of Wagner's ''Walkure'' last week, and all four were in Friday night's performance. The most interesting was Simon Estes, in his first Met Wotans. Mr. Estes looks evey inch a god, and sings in reasonably celestial fashion besides, with a firm command of the role's range, a lovely, even tone and a manly edge to his voice.

title: Steel Plant In China To Proceed
description: China will proceed with construction of the second stage of the troubled Baoshan steel complex near Shanghai, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: TV: TWYLA THARP ON DANCE SERIES
description: CHOREOGRAPHERS have been having a fascinating affair with television. Even the two most revered giants of this century, George Balanchine and Martha Graham, eventually dropped their persistent objections to the medium after working closely with sensitive producers on public television's ''Dance in America'' series. Someone like Merce Cunningham, in tandem with Charles Atlas, has been experimenting in video for years. And then there is Twyla Tharp. Somehow these days, there is always Twyla Tharp.

title: YANKS' BAYLOR CONFIDENT
description: Since his early years in baseball, Don Baylor has been better known to his friends and teammates as Groove, a nickname that evolved as a tribute to his swing.

title: MAYOR PREDICTS CITY WILL AVOID FULL POLICE CUT
description: New York City will not have to cut its police force by 1,800 next year, Mayor Koch said yesterday. ''Without doubt,'' the Mayor said, the state budget that was approved by the Legislature early yesterday morning in Albany will enable the city to avoid cutting the police force by as much as had been projected.

title: EUROMISSILES' VALUE
description: It looks increasingly likely that the United States delegation to the Geneva talks on medium-range nuclear missiles will present a new proposal before the recess at the end of March. If this means that the ''zero option'' - President Reagan's proposal to forego deployment of American Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in exchange for a Soviet agreement to dismantle its SS-20 missiles -is dead and buried, no tears should be shed.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 2 Davises Departing

title: Bridge: 5 New York Experts Hold Lead in Shanghai Tourney
description: A quintet of touring New York experts was in a rare situation here this morning. The five - Kathie Wei, Mike and Judi Radin and Alan and Dorothy Truscott - had completed play in Shanghai's second international team tournament but were in doubt whether they had won. The field consisted of 10 teams from 8 different cities.

title: IS POST-WATERGATE GOVERNMENT MORALITY SLIPPING?
description: The list of Reagan Administration officials accused of ethical violations has grown quite long lately, but few of the accusations have raised the furor that similar incidents did in other recent administrations. As a result, some observers of the Washington scene are asking whether the post-Watergate morality in Government is slipping back to pre-Watergate levels.

title: CLASSICAL GREEK WITHOUT APOLOGIES
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An opera listing in The Guide on Sunday gave an incorrect location for a concert by the New York Lyric Opera scheduled for Thursday at 8 P.M. It will take place at the Fashion Institute of Technology, 227 W. 27th St.

title: News Analysis
description: France's President, Francois Mitterrand, is up against a great many problems, but one of his central difficulties is expressed in this adage: Socialism in one country is difficult to pull off.

title: Alter Course, Pros Urge
description: In one of the strongest challenges ever to Deane Beman's authority as commissioner of the PGA Tour, a group of leading touring professionals petitioned him today to make changes in the Tournament Players Club course here. Among those who signed the petition were Jack Nicklaus, Tom Watson, Ben Crenshaw, Hale Irwin, Craig Stadler and Tom Weiskopf, who said Friday that playing on this course was ''like playing in a pinball machine.''

title: BORG GETS CLERC AS OPPONENT
description: The luck of the draw could make Bjorn Borg's last tournament one of the shortest of his illustrious career. Borg has been matched in first-round play Tuesday at the Monte Carlo Open against Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina, who is seeded third.

title: BINGO BOOM BRINGS TRIBES PROFIT AND CONFLICT
description: The largest bingo parlor in the West looms above the mesquite and cactus of the Yaqui Indian Reservation like a desert mirage: a 20,000-square-foot cinderblock building that cost $1 million to build and seats as many as 1,300 players at a time.

title: FEDERAL MEAT INSPECTION PROGRAM: EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: ELECTRONIC CHIP SALES STRENGTHENING
description: The makers of electronic chips, after suffering through poor sales last autumn and early winter, appear to be in the first stage of a recovery.

title: VETERAN SUGGS IS CONTENT WITH GENERALS
description: The New Jersey Generals gave Shafer Suggs a tryout last Thursday and signed him to a contract Friday, and he played an entire game for them at strong safety on Sunday. It was the first football game Suggs had played in 16 months, since he was with the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about the National Invitation Tournament in SportsMonday yesterday gave an incorrect schedule for the final evening of play, tomorrow at Madison Square Garden. There will only be a championship game. No consolation game is scheduled.

title: Concert Artists Honor Segal
description: Martin E. Segal, board chairman of Lincoln Center, is this year's winner of the Concert Artists Guild Award for ''distinguished service in the field of the arts.'' Past winners of the award, which is being offered for the 32d time, include the pianist Artur Rubinstein and Avery Fisher, who was last year's winner. The award will be presented to Mr. Segal by Mr. Fisher and the singers Shirley Verrett and Jessye Norman on April 27 at the New York Sheraton Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 56th Street; the event is by invitation only.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Frankest Interview?

title: SUTTON WINS T.P.C. AFTER COOK FALTERS
description: Hal Sutton, one of the young lions who stole the spotlight from the more famous touring pros this week, bogeyed the final hole today but still won the richest prize in the history of the PGA Tour because his closest rival, John Cook, hit his final tee shot in a lake.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Peter Serkin, Friends In 20th-Century Works
description: Peter Serkin and three of his musical friends offered a fascinating evening of 20th-century music at the Metropolitan Museum Saturday night. There was a fine sense of symmetry and contrast to the program - in the center, a concerto and sonata, both for two pianos, by Stravinsky, and these surrounded by two duo sonatas of Stefan Wolpe, one for oboe, one for violin and both shared by Mr. Serkin's piano.

title: VIETNAM FORESTS' PROGNOSIS IMPROVES
description: A scientist who toured forested areas of Vietnam that had been sprayed with Agent Orange and other herbicides in the Vietnam War has determined that the wooded areas have recovered at a rate much faster than scientists had estimated.

title: PARADYNE SHARES PLUMMET
description: The Paradyne Corporation lost a fifth of its market value in heavy trading yesterday, after charges were filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday accusing the company of fraudulently obtaining a $100 million Government contract and of failing to make proper disclosures to shareholders.

title: LEXICON
description: Last week, at an informal news conference, President Reagan chided one persistent questioner: ''Listen, you are using up your press availability right now.''

title: Carlos Montoya Concert Marks 80th Birthday
description: Carlos Montoya's concert at Carnegie Hall on Saturday marked the Madrid-born guitarist's 80th birthday. Mr. Montoya, who popularized flamenco as a concert music style independent of singers and dancers, performed three short sets of songs that included his own arrangements of traditional Gypsy tunes and original material inspired by old themes.

title: Grenada Says Attack By U.S. Is Imminent
description: Grenada joined Nicaragua today in charging that it was the target of ''an imminent attack'' by the United States.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: COMMUNITY PROFILE

title: BUS TERMINAL'S HOMELESS ARE OFFERED REAL BEDS
description: Prompted by a nudge from a police officer, a disheveled man sleeping on a wooden bench awoke to the cacophony of the Port Authority Bus Terminal.

title: Q&A
description: Q. If you stand in a darkened room before a mirror and crush a wintergreen Life Saver in your teeth, you will see sparks in your mouth. Why?

title: IN KANSAS CITY
description: This city is still feeling the reverberations of the moment nearly two years ago when steel ripped through steel and two suspended ''skywalks'' collapsed at the Hyatt Regency Hotel, taking the lives of 114 people at a Friday night tea dance.

title: HYTEK INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $9,752 for the quarter and $99,301 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $4,481 for the quarter and $32,407 for the 9 months.

title: Advertising; Laxative Maker's Campaign
description: IF any of them had been watching the tube at the time, the announcement that each of the three dancing bottles of Phillips Milk of Magnesia were the viewer's ''true blue friend'' would have come as a major shock to Smurf fans. After all, how many blue friends can one have?

title: TINSLEY LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for year to Jan 26.
description: b-Includes extraordinary gain of $383,070, or 65 cents a share, from the sale of property.

title: Pershing 2 Does Well in Test
description: The Pershing 2 missile was fired on its seventh long-range test flight today and Army officials said the flight was apparently a success. The 35-foot missile, which is scheduled for deployment in Western Europe later this year, traveled some 850 miles in 11 minutes before landing south of Bermuda, the officials said. ''The performance of the two stages appeared normal,'' said Dave Harris, spokesman for the Army Missile Command at Huntsville, Ala.

title: Kohl Announces the Makeup Of New West German Cabinet
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany officially announced his new Cabinet today at a meeting of conservative members of Parliament.

title: LATIN AMERICA'S NECESSARY SOLDIERS
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S THE USE OF A LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR?
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S KILLING BIGHORN LAMBS OF SANTA ROSA
description: SOMETHING sad and mysterious has been happening to the wild bighorn lambs that frisk among the scarps and crags of the Santa Rosa Mountains in southernmost California, 90 miles from Mexico. And local scientists and laymen have formed an organization to investigate.

title: TOURNAMENT SPIRIT CAUGHT BY CAMERAS
description: V iewers get accustomed to certain patterns in the telecasts of the major sports by the major networks. After each play in football, certain replays are expected. After each inning in baseball, a linescore is expected.

title: HIGH COURT TO RULE ON PROTECTION LABOR LAW PROVIDES TO EMPLOYEES
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Federal labor law protects an employee against dismissal for asserting a right provided for in a labor contract. The question has been the subject of a long dispute between the National Labor Relations Board and several Federal appeals courts.

title: Flaky Paint, and Chic
description: When Nancy Feldman took a studio apartment in Greenwich Village last December, according to a recent article in The Times's Home Section, the place was a mess. The walls were painted the fleshy color of a Band-Aid and the ceiling was falling in.

title: TV: KILEY READS POETRY
description: IN ''Verse Person Singular,'' tonight's American Playhouse presentation on Channel 13 at 9:30 o'clock, Richard Kiley promises that his one-man show will provide a ''joyful celebration of the spoken word.'' The press material declares that the hour offers an exploration of new video techniques. The program itself is simply pleasant.

title: 3 GUILTY IN HERSTATT FAILURE
description: Three West German currency dealers were found guilty today of fraudulent transactions contributing to the 1974 collapse of Bankhaus I.D. Herstatt in this country's biggest postwar bank crash.

title: ACCORD ON TAX AID OR BUILDERS FAILS
description: Efforts to extend New York City's major tax benefit program for developers fell apart early today as the State Legislature passed the 1984 budget.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I spoke with the Mayor. We had a discussion. I indicated I would support the Mayor's choice, and in this case the Mayor's choice is Bobby Wagner.''

title: SPRING ON 34th ST.
description: No matter what the weather, spring comes with exuberance the moment one sets foot inside Macy's. The store has again transformed its main floor into a huge garden with thousands of trees, growing plants and cut blooms for its ninth annual flower show, which began Sunday and continues through Saturday.

title: OXFORD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 25.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in December 1982.

title: U.S. FINDS ITSELF VIRTUALLY ISOLATED IN U.N. OVER THE NICARAGUAN CRISIS
description: After four days of occasionally heated debate on the fighting in Nicaragua, the United States has become virtually isolated in the Security Council in its attempts to portray the conflict as an internal Nicaraguan affair.

title: TRAVELODGE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: Information for 1982 has been restated to adjust for the affect of foreign currency translations in nformity with F.A.S.B. Statement No. 52 that was not adopted until the second quarter of 1982.

title: Cyrus Vance: Workaholic
description: LAST summer, Cyrus R. Vance's flower gardens received less than their usual loving attention. The former Secretary of State gave himself six weeks in which to finish most of ''Hard Choices,'' his forthcoming book on his years at the State Department, and what with long hours, the labors of writing and at least a few breaks for tennis, there simply wasn't as much time for the zinnias.

title: NEW YORK AREA CALLERS SEEK REASSURANCE ON EATING CARP
description: Concern that a staple of Passover, gefilte fish, might contain Lake Huron carp tainted with the toxic dioxin prompted hundreds of inquiries yesterday from consumers, distributors and retailers in the New York metropolitan area.

title: CLARK, J L, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
CABARET: BROADWAY SPOOF
description: ''FORBIDDEN BROADWAY,'' which started skewering the foibles of the Broadway theater, its shows and its stars in January 1982, has moved into its second year at Palsson's, 158 West 72d Street, with enough new and updated material to qualify as a second edition. The change has been going on gradually over the last year, not only as bits such as the Ann Miller and Rex Harrison numbers were replaced but also with cast changes that, for some reason, have affected only the two women in a cast of five.

title: JOHNSON PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Net losses including tax credits of $94,000 for the quarter and $154,000 for the 6 months.

title: U.S. Lofts a Satellite To Find Planes and Ships
description: A $53 million satellite was launched into earth orbit today as part of an international experiment aimed at locating downed planes and sinking ships. The satellite later malfunctioned, but engineers said they were confident they could repair it.

title: Place of Honor
description: China accounts for about one-third of the world's population, so it wasn't surprising that when the running boom spread to that country, there would be more joggers clogging the roadways there than anywhere else.

title: Grand Prix Ends
description: Organizers of the Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach and officials of Championship Auto Racing Teams announced today that next year's race through the downtown streets would feature Indy cars. That meant the end of Formula One racing in a city that for eight years had played host to the premier Grand Prix in the United States. On Sunday, John Watson of Northern Ireland had won the final Grand Prix here.

title: Weyerhaeuser Aide Confirms Dumping at Stringfellow Site
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company, the lumber products manufacturer that William D. Ruckelshaus will leave to head the Environmental Protection Agency, confirmed today that it once was among the largest users of the Stringfellow toxic waste dump.

title: DIFFERENT PATHS FOR 2 REDMEN
description: O n the unofficial first day of spring at St. John's University, members of the women's softball team played catch on the floor at Alumni Hall where the men's basketball team might have been preparing for another game. Lacrosse players stood with their equipment in the hallway that might have been occupied with students waiting in line for tickets to the national basketball semifinals and final scheduled for next weekend.

title: ISRAEL FINDS NO POISON AT 6 ARAB SCHOOLS
description: The Israeli Health Ministry said today that it had found no traces of poison at six Palestinian girls' schools on the occupied West Bank where hundreds of schoolchildren have fallen ill.

title: STETSON, JOHN B, CO reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: b-Includes equity in loss of the Wilshire Corporation of $87,169, a 47.1 percent owned affiliate.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: It's Decision Time for Yankees
description: Opening Day 1983 is slightly more than a week away, and the Yankees still have 14 players on the roster who must be cut before the first pitch is thrown next Tuesday night in Seattle.

title: Hecklers Delay Yamani Speech
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, was shouted down by protesters from the rear of a packed auditorium at Kansas State University today, interrupting his lecture for more than an hour and prompting five arrests.

title: FUNK: THE RETURN OF GEORGE CLINTON
description: company wrangling, he released a lively, commercially successful new album, ''Computer Games,'' on a new label recently, and Thursday night he was at the Red Parrot with the reformed Parliament-Funkadelic All Stars. (He will be there again tonight at midnight.)

title: Emery Air Freight
description: The Emery Air Freight Corporation said it had begun a new one-to-two day, door-to-door delivery service between North America and Western Europe. The service, called Emery International First Class Service, includes pickup from the shipper, reserved space to the destination and expedited customs clearance. A second service, called business class, will guarantee delivery in two to three days, the company said.

title: 'BIG BANG' HAS A REVIVAL IN NEW VIEW OF UNIVERSE
description: AREVOLUTION is taking place in the study of the cosmos. Theorists now believe it is possible that the entire observable universe evolved from a concentration of energy no more massive than a single apple.

title: Perahia Piano Recital Focuses on Structure
description: What sets Murray Perahia apart from other pianists is his extraordinary command of musical architecture. He illuminates the internal structure of any work he plays in a manner that is truly revelatory. Mr. Perahia opened his Sunday afternoon recital at Avery Fisher Hall with a performance of Mozart's D minor Fantasy that managed to blend the work's diverse and rather jagged contrasts into a convincing and homogenous totality.

title: LOW-TAR CIGARETTES ARE STILL DOMINANT, F.T.C. TESTS SHOW
description: Low-tar cigarettes continue to dominate the tobacco market, although there are fewer brands with 0.5 milligrams or less of tar, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.

title: Wainoco Notes Credit Default
description: The Wainoco Oil Corporation said that is in technical default on a $50 million credit, but that its banks are waiving the default until at least Thursday.

title: JUSTICES HEAR SEX-BASED PENSION CASE
description: A pension case that may have far-reaching implications for employees of state and local governments and nonprofit institutions reached the Supreme Court today. The Justices heard arguments on whether the Federal law against sex discrimination in employment outlaws retirement plans that pay women lower monthly benefits than men.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MARCH 29, 1983
description: International An American arms control initiative was reported by Reagan Administration officials. They said the American negotiator at the talks in Geneva would propose to Soviet officials today that they agree on an interim solution as a step toward the elimination of all medium-range missiles in Europe. (Page A1, Column 6.) Washington is virtually isolated in a four-day-long debate in the United Nations Security Council because of its effort to portray the conflict in Nicaragua as an internal affair. (A1:4-5.)

title: Halas Is Moved
description: George Halas, the 88-year-old owner of the Chicago Bears, was moved from Northwestern Memorial Hospital's intensive-care unit to a private room today, but there was no word on his condition. Halas was admitted March 3 for treatment of an obstruction in his bile tract and later developed jaundice. Both problems have been arrested, doctors said.

title: Olson May Leave Iowa
description: In his nine seasons at Iowa, Lute Olson has compiled a 167-91 record and led the Hawkeyes to five straight appearances in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. Those are attractive numbers, and University of Arizona officials apparently would like Olson to compile similar ones at their school. According to the Associated Press, Arizona, whose 4-24 record this season was the worst in the school's history, has offered Olson the head coaching job, and that the coach, who met with school officials over the weekend, could be named today.

title: BENJAMIN A. COLONNA
description: Benjamin A. Colonna, former head of Colonna & Company, producer and importer of marble, travertine and other stones, died March 21 at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Waco, Tex.

title: LENNAR CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
U.S. NOT DENYING SANDINIST CHARGES
description: Reagan Administration officials acknowledged today that they were doing nothing to dispel the impression that the United States is covertly supporting anti-Sandinist forces fighting in Nicaragua.

title: MACCHIAROLA SAYS HE BACKS WAGNER FOR SCHOOLS POST
description: Frank J. Macchiarola yesterday endorsed Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. to succeed him as Schools Chancellor of New York City. ''I support the Mayor's candidate,'' Mr. Macchiarola said at a news conference in answer to repeated questions by reporters. ''I spoke with the Mayor. We had a discussion. I indicated I would support the Mayor's choice, and in this case the Mayor's choice is Bobby Wagner.''

title: Long Island Utility Sells 12 5/8% Bonds
description: The Long Island Lighting Company sold $75 million of 12 5/8 percent bonds due in 1992, offered through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation at a price of 99.82 to yield 12.85 percent to maturity.

title: Gold Triumph
description: DENVER. March 28 (AP) - Ken Johnson passed for two touchdowns and Harry Sydney rushed for 83 yards and one touchdown as the Denver Gold scored a 22-12 victory over the Oakland Invaders tonight in a United States Football League game.

title: Joys of Obscurity
description: Although baseball is called the national pastime, it ranks a poor third to football and basketball at most of the universities that have major sports programs.

title: ARGENTINA IS PARALYZED BY A ONE-DAY STRIKE
description: A one-day strike by Argentina's labor unions brought the country almost to a standstill today despite the military Government's declaration that the work stoppage was illegal.

title: Citicorp Officer Moving to Pace
description: Stephen C. Eyre, 60 years old, senior vice president and corporate secretary of Citibank and Citicorp, will move to academia next month when he becomes Distinguished Professor of Finance in the newly established Citicorp Chair of Finance at Pace University.

title: ALA MOANA HAWAII PROPERTIES reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $232,469,216, or $13.90 a share, on the sale of properties. c-There are no comparable year- ago results because Ala Moana Hawaii Properties commenced operations on July 1, 1981.

title: Lone Star Loss Has Widened
description: Lone Star Industries said its loss in the first two months of the year widened to $20.1 million, from $13.2 million a year ago.

title: OLAJUWON CHARMS AND DOMINATES
description: There is a precious innocence surrounding Akeem Abdul Olajuwon, the 7-foot sophomore center for Houston, who has dominated and charmed this year's National Collegiate Athletic Association tournamant, both on and off the court.

title: HIGH P.L.O. OFFICIAL CONFERS IN JORDAN
description: A high-ranking Palestine Liberation Organization official met with Jordanian leaders today on a role for King Hussein in American-led Middle East peace talks and said the P.L.O. and Jordan were ''going in the right direction.''

title: GEORGIA CAMPUS HAS NEW HEROES
description: With the annual State 4-H Steer Show kicking up a stench outside his window, his basketball court dismantled to make room for livestock pens and the University of Georgia Coliseum crawling with reporters covering the first day of spring football practice, Hugh Durham, the school's basketball coach, does not usually hang around his office on the last Monday in March.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: It was not the best week France has ever had. How c ould it be? The franc was devalued, the Cabinet was reshuffled and t he people were stung by a new austerity program. If this was not t urmoil enough, French fashion seems to be undergoing a sort of m idlife crisis. For, with the exception of Sonia Rykiel and Karl L agerfeld, the new national hero, the French did not dazzle.

title: GNC Sees Profit By Mid-1984
description: The GNC Energy Corporation said it expected to return to profitable operations in the fiscal year 1984 first quarter ending June 30, basing the forecast on increased coal sales to steel manufacturers and improvement in the housing and road construction industries. GNC has operated at a loss for the past five years.

title: Jury Hears Testimony On Toxic Waste Handler
description: Testimony began today in a grand jury investigation convened to examine alleged illegal dumping by Chemical Waste Management Inc. of Chicago. Terry Zarowney, a chemist for the company until Jan. 4, testified about former company activities in a closed-door session.

title: 'BIRDS' OUTDREW 'WINDS'
description: The first segment of ''The Thorn Birds,'' ABC Television's fourpart, 10-hour serialization of the novel by Colleen McCullough, outdrew the initial portion of ''The Winds of War,'' a miniseries broadcast by the same network in February.

title: PANDICK PRESS INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: The year-ago share earnings for both periods were adjusted for a 5-for- 4 stock split distributed Jan. 17, 1983.

title: Soprano and Baritone Join Met's 'Butterfly'
description: Saturday night, the soprano Leona Mitchell and the baritone David Holloway joined the cast of the Metropolitan Opera's production of Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly,'' under the direction of Eugene Kohn.

title: 7 Seized in Drug Raid At Hotel on East Side
description: Six men and a woman were arrested yesterday on a variety of drug and weapons charges by narcotics detectives in a raid on an East Side hotel that yielded three handguns and 28 ounces of cocaine, the police said.

title: DEPAUL IN FINAL WITH FRESNO STATE
description: Like a zephyr out of the West, Fresno State swept into town yesterday and proved a point it has been trying to make for a long time. The Bulldogs answered those who criticized their credentials with an impressive 86-62 victory over Wake Forest to advance to the final against DePaul in the National Invitation Tournament.

title: OSHAWA GROUP LTD reports earnings for qtr to Jan 22.
description: b-Including a special gain of $1,415,000 for the quarter and year. c-Including special gains of $21,000 for the quarter and $107,000 for the year. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: PETROL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
BALLET: HAMBURG GIVES NEUMEIER'S 'MATTHEW PASSION'
description: BACH'S ''Saint Matthew Passion,'' as choreographed by the Hamburg Ballet's artistic director, John Neumeier, is not your everyday dance or musical event. The four-hour and one-time-only performance in New York attracted a capacity house at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Sunday afternoon.

title: A NEEDED GESTURE
description: The search - or rather the street fight - for a new schools chancellor has become so politically and racially polarized that fresh thinking by the city's leadership is needed to pull the situation back from potential chaos.

title: NEW STUDY FINDS LACK OF CREATIVITY
description: THE curriculum is ''sterile.'' Topics of great human interest ''on the way to the classroom are apparently transformed and homogenized into something of limited appeal.'' Students ''scarcely ever speculate on meanings'' or discuss ''alternative interpretations.'' Teachers ''teach as they were taught'' years ago in their own schooling. All the messages received by them ''conspire to reinforce the status quo. The cards are stacked against innovation.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A Company News item in Business Day Saturday misstated the terms of Carl Marks & Company's proposed purchase of M.H. Lamston. Carl Marks has offered $34.50 a share, or $19.8 million in total, for Lamston's 574,436 shares outstanding.

title: COHO RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After a writedown of investment in Coho Australia Ltd. of $1,045,113. c-Net income including a gain of $964,476 from equity issue by Coho Australia.

title: THREE CHILDREN AND FATHER KILLED IN FIRE IN JERSEY CITY
description: Three children and their father were killed early today in a fire that trapped them in a second-floor apartment, authorities said.

title: Seiko Time Corporation Sets a Spring Campaign
description: The Seiko Time Corporation, the United States marketing arm of the Japanese manufacturer, will break a new spring campaign next month with the theme ''Setting the standard for the future for the world,'' in both television and print.

title: ENVIRONMENAL GROUPS HAIL RUCKELSHAUS BUT STILL ATTACK PRESIDENT
description: Leading environmentalist groups said today that they welcomed William D. Ruckelshaus's nomination to head the Environmental Protection Agency, but they continued their criticism of Reagan Administration attitudes on protecting the public health and natural resources.

title: Topics; Sporting With the Law; Buttoned Lips
description: The hottest button in town is a two-inch metal shield bearing the word JUROR in one-inch characters. These treasures are handed out to those who have answered the New York County Clerk's call to jury service.

title: Talks on North Sea Oil
description: Douglas Hurd, Britain's Deputy Foreign Secretary, said today that North Sea oil producers are having an ''informal conversation'' with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries following this month's reduction in the benchmark price of oil. North Sea producers are under pressure to reduce prices as well, but OPEC has threatened a price war if North Sea oil falls below $30 a barrel.

title: CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 27.
CUOMO AND LEADERS REJOICE AS BUDGET IS VOTED ON TIME
description: The State Legislature completed passage of a new state budget early today and capped the moment with an extraordinary display of unity among the legislative leaders and their new Governor.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Optioned three p layers to its Rochester farm club: Cliff S peck, pitcher, Mike Young, outfielder, a nd Bob Bonner, infielder. CHICAGO (AL) - Cut Ron LeFlore, o utfielder. CINCINNATI (NL) - Placed Paul H ouseholder, outfielder, on the 21-day dis- a bled list. HOUSTON (NL) - Nolan Ryan, pitch- e r, left spring training to be examined in H ouston for a bladder infection. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Placed Dwight B ernard, pitcher, on waivers for the pur- p ose of giving him his unconditional re- l ease. MONTREAL (NL) - Sent Dave Tomlin a nd Bill Sattler, pitchers, to its Wichita f arm club; sent Don Dilks and Tom Dick- s on, pitchers, to its minor league camp in D aytona Beach, Fla.; placed David Palm- e r, pitcher, on the 21-day disabled list. OAKLAND (AL) - Released Bob Ow- c hinko, pitcher, Al Woods, outfielder, and J ohn D'Acquisto, pitcher; assigned Je- r ome King, pitcher, to the minor leagues, PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Sent the fol- l owing players to the minor leagues for r eassignment: Tony Ghelfi, Kelly Downs, E d Mojna and Bill Johnson, pitchers; and D arren Daulton and John Russell, catch- e rs. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Requested w aivers on Ross Baumgarten, pitcher, D ick Davis, outfielder, and John Milner, i nfielder; released Randy Jones, pitcher. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Placed Alan F owles, pitcher, on the 21-day disabled l ist; released Masanori Murakami, pitch- e r. SEATTLE (AL) - Placed Bobby B rown, outfielder, on waivers.

title: Florida Agency Issue Is Offered
description: The Florida Housing Finance Agency sold $60.195 million of 8 3/4 percent multifamily housing revenue bonds due in 1995 through underwriters led by the Merrill Lynch White Weld Captial Markets Group. The bonds were offered at a price of 100, and were all sold in the first day of sales, underwriters said.

title: NICARAGUA REPORTS ITS TROOPS BATTLE REBELS NEAR HONDURAS
description: Government troops fought anti-Sandinist rebels in northern Nicaragua near the Honduran border today, Nicaraguan officials said.

title: STATE BANKERS OPPOSE NEW 3% WITHHOLDING
description: Bankers said yesterday that it would be physically impossible to comply with the July 1 deadline of a new law that requires financial institutions and corporations to withhold 3 percent from all interest and dividends paid to New York State residents.

title: The U.N. Today; March 29, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, Legal Subcommittee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: A.T.& T. to Raise Rivals' Linkup Fees
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, acting on behalf of its 22 local phone company affiliates, notified the Federal Communications Commission today that it will raise connection charges to long-distance competitors about 18 percent effective April 16. The increase will last for the rest of the year.

title: 80 Sweepers Taken Out of City Service
description: Eighty of the city's 468 mechanical street sweepers were removed from service last week after one of them burst into flames and another was engulfed in smoke, the Sanitation Department said yesterday.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The veteran hockey player Ed Kea, was flown back to his St. Louis home for further treatment of a three-week-old head injury. Kea, 35, suffered a cerebral contusion March 8 when a bodycheck sent him into the boards during a Central Hockey League game for the Salt Lake Golden Eagles, a farm team of the St. Louis Blues.

title: Rates Steady in Quiet Trading; Move by Fed Is Awaited
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday in extremely quiet trading as investors and speculators waited for indications of whether the Federal Reserve would encourage higher interest rates after yesterday's meeting of its Federal Open Market Committee.

title: U.S. Proposes Fine Of $20,000 at Salem
description: The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission yesterday proposed a fine of $20,000 against Public Service Electric and Gas Company, operator of the Salem nuclear power plant in southern New Jersey, for allowing Unit No. 1 to operate for six months last year while a radiation monitor was broken.

title: HOLMES FINDS YOU CAN GO HOME
description: round decision over Lucien Rodriguez in the old armory here. And now the champion began to move toward the door.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Easing the Snow Watch

title: Strike Snarls Argentina
description: A 24-hour strike by Argentina's trade union movement brought economic activity to a virtual halt throughout the country today.

title: Atlanta Symphony Plays in Carnegie Hall
description: Last weekend's program by the Atlanta Symphony in Carnegie Hall seemed more appropriate to a day in August than to the wet March Sunday afternoon outside. There were Mendelssohn's Overture to ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' the summer fantasies of ''Les Nuits d'ete'' by Berlioz and, finally, the C-Major sunshine of Schubert's Ninth Symphony.

title: Nausea Fells 17 Yankees
description: Was it the ham sandwiches in the clubhouse after the game or the tiny shrimp in the dinner salads on the flight back? For now, the Yankees can only guess at the reason why 13 players, 3 coaches and 1 manager reported feeling nauseated today.

title: JAPAN'S CLASSROOM: A BUDDING 'BLACKBOARD JUNGLE?'
description: Japanese schools have traditionally been halls of order and decorum, and the students -boys garbed in black militarystyle jackets and girls in sailor suit unforms - models of dedication and obedience.

title: U.S. WILL PROPOSE AN INTERIM ACCORD ON MISSILES TODAY
description: The United States intends to propose to the Soviet Union on Tuesday that they agree on an interim solution as a step toward the elimination of all medium-range missiles in Europe, Administration officials said today.

title: OUT TROUBLED SCHOOLS
description: * Among freshmen entering New Jersey public colleges last fall, 61 percent lacked proficiency in algebra, 46 percent could not solve simple mathematical problems and 32 percent could not use the English language correctly.

title: LOUGHLIN PLAYERS PACE ALL-STAR TEAM
description: Less than a day after he scored 38 points in the state large high school championship game at Glens Falls, N.Y., Mark Jackson of Bishop Loughlin helped Brooklyn-Staten Island defeat Bronx-Westchester, 93-86, in a scholastic all-star game last night. The eighth annual competition of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association was held at Archbishop Molloy High School in Queens.

title: News Analysis
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger used a 48-hour visit here last week to press the leaders of the Socialist Government to resume Spain's full membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Ex-Bayer Division Head Takes Top Miles Posts
description: The former head of the pharmaceuticals division of Bayer A.G., Franz J. Geks, has been elected chairman, president and chief executive officer of Miles Laboratories Inc., the maker of Alka-Seltzer and One-A-Day multiple vitamins.

title: Publisher Is Named, By Psychology Today
description: The American Psychological Association, which last month acquired Psychology Today magazine from Ziff-Davis Publishing Company, said yesterday that it had named Joseph Benjamin, 48 years old, publisher, to replace Gerald G. Hotchkiss, 52.

title: Books Of The Times
description: ARARAT. By D.M. Thomas. 191 pages. Viking. $13.50.

title: Economist Named Dean at Rochester
description: Paul W. MacAvoy, an economist who served on the Council of Economic Advisers under President Ford, was named yesterday to a 12-year term as dean of the University of Rochester's Graduate School of Management.

title: Patrick F. Scanlan, 88, Edited Paper for Brooklyn Diocese
description: Patrick F. Scanlan, retired managing editor of The Tablet, the publication of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, died Sunday at the Belair Nursing Home in North Bellmore, L.I. He was 88 years old and had long been a resident of Floral Park, L.I.

title: Market Place
description: JACK W. VANDER VLIET serves as chief investment officer of Dean Witter Reynolds Intercapital Inc., the asset management division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. responsible for tending to $11 billion.

title: PIONEER OF 'JUNK' SCULPTURE
description: Richard Stankiewicz, the American sculptor whose whimsical scrapiron constructions made him one of the pioneers of ''junk art'' and assemblage, died of cancer Sunday in Worthington, Mass. He was 60 years old.

title: Talking Business with Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan; Seeking Stable Money Rates
description: For the last 10 years the world has been on a regime of floating exchange rates in which governments let market forces act as the principal determinants of currency values.

title: SYMPOSIUM MARKS 3 MILE ISLAND OBSERVANCE
description: The cooling towers of Three Mile Island, shaped like giant abstract hour glasses dimly visible in the cloudy distance, were a brooding presence here today as about 200 people gathered for a scientific symposium on the fourth aniversary of this country's worst nuclear accident.

title: Water Allocation Increased for City
description: The amount of water that New York City is allowed to draw from the Delaware River system was raised yesterday as the Delaware River Basin Commission ended its four-month-old drought warning.

title: EYES IN THE SKY: SATELLITES' USE GROWING WITH CAPABILITIES
description: When President Reagan displayed aerial photographs of what he said were Soviet installations in Central America and the Caribbean last week, he remarked, ''I wish I could show you more without compromising our most sensitive intelligence sources and methods.''

title: Chess:; Wily Smyslov Uses Bluff To Draw Candidates Game
description: Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union bluffed his way to a colorful draw with Robert Huebner of West Germany in the first game of their quarterfinal match for world championship candidates in Velden, Austria. Their second game was also drawn.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Brae Corp., San Francisco, said it had acquired 85 percent of the stock of American Sign and Indicator Corp., a closely held designer and manufacturer of electronic visual communications systems; terms were not disclosed.

title: Albany's Well-Balanced Beginning
description: The new budget adopted amicably this weekend by New York's Legislature balances $1 billion in extra taxes against thousands of state jobs and programs that the Governor had threatened to eliminate. Its soundness depends heavily on the accuracy of its tax predictions. If the revenue measures on which they are based leave room for doubt, however, they are still worth trying.

title: Who Shall Head the Fed?
description: President Reagan said recently he had not yet thought about whether to reappoint or replace Paul Volcker when his term as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board expires in August. This is probably the most important appointive decision Mr. Reagan still faces in his own term. It's time to think about it, and here's how:

title: FASHION TALE OF 4 CITIES: VIVE LA DIFFERENCE
description: Fashion was once a great leveler. A dozen years ago, when the young crowd was universally in battered jeans and sweatshirts and more sophisticated women wore pants suits or designer sweaters, it was difficult to tell anyone's national origin at the world's airports or shopping centers.

title: Higher Prices For Diamonds
description: De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. said today that its Central Selling Organization would raise diamond prices an overall 3.5 percent, effective April 5.

title: REPORT FROM THE FAIRE
description: NORTH of Silicon Valley, in the flatlands of San Francisco called the Civic Center, they have a faire each year. The ''e'' at the end of ''faire'' may at first seem an affectation, and it's true that the spelling originates in the nouveau baroque era which spawned such mass movements asflower children, head shops and personal computers, with their concomitant colorful, if sometimes incomprehensible, patois. But the added ''e'' is more than an orthographic mannerism. It reflects the true essence of the West Coast Computer Faire, a 20th-century technological rerun of the market fairs that made Hanover and the other great German cities postmedieval centers of commerce.

title: THE DANCE: SALLY HESS
description: SALLY HESS is a compelling and imaginative dancer-choreographer, but the best part of the concert she presented on Friday at the Merce Cunningham Studio was its warmth. This was an evening spent in good company.

title: CURRICULUM ADDRESSES FEAR OF ATOM WAR
description: FOR many youngsters, the possibility of never reaching adulthood because of an all-engulfing nuclear war is a frightening prospect, much on their minds but seldom mentioned in school.

title: Alfred M. Saperston, Lawyer And Cornell Trustee Emeritus
