description: Alfred M. Saperston, a lawyer and trustee emeritus of Cornell University, died yesterday at his home in Buffalo. He was 84 years old.

title: Swan and Strawberry Excel
description: With the opening of the season only one week away, the Mets got two gleaming performances today, but only one of them helped to solve the final decisions of spring training.

title: TAYLOR DEVICES reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 10, 1983.

title: CHICAGOANS DISPLAY NO SIGNS OF UNITY
description: As the campaign for mayor entered its final two weeks today, this city that is starkly divided along racial, residential and economic lines showed no signs of uniting behind either candidate.

title: TV: THE STORY OF THREE MILE ISLAND
description: ''SIXTY MINUTES TO MELTDOWN'' is an ambitious, mildly confusing and ultimately upsetting examination of the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant four years ago this week. It is ambitious in its attempt to synthesize everything we know about the accident; mildly confusing for exactly that same reason; and upsetting because it suggests that nuclear plants, although they are regulated more closely than they once were, are still not regulated enough. ''Sixty Minutes to Meltdown,'' part of public television's ''Nova'' series, will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 P.M.

title: SHOW'S ADS AFFECT NEWS COVERAGE
description: An editor of The Daily News acknowledged yesterday that the advertising policy of a Broadway musical has influenced his paper's coverage of that show.

title: Military Analysis
description: The United States Navy is entering the closing phases of a major training exercise that has illustrated some of the more technologically advanced dimensions of naval warfare.

title: Reagan Lawyer's Son Faces Murder Charge
description: The 20-year-old son of President Reagan's personal lawyer was charged today with firstdegree murder and rape in his mother's death.

title: Man With 105 Wives Is Sentenced to 34 Years
description: A convicted bigamist who testified he married 105 women in a wedding march that became a stampede over the years was sentenced today to the maximum 34 years in prison and fined $336,000.

title: Dancer Fitzgerald
description: Dancer Fitzgerald Sample has become agency for the United States and Canadian consumer finance group of the Beneficial Management Corporation, which had been a client of Al Paul Lefton Inc., for 25 years. There are indications that the account, which was believed to be in the area of $5 million in billings, might end up in the more affluent neighborhood of $10 million. Gary Susnjara, president of the agency's New York office, sort of alluded to that possibility when he talked of the client's ''ambitious growth plans.''

title: U.S. JUDGE BLOCKS SALE OF GEORGES BANK OIL LEASES
description: Just one day before it was to take place, a judge today stopped the sale of oil drilling lease rights on 2.8 million acres of the Georges Bank fishing grounds off New England, one of the world's richest fishing areas. The offering, the largest of its kind ever proposed by the Federal Government, was to go up for bids in New York City Tuesday morning.

title: U.S. STEEL DISCUSSING IMPORT PLAN WITH THE BRITISH, ANGERING UNION
description: The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that it was holding talks with the British Steel Corporation about importing unfinished steel from the state-owned British enterprise to U.S. Steel's Fairless Works and possibly some of its other plants. The announcement set off a furor in the steelworkers' union.

title: Christopher d'Amboise Explains Quitting Ballet
description: Christopher d'Amboise, a soloist with the New York City Ballet who has just left the company, has issued a statement on his reasons for resigning. ''I am leaving New York City Ballet at this time to pursue many other interests, which as a full-time dancer I had no other opportunities to develop,'' Mr. d'Amboise, the author of the recently published ''Leap Year,'' said.

title: Miss Navratilova Set for Outdoor Tests
description: When Martina Navratilova demolished Tracy Austin, 6-2, 6-1, in the final of the 1980 Colgate Series championships, many longtime tennis observers said they had never seen a woman play a more complete match.

title: South Africa Denies Its Police Raided Lesotho
description: South Africa denied charges by neighboring Lesotho today that members of its police force attacked a military barracks in the mountain kingdom last weekend.

title: Jersey Man Bitten While Petting Lion
description: A 23-year-old man performing community service at a zoo here as part of his probation was bitten by a caged lion as he petted the animal, officials said.

title: Magnetic Refrigeration
description: New and more efficient refrigeration, achieved by the magnetic heating of solids rather than by compression and expansion of a gas, is being developed at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico.

title: ORTHODOX JUDAISM IS BUOYED BY A RESURGENCE IN NEW YORK
description: Twenty years ago, Sabel's Kosher Bakery, halfway between 45th and 46th Streets on Fort Hamilton Parkway in Brooklyn, was the only store on the block to close for the Jewish Sabbath. Now, Osher Sabel, the Hasidic proprietor of the bakery, boasts that, with the arrival of other Orthodox merchants, they all do.

title: Japan Import Easing
description: The Japanese Cabinet has adopted a set of proposals designed to make it easier for foreign manufacturers to get their products into the Japanese market, the Chief Cabinet Secretary, Masaharu Gotoda, said in a statement over the weekend. Government officials said the measures, including proposed amendments to 17 laws, were designed to make Japan's standards and operating test methods more open to trading partners.

title: DEL-VAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $157,000, or 9 cents a share, on the sale of real estate.

title: BRITISH STEEL'S CHIEF TO RUN COAL BOARD
description: Ian MacGregor, the 70-year-old American chairman of the state-owned British Steel Corporation, will leave that job to take the reins of Britain's troubled coal industry on Sept. 1.

title: Nancy Reagan Narrates 'Carnival of the Animals'
description: When Camille Saint-Saens wrote the music, ''Carnival of the Animals,'' in 1886, he called it a ''grand zoological fantasy.''

title: SENECA OIL CO reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
2 Win $3.6 Million In Jersey's Lotto
description: Two men were declared the winners today of more than $1.8 million each in a Pick-6 Lotto drawing held by the state lottery.

title: CONVEST ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: SALES OF RECORDS ON THE RISE
description: After four years of plummeting sales, the recording industry finally appears to be on the way up. It is being propelled by several hit albums, aggressive price-cutting and marketing by the record companies, and the comeback of consumer spending -abetted by teen-agers' retreat from arcade video games.

title: Water Rate Rise Upheld by Court
description: A state appellate court today upheld a $4.18 million increase in rates for the Hackensack Water Company. It ruled that state agencies could rely on their own experts instead of taking the word of those proposing or contesting rate changes.

title: FUNDS VOTED FOR PHOTO DRIVER LICENSES
description: The Legislature voted this morning to finance a plan to require photographs on New York State driver's licenses. Passage of the measure followed 11 years of debate on the matter.

title: ARAFAT'S DOOR REMAINS SHUT
description: To the Editor:

title: Gillies Out Two Weeks
description: Clark Gillies, the Islanders' veteran left wing, will be sidelined for at least two weeks after spraining a medial collateral ligament in his left knee during Sunday night's 4-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: INTEGRATED CIRCUITS INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect 2-for-1 stock splits approved on Feb. 6, 1982 and Feb. 5, 1983.

title: WILD CELEBRATIONS SWEEP RALEIGH
description: Not since the days of the 1974 national championship team of David Thompson and Tom Burleson have the students at North Carolina State celebrated its success in basketball with such fervor.

title: Coors Moves Account From Bates
description: Much to the surprise of its agency of four years, Ted Bates Advertising/New York, the Adolph Coors Company has switched its main brand, Coors Premium Beer, to Foote, Cone & Belding, Chicago, which has been accumulating Coors assignments since 1979.

title: Ryder Unit Stake
description: The Capital Assurance Company, a unit of Ryder System Inc., has purchased a one-eighth interest in the First New York Syndicate Corporation. Robert S. Youpa, president of Capital Assurance, and Patrick J. Cesarano, president of Ryder's insurance division, will join the board of First New York Syndicate.

title: Jury Is Selected For Ayala Trial
description: A jury of nine women and seven men was selected today in the trial of Tony Ayala, the highly ranked junior-middleweight boxer charged with breaking into the apartment of a 30-year-old woman on New Year's Day and then raping and beating her.

title: Georgia-Pacific Energy Settlement
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation announced it would receive a $35.5 million initial cash settlement this year stemming from a natural gas contract dispute between Texaco Inc. and the Louisiana Power and Light Company.

title: A Pitch for Governor
description: Jim Bunning, the former Philadelphia right-hander who pitched the famous Father's Day perfect game against the Mets in 1964, announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor of Kentucky.

title: Arson Cited in Stable Fire
description: A fire that killed 12 horses and a pony in a stable here Sunday was the work of an arsonist, fire officials said today. ''It appears someone broke in the building and the fire was set in the hay,'' said Capt. Emil Nardone of the Fire Department. He said the department's arson squad wasinvestigating the fire that engulfed the Warren Street Stable, where privately owned horses were boarded.

title: Another Session In N.B.A. Talks
description: Faced with a threatened strike set for next Saturday, negotiators for the National Basketball Association held an unannounced threehour bargaining session Sunday with the players union. Later, both sides agreed to still another news blackout on the talks, which are aimed at achieving a collective bargaining agreement to replace one that expired 10 months ago.

title: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
Business Week Account
description: Business Week is moving its trade advertising account to Bozell & Jacobs to take advantage of its worldwide facilities. That means it will be leaving Fearon, O'Leary & Kaprielian, its agency of about six years. Billings will be in the $2 million area.

title: Japan Vehicle Exports Rise
description: Japanese vehicle exports rose to 485,800 in February, from 471,890 in January and 472,980 a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

title: People
description: * Alan Goldin has been promoted to senior vice president and group media planning director at Kenyon & Eckhardt Advertising/New York.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: Gridiron Excerpts

title: SCOTT'S LIQUID GOLD INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income after tax credit of $126,000.

title: AUSTRIANS TO DOUBLE POPULATION OF MARES WHERE 31 HAVE DIED
description: The Austrian Government announced plans today to double the number of brood mares at a farm for Lippizaner horses after a virus killed 31 mares and foals.

title: HOME BANKING BY COMPUTER
description: Larry M. Schwartz sits in front of a glowing computer screen in his bedroom in Queens, checking his finances. He shifts money from his money market account to his checking account. He calls up a stock quote. He writes an electronic check.

title: NATIONAL SHOES INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 29.
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $50,000 for the quarter and $880,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: ANECO REINSURANCE CO reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $250,000. c-Net loss after realized investment losses of $98,597.

title: Turkish Publisher On Trial for Incitement
description: Nadir Nadi, publisher of one of Turkey's oldest daily papers, Cumhuriyet, and a leading Turkish journalist, pleaded not guilty before a military court today to a charge of inciting people to violate the law.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Local Phone Companies Entering Bond Market
description: The corporate bond market is faced with a growing number of telephone company financings, in sharp contrast to the period since November 1981, when American Telephone and Telegraph Company affiliates were not making long-term debt offerings.

title: TELEFILE COMPUTER PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
Former Avis President Chosen Boscom Chief
description: When Norton Simon Inc.'s troubled Avis division announced the sudden resignation last month of Howard C. Miller Jr., its president and chief operating officer, it said he planned to pursue ''personal business interests.'' An announcement yesterday by the FMR Corporation made clear that Mr. Miller's new business will be far different from renting cars.

title: LITTLEFIELD, ADAMS & CO reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Wedding With a View

title: E(LECTION) P(ROTECTOR) A(GENCY)?
description: The turmoil at the Environmental Protection Agency raises a fundamental question: Is it acceptable politics - or is it illegal -to use Federal projects and expenditures to influence elections?

title: Tourism Rules Harass French
description: Travel agencies were mobbed today by French tourists trying to arrange foreign vacations before midnight, when the Mitterrand administration's new austerity program cuts their spending money abroad.

title: Deadlocked Jury Gets More Time in Marx Case
description: Jurors in the trial over the estate of Groucho Marx indicated today that they might have broken their deadlock; They asked for another day of deliberations on whether the comedian was defrauded out of $428,000.

title: Vornado Land Sale Terminated
description: Vornado Inc. said an agreement concerning the sale of its 17.7-acre Atlantic City property to Golden Nugget Inc. had been terminated. The company said conditions that had to be fulfilled under the agreement had not been met, but would not elaborate.

title: Pakistan Removes Last Formal Censorship
description: Pakistan's military ruler, Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, has announced the end of press censorship but warned that newspapers should exercise self-restraint and continue to observe self-censorship.

title: CONSUL CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $35,000 for the quarter and $118,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss. Year-ago results reflect accounting changes.

title: Net New Deposits
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that net new deposit receipts at savings and loan associations totaled $8.2 billion in February, down from January's record $14.5 billion. Net new deposit receipts amounted to $761 million in February 1982. The bank board said the month-to-month slowdown reflected a sharp drop in the inflow into money market deposit accounts.

title: Rating the Coaches
description: A year after his retirement, Irv Brown, a former supervisor of officials for the Western Athletic Conference, has offered a referee's-eye view of college basketball coaches. The coach with the best ''total knowledge of the game,'' he said, was Dean Smith of North Carolina, and Jack Hartman of Kansas State was a coach who never got great talent but managed to win anyway.

title: NATCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adams Express Co., Baltimore, has elected Monica C. Loh vice president-investment advisory services.

title: Sharpening Skills
description: The success in recent years of college soccer teams in the New York metropolitan area has not gone unnoticed by the Cosmos, the defending champions of the North American Soccer League.

title: N.A.A.C.P. IS VICTOR IN SUIT OVER NAME
description: The NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. was ordered today to drop the initials ''NAACP'' from its name to avoid public confusion between it and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: TARGETED SOVIET RITUAL
description: To the Editor:

title: ELECTRO-CATHETER CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: Share earnings reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid on March 25, 1983.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, exhibition game, at Vero Beach, Fla. After this second and last exhibition game against the Dodgers, the Yankees will have only four exhibition games before the regular season begins at Seattle next Tuesday night.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Technology, Art and Toys

title: Sampson Battled Other Pressures
description: When basketball fans talk about the pressure on Ralph Sampson these last four years, they are referring to the expectations that the 7-foot-4-inch center would lead the University of Virginia to at least one national championship, which he never did.

title: Topics; Sporting With the Law; At Deuce Too Long
description: Hu Na, the Chinese tennis star who defected to the United States last summer, still waits for word on her request for political asylum. The Immigration Service, bound by its own rules to deal expeditiously with such cases, has let State Department infighting and Chinese sensitivities delay action too long.

title: INFLUENTIAL THEORY ON 'BONDING' AT BIRTH IS NOW QUESTIONED
description: THE widespread concept that there is a special period right after birth during which mothers become ''bonded'' to their infants has prompted many hospitals to allow, even encourage, mothers and fathers to have immediate and prolonged contact with their newborn babies.

title: NESTLE-LE MUR CO reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $17,298, or 1 cent a share, for the latest year and $78,980, or 6 cents a share, for the previous year.

title: STERLING PIPE & SUPPLY CO reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
PLENUM PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
Stocks Show Broad Decline; Dow Off 6.77, To 1,133.32
description: The stock market fell broadly yesterday in much slower trading as concern over increasing interest rates and profit taking again weakened prices.

title: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
Clack, Ex-Giant, Put on Probation
description: Jim Clack, a lineman for the Giants from 1978 until his retirement in 1981, received three years probation today after plea bargaining to a charge of misdemeanor possession of cocaine.

title: CHRYSLER SETS LARGE SHARE SALE
description: The Chrysler Corporation will issue 26 million common shares today, in an unusually large and complex deal intended to eliminate some $1.1 billion in preferred shares now held by Chrysler's creditors.

title: CALVI'S FAMILY ASKS NEW INQUEST
description: The family of the late Roberto Calvi asked the High Court today to order a new inquiry into how the chairman of the bankrupt Banco Ambrosiano died. The original verdict was suicide.

title: TECHNOLOGY AND TRADITION MELD IN AFRICA
description: roof kitchen huts scrubbing utensils of wood and pottery. Children scamper around in the dust with improvised playthings. Here and there, people hoe a vegetable patch, make bricks of clay to dry in the sun or draw buckets of cloudy water from a family well.

title: LeFlore Is Suspended
description: Ron LeFlore, the White Sox outfielder who faces a drug charge stemming from a raid on his Chicago apartment last September, was placed back on suspension by the team yesterday pending the outcome of his trial on April 14.

title: 3 OF 7 POLICEMEN CONVICTED IN NEW ORLEANS RIGHTS CASE
description: A Federal jury convicted three New Orleans policemen today of violating the civil rights of a black man who charged that he was brutally interrogated in a hunt for the killer of a white police officer. Four other policemen were acquitted of all charges.

title: U.N. Chief and Andropov Discuss Afghan Situation
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar met today with Yuri V. Andropov for talks that included what the Tass press agency called ''ways of normalizing the situation around Afghanistan.''

title: Opportunity, Is Fumbled By Walker
description: In losing their first four games, the New Jersey Generals have fumbled 15 times and their opponents have recovered 11 of those fumbles.

title: Sotheby's Venture
description: Lord Harlech, a former British ambassador to Washington, has joined a New York business group interested in making a takeover bid for Sotheby's, the world's largest art auctioneers, The Daily Telegraph is reporting in today's issue. The newspaper said that Lord Harlech had joined a ''board-in-waiting'' formed by Stephen Swid and Marshall Cogan, co-chairmen of General Felt Industries, based in Saddle Brook, N.J. The two hold 14.6 percent of Sotheby's stock.

title: IRAN ASKS HELP TO FIGHT OIL SLICK
description: Iran asked its neighbors in the Persian Gulf today to help break up a huge oil slick that is threatening marine life and coastal desalting plants and power stations.

title: Indian Ocean Isle Gets a New Cabinet
description: Prime Minister Aneerood Jugnauth formed a new Cabinet today after the resignation of 11 of his 19 ministers last week.

title: US SHOE CORP reports earnings for qtr to Jan 29.
SUNSHINE MINING CO reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
BANKS GRANT BALDWIN WEEK'S DELAY ON DEBT
description: The financially troubled Baldwin-United Corporation said that its banks had agreed at the last minute to a one-week extension of $440 million in debt payments that had been due yesterday.

title: LOMAK PETROLEUM reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
SENTRY THIEVES REPORTEDLY HAD MOB PROTECTION
description: A court document indicated yesterday that the thieves who stole millions of dollars from the Sentry Armored Courier Corporation had paid organized crime for protection.

title: TUESDAY, MARCH 29, 1983; International
description: U.S. Steel said it is talking to British Steel about importing unfinished steel from the British concern for use in the Fairless Works and possibly other plants. The announcement set off a furor in the steelworkers' union, which said any such move could cost thousands of jobs. The union's local leadership had just accepted major concessions in wages and benefits. (Page A1.) Ian MacGregor will leave British Steel to take over Britain's coal industry. (D4.)

title: METRO-NORTH UNION OFFERS A NEW PROPOSAL BUT TALKS BREAK OFF
description: Leaders of the striking conductors and trainmen on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad yesterday put forward a modified proposal eliminating bonuses and easing manning requirements on partly empty trains.

title: COAST GUARD'S NONEMERGENCY RESCUES ARE TOO COSTLY, PANEL SAYS
description: The Coast Guard is spending too much of its time and money on nonemergency, or ''convenience,'' rescues of pleasure boaters and should concentrate on actual saving of lives, a study recommends.

title: DANCE: 4 SOLOS AND A DUET
description: SOLOS can be among the most challenging of all dance forms, for performers of solos are always alone in space. Yet, at the same time, they confront an audience. No ensembles and, usually, no fancy scenery assist them. Instead, they must communicate to the viewer solely through the power and beauty of their gestures.

title: A BOLD SHOT LEADS GOLFER TO SUCCESS
description: T here were several excellent shots, such as Ben Crenshaw's 50-yard wedge into the cup for an eagle 3 at the second hole, and many others that went astray, including John Cook's tee shot at the 18th hole that went into the water and cost him the tournament.

title: A BLACK PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDACY IS WEIGHED FOR '84
description: In a series of meetings here and around the country, black leaders have been debating the merits of a symbolic Presidential candidacy in 1984 by a prominent black.

title: Martha Graham Troupe Planning Theater Party
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company will hold a benefit theater performance and party on May 5.

title: Remembering Melissa
description: Two weeks ago a 14-year-old girl named Melissa Putney knelt on a Maryland railroad track, made the sign of the cross and waited for Amtrak 141. ''I am a weak person,'' she had written to her mother a few hours earlier, ''not able to handle the weight of life.''

title: Another Hedberg Due Any Moment
description: Anders Hedberg didn't fly to St. Louis on Monday with the rest of the Rangers, who had a game there against the Blues last night. The 32-year-old Swedish forward flew in alone yesterday morning, arriving shortly before 11 o'clock and taking a taxi straight to the Checkerdome for his team's pregame skate.

title: RANGERS DOWN 2-0, WIN
description: Earlier this season, if the Rangers fell behind by 2-0 in the opening seven and a half minutes of play, the way they did here tonight, it would have almost guaranteed a long, frustrating evening for them.

title: Several Italian Officials Warned of Investigations
description: Municipal officials in Rome and Milan were warned today that they were being investigated for possible abuses of office.

title: Bureau Director Is Named
description: Stephen Higgins, acting director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, was named today to the post permanently by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: SUZANNE: I have a problem with food. I eat. I mean I eat disgusting amounts of food. You can't imagine how much I eat. I go on binges. Then I start thinking about all those calories - and I make myself throw up. I can't stop myself. I hate myself, and I don't believe I'm telling you this.

title: REAGAN TOLD HE FACES SETBACK ON WITHHOLDING
description: A top Republican leader in the House of Representatives said today that if President Reagan carried out his pledge to veto a popular bill to repeal the 1982 law on withholding taxes from dividends and interest, the President could expect to be overridden.

title: Norstar Buys Bank Stake
description: As part of its agreement with the New York State Banking Board, First American Bankshares Inc., a bank holding company based in Washington, has sold its majority interest in New York's Bank of Commerce to Norstar Bancorp Inc. of Albany for $34.4 million.

title: MSR EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Market Place; Europeans Bullish on U.S.
description: EUROPEAN investors pay a lot of attention to currency risk. As a general rule, they like to find a country with a favorable long-term outlook for its currency before they invest in its securities. Otherwise, a weakening currency can reduce profits, or inflate losses, when stocks are sold.

title: MISSION WEST PROPERTIES reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Including tax credits of $138,000 for the latest first quarter and $178,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: A Shift at the Music Hall
description: W hen ''Porgy and Bess'' opens officially at Radio City Music Hall on April 7, it will be a sweet moment for the 90-member black cast. The shapely legs best known on the famous stage - over 5,000 pairs since the Rockettes began in 1932 - are all white.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,409,000 for the quarter and $4,132,000 for the year. c-After income from discontinued operations of $27,000 and a loss on the sale of discontinued operations of $710,000.

title: BEHAVIOR THERAPY FOR TROUBLED PETS
description: THE Duffy family of Brookline, Mass., was in crisis. Their 2-yearold golden retriever, Daisy, had suddenly reverted to puppyhood. She soiled the rugs, cowered under the table with the cat and refused to go out. Larry Duffy said they must get rid of her. Merry Duffy said, ''If Daisy goes, I go.'' The children cried. What to do?

title: 1,600 Police Fight Smugglers In Egypt With No Casualties
description: About 1,600 policemen had a two-hour gunfight with drug smugglers on camels in the desert outside Cairo today, the authorities said.

title: CIRCUS SET FOR 10 WEEKS AT GARDEN
description: TO absolutely no one's surprise but to a lot of children's delight, the circus is back in town. The 113th edition of the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus began a 10-week engagement at Madison Square Garden last night. A second unit began a shorter, two-week run at the D.C. Armory in Washington at the same time. The show is billed as ''all new,'' and there are many new acts, but the animals, the clowns, the aerialists, the noise and the smells are exactly as they have always been.

title: IN PRAISE OF BACON: LOVE AT FIRST BITE
description: I'M not a person to appreciate the subtler tastes in food. I like my steak rare and jalapenos raw. Delicacy in flavor passes over my palate unregistered. I can't help it. It's the way I am. That brings me to the subject of bacon.

title: GIBBS LYONS
description: Gibbs Lyons, former president of the First-Stamford National Bank and Trust Company, died Sunday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital.

title: SORG PRINTING CO INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
Peabo Bryson Presents Palladium Soul Concert
description: Peabo Bryson is the Pavarotti of soul singers. He has a cherubic presence, plenty of wholesome romantic appeal and a pure, booming tenor voice. Mr. Bryson writes his own love songs, though, and his ornate vocal lines come from gospel music rather than opera.

title: FOR EASTER: CONFECTIONS TO PLEASE THE EYE AND PALATE
description: THE art of the confectioner is never in more dazzling evidence than at Easter, a tribute, perhaps, to the inspiration springtime provides. For weeks now, shelves and windows of candy and pastry shops have been blossoming forth with a storybook array of chicks and rabbits, flowers and eggs, trimmed with delicate and edible pastel frostings.

title: CATHOLICS REPORT ZIMBABWE ATROCITIES
description: The Roman Catholic bishops of Zimbabwe said today that ''wanton atrocities and brutalities'' were still being committed by Government forces in their campaign to suppress armed deserters from the army.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Von Hayes, Philadelphia's expensive new slugging star, will be out through the first week of the season, and perhaps longer, because of a torn muscle in his left thigh. ... A shoulder separation will keep Willie McGee out of the St. Louis outfield for a week. ... Sugar Ray Seales, gold medal winner in boxing at the 1972 Olympics, underwent surgery for three and a half hours to repair a detached retina in his left eye. He had the same surgery on his right eye Saturday, after fighting the last two years with blurred vision. ... Jay Donald Feeley, with a 45-37 record in three years as Fairleigh Dickinson's basketball coach, will not be rehired.

title: ANTITRUST LAW LIMITS PROPOSED
description: The Reagan Administration, as part of an effort to aid in restoring the international competitiveness of American industry, proposes to abolish the triple-damage penalty in most antitrust lawsuits. Instead, private parties would be limited to recovering only the actual amount of the damages they suffer.

title: No Union Seen In Nissan Plant
description: The head of the Nissan Motor Company's new truck plant in Smyrna, Tenn., said there was no need to have unions in the highly automated plant, which will eventually employ 2,000 workers.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 4 percent stock dividend paid in May 1982.

title: A RICH DIVERSITY IS THE KEY INGREDIENT IN NEW YORK'S ABUNDANT FOOD SCENE
description: Spurred by an increase of foreign visitors and the growing sophistication of the local audience, New York is strengthening its traditional role as the country's most demanding and diverse city for food. This is true of both its restaurants and its retail shops. Diversity is the city's specialty, closely followed by professionalism in management. Despite the current recession being felt by many restaurants and fancy food shops, New York is now the world's leading market for high-quality wines and luxury food products.

title: SAUDI BOARD MEMBER
description: To the Editor:

title: POWER PLANT ON S.I. DELAYED INDEFINITELY BY CUOMO MOVE
description: A plan to build a $2.1 billion coal- and garbage-fueled power plant on Staten Island on the shore of the Arthur Kill was ''indefinitely postponed'' yesterday by the Power Authority of the State of New York.

title: BERNARD L. WHELAN, PILOT WHO LEARNED FROM WRIGHTS, DIES
description: Bernard L. Whelan, one of the nation's first licensed airplane pilots who was taught to fly by the Wright brothers and became a vice president of the former United Aircraft Corporation, died Sunday at his winter home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 92 years old and also lived in Hanover, N.H.

title: Sale by Braniff Cleared
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge yesterday approved an agreement for the Braniff International Corporation to sell 20 Boeing 727-200 aircraft to People Express Airlines, after People Express increased its offer to appease Braniff's creditors.

title: TRADE GAP WIDENED IN FEBRUARY
description: The nation's merchandise trade deficit widened slightly to $3.58 billion in February despite a plunge in oil imports to the lowest level in more than a decade, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 2 OSCAR-NOMINEE FILMS NOW SEEK EAST'S VOTES
description: The 400 members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences who live in the New York area may be given a last-minute chance to vote for the best foreign-language film.

title: W.R.G. Ends Account At National Geographic
description: Wells, Rich, Greene has resigned the National Geographic magazine account after a seven-year relationship. Kenneth Olshan, chairman of W.R.G./U.S.A., having noted that the Geo people were ''wonderful to work with,'' added, ''But the relatively small budget didn't allow us to give them the kind of management and staff time we like to commit to a client on a consistent basis.''

title: CONCERNS IN MOSCOW: MISSILES AND U.S. AND SOVIET LEADERS
description: The dominant impression from 10 days of conversations with officials in the Soviet Union is that they are waiting for developments in three areas: to see whether the United States will have the necessary political support to deploy new missiles in Western Europe; to gauge whether politics will push the Reagan Administration toward compromises, and, above all, to find out how the Soviet Union will ultimately fare under the new leadership of Yuri V. Andropov.

title: 'A MARRIAGE,' TRACING COURTSHIP AND DIVORCE
description: TED (Ric GitLin) and Nancy (Isabel Glasser) grow from starry-eyed high school kids into disenchanted young professionals on the brink of a divorce in ''A Marriage,'' Sandy Tung's knowing and believable portrait of their union.

title: FASSBINDER STORY
description: ''THE WIZARD OF BABYLON,'' which opens today at the Film Forum, is another footnote to the career of the late Rainer Werner Fassbinder, which means that it's something not to be missed by anyone interested in the career of that rare, disturbing film maker. It's an 82-minute documentary on the making of Fassbinder's last film, ''Querelle,'' scheduled to open here in the near future. The documentary was produced by Dieter Schidor, the producer of ''Querelle'' and one of its principal actors.

title: STAGE: 'SLACKS AND TOPS,' ONE OF A 'TRIPLE FEATURE'
description: A PLAYWRIGHT with a strong, fresh voice will always stand out sooner or later, but there's a sure way to expedite the process: put one of his one-act plays on the same bill with works by writers who speak in more familiar and measured tones.

title: YOUTH IS SET ABLAZE ON A DARE
description: A 17-year-old youth was set on fire at a party here early today after he doused himself with gasoline and dared a friend to ignite him, the Stony Point police reported.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: THE BLENDER REDISCOVERED: A KEY TO NEW SAUCES
description: A decade ago a blender was the cynosure of ''modern'' American kitchens, a shiny electric obelisk that could do it all - or at least all the tasks of that relatively ingenuous age, namely mixing batters, pureeing soups and frothing drinks. Then along came the flashy foreign food processor, with its French accent, Porsche-like motor and more blades than a lawn-mower factory. As home cooks became enamored of this exotic appliance, blenders were consigned to milkshake duty, or worse, stored away beside dusty fondue pots, waffle irons that hadn't been used since the kids left home and Rube Goldbergesque vegetable choppers purchased years ago from a rapidfire television announcer.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Brasilinvest S.A. Investimentos Participacoes e Negocios, Sao Paulo, said it extended its offer to acquire the First Women's Bank of New York for $15 a share, or $5.6 million.

title: Bryant Park's New Booth
description: T he bookstalls and flower sellers making inroads against the drug dealers in Bryant Park will get reinforcement today when the city's first discount ticket booth for music and dance opens.

title: PADDY FLOOD
description: Paddy Flood, a fight manager and former boxer, died Monday night at New York Hospital after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 48 years old.

title: METRO NORTH UNION GETS JOB GUARANTEE PROPOSAL
description: The Metro-North Commuter Railroad yesterday gave leaders of the striking conductors and trainmen a proposed draft of a crew-size rule, including a guarantee that none of the present conductors and trainmen would be laid off or furloughed.

title: No.1 to Be No.2
description: Avis may not know the secret, but the United States Auto Club has arranged for Hertz to be No.2 at the Indianapolis 500 this year. The No.1 car-rental company decided to sponsor Roger Penske's racing team, as the main sponsor for Al Unser's car and as the ''associate'' sponsor of the one driven by Rick Mears, the defending national champion.

title: DR. CLARK CALLED 'SELFLESS PIONEER'
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark, the artificial heart recipient, was eulogized before 1,300 mourners today as a seemingly ordinary man who became ''a selfless pioneer.''

title: WINE TALK
description: ITALY has been described as one giant vineyard, from the Alps to Sicily. That's a bit overdone. There are cities, beaches, highways and a few mountaintops where no grapes are grown - at least not at the moment. But there is one area where vines are really king: Emilia-Romagna.

title: SOLARON CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
Syria Says It Expects Israelis to Attack
description: Syria said today that it expected it would be attacked again by Israel.

title: Alexander Munsell, 87; Gave Away Inheritance
description: Alexander Ector Orr Munsell, the Harvard-educated scion of a family of bankers and industrialists who gave away a fortune and lived a life of austerity and radical politics, died of a heart attack Saturday at Beekman Downtown Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Kissinger Says U.S. Remains Superior in Arms Technology
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that the Soviet Union had built up its arms more rapidly than the United States in recent years but that American military technology remained superior.

title: PEKING STILL GRIM ON U.S. TIES
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang told United States members of Congress today that Chinese-American relations were unsatisfactory and were not improved by Secretary of State George P. Shultz's visit last month.

title: CHANGES IN FLORIDA COURT ATTACKED AS DETRIMENTAL
description: Florida's three-year-old experiment to reduce the burden on its Supreme Court may have gone too far and stripped the court of some necessary powers, according to critics and even some supporters of the effort.

title: Speeding Cited in Car Crash; Fatal to 3 in; Secret Service
description: The sheriff's automobile that collided with a car carrying three Secret Service agents preceding Queen Elizabeth II to Yosemite National Park was traveling about 75 miles an hour, the authorities said today.

title: FUNDSNET INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net loss. Results for the previous year are for the period from Feb. 25, 1981, when the company acquired its funds transfer business, to Dec. 31, 1981.

title: PRIEST 'UNAFRAID' OF MOB AT CHURCH
description: The Rev. Francis Ciezadlo says he was not frightened by the mob that burst into his church Sunday, cursing and screaming at former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and Representative Harold Washington, the Chicago Democratic mayoral candidate.

title: French Internists on Strike
description: Thousands of internists marched through central Paris today as part of a week-old strike that has crippled hospital services throughout the country. The doctors are protesting the growing difficulty in finding permanent jobs in France's university hospital network and in private practice.

title: THRIFTY CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: The 1982 net and share earnings for the quarter and 6 months were restated to reflect change in accounting for compensated absences.

title: Outlook for Canada
description: The head of Canada's central bank told Parliament today that, if Canada pursues a cautious economic policy, prospects are reasonably good for an economic recovery that will cut unemployment without rekindling inflation. Gerald K. Bouey, governor of the Bank of Canada, testified at the House of Commons Finance Committee.

title: Ciba-Geigy Deal
description: Ciba-Geigy A.G. said it had reached agreement in principle to acquire the Titmus Eurocon Group, a manufacturer and distributor of contact lenses and lens care products based in Aschaffenburg, West Germany. Terms were not disclosed.

title: NICARAGUA SAYS HONDURAN FIRED ON BORDER POSTS
description: The Foreign Ministry charged today that a 15-member Honduran patrol fired on two Nicaraguan border posts late Sunday afternoon and briefly tried to cross into Nicaragua.

title: Manager Responds
description: On Sunday, Frank Pastore, a Cincinnati pitcher, made some mildly disparaging remarks about Alex Trevino, suggesting obliquely that, although Trevino was a regular, he was not the team's top catcher.

title: Interest Rates Show Declines; Distorting Factors Seen
description: Interest rates moved lower yesterday, with the longer-term Treasury debt maturities posting the largest declines. But dealers said that actual credit market conditions are distorted this week by a variety of technical factors.

title: EDWARD KASPAREK
description: Edward Kasparek, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Mechanics and Farmers Savings Bank, died Sunday at his home.

title: COW MANURE FUELING POWER SYSTEM
description: A bitter north wind rattled the door of the large shed on, Robert Foster's farm, the largest dairy farm in the Champlain Valley. But inside, Mr. Foster's generator made the shed a virtual steambath.

title: 2 CONGRESSMEN, IN SALVADOR, ASK END TO STATE-OF-SIEGE LAW
description: Two United States Representatives visited prisons holding hundreds of political prisoners today and called for an end to the state-of-siege law here.

title: COMMUTERS' DIARY: FORTITUDE AND FRUSTRATION
description: For three weeks, 160,000 commuters have been waiting for a train. Struck with strikes, the regular riders of Metro-North and N.J. Transit, like any endangered species, have tried to adapt. At first, they could exult in their hardiness. But after days of rising early, arriving late and waiting in the rain, what was novelty has become drudgery.

title: Plan Ties U.S. Raises To Performance on Job
description: The Federal Government's top personnel officer today proposed to make annual pay increases, now largely automatic, dependent on job performance.

title: Seamen's Plans To Buy Thrift
description: The Seamen's Bank for Savings announced that it plans to acquire the Heritage Savings and Loan Association of Manchester, Conn. An agreement has been reached between the managements of Seamen's and Heritage under which Seamen's would pay $18 for each share of Heritage stock.

title: General Cinema Debentures Sold
description: The General Cinema Corporation, which is a major soft drink bottler as well as motion picture exhibitor, yesterday sold $100 million of 25-year 10 percent subordinated debentures at par through underwriters headed by Blyth Eastman Dillon Paine Webber Inc.

title: INTEREST TAX: TIME FOR A LITTLE MORE ANGER
description: To the Editor:

title: BUCKS' CLINCHING PUT OFF
description: Frank Johnson and Jeff Ruland got 24 points each tonight as the Washington Bullets beat Milwaukee, 94-81, and kept the Bucks from clinching their third straight National Basketball Association divisional title.

title: Careers; Achieving Computer Literacy
description: WHAT is computer literacy? Stripped of the mystique that has surrounded the concept for some time, it turns out to be simply another skill.

title: PENN TRAFFIC CO reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: b-Net loss. c-After a loss of $1,263,000 from discontinued operations.

title: ICH CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
Mets Get Bradley, Outfielder, in Trade
description: The Mets ended their search for a right-handed hitter today when they traded two minor league pitchers to the Los Angeles Dodgers for Mark Bradley, an outfielder who drove in 101 runs last year in the Class AAA Pacific Coast League.

title: The U.N. Today; March 30, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, Legal Subcommittee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

description: G overnor Cuomo came to his 57th-floor office at the World Trade Center late Monday afternoon for a news conference about the state's newly enacted budget.

description: Results for the latest quarter and year include a gain of $5,093,000, or 24 cents a share, from the sale of one- third of the company's interest in perdrug Stores PLC.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''To look down to an endless future with both of us sitting here with these horrible missiles aimed at each other, and the only thing preventing a holocaust is just so long as no one pulls the trigger, this is unthinkable.'' - President Reagan. (A15:1.)

title: Olson Shifts to Arizona
description: Choosing challenge over championship, Lute Olson, the most successful basketball coach in Iowa's history, quit his job yesterday to take over as head coach at Arizona, the Pacific-10 Conference's least successful team.

title: WRITTEN ROMANCE IN THE STACKS
description: With a collection aimed at the heart, the Westville Public Library thrives in this suburban town of 3,600 people in east central Illinois. Although a larger library in nearby Danville offers more books and services and longer hours, the small Westville library can claim perhaps the world's largest and most systematic collection of paperback romance novels.

title: Little Change In Eurobonds
description: Trading in Eurobonds was quiet today and prices of dollar bonds were barely changed from Monday's close.

title: U.S. WILL SUE COMPANIES FOR COST OF CLEANUP AT WASTE SITE ON COAST
description: The Justice Department says it plans to sue for millions of dollars in cleanup costs from some or all of more than 200 companies that dumped toxic wastes at the Stringfellow Acid Pits near Riverside, Calif.

title: General Electric
description: The General Electric Company, entering the personal computer market in a roundabout way, has announced plans to lease personal computers made by leading manufacturers to commercial customers, or to individuals with good credit ratings. The manufacturers of the computers G.E. will rent include the International Business Machines Corporation, Apple Computer Inc. and the Hewlett-Packard Company.

title: France Starts Money Curbs
description: The French Government's restrictions on currency for foreign travel came into effect today and customs officers at the two main Paris airports began checking to insure that travelers complied with the new law.

title: Rite-Aid Net Climbs 86%
description: The Rite-Aid Corporation of Shiremanstown, Pa., a retail drug, grocery and specialty retailer, yesterday reported fourth-quarter earnings for the period ended Feb. 26 rose 86.7 percent, to $24 million, or $1.14 a share, from $12.9 million, or 61 cents a share, reported in the quarter a year ago. Sales rose 28.4 percent, to $371.6 million, for the most recent period, compared with $289.3 million a year ago.

title: Advertising; Food Ads In Sunday Papers Up
description: AMONG the smaller changes wrought by a changing society, but interesting nevertheless, is that there has been an increase in retail food advertising in Sunday newspapers.

title: SIM-KAR LIGHTING FIXTURE CO reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
Cut Taxes One Year at a Time
description: Only weeks ago this page, like the White House, argued the case for accelerating the 10 percent tax cut that is due on July 1. Now, with economic recovery in sight but future deficits swelling to mountainous proportions, the debate has shifted again. Republicans as well as Democrats in Congress wonder whether there should be any tax cut at all.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have always presumed that evaporated milk and condensed milk were one and the same, but a friend disagrees. Can you tell me if there is a difference?

title: PROSPECTS FOR NEW AIR FARES
description: After four years of intensive fare wars, most of the nation's airlines are rallying behind a proposal that would eliminate a good part of deep discounting in many markets and restore a simpler structure that resembles what existed before deregulation of the industry.

title: PEP BOYS, MANNY MOE & JACK reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: The share earnings results were adjusted for the 3-for-1 stock split payable April 25, which was declared earlier.

title: U.N. TO PRESS AFGHAN EFFORTS
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today that he had received ''renewed encouragement'' from Yuri V. Andropov to pursue United Nations efforts to mediate the war in Afghanistan.

title: PLANT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-After a tax charge of $362,000. c-Net income after a tax credit of $728,000.

title: Zambia Seeks Talks on Debt
description: Zambia will apply to creditor governments for a rescheduling of its official debt, President Kenneth Kaunda told a news conference today.

title: NO MORE BLUEBIRDS
description: It's no secret that the United States and the Soviet Union prepare incessantly for war, believing that readiness for war will prevent war. Nor is it surprising that many sensible people expect these war preparations to go on forever, barring an accidental cataclysm, or until both parties collapse under the weight of their munitions bills.

title: WARMING IS STUDIED
description: Scientists studying air pollution that blankets millions of square miles in the Arctic report it was much heavier than they had expected this winter, raising concern about its effect on the world's climate.

title: TEAMSTERS' LEADERS DESCRIBED AS CRIME AIDE
description: Government prosecutors urged a Federal district judge today to sentence Roy L. Williams to prison and force his resignation as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to Feb 26.
NEW DIET CAN LOWER FOOD COSTS
description: A family of four can eat a well-balanced diet for $58 a week by using beans instead of meat for protein and drinking fruit juice instead of soft drinks, the United States Department of Agriculture says. The amount is based on the current maximum weekly food stamp allotment for a family comprised of a mother and three children, aged 3 to 14.

title: RATH'S NEW LEADER UP FROM THE RANKS
description: Lyle Taylor was elected president of the Rath Packing Company of Waterloo, Iowa, at its annual meeting last week. Unlike the prototypical chief executive officer, Mr. Taylor does not hold an M.B.A. degree from a prestigious business school - or from any other. Nor did he graduate from college. But he knows, from firsthand experience, virtually every aspect of his company's business.

title: Oil Futures Trading Set
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade will begin trading in crude oil futures contracts Wednesday. Such contracts obligate the holder to buy or sell a set amount of crude at a set price by a specific date. Analysts said crude futures traders are likely to be those who already deal in commodity futures.

title: NEW INQUEST SET IN CALVI'S DEATH
description: A British court today overturned a suicide verdict in the death of Roberto Calvi, the Italian banker. It ordered a new inquest because of the way the original one was conducted.

title: BROOKE SHIELDS LOSES COURT CASE
description: The state's highest court ruled today that a photographer who took nude pictures of the actress-model Brooke Shields when she was 10 years old could continue to market the photos as long as he did not sell them to pornographic publications.

title: Brink's Trial Jury To Be Anonymous
description: A judge decided yesterday to select an anonymous jury for the Federal trial of six defendants on charges involving a series of armed robberies, including the 1981 Brink's robbery and murders in Rockland County.

title: 3 NEW BISHOPS TO SERVE MILITARY
description: Three new Bishops have been appointed to assist Terence Cardinal Cooke in his role as chief pastor to Catholics in the military services, the Archdiocese of New York announced yesterday.

title: BONN BUDGET CUTTERS MAP WAR ON 'PEACE SCHOLARS'
description: The former West German Army colonel looked hopefully around the bright white walls of his newly founded Research Institute for Peace Politics.

title: TV: IMAGES OF AMERICA IN 'JOURNEY'
description: ''AMERICAN JOURNEY'' tries nothing less than to swallow up America, define it, quantify it, dig up its roots and find out what it's all about. Its inspiration is Alexis de Tocqueville, who wrote ''Democracy in America'' in 1835, but its sensibility is provided by Richard Reeves, a political journalist, who wrote a book called ''American Journey'' from which the program is loosely adapted. The two-hour public broadcasting film, full of elegant images, will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: THE FEDERAL BURDEN IN REFUGEES MISERY

description: M arty Glickman, the noted sailor, athlete and sports announcer, recalls docking his boat at a Georgia marina on a lovely fall afternoon two years ago and receiving no help whatsoever from the marina attendants.

title: MORRISON INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 26.
description: b-Including income of $567,394 from discontinued operations.

title: A.T.& T. Lists Prices for Phones
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today announced ''a guaranteed price list'' that shows consumers how much they would pay to buy the telephone they now rent if they wait until next year to make a decision. It lists the standard rotary dial instrument for $19.95.

title: ISLANDERS RESPECT IMPROVED CAPITALS
description: Underestimation can be a problem. The Islanders found that out at about this time last season, when they were nearly eliminated by the Pittsburgh Penguins in the opening round of the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: BRITAIN CALLS FOR LATIN TALKS AS THE U.N. DEBATE ON NICARAGUA ENDS
description: A five-day Security Council debate requested by Nicaragua came to an inconclusive end today, with Britain calling for a meeting of Central American countries to resolve the region's crisis.

description: THE DENTIST AND THE EMPRESS. The Adventures of Dr. Tom Evans in Gas- Lit Paris. By Gerald Carson. Illustrat- ed. 222 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $15.95.

COLUMBINE EXPLORATION reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
N.B.A.  Talks Called Hopeful
description: After almost four hours of negotiations yesterday, the National Basketball Association and the player union both called the talks harmonious and said th0t serious efforts were being made to avert a walkout after Saturday night's games. They agreed to hold another collective bargaining session this afternoon.

title: CONVENT BLENDS TASTES OF TWO CULTURES
description: IT is 7 A.M. and in their convent perched high in the western foothills of the Napa Valley, seven Mexican nuns from the order of Las Hermanas Guadalupana De La Salle have finished their morning devotions. Headed by Sister Veronica, superior of the small religious community, they leave the convent, cross the courtyard that overlooks hills of grapevines and, as they do every day but Sunday, file into the kitchen of the Mont La Salle Novitiate school and winery near Napa, Calif.

title: CITIZENS GROWTH PROPERTIES (CO) reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.

title: OUTLOOK IS BRIGHT FOR TROUT SEASON
description: B arring a dramatic change in the weather, the opening day of the trout season Friday in New York State should be one of the best in more than a decade.

title: Vault Mark Set
description: Brad Pursley of Abilene Christian bettered the American outdoor and the American collegiate pole vault records today when he cleared 18 feet 10 1/2 inches in a dual meet with Angelo State University. Pursley's height broke the record of 18-9 1/2 set by Dave Volz of Indiana on June 26, 1982.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MARCH 30, 1983
description: International President Reagan was conciliatory on the issue of missile defense while terming critics of his call for research into it ''irresponsible.'' Speaking with six reporters in the Oval Office, Mr. Reagan said that if the United States could develop a comprehensive defense against missiles, he could foresee some president offering to share the knowledge with the Soviet Union to spur an elimination of all offensive nuclear missiles. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Soviet leaders await developments in three key areas, according to impressions from 10 days of talks with them in Moscow. Their concerns are to see whether Washington will have the necessary political support to deploy new missiles in Western Europe, to gauge whether politics will push the Reagan Administration toward compromises and, above all, to learn how they will fare under the new leadership of Yuri V. Andropov. (A1:5-6.)

title: SEARCH FOR KILLER OF NEWSBOY,14, IS PRESSED ON L.I.
description: Ten days after a 14-year-old newsboy was stabbed to death, dozens of police detectives continue to track leads, following a maze of tips that have still not led to a breakthrough.

title: HORNBECK OFFSHORE SERVICES reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Those people who live and work there see a peculiar Manhattan every day, a Manhattan made up of individual gray blocks of concrete, signs that flash ''Don't Walk'' in red lights, the inside of elevators, the advertisements in subway cars, the back of the man ahead in the coffee line at the delicatessen, the stickers against the milky bulletproof divider that say the cabdriver cannot change more than $5 and is allergic to cigarette smoke and the blurry faces of hundreds of people trying not to make eye contact.

title: SANDINIST FACTIONS FIGHT, REAGAN SAYS
description: President Reagan today described the recent fighting between the military and anti-Government forces in Nicaragua as a factional conflict between different elements of the coalition that seized power in Nicaragua in 1979.

title: W.B.C. Rejects King's 2-Bout Bid
description: The World Boxing Council announced today that by a 19-2 vote it had rejected a request by the promoter Don King to hold fights in conjunction with its rival, the World Boxing Association. The decision threatened King's heavyweight championship doubleheader in May.

title: Atari Distribution Plan is Blocked
description: A Federal judge has issued a temporary restraining order barring the Atari video game and computer company from trying to force its wholesale distributors to stop selling competing brands of video games and software.

title: DECISION FILE By Michael deCourcey Hinds; 'Razor Bumps' Case Is Reopened
description: ''Razor bumps go away and stay away as proven in tests at a leading black university,'' North American Philips Corporation contended in advertisements for its ''Black Pro'' shaver.

title: RECITAL: PROGRAM BY MISS GORDONI
description: VIRGINIA COPELAND GORDONI, a soprano whose operatic career over the last generation has carried her to Broadway, national television and La Scala, returned to the Abraham Goodman House Sunday night with a program ranging from Verdi and Cherubini to Wagner and Strauss. Miss Gordoni's uppermost notes were occasionally strained and bent out of tune, but for the most part, this is still a voice of considerable strength in all its registers.

description: b-Net loss.

description: To his Atlanta Hawk teammates, Tom McMillen is Slaprock, named after the cartoon character Schlep-rock in the Flintstones, who moves awkwardly and is always pushing and bumping people.

title: COSTA RICA BOLSTERS PATROLS ON NICARAGUAN BORDER
description: Costa Rica has put its border patrols on alert since a recent sharp increase in the number of Nicaraguans crossing into the country.

description: Morning rain delayed play for two hours today, and officials postponed for at least a day the opening match of Bjorn Borg's final appearance on the Grand Prix circuit.

Media People Magazine Starting Up Again
description: Charles Mandel had barely gotten Media People, his new magazine for the communications industry, started than he shelved it two years ago to join Hearst Magazines as publisher in the magazine development group, which put him in charge of the reformatted Science Digest.

title: NURSE'S AIDE GETS 25 YEARS IN PRISON IN WIDOW'S SLAYING
description: A nurse's aide was sentenced today to 25 years to life in prison for arranging the murder of an elderly widow who she feared was going to cut her out of her will.

title: A Correction: Enrollments
description: An editorial Monday, relying on Board of Education figures, misstated the ethnic composition of New York City's 920,000 schoolchildren; 38.6 percent are black, 31.1 percent Hispanic.

title: Yetnikoff to Stay at CBS
description: Walter Yetnikoff, president of the CBS/Records Group, will not be leaving his post, it was announced yesterday by CBS.

title: REAGAN'S RISKINESS
description: President Reagan startled the world when he called on the ''scientific community in our country, those who gave us nuclear weapons,'' to provide a means of rendering ''nuclear weapons impotent and obsolete.'' As one of those scientists, I do not share Mr. Reagan's optimism.

title: Bourbon St. Jass Band At the Red Blazer Too
description: Bands that play traditional jazz sometimes take the traditions so seriously that their music shows an academic solemnity or they take the traditions so slightly that they drown them in comedy. The Bourbon Street Jass Band, a six-piece group from Boston jointly led by Greg Wall, a saxophonist and clarinetist, and Jon Seiger, a trumpeter, which made its New York debut on Sunday at the Red Blazer Too, Third Avenue near 88th Street, manages to go both ways at once - to mix a keen sensitivity for the styles of the 20's and 30's, an uncommon skill for playing in those styles, and a loose, hanging, high-spirited attitude that energizes their music and exhilarates their listeners.

title: HIGH COURT BARS SELECTIVE TAX ON PUBLISHERS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a state may not subject newspaper and magazine publishers to a tax that is not generally applicable to other businesses.

title: REAGAN GIVES STRONG HINT AT '84 BID
description: President Reagan, offering his strongest hint yet at a possible re-election bid, contended today that a single-term Presidency limited an incumbent's programs and the nation's stability.

title: Stock Oversubscribed At California Federal
description: California Federal Savings and Loan Association's first offering of stock, 15.4 million shares priced at $19 each, was oversubscribed yesterday, according to a spokesman for an underwriting group headed by E.F. Hutton & Company, Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group and Warburg Paribas Becker Inc.

title: Article 065980 -- No Title
description: Stamps worth more than $100,000 were stolen from the Randolph Post Office over the weekend. The police in this suburb south of Boston found a rear door forced open and the heavy steel door to the vault room cut open, as were two safes. A burglar alarm had been disabled and chemical fire extinguishers were sprayed on the vault door, the safes and the floor, apparently to obliterate any fingerprints or shoe marks, a postal inspector said.

title: BEVIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
CONFLICT OF CULTURES RESULTING IN DEATHS IN DETROIT
description: Charlie Simaan slipped the pistol off his cashier's counter and into a drawer when some visitors came up for a talk about the inner-city supermarket business. Guns have become a touchy element in that business in Detroit lately.

title: A Porch for Gracie Mansion
description: I n time for the last breath of spring, Gracie Mansion will get a new front porch. The old one, weakened by age and dilapidated from heavy use, has been torn down.

title: Low Expectations
description: Even though betting on the United States Football League has not lived up to the expectations of the legal bookmakers in Las Vegas, Nev., the situation among illegal bookies in New York may be even worse.

title: DESPITE GAINS, CRITICS ASSERT NUCLEAR SAFETY EFFORT LAGS
description: In the four years since the nuclear reactor accident at Three Mile Island, nuclear plants around the country have been forced by Federal regulators to spend as much as $15 million each on new safety devices and procedures. But some concern remains on Capitol Hill and among critics of the nuclear industry that the safety effort is lagging.

title: RECITAL: MANUEL BARRUECO AT TULLY HALL
description: MANUEL BARRUECO'S guitar recital at Alice Tully Hall Monday night was the work not just of a guitarist but of a superior musician. A guitarist he is - indeed, an exceptional instrumentalist.

title: BOLIVIAN WHO OUSTED BARBIE GETS A PROMISE OF AID FROM MITTERRAND
description: President Francois Mitterrand today warmly praised Bolivia's President, Hernan Siles Zuazo, the man largely responsible for delivering Klaus Barbie, the Nazi war criminal, to France. Mr. Mitterrand promised that his Socialist Government would aid Bolivia ''as much as its means will allow.''

title: MARKS & SPENCER reports earnings for year to Jan 31.
description: b-After a charge of $172,000 from store closing costs. c-After a charge of $130,000 from store closing costs and a tax credit of $1,250,000.

description: Fred Schwengel President, Capitol Historical Society

title: 7.5% Jobless Rate In Connecticut
description: State unemployment rose slightly to 7.5 percent in February, with 131,400 workers out of jobs - 100 more than were reported in January and 15,300 more than in February 1982, Labor Commissioner P. Joseph Peraro said yesterday.

title: Preservation Hall Band With Some New Faces
description: The annual appearance of the Preservation Hall Jazz Band at Avery Fisher Hall is, in many ways, a totally predictable event. Barring deaths and incapacity the seven musicians will be the same from year to year. The program will focus on a collection of marches, blues, old pop tunes, old jazz tunes and hymns that the band has been playing since it was formed more than 20 years ago. And the audience response will be enthusiastic, joyful and, given the opportunity to join the band in a simulated street parade through the aisles of the Hall, warmly participatory.

title: FRESNO RALLIES TO HERALD SQ.
description: Word that Fresno State had reached tonight's final of the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden has sent several hundred more Californians winging to New York, at about $1,000 a head. They will join about a thousand others who arrived Monday from the city in the San Joaquin Valley noted more for growing raisins than developing basketball players.

title: Safety Review Set For Salem A-Plant
description: The operator of the troubled Salem nuclear power plant in New Jersey has agreed to permit an outside consulting firm to evaluate quality control problems there, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: NEW YORK abounds with buildings that have plaques affixed to their sides. These plaques are not, as a rule, riveting to read. An exception occurred about a year ago when the following message, cast in bronze, appeared on an office building at 41 West 57th Street: More than once I've wakened with tears running down my cheeks. I have had to think whether I was crying or whether it was involuntary like drooling.

title: Soviet Buys U.S. Corn
description: The Soviet Union has re-entered the American grain market after an absence of nearly three months, purchasing 100,000 metric tons of corn, the Agriculture Department said today.

G.M. Recalls 300
description: The General Motors Corporation said it recalled 300 auto workers laid off in 1981 at its plant at Linden, N.J., effective Saturday. A spokesman said G.M. had increased production of big cars at the plant to 50 an hour from 45.

title: REAGAN'S COURAGE
description: In the fall of 1939, President Franklin D. Roosevelt made a decision and took immediate action. The first results were seen less than six years later, when the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki ended World War II. This March 23 marks another but very different turning point in world history. On that day, President Reagan in a few thoughful phrases denied the generally accepted idea that there is no defense against nuclear weapons.

title: RCA to Buy Part Of Arista Records
description: The RCA Corporation has agreed to buy approximately a half-interest in Arista Records, a United States subsidiary of Bertelsmann A.G., the large West German publishing company, it was announced.

title: WHITE HOUSE REVUE
description: In the last few days, President Reagan and his wife have never seemed happier. They have used the capital of the United States as a stage, and demonstrated the power of personality and the theater to influence politics.

title: Economic Scene; Global Debate On Currency
description: WOULD a new ''Bretton Woods'' international monetary conference, aimed at achieving greater currency stability, make sense? Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, who had earlier raised the idea and then appeared to back away from it, said in an interview last week that such a conference was ''entirely possible.'' He added, ''I am not forecasting or promising another Bretton Woods, but I do think the nations of the world have got to talk more about their currencies.''

title: Yanks' Rawley Sharp In Six Shutout Innings
description: Shane Rawley was motionless, sprawled on his back on the trainer's table and clutching an ice pack that was bandaged around the inside of his right thigh. But the Yankee pitcher spoke with no pain and nothing but confidence about his six scoreless innings against the Los Angeles Dodgers today.

title: AN EFFICIENT BLENDER
description: LIKE many home and professional cooks in this health-conscious age, I have been on a campaign to cut down on fat and calories in my diet. Being a Frenchman, however, I find the notion of forswearing sauces a fate worse than the guillotine. Instead, for more than a year I have been experimenting with blenders to create light, vegetable-bound sauces that employ a minimum of cream and butter.

title: BRITISH LABORITES OPPOSE CRUISE MISSILE PLAN
description: Britain's opposition Labor Party made public a party platform today that calls for cancellation of plans to station cruise missiles in Britain and for sharp increases in Government spending. It also reiterated a call for withdrawal from the European Economic Community.

title: DATA ARCHITECTS INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
Transcript of interview, page A14.
description: President Reagan said today that if the United States was able to develop a comprehensive defense against missiles, he could foresee some president offering to share it with the Soviet Union to encourage the elimination of all offensive nuclear missiles.

title: Durham's Complaint
description: According to Georgia's basketball coach, Hugh Durham, a Southern suzerainty over big-time college basketball has been threatened by recruitment on the part of Eastern coaches. The way Durham is telling it, colleges in the East have begun poaching on the South's proprietary recruiting preserve - the East.

title: STATE PLANS NEW SYSTEM FOR 'BLIND POOL'SYNDICATIONS
description: One of the hot investments in recent years has been real estate syndications. Although the State of New York has limited investing in some kinds of syndications, nationwide sales in public real estate syndication programs hit $2.5 billion in 1982, experts say. Their estimates of total investment in public and private syndications are twice that high.

title: JUPITER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
TELECOM PLUS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
No Coattails
description: Terry Holland has heard the rumors: how when his star player, Ralph Sampson, goes into the National Basketball Association next season, the coach of the University of Virginia would move along with him. Yesterday, while attending a reception at the ''21'' Club here for Sampson, who was honored as Kodak's college player of the year, Holland said he had no intention of ''riding Ralph's coattails.''

title: STATE'S BUDGET BRINGS PRAISE AND SOME GRIPES IN SUBURBS
description: The jubilation in Albany that accompanied Monday's passage of a $31.5 billion state budget was translated yesterday into sighs of relief, as well as a sharp complaint here and there, in the New York metropolitan area's suburban counties.

title: A Bad War in Nicaragua
description: Nicaragua's leftist regime may or may not be seriously damaged by guerrilla raids apparently mounted from bases in Honduras and Costa Rica. But the United States is surely being injured by its almost open collaboration with such cross-border insurgencies. One result may be to entrench rather than topple a revolutionary autocracy; another may be to isolate the United States throughout the hemisphere.

title: Infection Benches Ryan
description: Nolan Ryan's effort to pass Walter Johnson on the career strikeout list is being delayed. Ryan, originally scheduled to open the season for the Houston Astros next Tuesday, was diagnosed by a urologist yesterday as having a urinary-tract infection and will miss at least two starts.

title: Bridge: Shanghai Team Overtakes New York to Win Tourney
description: News of a victory by the home team in the second Shanghai international tournament Monday night was a disappointment to the touring New York team, which had left before the finish after posting a possible winning score of 129 victory points.

title: COLLEGE UNITS ASK CURB ON HECKLING
description: Alarmed by the disruption of speakers on the nation's campuses, organizations representing college presidents, faculty members and students urged the academic community yesterday to ''respect the right of others to listen to those who have been invited to speak on campus.''

title: China Assails U.S. on Bank
description: China today accused the United States of blocking its application to join the Manila-based Asian Development Bank and reiterated that Taiwan should be expelled from the organization.

title: Ruling May Block Fight
description: A state appeals court today issued a ruling that may force Aaron Pryor to cancel his title fight Saturday in Atlantic City unless he can reach an agreement with his estranged manager, Buddy LaRosa.

title: CONVENTION HALL MAY FACE DELAYS OF YEAR OR MORE
description: Completion of the New York City Convention Center will be delayed by at least a year and the cost will be significantly higher than previously projected, according to a report by a vice president of the state's Urban Development Corporation.

title: Great Western
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation said that an agreement on its planned acquisition of Financial Federation Inc. had been signed and approved by both boards. The company said that under the agreement it would exchange 1.8 common shares for each of the 4.2 million Financial Federation outstanding shares.

title: Sally Mae Prices Two-Part Offering
description: A two-part offering of $500 million of notes was priced by the Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sally Mae, yesterday.

title: YOUNG PARIS DESIGNERS: DIVERSITY OF TALENT
description: Not far below the hand-stitched surface of Paris fashion, one discovers that the young designers of this city are as varied in talent, temperament and taste as those of New York.

title: Captain's Farewell
description: C apt. Peter Jackson has sailed into New York harbor for 40 of his 44 years at sea. This week he came back by plane to say farewells that were skipped on Jan. 16, the day he retired as master of the Queen Elizabeth 2.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Lawyers for Bulgarian Present New Evidence
description: The lawyers for a Bulgarian imprisoned here displayed documents today that they said proved he was falsely accused of complicity in the 1981 shooting of Pope John Paul II.

title: VANITY FAIR SPARKS SHARP REACTION
description: With enormous public-relations fanfare and $10 million spent on finding an audience, the publishing concern Conde Nast, whose reputation rests on its flashy fashion magazines, revived Vanity Fair last month as a magazine of literature and the arts, politics and popular culture.

title: CONSTANCE WOODWORTH
description: Constance Woodworth, former fashion and beauty editor of Harper's Bazaar and Town and Country magazines and former women's page editor of The New York Journal-American, died of cancer Sunday at her home in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 71 years old, and also had homes in Manhattan and in Southampton, L.I.

title: BRIEFING
description: Brzezinski on Mondale

title: DETROIT POLICE FORCE IS UPHELD ON METHOD OF PROMOTING BLACKS
description: Detroit's method of increasing the number of black supervisors in its Police Department is legal and ''reasonable in all respects,'' the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit ruled today.

title: ACCORD SET ON FORMAT FOR VIDEO RECORDERS
