description: More than 120 companies have agreed on a common standard for the next generation of video cassette recorders. Gathered at a special conference here Monday, electronics, tape and camera manufacturers from around the world settled on a format based on quarter-inch cassette tape. The current generation of video recorders uses half-inch cassette tape.

title: METALLURGICAL INDUSTRIES, ARAB UNIONS OF reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Including a credit of $834,000 from recovery of taxes. c-Net income.

title: New Calliope Singers Present 'Lieder Recital'
description: Before the New Calliope Singers presented their program at Merkin Hall on Saturday night, Peter Schubert, the choral group's director, explained that he thought of the concert as a ''lieder recital'' for chorus. Each work was meant to create a miniature lyrical world, like that of a solo song.

title: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 30, 1983; The Economy
description: The Administration wants to abolish the triple-damage penalty in most antitrust lawsuits, according to officials familiar with a draft plan sent to Congress. Under the plan, patent protection would also be improved. (Page D1.)

title: SEMTECH CORP reports earnings for year to Jan 31.
Parker Pen Plan
description: The Parker Pen Company and two labor unions have agreed to a plan to modernize the company's plant, including the use of robots in pen production, and reduce the work force of 580 people by about one-third. Under the plan, Parker is to start work next month on the $8.5 million project.

title: BUSINESS AIDE WINS SUIT AGAINST MURCHISON
description: Stanley L. Neeley had his day in court, and he won - against Clint W. Murchison Jr., the Texas financier. Last week a Federal District Court jury in Dallas awarded Mr. Neeley $3.3 million.

title: France and Pakistan Discuss Nuclear Deal
description: The French Foreign Minister, Claude Cheysson, said today that his country disagreed with United States policy on nuclear technology for peaceful uses and was discussing the possible supply of a $1 billion nuclear power plant to Pakistan.

title: Blast Kills Welder In Plastics Factory
description: A welder at a plastics factory was killed today when a drum he was testing with air pressure exploded.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF GROUP INTERVIEW WITH PRESIDENT AT WHITE HOUSE
description: Following is a White House transcript of an interview of President Reagan in the White House today by the reporters Tom DeFrank of Newsweek, Susan Page of Newsday, Gary Schuster of The Detroit News, Ben Taylor of The Boston Globe, Paul West of The Dallas Times Herald and Loye Miller of Newhouse News. The transcript omits several words of the first question. Proposal on Missiles

title: AN OIL TARIFF THAT CAN ONLY HURT AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire Dept. Upheld On Test for Women
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday affirmed a decision that reserved up to 45 jobs for women who could pass an interim physical test for joining the New York City Fire Department.

title: INSURERS BALKING ON COMPANY LOSSES
description: American companies and their insurers are embroiled in bitter legal clashes over who will bear the costs of major corporate disasters. Many corporations facing unexpected liabilities have found their insurers unwilling to pay their claims. Insurance payments have been refused, at least in part, in cases ranging from the asbestos claims against the Manville Corporation to the costs of the recall that followed the deaths of seven people from cyanide-laced Tylenol capsules. More and more, corporations are taking their insurers to court to try to force them to pay.

title: Steel Union's View of Talks
description: Lloyd McBride, president of the United Steelworkers of America, said yesterday that the United States Steel Corporation told him last November that it might have to import steel to keep its plants open but only if the union and the company failed to agree on a new labor contract.

title: Hawaii Land Reform Act Ruled Unconstitutional
description: The Hawaii Land Reform Act, which gave the state authority to condemn some private residential land and sell it to people who had leased it, was declared unconstitutional by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit today.

title: Frank Maya, Singer, Satirizes Consumerism
description: Frank Maya, a nervously energetic young singer, songwriter and poet, has built a following on the local rock club circuit with his zany satirical songs that reflect sensibilities as wide-ranging as the Talking Heads, Peter Allen and Spike Jones. And at Danceteria on Friday, Mr. Maya, fronting a rock quintet, put on a speedy, amusing show that blended marimba-flavored punkish folk-rock, aggressive patter and declamatory pop poetry.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ARE cod and scrod the same thing? There are probably more legends about the name ''scrod'' than about any other fish. A waiter I knew years ago actually told me (incorrectly) that there really was no such thing.

title: E.E.C., Gulf States to Talk
description: The European Economic Community's Executive Commission and oil-producing nations in the Persian Gulf have agreed to hold meetings on energy, a commission spokesman said today.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: A WINTRY wind was whipping up the Avenue of the Americas and Eddy Grant, whose best-known song to date is ''Walking on Sunshine,'' shivered visibly inside his overcoat. ''Time for me to get back home,'' he said. ''This is why I left England - the cold.''

title: U.S. WOULD ASK CHILDREN TO PAY FOR PATIENT CARE
description: Federal officials, in a new interpretation of the Medicaid law, say that states may require people to help pay for care provided to their parents in nursing homes.

title: Joel Ryan Offers Some Computer Music
description: Joel Ryan, a computer-music composer from California, likes to surround his sounds with all manner of semiphilosophical explication. His ''256 Locations for Two Loudspeakers,'' the overall title of a program heard Thursday night at the Kitchen, derives from the 256 different spots into which a microcomputer can apparently position a loudspeaker cone, thus making 256 different kinds of sound.

title: GARDEN EYES NEW TOURNEY
description: A preseason college basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden is in the ''talking stage,'' Frank McGuire, the Garden's director of intercollegiate athletics, said yesterday.

title: 1. Chefs and Clowns
description: Children who are past the Easter bunny stage might be enchanted by Gillian's People. These are greeting cards that contain the elements of a whimsical character that the child can assemble and play with or tack on a bulletin board. The parts are held together by metal fasteners that allow the limbs and head to be moved into a variety of positions - lifelike or otherwise. Four characters are available: a mustachioed chef complete with toque and fancy cake; a mime dressed all in black; a clown with fuchsia hair, and a red-faced minstrel named Golly in pin stripes. Golly sells for $3; the other cards are $3.50 each, complete with white envelope for mailing. They are available at Classy Cards, 1089 Third Avenue (64th Street).

title: FOUNDERS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Including capital gains of $11,632 for the quarter and $161,574 for the year. c-After a capital loss of $8,699.

title: Alexander Tishman, 91, Dies; Former Construction Official
description: Alexander Tishman, former treasurer of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company and a leader in developing high-rise apartment houses on the Upper West Side in the 1920's, died of cardiac arrest last Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He had had surgery for a broken hip.

title: UNIVERSAL CIGAR CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
Letter: On Sovereign Immunity; You Should Be Able to Sue City Hall
description: To the Editor:

title: WARSAW UNDERGROUND CALLS FOR MARCHES
description: Three underground leaders of Solidarity, the outlawed labor movement, have issued a call for a repetition of last year's May Day demonstrations, when tens of thousands marched through Warsaw's Old Town in defiance of martial law.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Wyse Advertising has been selected by Maidenform Inc., the lingerie manufacturer, to handle its advertising account. The national advertising assignment, for two years at Creamer Inc., bills in the neighborhood of $5 million.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Chicago White Sox, exhibition, at St. Petersburg, Fla. This could be a critical start for the Mets' Rick Ownbey, whose 8.10 earned run average reflects the way he has struggled this spring. (Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Fordham vs. Brooklyn College, at Jack Coffey Field, Fordham Road and Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, 3 P.M. (Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7; 3 P.M.) Basketball DePaul vs. Fresno State, National Invitation Tournament, championship game, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 9 P.M. Three members of the all-N.I.T. team will be present at special halftime ceremonies: George Mikan, Tom Gola and Walt Frazier. (Television - Channel 9, 9 P.M.) Nets vs. Washington Bullets, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:35 P.M. Every game is important now for the Bullets, who have only nine left in their chase for the sixth and final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference. Jeff Ruland, their center, is the National Basketball Association's most recent player of the week. (Television - Sports@Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WVNJ, 620; 7:30 P.M.) Knicks vs. Clippers, at San Diego. (Television -Channel 9, approximately 11 P.M., after N.I.T. telecast.)

title: CURBS ON GRAND JURY DATA
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that state attorneys general, investigating possible violations of Federal antitrust laws, have no special right of access to material produced by Federal grand juries that have examined the same allegations.

title: Hartford Rejects Drinking-Age Bills
description: The legislature's General Law Committee today narrowly defeated proposals to raise Connecticut's legal drinking age to 20 or 21 from 19.

title: ANGELES CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After a loss of $214,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $455,000. c-Net loss after a loss of $5,317,000 from discontinued operations. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in February.

title: BEECHAM A SUCCESS IN ITS U.S. MARKETS
description: With its latest American acquisitions, Beecham, the British chemical and consumer product company, is stepping up a strategy of expansion that has served the company well for more than a decade.

title: BRUINS CAPTURE TOP SPOT
description: Two linemates, Barry Pederson and Rick Middleton, scored 76 seconds apart late in the third period tonight and lifted Boston to a 4-3 victory over the Quebec Nordiques. By winning, the Bruins clinched first place over all in the National Hockey League standing.

title: STERLING PIPE & SUPPLY CO reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: b-Net income. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Nancy Reagan Visits Mother
description: Nancy Reagan flew to Phoenix today to visit her mother, Edith Davis, before joining President Reagan in Los Angeles on Wednesday, in White House aides said. The Reagans will spend Wednesday night in Los Angeles and on Thursday will fly to their Santa Barbara ranch where they will remain until Easter Sunday. Before leaving for the ranch, Mr. Reagan will address a luncheon of the Los Angeles World Affairs Council.

title: NEW-HOME SALES DROP BY 5.9%
description: Sales of new single-family houses declined 5.9 percent in February, the Commerce Department reported today. However, housing industry spokesmen were not discouraged, noting that sales were still far better than they were at the same time last year.

title: Michigan Governor Signs 38% Income Tax Increase
description: Gov. James J. Blanchard today signed into law a 38 percent increase in the Michigan income tax, saying it was needed ''to rescue the state from bankruptcy.''

title: Austrians Trade Charges Over Lippizaner Deaths
description: The manager of a Lippizaner stud farm where 31 mares and foals died of a virus infection said today that the Agriculture Ministry ignored repeated pleas for help to contain the illness.

title: JAPAN'S PRODUCTIVE CAR UNIONS
description: Tetuo Ohsone, the top labor union official at the Toyo Kogyo Company, gives a visitor a small gift, a tie clip. Prominently displayed on it is the word ''Mazda,'' the trade name for Toyo Kogyo cars, and a symbol depicting the company's unique rotary engine. The union's initials are barely discernible.

title: SOVIET CALLS ANY NEW MISSILES IN EUROPE A THREAT
description: An authoritative Soviet commentator said today that any United States proposal for equal limits on American and Soviet medium-range missiles in Europe would be a device for insuring Western superiority.

title: ROBERT G. DEINDORFER
description: Robert G. Deindorfer, an author and public-relations executive, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 61 years old.

title: Stocks Fall for the Third Day
description: Stock prices dropped moderately yesterday for the third consecutive session. Trading continued to be slow. The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow range throughout the session, finished off 2.13 points, at 1,131.19. Declining stocks on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered issues that rose by 827 to 681.

title: Cosmos Defeat L.I.U., Fordham
description: The Cosmos, playing two games of 45 minutes each, defeated Long Island University, 1-0, and Fordham, 3-0, this afternoon at C.W. Post College.

title: 'THE MISSION,' EXILES FROM IRAN IN U.S.
description: ''THE MISSION,'' written, produced, directed and edited by Parviz Sayyad, is an appealing, technically accomplished oddity - a cleareyed, ironic, small-scale melodrama, shot entirely in and around New York City by Iranian exiles, the Farsi dialogue translated by English subtitles.

title: Republican is Elected To Succeed Jack Swigert
description: State Senator Dan Schaefer, a Republican, inheriting political support from the late Jack Swigert, easily defeated his Democratic opponent today to capture the Congressional seat left vacant by the death of the former astronaut.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alcan Aluminium, Montreal, has appointed Murray D. Lester vice president, energy resources, and Dudley G. Eustace treasurer.

title: Jane Chambers Memorial
description: A memorial for the playwright Jane Chambers will be held on April 17 at 4 P.M. at the American Place Theater, 111 West 46th Street. Writers and friends of the author will read from Miss Chambers's works as well as the writings of others. Miss Chambers died last month at the age of 45.

title: SERVOTRONICS INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $512,000 for the latest year and $456,000 for the previous year.

title: A LETTER FROM NOFZIGER ON RICE, FRIENDS AND ENEMIES
description: Lyn Nofziger, who resigned last year as President Reagan's special assistant for political affairs, used to complain that the White House wasn't doing a good job of rewarding its friends and punishing its enemies. As a Washington consultant, Mr. Nofziger is still sending that message to the President's aides, sometimes to their embarrassment.

title: IMPERIAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After a loss of $1,220,000 from discontinued operations.

title: NOVO CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $229,000, or 7 cents a share, for the latest year and $23,000 for the previous year. The share earnings results reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effected in April 1982.

title: ADOLESCENTS AND ALCOHOL: THE ZERO OPTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Says Klansman Killed Rights Worker
description: The former wife of a Ku Klux Klansman testified today that another Klansman, not an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, fired the shots that killed Viola Gregg Liuzzo, a civil rights worker, in Alabama in 1965.

title: GROUCHO MARX CASE CLOSES IN CONFUSION AS JURY BACKS BANK
description: After 10 days of deliberation and a temporary deadlock in the trial of Erin Leslie Fleming, Groucho Marx's longtime companion, jurors today awarded the Bank of America more than $450,000 in a judgment against her.

title: FACTORY ORDERS FALL 2.2%
description: New orders to factories for manufactured goods declined 2.2 percent in February, offsetting some of the gains of the previous two months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Jennifer O'Neill Guilty in Gun Case
description: Jennifer O'Neill, the actress, pleaded guilty today to illegal possession of a handgun with which she accidentally shot herself last October.

title: Officer Is Shot In Routine Arrest
description: A Transit Authority police officer was shot in the mouth last night after he stopped three disorderly youths - vandalism suspects - in an underground passageway at 38th Street and Avenue of the Americas, the police said.

title: GRAND AUTO INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 30.
AMEDCO INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: Results for the latest quarter and year include a gain of $773,000 from the sale of assets. Year-ago results include a gain of $452,000 for the quarter and year from the sale of assets. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in December 1982.

title: Chicago Immunizations Against Meningitis Start
description: Immunizations began today in one of the city's largest public housing projects to prevent an outbreak of meningitis from spreading, health officials said.

title: KOCH USES ROLE AS A MAGISTRATE TO BACK 2 BILLS
description: Seeking to put public pressure on the State Legislature to pass two of his criminal-justice proposals, Mayor Koch presided at an unusual City Hall hearing yesterday.

title: HENRY LEWIS LOWERRE
description: Henry Lewis Lowerre, a stockbroker and a member of the War Production Board during World War II, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Manchester, Vt. He was 70 years old and had lived in New York City before retiring to Vermont 10 years ago.

title: Bolivian Denies Visit Is Linked to Barbie
description: Bolivia's President, Hernan Siles Zuazo, said today that his visit to France was not linked to his country's decision to hand Klaus Barbie, the accused Nazi war criminal, to French authorities.

title: NATURE'S BOUNTY INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: COLLECTOR'S HOUSE: QUIET SURPRISES
description: ''ICAN'T stand living with things I can't use,'' says Robert Bishop, the director of the Museum of American Folk Art in Manhattan. The man who in six years has helped shape the institution into the major folk-art museum in the country has in fact managed to keep his own home from becoming a museum.

title: Drunken-Driving Dragnet
description: In most places, campaigns against drunken driving are based on new laws introduced with plenty of publicity. They may work for a time, but fear inevitably diminishes and the incidence of drunken driving returns to previous levels.

title: United Artists
description: The bulk of United Artists' operations will be moved from New York City to Los Angeles by late summer as the film company continues consolidation under the MGM-UA Entertainment Corporation, officials said. The Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company, based in Culver City, west of Los Angeles, acquired the United Artists Corporation two years ago. The studios maintain separate production units, butadvertising and distribution were pooled.

title: STRAWBRIDGE & CLOTHIER reports earnings for qtr to Jan 29.
description: The share earnings results give effect to 7 percent stock dividend payable in May.

title: NATIONAL DATA CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
JENSEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
NETS FAIL TO CLINCH A BERTH IN PLAYOFFS
description: The Washington Bullets, a rugged team hoping for a playoff berth, defeated the New Jersey Nets tonight, 100-97, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Punching at Shadows
description: Sugar Ray Seales, the 30-year-old boxer who is recovering from eye surgery in Portland, Ore., had an explanation for how he was able to pass boxing medical examinations in three states despite detached retinas in both eyes and vision so blurry his manager said he was ''virtually blind,'' and ''punching at shadows,'' for the last year. The examiners, Seales said, ''couldn't see that I couldn't see.'' The boxer, who won an Olympic gold medal in 1972, also memorized eye charts, according to his manager, and reassured doctors who noticed something wrong by promising to seek immediate treatment.

title: SUPERSCOPE INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Includes a charge of $1.2 million from the writedown of goodwill from the 1978 purchase of the Marantz Piano Co. and income of $1.1 million from the recovery of excess assets following termination of employees' retirement plan last November.

title: ELECTRONIC THEATRE RESTAURANTS reports earnings for year to Jan 2.
Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ADVANCE ROSS CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-After losses of $670,000 for the quarter and $781,000 for the year from discontinued operations. c-Net income after losses of $378,000 for the quarter and $152,000 for the year from discontinued operations. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the sale of the company's AMI Industries subsidiary in December 1982.

title: 15 SENATORS PRESS REAGAN ON A-ARMS
description: Fifteen senators from both parties urged the Reagan Administration today to press within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for a significant reduction of American tactical nuclear weapons now stationed in Western Europe.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When it comes to intermediate nuclear missiles in Europe, it would be better to have none than to have some.

title: CHINA ATTRACTS HONG KONG'S MONEY, AND GANGSTERS
description: The posters pasted on local walls condemn dark deeds - drug trafficking, armed robbery, burglary, vice, smuggling and gang fighting. They call on criminals to turn themselves in, and promise rewards to citizens who put the police on the trail of such fugitives.

title: CORRECTION
description: An Associated Press dispatch Tuesday erroneously quoted a spokesman for the Weyerhaeuser Company in regard to the deposit of wastes at the Stringfellow Pits site in California. The spokesman, Tom Ambrose, said Weyerhaeuser ranked 11th in volume among 199 companies known to have used the site, but he said the Weyerhaeuser wastes were nontoxic.

title: DR. EDGAR B. GRAVES
description: Dr. Edgar B. Graves, professor emeritus of history and former chairman of the history department at Hamilton College in Clinton, N.Y., died last Thursday at his home in Clinton.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Traditional

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
Jane Fonda and Her Spa Charged With Sex Bias
description: Three women who were former instructors at Jane Fonda's Workout, an exercise and health spa, filed a $3 million lawsuit against the company and the actress Jane Fonda today, charging sex discrimination, fraud and breaches of state labor code.

title: LISETTE MODEL, A PHOTOGRAPHER, IS DEAD AT 76
description: Lisette Model, a photographer whose work appeared in galleries and publications around the world and was influential as a teacher at the New School for Social Research for more than 30 years, died of heart and respiratory disease yesterday at New York Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ABKCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-After a loss of $5,745 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $2,254. c-Including income of $40,212 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $165,695.

title: Caterpiller Contract
description: The Army today awarded a $125.2 million, five-year contract for earth-leveling construction scrapers to the Caterpillar Tractor Company of Peoria, Ill. It was the third contract for Caterpillar from the Defense Department in as many months. Earlier ones were for $112 million to manufacture Army road graders and $6 million to $20 million for Marine Corps tractors.

title: U.S. STEEL DECLINES FOREIGN STEEL COMMENT
description: The United States Steel Corporation, faced with mounting criticism of negotiations aimed at importing semifinished steel products, declined comment yesterday on reports that it might consider competitive bids from a number of foreign steel producers.

title: FRISCH'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 6.
BOGUS PROFESSOR IS LINKED TO 'PAPER EMPIRE'
description: A man believed to have taught under different names at seven colleges is a ''true chameleon of identities'' who also may have set up a paper empire intent on buying banks in Georgia, art in Switzerland and land in Canada, a state prosecutor said today.

title: Wickes Posts a Smaller Loss
description: Wickes Companies, the large retailer that is trying to reorganize with protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code, reported yesterday that it lost $15.9 million in its fourth fiscal quarter ended Jan. 29, compared with a deficit of $256.3 million in the year earlier period.

title: INVESTORS MOVE TO SIDELINES
description: Growing confusion over the interest rate trend drove buyers away from the credit markets yesterday. With retail buyers mostly on the sidelines, dealers said, price moves offered no valid measure of either the short- or long-term debt market.

title: THEATER: LOUISVILLE HUMMANA FESTIVAL
description: During the seventh annual Humana Festival of New American Plays at the Actors Theater of Louisville, critics, producers, directors and others assembled for an intensive marathon of 10 theatrical events in a three-day period. At past festivals, Jon Jory's theater has discovered Marsha Norman, Beth Henley and Jane Martin, among others. To that list, last weekend one could add the name of Kathleen Tolan, a young actress turned playwright, and author of ''A Weekend Near Madison.''

title: I.R.A. Case Ruling Is Upheld by Court
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday affirmed a decision involving possible British intelligence links to the case of four men on trial in Brooklyn on charges of smuggling weapons to the Irish Republican Army.

title: INTEGRATION PLAN FACING NEW DELAY
description: Efforts to settle an 11-year-old school desegregation suit were delayed again today as some of the 23 suburban school districts that are defendants in the case continue their efforts to modify the latest plan.

title: HOME BEAT
description: HE contends he's the ''youngest designer to have a collection of furniture in production that is named after him.''

title: Marathon Problem
description: Charlotte Starke was hardly winded when she crossed the finish line 3 hours 7 minutes 5 seconds after the start of the Emerald City Marathon in Seattle on Sunday, and that, race officials said, was one reason they decided the 58-year-old woman must have taken a short cut in establishing a world record for her age group. There was also the fact that she had apparently never before run a marathon and had been seen walking during the race.

title: SOUTH AFRICA CUTS BLACKS' TAX
description: The Government announced today that, beginning next March 1, blacks paying income tax in South Africa would no longer have to do so at higher rates than whites.

title: Barclays Consolidation
description: Barclays Bank P.L.C. plans to merge its British banking business with Barclays Bank International Ltd., the overseas arm, Timothy Bevan, the bank's chairman, said in the annual report. He said the legal division between the group's two main companies does not make it easy to satisfy the demands of multinational customers and creates expensive capital problems.

title: Panel Bids Conrail Engineers Take Pay Cut to Help Railroad
description: A Presidential emergency board recommended today that the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers accept a 12 percent wage cut to enable Conrail, which serves the Northeast, to become profitable again.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: BRIEFING
description: Trying to Explain

title: 2 Indicted in Death During Drag Race
description: Two motorists, both Nassau Community College students, were indicted yesterday in the death of a third driver whose car they hit in Levittown, L.I., last February. The two are accused of drag racing each other at the time of the crash with the third car.

title: COURT REFUSES TO INCREASE WATER RIGHTS OF 5 TRIBES
description: The Supreme Court, in a decades-old dispute over rights to water from the Colorado River, ruled today that five Southwestern Indian tribes were not entitled to the substantially increased water rights they had sought.

title: Belgium-Sized Oil Slick Imperils Persian Gulf
description: A giant oil slick, said to cover an area the size of Belgium, is likely to hit the Persian Gulf state of Qatar in the next 24 hours, an environmental official said today.

title: PLANTING GREENERY TO FORM A SCREEN
description: SOMETIMES gardeners want to plant a screen for privacy. Or they may want to shield unsightly parts of a garden or to separate one growing space from another. If the house is new, rapid-growing screen plants will do a cheap temporary job until a formal landscape plan is developed.

title: CHARLES G. GAMBRELL
description: Charles Glenn Gambrell, retired vice president of the Irving Trust Company of New York, died Tuesday in Presbyterian Hospital in Charlotte, N.C. He was 81 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Shula Takes Blame
description: Don Shula, the coach of the Miami Dolphins, has exonerated his quarterback, David Woodley, for Miami's 27-17 loss to the Washington Redskins in the Super Bowl and placed the blame elsewhere - on himself. ''It was my fault,'' Shula said, discussing the poor performance by Woodley, who completed only four of 14 passes during the game and none of the eight he threw during the second half.

title: Books Of The Times
description: WRITING WITH A WORD PROCESSOR. By William Zinsser. 117 pages. Harper & Row. $12.95. BEFORE YOU BUY A COMPUTER. A Practical Guide to Computer Shopping. By Dona Z. Meilach. 210 pages. Illus- trated. Crown. Hardcover, $15.95; paper, $8.95. THE WORD PROCESSING BOOK. A Short Course in Computer Literacy. By Peter A. McWilliams. 270 pages. Illustrated. Prelude Books (Box 69773, Los Angeles, Cal. 90069). $9.95.

title: TRUSTY CLICHES FOR EVERY OCCASION
description: What sets a ''dangerous precedent,'' constitutes a ''cruel hoax,'' is ''no way to legislate,'' will make people ''rue the day,'' but can be ''cleaned up in conference''?

title: NICARAGUA ACCUSED ON RIGHTS
description: Nicaragua's human rights record has come under sharp questioning here by a committee of United Nations' experts.

title: GAF Files Suit
description: The GAF Corporation, a maker of chemicals and building materials, has filed suit in Federal court in an effort to prevent an insurgent slate of candidates for directors from voting their shares or soliciting votes in a proxy battle for control of the company. The outcome of the proxy fight, which began last month, is likely to be determined at the company's annual meeting, scheduled for April 28. The dissident director candidates are led by Samuel J. Heyman, a Westport, Conn., real estate developer who owns or controls about 4.7 percent of GAF common stock.

title: Bruins Invite Leveille
description: Normand Leveille, the Boston wing who has been partially paralyzed since suffering a cerebral hemorrhage last October, has accepted an invitation to attend a practice session in Montreal Saturday. Leveille, who is being treated at a rehabilitation hospital in Montreal, will be at the Montreal Forum in a wheel chair, a club spokesman said. He accepted the invitation Monday during a visit with Bruins' assistant coach, Jean Ratelle, and five teammates.

title: 2 FRESHMEN LEARN TO ADJUST
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. T his time last year, when the University of Louisville reached the Final Four, Billy Thompson was at home in Camden, N.J., camped in front of a television set. He had already been proclaimed the best high school basketball player in the country, and he had already decided to attend Louisville. ''So I watched my team,'' he said.

title: Last Seaver Start Canceled by Mets
description: The Mets tonight canceled Tom Seaver's final start of spring training because his strained left thigh was still hurting, and cast some doubt on his ability to pitch the opening game of the season Tuesday in Shea Stadium.

title: Shirley Excels as Yankees Rout Royals
description: Until tonight, success had been slipping away from Bob Shirley this spring. The 27-year-old lefthander, who signed as a free agent with the Yankees last Dec. 15, went from being the probable fourth starter in the pitching rotation to being the fifth, and recently it had seemed he was about to lose even that role to Jay Howell.

title: INTERNATIONAL PROTEINS CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: Results for the latest quarter reflect a writedown of $1,961,000 on marketable securities to market value and writedowns of certain investments and advances in El Salvador and Panama.

title: WILLIAM F. BERNART
description: William F. Bernart, former vice president of engineering for Pitney-Bowes Inc. of Stamford, Conn., died Monday at the Hermitage, a retirement home in Onancock, Va.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MARCH 31, 1983
description: International A new American arms control plan was announced by President Reagan. In a televised statement, he offered to reduce the planned deployment of new American medium-range missiles in Western Europe in exchange for a reduction in the deployment of Soviet medium-range missiles in Europe and Asia that would result in each side having the same total number of warheads. (Page A1, Column 6.) NATO allies hailed President Reagan for his new proposal for limiting medium-range nuclear missiles and called on Moscow for a quick and constructive response. (A10:4-6.)

title: BORG STARTS HIS LAST TOURNEY A WINNER
description: Bjorn Borg extended his career for another day today with a surprisingly easy victory over Jose-Luis Clerc at the Monte Carlo Open.

title: Saudi Pipeline Tactic
description: Saudi Arabia is reported cutting pipeline charges in half in an effort to increase use of the $1.6 billion trans-Arabian oil pipeline.

title: COOK UNITED INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 29.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3.1 million for the quarter and $5,018,000 for the year and an extraordinary credit of $523,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $379,000 for the quarter and $1,360,000 for the year.

title: BOOKER FOR CITY CONVENTION CENTER SEES DELAYS AS ECONOMIC DISASTER
description: The official in charge of bookings for New York City's new Convention Center said yesterday that ''it would be disastrous'' for the city's economy and reputation if the center's opening was delayed beyond the middle of next year.

title: MONTY PYTHON, 'THE MEANING OF LIFE'
description: ''MONTY PYTHON'S THE MEANING OF LIFE'' is a monumental revue, the ''Ben Hur'' of sketch films, which is to say that it's a tiny bit out of proportion, something like a Brooklyn Bridge constructed to span a bathtub.

title: U.S. AGENCY BACKS DEAL ON COMPUTER
description: The Social Security Administration said today that it had no plans to reconsider a $100 million computer contract it awarded a Florida company, despite charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that the company used fraud and deceit to obtain the contract.

title: NATO URGES QUICK SOVIET RESPONSE TO U.S. PLAN
description: The NATO allies acclaimed President Reagan today for his compromise proposal for limiting medium-range nuclear missiles and called on the Soviet Union for a quick and constructive response.

title: NEW YORK IS FACING A LAWSUIT ON CARE OF HOMELESS FAMILIES
description: The Legal Aid Society is challenging New York City and State on what it characterizes as inhumane care of homeless families with children. The society is charging that the families are frequently denied emergency housing or, if granted such housing, are placed in quarters that are dangerous and uninhabitable.

title: A PLACE FOR REVIVALS
description: THOUGH some might argue that the 1982-83 theater season is just getting going, the fact is that it's almost over. Believe it or not, we're now only weeks away from the season's official end - May 15, the cut-off of eligibility for Tony Awards nominations. If it's really true that time passes quickly when you're having fun, maybe this season has been better than anyone thought.

title: Colombia Is Combed For Kidnapped American
description: As many as 3,000 policemen began a search today for an American oil executive named Kenneth Bishop who was kidnapped by leftist guerrillas more than three weeks ago.

title: KENNINGTON LTD reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
FRESNO STATE DEFEATS DEPAUL TO CAPTURE N.I.T. TITLE
description: All Fresno State wanted was some respect. One of the more lightly regarded teams in the National Invitation Tournament came to New York to prove that its credentials were made of more than California plastic.

title: Bird Scores 53, A Celtic Mark
description: Larry Bird scored 53 points -the most ever by a Celtic player in a regular-season game - in Boston's 142-116 victory over Indiana tonight.

title: NEW DATA RAISE ISSUE OF MASS TRANSIT'S VALUE
description: A new Census Bureau analysis of the sharp decline in the use of mass transit has rekindled a dispute as to whether public policy should be used to maintain and revive old depressed communities or to help the movement of people to new places of growth.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: Opening Statement

title: The Talk of Midland, Mich
description: When Julius Grosberg moved here from Detroit 42 years ago, he would leave his footsteps in the soot blown on the street by the Dow Chemical Company's chimney. The tomatoes he grew tasted funny to his relatives back in Detroit. Aluminum screens began to pit and rot away after a couple of years in the Midland air.

title: THURSDAY, MARCH 31, 1983; International
description: British National Oil has proposed price cuts of up to 75 cents a barrel on North Sea oil, clearing the way for the first test of OPEC's new price structure. But the British, in pricing their best grade of crude, were careful not to breach the $30-a-barrel floor that OPEC has set under threat of a price war. (Page A1.)

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: COMPUTERS COME HOME, BUT WHERE DO THEY GO?
description: THE futurists who insist that all of us are going to rush out and buy home computers have addressed a lot of the more profound questions about the revolution they see coming. But there is a more prosaic one that they have largely ignored:

title: G.M. AGREES TO FIX DEFECTIVE BRAKES
description: The General Motors Corporation has agreed to rebuild the braking systems of 240,000 of its 1980 X-body cars at a cost of about $30 million, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today.

title: Boy Set Afire on Dare Reported Recovering
description: A 17-year-old youth who was burned over much of his body, reportedly after dousing himself with gasoline and daring a friend to set him on fire, was reported recovering today.

title: HOME AS OFFICE: MERGERS THAT WORK
description: AT 6 A.M. a producer of television commecials gts down to business in his East Side dining room. At midnight a fashion designer follows through on a creative burst in her TriBeCa loft. Twenty-four hours into the debugging of a program, a computer software designer is still at work in the comfort of his Upper West Side bedroom.

title: AMERICAN BILTRITE INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $969,000 for the quarter and $2,605,000 for the year and extraordinary charges of $476,000 for the quarter and $85,000 for the year. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $2,147,000 for the quarter and $1,006,000 for the year and an extraordinary charge of $2,493,000 for the year.

title: Acting Replacement Named For an Ousted E.P.A. Official
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced Tuesday that Don R. Clay has been named the agency's acting assistant administrator for pesticides and toxic substances.

title: Topics; Hemisphere Diversions
description: The Grenada Scoop

title: SOVIET SAYS ISRAEL IS PREPARING STRIKE ON SYRIA
description: The Soviet Government issued a formal statement today accusing Israel of preparing a ''piratic strike'' against Syria and warning that any such action would be ''playing with fire.''

title: FINANCIAL OFFICIAL IS NAMED BY STATE
description: Suzanne D. Jaffe, 39-year-old executive vice president of the Lehman Management Company, the investment advisory arm of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., has been named New York State deputy comptroller for the division of investments and cash management. In her new job, which she assumes May 1, Mrs. Jaffe will be responsible for the investment of virtually every cent of the state's funds, including the assets of the $18 billion common retirement fund.

title: THE NEWS WORLD TO BE REPLACED BY A NEW PAPER
description: The News World, a six-year-old New York daily newspaper, will cease publication at the end of this week. It will be replaced by The New York Tribune, which begins publication Monday with virtually the same staff as the current paper.

title: C.B.A. Guard Sets Playoff Mark
description: Tico Brown, a guard for the Detroit Spirits, scored 60 points, a playoff record, tonight in a 136-128 double-overtime victory over the Montana Golden Nuggets.

title: SHAREHOLDERS' INPUT: THE SYSTEM WORKS
description: To the Editor:

title: AVATAR HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income. c-Including a tax credit of $1,134,000.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Academy Insurance Group Inc., Valley Forge, Pa., said it had sold 1.6 million newly issued shares of common stock to Aachener und Munchener of West Germany for $44 million, or $27.50 a share.

title: NEW TRIAL WILL BE SOUGHT IN SLAYING OF BLACK MAN
description: The attorney for a white youth convicted of manslaughter in the fatal beating of a black transit worker clashed with the Brooklyn District Attorney yesterday over whether statements by a key prosecution witness after the trial require that the verdict be thrown out and a new trial granted.

title: Of Life and Death
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: The courage to go on living after the loss of a husband, particularly for the devoted wife who has bound her own self inextricably to her mate's, was movingly portrayed by Barbara Ascher (Hers, March 17). But separation is also a problem for husbands. Dr. Johnson, a man who possessed a sturdy sense of independent self, was really describing his own experience upon the death of his wife 28 years earlier in this 1780 letter of sympathy:

title: PAN AM DROPS U.S. FARES
description: Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it would temporarily cut some fares on its domestic routes to about half those recently proposed by American Airlines. The move would partly erode American's effort - widely supported by other carriers - to raise fares and limit discounts.

title: Testimony Starts In Ayala Trial
description: A 30-year-old woman wept on the witness stand today as she testified to having been raped in her West Paterson apartment early New Year's Day by Tony Ayala, the highly ranked junior-middleweight boxer.

title: THEATER: 'K2,' TWO MEN TRAPPED ON A MOUNTAIN
description: CHANCES are that you've already heard the one unassailable reason to see Patrick Meyers's play ''K2'': because the mountain is there. This scenic wonder is astounding. When the curtain rises at the Brooks Atkinson -very slowly, like a striptease - the audience seems to stop breathing.

title: Guy Lewis Faithful to Houston Tradition
description: Guy Lewis is a survivor. But so are most of the coaches at the University of Houston. Longevity has become a tradition at the school, where some of the coaches and professors are considerably older than the university.

title: HARRY KOEPPEL
description: Harry Koeppel, a New York real-estate investment broker and partner in Koeppel & Koeppel, died of a heart attack Saturday at the Palm Beach (Fla.)

title: GIT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: Year-ago results are for the period from Sept. 2, 1981, when GIT merged with its former majority-owned subsidiary, Midcon Industries, and another company, to Dec. 31, 1981.

title: Advertising; Shearson Signs With McCann
description: AMERICAN EXPRESS is sending some more of its business to McCann-Erickson, already the agency for the Gold Card. The shop has now been named agency for Shearson/American Express.

title: Topics; Hemisphere Diversions; Colder in Chile
description: The scandal of Chile is that so many of its best and bravest have been forced to live in exile for nearly a decade. So unforgiving is the Pinochet dictatorship that last week it barred a former Foreign Minister from his mother's funeral.

title: VISIONS FOR THE SCHOOLS BY 3 IN CHANCELLOR RACE
description: In the next few weeks, the Board of Education will select a new Schools Chancellor to replace Frank J. Macchiarola, who resigned last month to become president of the New York City Partnership. The New York Times invited the three leading candidates, Anthony J. Alvarado, superintendent of Community School Board 4 in Harlem; Dr. Thomas K. Minter, the deputy chancellor for instruction, and Robert F. Wagner Jr., a Deputy Mayor, to discuss in separate interviews this week the issues facing the country's largest public school system. These are excerpts from the interviews. Top Priority

title: Sohio Sees Drop In Results for 1983
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said 1983 results are unlikely to equal 1982's because of reduced oil production and lower petroleum prices.

title: SUMMIT CATERER: BIG BUSINESS
description: There will be the usual seven eminent powers at the economic summit conference at Williamsburg, Va., in May, but this time there likely will be an eighth - American big business.

title: NOW, TALK OF NEW STRAINS AMONG THE TOP AIDES
description: Stories about staff squabbling have been a staple of the Reagan White House, usually revolving around the rivalry between James A. Baker 3d, the chief of staff, and Edwin Meese 3d, the Presidential counselor and longtime associate of Ronald Reagan.

title: Reporter Is Sentenced to Jail For Refusal to Discuss Talk
description: BARRE, Pa., March 30 (AP) - A newspaper reporter has been fined $500 and sentenced to five days in jail for refusing to answer questions about an interview with a man accused of murdering 13 people, including five of his children, last September.

title: COURT RESTRICTS LIABILITY OF CITY IN CONSTRUCTION
description: New York City has been upheld by the state's highest court in its efforts to limit its liability to private contractors for construction delays. City officials said yesterday that the finding might save the city millions of dollars in pending lawsuits.

title: Salazar to Test Ailing Right Leg
description: Alberto Salazar will test a sore right leg today to determine whether he will enter the Rotterdam Marathon on April 9 against Robert de Castella of Australia or delay his spring marathon one more week until London (April 17) or Boston (April 18).

title: BAPTISM OF FIRE FOR ARMED SANDINIST VILLAGE
description: Seventy-year-old Samuel Lopez Saenz sat on the porch of the Government-run People's Supermarket in this mountain village today, cradling an old Soviet rifle in his lap.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The side of my white stove was painted black by a previous owner. I have tried using a scraper and a solvent, but I cannot get the paint off. Considering the amount of heat generated by the oven, would it be practical to cover that side of the stove with a contacttype paper?

title: TEAMSTERS WILL SHIFT COST-OF-LIVING RAISE TO FINANCE BENEFITS
description: The trucking industry is acceding to a demand by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to pay a 33-cent-an-hour cost-of-living increase beginning Friday. But none of the money will go into the pockets of union truckers and warehouse workers.

title: A FAMILY OF STEEPLEJACKS KEEPS A DYING ART ALIVE
description: ''JERRY G. O'NEIL, Expert Steeplejack, Church Decorating, interior and exterior, nationwide service,'' the business card reads. What it doesn't say is that the O'Neil service is a traveling family of steeplejacks operating out of Bay City, Mich., one of the few left in this country.

title: Home Federal Stock Offering
description: An initial public offering of 11.8 million shares of Home Federal Savings and Loan Association stock priced at $16.75 each was announced yesterday by an underwriting syndicate headed by Shearson/American Express, the Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group and Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

title: Metro-North Sets Policy on Credit
description: The strikebound Metro-North Commuter Railroad said yesterday that it would honor monthly commutation tickets for March when the walkout was over.

title: NURSING-HOME PATIENTS ILL-PROTECTED BY THE LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: BOWATER CORP. reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $7.5 million. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $10.5 million.

title: CLIPPERS RALLY TO BEAT KNICKS
description: After spending a frustrating night attempting to play defense on a much larger and quicker Bill Cartwright, Tom Chambers of San Diego got revenge.

title: DIONICS INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $203,200.

title: REAGAN OFFERS CUT IN U.S. MISSILE PLAN FOR WEST EUROPE
description: President Reagan offered today to cut back on the planned deployment of new American medium-range missiles in Western Europe in exchange for Soviet reductions in Europe and Asia. The cutbacks by the two sides would leave each with the same number of warheads on such missiles.

title: HERS
Saudis Limit Grain Buying
description: Saudi Arabia does not plan to import any more American grain this year because its domestic production has increased, a Government official said today.

title: PROGRESS REPORTED BY N.B.A. IN TALKS
description: The National Basketball Association owners began arriving in New York last night for a meeting of the Board of Governors today to discuss the status of contract negotiations between the league and its players union. The players have threatened to strike on Saturday unless they get a new contract to replace one that expired last June.

title: CLOSING OF JERSEY ATOM PLANT SAID TO COST MILLIONS
description: A delay in reopening the Salem 1 nuclear plant in southern New Jersey after the failure of a major safety system last month may be costing nearly $1 million a day for substitute fuel, according to spokesmen for the four utilities that own the plant.

title: COURT UPSETS MURDER CHARGE IN DEATH OF FETUS
description: The Kentucky Supreme Court ruled today that a man accused of killing his wife's unborn fetus could not be charged with murder.

title: Cutter Fires on Drug Vessel
description: The Coast Guard cutter Hamilton fired a machine gun to stop a fishing vessel carrying 13,000 pounds of marijuana, the Coast Guard said Tuesday. Seven Colombian crewmen were arrested aboard the 75-foot Anna I, which was disabled when the bullets struck its stern in Bahamanian waters Sunday, Petty Officer Mike Kelley said. He said the drugs and the seven crewmen would be turned over to the Federal authorities Wednesday.

title: DIGITAL COMPACT DISKS: REPLACEMENT FOR LPS?
description: The digital compact disk and player, which is making its debut in retail stores this month, is being likened in the music industry to the advent of stereophonic sound or the long-playing recording. Still, the CD's effect on record makers, manufacturers of audio equipment and - most important - the music-loving consumer will probably be more gradual than were the two previous revolutions, according to analysts.

title: COLOR ISSUE SURGING IN CHICAGO RACE
description: The elderly woman carried a sign saying ''Democrats for Epton'' as she approached her candidate for Mayor on the steps of the crowded neighborhood police station. ''God bless you, Mr. Epton,'' she said, ''You've got my vote.''

title: HEAD ACCUSES BONN
description: A West German holding company and its steel producing group, which operates mills in South Carolina and Texas, formally declared bankruptcy yesterday in West Germany after failing to raise money to pay at least 35 percent of their debts.

title: NAMED PRESIDENT OF STATION IN '74
description: Walter Neiman, president of WQXR, the radio station of The New York Times, died of cardiac arrest Tuesday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 57 years old and lived in Ardsley, N.Y., where he was a former Deputy Mayor and Village Trustee.

title: ECONOMIC INDEX UP BY 1.4%
description: The Government's index of leading economic indicators rose 1.4 percent in February, the Commerce Department reported today, suggesting a moderate recovery.

title: SHELDAHL INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Net income.

title: COMMERCIAL METALS CO reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
THOUGH ANDROPOV IS BACK ON JOB, U.S. OFFICIALS SEE HEALTH PROBLEM
description: Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, is now visibly back on the job, but American officials say they believe that his recent disappearance from public view points to problems that could complicate his taking full control.

title: RECORD EARNINGS AT GERMAN BANK
description: West Germany's three biggest banks, the Deutsche Bank, Dresdner Bank and Commerzbank, have reported record profits for 1982 on the strength of falling interest rates, which cut the cost of refinancing outstanding loans.

title: U.N. 'MUGGING' FAILS
description: Usually Israel is cast as villain and victim in political melodramas played out in the Security Council, but this past week, in the Nicaraguan matter, the United States was the intended victim of what has become an all-too-familiar scenario that features one victim, many attackers, a great deal of verbal violence and a large number of indifferent and/or intimidated onlookers.

title: SOUNDLY DEMOCRATIC VENEZUELA IS COPING WITH TRYING TIMES
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSE VOTES TAX RISE ON GAS AND WIDENS LEVY ON SALES
description: After a two-week struggle to round up enough votes, the state's House of Representatives today narrowly approved the first installment of higher taxes to erase part of Connecticut's deficit.

title: New Corporate Board Is Created by I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday that it had created a new corporate management board modeled after a corporate board of directors.

title: ENERGY RESERVES GROUP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $24.2 million. c-Net income after a loss of $13.7 million from discontinued operations. Year-ago results have been restated for an accounting change.

title: CALENDAR: LEARNING ABOUT ARCHITECTURE
description: ''Architects and Designers Discuss In- teriors,'' Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street at Fifth Avenue, 860-6868.

title: Bridge:; Single-Dummy Problems Are Gaining in Popularity
description: The double-dummy problem, in which the solver must work his way through a maze of possibilities, has long been out of fashion. But there is a steady demand for a more practical exercise, the singledummy problem. In this, the solver, as declarer, is shown his own hand and the dummy and is asked to find the best line of play in a given contract.

title: Phelps Dodge Plans to Diversify
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the nation's second-largest copper producer, plans to reduce its dependence on copper and dispose of some assets, its two top executives said. In the annual report to stockholders, George P. Munroe, chairman, and Richard T. Moolick, president, said money from the sale of selected assets would be used to help finance diversification.

title: COMPANY ASSERTS IT FOUND PCB'S IN FUEL OIL FOR RE-USE
description: Waste Management Inc., the nation's largest company for disposing of hazardous wastes, said yesterday that it had discovered evidence of chemical contamination in waste oil received for reclamation as fuel at one of its major sites in Ohio.

title: HOW THE LP AND CD SOUNDS COMPARE
description: From the standpoint of a music-lover, what does the new digital compact disk and player system sound like? This reviewer chose to compare the conventional LP and compact disk versions of Leonard Bernstein's performance of Shostakovich's Symphony No. 5, digitally recorded in Tokyo with the New York Philharmonic - a sonic blockbuster if there ever was one - plus a couple of cuts from the LP and compact disk versions of Billy Joel's ''Nylon Curtain'' rock album. In addition, there was a Philips compact disk classical sampler that included a variety of genres, among them the roof-rattling Act I finale of Puccini's ''Tosca,'' in the Colin Davis version with Ingvar Wixell as Scarpia.

title: COUNTDOWN IS BEGUN FOR LIFTOFF OF SHUTTLE MONDAY AT 1:30 P.M.
description: With the ''call to stations,'' the National Aeronautics and Space Administration began the countdown today for the much-delayed maiden voyage of America's second shuttle. The craft, the Challenger, is to lift off Monday bearing four astronauts and the world's largest communications satellite.

title: Downing Opens
description: A pilot program that will open Downing Stadium on Randalls Island to runners and other athletes on weekdays has been agreed upon by the city's Parks Department and the Metropolitan Athletics Congress.

title: ZIMBABWE ASSAILS BISHOPS FOR STATEMENT
description: The Government of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe criticized the country's Roman Catholic bishops today for their assertion that the army was continuing to commit atrocities in Matabeleland.

title: Italy Rejects a Plan by Rome For an 'Archeological Park'
description: Italy's Culture Minister has vetoed a plan by Rome's Mayor to use state money to create an ''archeological park'' in the center of Rome.

title: Reagan's Mideast Plan Is Rejected by Arafat
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader, rejected President Reagan's Middle East peace proposals tonight.

title: 76ers 120, Hawks 113
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI) - With Julius Erving scoring 26 points and Maurice Cheeks 24, the Philadelphia 76ers clinched the Atlantic Division championship. Dan Roundfield got 36 for the Hawks, who led by 46-35 with 8:12 to play in the second period.

title: ANTITRUST VS. THE PEOPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Legally Dead Gives Birth to a Boy
description: A woman who was declared legally dead in January has given birth to a son after her body was kept attached to life-support equipment for nine weeks, doctors reported today.

title: 2 American Journalists Released in El Salvador
description: A United States Congressman intervened with the Salvadoran police today and won the release of two American journalists suspected of having ties with leftist guerrillas and of arms trafficking.

title: Mrs. Reid Is Back
description: Another mother will be returning to the women's tennis tour next week. Kerry Melville Reid, who was once ranked as high as fifth on the Women's Tennis Association computer, has received a wild-card berth in the Family Circle Cup tournament at Hilton Head, S.C.

title: Technology; Issue of Deceit In Electronics
description: IN the fast-changing electronics industry, getting to market quickly with the latest product can be crucial to success. Two recent lawsuits, however, raise questions about whether the scramble to market is leading to unethical practices.

title: ISLANDERS SOLIDIFY SECOND-PLACE SPOT
description: Rod Langway, the Washington defenseman, knew he had the time factor wrong. This was not the playoffs. ''The Islanders make exceptional passes,'' said Langway. ''They move the puck very well. And they're extremely well coached and disciplined. But we knew that when we got into this series.''

title: CORRECTION
description: The Talking Business column on Tuesday misquoted Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan on the direction of agriculture and commodity prices. He said these prices ''are coming back and this should help other nations.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Scoring 100%

title: Russians Sign Gas Contract
description: The Russian gas export agency Soyuzgazeksport has signed a contract with Ruhrgas A.G. under which the Soviet Union will deliver an annual 850.2 million cubic yards of natural gas to West Berlin, Ruhrgas said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: King Kong's Return

title: Coach's Target
description: Ron Fraser, the baseball coach at the University of Miami, objects to the Florida school's being projected as ''Suntan U.'' What also irritated Fraser was a recently publicized study by a geography professor at the university that showed that students there were woefully weak when it came to pinpointing major cities on an unmarked map.

title: Soviet Loss Seen From Oil Cuts; U.S. Analysts Expect Deficit
description: Declining world oil prices are eroding the value of the Soviet Union's oil and gas exports, the biggest source of the hard currency it needs to pay for imports of Western goods, according to Government and private analysts here. As a result, they say, the country's balance of payments accounts could be thrown as much as $5 billion into deficit this year.

title: Air Canada Reports Loss
description: Air Canada reported today that it lost $32.6 million (in Canadian currency) last year, compared with earnings of $40.1 million in 1981, and said it could have a deficit again this year.

title: The Disabled Need Defenders
description: In the movie ''Lovesick,'' the young playwright Chloe Allen must accompany Marvin Zuckerman, a schizophrenic street person, to a Social Security office to help him obtain his disability benefit. Negotiations falter on the matter of his address: Mr. Zuckerman insists he lives on Neptune - not the avenue, the planet.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL EXPANDING
description: The American General Corporation, the big Houston-based insurance holding company, said yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agreement to acquire the insurance operations of the Gulf United Corporation for about $1 billion in stock.

title: WICKES COMPANIES reports earnings for qtr to Jan 29.
description: b-Including income of $1,527,000 for the quarter and a loss of $105,236,000 for the year from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $52,487,000 for the quarter and $68,276,000 for the year. Results for the latest year reflect a writeoff of debts, discount and expense in the first quarter of $52,205,000.

title: The U.N. Today; March 31, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, Legal Subcommittee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Dow Jumps 12.10 In Heavier Trading
description: The stock market, fueled by favorable economic news, yesterday snapped a three-session decline and finished sharply higher in accelerated trading.

title: ALLIED SELLS 7.2% OF RCA IN RECORD STOCK TRADE
description: The Allied Corporation said yesterday that it had sold its 7.2 percent stake in the RCA Corporation to Salomon Brothers, the investment house, in a transaction that represented the highest total amount ever paid for a single block of shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: RABBI MORRIS M. ROSE
description: Rabbi Morris M. Rose, former leader of congregations in Brooklyn and Queens, and in Morgantown, W.Va., died of a stroke Saturday at University Hospital. He was 85 years old, and lived in Kew Gardens, Queens.

title: Closings Friday
description: United States stock and commodity exchanges will be closed tomorrow in observance of Good Friday. Most exchanges abroad will also be closed. American banks will be open.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Anders Hedberg made a mighty effort to get back from St. Louis in time, but the Rangers' forward didn't quite make it to New York Hospital Tuesday night for the birth of his third child. Never mind.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
FOR CHILDREN'S SAFETY
description: PARENTS of young children must be diligent about eliminating possible hazards in the home: cleaning products, medicines, electrical cords and outlets. Several new products can increase home safety.

title: Market Place; Investment Choices Now
description: WITH many stocks at historically high levels, investment analysts are being kept busy these days updating their lists of issues to buy and to avoid. Six market professionals yesterday offered their candidates, based on their prospects for the next six months.

title: Aid for Third World
description: Developing countries will need an infusion of about $90 billion by 1985 to stop a slide to stagnation and restore economic growth, a United Nations report said today. This is $20 billion more than the agency, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, had recommended earlier this year. The plan will be presented to a 154-nation conference in Yugoslavia in June.

title: Eagles Drop Harris
description: Leroy Harris, a Philadelphia Eagles running back, was cut from the squad yesterday, but not, Coach Marion Campbell suggested, because of Harris's well-publicized recent legal problems. In a statement that made no mention of Harris's off-field activities, Campbell, who took over the team in January, said the decision to release the fullback, who had been used only sparingly last year, had been based on ''past performance.''

title: SUPPORT FOR POLISH AUSTERITY PLAN IS SOUGHT AT RALLY
description: Poland's rulers called more than 2,000 workers and Communist Party activists to a rally today aimed at mustering support for the new three-year austerity plan.

title: Japan Acts On Recession
description: The Japanese Government said today that it would introduce a nine-point package on April 6 to try to move the non-Communist world's second-largest economy out of recession.

title: Europeans Set Venture in U.S.
description: Pargesa Holding S.A. of Switzerland and Groupe Bruxelles-Lambert of Belgium plan to form a new financial holding company in the United States with share capital of $300 million, a Pargesa spokesman said.

title: SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid Feb. 14.

title: CONCERT: ZIMMERMAN AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: THE ideal musical performance should give off an air of improvisation, even when the piece at hand is as tightly organized as a Bach fugue. The listener, who knows better, lets himself be deluded into thinking, in some dark recess of his mind, that the musician is making up the work as he goes along. Rationally, of course, he knows that the performer is doing no such thing, but the ability to make the audience experience familiar music as if for the first time is one unfailing mark of the superior recreative artist.

title: HADSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest periods include net gains of $11,056,170 for the quarter and $17,588,071 for the year from the sale of undeveloped leaseholds. Results for the latest year also reflect a loss of $16,560,000 for the establishment of a reserve for uncollectable accounts and a loss of $8.9 million for leasehold impairment allowance.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Houston Astros, exhibition, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Ron Guidry is scheduled for his final tune-up before the regular season. Though he gave up eight hits in his last outing, he has still not yielded a run this spring. The Astros, meanwhile, may take another look at the right-hander Mike Scott, a former Met. (Radio - WABC, 770; 1:15 P.M.) Mets vs. Montreal Expos, exhibition, at St. Petersburg, Fla. (Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Hockey Devils vs. Buffalo Sabres, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:35 P.M. For the Devils, who have averaged about 13,500 in attendance during their first season in the Meadowlands, this is the final home game. (Television - Sports@Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WVNJ, 620; 7:30 P.M.) Rangers vs. Flyers, at Philadelphia. This is a playoff preview. The Rangers and the Flyers meet again next Tuesday night as the chase for the Stanley Cup begins. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M., tape.)

title: PIPER-HYDRO INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
Noguchi Loses 2d Plea on Job
description: The county's Civil Service Commission today refused for a second time to reinstate Dr. Thomas Noguchi as coroner, despite a hearing officer's recommendation that his demotion be overruled.

title: Saudi Riyal Devalued
description: The Saudi Arabian riyal was devalued to 3.45 to the dollar, from 3.44, effective immediately, a Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency spokesman said today in Riyadh. The riyal parity last changed on June 30, 1982, when it was devalued from 3.43. Dealers said the move had been expected for months, because the riyal had been far outside its 7 1/4 percent fluctuation range against the special drawing right, the value of which is determined by averaging current values of a group of major currencies.

title: Dee Finch, Disk Jockey With WNEW 26 Years
description: Dee Finch, who for 16 years was the straight-man partner of Gene Klavan on WNEW Radio's ''Klavan and Finch'' early morning show, died of a heart attack Tuesday in Binghamton, N.Y., after attending his mother's funeral.

title: Venezuela In Debt Talks
description: Venezuela's top finance officials met with a consortium of 11 banks yesterday to discuss ways to refinance $10 billion in shortterm debt due this year.

title: TENNIS DEFECTOR DIVIDES U.S. AIDES
description: An application for political asylum by Hu Na, a 19-year-old Chinese tennis player, has provoked a ''unique'' disagreement between the State Department and the Immigration and Naturalization Service, a Reagan Administration official close to the case said today.

title: 2 DIE IN JET CRASH AT NEWARK AIRPORT
description: A twin-engine Learjet business plane swerved while landing and hurtled into a ditch at Newark International Airport early yesterday, killing both pilots, the only people on board.

title: THE SPORTS LEGENDIZER
description: Walter Neiman, president of WQXR, the radio station of The New York Times, died of cardiac arrest Tuesday at Harkness Pavillion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 57 years old and lived in Ardsley, N.Y., where he was a former Deputy Mayor and Village Trustee.

title: IN THE EYE OF TELEVISION'S BEHOLDER
description: To the Editor:

title: Leniency Charge Delays Judgeship
description: Governor Kean has asked the State Senate to withhold confirmation of a Superior Court judge to a new term pending an investigation of reports by Gloucester County police chiefs that the judge is too lenient on drunken drivers.

title: KANSAS CITY VICTOR VOWS UNITY DRIVE
description: Mayor Richard L. Berkley, who was re-elected to a second four-year term Tuesday, says his first priority is to pull together a city government that can meet the ''real challenges ahead.''

title: Harlem Theater Awarded Grant
description: The conversion of Loew's Victoria Theater in Harlem into a fourscreen movie complex will be aided by an $800,000 Federal Urban Development Action Grant, City Council President Carol Bellamy, head of the city's committee on the grants, said yesterday.

title: GLADSTONE ATWELL
description: Gladstone Atwell, principal of Lefferts Intermediate School 61, at Empire Boulevard and New York Avenue in the Crown Heights area of Brooklyn, died of a heart attack Monday at Brookdale Hospital.

title: Murder Conviction Affirmed 2d Time
description: New York State's highest court yesterday affirmed the conviction of Charles E. Friedgood, a former Nassau County physician who is serving a sentence of 25 years to life for the 1975 murder of his wife, Sophie.

title: CURBS ON TRAVEL PROTESTED IN PARIS
description: Several thousand French travel agents, singing and shouting, marched through central Paris today to protest the Government's restrictions on holiday spending abroad.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: NICARAGUANS READ ALL ABOUT HOW TO USE GRENADE
description: The Nicaraguan Government, anxious to use what it calls the ''invasion'' by exile forces to revive enthusiasm for its policies, is fighting the propaganda war as intensely as the ''contras.''

title: MERLAND EXPLORATIONS LTD reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After a writedown of $21,800,000 in the carrying value of its U.S. properties. Other negative factors that resulted in the widened losses for the year were an increase in the petroleum and gas revenue tax to 29 cents a share from 16 cents and higher interest costs.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OPERA

title: MAKE TAXES EQUITABLE
description: While looking over my 1982 United States income tax form, I was startled to notice that the top bracket for single taxpayers begins at an income of only $41,500. A look at an old form showed that in 1970 the top bracket began at $100,000. That's $248,000 in 1982 dollars -roughly six times the current level. The reasons for this regressive change: the Reagan tax cuts and inflation.

title: CZAR RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: Year-ago net loss was restated.

title: BUYING SECOND-HAND FILE CABINETS AND OTHER USED ITEMS
description: BECAUSE businesses move, remodel and redecorate regularly in Manhattan, there is an abundance of second-hand office furniture to be found for the home office. Indeed, a shopper with archeological leanings can dig through dusty stacks in closet-size stores to unearth fine old roller-bearing file cabinets and desks of every size and variety.

title: LIBERALIZED TAX LAWS BENEFIT THE HOME-BASED BUSINESS
description: BASED businesses are on the rise, as people seeking extra income embark on activities as diverse as sewing, consulting work and freelance graphic design. These cottage industries are attractive not just for the extra income, but because changes in the tax law have significantly liberalized deductions for home office expenses.

title: 700 BANKERS TRUST WORKERS TO BE SHIFTED TO JERSEY CITY
description: The Bankers Trust Company announced yesterday that it would transfer 700 employees from New York City to new office space in Jersey City that the bank intends to create from a rundown waterfront warehouse.

title: Rolls Airplane Unit Has Loss
description: Rolls-Royce Ltd., the state-owned airplane engine manufacturer, said it had a 1982 pretax loss of $132.4 million against a profit of $26.2 million the previous year. Sales rose to $2.17 billion from $2.09 billion.

title: News Analysis
description: Reagan Administration officials and European diplomats acknowledged today that President Reagan's compromise offer on medium-range missiles would almost certainly be rejected by Moscow, but they felt it was nonetheless essential in the battle for the political support of Western Europeans.

title: Contract Talks Continue In Massachusetts
description: Negotiations on a new contract for about 30,000 state workers intensified today as a top state official predicted ''a fair chance'' of settlement before the old contract expired midnight Thursday.

title: The 'Love Boat' Market
description: Talk about your perfect advertising environment. It would be hard to think up a better place to slip a commercial for Caribbean cruises than during a Saturday night appearance of the ''Love Boat'' series on ABC-TV.

title: Zero Plus
description: President Reagan's tactical shift on Euromissles, from zero-zero to perhaps 75-75 or 150-150, is not - yet - a formula for dissolving the Soviet-American deadlock. It is, however, a significant concession to European allies, who face storms of protest while holding to NATO's resolve to deploy new American missiles before year's end.

title: Brewery Owner
description: The owner of the Schmidt's brewery and four others have been indicted by a Federal grand jury for defrauding Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Maryland of excise diesel fuel taxes.

title: Numex Settles Charges by S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged the Numex Corporation, a machine-tool manufacturer, and three of its top executives with violating securities laws by maintaining a secret bank account into which they diverted about $2.2 million of the company's funds.

title: SPACE LASERS MIGHT STOP HALF OF MISSILE ATTACK, EXPERT SAYS
description: The head of directed-energy weapons programs in the Pentagon has testified that a ''constellation of space laser platforms'' might be able to stop only half of a large intercontinental missile attack against the United States.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Electronic Components Co., Morristown, N.J., a unit of the Allied Corporation, has appointed Phillip W. Arneson president of its Amphenol division.

title: The decline in world oil prices is eroding the Soviet Union's main source of hard currency, United States analysts say. Page D3.
description: The British National Oil Corporation today proposed price cuts for North Sea oil ranging from 50 cents to 75 cents a barrel, retroactive to March 1, clearing the way for the first test of the pricing structure adopted by OPEC early in March.

title: Colleagues Join Hall of Fame
description: A multitude of agency and media mighties, as well as scores who wished they were, took over the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria at lunch yesterday as the American Advertising Federation installed Paul Foley and Alfred J. Seaman as the 88th and 89th tenants in its Advertising Hall of Fame.

title: MONEY MARKET RATES IN NEW YORK HIGHEST
description: For all the complaints about poor service and long lines at many New York banks, the city's banks and savings institutions are generally paying the highest rates in the country on their money market accounts.

title: Generals Lead in Turnovers
description: Although Coach Chuck Fairbanks continues to maintain an air of optimism about the New Jersey Generals and their halfback, Herschel Walker, the statistics argue differently.

title: DRIVER-HARRIS CO reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
